headline: On AIDS: Three Lessons From Africa
abstract: How Rwanda, Ethiopia and Malawi became “positive deviants” in the global fight against H.I.V./AIDS.
lead_paragraph: An AIDS fable: Once upon a time, in the years after AIDS went from being a death sentence to a manageable disease, at least for people rich enough to take antiretroviral therapy, many of the people who ran the world believed that these medicines weren’t appropriate for residents of very poor countries. Even leaving aside the cost, they thought that poor people couldn’t take their medicines on time. Andrew Natsios, the head of the United States Agency for International Development in the George W. Bush administration, argued against funding antiretroviral therapy in Africa. “People do not know what watches and clocks are,” he told the Boston Globe in June, 2001.

Reese answered that he viewed Wilson, the team’s first-round draft pick in 2012, as a “bonus” because the team had made other plans for its backfield.

headline: Weak Links in China’s Food Chain

Instead, it relied on its longtime partner the OSI Group, which had been linked to the fast-food titan ever since Ray Kroc, the McDonald’s founder, in the 1950s tapped the Chicago butcher Otto & Sons to provide consistent, reliable meats to his expanding empire.

headline: India: Dozens of Villagers Still Missing After Landslide
abstract: Rescue workers pulled eight survivors from the mud a day after a huge landslide hit the village of Malin in the Pune district of Maharashtra State in western India.
lead_paragraph: Although heavy rains hindered their work, rescue workers on Thursday pulled eight survivors from the mud a day after a huge landslide hit the village of Malin in the Pune district of Maharashtra State in western India. The workers also recovered the bodies of 31 people. The landslide buried at least 40 homes and more than 150 people, officials said. “The chances of finding anybody else alive are remote, but we still do not rule out the possibility,” said Surjeet Singh Guleria, a senior officer of the National Disaster Rescue Force. “We have deployed 378 soldiers and officers on the ground. They are working around the clock, but their work is hampered by continuous rains.” India’s home minister, Rajnath Singh, and Maharashtra State’s chief minister, Prithviraj Chavan, both visited Malin on Thursday. “This is a very heart-wrenching scene here,” Mr. Singh said.

headline: What’s on TV Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (Showtime) DAVID BOWIE: FIVE YEARS (2013) Drawing on Mr. Bowie’s personal archive of costumes, set designs, lyrics and memorabilia, the director Francis Whately touches on five seminal years in this performer’s career, exploring the source of his inspiration and where his ideas led him. The film begins in 1971, with the creation of his persona Ziggy Stardust, and then moves to 1975, when he released the album “Young Americans” and adopted yet another persona, the Thin White Duke; 1977, and the albums “Low” and “Heroes”; 1980, and his No. 1 single in Britain, “Ashes to Ashes”; and 1983, the year he conquered nightclubs with “Let’s Dance.” (Above, Mr. Bowie in 1979.) Next month, the Museum of Contemporary Art Chicago presents “David Bowie Is,” a retrospective of his career.

headline: Morning Views
abstract: Opinions on C.I.A. hacking in the Senate, medical marijuana in California, the immigration crisis and Congress, child casualties in Gaza and more.
lead_paragraph: The Central Intelligence Agency needs “a thorough overhaul,” at “its very core” for breaking into the computers of the Senate Intelligence Committee, says an editorial in The New York Times. C.I.A. director John Brennan apologized privately to the committee’s leadership and promised to determine who was responsible for the hacking, but the accountability and the apologies should go “much further,” the editorial says. “It’s not just two senators that the C.I.A. has offended by this shocking action. It is all of Congress and, by extension, the American public, which is paying for an intelligence agency that does not seem to understand the most fundamental concept of separation of powers.” The committee was working on a classified report detailing the agency’s controversial antiterror program when the hacking occurred. “Congress is supposed to oversee the intelligence community and rein in its excesses. It cannot possibly do so effectively if it is being spied on by the spy agency, which is supposed to be directing its efforts against foreign terrorists and other threats to national security.”

headline: The Making Of | Christophe Lemaire’s Striking, Sculptural Leather Bags
abstract: The Paris-based designer and his studio director and partner Sarah-Linh Tran walk T through the unique process of creating their fall carryalls.
lead_paragraph: Even two-plus decades into his distinguished and varied fashion career, the Paris-based designer Christophe Lemaire is still very much a man of the moment. He recently stepped down from his post as the artistic director at Hermès to focus on his own namesake line, which embodies fashion’s tilt toward discretion while maintaining its own specifically French brand of chic. As it has grown in renown, Sarah-Linh Tran, Lemaire’s studio director, muse and partner, has also become more prominent, reliably appearing on tastemakers’ Pinterest and Tumblr feeds. The two met eight years ago, when Tran was still a student and Lemaire was just restarting his business. “Very naturally, very quickly, we discovered that we had a certain sensitivity and complicity about aesthetics and style and art and movies,” Lemaire says. “And very naturally, we ended up doing what everybody said we shouldn’t do: work together.”

headline: What to Expect When You Shouldn’t Expect Lunch: A Dad’s Guide to Delivery Day
abstract: Fathers are vital components of delivery day — except not vital enough that anyone cares if they get hungry or need something.
lead_paragraph: My wife went into labor in the middle of the night. Not knowing how much time we had, I grabbed our hospital bag and headed for the door. I had wisely preassembled the bag from countless online lists – nightgown, toiletries, even a flashlight. Fifteen hours of labor later, I was proud: That bag had everything my wife needed. But as hard as this father-to-be had tried to think of everything, I had failed to pack my own necessities. Two hours into one of the most important days of my life, I suffered an excruciating case of the munchies.

abstract: I had two sources of warmth during the cold middle-school years: a cocoon of books and a bowl of shelf-stable noodles.
lead_paragraph: When I was in fifth grade, I developed an intense dislike of eating around other people. The cafeteria was a place of foul odors, gelatinous spills, horrific mixtures of chocolate pudding, fruit cocktail and ketchup consumed on dares, and I found myself fasting from breakfast, at about 6 in the morning, until 3:35, when I walked home through the woods from the bus stop. Each step up our hill, a narrow ridge in rural California, I fantasized about the big bowl of ramen I would make myself when I reached the top.

headline: Can Parenthood and Pessimism Live Side by Side?
abstract: Meditations on exposing an innocent adorable creature to this brutal, perverse world.
lead_paragraph: When I was about 10 or 11, my father took me to a nursing home one summer evening. As a pharmacist in the small Irish city of Kilkenny, he sometimes visited customers and other elderly acquaintances who were hospitalized or bedridden, and I would insist on going with him, as in those days I insisted on accompanying him wherever he went, relishing even the prospect of a trip to the dump if it meant spending time alone with my father, whom I idolized. This nursing home, a low and dreary building, was a place I’d never been to before; known locally as “the poor house,” it was a state-run institution for elderly and senile patients whose families could not afford to pay for their care.

headline: Scratch-Off Art on Subway Platforms
abstract: Finding order in the chaos of layers of advertisements lining the station walls.
lead_paragraph: To subway riders feeling impatient, restless or a little destructive, the print advertisements lining the walls of a station can make irresistible targets. Kevin Shea Adams, a photographer, began taking iPhone shots of ads in various states of decay and modification about four years ago. When layered on top of one another, the ads produce collage like art, as strips are peeled away to reveal underlying images. “They’re participatory, they’re public, they’re sort of chaotic and random,” he says. Because Adams commutes between Bushwick and Greenpoint, most of the stations he has frequented are in Brooklyn, where they tend to be less well maintained. “The ads are very tactile,” he says. “When you’re standing waiting for a train, bored out of your mind, you just want to pull them.” Julie Bosman

headline: 1914: Vociferous Crowds Cheer Kaiser
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: The Kaiser addressed the nation on the day Germany declared war on Russia in 1914.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Fifty thousand persons assembled yesterday [Aug. 1] afternoon before the Imperial Palace and cheered the Kaiser and the Empire vociferously and continuously. At 6.15 p.m. the Kaiser appeared at one of the windows of the palace, and the enthusiasm of the crowd then became almost frantic. Addressing the great throng in a loud clear voice, the Kaiser said: ‘‘This is a dark day and a sombre hour for Germany. Envious people on every side have forced us to a just defence. The sword is placed in our hands by force. I hope that, if at the last moment my efforts to bring about an understanding between ourselves and our adversaries and to maintain the peace do not succeed, we may, by the help of God, so use our swords that when all is ended we can replace them in their scabbards with honor. A war will ask from us enormous sacrifices of men and of money, but we shall show our enemies what it means to provoke Germany. And now I recommend you all to God. Go to church, kneel before Him and pray that He may sustain our brave army.’’ — The New York Herald, European Edition, August 2, 1914

headline: Inside the List
abstract: With the debut of Daniel Halper’s “Clinton, Inc.” at No. 10, there are now three volumes related to Bill and Hillary Clinton on the hardcover nonfiction list.
lead_paragraph: Power Couple: The title of Daniel Halper’s “Clinton, Inc.” refers to the marriage of Bill and Hillary Clinton — Halper, the online editor at The Weekly Standard, argues that the couple function as co-chief executives of a mighty enterprise whose main business is politics. But you could be forgiven for thinking his title also describes the publishing industry. With the book’s debut this week at No. 10, there are now three Clinton-related volumes on the hardcover nonfiction list; Halper joins Edward Klein, whose “Blood Feud” is No. 3 after five weeks, and Hillary Clinton herself, whose “Hard Choices” is No. 5 after seven weeks. This state of affairs is nothing new. By my count, the Clintons have featured in more than 60 best sellers since entering the national stage in 1992. And they retain a close interest in what’s written about them, according to Halper. “While I was still reporting on my book,” he told Politico last month, “James Carville’s office called, seemingly out of the blue, to grill me on whom I’d already spoken to. I obviously refused to indulge the questioner.” Halper also said that Clinton’s publisher had reached out to his publisher for information about the book, and that “Clintonites” were scrambling to identify his unnamed sources. “I’ve found the task of covering the Clintons fascinating,” he said. “They’re not exactly the people we see on television.” They may, however, be the people we see in literature — Halper sets his tone by opening “Clinton, Inc.” with a damning line from “The Great Gatsby”: “They were careless people, Tom and Daisy — they smashed up things and creatures and then retreated back into . . . whatever it was that kept them together, and let other people clean up the mess they had made.”

headline: A Thawing in Iceland
abstract: In 1986, the U.S.-Soviet meeting in Reykjavik seemed anything but a Cold War breakthrough.
lead_paragraph: Failure is in fashion these days. We read about failing fast and failing well, about grit incubated by repeated failure in school and innovation by repeated failure in business. So it may be a good time to consider the hidden virtues of failure in foreign policy. And who better to demonstrate those virtues than one of modern America’s great optimists?

headline: The Music of Time
abstract: In many of Jane Gardam’s stories, a figure from the past suddenly looms.
lead_paragraph: A novel can afford to unveil its secrets slowly. Not so a short story. With its constricted circuitry, it has to be a stairway of surprise (in Emerson’s phrase) or the reader will stop climbing at the second or third step. The most incisive stories by Jane Gardam, a writer well known in Britain for children’s books and a host of novels (including the “Old Filth” trilogy that has recently won her new readers in America), are constructed, more often than not, around a double take. From colonial postings abroad, from buried love affairs, from the lists of the presumed dead (or “near-dead,” as they are called in one of Gardam’s ghost-ridden stories), a once-familiar figure suddenly looms. The unsettling appearance of such revenants — as in Proust or Anthony Powell’s “A Dance to the Music of Time” — brings about, in these deftly written tales, a shift, a re-evaluation, a fresh sense of what really happened in the past and an opening into a possibly altered future.

headline: Mind Ablaze
abstract: The poet and novelist Stephen Crane “raced through his life,” documenting war and poverty until his death at 28.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Crane, whose likeness appears on the album cover of “Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band,” was America’s first rock-star writer. He self-published his realist novella “Maggie: A Girl of the Streets” at 21, losing so much money that he took to starving himself and wearing rubber boots because he couldn’t afford shoes. By the time he was 23, he had imagined “a creature, naked, bestial, / Who, squatting upon the ground, / Held his heart in his hands, / And ate of it. / I said, ‘Is it good, friend?’ / ‘It is bitter — bitter,’ he answered; / ‘But I like it / Because it is bitter, / And because it is my heart.’ ”

headline: Enchanted Connections
abstract: An exiled magician tries a risky heist in Lev Grossman’s novel, the final installment of a trilogy.
lead_paragraph: If Lev Grossman’s “The Magicians” was like “The Secret History” crossed with “Harry Potter,” and if its sequel, “The Magician King,” was a descendant of “The Chronicles of Narnia” (with a touch of the 1990s flick “The Craft” thrown in), then what cultural mash-up does Lev Grossman conjure in “The Magician’s Land,” the trilogy’s final book? I can’t tell you, because I was too thoroughly swept away by this richly imagined and continually surprising novel to be concerned with cute comparisons.

headline: Nowhere to Run
abstract: The perplexed heroine of Tom Rachman’s novel explores New York City and travels the world.
lead_paragraph: Once you flip past the title page of a novel or story collection, you are entering into a relationship with someone, the fiction writer, who will try to deceive you for his or her own selfish reasons — literary glory, financial gain, sexual display, take your pick. At some point you decide whether or not you will let yourself look past the motive that helped bring the book into being, a decision that depends on your sense of how fairly the writer has treated you.

headline: Best Exotic Kingdom
abstract: An Englishwoman made a career of her marriage to the “white rajah” of a jungle protectorate in northern Borneo.
lead_paragraph: “I have done almost everything in life except two things. I haven’t had a son, and I have never come down in a parachute.”

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – Sundance is sprouting an Asian offshoot.

abstract: A slideshow of arts events around the world worth knowing about this week.

headline: The Townhouse, Minus the Past
abstract: In Cobble Hill, Dumbo and Williamsburg, Brooklyn, at least a dozen new townhouse projects are in various stages of planning or construction.
lead_paragraph: In response to surging demand for larger spaces, developers in Brooklyn are going back to the classic townhouse, but building new variations with contemporary families in mind.

headline: Rules of Style | Danny Bowien on How to Look Sharp and Why He Chopped His Locks
abstract: The chef behind Mission Chinese and MIssion Cantina discusses biking style, where to buy the best T-shirts and the virtues of kitchen clogs.
lead_paragraph: The chef and restaurateur Danny Bowien claims he’s not into fashion, but he’s clearly got his own idiosyncratic ideas about style. A typical look involves an oversize, vintage Bulls athletic tank jersey turned inside out, blazing red nylon shorts from Creatures of Comfort and dark leather Bragard slip-on kitchen shoes paired with black knit socks. His trademarks are a pair of worn-in, sciencey specs and his two-tone hair, which he recently trimmed himself. The cut was inspired both by his six-month-old son Mino (“I didn’t want to be that dad with weird hair”) and his insanely busy schedule, which leaves little time for grooming. With two restaurants to run — Mission Cantina in New York and Mission Chinese Food in San Francisco — along with various pop-ups, including his newest at Mile End Deli on Bond Street, Bowien has been living out of his Y-3 backpack and traveling on his 3Rensho bike whenever possible. Earlier this week, he took a break in between lunch and dinner services to talk about his love of band T-shirts, why he had to quit using cologne and his former stint as a Uniqlo model (watch out, it could happen again).

headline: Deep End
abstract: In Yannick Murphy’s thriller “This Is the Water,” the mother of two girls on a competitive swim team is having an affair with her friend’s husband.
lead_paragraph: Rules, rules, so many stupid rules: “Don’t switch point of view.” “Don’t give away the identity of the killer.” “Don’t write in the second person.” Yannick Murphy, an author who seems drawn to high cliffs, ignores all the warnings in THIS IS THE WATER (Harper Perennial, paper, $14.99), an inventive thriller set in suburbia — and in the troubled minds of her characters. The second-person narrative voice that feels alienating at the outset (“This is the water. . . . This is the swim mom. . . . This is the bathroom”) soon becomes hypnotic (“This is you, Annie”) and then seriously unsettling (“This is the killer”). Annie, the mother of two girls on a competitive swim team, is the most appealing of all the moms in their pretty New England town who shell out $1,000 per child to get their kids on the team and hundreds more for those sadistically engineered racing suits that are supposed to shave milliseconds off their records. But while Annie dutifully volunteers to time the girls’ practice swims and drive to out-of-town meets, she can never satisfy a fanatic like Dinah, who monitors everyone’s moves and complains that “Annie and her daughters always seem to be doing what they’re not supposed to do.”

headline: What the Hearts Want
abstract: Fifty-nine short stories about love and other passionate longings, tinged with surreal potential, by Stuart Dybek, a master of the form.
lead_paragraph: Our American present seems best served by a literature of swerves. Whiplash plot changes. Arrivals that surprise, departures that are kicks in the teeth. Characters who veer violently off course: Think of poor Ned Stark from “A Game of Thrones,” or erratic Amy Dunne from “Gone Girl.” This is popular fiction’s response to the cloud of dark news that won’t quit raining on us. If life really has taken on a schizoid vibe, then maybe a narrative schizophrenia has come to look like real life.

headline: All Over the Map
abstract: Elizabeth Pisani trekked 26,000 miles around the Indonesian archipelago, searching for what binds this disparate nation.
lead_paragraph: This year, three of the world’s largest democracies are holding national elections — vast polls spread over several days and thousands of miles of territory, involving more than a billion voters. Two of these elections have attracted intense media coverage, or will. India’s national elections, which took place in May, swept out of office the long-ruling Congress Party and handed government of a rising economic and political power to the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party. Brazil’s elections, which will be held in October, are coming on the heels of the World Cup, one of several high-profile events that have marked the country’s emergence as the second giant of the Americas.

headline: Head Count
abstract: Thomas Robert Malthus’s ideas about population and scarcity have been invoked, extrapolated and polemicized for centuries.
lead_paragraph: Getting people to attach an “ian” (or an “ist”) to the end of your name is pretty impressive. Getting them to keep doing so 180 years after your death, not as a musty reference but as part of vital contemporary debates, well, that’s a phenomenon worth studying.

headline: War Comes to America
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Nigel Hamilton argues that Roosevelt’s genius for military leadership has been underrated and overshadowed.
lead_paragraph: Our understanding of the past is shaped in no small part by the letters and memoirs of the people who made history, or claimed to. Rival statesmen have long understood this. In their nearly 40 years of intimate but tendentious correspondence, Thomas Jefferson and John Adams were jockeying for posterity; in dueling memoirs a century and a half later, so were Richard Nixon and Henry Kissinger. Indeed, one reason Nixon installed the secret White House taping system was to make sure he could rebut Kissinger’s version of events.

headline: How Conservation and Groundwater Management Can Gird California for a Drier Era
abstract: Experts see a mix of conservation and groundwater management as the cheapest way for Californians to grapple with deepening drought.
lead_paragraph: It’s way past time for California to come to grips with the possibility that its extraordinary water woes are the new normal — and essentially the return of the old normal given the state’s climate history, in which drought has been the rule and the verdant 20th century the exception. In the weekly update to the U.S. Drought Monitor site yesterday, nearly 80 percent of the state was in extreme or exceptional drought conditions.

headline: Now, It’s Almost Family-Hour Fare
abstract: The Film Society of Lincoln Center presents a series of sleek, soft-core movies by Radley Metzger that pushed the boundaries of sexual explicitness.
lead_paragraph: As television and film have pushed the boundaries of sexual explicitness, an examination of the sleek, soft-core movies that were once viewed as upscale exploitation fare for prurient audiences resistant to hard-core pornography is long overdue. On Thursday, the Film Society of Lincoln Center begins its series “This Is Softcore: The Art Cinema Erotica of Radley Metzger” at the Elinor Bunin Munroe Film Center with “Carmen, Baby” (1967), this director’s take on Prosper Mérimée’s 19th-century novella that inspired the Bizet opera “Carmen.” Uta Levka plays the Gypsy temptress who, much to the distress of the policeman who loves her, sleeps her way to the top of the social ladder in 1960s Spain.

headline: An Auteur, in His Own Words
abstract: Robert Altman, who died in 2006, recounts his long career as a director via archival interviews in an Epix documentary.

That career receives a slick and enjoyable recapping on Wednesday at 8 p.m. when Epix offers “Altman,” a documentary in which Altman, who died in 2006, tells much of his own story via archival interviews.

headline: Hold On to Your Phone!
abstract: Bounden, a Dutch dancing game for two players, has the elegance of choreography when when its twists and turns are done right.
lead_paragraph: From the outside, Bounden may look like two people arduously inspecting the same iPhone: twisting and turning while grasping opposite ends of the device, eyes fixed on the screen. And essentially that’s what it is, though, if done right, those twists and turns have the elegance of choreography. Created by the Dutch design studio Game Oven, this recently released app steers users through entwining duets choreographed by Ernst Meisner of the Dutch National Ballet. To replicate the swinging, circular moves, you and your partner maneuver an icon along arcing, ever-shifting pathways, inevitably getting tangled. If we can’t put down our phones, Bounden exploits that isolating tendency to bring us closer — physically, at least. It’s fun, especially at early levels, where good dancing isn’t the point. As the game advances, it becomes trickier, monitoring your accuracy and flashing “Hurry up!” if you fall behind the music, like a good-natured ballet master. Videos, featuring dancers from Dutch National Ballet’s junior company, offer something to aspire to. (gameovenstudios.com.)

headline: Sci-Fi Beats With a Pacific Flavor
abstract: Ishmael Butler and Tendai Maraire — who compose the creative center of Shabazz Palaces — are shaking up Seattle’s diverse, idiosyncratic and growing hip-hop scene.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — It was a bright summer day here, but inside Shabazz Palaces’ studio, located in the Old Rainier Brewery building, it was dark as midnight. There were no windows, the walls were painted black, and the womblike interior was broken up only by a leopard-print rug. “Hip-hop should only take place at night,” said Palaceer Lazaro (real name: Ishmael Butler), 45, the mastermind of Shabazz Palaces, the eccentric experimental hip-hop act. “The parties, this, everything.”

abstract: Treatment of depression alone may not prevent many suicides among the elderly, a new study suggests.

More often, they blame their struggles with illness, disability, financial concerns, family difficulties and bereavement for their suicidal thoughts.

headline: The Squeeze on the Middlebrow
abstract: The implications of entrenched inequality described by the economist Thomas Piketty extend beyond the realm of political economy.
lead_paragraph: “Capital in the 21st Century,” by the French economist Thomas Piketty, has become this year’s most unlikely best seller, a crossover from the world of scholarship into general public discussion of a kind that seems rarer than it used to be. The book’s thesis — that economic inequality in the developed world is increasing, with potentially dire consequences for social justice and democratic governance — has struck a nerve in the American body politic. But its implications extend beyond the realm of political economy. Though it is expectedly dry, careful and data-driven, the book invites the re-examination of deeply held assumptions about the world.

headline: 1939: Hitler Proclaims War Holiday
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War I (1914-18)', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: In 1939, Nazi Germany marked the outbreak of World War I with historical comparisons.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The twenty-fifth anniversary of the outbreak of the last war will be celebrated tomorrow [Aug. 2] by the entire German nation. Twenty-five years after Russian troops invaded East Prussia and German troops crossed the Belgian frontier, this anniversary has now completed the full cycle of change from a symbol of defeat to a harbinger of eventual German triumph. By Chancellor Hitler’s personal command, tomorrow will be a holiday for the entire German Army — the largest and strongest in German history. Every garrison in the Third Reich will hold special exercises to mark the beginning of four years of war which ended in defeat for Germany. This paradox is elaborated — if not explained — in columns of historical comment which fill the German press today. The grim situation in Europe this summer is explained in this official history as a parallel to that of 1914 only in its external form. The difference between 1914 and 1939 is summed up in most German newspapers by the black headlines ‘‘August, 1914, Kaiser Wilhelm — August, 1939, Adolf Hitler.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 2, 1939

headline: Fantasy Football: Running Back Primer
abstract: It’s how you navigate a tricky running back field that will most likely determine the true strength of your fantasy team in 2014.
lead_paragraph: Along with a pass-happy mentality, a “running back by committee” approach has become the norm for N.F.L. offenses in recent years. This has made the most coveted of all positions that much harder to plan for on draft day. Last season, we had to endure nine running back busts among the first 20 taken, based on their Average Draft Position. That is a 20 percent increase from a rate of just 25 percent in 2012. As a result, more owners are de-emphasizing the running back position in favor of top-tier receivers and quarterbacks in the early rounds.

headline: James Franco on Fame, Directing and How He’d Spend a Night in Jail
abstract: Fresh on the heels of his Broadway run in “Of Mice and Men,” the remarkably productive actor has directed a new film, “Child of God,” out today.
lead_paragraph: In a corner booth at the Tribeca Grand Hotel, James Franco scans the menu and announces he’s getting the chopped salad. Professionally, however, he’s become notorious for ordering everything, ricocheting among projects like a pinball. His latest is “Child of God,” a bruising, low-budget adaptation of a 1973 Cormac McCarthy novel set in the Tennessee backwoods. Franco co-wrote, directed and appears briefly in the film, which follows Lester Ballard (Scott Haze), an unhinged loner who descends into madness, menacing the townsfolk with a shotgun, which he becomes increasingly eager to use. Franco, who recently wrapped a successful Broadway run as the star of “Of Mice and Men,” spoke with T about his unique fan base, his notorious productivity and his uneasy relationship with fame.

lead_paragraph: Dale Jamieson, who runs the Animal Studies Initiative at New York University, has a very silly laugh, and it can be welcome sonic accompaniment when he talks about the destruction of the planet. His most recent book, “Reason in a Dark Time: Why the Struggle to Stop Climate Change Failed — and What It Means For Our Future,” is a stormy read for hurricane season. Mr. Jamieson, 66, is also a professor of environmental studies, philosophy and law. You could say that bummer is his business. “The whole presupposition is that we failed to solve this problem,” he said. ”Now how are we going to suck it up and go on despite the failure?” Cue the silly laugh. Mr. Jamieson lives in I. M. Pei-designed faculty housing with Chun-Mei Li when she is in the United States; based in Shanghai, she runs women’s and children’s health programs in Asia and Africa for Johnson & Johnson.

headline: In a Swirl of Limbs, a Bird Takes Flight

lead_paragraph: Alvin Ailey’s 1972 work “The Lark Ascending,” set to romantic music by Ralph Vaughan Williams, begins not with the image of a light, fluttering bird, but with a male dancer poised on his knees with outstretched arms. His face wears a look of reverie; could he be dreaming of his lark? Other dancers cross his path: Four men move in lunging unison walks, while a couple breeze past in jumps and lifts that impart jubilance. Finally, the lark appears. Springing through the air in grand jetés, she soars.

headline: A Happy Little Oceanside Shack
abstract: At the Rockaway Beach Surf Club, on Beach 87th Street in Queens, the usual oceanside austerity has been elevated into a sort of laid-back chic.
lead_paragraph: Beach cuisine, generally speaking, is not known for its imagination or distinction: There are sturdy standbys (pizza, fish tacos) and serviceable snacks (nachos, chips and guacamole). But at the Rockaway Beach Surf Club, a happy little shack on Beach 87th Street in Queens, the usual oceanside austerity has been elevated into a sort of laid-back chic. The restaurant’s owners, Brady Walsh, a tattooed city firefighter, and Brandon D’Leo, a sculptor with elaborate hair, have adorned their joint with colorful surfing murals and, perhaps for balance’s sake, an art installation that is part of this summer’s Rockaway! show sponsored by MoMA PS1 and others. The chef, Patrick Quinn, meanwhile has equipped his menu with kale and quinoa and sriracha-dipped chicken wings. On a recent Sunday afternoon, the Surf Club’s outdoor patio was filled with suntanned brunchgoers eating meals from paper-lined baskets before walking the few short blocks to the beach.

headline: A Man and His Cat
abstract: I wasn’t going to be one of those pitiful pet people. Not me.
lead_paragraph: I LIVED with the same cat for 19 years — by far the longest relationship of my adult life. Under common law, this cat was my wife. I fell asleep at night with the warm, pleasant weight of the cat on my chest. The first thing I saw on most mornings was the foreshortened paw of the cat retreating slowly from my face and her baleful crescent glare informing me that it was Cat Food Time. As I often told her, in a mellow, resonant, Barry White voice: “There is no luuve … like the luuve that exists … between a man … and his cat.”

headline: Head for Home

lead_paragraph: It is one of the fundamental rules of baseball. To score, a runner must step on home. When a hitter leaves the batter’s box after making contact, he knows exactly where he is going. He runs with certainty, guided by the white lines and the white bases, circling in the hope that he will arrive safely at the same place from where he departed. Runners operate on instinct: They must get home. And the efficiency with which they round those bases, often with the help of others, is a matter of winning or losing.

Grab by the stem, put it in your mouth and bite. lead_paragraph: WHEN a doctor asks her patient a question, is the doctor engaged in free speech protected by the Constitution? If you think the answer is obvious, think again. According to a recent decision by the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit, everything a doctor says to a patient is “treatment,” not speech, and the government has broad authority to prohibit doctors from asking questions on particular topics without any First Amendment scrutiny at all.

lead_paragraph: The weekly TV recap — the snarky, obsessive, scene-by-scene description of a TV show, written by a fan working through what’s clearly a love/hate relationship — is now a ubiquitous genre, peddled online by Slate, The Onion, New York magazine, and others. But its progenitor was Daniel Drennan’s “Beverly Hills 90210” recap, which he wrote online from 1994 to 1998. Columbia Journalism Review credited Mr. Drennan with inventing the form, citing his successful mix of “opinions on bad writing and terrible acting”; pointed attacks on “receding hairlines and terrible outfits”; and “personal stories tangentially related to what was on the TV screen.”

The two were taken for questioning on July 22 by security police who confiscated their laptops and other property, with Iranian justice officials later commenting darkly about being “vigilant towards all kinds of enemies’ activities.” The couple has not been heard from since.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 7:35 A.M. (Encore) THROW MOMMA FROM THE TRAIN (1987) Danny DeVito directs and stars as Owen, a downtrodden writer who dreams of killing his dominating and trollish mother (Anne Ramsey, above, with Mr. DeVito), but can’t bring himself to finish the deed. Larry (Billy Crystal) is Owen’s writing instructor and is similarly plagued by a famous ex-wife who is airing their dirty laundry to the entire country. When Larry suggests that Owen watch Alfred Hitchcock’s “Strangers on a Train” to help his writing, it instead gives Owen a different kind of inspiration: a murder swap. “Most inspired, however, is the teamwork between Mr. Crystal and Mr. DeVito, who make one of the oddest pairs imaginable but have a rapport that’s a delight,” Janet Maslin wrote in her review for The New York Times. Speaking of Mr. DeVito’s performance, she said, “He’s irresistible even when playing someone only a mother could love.”

lead_paragraph: Genevieve Bell grew up among Aboriginal people in Australia, taught anthropology at Stanford and for the past 16 years has worked for Intel. It all shows in her lively mind: Ask her the time and, along with the hour, you might hear about how native Australian languages fuse the words for past, present and land, along with the history of the mechanical clock and how that determined people’s feelings about robots.

headline: Anti-Intellectualism That Dares Not Speak Its Name

At the same time, there’s the claim that liberal “experts” are poseurs, not real experts. Hey, we’re not anti-science, not us!

headline: High in the Rockies, a Chill Marijuana Debate ​
abstract: In Colorado, one town might embrace cannabis stores while another posts a keep-out sign. But on one thing they agree: leave your stoner humor at home.
lead_paragraph: GUNNISON, Colo. — Getting a feel for Gunnison, Colo., a town in the Rockies about four and a half hours southwest of Denver, takes a bicycle and a few minutes. On Main Street and nearby blocks you will pass a Wal-Mart, a pizza place called Pie-Zans, a bike-repair-and-espresso shop, the offices of The Gunnison Country Times, the campus of Western State Colorado University and Traders Rendezvous, which claims to have the state’s largest collection of antlers and mounted animal trophies. Ride long enough and you will find seven churches and five liquor stores, six if you count the Safeway.

headline: The Great Colorado Weed Experiment
abstract: The state is showing that legalization can work, though there are still kinks to be figured out.
lead_paragraph: In January, Colorado defied the federal government and stepped with both feet into the world of legal recreational marijuana, where no state had gone before.

headline: ‘The Marijuana Divide’
abstract: In Colorado, two towns near each other have had divergent reactions to their state’s legalization of marijuana.
lead_paragraph: I traveled to Gunnison County, Colo., to make this video about two towns that had taken different paths since medicinal marijuana was legalized in 2000 and recreational marijuana sales began this year. One, Crested Butte, has embraced the sale of retail and medicinal marijuana; the other, Gunnison, has so far rejected it. (While anyone in the state over 21 is free to use the drug on private property, it’s up to local governments to decide whether it can be sold.)

Where else in the United States, under one roof, can you select from more than a dozen varieties of perfectly sliced prosciutto, a loving selection of Italian wines and olive oils that are hard to find in the United States, as well as the perfect Romanesco broccoli, an odd cone-shaped vegetable that is actually related to cauliflower?

lead_paragraph: TWO weeks ago, in a vacant lot on the west side of Albuquerque, a few teenagers beat two homeless men to death. I read about the attack in a hotel room in Nebraska, en route to a new job, hours after leaving New Mexico for good. I wish I could say the news surprised me. But after three years of living in Albuquerque, I’d gotten used to hearing stories about arbitrary violence, especially against the homeless.

headline: Why Americans See Israel the Way They Do
abstract: The Israeli saga echoes in American mythology. But views are different in Europe, where anti-Semitism is rising.
lead_paragraph: TO cross the Atlantic to America, as I did recently from London, is to move from one moral universe to its opposite in relation to Israel’s war with Hamas in Gaza. Fury over Palestinian civilian casualties has risen to a fever pitch in Europe, moving beyond anti-Zionism into anti-Semitism (often a flimsy distinction). Attacks on Jews and synagogues are the work of a rabid fringe, but anger toward an Israel portrayed as indiscriminate in its brutality is widespread. For a growing number of Europeans, not having a negative opinion of Israel is tantamount to not having a conscience. The deaths of hundreds of children in any war, as one editorial in The Guardian put it, is “a special kind of obscenity.”

headline: Postcard From Saratoga Springs: Eternal Rest at a Shrine He Enlivened

These “millennials” are, without a doubt, the most narcissistic and hopeless cohort I have witnessed in my 35 long years on this stationary planet.

headline: How This War Ends
abstract: Any resolution won’t be cheap politically for either Hamas or Israel.
lead_paragraph: RAMALLAH, West Bank — I HAD held off coming to Israel, hoping the situation in Gaza would clarify — not in terms of what’s happening, but how it might end in a stable way. Being here now, it is clear to me that there is a way this cruel little war could not only be stopped, but stopped in a way that the moderates in the region, who have been so much on the run, could gain the initiative. But — and here is where some flight from reality is required to be hopeful — developing something that decent out of this war will demand a level of leadership from the key parties that has simply never been manifested by any of them. This is a generation of Arab, Palestinian and Israeli leaders who are experts at building tunnels and walls. None of them ever took the course on bridges and gates.

headline: The Mayor’s Showroom
abstract: The de Blasios chose the wrong way to make Gracie Mansion look like a real home.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg redid Gracie Mansion in 2002, it was featured in Architectural Digest. Mayor Bill de Blasio’s redecoration was featured this week on Instagram (2,718 likes by Friday). The medium by which the reveal was made says as much about the changing of the guard as the difference in taste shown by the photographs in question. Federal end tables are out, coffee tables you can rest your feet on are in. For New York City’s first family, the move to Manhattan from Park Slope clearly felt more like an upheaval than a dream realized. The story line was less about being true to the house’s roots than being true to their own.

abstract: As Israel began to redeploy significant numbers of troops away from populated areas of Gaza on Sunday, an Israeli Air Force missile struck near the school entrance.

headline: 1914: Germany Officially Declares War on France
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Germany declared war on France in 1914.
lead_paragraph: Germany officially declared war upon France at 5.45 yesterday evening. The notification was made by Baron von Schoen, the German Ambassador to France, when he called at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Paris yesterday to ask for his passports. Baron von Schoen declared that his Government had instructed him to inform the Government of the Republic that French aviators had flown over Belgium and that other French aviators had flown over Germany and dropped bombs as far as Nuremberg. He added that this constituted an act of aggression and violation of German territory.

headline: Cloud Revenue Jumps, Led by Microsoft and IBM
abstract: Titans from earlier heydays of computing have both seen recent increases that outstripped the cloud-computing industry generally, according to industry reports.
lead_paragraph: The virtue of fear as a source of animating energy has long been recognized in the quicksilver tech industry. “Only the paranoid survive,” as Andrew S. Grove, Intel’s longtime leader, put it — a guiding principle that was also the title of his 1996 book on management.

lead_paragraph: My 11-year-old son, Nate, perches on a stool in the kitchen, frowning at the sheet of paper in his hands. “O.K., I think I’ve got it,” he announces.

headline: Why Our Expectations of Childbirth Are Changing
abstract: Our ideas about what constitutes healthy, natural childbirth have changed. Yet 33 percent of women still deliver babies through C-sections. How are our expectations of childbirth changing?
lead_paragraph: When the filmmaker Irene Lusztig got pregnant, she prepared for the arrival of her child by collecting instructions about motherhood. She ordered home videos and used baby scrapbooks from eBay and unearthed medical and instructional videos.

headline: 1939: Woman M.P. Is 1st to Wed in Commons Crypt
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: The first wedding of a woman Member of Parliament at Westminster Crypt, in 1939.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Miss Thelma Cazalet, Conservative Member of Parliament for East Islington, London, was married today [Aug. 3] to David Keir, political correspondent of the London ‘‘News Chronicle,’’ in the ancient crypt of the House of Commons, which had been decorated with lilies. It was the first time that a woman Member of Parliament had been married in the crypt, which members may use for their weddings on payment of £25 for a special license from the Archbishop of Canterbury.

headline: China Says Nearly 100 Are Killed in Week of Unrest in Xinjiang
abstract: The Chinese authorities have characterized the unrest as terrorism, but Uighur advocacy groups have blamed a sweeping security crackdown.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — It was a bloody week in China’s far west, with nearly 100 people killed in unrest that the authorities have characterized as terrorism but that Uighur advocacy groups have said is a consequence of a sweeping crackdown aimed at silencing opposition to the government’s hard-line policies in the region.

lead_paragraph: Do the clothes make the dancer? The worlds of ballet and high fashion have intersected ever since Coco Chanel designed costumes for Diaghilev’s Ballets Russes, and this year the combination of the two fields will once again be the theme of New York City Ballet’s fall gala. City Ballet is to present three world premieres at the Sept. 23 gala, with the choreographers sharing the top billing with the couturiers.

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 6:30 P.M. (13) MOYERS & COMPANY Bill Moyers interviews the Tony-winning actor John Lithgow about playing King Lear in the Public Theater’s Shakespeare in the Park production, and how the role speaks to our times. “To me, the most pointed line in the whole play is: ‘I’ve ta’en too little care of this,’ ” says Mr. Lithgow (above, with Jessica Collins as Cordelia). “You know, we live fairly comfortable lives. And every day you’re reminded of — of the — the astonishing misery in the rest of the world.” He adds, “I don’t think there is a play which is so nakedly painful.” Mr. Lithgow, who has been blogging about the experience for The New York Times, is in rehearsals with Glenn Close for the Broadway revival of Edward Albee’s “A Delicate Balance.” His new film, “Love Is Strange,” in which he and Alfred Molina play a couple of 39 years who are forced to live apart after marrying, opens on Aug. 22.

headline: On the Bowery, Questions About the Catholic Church’s Shifting Mission
abstract: In a neighborhood once synonymous with being down and out, a building owned by the Archdiocese of New York has traded offering showers to the homeless for serving as a cultural center.
lead_paragraph: Men lined up outside St. Joseph House on the Lower East Side on a recent morning, some with their belongings stuffed in worn bags, all with their stomachs empty. Inside the dining hall, which is run by Catholic Worker, a hearty meal of stew and bread awaited. Most of the men were homeless, though not necessarily hopeless — this daily ritual gave sustenance and respite in a neighborhood that has steadily pushed them aside as tenements and poor people give way to luxury buildings.

headline: New Study Sees Atlantic Warming Behind a Host of Recent Climate Shifts
keywords: ['El Nino Southern Oscillation', 'Global Warming', 'Oceans and Seas']
abstract: A new study finds Atlantic Ocean warming is a powerful driver of a host of recent world-spanning climate and ocean patterns.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 3:10 p.m. | Using climate models and observations, a fascinating study in this week’s issue of Nature Climate Change points to a marked recent warming of the Atlantic Ocean as a powerful shaper of a host of notable changes in climate and ocean patterns in the last couple of decades — including Pacific wind, sea level and ocean patterns, the decade-plus hiatus in global warming and even California’s deepening drought.

headline: Earthquake Kills Hundreds in Southwest China

With dozens of people reported missing on Sunday night, the death toll was expected to rise.

headline: Viennese Classicism, Varied and Revealing
abstract: Viennese Classicism was on display at the Mostly Mozart Festival at Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: Innovation has been the watchword of the once staid Mostly Mozart Festival at Lincoln Center over the last dozen years, with Jane Moss as artistic director and Louis Langrée as music director. But those worthies can still muster a long, rich night of more or less Mozartean fare without resorting to an early-music or new-music band, a fully staged opera or an injection of dance or world music.

abstract: But the people they con may be a different story.

I did imply — and have said explicitly on many other occasions — that he is a con man. Why did I do that?

lead_paragraph: As the trading deadline approached last week, Mets Manager Terry Collins sought out the veteran pitcher Bartolo Colon to see if the constant trade rumors about him had become a distraction. Colon, considered the Mets’ most marketable and available asset, simply shrugged his shoulders. Rumors are part of the game, he told Collins.

headline: An Antidote to Illusion, Examining Restive Borders

David Eimer did, too, repeatedly, over the past decade, but he had a larger purpose in mind: to investigate the nature of Chinese rule in the restive border regions where its 55 ethnic minorities live.

headline: Mourning a Champion of Eclectic Performance With Pomp and Spirit
abstract: A wide assortment of performers gathered in Hearst Plaza on Friday for a concert in memory of Jenneth Webster, who directed Lincoln Center Out of Doors for 28 years.
lead_paragraph: If you didn’t know Jenneth Webster personally, you might have known her just by walking through Lincoln Center on a summer day. As the director of Lincoln Center Out of Doors for 28 years, Ms. Webster filled the plazas each summer with her eclectic, lively choice of dance and music, all of it free to the public. She died in April, and on Friday in Hearst Plaza, artists and guest speakers, including many of the choreographers and dancers she had championed, gathered for a concert in her memory.

headline: A President Hoist With His Own Petulance, Secretly Recorded
abstract: The strange little documentary “Nixon by Nixon: In His Own Words,” which airs Monday on HBO, alternates a public persona with a closeted monster revealed by secret White House tapes.
lead_paragraph: The strange little documentary “Nixon by Nixon: In His Own Words” (Monday on HBO) is engrossing despite itself. Timed to the 40th anniversary next Saturday of Richard M. Nixon’s resignation, it samples Nixon’s secret White House tapes to sketch the familiar portrait of the president as a closeted monster: paranoid, vicious, racist, sexist, anti-Semitic, with a casual disregard for anything besides his own standing.

headline: Familiar Faces Join Forces to Portray an Unlikely Duo
abstract: Kelsey Grammer and Martin Lawrence play lawyers in the new FX sitcom “Partners.”
lead_paragraph: The new FX sitcom “Partners” might have you doubting your own memory. The series, which stars Kelsey Grammer and Martin Lawrence, is so labored and unfunny that you may find yourself asking: “Wasn’t ‘Frasier’ sharp and urbane? Didn’t ‘Martin’ have some spunk? Where are those two guys?”

headline: Memorial Plan Called a ‘Five-Star Folly’
keywords: ['Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A House Natural Resources Committee report criticized the commission behind a memorial to Dwight D. Eisenhower over spending and its choice of a designer.
lead_paragraph: Fifteen years ago, federal officials approved the idea of building a memorial on the Washington Mall to honor Dwight D. Eisenhower, the general and president, and they later selected one of America’s foremost architects to design it. But the memorial is still far from being built, and congressional critics have come forward in recent days to depict it as just another Washington boondoggle or, in the words of a new report, “a five-star folly.”

headline: Holocaust Grafted to Beethoven
abstract: The Santa Fe Opera sets “Fidelio” in a concentration camp, though the details of the Holocaust are too abhorrent and too well known to be shoehorned into that work.
lead_paragraph: SANTA FE, N.M. — No audience members staggered out of the Santa Fe Opera House in search of assistance on Thursday evening after Stephen Wadsworth’s production of Beethoven’s “Fidelio” inspired by Bergen-Belsen. This wasn’t Burkhard C. Kosminski’s staging of Wagner’s “Tannhäuser,” which last year upset audience members in Düsseldorf, Germany, so much with its graphic depiction of gassings and shootings that some required medical attention. Mr. Wadsworth’s concentration-camp spin on the tale of a political prisoner who is liberated by his wife after she has disguised herself as a man and apprenticed with the prison warden was perfectly tasteful.

headline: Where the Stars Come to Shine in New and Unexpected Ways

lead_paragraph: VAIL, Colo. — High in the Rockies amid pine forests and ski slopes, the Vail International Dance Festival, now in its 26th season, has become an event of prestige, history and startling ambition. Each year, it features premieres, debuts, new partnerships and an admirably eclectic taste. Even for those performers and choreographers who return each year (a large number, and high level), it often opens some new chapter in their careers.

headline: Candlelight Reflections to Illuminate Harmonies
abstract: The violist Antoine Tamestit played a solo recital of Bach and Hindemith as part of the Mostly Mozart Festival on Saturday evening.
lead_paragraph: Some musicians experience synesthesia, associating certain colors with particular harmonies or sounds. For the violist Antoine Tamestit, Bach’s Suite No. 1 in G for cello evokes the color blue, along with a sense of fluidity and tranquillity. The Suite No. 3 in C makes him think of the sun and thus the color yellow. He feels the color in the sound, which informs his interpretation, he explained during his impressive solo recital at the Stanley H. Kaplan Penthouse on Saturday evening.

headline: Trombone Shorty Helps a Young Victim
abstract: When a 14-year-old boy was robbed of his trombone, one of the best-known musicians in New Orleans decided to do something.
lead_paragraph: The news reports shook New Orleans: A 14-year-old boy was robbed of his trombone last week by a gunman who fired several shots at him as he ran away. When one of the city’s best-known musicians, Troy Andrews, who performs as Trombone Shorty, heard about it while on tour in the Northeast, he decided to do something: He asked his foundation to replace the boy’s stolen instrument. “It is very unfortunate that this young man was robbed of his instrument and had to be a victim of New Orleans crime,” Mr. Andrews said in a statement. “I’m replacing his horn, because I want to make sure that he has what he needs to continue his education in music without missing a beat. He is the future of our music.” Mr. Andrews’s band, Trombone Shorty & Orleans Avenue, has performed at the Grammy Awards and the White House and has become familiar to television viewers of the HBO series “Treme.” His Trombone Shorty Foundation is dedicated to passing on New Orleans’s musical heritage through educational initiatives. Bill Taylor, the foundation’s executive director, said that on Saturday he brought the new trombone to the robbery victim, whose name was withheld for his safety. Then he put the teenager on the phone with Mr. Andrews, who was at the Newport Jazz Festival.

headline: Morning Views
abstract: Opinions on family super PACs, fast-food employee fairness, climate reality and a failed state in Libya.
lead_paragraph: “Attention, parents of political candidates. There is now a way to spend an unlimited amount on your child’s campaign for Congress, completely ignoring that annoying $2,600 legal limit on what you can give,” says an editorial in The New York Times. “All you do is set up a ‘super PAC’ for your kid and start writing checks. It’s not much harder than that 529 account you used for the same kid’s college education.” This is apparently what Martine Rothblatt, the founder of Sirius Satellite Radio, did for her son, Gariel Rothblatt, who is running for a Florida congressional seat. A group calling itself Space PAC, in promoting Mr. Rothblatt’s campaign, “has raised $225,000, all of it from Martine Rothblatt.” The Times says, “family-financed super PACs are only the latest and most outrageous examples of how super PACs are used in this campaign cycle to evade the limits on donations.” Congress should pass the Empowering Citizens Act, “a bill introduced in the House that would put strict limits on these kinds of coordinated contributions. But the more members of Congress depend on these groups, the less chance they will want to put a stop to them.”

lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Her Throne Defunct, a Princess Fights Eviction From Her Manhattan Walk-Up
keywords: ['Rent Control and Stabilization', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Evictions', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Ottoman Empire']
abstract: Zeynep Osman, a niece of a former Afghan ruler and the widow of the heir to the Ottoman throne, is trying to keep her $390-a-month rent-controlled apartment.
lead_paragraph: Tutankhamen, Richard III, Louis XVI — throughout history, the deaths of monarchs have set off wars, revolutions and writing careers. Now, the passing of the last of the imperial Ottoman Turks has led to a battle over the rent-controlled apartment of an Afghan princess on the Upper East Side.

headline: The Meaning of Emancipation Day
abstract: Why Harriet Jacobs, a slave turned journalist, urged black soldiers to keep fighting.
lead_paragraph: By August 1864, the abolitionist writer and former slave Harriet Jacobs had spent more than a year and a half providing relief for the refugees flooding the contraband camps of Alexandria, Va. – some 6,000 people, she reported that spring to her employer, the New York Yearly Meeting of Friends. By Jacobs’s count that March, the freedmen had put up 700 small houses in just eight months.

headline: Tunisian Grilled Peppers and Tomatoes with Couscous
abstract: This spicy, juicy meal, perfect for the summer, is one of a variety of Tunisian grilled salads. The couscous can be served warm or at room temperature.
lead_paragraph: This makes a heavenly summer meal. Reconstitute some couscous and top with this spicy, juicy mix of grilled pepper and tomato salad. You can serve the couscous warm or at room temperature. The pepper salad is typical of Tunisian grilled salads (mechwya), of which there are many versions (eggplant can be included in the mix). In Tunisia, a spice mix called tabil would be used to season the peppers. I keep the mix on hand, without the dried garlic, but here I’ve given you a mix of spices to use. You can substitute tabil if you have some; the mix will be a little hotter because there is cayenne in the tabil.

headline: A Hungry Little Squatter
abstract: Losing the battle with Burmese pythons, Florida wildlife biologists are fighting back against the tegu, the latest nonnative species to find a comfortable home out in the Everglades.
lead_paragraph: FLORIDA CITY, Fla. — Deer flies swarmed around Frank Mazzotti and Joy Vinci as they stooped to get a closer look at the creature thrashing around in a metal trap they had laid off a weedy dirt road. Inside it was what some biologists consider the most troublesome invasive species in the Everglades: not a Burmese python, but a 24-inch lizard, the Argentine black and white tegu.

headline: During Broadway Week, Two-for-One Deals
abstract: Broadway Week, from Sept. 1 to 14, will feature two-for-one offers on a number of high-profile shows.
lead_paragraph: The average price of a Broadway ticket topped $100 for the first time this year, according to the Broadway League, a nonprofit industry association. Some 12.2 million theatergoers in the 2013-14 season typically paid $103.88 per seat, and many much more, an inflationary trend that NYC & Company, New York’s tourism office, aims to relieve, at least temporarily, with Broadway Week.

headline: Border Fighting Intensifies Between ISIS and Lebanon
abstract: The fighting in the Lebanese town of Arsal appeared to be the worst spillover into Lebanon since the Syrian conflict began more than three years ago.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A deadly confrontation worsened on Monday between Lebanon’s armed forces and Islamist insurgents from Syria who seized the border town of Arsal over the weekend in what appeared to be the most serious spillover of the Syrian civil war into Lebanese territory since the conflict began more than three years ago.

headline: Popeyes Offers Chicken With Its Own Playlist
abstract: The restaurant chain’s campaign for its Tear’n Tenderloin Chicken, a menu item being offered for a limited time, includes a set of songs on Spotify.
lead_paragraph: Popeyes Louisiana Kitchen Inc. has introduced its latest limited-time-offer menu item, made from chicken tenderloin, with an ad campaign featuring a Spotify playlist.

lead_paragraph: The artisans at Marc Jacobs reveal the laborious process of making a signature handbag.

headline: Alabama’s Requirement for Abortion Clinic Doctors Is Ruled Unconstitutional
abstract: A federal judge said the law requiring doctors to have admitting privileges at local hospitals severely restricted access to an abortion.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Monday rejected as unconstitutional an Alabama law requiring doctors at abortion clinics to have admitting privileges at local hospitals.

headline: A Behind-the-Scenes Video Shows the Making of Marc Jacobs’s New It Bag
abstract: T has an exclusive look at the painstaking process behind the new Incognito, inspired by a doctor’s satchel.
lead_paragraph: Though Marc Jacobs is no stranger to shock value — he posed naked for his Bang men’s fragrance ad in 2010 and made Miley Cyrus the controversial face of his spring/summer 2014 campaign — his latest launch is an homage to understatement. A modern interpretation of a doctor’s bag with clean lines and a hand-constructed pleat detail, the Incognito is now available at Marc Jacobs stores in a range of custom colors and materials ($2,100 – $38,000). Here, an exclusive video provides an up-close look at the process of constructing the bag, which is comprised of 124 different pieces, at Jacobs’s atelier in Milan.

headline: Investigation Into Violence Toward Teenagers at Rikers Island
abstract: Preet Bharara, the U.S. attorney in Manhattan, released a 79-page report saying the New York City Department of Correction had systematically violated inmates’ civil rights.
lead_paragraph: Preet Bharara, the U.S. attorney in Manhattan, released a 79-page report saying the New York City Department of Correction had systematically violated inmates’ civil rights.

headline: Joshu Sasaki, 107, Tainted Zen Master
abstract: Mr. Sasaki was one of the most influential and charismatic Zen masters in America but a tide of sex-abuse allegations emerged to cast his character and his legacy in a harsh light.
lead_paragraph: Joshu Sasaki, who died on July 27 at the age of 107, was one of the most influential and charismatic Zen masters in America, imparting a mix of paradox, personality and transcendental insight to an estimated half-million people during a 50-year career.

headline: A Permanent Port of Call Tending Bar
abstract: Paul Gustings of Empire Bar at Broussard’s, an éminence grise in the New Orleans bartender community, is having a moment in the limelight.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — There are as many versions of the Sazerac here as there are bars. Still, the one made by the bartender Paul Gustings stands out.

headline: Japanese Music Festival to Be Renamed in Honor of Ozawa
abstract: The Saito Kinen Festival will be known as the Seiji Ozawa Matsumoto Festival starting in 2015.
lead_paragraph: The Saito Kinen Festival, which the conductor Seiji Ozawa founded in 1992, in Matsumoto, Japan, as a tribute to his teacher, Hideo Saito, will be renamed in honor of Mr. Ozawa, The Japan Times reported. At a news conference in Tokyo on Monday, the festival announced that starting in 2015, the annual summer series will be called the Seiji Ozawa Matsumoto Festival. Its principal ensemble, however, will continue as the Saito Kinen Orchestra.

headline: Time Warner Rebuff of Fox May Not Just Be Negotiating Ploy
abstract: With Time Warner Inc.’s rejection last month of an $80 billion bid by Rupert Murdoch’s 21st Century Fox, the mating ritual had begun, or so it seemed.
lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch tends to finish what he starts. So from the moment the news broke last month that Time Warner Inc. had rejected an $80 billion bid by Mr. Murdoch’s 21st Century Fox, the assumption on Wall Street and in the media world was that it was only a matter of time before a deal was struck.

headline: President Obama Acknowledges Torture, Upsets Liz Cheney
abstract: The former vice president’s daughter said the president’s remarks were “despicable.”
lead_paragraph: Nothing annoys a Cheney like anyone of prominence talking about the disasters that Vice President Dick Cheney helped engineer during the last Bush administration. So it wasn’t surprising that his daughter, Liz, was outraged when President Obama talked about the torture of prisoners after the 9/11 terrorist attacks.

headline: You Won’t Meet the Beatles in Space
abstract: The International Astronomical Union is letting people vote on naming distant worlds, but it’s not as fun as you’d think.
lead_paragraph: When you think about the far future of the human race, do you dream of sailing the tropical oceans on Gliese 1214b? Walking around like Superman on Kepler 7b?

headline: Death Toll Rises in Nepal Landslide as Search for Bodies Continues
abstract: At least 33 people have been reported dead after Saturday’s landslide, which struck near the Nepal-China border. More than 120 are missing.
lead_paragraph: KATMANDU, Nepal — The death toll from a major landslide near the Nepal-China border reached 33 on Monday as efforts to recover what was expected to be at least 120 more bodies continued.

headline: Calm After a Bank’s Collapse in Portugal Could Signal Eurozone Resiliency
abstract: The market reaction after the bailout plan for Banco Espírito Santo emerged could bode well for a larger, coming test of the region’s banks.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The collapse of the Portuguese bank seemed to have all the makings of a disaster. With little warning, a government in one of Europe’s most financially weak countries was suddenly confronted with a multibillion-euro rescue of Banco Espírito Santo. And the crisis hit during a period of acute uncertainty in Europe brought on by fighting in Ukraine.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Earnhardt Sweeps Pocono
abstract: Dale Earnhardt Jr. picked up his third season win, making it two at Pocono; Scott Dixon raced from a 22nd-place start to win the IndyCar race in Ohio.
lead_paragraph: Dale Earnhardt Jr., enjoying his most productive season in a decade, won the 400-mile Nascar Sprint Cup race Sunday at Pocono Raceway in Pennsylvania. Earnhardt, in scoring his third victory this season, got the best of the runner-up Kevin Harvick on a restart, with three laps to go in the 160-lap contest. Harvick had battled back from a midrace stop-and-go penalty for speeding on the pit road that placed him near the rear of the field.

headline: Sake With Your Burger? Japan Is Looking West to Save a Tradition
abstract: As domestic consumption falls, Japanese brewers are trying to increase exports, even going abroad to find the right pairings with Western cuisine.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Kensuke Shichida, the head of a centuries-old sake brewery in southern Japan, had spent a dizzying week in London restaurants tasting a variety of exotic and confounding dishes: pub food, gourmet burgers, French food, Angus beef, ceviche.

headline: Maker of Penfolds Wine May End Resistance to K.K.R. Buyout
abstract: Though there are risks to negotiating in public and K.K.R. could still walk away from its conditional bid, Treasury Wine’s days as a listed company look as though they will soon come to an end, Peter Thal Larsen writes in Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Treasury Wine Estates has decided that a grape is worth more in the bottle than on the vine.

headline: Protesters in Sri Lanka Disrupt Meeting on Civil War Missing
abstract: Protesters allied with the Sri Lankan government blocked the exits at a meeting hall as the families of missing people met with diplomats and civil-society groups.
lead_paragraph: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — Protesters allied with the Sri Lankan government prevented American and European diplomats from leaving a meeting of families of missing people for nearly two hours on Monday.

lead_paragraph: Running 130 otherwise perfect minutes, Sidney Lumet’s “Dog Day Afternoon” was punctuated by only two inauthentic moments as a feature film. One was invisible, and the other was barely audible.

headline: Music Festival From Beijing to Make American Debut in New York
abstract: The Modern Sky Festival, established in Beijing in 2007, will offer two days of concerts in Central Park in October.
lead_paragraph: The Modern Sky Festival, a music festival with indie leanings that was established in Beijing in 2007, plans to make its American debut in October when it presents two days of concerts at the Rumsey Playfield in Central Park, the organizers announced on Monday.

headline: Taking a Bullet, Gaining a Cause: James S. Brady Dies at 73
abstract: Mr. Brady, the White House press secretary who was wounded in an assassination attempt on President Ronald Reagan, championed tighter regulations from his wheelchair.
lead_paragraph: James S. Brady, the White House press secretary who was wounded in an assassination attempt on President Ronald Reagan and then became a symbol of the fight for gun control, championing tighter regulations from his wheelchair, died on Monday in Alexandria, Va. He was 73.

headline: How Wikipedia Could Improve Your Internet Surfing
abstract: Could the encyclopedia site reinsert the unexpected into what some say has become an all-too-predictable online world?
lead_paragraph: For years, critics have feared that the Internet will kill interestingness, offering us only what we’re looking for with none of the happy accidents that can spur creative thought. Might a solution to this problem come from the kind of browsing we do on Wikipedia?

headline: Who’s Moving In Now?
keywords: ['Elderly', 'Families and Family Life', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Research', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The luggage in the living room? Odds are, it’s not Grandma’s as multigenerational households trend younger.
lead_paragraph: Are we really seeing a return to “The Waltons”? Family members sharing the old farmhouse, with Grandma and Grandpa helping to raise the young ’uns and then, when they get too frail to bake pies or go fishing, being cared for by their adult children?

headline: Jason Dufner Finds a Voice, if Not His Putting Stroke
abstract: Dufner’s 2013 P.G.A. Championship title has made more people pay attention to him and his game, even if his putting remains shaky and he has not won lately.
lead_paragraph: AKRON, Ohio — Enlisted to make a celebrity appearance during a gala charity announcement on the eve of last week’s Bridgestone Invitational, Jason Dufner appeared to have put the most trying part behind him when he stepped away from the microphone after delivering a brief speech.

headline: Working in the Medium of Science
abstract: Arthur I. Miller’s new book examines the trend of contemporary artists and inventors whose works are also cutting-edge scientific advances.
lead_paragraph: Scientists are logical, making observations and running experiments, then building theories that explain the data. Artists are emotional, working in solitude and by intuition. Or so we are told.

headline: $320 Million Facility to Stoke China’s Musical Theater Industry
abstract: A new musical production center outside Beijing is intended to expand China’s role in the musical theater industry.
lead_paragraph: With musical theater markets growing robustly in South Korea, Japan and Australia, China is taking a step toward increasing its relatively modest role in the industry by building a major new musical production center outside Beijing, according to the China Daily website.

headline: Early Nick Drake Recording Pulled From Auction
abstract: An unreleased recording by the singer-songwriter, who died in 1974, was withdrawn from sale after a legal challenge.
lead_paragraph: An early demo tape by the singer-songwriter Nick Drake, which was to have been auctioned this week in London, may make its way to court before it gets near an auctioneer’s gavel. The tape, a demo probably recorded  in 1968, before Drake began work on his debut album, “Five Leaves Left,” has been in the possession of the British folksinger Beverley Martyn, a close friend of Drake’s, since shortly after Drake’s death from an overdose of antidepressant medicine in 1974, when he was 26. Martyn had consigned the tape this spring to Ted Owen & Company, a London auction house, saying that she was selling it because she was in poor health and needed the money.

headline: Walkabout: C.D.C. Issues Ebola Travel Guidelines
abstract: A weekly capsule of travel news curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Agency Issues Ebola Warnings The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has issued guidelines to airlines in response to the Ebola outbreak that has killed more than 800 people in western Africa. People exposed to the disease are asked not to travel for 21 days, and the C.D.C. suggests that airlines consider using their legal authority to deny boarding to sick passengers suspected of carrying the virus. The C.D.C. has also advised Americans to avoid nonessential travel to Guinea, Sierra Leone and Liberia, the three countries most affected by the outbreak. (The New York Times)

headline: Judge Awards $24.6 Million to Former Rauschenberg Trustees
abstract: A judge in Florida ruled that three men who administered the estate of the artist Robert Rauschenberg had done “an exemplary job” and merited significant payment.
lead_paragraph: The Robert Rauschenberg Foundation said Monday it was considering its legal options after a judge in Florida awarded $24.6 million to three trustees who had administered the late artist’s estate.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The federal government is shutting down three temporary shelters that had been opened to house a surge of unaccompanied children from Central America entering the United States across the southern border, officials said Monday afternoon.

headline: Reactions on Twitter to James S. Brady’s Death

headline: Iraq Agrees to Help Kurds Battle Sunni Extremists
abstract: Iraq’s prime minister ordered the air force to support Kurdish forces fighting ISIS, a thaw born of military necessity in the fraught relations between Baghdad and the Kurds.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki on Monday ordered Iraq’s air force to support Kurdish forces fighting Sunni extremists in the north, a move that represented a thaw, out of military necessity, in the fraught relations between the central government and Kurdish leaders.

headline: 1964: Attack in the Gulf of Tonkin
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Two U.S. warships have come under fire in Vietnam in 1964.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — North Vietnamese PT boats tonight [Aug. 4] made a ‘‘deliberate attack’’ on the U.S. destroyers Maddox and C. Turner Joy in the Gulf of Tonkin and two Communist vessels were believed sunk, the Defense Department announced. The department said the attack, involving six to ten PT boats, took place in the same general area where the Maddox’s guns drove off an attack on Sunday. The announcement of the new attack was made shortly after President Johnson had summoned congressional leaders to the White House to brief them on the turn of events in Southeast Asia. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 5, 1964

headline: A Global Trip to Find Himself Led Back Home
keywords: ['Family Business', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Business Travel']
abstract: A conversation with a seatmate on a flight from Nepal to India prompted Stew Leonard Jr. to join the family grocery store business.
lead_paragraph: I’M 59 years old, and at one point in my life it would be nothing for me to be in six different cities over the course of a week. I’m very active, but I don’t miss those kinds of trips. Two or three times a month is fine with me. I’m president and chief executive of my family’s owned and operated grocery stores, Stew Leonard’s, so I go to a lot of trade shows and have to visit a lot of suppliers.
