headline: Betty Fussell: Still Blazing Trails
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Food', 'Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: A visit with Ms. Fussell, a leader of the American food movement.
lead_paragraph: I walked the druid path through an oak grove to the Casa Dorinda, a retirement community in Montecito, Calif., where Julia Child spent her final days. I could have driven the main road like everyone else. But those weren’t the directions that Betty had given me.

headline: Caught in Indecision, Bulgarian Government Is Urged to Solve Banking Crisis
abstract: European Union regulators and international investors are urging the country to rescue depositors and bondholders of the Corporate Commercial Bank, which has been closed since a run in June.
lead_paragraph: Pressure is building on Bulgaria to deal with its worst banking crisis since the 1990s as the European Union and international investors have issued warnings about the fate of one of the country’s largest banks.

headline: David Wilson to Leave Football and Retire From Giants at 23
abstract: Wilson, a running back, seemed to accept on Monday that his N.F.L. career was over after doctors informed him that he would be putting himself at risk if he continued playing.
lead_paragraph: During his rookie season in 2012, Giants running back David Wilson delighted fans and irked opponents by performing a back flip in the end zone after scoring, stealing a page from the showmanship playbook of the Hall of Fame shortstop Ozzie Smith.

headline: In Libya, Parliament Convenes Amid Battles
abstract: Battles in Tripoli and Benghazi forced the leaders to meet in Tobruk as they sought to prove “that Libya is not a failed country.”
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Libyan leaders, struggling to keep their country from spinning further out of control, convened a newly elected Parliament for its first session on Monday.

headline: A Nose for Their Favorite Foods
abstract: Dogs have 60 times as many smell receptors as humans, but they have less than one-fourth the number of taste buds.
lead_paragraph: Q. Dogs have such exquisite olfactory abilities; do they also possess a superior ability to taste things?

headline: Washington Meeting of African Leaders Opens to Protests

abstract: Hundreds of protesters gathered outside the State Department to denounce some of the leaders in attendance as “torturers” and “killers.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hundreds of protesters gathered outside the State Department on Monday, the start of a summit meeting here of more than 40 African heads of state, to denounce some of the leaders as “torturers” and “killers.”

headline: Exclusive Google ‘Camp’ Draws Elite to Sicilian Resort
abstract: Google has gathered business leaders, tech luminaries and celebrities for high-minded discussions of global issues as well as schmoozing and basking in the Mediterranean sun.
lead_paragraph: Google’s latest innovation is not computerized eyeglasses or self-driving cars. Its major selling points are the more old-fashioned pleasures of sand, sun and schmoozing.

headline: White House Spokesman on James Brady
abstract: The White House press secretary, Josh Earnest, reflected on the death of an earlier press secretary, James Brady, during the daily press briefing.
lead_paragraph: The White House press secretary, Josh Earnest, reflected on the death of an earlier press secretary, James Brady, during the daily press briefing.

headline: Americans Are Bad at Math, but It’s Not Too Late to Fix
abstract: Americans rank in the bottom five in numeracy, and some believe gambling is a good deal. But there are ways for people to improve their knowledge of math.
lead_paragraph: When I lived in Las Vegas, there were billboards everywhere advertising different casinos. One of the most common was the type that promised “98 percent payouts.” I remember thinking how amazing that was. After all, 98 is a lot of percents! It seemed like a really good deal — until I thought about it for a minute.

headline: Penguins That Get Their Point Across
abstract: Adults and babies have different ways of expressing their needs, scientists have found.
lead_paragraph: Adult African penguins use four vocal cries, and babies only two, according to a study in PLOS One. Adults have a combat call, a contact call if lost, a come-hither song and a love song for birds paired in the nest. Both baby calls are pleas for food: one a peep, the other a moan.

headline: A Look at How We Process Painful Experiences
abstract: The habenula helps keep track of painful experiences and might be linked to motivation, a finding that could help in the treatment of depression.
lead_paragraph: A tiny part of the brain keeps track of painful experiences and helps determine how we will react to them in the future, scientists say. The findings could be a boon to depression treatments.

headline: A Key Malaria Drug Becomes Less Effective
abstract: Researchers have found signs of increasing resistance in Southeast Asia to artemisinin, a crucial drug that has helped save millions of lives.
lead_paragraph: The parasite that causes the most deadly form of malaria is becoming more resistant to the most effective drug used to treat it, scientists in Southeast Asia are reporting.

headline: Chegg Finds Partner to Handle Its Textbooks
abstract: The move by Chegg, a textbook rental company, is an attempt to answer investors who may be wary that its signature business is becoming obsolete.
lead_paragraph: For years, Chegg worked to become one of the biggest players in the business of renting textbooks to students. But since going public late last year, the company has suffered from a big investor concern: that its signature business was becoming obsolete.

headline: Xiaomi Tops Chinese Smartphone Market
abstract: Xiaomi, the Chinese smartphone vendor, transformed from a niche player into the biggest smartphone maker in China, seemingly overnight. How did that happen so fast?
lead_paragraph: Just last year, Xiaomi was a relatively obscure Chinese handset maker. But last quarter, Xiaomi was the top smartphone seller in the largest handset market in the world: China.

headline: Patients’ Symptoms Raise Concern About Ebola in New York
abstract: In the latest episode, a man who was recently in West Africa is being tested after visiting an emergency room with signs of the disease.
lead_paragraph: Heightened concern about the Ebola virus has led to alarms being raised at three hospitals in New York City. But so far, no Ebola cases have turned up.

headline: One-Two Punch in the Bullpen Takes Some Knocks

lead_paragraph: Jenrry Mejia held his palms to the sky and then put his hands on his hips as the gravity of the moment sank in. The first two outs of the ninth had come so easily, and now slowly, methodically, the San Francisco Giants had ground their way back.

headline: An End to Free Rides Through Speedier PreCheck Security
abstract: For a time, some travelers were sent through PreCheck airport security checkpoints without having paid a fee, but that will soon end.

headline: What Lykke Li, André Benjamin, Blood Orange and Other Stars Were Wearing at Lollapalooza
abstract: The photographer Andres Gonzalez captured new and established acts — and the rain-soaked but enthusiastic crowd — in Chicago over the weekend.
lead_paragraph: This year, the blissful Chicago summer turned nasty during Lollapalooza. The music festival, which celebrated its 10th year in Grant Park, saw plenty of rain and mud — conditions that have become as much a part of the festival’s tradition as shirtless frat boys and the sight of its its wiry founder, the Jane’s Addiction frontman Perry Farrell, roaming the premises. Still, the 300,000 revelers (including Malia Obama) who turned out didn’t seem to mind. They roared their approval for young stars like Lykke Li and the Chicago native Chance the Rapper (“This is the coolest show I’ve ever done,” he told the Sunday-night crowd), and turned out in full voice for elder statesmen like Eminem and OutKast. The photographer Andres Gonzalez braved the inclement conditions — and the mosh pits — to capture it all.

headline: Mississippi: Cochran Victory Is Challenged
abstract: State Senator Chris McDaniel filed a formal challenge on Monday to the outcome of the Republican United States Senate primary, citing evidence he said would show “a pattern of conduct” resulting in an improper victory for his rival, Senator Thad Cochran.
lead_paragraph: State Senator Chris McDaniel filed a formal challenge on Monday to the outcome of the Republican United States Senate primary, citing evidence he said would show “a pattern of conduct” resulting in an improper victory for his rival, Senator Thad Cochran. Mitch Tyner, a lawyer for the McDaniel campaign, said the evidence would show that thousands of votes in the June 24 runoff were invalid, some of them cast by people who may have violated state election law by voting in the Republican runoff after having voted in the Democratic primary (there is no party registration in Mississippi, though so-called crossover voting is illegal). Mr. Tyner said he was not seeking a new election but a declaration by the state Republican executive committee that Mr. McDaniel was the winner, and he asked for a hearing within eight days. Mr. Cochran won the runoff by roughly 7,700 votes, a victory that was helped by turning out black voters who rarely participate in Republican primaries. Mr. Tyner said the McDaniel campaign’s research would show that Mr. McDaniel had won by 25,000 votes.

He argues that the P.K.K. curbed violence when the Turkish state began making concessions to its demands related to Kurdish identity and autonomy. He omits that the state negotiated from a position of strength, and that its concessions came after years of responding to the group with unremitting force. headline: Morning Views
abstract: Opinions on regulating marijuana, a flatter health care curve, the legacy of James S. Brady and Lake Michigan’s tasty water.
lead_paragraph: “As voters and lawmakers in more states decide to legalize marijuana, policy makers will have to answer a fresh and difficult question,” writes Vikas Bajaj for The New York Times. “How should governments regulate the production and sale of the drug?” A functional regulatory system “has to limit the increase in drug abuse that is likely to accompany lower prices and greater availability” in a post-legalization America. First, lawmakers must institute a viable method of taxation — “policies that allow licensed businesses to undercut the illegal market but keep prices high enough so dependence on the drug does not increase a lot.” Second, distributors must not be permitted to market to minors: “Controls should emulate the restrictions on targeting young people, banning outdoor advertising and product placements that the tobacco industry accepted as part of its settlement with the state attorney general in 1998.” And finally, streams of cultivation and retail should be segregated — to avoid a similar system of juggernauts that dominates the tobacco industry. Ultimately, “whatever states decide to do, it is important that they stand ready to modify policies as legal marijuana markets evolve.”

headline: Deep Chords: Haruki Murakami’s ‘Colorless Tsukuru Tazaki and His Years of Pilgrimage’
abstract: Patti Smith reviews Haruki Murakami’s dreamlike new novel, in which a man seeks out old friends to understand why he was banished from their circle.
lead_paragraph: A devotional anticipation is generated by the announcement of a new Haruki Murakami book. Readers wait for his work the way past generations lined up at record stores for new albums by the Beatles or Bob Dylan. There is a happily frenzied collective expectancy — the effect of cultural voice, the Murakami effect. Within seven days of its midnight release, “Colorless Tsukuru Tazaki and His Years of Pilgrimage” sold over one million copies in Japan. I envision readers queuing up at midnight outside Tokyo bookstores: the alienated, the athletic, the disenchanted and the buoyant. I can’t help wondering what effect the book had on them, and what they were hoping for: the surreal, intra-dimensional side of Murakami or his more minimalist, realist side?

headline: Rubin Museum Show to Trace Francesco Clemente’s Indian Inspirations
abstract: “Francesco Clemente: Inspired by India,” is scheduled to open in September at the Rubin Museum of Art.

But one current that runs through much of his painting and sculpture has been the influence of Indian culture, mythology, symbolism and art.

headline: Sofia Coppola’s Latest Project: A Look Book for a New Line of California Casual Wear
abstract: The filmmaker has shot a new series of images for Calder, an L.A.-based collection of soft jersey layers designed by her cousin-in-law Amanda Blake.
lead_paragraph: Sofia Coppola has long acted as muse to marquee fashion designers like Marc Jacobs and Karl Lagerfeld (she interned at Chanel as a teenager). She has also directed commercials for Dior’s fragrance Miss Dior. Now the director of the upcoming live-action adaptation of “The Little Mermaid” is lending her talent to a lesser-known name: Calder, a made-in-L.A. label started last year by her cousin-in-law Amanda Blake. Coppola recently shot the look book for Calder’s fall/winter 2014 collection, a series of soft jersey tees, tanks and T-shirt dresses whose easygoing aesthetic dovetails with Coppola’s own. “I tried to show the line how I would wear it,” says Coppola, who shot the images in her New York apartment so as to feel “intimate and basic.” The results have the same warm, personal quality as Coppola’s films. “I just tried to show the clothes in a way that felt real.”

headline: 1964: Russians Warn of ‘Broad War’
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Russia condemns American military actions in Vietnam in 1964.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The Soviet Union tonight warned that further American ‘‘rash steps’’ in Vietnam could lead to a ‘‘broad armed conflict.’’ In a statement by the Tass news agency, the Russians called American action an ‘‘aggressive’’ act. Such actions, or further steps or provocations, ‘‘could lead to broad conflict with all the ensuing dangerous consequences,’’ Tass said. It added that the responsibility would lie on the United States. The statement was issued after a day in which Soviet news media refrained from comment, reporting only what American and North Vietnamese sources were announcing. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 6, 1964

headline: Mini Bell Peppers Stuffed with Goat Cheese
abstract: This side dish is a way to take advantage of the mini sweet peppers that are showing up by the bag in supermarkets. They should be roasted briefly and not peeled.
lead_paragraph: My oldest brother, Dan, and his wife, Margaret, hosted a wonderful party in Minneapolis in May to celebrate their 50th anniversary. The savory food on the gorgeous vegetarian buffet was catered by the well-known Minneapolis restaurant Lucia’s, whose chef/owner, Lucia Watson, is a friend of the family. One of my favorite items was minipeppers stuffed with goat cheese, the inspiration for this recipe. Mini sweet peppers have begun to proliferate in supermarkets; the ones I’m finding come in 12-ounce bags, roughly 12 to a bag (though they range in size, some being about two inches long, others about three), usually a mix of red and yellow. They are thin skinned, with very small seedpods and membranes. I roast them briefly to soften them and sweeten the flavor. There is no need to peel them, and they should not be roasted so long that the skin loosens. You will probably have a little filling left over, but it’s nice as a spread so it won’t go to waste.

headline: New Foundation Will Support, and Commission, American Music
abstract: The American Music Project is the brainchild of Lawrence A. Johnson, a music critic who got tired of complaining that groups were not performing enough American music.
lead_paragraph: Lawrence A. Johnson, a Chicago music critic, got tired of complaining that musical organizations were not performing enough American music and decided to do something about it. Mr. Johnson, the founder of The Classical Review, a group of websites with Chicago, Boston, New York and Florida editions, has spent the last few months putting together plans and raising support for a new venture, the American Music Project  a nonprofit foundation that hopes to put a brighter spotlight on the American repertory, old and new, and to commission new works.

headline: Gannett Could Have Given More Help to Its Print Spinoff
abstract: Instead of using Cars.com to buffer its print operations — the weaker half of the company — Gannett is forcing print to stand on its own, Jeffrey Goldfarb of Reuters Breakingviews writes.
lead_paragraph: Gannett is redefining the digital divide. The media conglomerate unveiled plans on Tuesday to spin off newspapers, including USA Today, to showcase the value of its broadcasting operations. At the same time, the company will take control of the parent of Cars.com, paying $1.8 billion for the 73 percent it doesn’t already own. Instead of using that online asset to buffer the weaker half, however, Gannett is forcing print to stand on its own.

headline: Grilled Pepper Omelet
abstract: Roasted peppers, chopped herbs and a little bit of Parmesan make for a quick omelet in the spirit of a pipérade.
lead_paragraph: I often make the classic Basque pipérade, eggs scrambled with stewed peppers and tomatoes. This time, I kept it a little simpler and used my roasted peppers to fill an omelet. I added chopped, fresh herbs and a little bit of Parmesan to the mix. If your peppers are already roasted (I had plenty on hand as I’d been working with roasted peppers all week) this is a 2- to 5-minute dinner. As always, the better the eggs (farm-fresh, pastured), the better the omelet.

But for some, finding art that speaks to that experience may be anything but easy.

lead_paragraph: While the unofficial ladies’ uniform here at T consists mostly of comfortable flats and boyish silhouettes, the staff’s jewelry choices fall on the opposite end of the style spectrum: the pieces are pretty and dainty. And where stones are concerned, there are few options more ladylike than pearls. As charming as grandma’s hand-me-downs can be, modern fine jewelers such as Sophie Bille Brahe and Ana Khouri offer fresh takes on the classic jewelry box staple, as seen in T’s Culture 2014 issue. Here, T’s women’s fashion team rounds up similar designs with real pearls, at a price that won’t break the bank.

headline: Alfresco, a Passionate Loner Beckons
abstract: The Paul Taylor Dance Company presented three works as part of Lincoln Center Out of Doors on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Some choreography seems to shrink on an outdoor stage, dwarfed by open space. The opposite was true on Friday at the Damrosch Park Bandshell at Lincoln Center, where the Paul Taylor Dance Company presented three works as part of Lincoln Center Out of Doors. The open-air setting, depending on the piece, served either to free up Mr. Taylor’s movement or complement its inherent freedom; his work contains equal measures of tension and effervescence. In all three dances — “Fibers” (1961), “Aureole” (1962) and “Piazzolla Caldera” (1997) — the company looked ripe, expansive, ready for anything.

headline: Millet and Red Pepper Polenta
abstract: Leftovers of this savory polenta – if you have any – can be reheated in a pan, grilled or eaten cold. There are two ways to make this dish.
lead_paragraph: One thing I like best about this savory polenta is that if you do have leftovers, you can reheat them or grill them for quick meals, or even eat the leftovers cold. Take them to work or pack them in a lunchbox. I have made this dish two ways: In the first, shown here, roasted peppers are stirred into the millet halfway through. In the second version, peppers and onions are sautéed with garlic.

headline: Languid, Meandering and Clearly Abetted by Satan
abstract: The clarinetist Martin Frost performed at Lincoln Center twice on Monday, with the Emerson String Quartet and as part of A Little Night Music at the Kaplan Penthouse.
lead_paragraph: In earlier times, the talent of Martin Frost would have attracted suspicion. Like that of Paganini, whom contemporaries suspected to be in cahoots with the Devil: How else to explain his wizardry on the violin, which surpassed everyone else in technique and brilliance?

headline: Like a Jazz Band, but 18th Century
abstract: The Philharmonia Baroque Orchestra will perform two Handel operas at the Mostly Mozart Festival, one with an assist from the Mark Morris Dance Group.
lead_paragraph: The choreographer Mark Morris calls the Philharmonia Baroque Orchestra “the car that parks itself.” This week it pulls into Lincoln Center to perform two early Handel operas at the Mostly Mozart Festival: the English masque “Acis and Galatea,” fully choreographed with singers sharing the stage with dancers from the Mark Morris Dance Group, and a concert version of “Teseo,” a flamboyant castrato vehicle in which the composer merged elements of Italian and French Baroque style. At the steering wheel: Nicholas McGegan, the British conductor and Baroque music expert who has led this period-instrument ensemble for 29 years and, in the process, turned it into the pre-eminent early-music group on the West Coast.

headline: It’s an Itch That Can’t Be Clicked
abstract: “Web Junkie” is a documentary that observes China’s efforts to treat young people, mostly teenage boys, who have an Internet addiction.
lead_paragraph: In the course of procrastinating over a deadline — I mean conducting research for this review — I typed “Is Internet addiction real” into a Google window and received 29 million results and no conclusive answer. Some experts think the addiction model fits compulsive, time-sucking online behavior perfectly, while others are skeptical. After a while, I stopped reading to check for Twitter updates and take a quiz or two, but two hours later, I’m not ready to admit that I have a problem.

abstract: In “A Fuller Life,” staged readings recount the lengthy career of the director Samuel Fuller.
lead_paragraph: “It’s not me talking, it’s my character.” That’s how Samuel Fuller responded to critics — for example, J. Edgar Hoover — who objected to the sketches of American lowlifes, mad men, racists and cynical soldiers in his thrillingly alive films. A shaky labor of love, “A Fuller Life” repays this filmmaker’s empathy by letting him have his say from beyond the grave through excerpts from his autobiography.

headline: Utah Officials Ask Justices to Hear Appeal of Ruling on Gay Marriage Ban
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Marriages']
abstract: The appeal is the first of several in same-sex marriage cases likely to reach the Supreme Court in coming months.
lead_paragraph: Utah officials on Tuesday asked the Supreme Court to hear their appeal of a ruling striking down their state’s ban on same-sex marriage, which voters adopted in 2004. The appeal is the first of several in same-sex marriage cases likely to reach the Supreme Court in coming months, and the justices may agree to hear one or more of them this fall, with a decision by next June. The choice for the Supreme Court, the officials’ petition said, “comes down to this: thousands of couples are unconstitutionally being denied the right to marry, or millions of voters are being disenfranchised of their vote to define marriage.”

headline: Dear Guests
abstract: Some new and significant things were revealed in the Gaza war.
lead_paragraph: KIBBUTZ EIN HASHLOSHA, Israel — At 6:02 a.m. on Saturday, the air raid siren sounded over Tel Aviv. I was rousted by the hotel staff from my room and ushered into the windowless service elevator area with two French families, everyone in their pajamas. After 10 minutes, when the Hamas missile threat had passed, we were allowed to go back to our rooms. As I slipped back into bed, the hotel loudspeaker bellowed, “Dear guests, you may return to your routine.”

headline: A ‘Culture of Violence’ at Rikers Island
abstract: The Justice Department is rightly calling for reforms at the jail complex after an investigation found that teenagers faced excessive force over minor infractions.
lead_paragraph: A much-anticipated investigation by the Justice Department has uncovered what amounted to a chamber of horrors at Rikers Island, where teenagers were beaten and battered for minor infractions by correction officers who acted without fear of discovery or punishment by senior officials. The report, released on Monday by Preet Bharara, the United States attorney in Manhattan, documents “a deep-seated culture of violence” that demands immediate remedial action by New York City, which is now at risk of facing a federal lawsuit if it does not take the steps outlined in the report — which wisely calls for removing adolescents from the jail complex altogether.

headline: Vladimir Putin’s Chess-Master Nemesis
abstract: As he vies for the presidency of the governing body of world chess, Garry Kasparov can’t escape his fiercest opponent: the president of Russia.
lead_paragraph: Garry Kasparov, the former world chess champion, put his head down, hunched his shoulders and walked hurriedly down the carpeted corridor of the Sands Cotai Central, a labyrinthine new complex on reclaimed land in Macau. Downstairs were two of the world’s most lucrative casinos and retailers like Saint Laurent Paris and Fabio Caviglia. There were restaurants, spas and an array of theme-park attractions from DreamWorks, including a daily parade through the lobby with characters from “Shrek,” “Madagascar” and “Kung Fu Panda.” Here on the fourth floor, though, hundreds of boys and girls from across Asia had just wrapped up their matches in a chess tournament. Spilling into the corridor, many of them gaped at Kasparov barreling by, as if Shrek himself had wandered up to the wrong floor. That was why he was rushing, he explained, when I managed to catch up to him as he turned toward a bank of elevators. “If you stop,” he said, “you’ll be there for 30 minutes.” He did not sound angry, just matter of fact. “Everyone circles around. They want pictures.”

headline: Argentina: Man Located After 37 Years

abstract: The head of a human rights organization that searches for hundreds of babies stolen by Argentina’s military dictatorship decades ago has located her grandson after 37 years.
lead_paragraph: The head of a human rights organization that searches for hundreds of babies stolen by Argentina’s military dictatorship decades ago has located her grandson after 37 years. Estela de Carlotto, leader of Grandmothers of the Plaza de Mayo, told reporters in Buenos Aires on Tuesday that she had found the son of her daughter Laura Carlotto, who was kidnapped while pregnant in 1977. She was later murdered as part of the dictatorship’s “dirty war” against guerrillas and people associated with leftist ideology. Mrs. Carlotto’s missing grandson, Guido Carlotto, 36, was raised as Ignacio Hurban. He is married and a pianist and approached Mrs. Carlotto’s organization because he doubted his identity. DNA tests proved that he was Mrs. Carlotto’s grandson.

The report reveals “‘a deep-seated culture of violence’ that demands immediate remedial action by New York City.” Adolescents on Rikers “were in constant danger of physical harm even when they present no risk to the system or safety of the staff” and “force was routinely used not so much to keep order but for the express purpose of ‘inflicting injuries and pain.’” This scandalous behavior went on for so long because of “a departmental code of silence” that “aided and abetted this brutal regime and shielded its practitioners from discovery and official rebuke.” The report recommends the removal of all teenagers from Rikers and improvement in officer training.

headline: 1939: Strike at G.M.C. Ends

William S. Knudsen, president of General Motors, announced that production would be resumed as soon as possible in the company’s scores of plants, possibly tomorrow and certainly on Tuesday. ‘‘We want to get everybody back to work,’’ Mr. Knudsen said. ‘‘We want to forget all the names we have called each other.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Aug. 7, 1939

headline: A Nomadic Museum Takes Up Temporary Residence in Istanbul
abstract: Following projects in Dubai and London, the newly founded Moving Museum sets up shop in the ancient Turkish city with a series of artist residencies.
lead_paragraph: The Moving Museum is pretty much exactly what it sounds like: an artistic institution that is perpetually on the go. Founded by Aya Mousawi and Simon Sakhai, who live and work together, it launched in May 2013 with a show in Dubai devoted to the lost cuisine of Iraqi Jews, who thrived in that country prior to the 1940s. A show in London followed last fall that was devoted to the city’s contemporary art scene. As part of the museum’s continuing effort to “respond to a city through artistic practice,” in Sakhai’s words, the duo has now headed to Istanbul, both for its bubbling political energy and its geographic and cultural location on the boundary between east and west.

abstract: When trying to score savings at the eleventh hour, it pays to shop around.
lead_paragraph: If last-minute hotel booking apps make you think of impetuous travelers on a budget, think again. During recent searches I found a room at the Four Seasons Hotel Miami for about $157 (compared with $259 on the hotel’s website), a room at the Westin Resort & Spa, Cancún for $75 (as opposed to about $200), and, in Maine, a room at the White Barn Inn & Spa in Kennebunkport, for $300, down from $630. Which sites will check you into the lap of luxury? I spent days with new apps and old standbys to determine the best tactics for nabbing a high-end hotel room at a (somewhat) down-to-earth price.

headline: No Longer an Invisible Photographer

lead_paragraph: Among the images in Vanessa Winship’s first retrospective are portraits taken with a view camera, which led her to slow down and engage her subjects rather than be fleetingly invisible.

headline: Drafting a Fantasy Football Team, With Help From Advanced Statistics
abstract: By applying an algorithm to aggregated player ranking data, and identifying natural tiers within the data, this system can improve your draft strategy.
lead_paragraph: Last year, I developed a statistical model for fantasy football that determines how to rank and tier players for every position based on consensus expert rankings. The algorithm found natural tiers and clusters within the rankings data. To help visualize this, I created charts for each week of the season, which could be used to help you decide your starting fantasy lineup.

headline: Texas Bolsters Border Patrol With Its Own
abstract: The state has spent $500 million since 2005 to beef up its border security, drawing criticism from scores of detractors who say the threat posed by illegal immigrants and the extent of crime have been exaggerated.
lead_paragraph: MISSION, Tex. — Along the Rio Grande here, the suspected smugglers trying to slip into the United States have certainly noticed their adversaries on the water: burly commandos in black-and-white boats mounted with .30-caliber machine guns and bulletproof shields. The patches on the officers’ camouflage fatigues identify them not as federal Border Patrol agents but as another breed of law enforcement entirely.

headline: Introducing Odessa, a Folk Singer Who Fell Off Her Bike and Decided to Become a Star
abstract: The young singer abandoned a career as a backup violinist for bands like Edward Sharpe and the Magnetic Zeroes to venture out on her own.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, the singer and multi-instrumentalist who goes only by Odessa had a nearly fatal bike accident. Afterward, she promised herself she would follow her muse. So she left a stable career playing backing violin for established bands like Edward Sharpe and the Magnetic Zeroes to work on her own. The experience “inspired me to fully commit to only what I wanted to do,” she says. “After that it was like, ‘Okay. I have no choice. This is why I’m on earth.'”

lead_paragraph: I talked a little bit, in my last post, about the argument that anything President Obama might do unilaterally on immigration policy is, if not justified, at least explained by congressional gridlock and particularly by the extraordinary intransigence of the current G.O.P. But I want to say something more about this point, because it’s come up in various responses to my warnings against presidential caesarism — this one from Ezra Klein, for instance, and this one from Jonathan Bernstein. I think Bernstein does a good job of making the case that the president faces an unusual situation with House Republicans, given their incentives and dysfunctions:

headline: Woods Says He’s Healthy; the Crowds Certainly Are

lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — This year’s British Open champion, Rory McIlroy, was in the parking lot next to Valhalla Golf Club early Wednesday afternoon. So was the defending P.G.A. champion, Jason Dufner. Another P.G.A. champ, Keegan Bradley, was also in the lot, laughing at the scene as he took photos on his phone. Other top pros were there, too, like Hunter Mahan and Rickie Fowler.

abstract: Miguel Feliz of the Dominican Republic helped convict his boss in a crack cocaine ring and solve homicides, some of which he participated in; now he is pressing officials to help him get a visa.
lead_paragraph: In a cell at a New Jersey detention center, Miguel Feliz awaits what he fears will be his fate. If the government succeeds in deporting him to his homeland, the Dominican Republic, he believes he is as good as dead.

headline: The Horrors of War — Between Matchsticks
abstract: A 1983 animated short film chillingly shows the realities of war.
lead_paragraph: Today we are inundated with ubiquitous news of war — graphic images and death counts from Syria, Gaza and Ukraine — but Garry Bardin’s simple, almost childlike stop-animation film from 1983, “Conflict,” offers a much different, but exceptionally chilling, account of conflict.

headline: ‘Side Show’ Revival Sets Broadway Opening
abstract: The show will transfer from the Kennedy Center in Washington, where it drew strong reviews.
lead_paragraph: A new revival of the 1997 musical “Side Show,” about the real-life conjoined twins Daisy and Violet Hilton, will come to Broadway this fall, starting preview performances on Oct. 28 at the St. James Theater and opening on Nov. 17, the producers said on Wednesday.

headline: Pakistan Detains Indian Soldier Who Accidentally Crossed Border
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Boats and Boating']
abstract: The Indian solider, who was involved in a boating mishap, was forced to swim to the Pakistan bank of the Chenab River, where he was picked up by Pakistani forces.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Pakistani forces took custody of an Indian soldier who accidentally crossed the border into Pakistan in the region of Jammu on Wednesday, an incident that Indian officials said they hoped would be swiftly resolved.

headline: All-of-a-Kind Family
abstract: In her first novel, “The Misadventures of the Family Fletcher,” Dana Alison Levy updates the traditional family-story structure by introducing same-sex parents and multiracial children.
lead_paragraph: The Fletchers are an unusual family. You might consider them unusual because they are all male — the family consists of four adopted boys and two fathers — but what really makes them stand out is how inclusive, loving and fun they are. In her first novel, “The Misadventures of the Family Fletcher,” Dana Alison Levy conjures up an enlightening tale for middle-grade readers, taking the traditional family-story structure and bringing it up to date by introducing same-sex parents and multiracial children.

lead_paragraph: With the Panama Canal’s official centennial on Aug. 15 this year, a number of events have been planned to celebrate the feat of engineering that connected the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans in 1914.

headline: Expert Panel to Consult on Ebola
abstract: The World Health Organization also said it was convening a panel to evaluate the possibility of using experimental treatments to combat the outbreak.
lead_paragraph: Scrambling to catch up with the worst outbreak of the deadly Ebola virus, the World Health Organization announced Wednesday that it was considering the declaration of an international public health emergency and would convene a panel of experts in coming days to explore the use of experimental treatments for the incurable disease.

headline: Perfidy Afoot in a Doomed Parking Lot
abstract: “Othello” will be the final production of Shakespeare in the Parking Lot at a municipal parking lot on the Lower East Side.
lead_paragraph: There are so many things working against “Othello” at Shakespeare in the Parking Lot that it’s a minor miracle that the show comes together so well. Traffic noise, funky smells and a few fumbled lines plagued one recent performance. Even so, by the end, there was more than a little magic in the air.

headline: Freeway Series May Be Key on the Road to the Title
abstract: The Dodgers and the Angels are squaring off for Southern California bragging rights this week, but each team has its eyes on a bigger prize.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — As if to mark the moment, the setting sun had turned the hills and the palm trees in Chavez Ravine a golden hue as Mike Trout stepped into the batter’s box for the first time Tuesday night. He shrugged off the boos from the sellout crowd, wished the umpire Chris Segal and catcher A. J. Ellis good luck, and dug in against Clayton Kershaw.

headline: Emigrate? And Give Up the Odessa Apartment?
abstract: Yelena Akhtiorskaya writes of an immigrant family living in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, in her first novel, “Panic in a Suitcase.”
lead_paragraph: Yelena Akhtiorskaya’s brilliant and often funny first novel, “Panic in a Suitcase,” begins in 1993, with the Nasmertovs of Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, receiving a visit from their son, Pasha, the last family member still living in Ukraine. After a long bout of travel, he’s weary and reluctant to tag along on a walk to the ocean.

headline: In Fashion Ads, Plenty of Déjà Vu
abstract: Glossy magazines are full of ads with the same themes, even the same models. That’s what sells clothes.
lead_paragraph: For an industry that pays a lot of lip service to originality and unique points of view, fashion can seem surprisingly lemminglike at times.

headline: Walgreen May Be the Exception to the Logic of Inversions
abstract: A backlash against corporate emigration may have affected the drug store chain’s decision, but harder numbers probably mattered more, Kevin Allison of Reuters Breakingviews writes.
lead_paragraph: Walgreen has encountered a limit to the logic of inversions. The drugstore chain will keep flying the American flag even after agreeing to buy the rest of Swiss-based Alliance Boots for about $15 billion. A backlash against corporate emigration may have affected Walgreen’s decision, but harder numbers probably mattered more.

headline: Walking, Stopping: It’s So Sentimental
abstract: Jacob Jonas the Company presented “In a Room on Broad St.,” a dance for nine, at the Ailey Citigroup Theater, with a cast specializing in hip-hop, contemporary ballet and acrobatics.
lead_paragraph: Jacob Jonas the Company, born in Los Angeles, is a relatively new venture led by a skateboarder turned street performer. Mr. Jonas discovered dance at 13 at a performance by the Calypso Tumblers on the Venice Beach boardwalk; eventually, he became a member. Now, as the artistic director of his own group, he strives to create a supportive environment with a mission statement that highlights producing “emotionally charged work with the intention to encourage and not compete.”

headline: From Street Art to High Art
abstract: Caledonia Curry started her career as a street artist, but leapfrogged to museums and galleries. Now she has expanded her work to include installation and performance art, often with an activist bent.
lead_paragraph: Caledonia Curry started her career as a street artist, but leapfrogged to museums and galleries. Now she has expanded her work to include installation and performance art, often with an activist bent.

headline: A Holy Guy Keeps His Worldly, Common Touch
abstract: A holy man’s on the loose in “Black Jesus,” a new series on Adult Swim.
lead_paragraph: Aaron McGruder moves his satire of contemporary African-American life from comic strips and animation to live actors with “Black Jesus,” his new series for Adult Swim, beginning Thursday night. It’s a looser, baggier, less pointed show than “The Boondocks,” his sometimes-brilliant cartoon that has occasionally popped up on Adult Swim over the last nine years. And it has a comfortable, which is to say familiar, feel, recalling comedies from “Chappelle’s Show” all the way back to “Sanford and Son.”

headline: At a Waylon Jennings Sale: Hank’s Boots, Buddy’s Bike and Willie’s Hair

lead_paragraph: How much for a matched set of vintage Willie Nelson braids? The hammer will go down on this unusual example of pop memorabilia on Oct. 5 at the Musical Instrument Museum in Phoenix, when Guernsey’s auctions off about 2,000 items owned by the country singer Waylon Jennings, who died in 2002.

headline: Bank of America Offers U.S. Biggest Settlement in History Over Toxic Mortgage Loans
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mortgage-Backed Securities', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']

lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:58 p.m. | After months of lowball offers and heels dug in, it took only 24 hours for Bank of America to suddenly cave in to the government, agreeing to the largest single federal settlement in the history of corporate America.

headline: Life of Wonderment
abstract: The artist Swoon blurs the line between where her artworks end and her activism begins.
lead_paragraph: With a glowing paper cutout pinned over her heart, the artist known as Swoon led a procession through the Brooklyn Museum early one summer night to her installation “Submerged Motherlands,” a site-specific jumble that includes two cantilevered rafts, seemingly cobbled out of junk; a tree, of fabric and wire, that reaches to the rotunda; and nooks of stenciled portraits.

headline: Does Allonzo Trier Still Have Game?
abstract: In 2009, Michael Sokolove profiled Allonzo Treir, a young basketball player who comes from the same overheated world of ‘‘elite grassroots basketball’’ that Reeves Wiedeman wrote about in last weekend’s issue.
lead_paragraph: I’ve found that a downside of being a magazine writer is that I don’t get to do follow-up stories, as they’re called in the newspaper business. I generally write about a subject and then, professionally speaking, move on. But I do maintain a personal curiosity, and I have a long list of people I once wrote about whom I occasionally do a little research on to see what they’re up to.

headline: For Jade Lai, of Creatures of Comfort, a Relaxed Hong Kong Homecoming
abstract: The retailer and designer shares snapshots and travel suggestions from a recent vacation spent visiting family.
lead_paragraph: “Most people, when they talk about Hong Kong, they’re like, ‘Oh, the parties, the bars, the shopping,'” says Jade Lai (top row, center), the Hong Kong-raised owner of Creatures of Comfort — a boutique with locations in New York and Los Angeles — and the designer of its in-house clothing and accessories line. “That’s all nice, but for me it’s about spending time with family — hiking, going to the beach, food.”

headline: In Homage to Mozart, Musical Wit and Allusions
abstract: The Mostly Mozart Festival’s concert on Tuesday evening at Avery Fisher Hall included works by Alfred Schnittke, Haydn and Mozart.
lead_paragraph: Parody and chaos are integral elements of the works of the Russian composer Alfred Schnittke, whose musical humor, like the most sophisticated jokes, sometimes surfaces unexpectedly with a witty turn of phrase. His “Moz-Art à la Haydn,” a pastiche based on an unfinished fragment by Mozart called “Music to a Carnival Pantomime,” opened the Mostly Mozart Festival’s concert on Tuesday evening at Avery Fisher Hall.

headline: Exploring a Jazzman and Gender Identity
abstract: Nellie McKay, in her latest cabaret show, “A Girl Named Bill,” portrays Billy Tipton, a female musician who passed as a man for most of her life.
lead_paragraph: Come up into the attic, and let’s play dress-up. There are piles of old costumes, stacks of sheet music and vintage 78s, a phonograph and a battered upright piano: everything we need to put on a show.

headline: Outrage Builds in South Korea in Deadly Abuse of a Soldier
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Corporal Punishment', 'Asphyxiation, Choking, and Suffocation', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: Veterans said corporal punishment and widespread use of violence have been condoned for years as a way to enforce discipline among low-paid conscripts.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The soldiers beat the 20-year-old private almost every day for more than a month. They flogged him with a mop handle until it broke. They made him eat toothpaste and lick their spittle off the floor. At one point, when he became groggy, they hooked him up to an intravenous drip, gave him nutrients and then, when he seemed to regain energy, they kicked and punched him some more.

headline: Study Shows Third Gene as Indicator for Breast Cancer
abstract: Mutations in the PALB2 gene raise risk in women by almost as much as mutations in BRCA1 and BRCA2, the genes implicated in most inherited cases.
lead_paragraph: Mutations in a gene called PALB2 raise the risk of breast cancer in women by almost as much as mutations in BRCA1 and BRCA2, the infamous genes implicated in most inherited cases of the disease, a team of researchers reported Wednesday.

headline: Why Britain’s Cabinet Is ‘a Clique of Posh White Men,’ Again

headline: For Nondrivers, a Summer Stuck in the Passenger Seat
abstract: Summer throws the unlicensed to the mercy of friends and strangers, necessitates byzantine strategic planning and may compel memorization of entire Jitney schedules.
lead_paragraph: On any given Friday afternoon in the New York summer, offices clear out early, weekend bags are hoisted onto shoulders, and many of those city dwellers who are, in colder months, perfectly happy to live concrete-encircled lives — they who, like the poet and devoted New Yorker Frank O’Hara, “can’t even enjoy a blade of grass unless I know there’s a subway handy” — slide into cars and head out of town.

headline: Let’s Talk About Risk at the Metropolitan Opera

lead_paragraph: On the opening night of the Metropolitan Opera’s revelatory new production of Borodin’s “Prince Igor” in February, you might have expected some of the backstage bitterness over the labor talks then looming to seep into the performance.

headline: Scotland’s Debate: Stay Big or Go Small

lead_paragraph: On Sept. 18, Scotland is scheduled to vote on seceding from Britain. We take a look at the issues at stake for the Scottish people.

headline: Proof That Voter Impersonation Almost Never Happens
abstract: There have been more than 1 billion votes cast in elections over the last 14 years. And just 31 cases of impersonation fraud.
lead_paragraph: An enduring Republican fantasy is that there are armies of fraudulent voters lurking in the baseboards of American life, waiting for the opportunity to crash the polls and undermine the electoral system. It’s never really been clear who these voters are or how their schemes work; perhaps they are illegal immigrants casting votes for amnesty, or poor people seeking handouts.  Most Republican politicians know these criminals don’t actually exist, but they have found it useful to take advantage of the party base’s pervasive fear of outsiders, just as when they shot down immigration reform. In this case, they persuaded the base of the need for voter ID laws to ensure “ballot integrity,” knowing the real effect would be to reduce Democratic turnout.

headline: Armed Animals Don’t Invent Themselves

lead_paragraph: Like millions of moviegoers over the weekend, Bill Mantlo watched “Guardians of the Galaxy,” the Marvel Studios space adventure that sold more than $172 million in tickets worldwide in its first four days of release.

headline: Jewish Film Festival Is Withdrawn From London Theater
abstract: The UK Jewish Film Festival withdrew after the Tricycle Theater in London objected to the festival’s partial financing by the Israeli government.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Tricycle Theater, which has hosted the UK Jewish Film Festival for the last eight years, says that in light of the conflict in Gaza it will not hold this year’s event in November if financing for the festival continues to be partly provided by the Israeli government.

lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — Searching for ways to hit back at Western sanctions without causing Russian consumers too much pain, President Vladimir V. Putin gave his government a broad mandate Wednesday to issue one-year bans on food and agricultural imports. But he included a proviso that the bans be lifted if they drive up prices or cause undue dependence on a single source.

headline: Powering Up a Phone, No Cords Needed

headline: Taking Chances With Mix and Match
abstract: The Vail International Dance Festival event “Now: Premieres” presented seven new works, including Matthew Neenan’s “Increasing.”
lead_paragraph: VAIL, Colo. — The choreographer Matthew Neenan seems to be one of the strange originals of American ballet. To judge from the works of his I’ve seen, he’s not remotely preoccupied by ballet’s virtuosity, hierarchy or orthodoxy. His taste in music includes pop, commissioned scores and classical music of the last two centuries. He makes dancers look vulnerable, openhearted and, above all, marvelously free. And he uses music to release different social and psychological layers in them. In consequence, his stage worlds, at their best, begin to have the complex reality of novels or plays.

headline: Damn the Torpedoes!
abstract: The story behind Adm. David Farragut’s dauntless assault on Mobile Bay.
lead_paragraph: Aug 5, 1864, 3 a.m. On a sultry night, 18 ships of the Union navy rest uneasily at anchor off the bar of Mobile Bay, Ala. Led by four ironclads, and strengthened by 14 experienced wooden warships, the Union flotilla is part of the West Gulf Blockading Squadron, commanded by Rear Adm. David G. Farragut. The admiral was the United States’s most experienced, and celebrated, flag officer. He had spent 51 years in the Navy: After service as a youth in the War of 1812, and fighting pirates in the West Indies, Farragut established his Civil War reputation by capturing New Orleans after a daring dash up the Mississippi.

headline: Reviving a Dyeing Technique
abstract: Aboubakar Fofana, a designer known for his traditional indigo-dyeing techniques, talks about the challenges of being organic in a synthetic world.
lead_paragraph: The simplest way to make indigo yarn and fabrics is to soak fibers in chemical dye. But Aboubakar Fofana, 46, a Malian-born artist and designer, recoils at the thought of a technique that is so undemanding. Indigo leaves for his dyeing vats have been ground with mortar and pestle, and the helpful bacteria that form there are fed often and sometimes given the chance to rest. The result is a shimmering blue that holds up even when left in the sun.

headline: A Right Like Any Other

Or to put it another way, there are constitutional rights and then there is abortion — a right, increasingly, in name only, treated as something separate and apart, vulnerable in its isolation from the mainstream of those rights the Constitution actually protects.

headline: Lebanon: Border Standoff Eases
abstract: The clashes between the Lebanese Army and Sunni extremist fighters from the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, who occupied a Lebanese border town last weekend, showed some signs of easing on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The clashes between the Lebanese Army and Sunni extremist fighters from the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, who occupied a Lebanese border town last weekend, showed some signs of easing on Wednesday, as a cease-fire that had collapsed the day before was revived for 24 hours and the militant group, known as ISIS, released three of at least 13 hostages its fighters had seized. At least some of the fighters were reported to have withdrawn from the town, Arsal, and emergency aid workers were able to reach civilians trapped by five days of fighting. But sporadic shelling interrupted the cease-fire throughout the day as Lebanese troops tightened a cordon around the town. In a new sign of Arab concern about Lebanon’s stability, the army received $1 billion in assistance on Wednesday from Saudi Arabia, which has supported the insurgency against the Syrian government but has joined other nations in condemning ISIS as a destabilizing terrorist group.

headline: The Guns of August
abstract: A century later, the lessons from the carnage of World War I should be to reflect on the forces that led Europe sleepwalking to self-destruction.
lead_paragraph: The centenary of the epic carnage we know as World War I has generated a tide of analyses, commentaries, exhibitions and ceremonies. Many people have been drawn to visit the battlefields, memorials and cemeteries of Europe, trying to comprehend how civilized nations could have been reduced to a slaughter in which as many as 20 million soldiers and civilians suffered horrifying deaths. When confronted with so cataclysmic an event, it is difficult not to seek a moral, a lesson that can guide us away from a repetition of such horrors.

Though layering up may feel far-off, this is the optimal moment — before the September shopping rush — to start building a cool-weather wardrobe. And the current retail landscape includes some especially well-executed takes on the essentials, such as vintage Levi’s jeans, cool sneakers, a perfect ribbed turtleneck and a versatile miniature black doctor’s bag. While some of these pieces’ price tags are formidable, consider them an investment in your style’s future. Get your hands on them now, before someone else does.

Both sides are claiming victory — “Israel for wiping out 32 underground tunnels” and “Hamas for still being alive” — but the result is a more entrenched status quo: “Neither side has achieved its main goal of destroying the other.” The possibility of a peace plan appears ever more remote: “There seems to be little room left in Israeli politics for those who would end the occupation of the West Bank and Gaza and create an independent Palestinian state.” The editorial adds, “it is so important that indirect talks between Israelis and Palestinians this week, mediated by Egypt, lay the ground for something bigger and more durable than one cease-fire.”

headline: An Insider’s Perspective on Corinne Day’s Posthumously Published Book of Photographs

lead_paragraph: Throughout her career, and especially during the 1990s, the photographer Corinne Day often escaped the fashion scene in which she had forged her reputation with a controversial Kate Moss shoot and other projects for glossies like Vogue. Instead, she documented her friends: models, stylists and musicians caught in a drug- and sex-addled haze. Day, a relentless diarist who died in 2010 at age 48, was unapologetic in her gaze. A portion of her ’90s-era snapshots appeared in “Diary” (2000), a stark, dark book that helped cement her position in the mainstream fashion industry as a grunge-era pioneer. Now, more than 150 additional images have been carefully documented in “May the Circle Remain Unbroken,” a photo book from the British publisher Mörel (the first since Day’s death in 2010).

headline: 1889: Hereditary Imagination
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Victor Hugo’s grandson was caught embellishing a shipwreck story in 1889.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The story of Victor Hugo’s grandson’s escape from shipwreck going round the Paris press was made out by the young gentleman to be rather more dramatic than it was in reality. M. George Hugo was a guest on board the 80-ton yawl Gilda, which left Havre last Monday to make a run to Trouville. The tide carried the yacht on to the Banc du Ratier. At low water the Gilda was left high and dry, but floated again on the return tide. In the meantime she had sprung a leak; she managed, however, with the help of a tug and under trysail, to return to harbor, when she sank in shallow water. Later she was floated into dry dock. M. George Hugo imagined it was necessary to wire to his friends that the Gilda had sunk and no lives lost. — The New York Herald, European Edition, August 8, 1889
