abstract: Arcade Fire, Buckethead, the Residents and some of the real-life musicians who, like the title character in “Frank,” have hidden their identities.
lead_paragraph: Who was that masked band? Other artists who have preferred to keep their faces covered:

headline: Self-Invention in a Papier-Mâché Head
abstract: The film “Frank” is primarily inspired by Frank Sidebottom (real name: Chris Sievey), who performed in an oversize costume head.
lead_paragraph: We have grown used to verisimilitude in our musician biopics. “The Buddy Holly Story,” “Walk the Line” and “Ray,” and even those that seem a little campy today, like Oliver Stone’s “The Doors,” follow the rules: The wigs can’t be too terrible, and the facts need to be intact. The recent James Brown biopic, “Get On Up,” is similarly straightforward. Even “24 Hour Party People” playfully broke the fourth wall but treated the life and death of its most famous figure, Ian Curtis, faithfully. But what if the musician at the heart of the story was a man who wore a giant puppet head in public?

headline: No Comment Necessary: Blaming the Ebola Victim
abstract: Ann Coulter has no sympathy for Kent Brantley, the American doctor who contracted Ebola in Liberia.
lead_paragraph: Ann Coulter, the conservative firebrand, expressed little sympathy for the American doctor, Kent Brantley, who contracted Ebola in Liberia and was transported back to the United States on Saturday for treatment.

headline: Snowden’s Lawyer on Residence Status
abstract: Anatoly G. Kucherena, the lawyer for the former American intelligence contractor Edward Snowden, said Russia has granted his client a three-year residence permit.
lead_paragraph: Anatoly G. Kucherena, the lawyer for the former American intelligence contractor Edward Snowden, said Russia has granted his client a three-year residence permit.

headline: Publisher of American Banker Is Sold to an Investment Firm
abstract: SourceMedia, the publisher of financial trade publications like American Banker and The Bond Buyer, has been sold to the investment firm Observer Capital.
lead_paragraph: The owner of SourceMedia, the publisher of financial trade publications like American Banker and The Bond Buyer, said that it had sold the media company to Observer Capital, an investment firm.

headline: Introducing Frank Bruni and Ross Douthat as the Moviegoers
keywords: ['ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Children and Childhood', 'Income Inequality', 'Monkeys and Apes', 'Movies', 'Priests', 'Seasons and Months', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Stars and Galaxies', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Welcome to the first installment of the Moviegoers, an occasional series on movies and culture. Today Frank and Ross jump from blockbuster pictures like “Dawn of the Planet of the Apes” and “Guardians of the Galaxy” to arthouse fare like “Ida” and “Calvary.” And one columnist begs: no women superheroes, please.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Moviegoers, an occasional new series in which the Op-Ed columnists Frank Bruni and Ross Douthat banter about movies, pop culture, television and other real-world distractions. From 1993-95, Frank was a movie critic for The Detroit Free Press, and he has written frequently on culture for The New York Times Magazine and for the Arts & Leisure section. Ross is the film critic for National Review and frequently writes about film and TV on his Times blog.

headline: Books for the Road
abstract: Patti Smith talks about her history of reading Haruki Murakami, and shares what she’s been reading on tour.
lead_paragraph: Patti Smith, who reviews Haruki Murakami’s “Colorless Tsukuru Tazaki and His Years of Pilgrimage” this week, first discovered the Japanese author’s work while browsing in the East Village. “Attracted by the title, I picked up ‘A Wild Sheep Chase’ about five years ago in St. Mark’s Bookshop,” Smith said in a recent email interview. She quickly read that novel and “Dance Dance Dance,” and was hooked. “I love how he weaves the interdimensional and the mundane and the offhanded way certain characters negotiate these shifts,” Smith said. “I love that there are sequels and reoccurring characters. Like Roberto Bolaño, he offers an ever-expanding, interconnected universe.”

headline: Wedding Q. & A.
abstract: What to do when a friend tells you are not invited to the ceremony, and how to word invitations when the wedding has multiple hosts.
lead_paragraph: A Less Hurtful Exclusion

headline: After a War, Life on the Mississippi
abstract: A Marine veteran took a canoe on the Mississippi in an effort to deal with post-traumatic stress disorder.
lead_paragraph: A Marine veteran took a canoe on the Mississippi in an effort to deal with post-traumatic stress disorder.

headline: Some Flexibility If Hawaiian Hurricanes Affect Travel Plans
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: With hurricanes expected to hit Hawaii this week, several airlines and hotels will waive change fees for customers holding reservations.
lead_paragraph: With two hurricanes expected to hit the Hawaiian islands beginning Thursday night, several airlines and some hotel chains have offered to waive change fees for customers with reservations for travel in the next few days.

headline: Obama Allows Limited Airstrikes on ISIS
keywords: ['Humanitarian Aid', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Kurds']
abstract: President Obama announced that he had authorized targeted American airstrikes against militants in Iraq, scrambling to avert the fall of the Kurdish capital. He also said that U.S. aircraft has dropped aid for tens of thousands of Iraqis trapped on a mountain range.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Thursday announced he had authorized limited airstrikes against Islamic militants in Iraq, scrambling to avert the fall of the Kurdish capital, Erbil, and returning the United States to a significant battlefield role in Iraq for the first time since the last American soldier left the country at the end of 2011.

headline: Ocean Liners Set Records, 6 Years Into the Jet Age
abstract: International travel by sea and air both reached new highs in the same week in 1964. That would not continue.
lead_paragraph: The Times has converted all of its 1964 issues into a digitized, searchable format. Each week, The Upshot will unearth an item from 50 years ago and put it in the light of today. “9,270 Will Sail for Europe Tomorrow on 10 Ships” appeared on Aug. 7 and can be seen in its original format on TimesMachine.

headline: Recalling the Crash, the Icelandic Way
abstract: “Revolution in the Elbow of Ragnar Agnarsson Furniture Painter” is an allegorical tale about economic crisis that’s set in, well, an elbow.
lead_paragraph: The global financial crisis of 2008 spread its pain far and wide, but it delivered a particularly stinging wallop to the tiny island country of Iceland, where a speculative banking bubble in the 2000s lent its people an unsustainable prosperity before bursting with gale-force shock. You can read the financial pages to chart the country’s recovery since, or you can head to the Minetta Lane Theater in Greenwich Village, where a troupe of Icelanders has been hunkered down since mid-June, making an odd new rock musical with an American cast and a British choreographer.

headline: Bloomberg Lays Off 25 and Cancels a TV Show
abstract: The layoffs, affecting about 25 people, come as the media company adds topic-based websites and TV shows.
lead_paragraph: Bloomberg Media canceled its Washington-based talk show “Political Capital With Al Hunt” and laid off about 25 employees, mostly in its television operations, as part of a broader effort to restructure the company and its news offerings, according to two staff members with knowledge of the moves.

headline: If We Link Boys With Bedlam, What Does That Say to Our Girls?
abstract: Our hosts this summer, all parents of girls, shook their heads ruefully as my sons romped. If I hear disapproval of my sons’ behavior in their comments, surely their daughters hear approval of more placid ways.
lead_paragraph: We are in London when my 6-year-old starts to climb the walls. Yes, he and his 3-year-old brother have been cooped up in trains a lot in the last 10 days — from Paris to Brussels to the North Sea to London — but there’s also something about the Victorian molding in my friend’s terraced home that looks enough like the parkour course at his school to encourage him to make the attempt.

headline: Hawaii Prepares for First Hurricane in 22 Years
abstract: Hawaii is poised to take its first direct hit from a hurricane since 1992, as two tropical cyclones barrel through the Pacific toward the state.
lead_paragraph: HONOLULU — Hawaii is no stranger to natural disasters. The state has endured tsunamis. Lava flows almost constantly from its volcanoes. An earthquake shook the Big Island on Thursday morning.

headline: Both Sides in Gay Marriage Fight in Utah Agree: Supreme Court Should Hear Case
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: In an unusual move, same-sex marriage advocates fresh off a legal victory in Utah are supporting efforts to ask the Supreme Court to weigh in.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Lawyers for three couples challenging Utah’s ban on same-sex marriage said Thursday that they would join with their opponents to urge the Supreme Court to hear their case, even though they recently won an appeals court ruling striking down the law.

headline: Gray Tassels Along the Fringe
abstract: The chance to put on a show cheaply in New York makes FringeNYC, known for its young artists and audiences, a lure for veteran performers, too.
lead_paragraph: FOR the past couple of summers, Joan Shepard has packed up her cabaret show and headed for Scotland to perform at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe. This summer, she’s working much closer to her East Village home.

headline: County of 95 Sees Opportunity in Toxic Waste
abstract: Officials in Loving County, Tex., population 95, hope the federal government — with $28 billion to spend on the disposal of high-level radioactive waste — will consider it as a storage site.
lead_paragraph: MENTONE, Tex. — Loving County is big, dry and stretches for miles, and is the perfect place, local officials say, to store high-level radioactive waste.

headline: We Welcome Nuclear Waste
abstract: Some people in Loving County, Tex., the second-least-populous county in the United States, think that storing the entire country’s nuclear waste would be a good thing for their community.
lead_paragraph: Some people in Loving County, Tex., the second-least-populous county in the United States, think that storing the entire country’s nuclear waste would be a good thing for their community.

headline: Celebrity Magazine Sales Plummet on Newsstands
abstract: Data released by the Alliance for Audited Media showed celebrity magazines like InStyle suffered mightily on the newsstand in the first half of 2014.
lead_paragraph: Celebrity magazines used to be the impulse purchase at the airport or the supermarket checkout line. But those impulses are apparently being resisted.

headline: Museum Under Fire for Selling Its Art
abstract: Censured for having auctioned off a painting to pay its bills, the Delaware Art Museum nonetheless plans to sell even more works.
lead_paragraph: WILMINGTON, Del. — If the Delaware Art Museum has a signature painting, surely it is Howard Pyle’s “Marooned.” A native of this city, Pyle is justly remembered as the father of American illustration. His “Marooned” (1909) is an image of genuine drama and distress. It shows a pirate near death, curled up on a sand bar, a tiny figure enveloped by a burning yellow sky.

headline: Take the Job Seriously, but Not Yourself
keywords: ['Executives and Management (Theory)', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Careers and Professions', 'Entrepreneurship']
abstract: Logan LaHive, the chief of Belly, a customer rewards business, says he “can’t stand walking into a company that has seven values on the wall that no one actually cares about or can remember.”
lead_paragraph: This interview with Logan LaHive, chief executive of Belly, a customer rewards company, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Berghain, Berlin’s Legendary Nightclub, Celebrates Its 10th Anniversary With an Art Show
abstract: Starting tonight, the iconic techno-fueled party venue is exhibiting works by a number of artists, many of whom are current or former staffers, in a massive space behind the dance floor.
lead_paragraph: With its 10th anniversary approaching in December, the Berghain — Berlin’s most famous electronic music institution — is kicking things off tonight with a fine art prelude to a series of upcoming house- and techno-fueled celebrations. Titled simply “10,” the show takes place at the Halle, a vast section of the converted neoclassical power plant just beyond the dance floor that is open only on special occasions. Each work in “10” interprets the trinity of music, clubbing and debauchery in relation to Berghain’s potent architecture.

headline: 1939: Albanian Royals at Versailles
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: The Albanian royal family in exile took up residence in Versailles in 1939.
lead_paragraph: King Zog, exiled monarch of Albania, now an Italian principality, and Queen Geraldine were expected to take up residence in Versailles today, coming from Antwerp, where they arrived yesterday from Oslo aboard the steamer Brabant. With them were the infant Prince Alexander, Princesses Myzein, Ruheje and Maxhide, sisters of King Zog, and a royal entourage of a score who will take up residence with the King and Queen. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 8, 1939

headline: N.C.A.A. Votes to Give Richest Conferences More Autonomy
abstract: The Division I board of directors approved the first step toward an informal aristocracy that will give five powerful conferences the ability to make their own rules on some athletic issues.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — The first step toward an aristocracy in college sports was codified Thursday, when the five richest conferences and their 65 universities were awarded the right by the Division I board of directors to make their own rules on several issues affecting athletes and competition.

headline: Combining Culture and Exercise: The First Elastic City Walks Festival
abstract: The Elastic City Walks Festival will have artists lead walks that aspire to be art works.
lead_paragraph: Music and dance festivals are so last month. Next month New York will have what organizers are calling a “participatory walks” festival. Elastic City an organization that since 2010 has engaged artists in various disciplines to lead walks that are less about sightseeing than about finding fresh ways to think about a city’s history, architecture and traditions, is presenting its first Elastic City Walks Festival, from Sept. 26 to Oct. 7.

headline: Robert H. Ellsworth Is Dead at 85 After a Life Devoted to Chinese Art
abstract: Mr. Ellsworth, a prominent dealer, helped shape the holdings of prominent collectors and museums.
lead_paragraph: Robert H. Ellsworth, a prominent dealer of modern Chinese painting, Ming dynasty furniture, archaic jade and other examples of Asian art who helped amplify many of the major Asian collections in the United States, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 85.

headline: The Pain and Pleasure of Falling in Love
abstract: Local beers and deli specialties are found in and near the Bronx Beer Hall in the heart of the borough’s storied Italian-American neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: The chicken wing was juicy and laced with an invisible layer of tempestuous spices, and the moment I bit into it, I turned into Nicolas Cage in “Moonstruck.” Words welled up inside. I needed to tell that chicken wing how I felt: “I’m in love with you.” At that instant, the spices reared back and smacked me across the lips. Delicious agony began to spread to the rest of my mouth. Sips of cold beer did nothing to diminish the impact. Hours later, I could still feel the sting.

headline: Wine Dealer Sentenced to 10 Years for Defrauding Clients
abstract: Rudy Kurniawan sold wealthy clients bottles of purportedly rare and sought-after wines that were actually old bottles of blended wine.
lead_paragraph: A well-known wine dealer was sentenced on Thursday to 10 years in prison for defrauding wealthy clients out of millions of dollars by selling bottles of purportedly rare wines that were actually old bottles of wine mixed together.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘The One I Love’
abstract: The director Charlie McDowell narrates a sequence from “The One I Love,” featuring Elisabeth Moss and Mark Duplass.
lead_paragraph: The director Charlie McDowell narrates a sequence from “The One I Love,” featuring Elisabeth Moss and Mark Duplass.

headline: Charlie McDowell Narrates a Scene From ‘The One I Love’
abstract: The writer and director discusses his film featuring Mark Duplass and Elisabeth Moss
lead_paragraph: Things aren’t quite as they seem with a couple in “The One I Love,” Charlie McDowell’s romantic comedy with a twist. In this video, the writer and director discusses a scene between the film’s two main characters, Ethan (Mark Duplass) and Sophie (Elisabeth Moss). “The One I Love” is currently available on demand and opens in theaters August 22.

headline: Wheelies: The Million Franc Delahaye Edition
abstract: A 1930s Delahaye racecar is headed back to the track in Monterey, Calif.; police in a Chinese town devise singular way to deter abuse of brights.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: China Moves to Rein In Messaging for Mobile
abstract: New rules, widely believed to be aimed at WeChat, are intended to curb the sharing of unauthorized political news and information.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The Chinese authorities imposed new restrictions on the country’s most popular mobile instant messaging services on Thursday, including rules meant to curb the sharing of unauthorized political news and information.

headline: 2 New Interns at City Hall: Teenagers Named de Blasio
abstract: Chiara de Blasio is in the Office to Combat Domestic Violence this summer, and her brother, Dante, is working in the first deputy mayor’s office, their mother, Chirlane McCray, announced.
lead_paragraph: New York’s first daughter and son — Chiara and Dante de Blasio — are spending the rest of the summer at City Hall as unpaid interns.

headline: IBM Develops a New Chip That Functions Like a Brain
abstract: The processor, named TrueNorth, may eventually excel at calculations that stump today’s supercomputers.
lead_paragraph: Inspired by the architecture of the brain, scientists have developed a new kind of computer chip that uses no more power than a hearing aid and may eventually excel at calculations that stump today’s supercomputers.

headline: Yes, Alaska Is Hard to Poll. So Is Everywhere Else.
abstract: Despite its reputation, Alaska is ahead of New York, Maine, Maryland and Georgia when polling errors are averaged in Senate races since 1992.
lead_paragraph: Alaska is notorious for being difficult to poll. It’s a common refrain, common enough that you could be forgiven for not stopping to wonder why.

headline: Domestic Surveillance Has a Fan
abstract: Judge John D. Bates has sent a third letter to Congress denouncing its attempts to reform the domestic surveillance law.
lead_paragraph: Judge John D. Bates, who has appointed himself as a spokesman for the entire judiciary from his sinecure as secretary of the Judicial Conference, has sent a third letter to Congress denouncing its attempts to reform the domestic surveillance law.

headline: Screen Voices, Banished but Not Silenced
abstract: Two film series honor writers punished for their politics.
lead_paragraph: The close-up, the big screen, the eternal klieg light of unending media coverage: Motion pictures, especially those made in Hollywood, are a technology of magnification. How else to explain that the tale of the 300 or so movie studio employees whose political associations cost them their jobs has come to dramatize the repressive hysteria of the McCarthy era?

headline: Recording the Not-So-Dolce Vita
abstract: “Love in the City” (1953) brings together five shorts from Italian directors, including Fellini and Antonioni, all working to varying degrees in the neorealist idiom.
lead_paragraph: The prolific screenwriter and sometime filmmaker Cesare Zavattini (1902-89) was the chief theoretician of Italian neorealism. Zavattini, who once proposed a two-hour feature dramatizing the purchase of a pair of shoes, was also a pioneer of documentary fiction (sometimes called “hybrid cinema”), in which nonactors essentially play themselves, dramatizing their particular situations.

headline: Russia and E.U. on Food Sanctions
keywords: ['Embargoes and Sanctions', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Food', 'Poultry']
abstract: Dmitri A. Medvedev, the Russian prime minister, and Frédéric Vincent, a spokesman for the European Commission, discussed Russia’s ban on food imports from the United States and other countries.
lead_paragraph: Dmitri A. Medvedev, the Russian prime minister, and Frédéric Vincent, a spokesman for the European Commission, discussed Russia’s ban on food imports from the United States and other countries.

headline: How New N.C.A.A. Rules Will Work
abstract: Questions and answers about the loosened set of rules the N.C.A.A. approved to placate its five biggest conferences.
lead_paragraph: To the typical fan, college sports will look much the same. The football field will still be 100 yards and a 3-pointer will still be worth, well, 3 points.

headline: “Keep It Healthy” by Warpaint
abstract: A single from the all-girl band.
lead_paragraph: A single from the all-girl band.

headline: ‘Fun Home’ Will Reach Broadway Just Before Tonys Deadline
abstract: The musical “Fun Home,” which had an acclaimed run last fall at the Public Theater, will move to Broadway this spring.
lead_paragraph: The new musical “Fun Home,” which had a critically acclaimed run last fall at the Public Theater, will move to Broadway this spring, the producers announced on Thursday. The show, about a young woman awakening to her sexuality and to her father’s secrets, is scheduled to begin preview performances on April 4 at Circle in the Square Theater and hold its opening night on April 22. The deadline for potential Tony Award nominees is typically at the end of April.

headline: Owner of Lingerie Chain Agent Provocateur Said to Hire Goldman to Run a Sale
keywords: ['Lingerie and Underwear', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity']
abstract: The British private equity firm 3i has hired Goldman Sachs to run a potential sale of the luxury lingerie chain, a person briefed on the matter said on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Over two decades, Agent Provocateur has become one of the best-known purveyors of high-end lingerie, thanks in part to notoriously risqué advertising. Now the retailer may sell something even pricier: itself.

headline: Phong Bui Curates ‘Bloodflames Revisited’
abstract: An incendiary show of works by more than two dozen artists is inspired by a futuristic 1947 exhibition.
lead_paragraph: ‘BLOODFLAMES REVISITED’

headline: Two Girls Fuel Their Teams’ Push Toward Little League’s Pinnacle
abstract: Kayla Roncin, 12, of Toms River, N.J., and Mo’ne Davis, 13, of Philadelphia, played together in regional events that award berths to the Little League World Series.
lead_paragraph: BRISTOL, Conn. — As the only girl in New Jersey Little League all-star baseball, Kayla Roncin is used to attention.

headline: When the President Does It, That Means …
keywords: ['Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The bureaucratic sophistry behind the president’s immigration gambit.
lead_paragraph: I’m grateful to Greg Sargent for conducting this probing interview with John Sandweg, who served as a Department of Homeland Security counsel during the crafting of the Obama administration’s 2012 deferred action program for illegal immigrants who arrived in the United States as minors. Here is Sandweg explaining the legal justification for that program, and (by extension) for the course the White House is currently considering, which could extend the same provisional legalization to up to half the illegal-alien population:

headline: Westwood, Despite Troubles, Shares Lead
abstract: Lee Westwood was atop the P.G.A. Championship leader board after the first round, tied with the Americans Ryan Palmer and Kevin Chappell.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Lee Westwood was having an unlucky day at the 96th P.G.A. Championship. Three times Thursday, his golf ball rolled into a fairway divot or the pitch mark of another player’s ball, a rare trifecta of star-crossed doom given the green, unblemished expanse of Valhalla Golf Club.

headline: New Scenic Routes in the Outer Banks
abstract: New driving trails and a kayak network along the Outer Banks National Scenic Byway in North Carolina take travelers to heritage sites and through coastal creeks.
lead_paragraph: Four new driving trails link cultural and natural heritage sites along the Outer Banks National Scenic Byway in North Carolina, and a new kayak network weaves through miles of pristine coastal creeks and sounds.

headline: Long Days in the Fields, Without Earning Overtime
keywords: ['Migrant Labor (Agriculture)', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Working Hours', 'Overtime']
abstract: Legislators in Albany have tried for years to change the law to protect the wages of the state’s thousands of farmworkers; advocates see an opening for change after the November election.
lead_paragraph: RED HOOK, N.Y. — In the early stage of the harvest season, Antonio, a farmworker in his 50s, picked peas from daybreak until sundown, 14 hours a day, six days a week, with an hour off each day for lunch.

headline: Marni Kotak: ‘Mad Meds’
abstract: Ms. Kotak, dealing with medications she was prescribed to cope with postpartum depression, turns her pharmaceutical withdrawal into a gallery show.
lead_paragraph: MARNI KOTAK

headline: Build an Open Source Community Platform With New York Times, Washington Post and Mozilla
abstract: The search for the 2015 Knight-Mozilla Fellows is now open, and staffers from The New York Times, Mozilla OpenNews and The Washington Post are seeking two fellows to join their community platform collaboration.
lead_paragraph: Each year, Knight-Mozilla OpenNews selects developers, technologists, civic hackers and data crunchers to spend 10 months working as fellows embedded in their partner newsrooms. Fellowships are paid positions, and emphasize open source development that strengthens specific newsrooms and the larger journalism-code community.

headline: Detroit-Area Man Convicted of Murdering Teenager on His Porch
abstract: Theodore P. Wafer, 55, was found guilty of shooting Renisha McBride, 19, who banged on his front door in the middle of the night in Dearborn Heights, Mich.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — No one disputed that in the early morning hours of Nov. 2, Renisha McBride, 19, stood on the front porch of a bungalow in suburban Dearborn Heights, Mich. She pounded at the door with her hands, moving to the side of the house and back to the front. Minutes later, the homeowner, a 55-year-old airport maintenance worker named Theodore P. Wafer who had been roused from his sleep, opened the inside front door, fired a single shotgun blast and killed her.

headline: A Hip Way to Take Street Photos
abstract: A plastic auto-focus camera freed Ken Heyman to shoot New York City streets from odd angles, often going unnoticed by his subjects.
lead_paragraph: A plastic auto-focus camera freed Ken Heyman to shoot New York City streets from odd angles, often going unnoticed by his subjects.

headline: Paper Robot That Puts Itself Together
abstract: Using flat materials and a design inspired by origami, the art of paper folding, researchers have created a robot that can assemble without human intervention.
lead_paragraph: Using flat materials and a design inspired by origami, the art of paper folding, researchers have created a robot that can assemble without human intervention.

headline: 2 Officials at Queens Tutoring Center Charged With Assaulting Children
abstract: Students from South Korea were hit and denied food and bathroom breaks at Crown Academy, the district attorney's office said.
lead_paragraph: The children, here from South Korea without their parents, were hit, made to hold piles of books above their heads and denied food and bathroom visits.

headline: Origami Inspires Rise of Self-Folding Robot
abstract: A creation made of composite paper can fold and assemble itself and start working without intervention. Such robots could be deployed cheaply and quickly.
lead_paragraph: An intricately cut sheet lies flat and motionless on a table. Then Samuel Felton, a graduate student at Harvard, connects the batteries, sending electricity coursing through, heating it. The sheet lurches to life, the pieces bending and folding into place. The transformation completes in four minutes, and the sheet, now a four-limbed robot, scurries away at more than two inches a second.

headline: Tiny Furniture: A Diaspora of Dollhouses
abstract: Dollhouses and dollhouse furniture from major personal and museum collections are appearing on the market and going all over the world.
lead_paragraph: Major collections of dollhouses and dollhouse furniture are appearing on the market, providing ample evidence of the evolution of the industry.

headline: Discord Among Private Equity Firms Is Their Best Defense in Lawsuit
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The friction among private equity firms over settling a lawsuit accusing them of collusion casts doubt on whether the buyout barons could have concurred on deal valuations, Jeffrey Goldfarb writes in Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Even when it might help them, private equity firms can’t seem to cooperate.

headline: Conceptual Art by Kate Ericson and Mel Ziegler
abstract: The artists, who worked together from the late 1970s until Ms. Ericson’s death in 1995, fused Conceptual art, community action and Americana in ways few others have.
lead_paragraph: The artists Kate Ericson and Mel Ziegler, who worked together from the late 1970s until Ms. Ericson’s death in 1995, fused Conceptual art, community action and Americana in ways few others have, before or since. For a 1991 project in Charleston, S.C., they painted the exterior of a house just outside the city’s historic district in a riotous camouflage of colors (each one drawn from a list approved by the city’s Board of Architectural Review, which probably had not anticipated anyone wanting to use them all at once).

headline: Living With Cancer: Difficult Choices
abstract: A series of problematic choices confront anyone dealing with cancer.
lead_paragraph: As if confined in a sinister maze, cancer patients often discover that some routes lead to forking branches. It may be impossible to find a way through the bewildering medical labyrinth without feeling lost. My oncologist Dr. Matei, pointing out treatment paths, tells me to choose: “It’s up to you,” she says.

headline: Kevin Love to Be Traded to Cavaliers
abstract: Cleveland has agreed in principle to send a package that includes Andrew Wiggins and Anthony Bennett, the N.B.A.’s past two No. 1 picks, to Minnesota for Love.
lead_paragraph: In a move that transforms them from an intriguing contender to a possible favorite in the Eastern Conference, the Cleveland Cavaliers have reached an agreement in principle to acquire power forward Kevin Love from the Minnesota Timberwolves, according to a person in basketball briefed on the deal.

headline: Art at the Terminal and Beyond
abstract: From Staten Island to the Bronx, summer adventures of all kinds beckon.
lead_paragraph: It seems to happen every summer: Just as the Miser starts to feel as if he finally had a grasp on what he wants to do with it, the calendar rolls ruthlessly over into August. So as not to squander our last few precious weeks of warm weather, let’s hit some of the city’s ferries, beaches, gardens and parks.

headline: On the Record: ‘The Nixon Tapes 1971-1972’ and ‘The Nixon Defense’
abstract: Two books based on President Nixon’s taped conversations show him reveling in foreign policy success and lying about Watergate.
lead_paragraph: On June 1, 1972, President Richard Nixon triumphantly reported to a joint session of Congress on the summit meeting in Moscow from which he had returned just hours earlier. He trumpeted the signing of major arms-control agreements with the Soviet Union, conspicuously including a long-sought antiballistic missile treaty. “The foundation has been laid,” he exulted, “for a new relationship between the two most powerful nations in the world.”

headline: Red Alert
abstract: Darragh McKeon’s novel of the Chernobyl disaster captures the inner workings of a crumbling Soviet Union.
lead_paragraph: The nucleus of “All That Is Solid Melts Into Air,” Darragh McKeon’s whirling first novel, is the Chernobyl nuclear accident, a catastrophe that embodies the political, economic and moral bankruptcy of the waning Soviet Union. McKeon makes it the center of a much larger, interconnected story, as the great Soviet writer Vasily Grossman did with the Battle of Stalingrad in “Life and Fate.”

headline: Winged Victories
abstract: Two scientists’ studies of migrating birds shed light on their intelligence and ability to love.
lead_paragraph: Avian migration is such a vast and complex phenomenon that it can accommodate star treatment in two new books. “The Thing With Feathers,” by Noah Strycker, takes on the miracle of navigation as part of a sweeping look at bird behavior. For Bernd Heinrich, in “The Homing Instinct,” the biannual odyssey of billions of birds is the heart of the matter.

headline: A Finale to Soothe Cravings for Magic
abstract: “The Magician’s Land,” the final volume of Lev Grossman’s trilogy for grown-ups, evokes that breathless, stay-up-all-night, thrumming excitement of reading as a child.
lead_paragraph: Toward the end of “The Magician’s Land,” the final volume of Lev Grossman’s wonderful trilogy for grown-ups, Julia and Quentin, both 30-ish, visit a magic garden whose plants are expressions of human emotions. The garden is in Fillory, the Narnia-like world that appeared in a series of books that they loved as children and that, thrillingly, turned out actually to exist.

headline: How to Pre-Game Like a Grown-Up
abstract: Aperitifs offer a quintessentially adult buzz.
lead_paragraph: Editors’ note: We’re resurfacing this 2014 Drink column for Smarter Living so you can enjoy the sophisticated pleasures of a pre-dinner aperitif cocktail all year long.

headline: Michael Phelps’s Best Event Is Same, but Talent Is Deeper
abstract: Phelps’s next event at the United States long-course national championships is the 100-meter butterfly, but after two years away from the sport, he returns to a more competitive landscape.
lead_paragraph: IRVINE, Calif. — With the applause not meant for him ringing in his ears, Michael Phelps moved on from his seventh-place finish in the 100-meter freestyle at the United States long-course swimming championships. Speaking after his race Wednesday night, Phelps said, “There is going to be another chance to swim that race in a couple of weeks.”

headline: Unicef on Iraq’s Crisis in Sinjar
abstract: Will Parks, the United Nations Children’s Fund chief field officer in the northern Kurdish region of Iraq, discussed the crisis in Sinjar, where tens of thousands of people are stuck in the mountains.
lead_paragraph: Will Parks, the United Nations Children’s Fund chief field officer in the northern Kurdish region of Iraq, discussed the crisis in Sinjar, where tens of thousands of people are stuck in the mountains.

headline: Senator Quits Montana Race After Charge of Plagiarism
abstract: Senator John Walsh bowed to pressure from Democrats to step aside so that a new nominee could be named.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Under pressure from fellow Democrats, Senator John Walsh of Montana, who has served in office for just six months, said Thursday that he was dropping his election bid, clearing the path for his party to nominate a new candidate.

headline: A Waiver to Let the de Blasio Children Work as Unpaid Interns
abstract: The city’s Conflicts of Interest Board determined that Mayor Bill de Blasio’s children may serve one-month, unpaid internships at City Hall.
lead_paragraph: The city’s Conflicts of Interest Board determined that Mayor Bill de Blasio’s children may serve one-month, unpaid internships at City Hall.

headline: Too Many Cooks Spoil the Village
abstract: French haute cuisine clashes with Indian cooking in “The Hundred-Foot Journey,” starring Helen Mirren and Om Puri.
lead_paragraph: The first faces on screen at a recent advance showing of “The Hundred-Foot Journey” belonged to Oprah Winfrey and Steven Spielberg, who do not appear in the movie itself but are credited among its producers. It’s a bit unusual to be subjected to a promo trying to sell you on a movie you have already committed to seeing, but Mr. Spielberg and Ms. Winfrey clearly could not contain themselves, and took a moment to share their enthusiasm. In the clip (which has also aired on television), Ms. Winfrey, using the trademark falsetto singsong that is her version of conversational italics, tells us how excited she is to present this amazing movie, while Mr. Spielberg uses variations on the word “incredible” at least three times. Noting that “The Hundred-Foot Journey,” based on a popular novel by Richard C. Morais, is about food, Ms. Winfrey asks, “Can I say it’s delicious?”

headline: Unorthodox Star Took U.S. Soccer on New Path
abstract: Landon Donovan announced that he would retire at the end of the M.L.S. season, but it will be a while before the United States sees another player like him.
lead_paragraph: Traditionally, starting lineups in soccer feature players who wear jerseys numbered 1 through 11, with each number referring to a particular position. No. 1 is always the goalkeeper, for example. No. 3 is a stout defender. No. 9 is a lone striker.

headline: Yankees Take Series vs. Tigers Behind Starter and a Stopper
abstract: Francisco Cervelli blocked a David Robertson pitch in the dirt to help the Yankees preserve a fantastic effort by starter Shane Greene and cap an impressive series.
lead_paragraph: Francisco Cervelli was a talented soccer goalie in his youth in Valencia, Venezuela, leading his school, Cruz Vitale, to a state tournament before quitting the sport at 15 to concentrate on baseball.

headline: Lululemon Strikes Deal With Yoga Sportswear Maker’s Founder, Avoiding Fight
abstract: Under the terms of the deal, Chip Wilson will sell half of his stake in the company to Advent International for $845 million. The retailer will give the private equity firm two director seats.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:24 p.m. | Lululemon Athletica has reached a pact with its founder, Dennis J. Wilson, potentially averting a costly battle over control of the embattled sportswear maker’s board.

headline: Readers Respond to Friedman and Saif on the Gaza Conflict
abstract: Readers who commented on two recent columns about Gaza had diverse opinions on the conflict.
lead_paragraph: As the war in Gaza appears to wind down, readers are responding to Times columns about the self-perpetuating nature of armed conflict, the ethics of the United States’ position toward the Israeli offensive, and the suffering of the victims of war.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Your nightly briefing is ready for you.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know from NYT Now:

headline: Artist Comes Cackling Back to the Limelight
abstract: “Fifi Howls From Happiness” brings Bahman Mohassess out from obscurity.
lead_paragraph: It isn’t until late in “Fifi Howls From Happiness” that you learn the meaning of the cryptic title. Even so, you may soon intuit that there’s a strong link between the howling and the cackling that regularly erupts from the movie’s subject, the Iranian artist Bahman Mohassess. It’s an unnerving sound because of its wincingly harsh, broken resonance, but also because of the eerie juxtaposition created by the image of Mr. Mohassess’s cigarette smoke curling around his head, not far from a portable oxygen device. It’s hard not to think that he may be on a suicide mission, though this thoughtful, moving documentary does make you wonder if, after a lifetime of trouble, he’s just laughing at fate.

headline: “Star Wars”: Still The One
abstract: Announcing a new feature, and rebutting outrageous claims about “Guardians of the Galaxy.”
lead_paragraph: For readers who wish this blog had more pop culture commentary and fewer rants against presidential despotism, I’m very pleased to announce that my colleague Frank Bruni and I are launching a new feature in which we ping-pong back and forth about the movies we’ve seen lately (and possibly the occasional TV show as well, when it seems appropriate), sometimes touching on their political significance but hopefully also offering a partial refuge from the politicized life as well. The feature should run monthly, roughly, but perhaps more frequently depending the quality and significance of what’s showing at a given moment; I hope readers find it to be an entertaining, not-too-self-serious diversion amid the Op-Ed team’s coverage of the grim and getting grimmer issues of the day.

headline: The Executive Editor on the Word ‘Torture’
abstract: Times editors and reporters revisit the use of the word “torture” in connection to C.I.A. interrogations.
lead_paragraph: Dean Baquet is the executive editor of The Times.

headline: Dipping Into Fitness: Workouts in the Water
abstract: Affordable water exercise classes abound throughout the city’s five boroughs.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORKERS are surrounded by water, but working out in it can present financial and logistical challenges. Fortunately, if you know where to look, ample water aerobics options around the city offer refreshing and affordable ways to shape up amid the summer heat.

headline: When Getting to a Body Count Takes More Than Math
abstract: Two graphics have tried to visualize the cost in human lives of the conflict in Gaza and gun violence. Do we count the dead for political reasons, or to remember who they are and how they died?
lead_paragraph: How do we count the dead? Why do we do it? Two striking graphics — on the conflict in Gaza, in The Washington Post, and on gun violence, at Slate — offer examples and clues.

headline: Digging Into Fitness: Sandbox Play for Grown-Ups
abstract: Andia Winslow, a sports performance coach, offers guidance for exercising in the sand, which is more difficult, and therefore more beneficial, than doing the same moves on a hard surface.
lead_paragraph: FOR many people, time spent in the sand means relaxing on a blanket or in a chair. Not so for Andia Winslow, a 31-year-old professional athlete and sports performance coach: The sand presents an opportunity to get fit.

headline: Israel’s Supporters Try to Come to Terms With the Killing of Children in Gaza
abstract: Outrage over the killing of hundreds of children has been expressed by partisans on both sides of the conflict.
lead_paragraph: While the precise number of civilians killed in Israel’s monthlong bombardment of Gaza is once again the subject of a debate, outrage over the hundreds of Palestinian children killed has been expressed by partisans on both sides of the conflict.

headline: What Warpaint, L.A.’s Coolest All-Female Band, Packs on Tour
abstract: The women, who play at a film event for Sundance Next Fest this Sunday at the Ace Hotel in Downtown L.A., share their favorite beauty and fashion items, gadgets and more — plus a track from their hypnotic second album.
lead_paragraph: When Warpaint returned to Los Angeles in July after a two-month tour that spanned the western hemisphere, Emily Kokal, one of the all-female quartet’s vocalist/guitarists, would often find herself wandering the hills of her Echo Park neighborhood instead of relaxing at home. “I’m so used to moving and seeing new things,” she said over coffee recently at a local cafe. “It’s hard to be in the zone of staying still.”

headline: Walsh Statement to Supporters
abstract: Senator John Walsh of Montana said on Thursday that he was dropping his election bid in an email to supporters.
lead_paragraph: Senator John Walsh of Montana said on Thursday that he was dropping his election bid in an email to supporters.

headline: Two Parks, One Statue, Lots of Pieces Lying Around
abstract: Parts of Danh Vo’s “We the People,” an actual-size but fragmentary copy of the Statue of Liberty, is on display in City Hall Park in Manhattan and in Brooklyn Bridge Park.
lead_paragraph: If you can get past the glaring obviousness of its central metaphors, Danh Vo’s “We the People” — a fragmentary replica of the Statue of Liberty, made in China — looks pretty compelling in its latest incarnation as a Public Art Fund project. After popping up in various American, European and Asian museums, the work — or a portion of it, at least — is now ideally situated in two city parks at opposite ends of the Brooklyn Bridge.

headline: A Return to the Fight in Iraq
abstract: Should the United States military become more involved in the region as the threat of ISIS grows?

headline: Where Minimalist Meets Showy
abstract: Works by Zhang Huan and Virginia Overton at Storm King offer operatic showiness and Buddhist simplicity, but maybe not the ones you’d expect.
lead_paragraph: MOUNTAINVILLE, N.Y. — Sculptures by the two artists featured here in temporary presentations at Storm King Art Center this year couldn’t be less alike. A single Minimalist piece by the New York sculptor Virginia Overton is gracefully fitted to the landscape of gently rolling hills. Six monumental, figurative sculptures by Zhang Huan of Shanghai are ponderously theatrical.

headline: Elevated Perspectives
abstract: A walk on the High Line will include the “Archeo” exhibition as well as other outdoor artworks.
lead_paragraph: “Archeo” is this season’s exhibition of artworks presented on the High Line, the elevated railway turned greenway on the West Side of Manhattan that has become a tourist magnet and emblem of gentrified New York. Shortening the word “archaeology,” the exhibition of outdoor sculpture by seven contemporary artists focuses on technology and obsolescence. It also provides some connection with the history and culture of the High Line, which, with its carefully selected benches and botanicals, can otherwise feel like a detached people mover carrying you through a bucolic landscape in the sky.

headline: Fine Lines Drawn Among the Flora
abstract: Rachel Feinstein has set up “Folly,” a set of three sculptures that evoke the whimsical garden structures on 18th- and 19th-century estates, in Madison Square Park.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Feinstein’s “Folly,” a set of three sculptures in Madison Square Park, evokes the whimsical garden structures on vast 18th- and 19th-century estates. Each sculpture is a sort of frothy confection, whipped up from thin sheets of aluminum that have been coated in white powder and printed with gray lines to look like enlarged sketches. One looks like a house on a cliff; another is a rococo hut. Most intriguing, if least accessible, is the ship moored high overhead in a tree.

headline: Millennials Turned Yuppies (Really), Pulling Together
abstract: “About Alex,” in which college friends reunite, features allusions to “The Big Chill,” a reunion film of another generation.
lead_paragraph: ABOUT ALEX

headline: Museums See Different Virtues in Virtual Worlds
abstract: The Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Brooklyn Museum — both ambitious cosmopolitan art institutions — have taken diverging paths on the Internet.
lead_paragraph: LIKE vodka and fun-house mirrors and trips to Japan, the Internet can make you feel bigger than you are.

headline: Ordinary Objects, Reimagined
abstract: A new public art program at Governors Island features four sculptures by Mark Handforth and a work by the sound artist Susan Philipsz.
lead_paragraph: There is a lot of art on Governors Island, much of it mounted in buildings along the waterfront or the bright yellow houses in Nolan Park. Past years have included ambitious installations of monumental sculpture by Mark di Suvero, as well as Allison Smith’s “Muster,” a mock-military gathering inspired by the island’s history. This is the first year of a new public art program headed by Tom Eccles, and it features four sculptures by Mark Handforth that fit in well with the island’s increasing move to becoming a Colonial Williamsburg-type family playground.

headline: Dealing With Home-Equity Resets
abstract: New research suggests the payment shock expected to hit millions of consumers with home equity lines may not pose as much of a risk to lenders as feared.
lead_paragraph: New research from TransUnion, a credit information service, suggests that the payment shock expected to hit millions of consumers with home equity lines over the next few years may not pose as much of a risk to lenders as feared.

headline: DeGrom Keeps Mets in the Game, but Harper’s Home Run Ends It
abstract: Jacob deGrom faced something he has not encountered recently — adversity — as the Mets had trouble scoring against the Nationals.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jacob deGrom put his glove under his armpit, massaged a baseball with his hands and paced a few feet beyond the mound. He had just allowed his first home run in about two months, a period in which he had become the Mets’ most consistent starter and adversity had faded to a foreign concept. The question now was simple: How would he respond?

headline: Summer Art, Barefoot in the Park
abstract: A selection of outdoor art exhibitions, at Madison Square, City Hall Park, the High Line, Brooklyn Bridge Park, Governors Island and Storm King.
lead_paragraph: A QUESTION that has long dogged modern art is: “Who’s it for?” Animated by antipathy to mainstream tastes and values, it first appealed mainly to a self-selected minority of cognoscenti. Since the 1960s, however, the audience for modern and contemporary art has grown, and the answer now would be something like: “For anyone who’s interested.”

headline: The Questions We Share

lead_paragraph: How can we repair our public discourse?

headline: Animal Welfare Advocates Notch a Win Against Dog Traders
abstract: A group of animal lovers from across China rescued about 2,400 dogs that might have otherwise ended up on the dinner table.
lead_paragraph: It’s rare that stories of grass-roots activism in China end well, yet that seems to be the case for a group of animal lovers who rescued some 2,400 dogs that might have otherwise ended up on the menu.

headline: 36 Hours: Lake Como, Italy
abstract: The views — from above, the shore or a boat — may steal the show, but there’s more to do in this area of northern Italy than simply gaze at the scenery.
lead_paragraph: In the foothills of the Alps in northern Italy, Lake Como deserves its reputation as a playground for the wealthy. Virtually deserted during the winter, the wishbone-shaped lake awakens from its slumber in mid-March when glamorous crowds begin flocking to the pretty towns clustered around its midsection: Bellagio, Menaggio, Tremezzo, Varenna. But in recent years, the city of Como, on the lake’s southwestern tip, has quietly blossomed into the most interesting spot for visitors of all bank account sizes. A raft of openings has infused new life there, transforming the oft-overlooked transit hub into the lake’s new place to be seen.

headline: Visiting ‘Shawshank’ Sites, 20 Years Later
abstract: Two decades after “The Shawshank Redemption” was released, the author explores spots in Ohio where the film was made.
lead_paragraph: Richland County refers to itself, because of its character and geographical location, as the “heart of Ohio.” But for a large number of visitors, it is better known as the home of perhaps the most storied prison in movie history.

headline: ‘The Fifth Season’
abstract: This stimulating group show imagines the consequences of drastic environmental change.
lead_paragraph: The title of this stimulating group show comes from a centrally placed installation by Mark Dion. Called “Harbingers of the Fifth Season,” it presents the imaginary workroom of a scientist-illustrator who is studying shifts in animal behavior caused by drastic environmental change.

headline: Making the Best of Trash, While Finding Meaning
abstract: “Human Resources,” on Pivot, is a workplace reality series that offers an example of meaningful work for millennials.
lead_paragraph: Participant Media’s Pivot aims its programming at millennials and uses the motto “It’s your turn.” But plenty of millennials have found that it is not their turn. They’re stuck in drab low-level jobs despite excellent educations and high aspirations.

headline: An Eclectic Mix of Hard-Luck Tales
abstract: Emmylou Harris and Rodney Crowell played at Americanafest NYC, a collaboration between Lincoln Center Out of Doors and the American Music Association, which runs through Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Emmylou Harris and Rodney Crowell foraged through history both distant and recent at the Damrosch Park Bandshell on Wednesday night, finding some of the strongest traction in vintage songs of their own design. Among them was “ ’Til I Gain Control Again,” written by Mr. Crowell and originally recorded by Ms. Harris in 1975, not long after their first meeting. Underplaying its broken reassurance and desperate devotion, they made it feel lived-in and true.

headline: Does Zephyr Teachout Live in New York? The Governor Wants to Know.
abstract: Andrew Cuomo is no longer treating his rival as a mere inconvenience. He hired an election expert to pore over her records.
lead_paragraph: Zephyr Rain Teachout, a law professor at Fordham University in New York, is a very brave woman. So brave, in fact, that she is running for governor in the Democratic primary against Andrew Cuomo.

abstract: The works of the exhibition’s 13 artists revolve around themes of chance and games, centering on the economic and gambling conundrum of risk known as the St. Petersburg Paradox.

headline: Once Scorned, Now Rich and Vengeful
abstract: A revamped version of the musical “The Visit” at the Williamstown Theater Festival stars Chita Rivera as a billionaire who returns to her hometown, carrying a lethal grudge.

Portraying the much-married, well-widowed Claire Zachanassian, a billionaire for whom patience is a vicious virtue, Ms. Rivera holds calm and queenly sway over the macabre frenzy of “The Visit,” John Doyle’s newly revamped version of the 2001 John Kander and Fred Ebb musical at the Williamstown Theater Festival.

headline: In a Balm of Space and Time, Healing
keywords: ['Modern Love (Times Column)', 'Death and Dying', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: The loss of our friends was a silent stowaway, riding atop our shoulders for a year; but then in writing a book about them, it opened up love, buoyant and uplifting.
lead_paragraph: Twelve years ago, my husband, Nick, and I were halfway through a yearlong round-the-world trip when we arrived in Jaisalmer, India, on a furnace-hot July afternoon. As we made our way from the train station up the winding streets to the cheapest hotel we could find, our rickshaw became snarled in traffic in an alley alongside other rickshaws, a donkey cart and cows noshing on garbage.

headline: Sympathy Can Wait
abstract: How to handle ill-timed condolences, house-sitting mishaps, scratched cars and patronizing nicknames.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, we lost our 18-year-old son to an undiagnosed heart condition. We are still grieving, though time is making things a little better. But we find it extremely distressing when people we haven’t seen in the last year rush up to us at social events to tell us how sorry they are and how they “just can’t imagine” our loss. We know they mean well, but it makes us overwhelmingly sad and ruins festive occasions. My husband doesn’t want to go out anymore! What can we do to stop people from launching into their grief for us?

headline: Throwback Thursday
abstract: Just a little reminder how marvelous we used to be.
lead_paragraph: Yes, this is a photo of me when I was 26. Am I not the most adorable thing you have ever seen? Can you believe that was my real, gorgeous hair color? I ask because I can’t always post stories of my work, or share photos of my grandchildren or link to the work of the successful people I want to suck up to here on Facebook. It is important to give back.

lead_paragraph: Summer Streets (Saturday and Aug. 16) Play continues to have the right of way on some Manhattan streets during this free festival, which began last week. For the next two Saturdays, from 7 a.m. to 1 p.m., Park Avenue will be vehicle-free, from the Brooklyn Bridge to 72nd Street, and parts of Lafayette Street and other streets will also be closed. In its seventh year, Summer Streets is part of the New York City Transportation Department’s Weekend Walks, an effort that encourages civic groups and businesses to sponsor free street events.

headline: An Invitation to Play, and Then Wash
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Hygiene and Cleanliness', 'Kitchens', 'Bathrooms and Toilets']
abstract: Delta Faucet is marketing its kitchen and bathroom fixtures through an appeal to cut loose and get dirty, then rely on Delta for cleaning up.
lead_paragraph: FOR decades Mr. Bubble, the brand of bubble bath for children, has used a slogan that aimed to win over children who hate taking baths, “Makes getting clean almost as much fun as getting dirty!” Now adults are being pitched a similar message that exalts washing up after exercise or messy projects, but this time it is to sell faucets and showerheads.

headline: China Curbs on Metals Are Again Found to Violate Trade Law

headline: Morning Agenda: What’s Behind the Surge in Mergers

lead_paragraph: WHAT’S BEHIND THE STAMPEDE OF MERGERS | “Something big is happening on Wall Street that is making investment bankers richer,” Peter Eavis and David Gelles write in DealBook. That something is a boom in mergers and acquisitions, which is expected to continue even after Rupert Murdoch’s bid for Time Warner and Sprint’s attempt to buy T-Mobile crumbled earlier this week. A sharp upturn in deal activity is often thought to herald a stronger economy and a buoyant stock market. The theory is that corporate chieftains see strength building in their business lines, which gives them the confidence to pursue ambitious acquisitions of other companies.

headline: 1889: Thomas Edison Testifies
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Electric Light and Power']
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Thomas A. Edison explains electrical current.
lead_paragraph: An unusually interesting hearing in the Kemmler case in New York was the recent one when the great electrician, Thomas A. Edison, testified. Everyone present, including W. Bourke Cockran, Kemmler’s attorney, was extremely anxious to hear the evidence of the man who, by general consent, is regarded as the greatest electrician of the age. The clear, concise way in which Mr. Edison explained many subjects which had not been understood after two weeks of evidence from numerous witnesses would have convinced anyone who did not know his reputation that his knowledge of electricity was at once comprehensive and accurate. All listened to his testimony with the greatest interest, and when he had finished felt that their knowledge of electricity had been greatly increased. — The New York Herald, European Edition, August 9, 1889

headline: The ’80s Supermodel Leslie Winer Reissues Her Lost ’90s Album
abstract: With the re-release of her cult LP “Witch,” this muse to Basquiat and Gaultier and current face of Vivienne Westwood is ripe for rediscovery. A track appears here.
lead_paragraph: Leslie Winer was, in the words of Jean-Paul Gaultier, “the first androgynous model.” In the 1980s, her angular features landed her campaigns for Valentino and Miss Dior; covers of The Face and European editions of Vogue; and shoots with legendary photographers like Helmut Newton, Irving Penn and Pierre et Gilles. She fell into fashion by happenstance after moving to New York City from Massachusetts to attend the School of Visual Arts. There, she became a protégé of William Burroughs, partied hard and ran with the downtown demimonde of the era, dating Jean-Michel Basquiat for a time. Modeling, however, was just a job; music and writing were her true passions. “The fashion world was much smaller and less mainstream then than it is now,” she says. “No one outside of fashion had any idea who you were. There wasn’t the big money or the celebrity that occurred later.”

headline: Need Kids to Follow Instructions? Don’t Ask. Tell.
abstract: “Do you want to put on your shoes now?” “Should we have macaroni and cheese for dinner?” “How about you go brush your teeth?” These are not really questions.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, I committed what is known as a “mom fail” (basically any false move committed during the act of mothering). Preparing my then-2½-year-old son to go out in the morning for a play date, I asked him, “Do you want to go to H.’s house?” Emphatically, he said no. “Well, we have plans; he’s expecting us,” I amended lamely. My son burst into tears, and no matter how I tried to spin it, he was adamant. Maybe he was tired; maybe the dark, cloudy morning visible from our windows was too uninviting. Whatever the case, I was now in the awkward position of having to drag him, kicking and screaming, down four flights of stairs (we lived in a walk-up) while also toting my younger boy, then an infant. So I canceled the play date (thus committing a “friendship fail,” too, all in one morning).

headline: Who Made That Twitter Bird?
abstract: The streamlining of Larry, the first of several iconic tweet logos.
lead_paragraph: “Twitter is the bird, the bird is Twitter,” the social networking company’s former creative director, Doug Bowman, said in a 2012 announcement about the latest redesign of the Twitter logo. Its slightly goofier predecessor had a tufted head and was sometimes accompanied by the company name; Bowman’s new bird was a sleeker update. Resembling a mountain bluebird with a dash of hummingbird thrown in, the Twitter bird has a beak and body that point toward the sky in what Bowman called “the ultimate representation of freedom, hope and limitless possibility.” Unlike previous iterations since the company’s 2006 launch, all of which were named “Larry the Bird” after the Boston Celtics legend, the current logo is known simply as the Twitter Bird.

headline: Staking Out the Great White Shark
abstract: A rare photograph of a nighttime breach.
lead_paragraph: In the nearly 40 years since the premiere of “Jaws,” defenders of the great white shark have tried diligently to repair the animal’s reputation. The sharks are not all that hungry for humans, scientists say; seals are their preferred prey. One way great whites capture them is by breaching. Michael Muller, a photographer, used waterproof strobe lights he designed himself and a boat dragging a seal decoy to get a rare photo of a shark breaching at night. Muller, who traveled to False Bay, South Africa, to photograph sharks for a book coming out in 2015 from Taschen, said waiting for a shark in the dark is an intense experience. “They come up like a missile, knock the seal to shock it and then they bite it,” he says. “There’s no noise, no warning. I’m sitting there for hours on end looking through my lens, and then all of a sudden the shark appears." Julie Bosman

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Liane Moriarty, whose “Big Little Lies” is No. 1 on the hardcover fiction list, realized something while reading “Fifty Shades of Grey”: “I couldn’t write a sexy spanking scene to save my life.”
lead_paragraph: Coming Clean: The Australian novelist Liane Moriarty, like a lot of writers, is ambivalent about modern technology. “I have social media anxiety,” she confessed on her blog last year, and she wasn’t kidding — that post, dated May 6, 2013, remains her most recent as this column goes to press, and the blog as a whole has averaged just a handful of entries per year since it began in 2010. Too bad, since Moriarty turns out to be a natural blogger, droll and daffy and confiding. Here she is, for instance, on reading “Fifty Shades of Grey”: “Why didn’t any of you lovely readers tell me that you wanted more spanking? (Ha.) . . . Maybe you realized that I couldn’t write a sexy spanking scene to save my life. (Well, I don’t know. Perhaps I could to save my life. Except I’d be quite nervous and distracted by the person trying to kill me.)” Moriarty does maintain an active presence on Facebook, where, to promote her latest novel, “Big Little Lies” — new at No. 1 on the hardcover fiction list — she recently asked readers to reveal little lies of their own. “My publishers asked me to get in the spirit of things by also making a confession,” she wrote, “so here’s one: When my son’s kindergarten class was putting together a recipe book of ‘favorite easy recipes’ I sent in a nutritious-sounding avocado muffin recipe that I had never made in my life just so I would look like a good mother.”

headline: The Interpretation of Freud
abstract: In this brief biography, Adam Phillips focuses on the discovery of the unconscious.
lead_paragraph: This book is a biography not of Freud and psychoanalysis but of Freud as psychoanalysis. Adam Phillips explains that what the reader does not need in any biographer’s attempt to write “that impossible thing, a Freudian life of the young Freud, is the always fanciful (i.e. wishful), novelettish setting of scenes, and thumbnail sketches of characters, with their suppositions about what people were thinking and feeling and doing.” What is needed, he believes, is what he supplies: a sketchy chronology of Freud’s first 50 years threaded through the step-by-step story, richly told and richly interpreted, of how psychoanalysis came to be.

headline: Reality Bites
abstract: Christopher Beha’s antihero, a washed-up actor, makes a Faustian bargain with a cynical television producer.
lead_paragraph: Why? Why would anyone put himself through this? It’s a question I often ask myself while watching the endless parade of reality “stars” cavorting/jiggling/crying/strutting/tottering across my television screen. Why subject oneself to the vicious cycle of ridicule, redemption, repeat? The promise of easy money must prod many into the field, but a vast majority of reality show participants never make substantial cash from their television appearances. What else is there, then? Well — duh — fame. And what is the purpose of fame? Well — duh — more fame.

headline: Seduction and Betrayal
abstract: Two sisters from Ohio reinvent themselves in 1940s America.
lead_paragraph: No Amy Bloom character ever acted out of boredom. Once a practicing psychotherapist, Bloom knows that dire circumstances can drive people to their most compelling extremes. At her best, when she sets these driven souls on a journey across a landscape shadowed by immigration or war, the results can be stunning.

headline: Striking It Rich
abstract: For tens of thousands of Americans who journeyed west, the gold rush offered a chance for a better life.
lead_paragraph: The American mining frontier burst on the scene with an undeniable frenzy in the spring of 1849. “No one,” Edward Dolnick writes, “could have imagined how quickly the West would change.” Shouts of “Gold!” would later be raised in such scattered locales as Bannack, Mont., Cripple Creek, Colo., and Nome, Alaska, but it all began in California near a place called Sutter’s Mill.

headline: Enlisted Women
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Following three women to Afghanistan and back home.
lead_paragraph: Helen Thorpe’s comprehensively researched new book, “Soldier Girls,” follows the lives of three women from enlistment in the Indiana National Guard through deployment and back home again.

headline: Seen on the Street | Outside the Spring/Summer 2015 Copenhagen Shows
abstract: A glimpse at what some of the women and men were wearing in Copenhagen during the city’s just-concluded fashion week.
lead_paragraph: A glimpse at what some of the women and men were wearing in Copenhagen during the city’s just-concluded fashion week.

headline: Unmasters of Sex
abstract: The heroine of Anya Ulinich’s graphic novel goes on a campaign to rectify her woeful romantic inexperience.
lead_paragraph: One of the most compelling panels in “Lena Finkle’s Magic Barrel,” Anya Ulinich’s engrossing graphic novel about the vicissitudes of love, family, immigration and art, is a full-page depiction of the title character staring into a mirror. With resolve in her deep-set eyes, she hacks away at her hair with a fearsome pair of scissors. This is Lena Finkle, and Ulinich renders her in a naturalistic style, with sophisticated use of perspective, shadowing and ink-wash technique. As Lena lops off her hair, she recalls an argument with her ex-husband. This memory is presented cartoonishly; the remembered Lena’s frown is a slash, her curly hair a furious scribble.

headline: You Mean It’s Not Dead?
abstract: Michael Schmidt surveys 700 years of the novel, from Austen to Zola.
lead_paragraph: Michael Schmidt’s 1,172 pages encompass similarly big numbers. Seven hundred years of fiction are chronicled, hundreds of novelists looked at, and even more novels summarized. The biggest number of all, which can only be guessed at, wincingly, is how many hours of reading this intrepid book distills between its straining covers. Schmidt reveres Cervantes as one of the fathers of modern fiction, and there is something quixotic about Schmidt’s own enterprise. As the French general Bosquet said, watching the charge of the Light Brigade into the valley of death, “C’est magnifique.” But, to paraphrase the second half of his tribute, “Ce n’est pas la critique littéraire.” It is not literary criticism — at least not the currently approved kind that gets you a Ph.D., tenure and an endowed chair.

headline: The Search Continues
abstract: In Bret Anthony Johnston’s debut novel, the rescue of a missing boy is only the beginning of his family’s healing process.
lead_paragraph: “I am convinced,” Wayne C. Booth wrote in “The Rhetoric of Fiction” in 1961, “that most novelists today . . . feel an inseparable connection between art and morality, quite apart from what it is popular to say about morality.” He argued that a novelist’s control of narrative distance — his manipulation of the relationships among author, narrator, character and reader — has everything to do with the novel’s moral life. “And yet we go on talking as if technical triumphs had no relation to the value of what they achieve.”

headline: Between God and the Führer
abstract: A biography of Dietrich Bonhoeffer, the German theologian who was executed by the Nazis in 1945.
lead_paragraph: Coming to terms with the genocidal century just past, especially the unvarnished evil of Nazi Germany, has prompted theologians and philosophers to adjust and recalibrate much of what they thought they knew. Writers as diverse as Reinhold Niebuhr, John Pawlikowski, Richard Rubenstein and Elie Wiesel — some more successfully than others — have all struggled to reconcile the existence of the divine with unspeakable atrocities, many of them carried out in the name of God.

headline: Paul McCartney Collaborates on a Video Game Score
abstract: The former Beatle has also written a theme song for Destiny, the highly anticipated video game due for release on Sept. 9.
lead_paragraph: Collectors of Paul McCartney’s music may have to add a new format – a version of PlayStation or Xbox — to their stacks of LPs, tapes, CDs, DVDs and digital downloads. His next major project is the score for Destiny, the highly anticipated video game from Bungie and Activision, due on Sept. 9.

headline: A Ranch With 1,000 Acres, for Your Inner Buckaroo
abstract: Recreational ranches offer the ultimate anti-Hamptons getaway.
lead_paragraph: Most New Yorkers would barely know what to do with 1,000 square feet of space, let alone 1,000 acres. But what’s to stop us from trying to figure it out.

headline: The Distance Between
abstract: From Mexico to Chicago, from past to present, Maria Venegas confronts her gun-toting father’s violent legacy.
lead_paragraph: Jose Venegas, the father at the center of Maria Venegas’s vividly evocative memoir, “Bulletproof Vest,” is an outlaw in the grand tradition. He is, in other words, a moving target — sometimes mythic, sometimes depressingly real. We romanticize outlaws, which is our romantic word for “criminals.” I suppose it has something to do with their vitality, an extraordinary life force manifested by brilliant clothes, flamboyant sexuality, bullets and dead bodies. Even victims can be susceptible to a form of awe. And an outlaw’s children, of course, can be prone to a vexed and powerful love.

headline: Britain’s Drinking Problem
abstract: The experiment to discourage overconsumption would have a greater chance of success if it were bolder.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British relationship with strong drink, which might be even more tangled than the American one, has taken a new twist: London is to experiment with the “sobriety tags” for which much success has been claimed in the United States, where the bracelets are known by a more snappy acronym, SCRAM, or Secure Continuous Remote Alcohol Monitoring. Those committing minor crimes in which alcohol has played a part will be barred from drinking for up to 120 days in a pilot program employing the alcohol-detecting anklets, which are made by a Colorado company and have been modeled by celebrities like Lindsay Lohan, Tracy Morgan and Jayson Williams.

abstract: Plus, fine-tuning the equalizer in iTunes.
lead_paragraph: Q. Some YouTube videos have closed captioning that may be automatically generated by computer, perhaps on the fly. What software is available to caption simple videos with a clearly spoken soundtrack?

headline: Cava Is Overlooked Everywhere but Catalonia
abstract: Cava from Spain, made predominately from xarello grapes, has the complexity and finesse of any fine wine.
lead_paragraph: ST.-SADURNÍ d’ANOIA, Spain — If ever a grape needed a champion, it may well be xarello. It suffers pronunciation woes (in Catalan, it’s shah-RELL-lo; in Castilian, hah-RELL-lo; in English, zah-RELL-oh). It has spelling issues (it’s often written xarel-lo among numerous other renderings). Most important, it is guilty by association as a key component of cava, the Spanish sparkling wine that most people consider at best cheap and cheerful and at worst a headache in a glass.

headline: In China, British Investigator Hired by Glaxo, and Wife, Sentenced to Prison
abstract: A couple pleaded guilty to illegally obtaining private records on Chinese citizens and were sentenced to prison terms.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — In spring 2013, GlaxoSmithKline, a British pharmaceutical giant, hired a firm to investigate a former employee, who was suspected of trying to smear the drugmaker’s top executive in China. Glaxo management told the firm’s British investigator that the company had received a sex video of the executive. The investigator called the case “Project Scorpion.”

headline: Why You Lie About Where You’re From
abstract: Where you’re from says a lot about who you are. But, for some, where you’re not from is even more important.
lead_paragraph: I am from Chicago. I am also not from Chicago. It depends on who you ask.

headline: 1914: France Reclaims Alsace
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: France reclaims Alsace, August 8, 1914.
lead_paragraph: Official despatches made public by the French Ministry of War at 11.30 last night [Aug. 8] show that the French troops are advancing rapidly in Upper Alsace, driving the Germans before them at the point of the bayonet. Mulhouse has been occupied, and French cavalry is pursuing the fleeing Germans further to the north. The occupation of Mulhouse followed upon that of Altkirch, reported earlier in the day. The entrance of the French troops into Alsace is a historic event, which will arouse the enthusiasm of the whole French nation. The advance guard of the French army reached Altkirch at nightfall on Friday. The town was defended by very strong field works and was occupied by a German brigade. The French advance guard also consisted of a brigade. The French troops dashed to the assault with magnificent ardor. An infantry regiment, in a furious bayonet charge, carried the German trenches after a hot engagement in front of the lines. Once again the bayonet charges put the Germans to flight. — The New York Herald, European Edition, August 9, 1914

headline: Searching for Vintage Toilet Seats and Other Parts

lead_paragraph: The space on the jersey fronts of the world’s top soccer teams is valuable real estate. Manchester United’s new sponsorship deal with Chevrolet will pay the club almost $80 million a year — the most of any team, anywhere. The financial food chain descends from there, as the big multinational advertisers fall away and opportunities arise in unlikely places and for unlikely prices.

lead_paragraph: Cross-border strikes between Israel and militants from Gaza resumed after a three-day cease-fire expired.
