headline: What We Mean When We Say Student Debt Is Bad
abstract: Student loans need reform. But recent gloomy reports obscure the key benefit of borrowing for college: a college education.
lead_paragraph: Once again, the headlines are filled with claims that student loans are bad. Several articles have highlighted results from a Gallup poll that shows that college graduates who borrow for college are less happy, healthy and wealthy than debt-free graduates. The Gallup report (which is cautious in its interpretation of the data) has been drawn into a rising chorus of news media reports on the negative consequences of borrowing: Student loans not only make you sick but also hamper homeownership and delay marriage.

headline: Going for a Run Around the World
abstract: Kevin Carr, who's in the middle of a trip that will cover more than 18,000 miles, talks about the challenges and surprises he's encountered so far.
lead_paragraph: After struggling with depression and anxiety in his early 20s, Kevin Carr, 34, decided “mental illness must never be confused with mental weakness.” He set out to prove this through extreme running. He ran 50 marathons in 50 days and then tackled the mountainous route between Land’s End, England, and John O’Groats, Scotland, taking a roundabout 1,200-mile, six-week journey between the two points on opposite ends of Britain. Now, he is about halfway through an around-the-world run in which he will cover more than 18,000 miles over six continents.

headline: Seeing Mexico City, Guided by Architects
abstract: A pair of Mexico's starchitects lead a selective tour of the capital's buildings, including some of their own design.
lead_paragraph: When you first arrive in Mexico City, your senses are overwhelmed by the sheer size and the never-ending hum of activity. Choosing a focal point can be exhausting. Every facet of the city seems as important as the next.

headline: Restoring Acadia’s Trails
abstract: Work crews are following in the footsteps of 19th-century trail blazers to revive the scenic paths of Acadia National Park in Maine.
lead_paragraph: A 120-foot white pine shaded what was left of the trail. The best indication of which way to walk was an auburn arc of fallen pine needles, bending to the right. Then a small clearing. Then flecks of blue filtering through the branches and the muted growl of the Atlantic meeting the shore of Mount Desert Island, in Maine.

headline: A Boy at Play in Gaza, a Renewal of Warfare, a Family in Mourning
abstract: Hundreds gathered to mourn Ibrahim Dawawsa, 10, the first casualty in the latest chapter of the battle between Hamas and Israel in the Gaza Strip.
lead_paragraph: GAZA CITY — Sabah Dawawsa was in the kitchen Friday morning, frying the chicken livers her 10-year-old son, Ibrahim, had requested for the after-prayer meal. With Palestinian rockets having resumed at the 8 a.m. expiration of a 72-hour cease-fire, followed by Israeli airstrikes, Ms. Dawawsa said she had told Ibrahim to stay inside, in their house in Gaza City’s Sheikh Radwan neighborhood.

headline: Blast in Ukraine’s Capital Stirs Fears of New Conflict
abstract: The explosion, which injured at least two people, came as protest barricades and tents still stand in the central square months after demonstrations that toppled the government.
lead_paragraph: ARTEMIVSK, Ukraine — An explosion in downtown Kiev, Ukraine, on Friday injured at least two people and ignited fears of new conflict in the city, where protest barricades and tents still stand in the central square months after demonstrations that toppled the government.

headline: The Magic of Swimming on Martha’s Vineyard
abstract: A celebration of the island’s aquatic riches.
lead_paragraph: A correspondent friend, whose work has taken him to hundreds of places here and abroad, has a huge map pocked with colored pins marking every place he’s visited in his journalistic travels. My comparable map, which exists only in my mind, is not of the world’s majestic cities or one-stoplight towns, but of its bodies of water in which I have swum — oceans, sounds, ponds, rivers, cenotes and pools indoor and out.

headline: The Flavor of Corn, but With Sizzle
abstract: Fresh corn griddle cakes are like pancakes, but are so much more substantial, topped with salsa.
lead_paragraph: Sweet tender corn, one of summer’s great joys, is in season, though it may seem too obvious to mention. It’s pretty much everywhere, there’s a lot of it, and it’s oh so easy to love.

headline: Ryerson, an Old Chicago Steel Company, Slumps in Market Debut
abstract: The company, owned by the Los Angeles private equity firm Platinum Equity, had priced its shares at $11 each in an I.P.O. on Thursday evening, the bottom of an expected range.
lead_paragraph: Ryerson Holding, a Chicago steel distributor with a history almost as long as that of the city itself, stumbled on Friday as it began a new chapter on the public markets.

headline: Restaurant Report: The Raeburn in Edinburgh
abstract: This spot, opened in March in the currently trendy neighborhood of Stockbridge, serves familiar favorites jazzed up with a few modern touches.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, the scene outside a slate-brown Georgian house in the quaint but currently trendy neighborhood of Stockbridge in Edinburgh on a Friday night is a little befuddling. The swarm of beer-toting young professionals buzzing about biergarten-style benches in the front yard implies something very casual, with a slight whiff of a dating meat market.

headline: On Fishers Island, N.Y., Summertime Style and Flavors Run in the Family
abstract: On the 9-mile-long stretch of sand off the North Fork of Long Island, two fashionable young sisters have launched a canned spiked lemonade and a chic boutique (right next door to their mother’s new gourmet market).
lead_paragraph: Not much happens on Fishers Island, New York, pop. 236, a low-key, 9-mile-long stretch of sand east of Long Island’s North Fork that can only be reached by ferry from New London, Conn. And that’s just how residents and holiday regulars like it. This summer, however, one family is offering up several reasons to visit. Sisters Kate and Bronya Shillo — alongside their parents Greg and Debi Shillo, the proprietors of the no-frills Pequot Inn — have launched a spiked lemonade business, a chic beach boutique and a curated gourmet market.

headline: Bloomberg’s Bruised Legacy
abstract: Several problems left over from Michael R. Bloomberg’s mayoralty are now plaguing his successor and casting new light on his reputation, Ginia Bellafante writes.
lead_paragraph: Last year, toward the end of Michael R. Bloomberg’s mayoralty, many who deliberated the matter of his legacy concluded that, although he had driven inequality to untenable extremes, liked charter schools too much and perhaps heavyset people not enough, he ran New York City efficiently and, ultimately, extremely well.

headline: Papers, Please!
abstract: The South’s internal-passport system gave whites a sense of what it felt like to be a slave.
lead_paragraph: By early 1864, members of the Confederate Congress had had enough. Despite their high positions in the government, for years they had suffered constant humiliation at the hands of provost marshals, military guards and passport clerks who forced them to comply with the regulations of a unique, and frustrating, feature of the Confederacy: the domestic passport system, a mechanism of population control they had never actually approved. Now they were demanding to know who had established this system in the first place, and under what authority. The answer revealed much about the nature of the Confederacy, a paradox that was, at the same time, a weak political entity and an oppressive slavocracy.

lead_paragraph: During photography of the 2015 BMW 435i convertible, I shot beautiful video of flowers, clouds, horses and scenic vistas along rural roads. Almost none of it is used in the piece. This is, after all, a car review, not a CBS Sunday Morning sound and picture piece. But, as a convertible owner myself, I’m compelled to communicate what I see and smell when the top is down. It’s not only about getting a deeper tan (something doctors will frown upon anyway).

lead_paragraph: You may have heard about “corporate inversion” this week. That’s a tax-avoidance maneuver in which an American company is acquired by a smaller foreign competitor, allowing it to move its tax residency abroad while keeping most of its operations in the United States.

headline: Not Enough to Smooth the Bumps
abstract: The Jetta GLI is the most sporting, most expensive version of VW’s best-selling car in America, but there’s still a lot of the $18,000 Jetta S in the $30,000 GLI.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: Losing It Solved!
abstract: Readers solve the case of a middle-aged man who loses weight, strength and the hair on his legs.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to take on the case of a 55-year-old man who suddenly began to lose his leg hair, his strength and his muscle mass. I asked for the cause of the losses and the underlying disease process. More than 300 of you wrote in with suggested diagnoses. Many of you had half of it right, and a dozen of you had it totally right.

headline: Bipartisan Support, With Caveats, for Obama on Iraq Airstrikes
abstract: President Obama faced some skepticism among Republicans and Democrats over his strategy for the attacks on militants from the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama drew bipartisan support on Friday from members of Congress for his decision to authorize military strikes in Iraq, but the backing was tempered with substantial concern — including within Mr. Obama’s own party — about his strategy for the operation.

headline: How Math Got Its ‘Nobel’
abstract: The true story behind the field’s most prestigious award.
lead_paragraph: ON Wednesday in Seoul, the International Congress of Mathematicians will announce the winners of the Fields Medal. First awarded in Oslo in 1936, the medal is given every four years to two to four mathematicians. It is considered the “Nobel Prize” of mathematics (even the organizers of the congress call it that), filling a gap left by Alfred Nobel, who did not include mathematics among the prizes endowed on his death in 1896.

headline: Voice Recognition Still a Top Complaint, Study Says
abstract: A J. D. Power executive said that 32 percent of all infotainment-related complaints were a result of voice-recognition errors.
lead_paragraph: The technology in new cars that bedevils drivers more than any other is voice recognition.

He was pronounced dead on arrival at Knickerbocker Hospital in Harlem. Mr. Nakasa was 28 years old.

headline: The Half-Century-Long Renovation of Rundale Palace, the Versailles of Latvia
abstract: Restoring the 54-room, 18th-century manse to its former glory has been one man’s life-long labor of love.
lead_paragraph: Last May, Rundale Palace, a 18th-century Baroque palace in Latvia, celebrated the completion of 50 years of renovation work with the opening of the Duke’s Library, one of several rooms finally open to the public for the first time. The Duke in question was Ernst Johann von Biron, the Duke of Courland, for whom the palace was built between 1736 and 1740 by the Italian architect Francesco Bartolomeo Rastrelli as a summer residence. It boasts 54 rooms, including a 1770s-era billiards room and a banquet hall known as the Great Gallery, which have also finally been restored to their original splendor. Some have called the palace the Versailles of Latvia.

abstract: Paavo Jarvi led the Deutsche Kammerphilharmonie Bremen in an all-Brahms program as part of the Mostly Mozart Festival on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The Mostly Mozart Festival has been offering more varied fare lately, but plenty of it still looks staid. At first glance, an overture-concerto-symphony program of Brahms, Brahms and Brahms — with encores of Brahms — appears conservative. But it didn’t turn out that way with Paavo Jarvi and the Deutsche Kammerphilharmonie Bremen, who stormed through this Thursday concert at Alice Tully Hall with a rare intensity.

headline: A Letter to the President, and a Well-Timed Response
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Vietnam War']
abstract: In June, a Marine Corps veteran who was a judge advocate during the Vietnam War wrote to President Obama, expressing concern that militants’ advances in northern Iraq might prompt the United States to send troops back there. The response he received seemed prescient.
lead_paragraph: In June, a Marine Corps veteran named David Nelson wrote a letter to President Obama expressing concern that the rapid advances of Islamist militants in northern Iraq might prompt the United States to send troops back to bolster the shaky government in Baghdad. In his letter, Mr. Nelson, who was a judge advocate during the Vietnam War, wondered whether the Obama administration might use the successes of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, or ISIS, much the way President Lyndon B. Johnson used confrontations between North Vietnamese torpedo boats and an American destroyer in August 1964 to justify expanded military action in Vietnam.

headline: A Voyage That Is Finally Complete
abstract: John Doswell and Jean Preece, who became “life partners” in the early 1970s, married on a decommissioned fireboat on the Hudson River.
lead_paragraph: As a girl in St. Petersburg, Fla., in the 1940s and ’50s, Jean Preece lived for her dance lessons and the 50-cent double feature at the local movie hall, where she sat transfixed as Gene Kelly and Debbie Reynolds cavorted in “Singin’ in the Rain.” She was so devoted to the film that years later, when she was working with a New York-based Spanish dance troupe visiting Madrid, she saw that the movie was playing in a local theater, in Spanish, and went. It did not matter that she spoke almost no Spanish; it was about the songs, the dancing. She knew what she wanted in a movie.

headline: The Murakami Effect
abstract: This week, the Book Review cover features a review of the latest novel from Haruki Murakami, who has a cult following that includes the review’s author, Patti Smith.
lead_paragraph: This week our cover features Patti Smith’s review of the new Haruki Murakami novel, “Colorless Tsukuru Tazaki and His Years of Pilgrimage.” Murakami is, of course, an internationally best-selling author with a huge following here and in Japan, where this most recent novel sold one million copies in its first week.Murakami always merits attention in the Book Review. His last book, “1Q84,” was reviewed on our cover by Kathryn Schulz, now the book critic at New York magazine. Even before we had our review assigned, we were pretty sure this new novel, which was unusually — for a major literary novel — released in the summer rather than the fall, would merit a cover review. (Even in a year when Murakami doesn’t have a new book, he can wind up in the Book Review, as he did in this delightful Sketchbook Grant Snider did for us two years ago, “Haruki Murakami Bingo.”)

headline: Where Big Stars and Little Stars Shine, for a Bargain
abstract: Stars dotted an evening at the Vail International Dance Festival, where the ticket prices matched the year: $20.14 and $14.
lead_paragraph: VAIL, Colo. — Every summer, the Vail International Dance Festival presents one evening when the prices match the year — sort of. So in 2013, all seats in the Gerald R. Ford Amphitheater were $20.13, with all places on the lawn going for $13; this year they’re $20.14 and $14. (Children 12 or under sit free on the lawn.) Obviously, this system won’t last beyond 2020, but while it does, it has extraordinary value.

headline: A Trip to the Big City
abstract: A wedding invitation initiates a terrifying journey to New York with two parents in their 80s.
lead_paragraph: I knew what I was up against the moment I opened the “Save the Date” email. It was from a childhood friend, begging me to bring my parents to her summer wedding in New York City. “It would mean so much to me to see your folks sitting in the church,” she wrote. “It would be as if my own parents were there,” she added of her now deceased mother and father.

headline: Tennessee Ignores the Koch Brothers

lead_paragraph: Participants in Tennessee’s judicial elections on Thursday rejected a malodorous effort to oust three capable sitting state Supreme Court justices: Chief Justice Gary Wade and Justices Cornelia Clark and Sharon Lee.

headline: An Old Love Story, Tinkered for the Times
abstract: Mark Morris’s ballet version of Ovid’s love story of the shepherd Acis and the sea nymph Galatea arrives in New York with some important details adjusted.
lead_paragraph: In his two-act staging of “Acis and Galatea” at the David H. Koch Theater, Mark Morris plunges his audience into the heart of the pastoral genre. He sets the love story of the shepherd Acis and the sea nymph Galatea within a landscape chorally filled with lovers. Though, on the one hand, these other people are anonymous, it’s as if they were Daphnis and Chloe, Phyllis and Corydon, and all the amorous couples created by Theocritus, Virgil, Longus and other classical authors. On the other, it’s as if they were nature itself. And so Acis and Galatea — whose story is found in the “Metamorphoses” of Ovid — become part of a long tradition of the classical idyll in which love is interrupted by death.

headline: There’s Always Someone You’re Smarter Than

One resource we have in abundance is stupidity, and television’s long history of exploiting it continues with two new shows in the next few days, one whose title is its most attention-getting feature, the other equally drab but in different ways.

headline: Khajak Keledjian: Zero to 60, and Back Again
abstract: Mr. Keledjian, 41, is the co-founder and C.E.O. of Intermix, a luxury fashion retailer. In the summer, he and his wife spend most weekends at their 4,000-square-foot home in Sagaponack, on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: Khajak Keledjian, 41, is the co-founder and C.E.O. of Intermix, a luxury fashion retailer that was sold to the Gap for $130 million in 2012. Lebanese by birth, Mr. Keledjian moved with his siblings from Beirut to Manhattan when he was a teenager. In 1993, at 19 years old, he opened the first Intermix store with his brother. Mr. Keledjian’s wife, Maryam, a former lingerie model who now works in fashion sales, is expecting their first child. In the summer, the couple spend most weekends at their 4,000-square-foot home in Sagaponack, on Long Island.

lead_paragraph: At times the battle between a group of New York hedge funds and the country of Argentina feels more like a game of legal Ping-Pong than a case involving billions of dollars at stake.

headline: Medicine Man and Mayor, Blended
abstract: On a corner in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, Robert Warner, known as Coconut Rob, sells juices that, he says, come with “a piece of who I am.”
lead_paragraph: On the corner of Fulton Street and South Elliot Place in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, there’s a distinctive summer soundtrack: the whirring of blenders, the crunch of pressed sugarcane and the occasional thwack of a machete opening a coconut.The source of it all is a nattily dressed man who, depending on the day, might be wearing a white linen suit and straw boater, a newsboy cap and striped dungarees, or a kilt. And who, like his seven-year-old juice stand, is known as Coconut Rob.

headline: Recollections, Past and Future
abstract: Chris Marker’s movies are the work of a poet and collagist and slightly obsessive philosopher.
lead_paragraph: The French filmmaker Chris Marker (1921-2012) has been described as a cine-essayist, which is true but inadequate. His movies are the work of a poet and collagist and slightly obsessive philosopher, who roams widely but keeps looping back to a potently cinematic theme: memory. BAMcinématek’s retrospective “Chris Marker” also roams widely, providing a chance for the curious to catch up on films from his best-known works, like “La Jetée” (1962), a time-traveling meditation on war and (of course) memory, made up mostly of still photographs, to “Level Five” (1997), receiving its North American theatrical premiere in a weeklong run (Friday through Aug. 21).

headline: Cashew Juice, the Apple of Pepsi’s Eye
abstract: While farmers in India once left cashew apples to rot, some are now selling them as the source of what Pepsi hopes could be the next coconut water.
lead_paragraph: RATNAGIRI DISTRICT, India — When the cashew harvest starts here, the orchards clinging to the lush, wrinkled hills are blanketed by a brilliant yellow, orange and red carpet, created after farmers pluck the nut and toss its stem to the ground. There, the cashew apples, as the stems are known, quickly rot, except for a few used to brew a local spirit called feni that is popular in neighboring Goa.

headline: Chimney Swift: Suited for Ashes and Soot
abstract: Originally denizens of old, undisturbed woodlands, the chimney swift became one of several animal species strongly associated with, and even reliant upon, human habitation.
lead_paragraph: Dark and streamlined, chimney swifts dart past, their long, stiff wings in constant motion as they chase tiny flying food like mosquitoes, gnats, flies and beetles. The birds are well named. Appearing completely black against a bright sky, when examined closely they are colored exactly as if they really had flown through a chimney — virtually uniform except for a slightly paler gray patch under their throats.
