headline: Virginia Ex-Governor’s Trial Keeps Focus on Key Donor’s Character
abstract: The corporate mentor of Jonnie R. Williams Sr., a witness in the corruption case against former Gov. Bob McDonnell, said his protégé jeopardized the company trying to curry political favor.
lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Va. — The corporate mentor of the dietary supplement executive who lavished gifts on former Gov. Bob McDonnell of Virginia denounced the businessman on Friday as someone who continually put politics above science and jeopardized his company as he tried to curry favor.

headline: Yields on 10-Year Treasuries Fall, Confounding the Experts
abstract: The 10-year Treasury note fell to 2.42 percent with some analysts contending the decline was a response to current events.
lead_paragraph: The mantra in the bond market over the last several years has been that yields will inevitably rise. From time to time, that has even been true. But not lately, and especially not on Friday.

headline: It’s a Can’t-Lose Year
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'ABORTION', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: Seriously, people. It’s only a bad year if you’re Santa Claus.
lead_paragraph: Wow, it appears that Republicans in Tennessee just gave a vote of confidence to a right-wing congressman-doctor who has a history of having sex with his patients and encouraging the women in his life to end inconvenient pregnancies by abortion.

headline: Taking the Express to Zen
abstract: Max Dixon has become known as the Train Man in his neighborhood of South Ozone Park, Queens, because of the nifty rail system he has set up in his yard.
lead_paragraph: Max Dixon — handyman, hobbyist, household tinkerer — says he has not used the subway in nearly 25 years and “couldn’t even guess what the fare is now.”

headline: 29 States Seek Tighter E-Cigarette Regulations
keywords: ['Smoking and Tobacco', 'E-Cigarettes', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'States (US)', 'Attorneys General', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: The attorneys general urged the federal government to prohibit the sale of most e-cigarette flavoring, fearing their appeal to children.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-nine state attorneys general on Friday urged the Food and Drug Administration to strengthen its proposed regulations on electronic cigarettes, a business that has exploded into a $2.5 billion industry with virtually no regulatory oversight.

headline: Half a Ton of This, Half a Ton of That: Russia Is Calm Over Food Import Bans
keywords: ['Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Food', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Retaliatory sanctions against Western products have led to a “buy Russian” campaign and some signs that there were ways around the problem.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — When the chef Jonas Grip heard that the latest Russian sanctions included banning all fish imports from Europe, he instantly called his Russian suppliers.

headline: Tiny Lead for Incumbent in Tennessee Primary Vote
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Voting and Voters', 'ADULTERY']
abstract: Representative Scott DesJarlais led State Senator Jim Tracy by 35 votes after their Republican primary on Thursday, in which more than 77,000 Tennesseans voted.
lead_paragraph: MURFREESBORO, Tenn. — Less than two years after tawdry details of his divorce and extramarital relationships burst into public view, Representative Scott DesJarlais, Republican of Tennessee, held a minuscule advantage on Friday in a primary election battle that could become a startling example of political survival.

headline: Inquiry Seeks Twitter User in Brooklyn Bridge Flag Case
abstract: A lawyer for a Twitter user who claimed responsibility for putting white flags on the bridge said the site had received a subpoena from the Manhattan district attorney’s office in a bid to identify his client.
lead_paragraph: The Twitter account purportedly representing an “all-powerful” coalition of radical cyclists has claimed responsibility for knocking out Metro-North Railroad service, swinging the World Series and strong-arming Bruce Springsteen into changing a song title to “Thunder Lane.”

headline: Speaking Openly, but Giving Conflicting Accounts of ‘Knockout Game’ Assaults
abstract: Comments by a man accused of playing a violent game in Brooklyn have tended to change.
lead_paragraph: The man accused of playing the so-called Knockout Game, sucker-punching unsuspecting strangers in Brooklyn late last year, nodded politely and held open the front door of his home on Friday.

headline: Nazi Spies and New York Perspectives
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: Looks at a book about how the F.B.I. broke up a spy ring during World War II, the Hudson Valley, and a collection of photographs of recognizable New York City sites taken from unique angles.
lead_paragraph: The opening credits to the 1945 spy thriller “The House on 92nd Street,” released just a month after Hiroshima, coyly proclaim that the film “could not be made public until the first atomic bomb was dropped on Japan.”

headline: Living, and Leaving, the Dream
abstract: Adrian Cardenas played for the Cubs in 2012; now 26 and a student at N.Y.U., he wants to be a novelist and explore the world in ways he said baseball would not allow.
lead_paragraph: Sitting in a Greenwich Village cafe one afternoon this spring, Adrian Cardenas was hunched over a laptop with a cup of coffee in one hand. With books tumbling out of a backpack on the floor next to him, he looked every bit a college student as he animatedly discussed his latest poetry.

headline: Questions on Telephone Poles and Subway Globes
abstract: Tracking down utility wires in New York City, and deciphering the meaning of the color-coded subway station bulbs.
lead_paragraph: Q. I know there are no telephone poles in Manhattan, where all utility wires are supposed to be strung underground. But how many utility poles are there in the other boroughs?

headline: Motorbikers in North Korea Are Told to Park to Save Fuel
keywords: ['Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Motorbike use by ordinary citizens has been cut to rush hours to ensure fuel for the government and the military personnel, two websites that monitor North Korea said, adding that a decline in Chinese oil imports was probably responsible.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — It is no secret that North Korea suffers chronic shortages of fuel, to the point that nighttime satellite photographs of the Korean Peninsula show a glittering south and a darkened north, beginning exactly at the 38th parallel that divides them. Now the scarcity, apparently made even worse by a drop in oil imports from China, has claimed a new class of victims: motorbike riders.

headline: Guided by History, a Jew Tries to Unite Two Faiths Divided by War in Gaza
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Prayers and Prayer Books', 'Volunteers and Community Service']
abstract: As tensions between Muslims and Jews worsen abroad, an American Jew working for an Islamic nonprofit organization has received vitriol from Jewish communities for his criticism of Israel.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK, Del. — Shortly after the latest cease-fire expired in Gaza on Friday, Jacob Bender gingerly climbed the steps of the mimbar, the pulpit at the Islamic Society of Delaware here. A Jew in a mosque, his hands palpably quivering but his reedy voice steady, he read some brief comments to close the afternoon’s worship service, called Juma’a.

headline: Massachusetts: Health Site Will Stay State-Based
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Officials said Friday that they would use a retooled state health exchange website for this fall’s open enrollment period.
lead_paragraph: Officials said Friday that they would use a retooled state health exchange website for this fall’s open enrollment period. The Massachusetts Health Connector was established by the state’s 2006 health overhaul law, but it sputtered when it was updated to comply with the Affordable Care Act, sending 250,000 people to temporary coverage. In the spring, Connector officials decided to buy new software for the state health insurance marketplace while preparing to join the federal exchange if necessary. They met Thursday with federal officials, who supported the decision to move forward with the state-based exchange. Connector officials plan to contact up to 450,000 individuals, including those with temporary or legacy coverage, who need to apply this fall for plans that comply with the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Dashing Good Looks With a Menu to Match
abstract: The Inn at Pound Ridge by Jean-Georges, with its keen attention to detail and its bountiful expenditure of resources to get things right, should quell critics who deride the trend in name-chef empire building.
lead_paragraph: On a November night swirling with snow, weeks before the Inn at Pound Ridge by Jean-Georges opened, I caught a glimpse of white toques bobbing under bright lights in the new kitchen as I drove past. The late hour, and the formality of the toques, somehow spoke to the seriousness of the enterprise.

headline: De Blasio to Gather Clergy on Police-Community Divide
abstract: Bill de Blasio and his aides are hoping this meeting will be more effective than one last month, where the Rev. Al Sharpton’s comments undercut the mayor’s attempt to ease tensions.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio, under increasing pressure to contain an escalating controversy over aggressive policing, said on Friday that he would convene a meeting of religious leaders led by Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan to “heal and deepen” the relationship between the police and community leaders.

headline: Turkey Votes for a President
abstract: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan Erdogan is considered the leading candidate as Turkey conducts its first direct election for president.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan Erdogan is considered the leading candidate as Turkey conducts its first direct election for president.

headline: Frustrated and Clutching His Back, Woods Misses the Cut
abstract: Tiger Woods struggled through back pain during the second round of the P.G.A. Championship and missed the cut for only the fourth time in 66 major championships as a professional.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Whether Tiger Woods would, or even should, play in this week’s P.G.A. Championship generated a great deal of debate, given the state of his back. But the poor state of his game over 36 holes at Valhalla Golf Club, the site of one of his most notable victories, left little doubt that 2014 would go down as another lost season for him.

headline: Turkey’s Premier Tries to Keep Power, as President
abstract: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan is expected to win Sunday’s presidential vote and transform an office that has been largely ceremonial.
lead_paragraph: ANKARA, Turkey — Just before Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s motorcade swept into the airport here, workers rolled up a red carpet that had been used for the departing president and put down a turquoise one for Mr. Erdogan.

headline: New Jersey Republican Killed in Apparent Murder-Suicide
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: Joan Bramhall had served alongside Gov. Chris Christie in the 1990s as a freeholder in Morris County.
lead_paragraph: A former county clerk who served as a Republican freeholder alongside Gov. Chris Christie in the 1990s was found dead in her home this week with her husband in what the authorities said Friday was an apparent murder-suicide.

headline: Out-of-State Clinic Is Central in Texas Abortion Law Fight
abstract: The state’s reliance on the New Mexico clinic is being disparaged by the law’s critics, who say that would be contrary to a recent abortion ruling in Mississippi.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Of all the clinics and facilities at the center of a federal lawsuit challenging Texas’ sweeping abortion law passed last year, one has stuck out.

headline: A Water-Propelled Jetpack
abstract: Jetpack America instructors and their customers fly over water in Newport Beach Harbor.
lead_paragraph: Jetpack America instructors and their customers fly over water in Newport Beach Harbor.

headline: New York Settles Lawsuit Over Man Killed by Police Car
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Police']
abstract: The family of Tamon Robinson, who was killed in 2012 by a patrol car at a housing project in Brooklyn, is still calling for charges against the officers who were driving the car.
lead_paragraph: The family of Tamon Robinson, who was killed two years ago by a patrol car at a housing project in Canarsie, Brooklyn, has reached a $2 million wrongful-death settlement with New York City.

headline: Thrill Ride Flies in the Face of Gravity, as Well as Cautious Officials
keywords: ['Jetpacks', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Noise', 'Boats and Boating', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'AMUSEMENT AND THEME PARKS', 'Gravitation and Gravity']
abstract: Instruction, rental and sale of jetpacks has proved popular for a company in Newport Beach, Calif., and other shorefront communities.
lead_paragraph: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif. — When the jetpacks first began flying here a few years ago, they were their own best form of advertising. Residents and tourists would see a person strapped to a small water-propelled rocket, whooshing high above the ocean, then wander into the small storefront tucked behind a bayside dock and ask, “Can I do that, too?”

headline: Keep Planes a Quiet Space
abstract: Passengers do not really need to make phone calls at 30,000 feet.
lead_paragraph: Cellphones have provided humanity with many benefits. They have also enabled the most annoying among us to find new ways to disturb the peace in all sorts of public places, like trains, theaters and restaurants. One shared space that has heretofore been protected from the chattering of cellphone users may soon join that list: airplanes.

headline: Spot on U.S. Ryder Cup Team Is Possibility for Stricker
abstract: Not expected to be a competitive member of the squad, Steve Stricker improved his chances by shooting a 68 that placed him just four strokes off the lead at the P.G.A. Championship.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Among those making a charge at Rory McIlroy in the second round of the P.G.A. Championship was 47-year-old Steve Stricker, who, earlier this week, was picked as an assistant captain on the United States Ryder Cup team. That was meant to signal that Stricker, who now plays sparingly on the PGA Tour, would not likely be a competitive member of the team.

headline: A Misguided Tobacco Proposal
keywords: ['Smoking and Tobacco', 'Editorials', 'E-Cigarettes', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The F.D.A. should abandon its “lost pleasure” approach before issuing a rule regulating electronic cigarettes, cigars and other tobacco products.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration has received thousands of comments on a proposed rule to regulate electronic cigarettes, cigars and other tobacco products. Among its important criteria is a cost-benefit analysis that strikes us as misguided, if not absurd.

headline: Keeping Track: Another Labor Suit for Apple, Stop-and-Frisk
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Search and Seizure', 'Workplace Environment', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Apple faced another labor related class-action suit, while the City of New York tries to close the book on the Police Department’s stop-and-frisk program.
lead_paragraph: Apple’s Labor Violations

headline: Judge Backs New Limits on North Carolina Voting
abstract: A federal judge rejected an effort to block a state law that opponents said will disproportionately hinder African-American voters.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — A federal judge in North Carolina on Friday rejected an effort by civil rights groups and the Justice Department to block the application of key elements of a Republican-backed state law that curtailed early voting and other opportunities for residents to cast their ballots.

headline: In Pursuit of the Perfect Pie
abstract: With the help of a posse of pie lovers, George Blecher scoured the North and South Forks for baked masterpieces.
lead_paragraph: For 40 years or more, I’ve been on a search for the perfect pie. Part of it may be false nostalgia: Mom was no pie maker, and the only pies that I remember from my childhood were the gummy but delicious slices behind the peepholes of Horn & Hardart’s Automat.

headline: Arrest in New Jersey Boy’s Death Stirs Memories, but Mysteries Remain
abstract: Among the questions left unanswered when Michelle Lodzinski was charged this week with killing her 5-year-old son, Timothy Wiltsey, 23 years ago: What led the authorities to charge her with the boy’s murder after all this time?
lead_paragraph: Michelle Lodzinski’s screams rose above the din of clanging rides and carnival games. It was a spring evening in 1991, and she told anyone who was listening that she had brought her 5-year-old son to the carnival in Sayreville, N.J. Now, he was missing.

headline: Florida Redraws an Election Map That Was Ruled to Be Unconstitutional
abstract: With Florida’s election schedule in disarray after a judge ruled the state’s congressional map unconstitutional, lawmakers on Friday approved redesigned districts — drawn in private by the two Republican committee heads, their staff and outside lawyers.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — With Florida’s election schedule in disarray after a judge ruled the state’s congressional map unconstitutional, state lawmakers moved one step closer to resolving the uncertainty during a special session on Friday in Tallahassee.

headline: To Curb Drug Use, an Electronic Music Concert in Brooklyn Restricts What Guests Can Bring
abstract: In the wake of several deaths related to Ecstasy, the Mad Decent Block Party this weekend will prohibit masks, pacifiers, dolls, eyedroppers, spray paint, unsealed tampons and other items.
lead_paragraph: After a series of drug-related deaths at electronic dance music concerts across the country and in Canada, an unusual set of safety measures has been put in place for a similar outdoor show scheduled for Saturday in Coney Island.

headline: Swinging Joints
abstract: A twisty puzzle by Josh Knapp that temporarily gave me a boost of self-confidence before tearing me apart completely. But that’s O.K.; it’s Saturday, and that’s as it should be.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — I prematurely gave myself a big head by starting in the northwestern sector of Josh Knapp’s twisty Saturday puzzle. Once I had that filled in, however, things sort of crawled to a snail’s pace — as opposed to a NAUTILUS’s — and it took me much longer to finish the puzzle than I had anticipated, considering that it only had 64 entries.

headline: Obama on the World
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Palestinians', 'Kurds', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Sunni Muslims', 'International Relations', 'Shiite Muslims', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: In a wide-ranging interview, the president explains American policy on Iraq, Putin and the Israelis and Palestinians.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s hair is definitely grayer these days, and no doubt trying to manage foreign policy in a world of increasing disorder accounts for at least half of those gray hairs. (The Tea Party can claim the other half.) But having had a chance to spend an hour touring the horizon with him in the White House Map Room late Friday afternoon, it’s clear that the president has a take on the world, born of many lessons over the last six years, and he has feisty answers for all his foreign policy critics.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Aug. 8, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Obama on Israel
abstract: Thomas L. Friedman asks President Obama if he is worried about Israel’s survival. This is an excerpt of the full interview.
lead_paragraph: Thomas L. Friedman asks President Obama if he is worried about Israel’s survival. This is an excerpt of the full interview.

headline: Obama on America’s Place in the World
abstract: President Obama talks to Thomas L. Friedman about how ​the United States can be a benevolent force as well as a superpower. This is an excerpt of the full interview.
lead_paragraph: President Obama talks to Thomas L. Friedman about how ​the United States can be a benevolent force as well as a superpower. This is an excerpt of the full interview.

headline: Differences Between Israel and U.N. Over Gaza Episodes Go Back Years
abstract: Israeli attacks on United Nations facilities are repeating a pattern that an agency board of inquiry reported in 2009. Israel says it is addressing the issues.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Israel said Gaza militants had been firing from inside what it called a booby-trapped United Nations school. Its forces responded with mortar rounds that exploded in front of the school, wounding seven people who had taken shelter inside and killing many more outside.

headline: This Is Reform?
abstract: The real reformer is Judge Claudia Wilken, not the college sports establishment.
lead_paragraph: TOO little, too late.

headline: A Front Line Against Ebola Runs Through Newark’s Terminal B
abstract: Erica J. Sison, the head quarantine officer at Newark Airport, has been on an increased lookout for symptoms of Ebola since a outbreak in West Africa that has killed nearly 1,000 people.
lead_paragraph: Erica J. Sison has dealt with sick and dead dogs and cats, 40 dead lab rats in bags, trophy animals, cooked monkey meat on sticks, human skulls from Indonesia and a live Asian bat that flew out of an airplane cargo hold.

headline: When a Car Loan Means Bankruptcy
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Editorials', 'Consumer Protection', 'Credit and Debt', 'Automobile Financing', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The federal government must crack down on the auto lending industry’s all-too-common risky and deceptive practices.
lead_paragraph: The mortgage industry set the stage for the recession by luring people into ruinously priced loans they could never hope to repay, then selling those loans to Wall Street in mortgage-backed securities that went bad. The federal government has since tamed that industry, outlawing most of the risky and deceptive practices that led to that crisis. It must now do the same with the auto lending industry, where the practice of roping people into loans that damage them financially is all too common.

headline: A Spot for Local Tastes and Good Cheer
abstract: Oak Haven Table & Bar, in New Haven, uses a local-and-seasonal approach to its menu.
lead_paragraph: In an ideal world, a restaurant should function not just as a place to eat, but as a hub for kinship and connection. By that logic, an eatery that enlivens and elevates a community deserves special recognition, even if what’s happening in the kitchen isn’t always magical.

headline: Bankruptcy Judge Gets View of Detroit Outside Courtroom
abstract: A three-hour excursion for officials and creditors that was intended to show the disparate faces of a financially troubled city.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Judge Steven W. Rhodes, who is overseeing Detroit’s reorganization in federal bankruptcy court, took a bus tour of the city on Friday, ahead of hearings later this month on a proposed plan of adjustment.

headline: While Offering Support, Obama Warns That U.S. Won’t Be ‘Iraqi Air Force’
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The president, addressing critics in both parties, asserted that the United States has a “strategic interest in pushing back” ISIS.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama said Friday that he was open to supporting a sustained effort to drive Sunni militants out of Iraq if Iraqi leaders form a more inclusive government, even as he vowed that the United States had no intention of “being the Iraqi air force.”

headline: O’Bannon Case Decision
abstract: Judge Claudia Wilken’s 99-page decision issued a resounding rebuke to the foundation of the N.C.A.A., issuing an injunction against current rules that prohibit athletes from earning money from the use of their names and images in video games and television broadcasts.
lead_paragraph: Judge Claudia Wilken’s 99-page decision issued a resounding rebuke to the foundation of the N.C.A.A., issuing an injunction against current rules that prohibit athletes from earning money from the use of their names and images in video games and television broadcasts.

headline: Fear of ‘Another Benghazi’ Drove White House to Airstrikes in Iraq
keywords: ['Benghazi Attack (2012)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: Interviews with multiple officials in the Obama administration paint a portrait of a president forced by the unexpectedly rapid deterioration of security in Iraq to abandon his longstanding reluctance to use military force.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On Wednesday evening, moments after finishing a summit meeting with African leaders at the State Department, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff delivered a stark message to President Obama as they rode back to the White House in Mr. Obama’s limousine.

headline: Rudderless Craft to Get Glimpse of Home Before Sinking Into Space’s Depths
abstract: The International Sun-Earth Explorer-3 will pass about 9,700 miles from the surface of the moon at 2:16 p.m. Eastern time Sunday.
lead_paragraph: A 36-year-old NASA spacecraft, still largely in working condition, will zip through Earth’s neighborhood on Sunday for the first time in decades before receding again into the solar system.

headline: A World Desperate for a Little Good News
abstract: Boiling points in Iraq, Gaza and Ukraine accompany the spread of a disease in West Africa.
lead_paragraph: “The world is too much with us,” wrote the poet, a sentiment President Obama most likely shared this past week as he reluctantly ordered warplanes back over Iraq. As he did so, another Israeli-Palestinian cease-fire ended in resumed bombardment, Vladimir V. Putin defiantly ordered his own sanctions against the West and a terrible virus spread farther through West Africa.

headline: Love Reaches the Technologically Challenged
abstract: “Lucky Me,” romantic comedy written by Robert Caisley that is receiving its premiere at the New Jersey Repertory Company in Long Branch, involves a cranky father and two 40-somethings with a blossoming romance.
lead_paragraph: When Leo went to an eye doctor, he says, he was told that there was good news and bad. The bad news was that he would soon be blind. And the good news? “I didn’t have to renew my prescription.”

headline: What the O’Bannon Ruling Means for Colleges and Players
keywords: ['College Athletics', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The landmark decision may cost the N.C.A.A. hundreds of millions of dollars, but it may not create a windfall for any individual athlete.
lead_paragraph: The landmark decision in the so-called O’Bannon case that found that the N.C.A.A. violated antitrust laws may be precedent setting and may ultimately cost colleges hundreds of millions of dollars. But it is unlikely to create a windfall for any individual athlete. In her 99-page decision, Judge Claudia Wilken laid out the justification for her injunction.

headline: China Looks to High-Speed Rail to Expand Reach
abstract: For China, the strategic importance of a proposed line can barely be overstated: It would provide an alternate to the longer and increasingly contentious trip through the South China Sea.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A favorite export from China to its neighbors these days are high-speed rail lines designed to make trade routes in the vast stretches of Asia more accessible and fortify Chinese dreams of turning its southern reaches into the capital of mainland Southeast Asia.

headline: Idris Muhammad, Drummer Whose Beat Still Echoes, Dies at 74
abstract: Mr. Muhammad was there at the intersection of jazz, R&B and funk, especially in the pivotal 1970s and for the original Broadway production of “Hair.”
lead_paragraph: Idris Muhammad, a drummer whose deep groove propelled both a broad career in jazz and an array of hits spanning rhythm and blues, funk and soul, died on July 29 in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 74.

headline: Fiddling and Matchmaking, 50 Years Later
abstract: The Goodspeed Opera House’s triumphant production of “Fiddler on the Roof” in East Haddam manages to be both reverent and utterly fresh.
lead_paragraph: In the theater, some things are sacrosanct. Nobody will cut Hamlet’s “To be or not to be” speech. Godot will never arrive. And there will always be a bottle dance in “Fiddler on the Roof.” Moreover, it will bring down the house, as it did when the show opened on Broadway 50 years ago and as it does in the tender, impeccable revival at the Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam.

headline: ‘The Knick’ Recap: Blood, Scalpels and a Good Dose of Racism for 1900 New York
abstract: The camera doesn’t shy away from blood and viscera, but doesn’t put them right in your face, either.
lead_paragraph: Season 1, Episode 1, “Method and Madness”

headline: Lessons From Libya
abstract: Barack Obama discusses what he’s learned about foreign policy during his presidency. This is an excerpt of his full video interview with Thomas L. Friedman.
lead_paragraph: Barack Obama discusses what he’s learned about foreign policy during his presidency. This is an excerpt of his full video interview with Thomas L. Friedman.

headline: Before Victory, Mets Look to Future With Decision on Shortstop
abstract: The Mets announced that Wilmer Flores would play shortstop for the last seven weeks of the season, a subtle sign that the team had shifted its gaze toward 2015.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Over the All-Star break, Wilmer Flores walked into a parlor in Las Vegas and got his first tattoo. He decided on a bracelet design that wrapped around his right wrist. He had no particular reason for going, and the design carried no significance.

headline: Flugelhorns and Fame, by Way of Serbia
abstract: The documentary “Brasslands” will be shown Aug. 21 at the Jacob Burns Film Center in Pleasantville.
lead_paragraph: Michael Ginsburg, a lean man with a lifetime of teaching gym behind him, might at first seem more suited to the ball field than the bandstand, knocking out Balkan tunes. But as he worked his way through a selection of such tunes last month, coaxing an expertly controlled vibrato and adroitly turned ornaments out of his rotary valve flugelhorn, the Yonkers resident was clearly in his element.

headline: Phelps Shakes Off Rust in His Favorite Event
abstract: Michael Phelps finished second in the 100-meter butterfly at the USA Swimming long-course championships, earning a berth on the United States team for the Pan Pacific Championships.
lead_paragraph: IRVINE, Calif. — Linus van Pelt, the Peanuts character, has his blue blanket; Michael Phelps, the swimming star, has the 100-meter butterfly. There is no greater source of security for Phelps, the three-time reigning Olympic champion in the event who has had a lock on the world record for the past five years, including the 18 months he spent retired.

headline: Iraqis’ Squandered Opportunities
abstract: President Obama explains that the United States military cannot do for the Iraqis what they won’t do for themselves. This is an excerpt of a full video interview.
lead_paragraph: President Obama explains that the United States military cannot do for the Iraqis what they won’t do for themselves. This is an excerpt of a full video interview.

headline: Chapman Pincher, Fleet St. Scoop Specialist, Dies at 100
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'News and News Media', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Nuclear Tests']
abstract: Mr. Pincher was a journalist whose career was spent unearthing exclusive stories from the world of double agents and secret weapons.
lead_paragraph: Chapman Pincher was ballyhooed by his own newspaper, The London Daily Express, as the world’s greatest reporter, and he introduced himself as such. He insinuated himself into the murky world of spy chiefs, generals, politicians and royalty by taking them to lunch at a fine French restaurant, say, or joining them for pheasant hunting and salmon fishing.

headline: A Soundtrack for His Ears Only
abstract: “My Life Is a Musical” at the Bay Street Theater in Sag Harbor is Adam Overett’s inspired new musical.
lead_paragraph: In a flashback to an experience when he was 7 years old, Parker, the bewildered hero of “My Life Is a Musical,” discovers that he is apparently the only person who hears people bursting into song all around him every day. His mother tries to teach him the difference between song and spoken conversation by demonstrating: “This is singing. This is talking.” But the audience hears her as he does, trilling with operatic abandon (in a funny performance by Wendi Bergamini) during the second sentence as well as the first.

headline: China as a Free Rider
abstract: President Obama on how the United States is a different sort of superpower from China. This is an excerpt of a full video interview by Thomas L. Friedman.
lead_paragraph: President Obama on how the United States is a different sort of superpower from China. This is an excerpt of a full video interview by Thomas L. Friedman.

headline: Yankees Continue to Use Stadium to Their Advantage
abstract: The Yankees improved their home record to 29-27, and 11-4 since the All-Star break, with a victory over Cleveland that was fueled by two five-run innings.
lead_paragraph: Through the end of its 85-year tenure, the old Yankee Stadium remained a place where opposing teams feared playing. The lore grew to the point that ghosts were rumored to inhabit the building.

headline: Corrections: August 9, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on August 9, 2014.
lead_paragraph: BUSINESS DAY

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, August 9, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, August 9, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “Fifty percent of my questions are about why their hair is not falling out. It is the zillionth time I have answered it.”

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (Starz) OUTLANDER Claire Randall (Caitriona Balfe, above), an English combat nurse, touches a druid monument while on her honeymoon in Scotland and is transported back to the 18th century, where she’s kidnapped by Highlanders and meets the sensitive hunk Jamie (Sam Heughan) in this new series, adapted from the novels by Diana Gabaldon. “The ‘Outlander’ books date to 1991, but it seems likely that TV executives looked at them and thought, oh, ‘Game of Thrones’ meets ‘Downton Abbey,’ ” Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times. “Ms. Balfe, Mr. Heughan and Tobias Menzies as the modern husband (who also pops up, inconveniently, in 1743) acquit themselves well, sharing the screen with the scenery and costumes and keeping straight faces through all the fantasy-romance conceits. They seem to be having a good time, and if you have a weakness for muskets, accents and the occasional roll in the heather, you probably will too.”

headline: Analytics: Common Denominators
abstract: Elizabeth Green’s article on Americans’ struggles with math received more than 940 comments online. Here’s what readers said.
lead_paragraph: The following Analytics appears on the Reply All page in the Aug. 10 issue of the magazine.

headline: 2 Hawaii Democrats Face Tough Primary Challenges
abstract: With Hawaiians voting Saturday, Gov. Neil Abercrombie has trailed in almost every recent poll, and Senator Brian Schatz is locked in a tight contest.
lead_paragraph: HONOLULU — With two hurricanes bearing down toward his state, Gov. Neil Abercrombie refused to discuss this weekend’s Democratic primary election in which he is fighting to preserve his political life.

headline: Obsessed? Bewildered? Ask Dr. Mahinder Watsa
abstract: A selection of questions and answers from the Ask the Sexpert Column in The Mumbai Mirror.
lead_paragraph: For nine years, Mahinder Watsa, 90, has been shocking Indian sensibilities with his Ask the Sexpert column for The Mumbai Mirror. Tens of thousands of people have sought advice on a variety of issues, including the size and shape of penises, fears of masturbation and hymen reconstruction. Following are selections from his correspondence published in The Mumbai Mirror and a site created by his fans.

headline: At Bletchley Park, a Reminder About the History of Cracking Codes
abstract: Bletchley Park, once Britain’s highly classified government center for code breaking during World War II, now invites curious guests who want to poke around and learn its secrets.
lead_paragraph: Hackers are regularly in the news these days for cracking secret codes, so it’s sometimes easy to forget that breaking codes has a long history. The newly restored Bletchley Park heritage site in Britain offers a nice reminder.

headline: Dispute Between Amazon and Hachette Takes an Orwellian Turn
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'E-Books and Readers', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: The retailer suggests that writers who do not support it are holding back the future. But mistakenly accusing one of the 20th century’s most famous authors of collusion will probably not help its cause.
lead_paragraph: Maybe Amazon really is rattled by the whole Authors United phenomenon organized by Douglas Preston. The writers are encouraging their readers to email Jeff Bezos, the Amazon chief executive, and tell him to stop holding books hostage as the company negotiates with Hachette Book Group.

headline: Iraq Airstrikes May Continue for Months, Obama Says
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Kurds', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Military Aircraft', 'Terrorism']
abstract: President Obama sought to prepare Americans for an extended presence in the skies over Iraq, saying the airstrikes he ordered last week, which continued Saturday, could last months.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama said on Saturday that the airstrikes and humanitarian assistance drops he ordered last week in Iraq could go on for months, preparing Americans for an extended military presence in the skies there as Iraq’s leaders try to build a new government.

headline: Libertarian Fantasies
abstract: No, we’re not living in an Ayn Rand novel.
lead_paragraph: Robert Draper’s long magazine piece about the possibility of a “libertarian moment” has drawn a fair bit of commentary; much of it involves questioning the supposed polling evidence. As Jonathan Chait points out, independent polling — as opposed to surveys conducted by libertarians seeking to boost their own profile — suggests that young Americans are actually much more pro-government than their elders. They may look relatively kindly on anti-war libertarians, but they really don’t support the policy agenda.

headline: Sarah Barnett of SundanceTV: Your Imperfection Can Be Your Strength
abstract: The president of a cable and satellite network says “there’s a certain liberation and relief” in having a company culture that allows for mistakes.
lead_paragraph: This interview with  Sarah Barnett, president of SundanceTV, a cable and satellite network owned by AMC Networks, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Thrills, Chills and Memories
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Careers and Professions', 'AMUSEMENT AND THEME PARKS']
abstract: Raheem Echols, who grew up in Coney Island, is now a supervising ride operator at Luna Park there.
lead_paragraph: Raheem Echols, 24, is a supervising ride operator at Luna Park, on the site of the former Astroland amusement park at Coney Island, Brooklyn.

headline: Living Like the Kardashians, via Smartphone
abstract: A fantasy game, “Kim Kardashian: Hollywood,” pushes players to build their own celebrity and business prowess.
lead_paragraph: It was quite a glamorous weekend. First, I flew to Los Angeles to star in a commercial for athletic wear. Then I flew right back to New York, where I met my handsome boyfriend, Christian, a famous music producer, for a romantic date at our favorite nightspot. That was all on Saturday. On Sunday, I jetted off to Miami with my entourage for a glitzy club appearance.

headline: The Trucking Industry Needs More Drivers. Maybe It Needs to Pay More.
keywords: ['Wages and Salaries', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy', 'Trucks and Trucking']
abstract: While the trucking industry complains of too few qualified drivers, inflation-adjusted wages for those behind the wheel have fallen 6 percent over the past decade.
lead_paragraph: Swift Transportation’s 20,000 workers haul goods in almost 14,000 big-rig trucks that travel the interstates and back roads of the United States every day. The company’s performance is closely tied to the nation’s economy, which has been looking increasingly sunny lately.

headline: Where Surfboards Meet Whiteboards
abstract: The office of a Wells Fargo executive in San Francisco shows his surfer side — while offering a sweeping bay view.
lead_paragraph: Steve Ellis is the executive vice president and head of the wholesale services group at Wells Fargo in San Francisco.

headline: Israelis and Gazans Clash, but Fighting Is More Subdued
abstract: With a temporary cease-fire expired, Israel said it had struck more than 30 targets, and militants fired almost a dozen rockets from Gaza.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Cross-border hostilities between Gaza and Israel continued on Saturday, a day after a temporary cease-fire expired. But the simmering exchanges were on a lower scale than the fighting that has raged for most of the last month, as Egyptian-brokered efforts continued for a new cease-fire and a resumption of talks on a more durable end to the conflict.

headline: A Corporate Tax Break That’s Closer to Home
keywords: ['Corporate Taxes', 'Tax Shelters', 'Real Estate Investment Trusts', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Real Estate (Commercial)']
abstract: By allowing a telecom company to spin off part of itself into a real estate investment trust, the I.R.S. has opened a window to a way for many corporations to have lower tax bills.
lead_paragraph: Rage is rising over American corporations that chop their tax bills by acquiring entities in lower-tax countries. Medtronic, AbbVie and Mylan have all announced such plans — known as inversions — in recent months. And Walgreen was poised to relocate to Switzerland after it completes its purchase of Alliance Boots, but did an about-face last week in the face of widespread denunciation.

headline: Fee for Dumping the Furniture
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Rent Control and Stabilization']
abstract: Answers to questions about furniture disposal, liability for water damage and repairs in rent-stabilized apartments.
lead_paragraph: Ask Real Estate is a weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: When She Talks, Banks Shudder
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In a quest for tougher rules on banking, Anat R. Admati, an industry gadfly, is rapidly gaining a broader audience.
lead_paragraph: Bankers are nearly unanimous on the subject of Anat R. Admati, the Stanford finance professor and persistent industry gadfly: Her ideas are wildly impractical, bad for the American economy and not to be taken seriously.

headline: Obama Says Iraq Airstrike Effort Could Be Long-Term
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: President Obama sought to prepare Americans for an extended operation to aid thousands of refugees and to drive back militants in Iraq.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama sought to prepare Americans for an extended presence in the skies over Iraq, telling reporters on Saturday that the airstrikes he ordered this week could go on for months as Iraqis try to build a new government.

headline: Oversize Expectations for the Airbus A380
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'International Trade and World Market', 'AIRPORTS', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Why is the giant A380 jet wowing passengers, but not many airlines? Its maker may have made the wrong bet on air travel’s future.
lead_paragraph: To get a sense of the Airbus A380’s size and ambition, walk up the grand staircase of an Emirates version of the aircraft, past the showers and the first-class suites and then through endless rows in business class to the bar at the back of the upper deck. This sleek semicircle, alluringly underlit and fully stocked with pricey spirits like Grey Goose vodka, is undoubtedly one of the defining features of this aircraft, which can hold more than 500 passengers. The plane dwarfs every commercial jet in the skies.

headline: What, No Teddy Bear?
abstract: Hotels offer new ways to help their guests get a good night’s rest.
lead_paragraph: One of the biggest luxuries in a time-pressed world might just be a good night’s sleep, and now hotels are offering new ways to help their guests get the best rest possible, often with a dose of wellness before bedtime.

headline: Variety: An Unpredictable Acrostic
abstract: An acrostic by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon that starts out on one topic, then yields to another.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — As someone who writes every day, my honest reaction to this week’s quote was a loud “Amen!” It’s always comforting to know that a genius like RAY BRADBURY also struggled to conjure up his Muse. And it’s a good reminder not to give up if IDEAS are elusive.

headline: As ISIS Militants Exert Their Control, U.S. Pursues a Military Middle Road
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Yazidi (Religious Sect)']
abstract: In carrying out limited airstrikes, the United States is trying to contain the threat posed by Islamic militants but not break their hold on northern and western Iraq.
lead_paragraph: In carrying out limited airstrikes in Iraq, the Obama administration is pursuing a strategy that attempts to contain the threat posed by Islamic militants but that does not seek to break their hold on northern and western Iraq.

headline: Watson Wants His Team to Have a Trait He’s Never Lacked: Heart
abstract: Tom Watson, the 64-year-old captain of the United States Ryder Cup team, is making his 33rd and probably final appearance in the P.G.A. Championship, the only major he has never won.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Tom Watson’s slacks were covered by dark rain pants on a wet Friday morning at Valhalla Golf Club, but his shirt and golf glove were yellow. That look would have been at home during the 1970s, when Watson was forging his reputation as one of the best golfers born after World War II.

headline: For Refugees on Mountain, ‘No Water, Nothing’
abstract: After fleeing from ISIS, the Yazidis, a tiny religious minority, are caught up in a larger refugee disaster occurring across Iraq, one that is hitting Kurdistan especially hard.
lead_paragraph: FISHKHABOUR, Iraq — Amid the low scrub on Mount Sinjar in northern Iraq, new piles of loose stones mark a bleak landscape: makeshift graves for scores, perhaps hundreds, of Yazidis, left behind by survivors desperate to find an escape from the Sunni militant fighters chasing them.

headline: A Paternal Touch Yields a Smooth Swing
abstract: The Indians’ Michael Brantley, known for his consistent swing and professionalism, learned from his father, Mickey, a former major league hitting coach.
lead_paragraph: Hitters change their swings subtly throughout a season, with slight alterations that can make a big difference. Most of these are unintentional, but inevitable.

headline: Tracing Ebola’s Breakout to an African 2-Year-Old
abstract: The current Ebola outbreak, the largest ever, seems likely to surpass all previous known Ebola outbreaks combined, and epidemiologists predict it will take months to control.
lead_paragraph: Patient Zero in the Ebola outbreak, researchers suspect, was a 2-year-old boy who died on Dec. 6, just a few days after falling ill in a village in Guéckédou, in southeastern Guinea. Bordering Sierra Leone and Liberia, Guéckédou is at the intersection of three nations, where the disease found an easy entry point to the region.

headline: Can Family Leave Policies Be Too Generous? It Seems So
keywords: ['Family Leaves', 'Women and Girls', 'Work-Life Balance', 'Parenting', 'Paid Time Off', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: In countries with family-friendly policies, women are likelier to stay in the labor force, but less likely to reach positions of real power.
lead_paragraph: When measured by who holds a job, American women are falling behind women in other developed countries. Yet the American women who are working tend to have more high-achieving careers. Within that paradox lies a puzzle about how to shape maternity leave.

headline: President Obama’s Statement on Iraq
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'International Relations']
abstract: President Obama said on Saturday that airstrikes he ordered in northern Iraq had destroyed arms and equipment held by Islamic State forces but that it will be a long-term project.
lead_paragraph: President Obama said on Saturday that airstrikes he ordered in northern Iraq had destroyed arms and equipment held by Islamic State forces but that it will be a long-term project.

headline: Informant Debate Renewed as Air Force Revisits Cadet Misconduct
keywords: ['Informers', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Sex Crimes', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: The announcement of an investigation into misconduct by student athletes at the United States Air Force Academy reopened questions about a discontinued informant program.
lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS — Eric Thomas was a third-string linebacker at the United States Air Force Academy who also played a far more secretive role on campus: He was a confidential informant, one of dozens of student spies assigned by the academy in the past decade to investigate drug use and sexual misconduct.

headline: Ukraine Strategy Bets on Restraint by Russia
abstract: Despite growing jitters in the West, Ukraine’s military leaders said they were making a well-calculated gamble, betting that Vladimir V. Putin of Russia felt he had too much to lose to invade.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — The warnings from the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the White House over the past week could not have been graver in tone: The Russian Army, they said, had massed enough forces on the border with Ukraine to invade.

headline: Soaking Up Catalina, Tourists Pose a Dilemma
abstract: Twenty-two miles across the sea, California’s Catalina Island, once starved for tourists, must now welcome them cautiously during a drought.
lead_paragraph: AVALON, Calif. — Just an hourlong ferry ride from Los Angeles, Catalina Island is enjoying a renaissance. After years of declining tourism, businesses here have spent more than $40 million updating this quaint island town. Hotels have been remodeled and new restaurants added. A zip line overlooking the ocean was installed. The beach — long among the dirtiest in California, befouled by an aging sewer system — was cleaned up.

headline: Deadly Clashes With Police Erupt at Pakistan Protests
abstract: A second day of confrontations between Pakistani police and supporters of Tahir-ul Qadri, a cleric who opposes Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, left at least two people dead and several hundred injured.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Violent clashes between the police and opponents of Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif swept across Pakistan’s Punjab Province on Saturday, leaving at least two people dead and more than 100 injured as Mr. Sharif’s 14-month-old government sought to forestall a series of planned street protests aimed at ousting it.

headline: Despite Failure, Campaign to Oust Tennessee Justices Keeps Conservatives Hopeful
keywords: ['Supreme Courts (State)', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'States (US)', 'Elections, Courts and the Judiciary', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: The effort to remove three jurists from the State Supreme Court swayed voters despite having no single rallying issue — an encouraging development for activists targeting the judiciary.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — When a Tennessee Supreme Court justice who had been targeted for defeat by conservative groups and business interests declared victory on Thursday night, it did not take long for grateful sentiments to give way to a bit of swagger.

headline: McCain Says Limited U.S. Strikes on Militants in Iraq Are Not Enough
abstract: Senator John McCain said he would favor sending combat air controllers into Iraq to help identify airstrike targets and expand the operation into Syria.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s authorization of limited military operations against militants in Iraq is not enough to counter a growing threat to the United States from “the richest, most powerful terrorist organization in history,” Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, said on Saturday.

headline: After Flight, a Fight to Survive in Iraq
abstract: A refugee crisis has struck Iraqi Kurdistan, once the most stable part of the country, as Sunni militants have advanced.
lead_paragraph: A refugee crisis has struck Iraqi Kurdistan, once the most stable part of the country, as Sunni militants have advanced.

headline: Vikings’ Temporary Home Rife With Gophers
abstract: The Minnesota Vikings of the N.F.L. are expected to play two seasons at the University of Minnesota’s TCF Bank Stadium while their new home is under construction.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Rick Thomet bought his first Minnesota Vikings season tickets in 1971, when he was 16 years old. One of the most noteworthy plays in Vikings history happened in front of his section at Metropolitan Stadium — the 50-yard touchdown catch by Dallas Cowboys wide receiver Drew Pearson that eliminated the Vikings in a 1975 playoff game. Vikings fans insist Pearson pushed cornerback Nate Wright to get open.

headline: Nina Hoss
abstract: An actress on hiking in Switzerland, singing a duet at Glastonbury and the guilty pleasure of reality TV.
lead_paragraph: Nina Hoss is a German actress. Her most recent film is the adaptation of John le Carré’s novel “A Most Wanted Man,” in which she stars opposite the late Philip Seymour Hoffman.

headline: A Cathedral Under Siege
keywords: ['Wilderness Areas', 'Cable Cars and Trams', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores']
abstract: The Grand Canyon faces desecration on two fronts from developers.
lead_paragraph: FLAGSTAFF, Ariz. — WHEN I worked as a white-water guide at the bottom of the Grand Canyon, I was often struck by how many passengers concluded their odyssey through the most iconic landscape in the United States by invoking the very same epiphany. At the end of each two-week, 277-mile journey down the Colorado River, someone would often come up to me and declare that the canyon was “America’s cathedral — a church without a roof.”

headline: Is a Hard Life Inherited?
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Minimum Wage', 'Men and Boys', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Education (K-12)', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Meet Rick Goff of Yamhill, Ore. His life story is a study in the national crisis facing working-class men.
lead_paragraph: YAMHILL, Ore. — ONE delusion common among America’s successful people is that they triumphed just because of hard work and intelligence.

headline: The ‘Starchitect’ Image
abstract: Readers respond to a letter by Peggy Deamer, an architect, calling for less arrogance and more collaboration in architecture.
lead_paragraph: Readers respond to a letter by Peggy Deamer, an architect, calling for less arrogance and more collaboration in architecture.

headline: Hit the Reset Button in Your Brain
abstract: Vacation isn’t a luxury. Neither is daydreaming. Don’t skimp.
lead_paragraph: THIS month, many Americans will take time off from work to go on vacation, catch up on household projects and simply be with family and friends. And many of us will feel guilty for doing so. We will worry about all of the emails piling up at work, and in many cases continue to compulsively check email during our precious time off.

headline: Don’t Let Your Children Grow Up to Be Farmers
abstract: Local food may be celebrated, but those of us who do the work aren’t making any money.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — AT a farm-to-table dinner recently, I sat huddled in a corner with some other farmers, out of earshot of the foodies happily eating kale and freshly shucked oysters. We were comparing business models and profit margins, and it quickly became clear that all of us were working in the red.

headline: A Broadcaster Knows Long Shots, and Not Just Those of the Slap Variety
abstract: Eddie Olczyk, a former Ranger and current N.H.L. analyst, is moonlighting this summer as a member of NBC Sports Group’s horse racing broadcast team.
lead_paragraph: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — Before Eddie Olczyk was a hockey player, he was a horseplayer — a serious one. When he talks about his method for handicapping, it may as well be from the pulpit. Eddie O. preaches race flow and considers ignoring surface biases one of handicapping’s deadly sins.

headline: The Pigeon Fliers of New York
abstract: Carmine Gangone’s birds mattered to him not because they were a substitute for human companionship but because they connected him to a new community.
lead_paragraph: A decade ago, when I lived in Bushwick, Brooklyn, I used to watch the sunset from my rooftop. All around me were large flocks of pigeons, their white wingtips glittering as they swirled in the sun’s golden hour. These were not street pigeons. Their movements were too choreographed, and they hovered above particular tenements as if attached by marionette strings. Atop the buildings, I could just make out the silhouettes of men whistling at the birds while waving jerry-built flags. These were the puppeteers.

headline: Protest March in Chokehold Case Is Moved From Verrazano Bridge to Staten Island
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Protesters initially planned to march across the bridge, but will instead begin on Staten Island, where a man died last month after an encounter with the police.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Al Sharpton, seeking to defuse political and logistical concerns over his proposal to lead a protest march across the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, said on Saturday that the march against aggressive policing would instead be held on Staten Island, where a man died last month after an encounter with the police.

headline: The Opposite of Stagflation
abstract: It’s looking pretty Keynesian out there.
lead_paragraph: One of the truly amazing (and disheartening) things about the Great Recession and its aftermath has been the continuing insistence of many economists that it’s somehow a supply-side slump, driven by the evils of Obamacare or something. This tends to come from people who view stagflation in the 1970s as having permanently refuted all things Keynes.

headline: In Praise of the DMV
abstract: Not that bad. Really.
lead_paragraph: OK, not exactly. But I see that some of the commenters on my libertarian piece invoke the old “horrors of the DMV” line to claim that government never works.

headline: Gastro-Architecture
abstract: A tour of the world’s edible architecture. Take a photo, or a bite.
lead_paragraph: A tour of the world’s edible architecture. Take a photo, or a bite.

headline: Medical Marijuana Research Hits Wall of U.S. Law
abstract: Though over one million people are thought to use marijuana to treat ailments, there are few studies on its effectiveness. A major reason: The federal government puts tight restrictions on research.
lead_paragraph: Nearly four years ago, Dr. Sue Sisley, a psychiatrist at the University of Arizona, sought federal approval to study marijuana’s effectiveness in treating military veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder. She had no idea how difficult it would be.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Aug. 10
abstract: This week, President Obama authorized targeted airstrikes against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, a militant group that has taken over large parts of northern Iraq, drawing the United States back into the conflict in Iraq.
lead_paragraph: In a brief news conference on Saturday, President Obama called the crisis in Iraq a “long-term project,” but reiterated that the United States would not send ground forces to the region. Earlier this week, Mr. Obama said the stranded Yazidis, a religious minority, were in danger of “genocide” at the hands of militants with the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria. Mr. Obama authorized targeted airstrikes against ISIS on Thursday, drawing bipartisan support from Congress.

headline: Men Often Mentored by Women at the Pool
keywords: ['Swimming', 'Women and Girls', 'Coaches and Managers', 'Athletics and Sports']
abstract: Becky Hammon made news last week when the Spurs hired her as the N.B.A.’s first full-time female assistant coach, but in swimming, it is common for male athletes to be coached by women.
lead_paragraph: IRVINE, Calif. — The San Antonio Spurs’ hiring of Becky Hammon on Tuesday as the N.B.A.’s first full-time female assistant coach caught the eye of Dorsey Tierney-Walker, who was thrilled to welcome another woman into a club that she never viewed as exclusive.

headline: Uniting to Take Congress, G.O.P. Tries to Become the Party of ‘Yes’
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Elections, Senate', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: With control of Congress within reach, party leaders say that Republicans will need to be realistic about what they can achieve and that a high level of party unity will be essential.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With control of Congress within reach, Republicans are quietly assembling an aggressive 2015 agenda built around a push for a balanced budget and quick passage of measures, like approval of the Keystone XL pipeline and repeal of a medical equipment tax, to show they can govern.

headline: Swimming Against the Rising Tide
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Religion and Belief', 'Evangelical Movement', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions']
abstract: Those of us who believe the science on climate change might take a lesson from evangelical Christians.
lead_paragraph: IT never feels like summer starts until the first time I go to the beach. To stand nearly naked and heavy from winter on the water’s edge, wade awkwardly into the shallows, dive under the first cold wave, taste first salt, surface and dive again to reach the calmer waters beyond, floating there until water and skin become the same temperature — this is the best way I know to belong again, body and soul, to some larger part of the planet, not just the city, not just the job. But it’s already August, and I still haven’t gone swimming.

headline: Grief, Smoke and Salvation
keywords: ['Restaurants', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Alcohol Abuse', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: A trailblazing ambassador for Israeli food acknowledges his secrets, his struggle and how the violence of his homeland factored into it all.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — PEOPLE who don’t know the full truth about Mike Solomonov judge him by his fried chicken at Federal Donuts, a cult favorite in this city, and by his hummus at Zahav, an Israeli restaurant here of national renown. They’re the signposts in a career that has burned bright in recent years and seems destined to burn brighter still.

headline: Mr. Obama, Your Move
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Deportation', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Since Congress refused to act on immigration reform, it is the president’s duty to use his executive authority to protect unauthorized immigrants from deportation.
lead_paragraph: Sometime in late summer, if predictions are right, President Obama will use his executive authority to protect many unauthorized immigrants from deportation.

headline: Back to Iraq
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Once again, we are ensnared in our mess in Mesopotamia.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — IT was exhilarating to drop a bunch of 500-pound bombs on whatstheirname.

headline: J. W. Hastings, 87, a Pioneer in Bioluminescence Research, Dies
abstract: Mr. Hastings was a Harvard biochemist whose discovery of how bacteria communicate became the foundation for groundbreaking research in the development of more effective antibiotics.
lead_paragraph: J. Woodland Hastings, a Harvard biochemist whose improbable discovery of how bacteria communicate became the foundation for groundbreaking research in the development of more effective antibiotics, died on Wednesday at his home in Lexington, Mass. He was 87.

headline: Too Big to Regulate
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Law and Legislation', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Banks that fail to submit credible “living wills” should be forced to downsize.
lead_paragraph: If the Dodd-Frank financial reform law was working as it is supposed to, the biggest American and European banks would soon be facing stricter capital and leverage requirements, restrictions on their growth and operations, and even, in some instances, the forced divestiture of entire business units.

headline: The Right War
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: America can’t fix Iraq, but we can make a difference.
lead_paragraph: THREE times before last week’s decision to launch airstrikes against the self-styled caliphate, the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, President Obama was urged to intervene in Middle Eastern conflicts: in Libya in the spring of 2011, in Syria from 2011 onward and in Iraq two short months ago, when Baghdad was threatened by the swift advance of ISIS.

headline: A Witness to Ebola’s Discovery
abstract: Dr. Frederick Murphy was the first person to see Ebola up close in 1976. He reflects on disease he has come to know over the last 38 years.
lead_paragraph: It was October 1976 in Atlanta, and a disease that no one had ever seen was coming into focus. Word came from an amateur radio network in Africa that the mystery illness had killed hundreds of people in just over a month. The chief of the viral pathology branch at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention was standing over an electron microscope. Dr. Frederick Murphy, now a professor of pathology at the University of Texas Medical Branch at Galveston, was the first to see this unknown killer up close.

headline: A Star-Powered School Sputters
abstract: With its academics and its finances under fire, the Texas sports academy created by Deion Sanders, the Hall of Fame cornerback and N.F.L. commentator, is facing the loss of its state charter.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — A few years back, Deion Sanders, the Hall of Fame cornerback and N.F.L. commentator who still digs being called by the nickname Prime Time, was approached with a splendid business proposition.

headline: A View From the Sea, as China Flexes Muscle
abstract: A two-and-a-half month standoff over a Chinese oil rig illustrated the long reach of China’s nautical ambitions.
lead_paragraph: ABOARD CSB-8003, in the South China Sea — As the large white Chinese ship closed in, the smaller Vietnamese Coast Guard vessel could only veer off, black exhaust billowing from its stack. The Vietnamese vessel had advanced to within 13 miles of the Chinese offshore oil rig, and the Chinese decided it could come no closer.

headline: Will the Voices of Conscience Be Heard?
abstract: Israelis and Palestinians struggle to defeat fear.
lead_paragraph: THERE are good people and bad leaders the world over, but perhaps nowhere more so than in the Middle East. Plenty of Israelis and Palestinians work to build bridges, but their voices are lost in the stampede of zealots schooled in hatred and cynics adept in the manipulation of fear for the consolidation of power.

headline: Eric Cantor’s Big Payoff
keywords: ['Editorials', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Campaign Finance', 'Executive Compensation']
abstract: After losing the Republican primary in June, the former House majority leader is set to become Eric Cantor Inc. and make lots of money.
lead_paragraph: Residents of Virginia’s Seventh Congressional District won’t be able to meet their representative at a town hall during the August recess because they won’t have one as of Aug. 18. Their congressman, Eric Cantor, announced his resignation a few days ago after losing the Republican primary in June to someone further to the right. Ostensibly, he did so to give his successor slightly higher seniority (which might mean nothing more than a better office), but the real reasons are more venal.

headline: Olympiad Is Shadowed by Leadership Showdown
abstract: In a tournament of upsets, the big news is the World Chess Federation’s presidential election between Kirsan Ilyumzhinov and Garry Kasparov.
lead_paragraph: It is election season at the World Chess Federation, with a vote at the Chess Olympiad on Monday that pits the incumbent president against a former world champion.

headline: Classy Dames in Desperate Straits
abstract: Cate Blanchett and Isabelle Huppert engage in intense, whiplash physicality in a rip-roaring production of the Jean Genet play “The Maids,” directed by Benedict Andrews, at City Center.
lead_paragraph: Some real classy dames are tearing up the joint at City Center, where the Sydney Theater Company is performing its rip-roaring production of Jean Genet’s “The Maids” as part of the Lincoln Center Festival through Aug. 16. You might add that these ladies, embodied in the august personages of Cate Blanchett and Isabelle Huppert,  are stinking up the place, as well.

headline: Moves Rarely Seen in the East Village
abstract: The Drive East festival is back with another week of exceptional programming.
lead_paragraph: August is typically dance’s hibernation period. But last year, some extraordinary sights and sounds filled La MaMa’s intimate East Village theater when it was transformed into a haven for classical Indian music and dance. Beginning Monday, the Drive East festival is back with another week of exceptional programming, organized by Navatman, the South Asian performing arts group, and devoted to the dance styles of Bharatanatyam, Kathak and Kuchipudi, as well as a rarer form: Sattriya, originally practiced by celibate monks.

headline: Bringing the Harp to Center Stage
abstract: Xavier de Maistre has expanded the repertory for harp with commissions and his own arrangements.
lead_paragraph: I recently heard the harpist Xavier de Maistre for the first time at the Istanbul Music Festival, where he performed with the soprano Diana Damrau and impressed with his musicality, muscular technique and imaginative flair. Mr. de Maistre, the former principal harpist of the Vienna Philharmonic, has carved out a career as an orchestral soloist, chamber musician and recitalist and has expanded the repertory for harp with commissions and his own arrangements. He will perform some of them at 10 p.m. Thursday in the intimate, candlelit series A Little Night Music, part of Mostly Mozart, at Lincoln Center’s Stanley H. Kaplan Penthouse. That program includes his arrangements of pieces by Mozart, Liszt, Fauré and Smetana.

headline: Crossing a Line in the Sea
abstract: The Wallace Line swerves among the islands of Indonesia from just west of Bali to the seas south of the Philippines.
lead_paragraph: The Wallace Line swerves among the islands of Indonesia from just west of Bali to the seas south of the Philippines. It’s named after the British naturalist Alfred Russel Wallace, who discovered in the mid-19th century that different species of flora and fauna grew on either side. “East of the Wallace Line: Monumental Art From Indonesia and New Guinea,” opening Friday at the Yale University Art Gallery, will present more than 120 works of art and craft from the 17th to the 19th century made by people living east of that line. These habitats include the islands of Timor, Flores and the Moluccas of eastern Indonesia and, in western New Guinea, the Raja Ampat Islands and Cenderawasih Bay. Drawn from the gallery’s Indo-Pacific art collection, the exhibition will include large, ritual and ancestral statues carved from wood; small, intricately carved ceremonial and utilitarian objects made of wood, ivory, and brass; richly patterned textiles; and wooden shields inlaid with mother-of-pearl. (1111 Chapel Street, New Haven; artgallery.yale.edu.)

headline: With No Regard for Pop Conventions
abstract: FKA twigs, spare and intense, tries a different tack in R&B, sweating the details on her first full album, “LP1.”
lead_paragraph: “All those years in isolation/helped me want for you,” FKA twigs sings in “Closer,” a track deep into her first full album, “LP1.” “Lead me to a place I’m free from/all the wrongs I do.” Like a lot of lines on the record, these can be understood in three ways: a call to an old lover, a plea for spiritual salvation or a credo of the young perfectionist artist facing a new audience. Or perhaps in one big way: transformative desire, private and public, in body and soul, in real life and metaphor.

lead_paragraph: On the long-running BET series “The Game,” Jay Ellis plays Bryce Westbrook, a Heisman Trophy-winning wide receiver and first-round draft pick for the fictional San Diego Sabers football team. The role has made Mr. Ellis a favorite among the show’s female fan base and sparked numerous magazine articles that promise to reveal this 32-year-old actor’s “sexy secrets.”

headline: Identity Crisis Under Cover
abstract: “Who am I?” becomes more than just metaphysical navel gazing in “Legends,” starring Sean Bean as a deep-cover F.B.I. operative who morphs into a different character with each new job.
lead_paragraph: “Who am I?” becomes more than just metaphysical navel gazing in “Legends,” starring Sean Bean as Martin Odum, a deep-cover F.B.I. operative who morphs into a different character with each new job, then loses his compass when fact and fiction blur. “It’s not fair,” he says, apparently channeling an alter ego. “I did everything right. Learned a trade. Worked hard.” His craggy British accent turns stuttering American. “I deserve better.”

headline: Imperfect Duo, on a Short Tour
abstract: Eminem and Rihanna may be two of the biggest pop stars of the 2000s, and are frequent collaborators, but the similarities stop there.
lead_paragraph: Eminem and Rihanna may be two of the biggest pop stars of the 2000s, and are frequent collaborators, but the similarities stop there. Eminem is a scabrous self-excavator, a man who raps his way through trauma at lightning speed and with a disregard for the feelings of others (or his own, for that matter). Rihanna is a chilly narcissist with a slick voice that’s almost never touched a feeling. Still, they’re uniting for a brief tour — first a pair of shows in Pasadena, Calif., then a pair in New Jersey before closing out with a pair in Eminem’s hometown, Detroit. Maybe they want to celebrate their collaborations — “The Monster,” “Love the Way You Lie (Part II)” — which have served to soften Eminem and coarsen Rihanna, each achieving something they can’t quite nail on their own. (Next Saturday and Sunday, MetLife Stadium, East Rutherford, N.J.; metlifestadium.com.)

headline: Straight Out of Wales, With Murders
abstract: “Hinterland,” a police drama set in a tiny town in Wales, unfolds in dark storybook settings.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In the first episode of “Hinterland,” a police drama set in a tiny town in Wales, an elderly woman is reported missing, and the lead investigator, Detective Chief Inspector Tom Mathias (Richard Harrington), finds a clue in a local landmark.

headline: Rio’s Slums to Jacob’s Pillow
abstract: The Brazilian troupe Companhia Urbana de Dança is bringing its hip-hop moves to Jacob’s Pillow.
lead_paragraph: As the protests surrounding the World Cup this summer underscored, Brazil is a complex country, blessed with gorgeous beaches and breathtaking landscapes, bursting with music, but also plagued by poverty and violence. Extremes of beauty and ugliness rub shoulders; they are intertwined in the national character. This tension is precisely what the choreographer Sonia Destri Lie, founder of the contemporary hip-hop troupe Companhia Urbana de Dança, strives to capture in her work. The company will appear at the Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival in Becket, Mass., from Wednesday to Saturday.

headline: Loss Isn’t Only Reminder That Era of Yankees’ Dominance Has Waned

lead_paragraph: A postseason berth no longer comes easily for the Yankees, who dominated the baseball landscape not too long ago. headline: Baby Pictures at the Doctor’s? Cute, Sure, but Illegal
abstract: The “baby wall” at obstetricians’ and midwives’ offices is gradually going the way of cigars in the waiting room, because of the federal patient privacy law known as Hipaa.
lead_paragraph: Pictures of smiling babies crowd a bulletin board in a doctor’s office in Midtown Manhattan, in a collage familiar to anyone who has given birth. But the women coming in to have babies of their own cannot see them. They have been moved to a private part of the office, replaced in the corridors with abstract art.

headline: No. 1 Friends
abstract: A Sunday grid by Elizabeth C. Gorski can be considered a puzzler’s best friend.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — All together now: “Awwwww!” You cannot be sad doing this puzzle by Elizabeth C. Gorski, the mistress of visual puzzle art. Sorry, it’s not allowed. Even if you’re not a dog lover, you have to admit that this puzzle is pretty awesome. We’ve got an adorable pup drawn in the grid, and Ms. Gorski has managed to do that without even going over the 140 entry limit. That’s masterful in itself.
