headline: 1939: U.S. Zionist Delegation to Geneva in Quest of Solution to Palestine
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: An American delegation travels to the World Zionist Congress in 1939.
lead_paragraph: To work out a solution to the Palestine problem which will satisfy the Arabs as well as the Jews will be the principal concern of the World Zionist Congress meeting in Geneva on August 18, according to Herman P. Kopplemann, former Congressman for three terms from Connecticut and member of the large American delegation to the meeting in Switzerland. “Outside influences have been creating discords which are unfortunate and unfair to both Arab and Jew in Palestine. We are far from satisfied with the British White Paper, which nullifies the Balfour Declaration, but we are going to do the best in our power to settle the controversy — particularly unfortunate at this time of racial discrimination — in a fair and peaceful way,” said Mr. Kopplemann. Mr. Kopplemann is one of the members of the American delegation which is meeting in Paris before the start of the congress to act as a steering committee for the delegation as a whole, which numbers some thirty-two persons. “We Americans feel that we have done a major part of the work of building up the wastelands and draining the swamps of Palestine, making that land, in fact, one of the most productive parts of the world. We have raised the standard of living there, not only of the Jew but also of the Arab. We feel that the American delegation should therefore participate in the congress to the fullest degree.” — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Aug. 11, 1939

headline: 1964: Turkish Jets Again Raid Cyprus Despite Truce
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Turkey attacks Cyprus despite cease-fire agreement in 1964.
lead_paragraph: NICOSIA — Turkish fighter planes today [Aug. 10] attacked Cyprus for the fourth consecutive day despite a cease-fire agreement. The strafing attack was made against the northwestern village of Polis, but it was believed to have been launched in error by pilots who had not yet received their cease-fire orders from Ankara. Throughout the rest of the island, the situation eased somewhat when it was learned that Turkish troops had not invaded the island as alleged last night by the Greek Cypriot government. The government had charged that four Turkish destroyers were unloading men and material at Kokkina, the last major stronghold of the Turkish Cypriots on the northwestern coast. But the UN found no evidence to support the allegation. Col. Johnas Waern, commander of the UN Swedish contingent on Cyprus, inspected the area and reported seeing only a ‘‘very small ship’’ offshore which was not unloading anything. There was a brief flareup of shooting in Nicosia tonight, but there were no reports of any casualties. Firing also continued sporadically throughout the day between Greek and Turkish Cypriots in the Kokkina area, according to reliable reports reaching Nicosia tonight. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Aug. 11, 1964

headline: Controlling the Ebola Epidemic
abstract: The virus’s spread is showing how unprepared America and other advanced countries are to help protect and treat thousands of Africans threatened by a disease for which there is no cure.

Not much. Apart from inflicting a staggering human toll, the spread of the Ebola virus in West Africa has laid bare how unprepared the United States and other advanced countries are to protect and treat thousands of Africans whose lives are threatened by an extremely dangerous virus for which there is no cure.

headline: What’s On TV Monday

lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (Starz Cinema) THE PAST (2013) An Iranian, Ahmad (Ali Mosaffa), returns to Paris to give his estranged wife, Marie (Bérénice Bejo, above, with Mr. Mosaffa), the divorce she seeks — and in the process opens a Pandora’s box of secrets and lies — in this drama written and directed by Asghar Farhadi. Tahar Rahim plays the man Marie has taken up with, whose wife is in a coma. Elyes Aguis is their son, whose presence in Marie’s house means a playmate for her younger daughter (Jeanne Jestin). And Pauline Burlet is Marie’s older daughter, who finds the situation nearly intolerable. “The narrative complications can be distracting, at times exasperating, but they’re finally irrelevant because Mr. Farhadi’s filmmaking is so fluid, and the performers, Ms. Bejo, in particular, are so attractive,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “As in ‘A Separation,’ Mr. Farhadi shows a masterly gift for moving his characters and camera through rooms that — with a raised voice, a violent exit — become stages in a ferocious domestic drama. But here, keep your eye on the littlest players, the small ones trembling in the wings.” In French and Persian, with English subtitles.

lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korea on Monday proposed high-level talks with North Korea to discuss holding a new round of reunions of aging Koreans separated by the Korean War six decades ago.

headline: Kerry Issues Warning to Iraqi Leader
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry cautioned Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki that a power grab would result in reduced international support to Iraq.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Secretary of State John Kerry warned Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq on Monday not to interfere with the process of picking a new Iraqi leader, cautioning pointedly that a power grab would lead to a cutoff of international support.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | ‘A Safe Haven That Quickly Became a Place of Danger’ for Iraqi Refugees
abstract: Who are the Yazidis, why have they been forced to leave their homes and what hardships have they encountered en route to refugee camps?
lead_paragraph: In “For Refugees on Mountain, ‘No Water, Nothing,’” Alissa J. Rubin reports on conditions faced by the Yazidis of Iraq as they flee their homes.

headline: Crossing Rivers, Searching for the Future
abstract: In his years covering immigration, Nick Oza has assembled a body of work that reflects the complexity of human beings flowing across borders.
lead_paragraph: Marking a portion of Mexico’s southern border with Guatemala, the Suchiate River beckons many of those embarking on the odyssey from Central America to the southwestern United States. Its name originates from Xochiatl, the Nahuatl word for “flower water.” Some cross the river on makeshift rafts. Others have been known to go by zip line.

headline: An Early Look at ‘JFK’ Opera
abstract: The opera “JFK,” by David T. Little will not have its premiere until 2016 but a workshop performance has been scheduled for New York in November.
lead_paragraph: David T. Little’s opera “JFK,” which looks at the 12 hours leading up to John F. Kennedy’s assassination in Dallas, is scheduled to have its world premiere at the Fort Worth Opera on April 23, 2016. But New Yorkers will be able to get an advance look in November. The American Lyric Theater, which is developing the score in a partnership with the Fort Worth company, will present a workshop performance of the opera-in-progress at Merkin Concert Hall on Nov. 25.

headline: Balfour Beatty Rejects New Carillion Merger Effort
abstract: The British construction and services company said that Carillion was still insisting that the Balfour-owned consulting business, Parsons Brinckerhoff, not be sold; the dispute had also derailed merger talks last month.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The British construction and services company Balfour Beatty said on Monday that it had rejected a renewed merger approach from its rival Carillion after calling off talks last month.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Robert Draper on Libertarianism’s Prospects
abstract: Robert Draper, a contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this week’s cover story about the rise of libertarianism. Here, he discusses the movement’s prospects.
lead_paragraph: Robert Draper, a contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this week’s cover story about the rise of libertarianism. Draper is the author of ”When the Tea Party Came to Town.” His last article for the magazine was about Wendy Davis.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

headline: New York Today: Central Park, Untamed
abstract: What you need to know for Monday: a preserve within the park, the end of a sunny spell, and a charity sea paddle.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this sunny Monday.

headline: From Metta World Peace to ‘The Pandas Friend’
abstract: Metta World Peace, the American basketball player formerly known as Ron Artest, is changing his name once again as he joins the Sichuan Blue Whales.
lead_paragraph: Call him “The Pandas Friend.”

headline: Morning Views
abstract: Opinions on a staggering Ebola outbreak, ugly judicial elections, inequality in college sports and “shell” democracy in Turkey.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Margaret Chan, the director general of the World Health Organization, has declared the Ebola outbreak in West Africa “the largest, most severe, most complex” in “the nearly four-decade history of the disease,” according to an editorial in The New York Times. “Apart from inflicting a staggering human toll, the spread of the Ebola virus in West Africa has laid bare how unprepared the United States and other advanced countries are to protect and treat thousands of Africans whose lives are threatened by an extremely dangerous virus for which there is no cure.” Because drug companies have little financial interest in developing a vaccine, “traditional public health measures, like finding and isolating patients who become sick, tracing their contacts and using stringent infection control procedures in hospitals, remain the best bet for containing the epidemic.”

headline: Vietnam Gives Brief Show of Openness in Standoff With China
abstract: Vietnam invited foreign reporters to embed with its Coast Guard and see what challenges it faced from China’s presence in the South China Sea.
lead_paragraph: The reporters’ trip with the Vietnamese Coast Guard started with a meal, and the meal started with toasts.

headline: Daily Report: Acculturating New Employees at Apple Through Careful Training
abstract: The tech company’s highly secretive internal training program is like its products: meticulously planned, with polished presentations and a gleaming veneer that masks a great deal of effort.
lead_paragraph: Steven P. Jobs established his company’s internal training program, the so-called Apple University, as a way to inculcate employees into Apple’s business culture and educate them about its history, particularly as the company grew and the tech business changed. Courses are not required, only recommended, but getting new employees to enroll is rarely a problem, Brian X. Chen reports.

headline: It's Not Too Late for Republicans to Win Latino Votes
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: The party's stance on immigration is a deal-breaker for many Hispanics who would otherwise consider supporting it.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes it looks as if Republicans want to attract Latinos. The G.O.P. post-mortem on the 2012 election recognized the need to “embrace and champion immigration reform.” Reaching out to Latino voters was highlighted in the party’s Growth and Opportunity Project report as essential to the party’s long-term sustainability. With good reason: Only 27 percent of Latinos voted for Mitt Romney in 2012, down four points from the 31 percent supporting John McCain in 2008.

headline: Lessons From the Low-Tech Defeat of the Guinea Worm
abstract: Sometimes medical advances are accomplished not through scientific breakthroughs, but through education and persuasion.
lead_paragraph: Given all the talk about the hepatitis C drug Sovaldi in recent weeks, as well as the high prices on many other recent innovations, you might think that we’re entering a time when leaps forward happen only at great cost. That misses the point. It also strengthens the false notion that we can move forward only through advances in technology. As I said in another column not long ago, people are more important than technology.

headline: Trying to Understand the Impact of a Higher Minimum Wage on Small Businesses
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Minimum Wage', 'Small Business', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: The Congressional Budget Office recently estimated that if the federal minimum wage were to rise to $10.10, a total of 16.5 million workers would make more money.
lead_paragraph: Does the battle over the minimum wage pit employees against small-business owners? That was the notion put forth on the Real Clear Politics website recently. In an essay titled “Living the Wage? Try Living the Small Business,” Tom Bevan, a co-founder of the site, ridiculed Democratic politicians who had embarked on an effort to understand how people subsist on minimum wage.

headline: A Taste of Russian Dance in London
abstract: The Mariinsky Ballet is dancing mixed bills of Balanchine, Fokine, Ashton and Ratmansky -- a chance to see its dancers in varying styles, techniques and aesthetics.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Russia’s two great ballet companies have been on the road of late. The Bolshoi, based in Moscow, just ended a two-week tour of New York, and the Mariinsky Ballet from St. Petersburg is in the middle of a substantial season here. Despite laments of cultural homogeneity, Russian ballet is clearly still a powerful cultural export with its own audience-luring mystique.

headline: Iraqis Nominate Maliki Successor, Causing Standoff
abstract: The Iraqi president nominated the Shiite leader Haider al-Abadi to replace Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, who has demanded to remain in power.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Under heavy pressure from the United States, Iraqi lawmakers took a significant step on Monday by choosing a replacement for Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, widely blamed for their country’s polarized politics. But Mr. Maliki angrily rejected the move, vowing to fight in the courts and perhaps by use of force, throwing the country into new uncertainty even as it fights an onslaught by Sunni militants.

headline: R.B.S. Exploring Sale of International Arm of Coutts Private Bank Unit
abstract: The potential sale comes as the Royal Bank of Scotland reshapes its operations into a smaller, more British-focused bank.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The Royal Bank of Scotland is exploring options for the international operations of its Coutts & Company private banking unit, including possible joint ventures or a sale, according to an internal memorandum on Monday.

headline: F.B.I. Steps In Amid Unrest After Police Kill Missouri Youth
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Looting (Crime)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: The agency opened a civil rights inquiry into the fatal shooting of an unarmed black teenager as protests went into their third day in a St. Louis suburb.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — The F.B.I. on Monday opened a civil rights inquiry into the fatal shooting by a police officer of an unarmed black teenager here as protests bubbled into a third night in this St. Louis suburb.

headline: Morning Agenda: Kinder Morgan to Consolidate
abstract: The pipeline group Kinder Morgan plans to reorganize as a single corporation. | The drop in Treasury yields has confounded experts. | An investor group is considering legal action after being burned by losses on Portuguese bank bonds. | A Stanford finance professor is rapidly gaining a broader audience.
lead_paragraph: KINDER MORGAN TO REORGANIZE | The pipeline group Kinder Morgan, the biggest of the master limited partnerships, announced on Sunday that it would acquire its three associated companies and reorganize as one corporation based in Houston, DealBook’s David Gelles writes. The new Kinder Morgan will have an estimated enterprise value of about $140 billion ‒ $100 billion of market value and $40 billion of debt ‒ making it the third-biggest energy company in the United States, after Exxon Mobil and Chevron.

headline: On Supreme Court, Does 9-0 Add Up to More Than 5-4?
abstract: The Supreme Court’s split decisions are not necessarily seen as less credible than unanimous ones, a new study finds.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court issued a remarkable number of unanimous decisions last term, and in their public remarks the justices seemed unanimous in saying that unanimity was a good thing. But is it?

headline: Louis Vuitton Debuts at Dover Street Market, a New Moon Juice in L.A. and Dancing in the Bronx
abstract: Plus, ten star chefs team up in upstate New York, art shows across the country and more things to do and see in the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: T’s list of things to do and see in the week ahead.

headline: From Hero to Hateful: Recalling an Afghan Soldier’s Descent
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'ANGER (EMOTION)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A former CIA paramilitary operations officer in Afghanistan wonders what caused the spiraling downward of his friend, Castro, an Afghan soldier. The P.T.S.D.? Or anti-American radicalization?
lead_paragraph: The recent green on blue attack that claimed the life of Gen. Harold J. Greene, the deputy commander for the Combined Security Transition Command–Afghanistan, has, for good reason, caused a fury of questions in the media about these attacks and what they meant. Who are the Afghans that carry them out? Why do they seem to suddenly turn on the Americans that have been fighting with them for years and years, struggling to help Afghanistan build something from the ruins of three decades of war. The answers, it seems, are complex, but also nuanced. And the questions reminded me of the worst case of post-traumatic stress syndrome that I’ve ever seen.

headline: Despite Criticism, Cuomo Holds Wide Lead Over Republican Challenger, Poll Finds
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Voting and Voters', 'Elections, Governors', 'Midterm Elections (2014)']
abstract: Fifty-eight percent of likely voters said they would vote to re-elect Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, a Siena College poll found, even after criticism over his handling of an ethics panel.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo continues to hold a wide lead over his Republican opponent, even after a drumbeat of criticism over his office’s hobbling of ethics investigations, according to a Siena College poll released on Monday.

headline: Dream of a Gaza Seaport Is Revived in Truce Talks
abstract: The long-delayed plans for the port, a potential economic engine, could be a crucial element in ending the monthlong battle between Israel and Palestinian militants.
lead_paragraph: SHEIK EJLEEN, Gaza Strip — An unmarked dirt lot about the size of a football field, on a cliff above the crashing waves of the Mediterranean, could be a crucial element in ending the monthlong battle between Israel and Palestinian militants in the Gaza Strip.

headline: A Felt Frenzy
abstract: Inspired by industrial fabric, designers are adding heft and durability to ladylike looks.
lead_paragraph: Inspired by industrial fabric, designers are adding heft and durability to ladylike looks.

headline: Chiquita Banana Brand Receives a Counter to Its Inversion Plan
abstract: The banana producer received an unsolicited offer on Monday from the Cutrale Group and the Safra Group for $13 a share. A deal would derail a planned inversion with Fyffes.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 11:38 a.m. | Chiquita Brands International, the banana producer that is seeking an inversion with a $526 million deal for its Irish rival Fyffes, received an unsolicited offer on Monday from an unlikely pair of private companies.

headline: Understanding a Ballplayer Turned Writer
abstract: Ben Strauss wanted to know what motivated Adrian Cardenas, a player for the Chicago Cubs, to quite baseball to pursue a career as a writer.
lead_paragraph: Ben Strauss is a contributing writer for The Times. We asked him about the back story of his recent profile of Adrian Cardenas, a baseball player from Florida, who left a career as a high-earning professional athlete to study creative writing at New York University.

headline: Postal Service Quarterly Loss Was $2 Billion, Despite Higher Prices
abstract: The net loss for the quarter was up from $740 million in the same period last year, despite increases in mail prices and growth in shipping services.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Despite an increase in revenue for nearly all of the Postal Service’s products, the agency continues to be mired in debt because of a congressional requirement to pay about $5 billion into a future retiree health care fund, post office officials said on Monday.

headline: Looting Erupts in Missouri After Vigil
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Attacks on Police', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Crowds smashed car windows and looted stores following a vigil for an unarmed teenager who was shot and killed by a police officer in Ferguson, Mo., a suburb of St. Louis.
lead_paragraph: Crowds smashed car windows and looted stores following a vigil for an unarmed teenager who was shot and killed by a police officer in Ferguson, Mo., a suburb of St. Louis.

headline: Relearning How to Eat Fish
abstract: A sustainable seafood industry requires sounder farming practices and smarter consumers.
lead_paragraph: On a recent weeklong cruise along the shores of southeast Alaska, the dining room menu included wild salmon, Dungeness crab and sablefish. Many of my fellow 63 passengers had neither heard of nor tasted sable.

headline: ‘Men in Blazers’ Soccer Duo Moving to NBC
abstract: After crossing over to the sports media mainstream during the World Cup, Roger Bennett and Michael Davies will host their own show on NBC Sports.
lead_paragraph: Men in Blazers, the cheeky British soccer analysts who became breakout media stars during the World Cup, are taking their self-proclaimed “suboptimal ramblings” to network television.

headline: Cool Beans
abstract: Now trending: designer coffee, courtesy of Ralph Lauren, Bergdorf Goodman and LVMH.
lead_paragraph: From Ralph Lauren to Bergdorf Goodman, something’s percolating in the fashion world.

headline: Learning to Shun the Instagram Life
abstract: A picture-perfect reality will always be out of reach, and learning to let go of its pursuit is healthier, a financial planner writes.
lead_paragraph: "We should just move to the country and live in a tent.”

headline: A College Beach Party With a Twist, and More Than a Few Wrinkles
abstract: Instead of being overrun with partying youngsters, Kingsborough Community College’s beach is visited most often by older adults, who take summer classes at reduced rates.
lead_paragraph: Building a college directly atop its own beach does not at first glance seem to be a great formula for academic success. A beautiful, protected beach, no less, with gentle waters and a wide apron of sand. By the logic of 1960s cinema, a setting like that should make students drop their books, run outside and peel down to their bathing suits for a dance party and a bonfire.

headline: Kerry Asks Maliki to Not Stir Waters
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry said that the formation of an Iraqi government was critical for stability and urged Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki to “not stir those waters” by interfering.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State John Kerry said that the formation of an Iraqi government was critical for stability and urged Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki to “not stir those waters” by interfering.

headline: Medicaid Rolls Are Growing Even in States That Rejected Federal Funds
keywords: ['Medicaid', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'States (US)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', "State Children's Health Insurance Program (S-CHIP)", 'Federal Aid (US)']
abstract: Many people who were always eligible for the program realized they could sign up, in part because of widespread discussion about the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: Call it a side effect of the Affordable Care Act: Even in states that haven’t changed their Medicaid programs, nearly a million people signed up for Medicaid this year.

headline: 1939: Cannes Prepares Film Festival
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Cannes prepared for the precursor of its film festival in 1939.
lead_paragraph: CANNES — The first International Film Festival, which opens here on September 1, will last three weeks, during which  the best films of world production will be  presented at a series of brilliant gala  performances. The most celebrated French and foreign screen stars will be present. All film-producing countries have been invited to participate in the festival. American producers are particularly enthusiastic about this unique festival, at which they expect to show Hollywood’s most recent pictures. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 12, 1939

headline: Mourning a Racer Who Died ‘Living His Dream’
abstract: Acquaintances said that Kevin Ward Jr., who was killed Saturday when he was struck by a car driven by the Nascar star Tony Stewart, had always dreamed of being a racecar driver.
lead_paragraph: PORT LEYDEN, N.Y. — One friend learned the terrible news at 3 a.m. Sunday when his ringing phone woke him. Another was riding the bus to work when he heard. A woman found out in church, where the pastor offered prayers for Kevin Ward Jr. and his family.

headline: Stand Out With an Anti-Résumé for Your Next Job Application
abstract: One writer has created a detailed list not just of her accomplishments but of her rejections, too.
lead_paragraph: The writer Monica Byrne has created an Excel spreadsheet of everything she’s ever failed at. Well, not everything — there are almost certainly some childhood spelling bees or soccer games, or both, left off. But her spreadsheet, which she calls her “anti-résumé,” does include all the rejections she’s received for her creative work over the past six years — over 500 of them.

headline: U.S. Finds Fresh Use for Seldom-Used Statute in Subprime Cases
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The Justice Department is using a powerful civil fraud provision to investigate potential fraud in the marketing of securities backed by risky auto loans, Peter J. Henning writes in the White Collar Watch column.
lead_paragraph: Like a child with a new toy, the Justice Department is using a powerful civil fraud provision to investigate potential wrongdoing in the marketing of securities backed by risky auto loans. This opens up a new front for the government to pursue large monetary penalties against companies that package loans made without paying too much attention to whether the borrowers are credit worthy.

headline: In Britain, Nuclear Reactors to Be Shut Down in Fault Investigation
abstract: Nearly a quarter of Britain’s nuclear generating capacity will be halted as a precaution after a defect was found at another EDF Energy reactor that was shut down in June.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — EDF Energy, the British subsidiary of the French state-controlled utility, said on Monday that it was shutting down three nuclear reactors and that a reactor with a fault that has been shut down since June would remain so. The facilities, which are being investigated as a precaution, generate nearly a quarter of nuclear capacity in Britain.

headline: Introducing ‘36 Hours’
abstract: The new video series from The New York Times is a traveler’s guide to a city’s most delicious, adventurous and fascinating must-see destinations.
lead_paragraph: The new video series from The New York Times is a traveler’s guide to a city’s most delicious, adventurous and fascinating must-see destinations.

headline: In Performance | Ramin Karimloo
abstract: Ramin Karimloo, on banjo, with Sergio Ortega on guitar, performs “Bring Him Home” from the musical “Les Misérables,” now at the Imperial Theater.
lead_paragraph: Ramin Karimloo, on banjo, with Sergio Ortega on guitar, performs “Bring Him Home” from the musical “Les Misérables,” now at the Imperial Theater.

headline: Upscale Hotel, Working Farm
abstract: The Home Ranch in Colorado, a Relais & Chateaux property, has its own farm, site of an open-air dining venue called Farm Kitchen.
lead_paragraph: Many upscale hotels have on-site gardens, but the Home Ranch, a Relais & Châteaux property situated in the Elk River Valley in Clark, Colo., is going one step further with its new six-acre farm.

headline: Daniel Finkel’s Flying Squirrel-Frog
abstract: Will the squirrel-frog escape its feline pursuers? Test your powers of strategy and logic with this fur-raising challenge by Daniel Finkel.
lead_paragraph: This week’s challenge was suggested by regular contributor Daniel Finkel, who plunges us into the wild world of nature to witness a rare semi-amphibious creature in an unfortunate predicament. Here’s Dr. Finkel with —

headline: Bloomberg Names New Head of Live TV Unit
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: The new head, Claudia Milne, is a veteran BBC news producer.
lead_paragraph: Bloomberg has appointed Claudia Milne, a veteran news producer for the BBC, as its new head of live television in the United States.

headline: No Comment Necessary: ‘Join a Militia’
abstract: Tom Tancredo, the former congressman, says Republicans must “call Obama’s bluff on impeachment.”
lead_paragraph: Tom Tancredo, the former five-term congressman and co-chairman of the right-wing Team America PAC, suggested that if Republicans failed to make the case for impeaching President Obama, then the base might as well “join a militia.”

headline: Rag & Bone Interprets Its Fall/Winter 2014 Collection Through Dance
abstract: A new short film offers a unique lens onto the line.
lead_paragraph: For the fall season, “we wanted to show our women’s wear collection from different points of view,” says Marcus Wainwright, the co-creative director, with David Neville, of Rag & Bone. Points of view are historically important to the label: in previous seasons, Wainwright and Neville have given models the freedom to photograph their own campaigns.

headline: Barneys Agrees to Pay $525,000 in Racial Profiling Inquiry
abstract: Barneys New York said it would institute reforms after a state investigation showed that the department store singled out minority shoppers for heightened surveillance.
lead_paragraph: After a nine-month investigation, Barneys New York has agreed to pay $525,000 in costs, fees and penalties and institute a host of reforms to settle accusations that it singled out minority shoppers for heightened surveillance at its store on Madison Avenue.

headline: Bob Weir Cancels Tour; Kings of Leon Cancels One Show
abstract: A planned tour of Bob Weir’s band RatDog was canceled because of “circumstances,” without further explanation; Kings of Leon plans to return to schedule after canceling a Sunday show.
lead_paragraph: A message appeared on Bob Weir’s website on Sunday saying that Mr. Weir, 66, a founding member of the Grateful Dead, was canceling all scheduled performances – specifically, a tour with his band RatDog – through January 2015. The tour was to have started in Boston on Thursday. Ticket refunds were offered, but no reason was given for the cancellation other than that it was necessitated by “circumstances.”

headline: Statins Don’t Require Routine Liver Tests
abstract: There is no need for people on statins to have a test for the sole purpose of monitoring liver function.
lead_paragraph: When statins first came into wide use, warnings about possible liver damage were common, and some patients on the cholesterol-lowering drugs have their liver function monitored. Now a study has found that the risk was probably exaggerated.

headline: In a Novelist’s World, You Choose Your Race
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Jess Row’s new novel, “Your Face in Mine,” explores “racial reassignment” and what it could mean for identity.
lead_paragraph: In the weak light of a February afternoon, Kelly Thorndike has a strange chance encounter in a Baltimore parking lot with Martin Lipkin, an old friend from high school. But time has brought a big change. The Martin that Kelly knew was white. The man standing before him is black.

headline: Aspirin May Cut Cancer Risk
abstract: Taking small amounts of aspirin over long periods of time reduces the risk of colon cancer and certain other cancers.
lead_paragraph: A large review of available data has confirmed what many experts have long suspected: Taking small amounts of aspirin over long periods of time reduces the risk of colon cancer and certain other cancers.

headline: Measuring the Apology of Kevin Rudd, Former Prime Minister of Australia
abstract: In the third installment of the Apology Metrics series, Dov Seidman invites readers to participate in a survey on the apology of Kevin Rudd to Australia’s indigenous community.
lead_paragraph: This is the third apology in our Apology Metrics series in which we present apologies for readers to assess. Our goal is not to evaluate apologies as theatrical performances but to evaluate the apologizer’s behavior over time to see whether there has been genuine change. This time, we will look at the apology of Kevin Rudd, the former prime minister of Australia, to Australia’s indigenous community in 2008. With the benefit of six years of hindsight, we are in a much better position to judge the apology’s authenticity.

headline: Coaxing Fire and Police Staffs in Arizona to Cut Own Pensions
keywords: ['Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Government Employees', 'Police', 'Fires and Firefighters']
abstract: With many pension plans for the state’s police officers and firefighters underfunded, the firefighter association’s leader says his group must protect the public from financial ruin.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Bryan Jeffries, the chief of Arizona’s firefighters’ association, has been arguing to anyone who will listen that his members — and the state’s police officers, too — should volunteer to cut their own pension benefits.

headline: Cold Poached Pacific Cod with Spices
abstract: If you use a whole fish, you can use the bones to make a fish stock for poaching. But fillets can also be poached in a lighter broth. They are rubbed with a Middle Eastern spice mix.
lead_paragraph: In the authentic Middle Eastern version of this fragrant/spicy dish, a whole fish is filleted, the bones are used to make a fish stock, and the fish fillets are rubbed with a spice mix and poached in the stock. But fillets off the bone are easier to find than whole fish, and Pacific cod is a good choice. I used a vinegar court-bouillon, an easy, lighter fish poaching stock to throw together. Alternatively, use a fish stock or a plain vegetable stock. You may need to poach the fish in batches, which is fine as they are served cold.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Nascar Victory Shares Spotlight With Tragedy
abstract: A. J. Allmendinger won the Sprint Cup race in the shadow of a fatal dirt track crash; Marc Marquez won his 10th straight victory of the 2014 MotoGP season.
lead_paragraph: A.J. Allmendinger scored a redemptive victory in the Nascar Sprint Cup race at Watkins Glen, N.Y., on Sunday, but it was a day of mourning and soul-searching in the racing community.

headline: Grilled Skirt Steak With Herbs
abstract: Melissa Clark shows how to grill and slice skirt steak, which she first marinates in a mixture of garlic and herbs.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark shows how to grill and slice skirt steak, which she first marinates in a mixture of garlic and herbs.

headline: Skirt Steak Works Great for Grilling
abstract: Skirt steak defies its awkward appearance to become a go-to for throwing on the grill.
lead_paragraph: Skirt steak isn’t winning any beauty pageants. It’s a long, lanky, awkward contender for your grill. You won’t be able to give it those pronounced crosshatched grill lines, and its flat shape gives you thin, squiggly slices rather than nice, wide planks. If you want pretty and iconic, splurge on a rib or strip steak.

headline: An Unusual Gangster: Doug J. Swanson Talks About Benny Binion
abstract: Mr. Swanson’s new book, “Blood Aces,” tells the story of the Dallas crime boss who moved to Vegas and started the World Series of Poker.
lead_paragraph: Doug J. Swanson’s “Blood Aces” documents the colorful, violent life of Benny Binion, the gangster who made his bones in Depression-era Dallas before moving to Las Vegas (with the law in hot pursuit). In the desert, he opened the Horseshoe casino and introduced the World Series of Poker. The book also tells the story of Binion’s rivals, like Herbert Noble, nicknamed the Cat because he survived 11 attempts on his life — but alas, not the 12th. In a recent email interview, Mr. Swanson discussed Binion’s penchant for danger, the difficulties in researching his life and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation.

headline: Fantasy Football: Preseason Stock Watch, Week 1
abstract: Preseason games in the N.F.L. can sometimes be misleading, but they are still important when it comes to fantasy football. A look back at the first week.
lead_paragraph: Preseason games in the N.F.L. can sometimes be misleading when it comes to fantasy football analysis. Every coach has a different agenda in preparing for the season and players are competing in situations that do not resemble a regular season game, when fantasy points are calculated.

headline: Jeff Goldblum and His Jazz Band to Kick Off Season at Café Carlyle
abstract: Jeff Goldblum, Rita Wilson and Molly Ringwald are among the performers to be feature in the Café Carlyle’s fall season.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Goldblum, Rita Wilson and Molly Ringwald are among the actors set to display their musical merits at the Café Carlyle this fall, organizers of the Carlyle Hotel’s cabaret announced Monday.

headline: Roger Vivier’s New Muse
abstract: A classic bag whose design was initially inspired by France’s former First Lady gets a flashy upgrade, courtesy of the design-world darling Ambra Medda.
lead_paragraph: The curator and design-world darling Ambra Medda has collaborated on a special sequined version of the house’s classic Miss Viv’ bag, inspired originally in 2009 by another statuesque beauty: France’s former First Lady, Carla Bruni-Sarkozy.

headline: Kasparov Is Soundly Defeated in Bid to Lead Chess Federation
abstract: The former world chess champion lost an election in Norway in his effort to unseat the incumbent, Kirsan N. Ilyumzhinov.
lead_paragraph: Garry Kasparov, the former world chess champion, rarely tasted defeat in his long playing career. But on Monday, in an election for the presidency of the World Chess Federation, the game’s governing body, Mr. Kasparov received a stinging rebuke in his effort to unseat the incumbent, Kirsan N. Ilyumzhinov. Mr. Ilyumzhinov won handily, by a vote of 110 to 61, in Tromso, Norway.

headline: 1964: Paris Studying Les Halles Area
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Parisians debated plans to rebuild Les Halles in 1964.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Paris Municipal Council said today [Aug. 11] that it has appropriated $300,000 to study what to do with the tradition-cloaked Les Halles market area once the market moves out two years hence. The cramped wholesale food market, which has tied up traffic near the center of the city for years, will be replaced by a new complex in the suburban town of Rungis. One of the most controversial plans for the Halles area would raze completely a 750-acre slice of land. Out of the rubble a business center would rise with Paris’s first real skyscrapers. The war against a “Brasilia-on-the-Seine” has been mounting in the Paris press. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 12, 1964

headline: The Work of Art That We All Inhabit
abstract: Bernhard Edmaier’s latest book of stunning photographs of Earth’s topography focuses on the vibrant, dazzling and almost unlikely colors that abound in nature.
lead_paragraph: Bernhard Edmaier, who was trained as a civil engineer and geologist, decided 20 years ago to concentrate on photography. His “Patterns of the Earth” (2007) emphasized shapes; “Earth on Fire” (2009) focused on volcanoes and lava. His new book of geology-informed photographs, “EarthArt: Colors of the Earth” (the title page renders “EarthArt” as EARTH), ravishes the eye with combinations of pattern and riotous colors from around the world, in coffee-table size.

headline: New Concerns About an Old Heart Drug
abstract: A large new study found that digoxin, one of the oldest and most commonly used heart medications, may shorten the lives of patients with atrial fibrillation, a common type of irregular heartbeat.
lead_paragraph: A large new study found that one of the oldest and most commonly used heart medications may shorten the lives of patients with atrial fibrillation, a common type of irregular heartbeat that afflicts about three million Americans. The findings are prompting some experts to warn that the drug should be prescribed less widely.

headline: A Sour Note on a Day for Schubert
abstract: There were lengthy concerts, engaging lectures and unexpected fireworks onstage on the first weekend of the Bard Music Festival.
lead_paragraph: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. — During a period when classical music institutions fret over how to entice audiences, the conductor and music historian Leon Botstein has asserted that the worst thing we can do is dumb down the programming. The longtime president of Bard College, Mr. Botstein has put this credo into practice with the annual music festivals he presents on the Bard campus, offering two jampacked weekends of concerts and lectures exploring the life and times of a particular composer. Friday night, the first weekend of the 25th anniversary Bard Music Festival, “Schubert and His World,” opened with an engaging lecture by Mr. Botstein, presenting an overview of Schubert, followed by a three-hour concert touching on several realms of his output.

headline: What Jenny Lewis, Macklemore, The Flaming Lips and More Wore at the Outside Lands Music Festival
abstract: Scenes from the photo diary of Andrea Sonnenberg.
lead_paragraph: Another summer weekend, another star-studded music festival. This one was the seventh edition of Outside Lands, held late each summer in San Francisco’s Golden Gate Park. It calls for more covered-up, layered looks than other summer music bashes thanks to a unique set of climate conditions described by the locals as “Fogust.” Headliners such as Jenny Lewis (in a rainbow-hued pantsuit that matched her guitar) and the Flaming Lips’s Wayne Coyne (in a shaggy tinsel-trimmed jacket) sported warm yet statement-making ensembles that hinted at fall styles to come. Audience members bundled up in sweaters, long skirts and one odd American flag jumpsuit. The photographer Andrea Sonnenberg snapped the action onstage and off.

headline: Iran: Permanent Contraception Through Surgery Is Outlawed
keywords: ['Population', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']
abstract: Moving to allay the concerns of Iran’s supreme leader about the country’s declining fertility rate, Iranian lawmakers passed legislation that prohibits all surgical operations to permanently prevent pregnancy.
lead_paragraph: Moving to allay the concerns of Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, about the country’s declining fertility rate, Iranian lawmakers on Monday passed legislation that prohibits all surgical operations to permanently prevent pregnancy. Passage of the legislation was part of a plan to “prevent a population decline,” the official Islamic Republic News Agency reported. Under the measure, any violation would be considered a crime, punishable by fines. Exceptions were made for surgery urgently required for a patient’s health. Ayatollah Khamenei expressed alarm last winter about the conspicuous decline in births in Iran, saying he was “shaking with fear” about demographic trends that could reduce population growth to zero. The number of children per couple has fallen to 1.3 from a peak of 3.6 in the years after the 1979 Islamic revolution. Many young couples have said they are fearful of bringing children into the world, given Iran’s weak economy and isolation from Western sanctions.

headline: Human Rights Council Plans to Investigate Gaza Conflict
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The United Nations Human Rights Council has appointed three legal experts to an international commission to look into whether violations of international humanitarian and human rights law were committed during the conflict in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations Human Rights Council on Monday appointed three legal experts to an international commission to look into whether violations of international humanitarian and human rights law were committed by Israel and the militant Palestinian group Hamas during the conflict in Gaza. The council, based in Geneva, set up the inquiry last month, and Navi Pillay, the United Nations’ top human rights official, said war crimes might have been committed by both sides in the conflict. A Canadian law professor, William Schabas, will lead the commission and will be joined by Doudou Diène, a lawyer from Senegal who has worked as a United Nations expert on racism. Amal Alamuddin, a British-Lebanese international law specialist, was announced as the third member, but later in the day she said she would be unable to serve on the commission, The Associated Press reported. Israel condemned the resolution setting up the inquiry as “biased, misconceived and destructive.”

Equally popular is the spa’s organic in-house skincare line, Om Aroma and Co., crafted from herbs grown in the Northeast and manufactured in the Catskills region near where the owner Angela Jia Kim and her family rent a weekend country house. So naturally, the next step for Kim’s business was to spin off a second location upstate. The newly opened 2,000-square-foot space, housed on the upper level of a barn house just east of downtown Woodstock — convenient to the Hudson Valley as well as the mountains to the west — offers yoga classes that incorporate aromatherapy and enough room to stretch out and stay all day. It is, Kim says, “a place for people to come and breathe.”

headline: Memo to Self: Do Not Run for Office

lead_paragraph: Last month, Eliana Johnson of National Review gained access to a 144-page memo that was prepared by a team of political strategists working for the senate campaign of Michelle Nunn, the Georgia Democrat. Nunn, the daughter of Sam Nunn, the state’s longtime senator, is running against David Perdue, a Republican, to succeed Saxby Chambliss, who is retiring. While I am obviously not smart enough to be a “political strategist” — otherwise I would be paid more — it strikes me as advisable to keep a document like this under wraps, especially when it is so brutally self-critical in places (saying, among other things, that voters might dismiss Michelle Nunn as being a “lightweight,” “too liberal” and “not a ‘real’ Georgian”). Already the document has become fodder for Twitter ridicule and at least one attack ad.

lead_paragraph: Over the last four days, Adam Ferguson has photographed members of Iraq’s Yazidi minority religious group who had been surrounded on a mountaintop without water or food as a result of battlefield advances made by Sunni militants. As the refugee crisis continues, some have been able to escape into Syria this weekend. Mr. Ferguson, 35, freelances extensively for The New York Times as well as for National Geographic and Time magazine, and he spoke to James Estrin on Monday morning by phone from northern Iraq. Their conversation has been edited.

lead_paragraph: The doctor who had been leading Sierra Leone’s battle against the Ebola outbreak was now fighting for his own life, and his international colleagues faced a fateful decision: whether to give him a drug that had never before been tested on people.

headline: Morning Views
abstract: Opinions on a leadership crisis in Iraq, abuse of Rikers juveniles, an anti-marijuana campaign for teenagers in Colorado and Turkey’s new president.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq “emerged from relative obscurity” in 2006, a New York Times editorial begins. “The best service he could perform now for his country would be to return to that obscurity as soon and as peacefully as possible.” The country is in “mortal danger” from Islamist militants and “needs a unifying hand at the helm,” which Mr. Maliki “emphatically” is not. “He bears heavy responsibility for the current crisis by alienating Sunni, Kurdish and other minority groups and undermining the Army and other national institutions through cronyism and corruption.” Iraq’s president named a more universally accepted candidate Monday, but Mr. Maliki refused to resign. “Adding a constitutional crisis and a potential military coup to the great danger already posed by the jihadists is madness,” the editorial board writes.

headline: Photographing New York City in the Dark
abstract: Vincent Laforet, a former Times photographer, describes getting a photo that now hangs in The Times’s newsroom.
lead_paragraph: Throughout The Times’s headquarters on Eighth Avenue, the walls are decorated with news images from the past. In this series we’ll take you inside the building to see the photographs — many of them rich in history — and the stories behind them.

headline: Dealing With the Press in China: Be Prepared to Sing!
abstract: In China, many interview programs include several segments. You’ll be able to talk about your business, but there may also be questions about your personal life, your opinions about the government, and your overall experience in China. You may even be asked to sing a song.
lead_paragraph: Radio shows, TV appearances and print interviews are all part of a chief executive’s job, whether in China or the United States. But journalists work very differently in China, where editors typically give them a list of questions to ask — and very little leeway to go “off script.”

headline: Salzburg Festival’s ‘Charlotte Salomon’ Falls Short on Drama
abstract: Marc-André Dalbavie’s “Charlotte Salomon,” which had its premiere at the Salzburg Festival, is a reminder that beautiful, thoughtful music does not equal an opera.
lead_paragraph: SALZBURG, Austria — Marc-André Dalbavie has long been a master of haze. “Seuils” (“Thresholds”), which this French composer wrote in 1991, the year he turned 30, opens with a ghostly, enveloping shimmer.

headline: Morning Agenda: Uncertainty Over Master Limited Partnerships
abstract: Kinder Morgan’s reorganization puts master limited partnerships in question. | An arbitration panel has eased the blame on Ernst & Young for audits of Lehman Brothers. | New York prosecutors have accused payday lenders with usury. | Chiquita Brands has received a counter to its inversion plan.
lead_paragraph: When Kinder Morgan, a $100 billion empire that transports much of America’s oil and natural gas, announced on Sunday that it was abandoning the master limited partnership it helped popularize, questions emerged about what would happen to the many other such structures, DealBook’s David Gelles writes. Largely because of Kinder Morgan’s success, the partnerships have become increasingly popular for energy companies. The structure allows them to pass all profits along to their investors as dividends and pay no corporate taxes, though the investors are subject to taxes on the distributions.

headline: In a Word
abstract: An extra-large grab bag of grammar, style and other missteps, compiled — as always — with help from colleagues and readers.
lead_paragraph: Here’s an extra-large grab bag of grammar, style and other missteps, compiled with help from colleagues and readers.

headline: In Performance: Ramin Karimloo of ‘Les Misérables’
abstract: The actor sings and plays the banjo on the number “Bring Him Home.”
lead_paragraph: This week, as several theater critics of The New York Times revisit some long-running Broadway shows, our In Performance video is from the new Broadway revival of the musical “Les Misérables,” a show that originally opened on Broadway in 1987 and ran for over 16 years. The video features the number “Bring Him Home” sung by the actor Ramin Karimloo on banjo, with Sergio Ortega on guitar. Mr. Karimloo, in his Broadway debut, was nominated for a Tony Award for his performance as Jean Valjean. The show is at the Imperial Theater.

lead_paragraph: MANILA — The Philippine military on Tuesday captured a former army general wanted in connection with the disappearance of two students in 2006, a case that human rights groups say has come to symbolize the country’s legacy of abductions and abuses of leftist activists by members of the security forces.

headline: Daily Report: Silicon Valley Hotel Puts Robotic Bellhop to the Test
keywords: ['Artificial Intelligence', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Robots and Robotics']
abstract: The Aloft hotel in Cupertino, Calif., will begin testing a robot that can shuttle items from the hotel lobby desk to guest rooms.
lead_paragraph: On Aug. 20, the Aloft hotel in Cupertino, Calif., across the street from Apple’s corporate campus, will begin testing “Botlr,” a robotic bellhop that can shuttle items from the hotel lobby desk to guest rooms. Whether a gimmick or a sign of things to come, Botlr is the latest among a new generation of robots — like Google’s self-driving car, Aetheon’s Tug hospital supply robot and Caddytrek’s electric golf caddy — that are starting to walk or roll around the everyday world, John Markoff reports.

One day earlier, Audi said that in one province, the dealership network of its Chinese joint venture had broken national antitrust rules and would be punished by the government.

headline: With 4 Senior Lawmakers Retiring, Michigan Faces Loss of Its Clout in Congress

lead_paragraph: YPSILANTI, Mich. — When four senior members of Congress from Michigan retire this fall after a collective 134 years of service, they will leave a legacy that stretches from the woods of the Upper Peninsula to downtown Detroit.

headline: Drummer’s Injury Sidelines Kings of Leon
abstract: After the band’s drummer suffered broken ribs in an accident, Kings of Leon has canceled nine shows.
lead_paragraph: Nathan Followill, the drummer for Kings of Leon, will be out of action through the end of August, and with one exception – the group’s Tuesday evening performance on “The Tonight Show” – so will the band. Mr. Followill’s ribs were broken in a traffic accident on Saturday night, when the band’s tour bus stopped suddenly to avoid hitting a pedestrian. The group canceled its Sunday evening show in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., and posted a message about the accident on its Facebook page, but held off on announcing further cancellations until Mr. Followill’s doctors weighed in. On Monday, they did.

headline: Was an Accusation of Plagiarism Really a Political Attack?
abstract: A Times article on Rick Perlstein’s Reagan book draws criticism for amplifying an accusation unfairly.
lead_paragraph: There aren’t too many worse things you can suggest about an author than that his or her work is plagiarized. It’s the book-world equivalent of spreading the word that a financial adviser has cooked the books or that the parish priest has designs on the altar boys. By its nature, even the suggestion is tarnishing.

headline: An Alien at Home on TV
abstract: For Robin Williams, television was his start and, in some ways, perfect for his talents.
lead_paragraph: In 1978, when “Saturday Night Live” still had almost all of its original cast, and prime time offered “All in The Family,” “M*A*S*H,” “WKRP in Cincinnati,” “Taxi” and “Rhoda,” there didn’t seem to be any room — or need — for something fresh and different on television.

headline: 1939: Grouse Head to White House
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: In 1939, English grouse to grace the White House’s menu.
lead_paragraph: LONDON  — A crate of grouse, destined for President Roosevelt’s dinner table at the White House, flew westward over the Atlantic tonight [Aug. 12] as part of the cargo of the Imperial Airways flying boat Cabot, making the second British air mail flight from Southampton to New York. The grouse were shot on Yorkshire’s famed Helmsley Moor early this morning soon after the dawn of the ‘‘Glorious Twelfth’’ of August which signals the open season on English and Scottish moors. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 13, 1939

headline: Helping Children Find Friends in a New Town (That Aren’t Your Friends, Too)
abstract: My children say they’ve made plenty of friends in our new town. Trouble is, they’re all my co-workers. And as awesome as their grown-up friends are, children need kid friends, too.
lead_paragraph: There’s a thing I do sometimes — I assume other parents do it, too — where I refer to myself and my children as a collective unit. It makes sense a lot of the time, because we do indeed go around as a group quite a bit. “We” are stuck in traffic. “We” love a lazy Sunday stroll. “We” hate banana-flavored candy.

headline: 1964: Creator of James Bond Dies
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: The creator of James Bond, Ian Fleming, dies in 1964.
lead_paragraph: CANTERBURY, England — Ian Fleming, 58, creator of the James Bond novels, died today [Aug. 12] following a heart attack. Mr. Fleming, a World War II naval intelligence commander, often was identified by Bond fans with the fictional hero. But the dapper former newspaperman scoffed at the idea, although some of those who served under him during World War II speculated that several of his exploits still might be cloaked by official secrecy. Mr. Fleming had been on vacation at Sandwich Bay, Kent, with his wife and son when he was taken ill suddenly last night, a friend of the family said. He died about 2:30 a.m. in Canterbury Hospital. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Aug. 13, 1964

headline: Michael Muller on the Shark Photograph That Took One Year to Get
abstract: Capturing a shark breaching at night required a long-term commitment from the photographer.
lead_paragraph: As a photographer who specializes in celebrity portraiture, Michael Muller has photographed some of the most famous people in the world, including Manny Pacquiao, Joaquin Phoenix and Rihanna. But one subject proved particularly elusive: a great white shark breaching at night. After a failed first try, Muller finally got his shot one year later when he returned to False Bay, South Africa. The resulting photograph ran in the Aug. 10 magazine.

headline: Photoville Exhibition Returning to Brooklyn Bridge Park
abstract: The project, at Pier 5 in the park, will include dozens of exhibitions, talks and workshops.
lead_paragraph: United Photo Industries, the Brooklyn photography cooperative probably best known for “The Fence” – the 1,000-foot-long photo installation that began in Brooklyn in 2012 and has since had versions in Boston and Atlanta – will set up its third annual Photoville, a pop-up, modular exhibition space, in Brooklyn Bridge Park from Sept. 18 to 28.

headline: Aurelie Bidermann Sets Up Shop in SoHo
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Jewels and Jewelry', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: The Parisian jewelry designer is debuting her first U.S. flagship on Lafayette Street.
lead_paragraph: Aurelie Bidermann’s fanciful, travel-inspired jewelry has for several seasons been the toast of Paris. Tomorrow, the French designer opens her first U.S. boutique in New York, a city she calls her “second home.” The Lafayette Street storefront, with its striped awning and airy color palette, was inspired by New York and Los Angeles in the ’60s and ’70s, while the assortment within includes a series of exclusive scarab-themed pieces accented with lapis lazuli. “The blue felt very New York to me,” Bidermann explains.

headline: Scenes of Chaos Unfold After a Peaceful Vigil in Ferguson
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Looting (Crime)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Julie Bosman, a New York Times reporter, used Twitter to describe what she was seeing as rioting and looting followed the death of Michael Brown.
lead_paragraph: Three days of unrest have convulsed Ferguson, Mo., after Michael Brown, 18, an unarmed black teenager, was shot and killed by the police on Saturday. A peaceful vigil on Sunday was followed by rioting and looting that led to 32 arrests overnight. On Monday, scenes of unrest continued.

headline: A Meet-Cute of Professional Networking and Online Dating
abstract: Networks for professionals are being mined as a way to meet mates. Dating sites are applying their expertise to finding jobs. Can professional networking and dating go hand in hand?
lead_paragraph: Work and romance may seem like a bad combination, but as more work, and more romance, goes online, the two are meeting in interesting ways. LinkedUp is one startup banking on a version of the old saw that you’re likely to meet your mate at work, while eHarmony, a veteran of online dating, has decided to deploy its expertise to match job seekers with potential employers.

abstract: A perfect dish for summer tomatoes. It works well with two uncooked sauce options: one sweeter, one mintier.

headline: Robin Williams, R.I.P.
abstract: Notes on a great comedian’s dramatic range.
lead_paragraph: When Philip Seymour Hoffman died untimely earlier this year, my post on his legacy noted that he began to make his move as an actor – to make small roles big, to show that he deserved bigger chances still – around the time that I started to really pay attention to the movies, as a teenager in the late 1990s. So even if (like many people) I fully appreciated his place in the pantheon only after his death, there was never really a time when I didn’t associate Hoffman with great acting, and that greatness with the moviegoing experience writ large.

headline: Rihanna’s Summer Bucket Hat
abstract: Now is the perfect time of year to sport an updated version of the classic hot-weather cap. Here, three well-priced options.
lead_paragraph: August, for most of the fashion world, is the quietest month — a moment to soak up the sun before fashion week hits again in September. It’s also a great time for both men and women to sport a no-fuss summer staple recently resurrected by Rihanna: the bucket hat. Also spotted at resort 2015 shows from brands such as Max Mara and Acne, the style will add swagger to any ensemble while shielding skin from ultraviolet rays. Whether plans call for yachting in Ibiza, camping in Oregon or a staycation in the city, these well-priced updates on the classic accessory balance function and fashion.

headline: Baby Pictures at the O.B.’s Office? No More.

headline: Veracruzana Vinegar-Bathed Shrimp
abstract: The cuisine of the state of Veracruz in Mexico has much in common with Spain’s, including this spicy cousin of the Spanish escabeche. The dish calls for a mild vinegar.
lead_paragraph: The state of Veracruz in Mexico is home to many wonderful fish dishes. It’s also a region where olive oil is used, a legacy of its once close trade ties to Spain. Many of the signature dishes of this region have much in common with Spanish cooking, with a widespread use of olives, capers and almonds, and indeed, this is a spicy cousin of Spanish escabeche. Vinegar is widely used in Veracruz, but it is a milder vinegar than our wine vinegars. The vinegar traditionally used in this dish is pineapple vinegar, something I saw being sold in fruit stands all over the state of Veracruz when I traveled there. I use rice vinegar instead, because it’s mild like the pineapple vinegar. If you want a smoky, spicy flavor, use chipotles. Either choice is typical of the region.

lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — A FEW months ago, a patient came to our hospital, seeking help. One of us, Edward, was on the team that treated him. He was pleasant, if slightly withdrawn, and cogent. He was a college graduate in his 20s and had recently been fired from his job as a high school math teacher, because of unexpected absences. He had come to believe that government agents were conspiring against him, and he had taken to living out of a truck and sleeping in different parking lots. By the time he came to us, he was exhausted. A diagnosis became clear: he had schizophrenia.

Prosecutors said the former associate dean, Gabriel Bitran, 69, and his son Marco, 39, a money manager with degrees from M.I.T. and Harvard, falsely told clients they would invest their money using a mathematical model based on the elder Mr. Bitran’s research at M.I.T. that had earned returns between 16 percent and 23 percent, and later lied to investigators seeking to verify their claims. If their pleas are accepted, the Bitrans will each face between two and five years in prison.

headline: North Korea: Captive’s Kin Apologize
abstract: The family of an Ohio municipal worker, arrested more than three months ago while visiting North Korea, publicly offered a “heartfelt apology” to the North Korean authorities and pleaded for his release.
lead_paragraph: The family of Jeffrey E. Fowle, an Ohio municipal worker arrested more than three months ago while visiting North Korea as a tourist, publicly offered its “heartfelt apology” on Tuesday to the North Korean authorities for whatever offense he may have committed and pleaded for his release on humanitarian grounds. In a statement issued by the family’s lawyer, Mr. Fowle’s wife and three young children also said they had received only one letter and one telephone call from him. In an Aug. 1 Associated Press interview with Mr. Fowle that had been approved by the North Korean government from an undisclosed place of confinement, he expressed contrition and said he expected to be tried soon. Neither he nor North Korean officials specified the charges against him, but he is believed to have left a Bible in his Pyongyang hotel, which could have been construed as a hostile act. Mr. Fowle is one of three Americans known to be in the custody of North Korea, which has no diplomatic relations with the United States and regards the American government as its chief enemy.

headline: India: Modi Criticizes Pakistan
abstract: On a visit to Indian-administered Kashmir on Tuesday, Prime Minister Narendra Modi made his toughest statement yet on Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: On a visit to Indian-administered Kashmir on Tuesday, Prime Minister Narendra Modi made his toughest statement yet on Pakistan, saying it “has lost strength to fight conventional war, but continues to engage in a proxy war through terrorism.” The two countries have fought three wars over the disputed territory of Kashmir, as well as a more limited conflict, known as the Kargil war, in 1999. On Tuesday, Mr. Modi visited the town of Kargil, near the Line of Control, to inaugurate a power plant. Top civilian officials have rarely visited Kargil since the conflict there, in which India lost more than 500 soldiers. Estimates of Pakistan’s losses vary, but are believed to be higher. After being elected in May, Mr. Modi took a relatively warm tone toward Pakistan, inviting its prime minister to attend his swearing-in and leaving the impression that the two nuclear-armed neighbors were prepared for a period of calm. Since then, however, cease-fire violations on the Line of Control have become more frequent.

headline: 36 Hours in Nice, France
abstract: A city for all budgets, Nice now buzzes with an energy and diversity that often surpasses its rivals on the Riviera.
lead_paragraph: You have to pity Nice. Overshadowed by megawatt Riviera neighbors like aristocratic Monaco, red-carpet Cannes and Champagne-soaked St.-Tropez, France’s fifth-largest city is often written off as a dowdy haven of retirees. Yet Nice packs most of its neighbors’ lures — year-round sun, Mediterranean Sea, belle époque and Art Deco architecture — with the bonuses of an atmospheric old quarter, an evolving restaurant scene, the Riviera’s best museums and some high-profile public works. Place Garibaldi, the central square, has been pedestrianized and spruced up, while the formerly lackluster port area is filling up with the city’s coolest restaurants and bars. And thanks to the new Promenade du Paillon, Nice has an alluring public park in its heart. A city for all budgets, Nice now buzzes with an energy and diversity that often surpasses its coastal rivals.

(HBO2) ARGO (2012) Ben Affleck, above, directed and stars in this Oscar winner for best film, which covers a little-known chapter of the Iranian hostage crisis, in which Antonio J. Mendez, a Central Intelligence Agency officer and a wizard of disguise, was tapped to help free six State Department employees stranded in Tehran after revolutionary forces seized the United States Embassy on Nov. 4, 1979. His plan: to have them pose as a Canadian movie crew filming a science-fiction flick called “Argo.” John Goodman and Alan Arkin play the Hollywood makeup artist and producer who help him. Bryan Cranston, his neck tendons popping, is one of his bosses; and Clea DuVall, Tate Donovan, Scoot McNairy, Rory Cochrane, Christopher Denham and Kerry Bishé are the escapees. After setting your pulse racing, Mr. Affleck “smoothly downshifts, easing from the high anxiety of the opener — which evokes 1970s political thrillers like Sydney Pollack’s ‘Three Days of the Condor’ — into something looser, mellower and funny,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times.

headline: The Rise of Beefcake Yoga
abstract: Diamond Dallas Page, a former W.W.E. wrestler, created a new form of healing for broken-down macho guys like himself.
lead_paragraph: A horde of screaming middle-aged wrestling fans gathered one Saturday evening in April at the Smoothie King Center in New Orleans to celebrate professional wrestling’s Hall of Fame induction ceremony. The world’s most popular fake-sport organization, World Wrestling Entertainment doesn’t maintain a brick-and-mortar Hall of Fame — no bronze plaques to commemorate its greats (the Ultimate Warrior, Superfly Jimmy Snuka), no interactive widgets to teach young fans storied techniques (“the camel clutch,” “the piledriver”). Instead, once a year, W.W.E.’s former stars relive their glory together, on a stage, face to face with thousands of their most fervent admirers. Throughout the preceding week, these fans traipsed up and down Bourbon Street until 2 a.m., screaming the names of their favorite wrestlers into the night. Now they wore fake championship belts and chanted ecstatically as retired stars strutted by in big ‘n’ tall tuxedos and sequined gowns. A deafening “hoooe!” greeted (Hacksaw) Jim Duggan; (Nature Boy) Ric Flair earned a high-pitched “woooo!” Hulk Hogan, who arrived in a black suit, black bandanna and yellow wraparound shades, sent hundreds of so-called Hulkamaniacs into a fit of rapture.

headline: Morning Views
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Referendums', 'Segregation and Desegregation', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Opinions on our toxic racial legacy, Egypt’s dismal human-rights record, the right to vote in British prisons, verifying humanitarian aid in Ukraine and improved Iraqi governance.
lead_paragraph: “The F.B.I. may be able to answer the many questions surrounding the death of Michael Brown, an 18-year-old black student from Ferguson, Mo., who was a few days from heading off to college when he was shot by a police officer on Saturday,” begins an editorial in The New York Times. “But it doesn’t take a federal investigation to understand the history of racial segregation, economic inequality and overbearing law enforcement that produced so much of the tension now evident on the streets.” St. Louis, the editorial says, “has long been one of the nation’s most segregated metropolitan areas,” with whites dominating the City Council and police department. For decades whites used zoning laws to keep blacks out of desirable areas; among black residents “within the city, poverty and unrest grew.” The black population has also been subjected to intervention from the largely white police force “far out of proportion to their population,” according to the editorial. “The circumstances of Mr. Brown’s death are, inevitably, in dispute,” says the editorial, but “what is not in dispute is the sense of permanent grievance held by many residents and shared in segregated urban areas around the country.” Mr. Brown’s death serves as “a reminder of a toxic racial legacy that still infects cities and suburbs across America.”

headline: Pitfalls of Privilege
abstract: In Mary Gordon’s novellas, serenity is upended and sheltered lives become tinged with misgivings.
lead_paragraph: When asked about the difference between writing a short story and writing a novel, I invariably fall back on an analogy to painting: the delicate watercolor versus the large canvas in oil. But what of my favorite form, the novella, or “the long story,” as students say these days? The novella requires quick, deft strokes, but allows for enough space and time to build up layers. Light may show through in dark areas; deep shadows may fall. At its best, the novella has a specific density all its own, engaging the reader with a bright surface and hidden depths. Henry James, who adored what he called “the dear, the blessed nouvelle,” lamented that in his time it was “foredoomed at the best, in more cases than not, to editorial disfavor.”
