headline: Syria and the Risks of Intervention
abstract: Why arming the “moderate” Syrian rebels probably would have been a mistake.
lead_paragraph: Now that I’ve tried to make and defend the case for our current intervention against ISIS, I want to also expand on my reasons for skepticism about the kind of intervention that a number of hawks (including the next Democratic nominee for president, it would seem) believe would have made the current war unnecessary — that is, the kind of military support for Syria’s more moderate/liberal/secular rebels that, it’s argued, would have prevented more radical groups from getting traction in that conflict, and thus forestalled the rise of ISIS to its current bad eminence.

headline: Fiscal Flimflam, Revisited
abstract: What was wrong with the Ryan budget?
lead_paragraph: Brad DeLong reminds us of the original Ryan budget plan — or actually “plan”, as I’ll explain — and emphasizes its dire warnings about a looming debt crisis that wasn’t. But pointing out that the debt panic was unjustified only gets at part of what was wrong with that Ryan budget (and all his subsequent proposals). For the fact is that it wasn’t a proposal made in good faith.

headline: Caffeine May Reduce Tinnitus Risk
abstract: A new study reports that caffeine intake is associated with a reduced risk for tinnitus — ringing or buzzing in the ears.
lead_paragraph: A new study reports that caffeine intake is associated with a reduced risk for tinnitus — ringing or buzzing in the ears.

headline: ‘Love Letters’ and ‘Honeymoon in Vegas’ Swap Broadway Theaters
abstract: “Love Letters” and “Honeymoon in Vegas” will shift to theaters better suited to the productions.
lead_paragraph: Two Broadway productions scheduled to open in the fall – “Honeymoon in Vegas,” a musical by Andrew Bergman and Jason Robert Brown, and “Love Letters,” a revival of A.R. Gurney’s 1989 two-person play – will switch theaters to better suit their needs. The swap was announced by the Nederlander Organization, which operates both theaters.

headline: Hillary Clinton Doesn’t Know When to Stop
abstract: Her attack on President Obama’s policies shows that she doesn’t have an internal braking mechanism.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to dispute that Hillary Clinton is the smartest person in most rooms. That’s why The Times editorial board endorsed her in the Democratic primary in 2008 over Barack Obama.

headline: Court Refuses to Stay Its Decision Striking Down Virginia’s Same-Sex Marriage Ban
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Couples could start marrying by next week as a federal appeals court panel denied a request to delay its ruling striking down Virginia’s ban on same-sex marriages.
lead_paragraph: The federal appeals court that last month struck down Virginia’s ban on same-sex unions refused Wednesday to delay the effects of its ruling. State officials said that unless the United States Supreme Court interceded, Virginia counties could begin issuing marriage licenses to gay couples next week.

headline: Cuomo, Visiting Israel, Joins Growing U.S. List
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: Andrew M. Cuomo’s trip to Israel, his first travel abroad as governor of New York, comes as more and more American officials are visiting, eager to show support.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — It is high season for travel to the Holy Land.

headline: 1939: Bastille Stone Found in House
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: A stone from the Bastille prison is found in a house of the Sens region in 1939.
lead_paragraph: SENS — Set in the wall of an old house in Saint-Julien-du-Sault is a stone from the Bastille, one of the few authentic relics of the grim fortress of which no vestige exists in Paris since its destruction in 1789 by the revolutionary masses. The stone bears the following inscription in Latin and French: ‘‘This stone has been taken from the ruins of the Bastille. Patriotism has dedicated it to a better use by placing it here to give to this square the sweet name of Liberty. In the second year of French liberty.’’ For several years, stones from the Bastille were very fashionable. Small fragments of them were set like jewels and worn by women in rings and necklaces. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 14, 1939

headline: Man Is Shot and Killed by the Police in California
abstract: The police said the man had lunged for an officer’s weapon, but family members contended he had been lying on the ground when he was shot three times.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The police shot and killed an unarmed black man in South Los Angeles on Monday night, the Los Angeles Police Department said. The police said that the man, whom the department did not identify, had tackled an officer and lunged for the weapon in his holster before being shot at by both the officer and his partner.

headline: Militants’ Siege on Mountain in Iraq Is Over, Pentagon Says
keywords: ['Yazidi (Religious Sect)', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Defense officials said that American airstrikes and Kurdish fighters had broken the Islamic militants’ siege of Mount Sinjar, allowing thousands of the Yazidis trapped there to escape.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Defense Department officials said late Wednesday that United States airstrikes and Kurdish fighters had broken the Islamic militants’ siege of Mount Sinjar, allowing thousands of the Yazidis trapped there to escape.

headline: Runway Report | Where the Wild Things Are
abstract: Leopard, the naughtiest of prints, is back in fashion. But the look is tailored and covered up, leaving any risky business to the imagination.
lead_paragraph: Leopard, the naughtiest of prints, is back in fashion. But the look is tailored and covered up, leaving any risky business to the imagination.

headline: A Lighthouse Museum, 16 Years in the Making, Is Taking Shape
abstract: The National Lighthouse Museum, a few hundred feet south of the St. George Ferry Terminal on Staten Island, is set to open in late fall.
lead_paragraph: After 16 years of fog — thick as pea soup at times — a lighthouse museum is finally coming into view on Staten Island.

headline: Smartphones Overstate Their Social Intelligence
abstract: With access to our calendars, contacts and location, phones should be able to communicate with great intelligence, but often buzz at just the wrong time.
lead_paragraph: When a smartphone app wants to alert you to a coming appointment, a text message or some bit of breaking news from your social network, it sends a tiny flare that lights up your phone’s lock screen. Depending on how you’ve set it up, the app might then buzz your pocket like a manic bee, sound a citywide panic alarm or begin playing “La Cucaracha.”

headline: Maliki Plans to Carry Bid for Power to Iraq Courts
abstract: Despite increasing pressure, Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq said he would not give up his claim to forming a new government and holding on to the prime minister’s post.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki said Wednesday that he would press ahead in the Iraqi courts with his increasingly unlikely bid to retain power, and would not turn to the army.

headline: 6 Climbers Killed in Fall From French Peak
abstract: Amid bad weather, the authorities spotted the bodies of the six climbers, who apparently fell as they prepared to descend from the 12,800-foot “Aiguille d’Argentière.”
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Six French climbers were reported dead on Wednesday after falling hundreds of feet as they began to descend one of the highest peaks of the Mont Blanc range in France, the authorities said.

headline: David Furnish on Food, Fizz and Fun in Las Vegas
abstract: The creative director behind the Las Vegas lounge Fizz (and husband of Elton John) talks about what he likes to see and where he likes to eat in the city.
lead_paragraph: “I think people go to Vegas to celebrate, to treat themselves, and I can’t think of a better way to do that than with a glass of champagne,” said David Furnish, the creative director behind the Las Vegas lounge Fizz in Caesars Palace, which specializes in bubbly. Fizz, which opened in March, has more than 40 champagnes on its menu, and offers 14 of them by the glass.

headline: A Corner of Durham, N.C., Comes to Life
abstract: In the once-neglected Central Park District, you can find top-notch barbecue, live music, fair trade coffee and more.
lead_paragraph: Like firecrackers exploding around downtown Durham, clusters of small businesses are popping up and enlivening one desolate block after another. Over the past months, the loudest bangs have been heard in the Central Park District near the corner of Rigsbee Avenue and West Geer Street. The intersection was first settled by Fullsteam Brewery, whose cavernous tavern lured locals (and lots of food trucks) to this previously neglected part of town. Now there’s live music, top-notch barbecue, fair trade coffee, and even valet parking on a block that five years ago was deserted after dark.

headline: Solving the Journalism Riddle — Somehow
abstract: Reports from all over on the challenges in a difficult week, and decade, for newspapers.
lead_paragraph: On vacation last week I left my laptop behind and realized once more that cell service was spotty at the lakeside house where my family gathers. So it was easy to do what I planned to do: Unplug and get off the grid.

headline: Teenager Slain in Ferguson, Mo., Mourned
abstract: A cousin of Michael Brown, a lawyer representing the Brown family and the Rev. Al Sharpton spoke at St. Mark’s family church in Jennings, Mo., days after the teenager was killed in nearby Ferguson.
lead_paragraph: A cousin of Michael Brown, a lawyer representing the Brown family and the Rev. Al Sharpton spoke at St. Mark’s family church in Jennings, Mo., days after the teenager was killed in nearby Ferguson.

headline: Ackman’s Sales Pitch for His Hedge Fund, and His I.P.O.
abstract: In a letter to investors, William Ackman noted the returns of his hedge fund since it started 10 years ago (627 percent) and said a separate public listing was set for “later this year.”
lead_paragraph: Ever the salesman, William A. Ackman told investors on Wednesday that if they had put money into his hedge fund Pershing Square Capital Management when it started 10 years ago, they would have seen a 627 percent return.

headline: In Middle Tier, College Sports Tries to Adjust
abstract: Fresno State is a bellwether for how next-tier programs view the changes that seem destined to mostly help the nation’s top programs.
lead_paragraph: FRESNO, Calif. — As hundreds of universities try to make sense of the seismic jolts remaking the landscape of college sports, the only certainties appear to be that the rich are getting richer and that the poor will fall further behind. Stuck in the middle are universities like Fresno State.

headline: In The Times: Remembering Lauren Bacall
abstract: Tracing the life and work of the actress through the years.
lead_paragraph: Though born and raised in New York City — where she died on Tuesday — Lauren Bacall managed to evade the attention of The New York Times for 20 years.

headline: Government Grants May Help Ease Business Challenges
abstract: Programs at the federal, state and local levels typically come with strict requirements, but they can help pay for training employees and more.
lead_paragraph: For more than two decades, from a Willy Wonka-like studio in New York’s garment district, Michelle Feinberg’s company, the New York Embroidery Studio, has helped amateurs and brand-name designers embellish garments with decorative stitching, rhinestones, sequins and other items. So, when a longtime client, Ralph Lauren, approached her in 2010 and asked her to help create uniforms for Team USA at the Sochi Olympics, Ms. Feinberg jumped at the chance.

headline: That Voice, and the Woman Attached
abstract: From the beginning of her career, Lauren Bacall projected an indelible screen persona: that of the tough, quick-witted American woman who could fight alongside her man.
lead_paragraph: Her voice comes at you low and flat, wildly insinuating, electric and lingering. In another age, Lauren Bacall’s voice might have been called mannish. When she opened her mouth in “To Have and Have Not” — taking a long drag on a cigarette while locking Humphrey Bogart in her gaze — she staked a claim on the screen and made an immortal Hollywood debut. But in 1944 at the exquisitely tender age of 19, she was also projecting an indelible screen persona: that of the tough, quick-witted American woman who could fight the good fight alongside her man.

headline: Rainy Day Video Game Rules: Is iPad Monopoly ‘Screen Time?’
abstract: There are only two children at home on this rainy day, and only one child wants to play Monopoly — which brought up a new question. Is playing Monopoly against the iPad really a “video game”?
lead_paragraph: It’s a rainy summer day here. Pouring, in fact. But it remains a weekday, and the usual household rules are still in effect: iPads, computers, television and all video games are for weekends only.

headline: An Epic Road Trip in an Electric Tuk Tuk
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Road Trips', 'Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: Naveen Ravelli, a 33-year-old electrical engineer from Bangalore, India, hopes to drive his custom-built electric auto rickshaw from India to England.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, Naveen Rabelli, 33, an electrical engineer from Bangalore, India, had an idea while sitting in traffic surrounded by the ubiquitous and polluting three-wheel vehicles known colloquially as tuk tuks. Why not, he recalls thinking, make one that runs on solar-electric power?

headline: Nickelodeon Cartoon Pitches at Comic-Con Turn Up a Winner
abstract: Nickelodeon held an open call for new cartoon ideas at Comic-Con and will turn the proposal for “Cupcakery of Doom,” pitched by a 28-year-old journalist, into an animated short.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Nickelodeon said on Wednesday that an unusual open call for new cartoon ideas had produced a surprisingly strong result: “Cupcakery of Doom.” A 28-year-old newspaper employee pitched the idea, and it will be developed into an animated short with the potential to turn into a television series.

headline: Culture Club to Tour With Original Lineup
abstract: The reunited group will tour the United States and Britain this fall.
lead_paragraph: The British band Culture Club will reconvene with its original lineup – the flamboyant singer Boy George, the guitarist and keyboardist Roy Hay, the bassist Mikey Craig and the drummer Jon Moss – for an American tour in November and a British tour in December, Boy George announced on his webpage. Reports of a reunion had been circulating since May, but the posting is the first official confirmation that the Culture Club has reunited and plans to tour.

headline: Classical Playlist: Bruckner, Richard Reed Parry, Brahms and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: BRUCKNER: Symphony No. 7Budapest Festival Orchestra, Ivan Fischer, conductor(Channel Classics CCS SA 33714)For more than 30 years the conductor Ivan Fischer has been drawing inspired, fresh and intelligent performances from the impressive Budapest Festival Orchestra, an ensemble he co-founded and still conducts. Some Bruckner-lovers may find this account of the great Seventh Symphony lacking in mysticism and gravity. I suspect that most listeners, like me, will be drawn into the vibrant, glowing and revitalized performance Mr. Fischer draws from his excellent players. The sound of the orchestra is lush and rich, yet wondrously lucid. (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: Kimbra, the New Zealand Songstress Who Moved to a Sheep Farm in L.A.
abstract: It’s part of an overall strategy of embracing the surreal for the pop star, best known for the hit single she recorded with Gotye. Her sophomore album is out this week.
lead_paragraph: The New Zealand–born pop singer Kimbra is full of surprises. She’s a Prince fanatic who studies the way the Purple One’s backing vocals “jump into your face, so loud and invasive, like they’re characters themselves, or a gang.” She’s an armchair philosopher who muses, “There’s a rousing frequency in the universe that could be divine, or primal, or human, but it’s a sound that calls you outward to where you feel unbound by time and space.”

headline: ‘Finding Neverland’ to Come to Broadway in March
abstract: A new musical, based on the 2004 film about J. M. Barrie, will begin performances in March.
lead_paragraph: “Finding Neverland,” a new musical based on the 2004 film about the “Peter Pan” playwright J. M. Barrie, will begin performances on Broadway in March, a spokesman for the show’s producer, Harvey Weinstein, said on Wednesday. A tryout production of the musical is underway at the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass., where it will officially open on Wednesday night.

headline: The Science Behind Suicide Contagion
abstract: Publicity about suicides, especially those of celebrities, has been linked to an increase in suicides, especially among young people.
lead_paragraph: When Marilyn Monroe died in August 1962, with the cause listed as probable suicide, the nation reacted. In the months afterward, there was extensive news coverage, widespread sorrow and a spate of suicides. According to one study, the suicide rate in the United States jumped by 12 percent compared with the same months in the previous year.

headline: Man Gets Probation in Attack on Ai Weiwei Vase
abstract: Maximo Caminero, a 51-year-old artist from the Dominican Republic, will be on probation for 18 months, after what he called “an act of solidarity” with Ai Weiwei.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — As part of a deal with prosecutors, the man accused of smashing a vase by the Chinese artist Ai Weiwei in a museum here pleaded guilty Wednesday to criminal mischief but avoided any more jail time beyond the two days he spent behind bars after his arrest.

headline: A New Voice at the Tracks in New York
abstract: Larry Collmus, the race caller for NBC’s Triple Crown broadcasts, was hired by NYRA to replace the longtime announcer Tom Durkin.
lead_paragraph: They are big binoculars to fill, but Larry Collmus will replace Tom Durkin as the voice of New York racing.

headline: Bieber Pleads Guilty in Florida Case
abstract: In one of a number of legal cases he is facing, Justin Bieber pleads guilty to careless driving and resisting arrest after an incident in Florida.
lead_paragraph: Justin Bieber may be making more money for his lawyers, and for anger management clinics, than for his record company these days. Barely a month ago he pleaded no contest to egging a neighbor’s house in Los Angeles, and agreed to pay restitution and undergo anger management therapy.

headline: After a Hawaii Storm, a Moment in the Sun: A Rural Area Will Cast a Close Race’s Last Votes
keywords: ['Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Elections, Senate', 'Midterm Elections (2014)']
abstract: A remote Hawaiian area that has often felt neglected is receiving unaccustomed attention after rescheduling its vote in a close Democratic Senate primary.
lead_paragraph: PUNA, Hawaii — Politics seldom intrudes on the easternmost district of the Big Island of Hawaii, a hard-to-reach paradise where the homes are nestled among lava-formed cliffs and the papaya and macadamia nut harvests loom larger than the machinations in Honolulu, let alone in Washington.

headline: HBO Orders a Second Season of ‘The Leftovers’
abstract: The well-reviewed drama follows the mysterious disappearance of 140 million people in a spontaneous act suspected to be the Rapture.
lead_paragraph: HBO made official on Wednesday the expected news that “The Leftovers” would be renewed for a second season.

headline: N.R.A. Model Sheriff Wins in Milwaukee
abstract: David Clarke posed with a white cowboy hat and told his constituents to arm themselves.
lead_paragraph: For the past 12 years, Sheriff David Clarke Jr. has been hard to ignore in the political arena of Milwaukee county, Wis. He favors posing confidently on his horse with a white cowboy hat, sunglasses and a pistol on his hip. His message to constituents has been to wise up and arm themselves against the criminal element. Police can’t do it all. “It’s no longer a spectator sport,” the sheriff told them last year in a public service announcement. “I need you in the game.”

headline: Wheelies: The 99 Continental GT3-Rs Edition
abstract: Bentley to introduce the Continental GT3-R in the United States at Pebble Beach; Truecar stock price soars.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: ‘Guardians of the Galaxy’ Soundtrack Is No. 1
abstract: The soundtrack, subtitled “Awesome Mix Vol. 1,” hit the top spot in its second week.
lead_paragraph: Disney has sent another soundtrack to No. 1, as “Guardians of the Galaxy” follows “Frozen” to the top spot on Billboard’s chart.

headline: A New Resort in Key West
abstract: The 96-room, three-pool Marker Waterfront Resort in Key West, Fla., is scheduled to open in October.
lead_paragraph: According to the travel research firm STR Inc., hotels in the Florida Keys had the highest hotel occupancy and were among the top 10 in revenue per available room in the country in the first quarter of 2014.

headline: Enlivening Beethoven With a Sprightly Pace
abstract: Gianandrea Noseda conducts a lively account of Beethoven’s Ninth Symphony at the Mostly Mozart Festival.
lead_paragraph: The Mostly Mozart Festival has been trying in recent years to enliven its offerings with contemporary music programs and unusual repertory. So playing Beethoven’s Ninth Symphony, as the festival orchestra did on Tuesday, though an ambitious undertaking, was not very daring.

headline: Waiting Out Rain for Haydn, Schoenfield and Weber
abstract: Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center played a program of Haydn, Schoenfield and Weber in Central Park.
lead_paragraph: Pleasant weather marked the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center’s concert at the Naumburg Bandshell in Central Park on Tuesday. Pleasant weather for the fish in the nearby lake, that is. Haydn was a famous exponent of “Sturm und Drang,” but the torrential rain that began as the society’s players prepared to emerge for one of his piano trios seemed a joke too far.

headline: The Art Book Publisher Gestalten Launches an Imprint for Kids
abstract: The new offshoot, Little Gestalten, features titles that both adults and youngsters will enjoy.
lead_paragraph: Kids will ask for the same book, night after night, for months, even years. So parents know how critical it is that an oft-requested tale be pleasing to both adults and little ones. The Berlin-based art publisher Gestalten has just launched a new children’s book imprint, Little Gestalten, that marries thoughtful storytelling with supercool visuals. “Elsa and the Night,” by the Swedish author, illustrator and filmmaker Jöns Mellgren, tells the tale of a little girl who makes friends with both the night and an elephant named Olaf. In “The Zoo’s Grand Opening,” the German author and designer Judith Drews zips through the colorful letters of the alphabet, pairing each with an animal and witty remark (“Our skunk might look all cute and fluffy/But you should run like mad if he gets huffy”). Small hands will enjoy turning the oversize pages of the Japanese fairy tale “Issun Bôshi,” which has been reimagined by Mayumi Otero and Raphaël Urwiller, the duo behind the French design house Icinori. Even the classic “Little Red Riding Hood” seems new again in Little Gestalten’s version, with cutout images that can be held up to the light to cast shadows on the wall until it’s time to say, “My, what big, tired eyes you have.”

headline: Cuomo Meets With Netanyahu
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York expressed his solidarity with Israel in a meeting with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in Jerusalem on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York expressed his solidarity with Israel in a meeting with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in Jerusalem on Wednesday.

headline: Celine Dion Puts Her Career on Hold Over Health Issues
abstract: The Canadian singer has “decided to postpone all of her show business activities indefinitely” in order to focus on her family and on health issues.
lead_paragraph: A message posted on Celine Dion’s website early Wednesday said that the Canadian singer has “decided to postpone all of her show business activities indefinitely” in order to focus on her family and on health issues that both she and her husband, René Angélil, are facing.

headline: Gift of GQ Magazine Prompts Outcry From Lands’ End Customers
abstract: Some Lands’ End shoppers were none too pleased to receive a free copy of GQ that featured a model posing topless except for a strategically placed lei.
lead_paragraph: The free magazine was meant as a gift from Lands’ End — the retailer known for its conservative, sturdy clothing — to its most valued customers.

headline: Inevitable Mission Creep in Iraq
keywords: ['Humanitarian Aid', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The president said there would be no ground troops. And yet…
lead_paragraph: Just a few days after the American military operation began to help the refugees atop Mount Sinjar in northern Iraq, comes the inevitable headline: “U.S. Could Use Ground Troops to Aid Rescue of Iraq Refugees.”

headline: Pryor, Jets’ Top Selection, Is Set to Make His Debut
abstract: The rookie safety Calvin Pryor sat out the Jets’ first preseason game because of a concussion.
lead_paragraph: CORTLAND, N.Y. — When Saalim Hakim used a slant pattern to pull in a pass from Tajh Boyd during Jets practice on Tuesday, the rookie safety Calvin Pryor remained mindful that tackling is not permitted during training camp sessions. Since bumping is allowed, Pryor bumped Hakim, a reserve wide receiver, with enough force to send him sprawling.

headline: A Pilgrim’s Progress, or Lack Thereof
abstract: In “Colorless Tsukuru Tazaki and His Years of Pilgrimage,” Haruki Murakami traces an adolescent breakup and a decades-long search for why it happened.
lead_paragraph: Chalk up some of Haruki Murakami’s rock-star status to the way he evokes the self-pitying narcissism of youth. At 65, Mr. Murakami can still channel the agonies of a high school student who thought that he and his four best friends were the center of the universe — until the cruel, fateful day when the friends stopped speaking to him for no apparent reason.

lead_paragraph: What are the kids today up to? They are tweeting jokes about being losers.

headline: Anonymity in Police Shooting Fuels Anger in Missouri
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: In the days since an unarmed man was killed by a police officer in Ferguson, Mo., the selective release of information, and especially the anonymity granted the officer, has stoked frustrations.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — In the five days since an unarmed young black man was fatally shot by a police officer here, the selective release of information about the shooting, and especially the anonymity granted to the officer, has stoked frustrations in this largely African-American community north of St. Louis, where residents describe increasingly tense relations with the police.

headline: Giants’ Manningham Won’t Let One Catch Define Him
abstract: Mario Manningham, a wide receiver who helped the team win a Super Bowl, is looking to catch on with the Giants a second time.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Saturday night’s preseason game between the Giants and the Indianapolis Colts will return Mario Manningham to the field where he made the defining catch of his career. But do not expect Manningham to feel nostalgic when he enters Lucas Oil Stadium, site of the Giants’ victory over the New England Patriots in Super Bowl XLVI.

headline: A Deal From the Fast Pairs Championship
abstract: The Summer Nationals were held in Las Vegas last month.
lead_paragraph: The World Youth Team Championships start on Thursday in Istanbul. There are four events: juniors, girls (both for those born in 1989 or later), youngsters (born in 1994 or later) and kids (born in 1999 or later).

headline: Digitizing Warhol’s Film Trove to Save It
abstract: The Andy Warhol Museum in Pittsburgh and the Museum of Modern Art are working together, hoping to lift Warhol’s film work to the level of his other art.
lead_paragraph: Andy Warhol wrote lovingly of his ever-present tape recorder. (“My tape recorder and I have been married for 10 years now. When I say ‘we,’ I mean my tape recorder and me.”) But for almost a decade beginning in the 1960s, his real boon companions seemed to be his 16-millimeter film cameras, which he used to record hundreds of reels, many of which are still little known even among scholars because of the fragility of the film and the scarcity of projectors to show them on.

headline: Hedge Fund Holdouts Fail to Reach Private Deal Over Argentine Debt
abstract: Aurelius Capital Management said that a deal involving private banks was no longer on the table.
lead_paragraph: Aurelius Capital Management, one of the hedge funds that has battled with Argentina over billions of dollars in bond payments, said on Wednesday that efforts to reach a deal with private parties in the wake of the country’s default had collapsed.

headline: A Joint Laid to Ruin by Recession
abstract: The rock musical “Revolution in the Elbow of Ragnar Agnarsson,” an import from Iceland, addresses the economic tumult in a town that resides in the titular body part.
lead_paragraph: See if you can spot the joke built into the title of the new rock musical at the Minetta Lane Theater: “Revolution in the Elbow of Ragnar Agnarsson Furniture Painter.”

abstract: For a few weeks after D-Day, John G. Morris, a photo editor, took pictures of French life during wartime. Seventy years later, they are being exhibited.
lead_paragraph: For a few weeks after D-Day, John G. Morris, a photo editor, took pictures of French life during wartime. Seventy years later, they are being exhibited.

lead_paragraph: An uncompromising youthquake revitalized the fall runways with collegiate starter jackets, short skirts and nubby sweaters that inspire a coltish confidence.

headline: Laughing Off Threats in the Fight Against ‘Fake Democracy’
abstract: At least one of the leaders of a civil disobedience movement seeking universal suffrage in Hong Kong has received threats that reflect the tensions between those who want a democratic city, and those who want a semi-authoritarian one, at best.
lead_paragraph: Chan Kin-man, a prominent Hong Kong democracy activist, receives many anonymous threats. He has gotten a razor blade in the mail and messages like: ‘‘Hunt and Kill Traitors!’’ Sophisticated hacking attempts occur daily, often from email addresses belonging to friends or students. Some threats are unprintable, about what the sender would like to do to Mr. Chan’s mother.

headline: A Betrayed Wife, Clinging to Hope
abstract: Like so many spectacularly successful comic playwrights from the first half of the 20th century, George Kelly (the uncle of Grace) is mostly forgotten.
lead_paragraph: Like so many spectacularly successful comic playwrights from the first half of the 20th century, George Kelly (the uncle of Grace) is mostly forgotten. The interest that he does occasionally draw from contemporary producers is for his early satires. In 2000 Dylan Baker directed a droll and flamboyant production of “The Torch-Bearers,” Kelly’s 1922 sendup of community theater, which featured a memorably bravura performance by Marian Seldes. “The Show-Off,” which Kelly wrote two years later, is also periodically remounted. But the Mint Theater is not content with producing an ignored writer. Drawn to obscurity like a certain kind of obsessed indie music fan, it searches out the ignored works of ignored writers. So this month, the Mint mounts a rare production of one of Kelly’s later plays, “The Fatal Weakness” (1946), about a woman in a 28-year marriage who discovers that her husband is having an affair. Her fatal weakness is that she’s a hopeless romantic. (“The Fatal Weakness” starts previews on Tuesday at the Mint, 311 West 43rd Street, Clinton; minttheater.org, 866-811-4111.)

headline: Be Yourself, Music Videos Tell the Young

A crew member blows by and says they found her in the green room, apparently smitten to the point of distraction by a big strapping cowboy, my father. Bill Rotert, Mom would scold, later, on their drive home.

headline: Recipes for Kitchen Redesigns
abstract: “The Kitchen Bible” offers aspirational examples as well as advice for do-it-yourselfers tackling kitchen makeovers themselves.
lead_paragraph: Kitchens tend to be busy, messy places thanks to the role they’ve assumed as the hub of the home. And apartment kitchens are often cramped and lacking in natural light and views. These are not the sorts of kitchens you will find in “The Kitchen Bible: Designing the Perfect Culinary Space” (Images Publishing; $45), by Barbara Ballinger, Margaret Crane and Jennifer Gilmer, a kitchen designer of three decades. The aspirational spaces pictured here, many designed by Ms. Gilmer, are mostly amply sized, outfitted with the latest appliances and carefully propped for their close-ups. But the book also clearly lays out the steps involved in a kitchen redo. Although geared more toward those who will be working with a kitchen designer than those tackling makeovers themselves, the book offers advice on things like hanging stove hoods that is useful for do-it-yourselfers, too.

headline: Ex-Head of Washington Schools Steps Down at Advocacy Group
abstract: Michelle A. Rhee, the divisive former schools chancellor in Washington a is stepping down as chief executive of StudentsFirst, the advocacy group she founded four years ago.
lead_paragraph: Michelle A. Rhee, the divisive former schools chancellor in Washington and one of the most public faces of a campaign to change public education, is stepping down as chief executive of StudentsFirst, the advocacy group she founded four years ago. In a blog post on the group’s website on Wednesday, Ms. Rhee said that it was “time for my next step in life” and that she would focus on her family and support her husband, Mayor Kevin Johnson of Sacramento, as “he continues to move forward with his career.” She also has two children with her ex-husband, Kevin Huffman, the commissioner of education in Tennessee. Ms. Rhee, who raised millions of dollars from donors including the Walton Family Foundation and the Broad Foundation, pursued an aggressive agenda involving changes in state laws regarding teacher tenure, performance evaluations and testing. In her statement, she said: “While I remain 100 percent committed to the success of StudentsFirst, it’s time for a shift in the day-to-day management of the team and our advocacy work.”

headline: Lucky Magazine Gets an E-Partner to Shop With

lead_paragraph: WHEN LUCKY MAGAZINE arrived on newsstands almost 14 years ago, it was the most exciting thing to happen to Condé Nast since Rice Krispies Treats in the Frank Gehry-designed cafeteria at 4 Times Square. And for readers, Lucky was not unlike a Rice Krispies Treat: hard to resist; easy to accuse of lacking nutritional value; “sticky” with its decals that one could affix, with the glee of a preschooler, to pictures of items one planned to buy. Hitherto American women’s publications had cloaked their mercenary objectives in the soft batting of short fiction and horoscopes and etiquette advice; this one declared nakedly on the cover that it was the “magazine about shopping.”

Fuller, would be moved before other judges. Judge Fuller, of the Federal District Court for the Middle District of Alabama, was charged with battery after the police were called to a luxury hotel in Atlanta. He was released on bond on Monday on a misdemeanor charge. Judge Fuller joined the bench in Montgomery in 2002 after being nominated by President George W. Bush.

That’s mostly thanks to its historic center, home to nearly 300 Colonial-era houses — the most of any town in the United States, according to the local Chamber of Commerce. The fishing town was one of the most prosperous in the colonies. Shipmasters, bakers and cordwainers alike found the money to build solid and beautiful homes that are still much in demand today.

headline: Mexico: Lawmaker Punished in Scandal
keywords: ['Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Parties (Social)', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Mexico’s conservative opposition party has removed one of its congressional whips after a video emerged showing him and other legislators at a party with table dancers.
lead_paragraph: Mexico’s conservative opposition party has removed one of its congressional whips after a video emerged showing him and other legislators at a party with table dancers. The National Action Party, whose members often talk of maintaining wholesome family values, removed Luis Alberto Villarreal on Wednesday as coordinator of its legislators in the lower house as well as Mr. Villarreal’s deputy, Jorge Villalobos, who also appears in the video. It was taken earlier this year at a party at a beach resort but was disclosed this week on ReporteIndigo.com, a news website. Former President Felipe Calderón, a member of the party, said Wednesday in a radio interview that the video showed the “moral decomposition” of the party. Mr. Villarreal said in a statement that the video was illegally recorded at a private party for which no public funds were spent. The episode was the latest example of electronic eavesdropping that often propels political scandals here.

headline: Public School’s Got a Brand-New Bag

lead_paragraph: Maxwell Osborne and Dao-Yi Chow of the CFDA-award-winning line Public School have been shaking up the men’s fashion scene with their streetwear-inspired styles since they launched in 2008. On the fall/winter 2014 runway, they debuted their first women’s collection; now they’ve added accessories. Tomorrow, the duo will launch two limited-edition unisex bags — a weekender ($850) and a backpack ($575) — in collaboration with Killspencer, the L.A. leather goods brand run by Spencer Nikosey, a former industrial designer. Both styles are made from the same pressed Italian matte leather that was used in Public School’s fall collection and feature waterproof interiors and quilted topstitching details. The bags are “intricate and functional,” says Osborne. “We wanted to make that type of bag for a guy — durable but still clean, sharp and exact.”

The lineup includes “A Dog’s Life” (1918), in which a mutt lifts the Tramp (Chaplin) and his girlfriend, a dance hall singer (Edna Purviance), out of destitution, at 9; “The Kid” (1921), in which the Tramp plots to get his adopted son (Jackie Coogan, above with Chaplin) back after the authorities return him to his biological parents, at 9:45; and “The Idle Class” (1921), in which the Tramp incites chaos at a golf resort when he steals the balls, at 10:45.

headline: Our Microbiome May Be Looking Out for Itself

headline: Should You Fear the Pizzly Bear?
abstract: As climate change alters habitats, once-disparate animals are shacking up, creating hybrids that challenge our notion of what it means to be a species.
lead_paragraph: In New England today, trees cover more land than they have at any time since the colonial era. Roughly 80 percent of the region is now forested, compared with just 30 percent in the late 19th century. Moose and turkey again roam the backwoods. Beavers, long ago driven from the area by trappers seeking pelts, once more dam streams. White-tailed deer are so numerous that they are often considered pests. And an unlikely predator has crept back into the woods, too: what some have called the coywolf. It is both old and new — roughly one-quarter wolf and two-thirds coyote, with the rest being dog.

headline: An Editor’s Photos of Wartime France

lead_paragraph: Closing in on 100, John G. Morris is perhaps the best-known living photo editor — partly because photographers usually become famous, not picture editors. He edited, and was close to, Robert Capa, Henri Cartier-Bresson, Alfred Eisenstaedt and W. Eugene Smith.

headline: Morning Views
abstract: Opinions on college sports, Ferguson, Ebola, plastic bags and more.
lead_paragraph: Claudia Wilken, a federal judge, handed down a decision meaning “college athletes will almost certainly be better off financially,” according to an editorial in The New York Times. “And the notion that these athletes are pure amateurs – ‘students first, athletes second’ – will be impossible to sustain.” Judge Wilken issued an injunction against a ban on payments to players for “the commercial use of their names, images and likenesses,” which she claims was in violation of antitrust law. “She also ruled that college sports’ governing body, the National Collegiate Athletic Association, may not prohibit universities from offering cost-of-living stipends in addition to scholarships.” The O’Bannon Ruling, as it’s known, is named for Ed O’Bannon, “a former basketball player for the University of California, Los Angeles,” and “other plays like him who until now have been unable to share in the considerable wealth generated by their skill and hard work.” The N.C.A.A. “built a lucrative commercial enterprise that depended in large part on unpaid labor.” Judge Wilken’s decision is a step toward righting those decades of exploitation.

headline: The Downside of Running With Others
abstract: I found fellow runners on Facebook and felt like I’d found a team. But running with others, I soon learned, can have its downsides.
lead_paragraph: My husband won’t talk to me when we run. Me, I need to carry on a conversation from the minute I start running to the minute I stop. The chitchat helps me forget the misery of the task at hand. But more than that, when I run alone, my mind will bully me into slowing down or stopping. When I run with other people, my mind won’t dare speak up – and I wind up running longer and faster than when I run alone.

headline: 1889: London’s Disgrace. Painful Experience of a Healthy Man on The Underground
abstract: A passenger on the London Underground in 1889 tells a story of a terrifying journey.
lead_paragraph: At half-past three o’clock yesterday a well-dressed man of thirty, with clean face, and a buoyant, healthy, contented expression entered the Charing Cross Station of the Underground Railway. At twenty minutes to five he came out again with a greasy, dirty face, with his eyes red, his ears full of cinders, his collar and cuffs soiled, his face pale, and his whole look weary, dejected, and limp. He scarcely seemed to be the same person as he sadly inquired the way to a bath. And he had simply taken a trip around the inner circle to personally undergo what millions of the traveling public have to suffer daily.

headline: 1939: Fascist Italy Issues Book Ban
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Italy bans books it deems unsuited for the fascist spirit in 1939.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The works of famous writers, including many Jews, and such books as the Nick Carter series of red-blooded adventures that thrilled American boys a generation or two ago, as well as Emil Ludwig’s biography of Lincoln, have been condemned officially as unsuited to the Fascist spirit. Booksellers and librarians received the list, which included books that have been seized and destroyed and others of which the sale has been forbidden. The condemned authors include Casanova, Balzac, Boccaccio, Machiavelli, Rabelais, Voltaire and Poe. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 15, 1939

headline: Morning Agenda: A Market for Delinquent Mortgages
abstract: The housing recovery is creating a market for delinquent-mortgage bonds. | A call for a more ambitious overhaul of the repo market. | William A. Ackman pitches for an I.P.O. of his Pershing Square Holdings fund. | A takeover battle for Chiquita Brands International may put inversions to the test.
lead_paragraph: The recovery in housing is creating a market for newly minted bonds that are backed by the mortgages on homes on the verge of foreclosure, DealBook’s Matthew Goldstein writes. “It is not just vulture hedge funds swooping in to try to profit from the last remnants of the housing crisis,” he adds. The investors making money off these obscure bonds, none of which are rated by a top credit rating agency, include United States mutual funds. One of the biggest sellers of severely delinquent mortgages to investors is a United States government housing agency.

headline: At Least 10 Injured After Police Fire on Tibetan Protesters
abstract: The shootings took place on Tuesday, after Tibetans had gathered to protest the detention the previous day of a respected village leader.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Chinese police officers opened fire on Tibetan protesters this week in a Tibetan area of southwest China, injuring at least 10 people, according to reports late Wednesday by the International Campaign for Tibet, an advocacy group, and Radio Free Asia, which is financed by the United States government.

headline: Imbibing a World of Delight and Degradation
abstract: “The Paris of Toulouse-Lautrec,” MoMA’s exhibition of 100 works by the artist, depicts the vibrant, louche and often sympathetic denizens of a late-19th-century demimonde.
lead_paragraph: Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec’s aristocratic parents were first cousins, and his numerous  genetic defects, including bone abnormalities, are attributed to a family history of inbreeding. At 13, he fell and broke a thigh bone, and at 14, the other. The breaks didn’t heal properly, and his legs stopped growing. As an adult he stood 4 feet 11 inches. He had the body of a grown man but walked on childlike legs with the help of a cane. His lips and nose outgrew the rest of his face, causing him to lisp and drool and suffer from chronic sinus problems.

headline: After Celebrity Drug Cases, Industry Signs Deal in Beijing
abstract: Forty-two artist management agencies in Beijing have signed an agreement with the police vowing to take action against illegal drug use within the industry, a newspaper has reported.
lead_paragraph: Forty-two artist management agencies in Beijing have signed an agreement with the police vowing to take action against illegal drug use within the industry, The Beijing News reported.

headline: More Churches Lose Their Crosses Despite Protests
abstract: The police have cut down the cross from atop Salvation Church in Wenzhou, witnesses say, ending a weekslong standoff with parishioners.
lead_paragraph: Crosses have been removed from two more Christian churches this week in the eastern Chinese province of Zhejiang, part of a continuing campaign by the local authorities to lower the profile of the country’s fastest-growing religion.

headline: Hong Kong Newspaper Prints Fake Obituary of Rival’s Owner
abstract: A full-page obituary in the Chinese-language Oriental Daily claimed that the owner of a rival newspaper, Apple Daily, had died.
lead_paragraph: It was the journalistic equivalent of putting a horse’s head in your rival’s bed. Lai Chee-ying, 65, also known as Fatty Lai and a native of Shunde in the southern Chinese province of Guangdong, had died of AIDS and cancer on Aug. 7. Since his family members were also sick, there would be no funeral.

headline: Arena Football Is Crossing Into New Territory: China
abstract: Owners of an American team have reached an agreement to launch the China American Football League, which is expected to begin in 2015.
lead_paragraph: Marty Judge is fully convinced that China wants football — not the type played by the N.F.L. but the indoor version found in the Arena Football League, where the field is 50 yards long, there are eight players a side, and the ball can be rebounded off nets above the end zone.

headline: Ask.com Buys Ask.fm, an Anonymous Q.&A. Start-Up
abstract: Ask.fm has 180 million regular monthly users and a particularly strong appeal to a highly desirable young age demographic. But the deal comes with some strings attached.
lead_paragraph: Updated | Ask, and ye shall receive.

lead_paragraph: Many consumers still appear reluctant to open their wallets, according to a mixed batch of retail earnings this week that shows little growth in spending at some of the nation’s biggest stores.

headline: Luis Suárez’s Ban for Bite Is Altered but Upheld
abstract: Suárez, a striker from Uruguay, must serve the rest of his four-month ban for biting an opponent at the World Cup, but he will be allowed to practice with his club team, Barcelona, and attend games.
lead_paragraph: The Court of Arbitration for Sport on Thursday upheld Luis Suárez’s four-month ban from soccer, ruling that he could not play in an official game for his club team, Barcelona, until the end of October.

headline: New Tack on Unrest Eases Tension in Missouri
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: As the local police prepared to release the name of the officer who fatally shot an unarmed teenager, the Missouri State Highway Patrol took over security in Ferguson.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — President Obama on Thursday called for an end to the violence here, denouncing actions both by the police and by protesters. Hours later, the Missouri governor, Jay Nixon, ordered the state highway patrol to take over security operations from local law enforcement.

headline: Music for Its Own Sake, Until a Dreamer Intrudes
abstract: “Frank” centers on a highly eccentric musical group whose equilibrium is disturbed when it is joined by an admiring outsider.
lead_paragraph: Popular music has always had a place for eccentrics and visionaries, artists whose inventions sometimes take them to the borderlands of madness. “Frank,” a captivatingly low-key new film directed by Lenny Abrahamson, was inspired by the life and work of one such musician, a singer known as Frank Sidebottom, who flourished in Britain in the 1990s. At one point, Mr. Sidebottom hired a keyboard player named Jon Ronson — though “hired” may suggest too conventional an arrangement — who later embellished, edited and updated his experience into the screenplay for this movie, which takes place in the present-day world of social media and South by Southwest.

headline: Changing South Is at Intersection of Demographics and Politics
abstract: Some Southern states are becoming more Democratic-leaning as new arrivals from the North move in. But this is not true in every state.
lead_paragraph: The South is the fastest-growing region of the country, and Democrats are hoping that a flood of Northern expats and demographic change will allow them to turn red states to blue at a fast enough pace to counter the region’s growing share of the Electoral College.

headline: In Ferguson, Focus on Police Action, Not Police Gear
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Armored vehicles aren’t themselves the problem.
lead_paragraph: The web is full of ridicule at the dark armor and military weaponry of the suburban St. Louis police officers, who have been confronting unarmed protesters over the last few days as if they were ISIS militants. The anger, however, is misplaced. The focus should not be on police gear, but on police conduct, which is increasingly appalling. The vast amount of tear gas fired just last night seemed wholly unjustified.

headline: Rent a Toy, Learn a Lesson
abstract: What would children learn if we made them give away some of their favorite toys after a month? Maybe that ownership and appreciation aren’t linked.
lead_paragraph: What would children learn if we made them give away some of their favorite toys after a month?

abstract: The Treasury had hoped to conduct a retail offering this fall but has delayed those plans because of concerns about how the sale would fare.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The British government has delayed plans to sell a portion of its remaining stake in the Lloyds Banking Group to retail investors until after next year’s general election, according to people briefed on the matter.

lead_paragraph: The Blackstone Group is going deeper into the natural gas business, with a $1.2 billion deal to buy into a Louisiana shale field.

headline: Aug. 14 Updates on Protests Over Police Shooting in Ferguson, Mo.
abstract: Live updates from Ferguson, Mo., where residents and the police have clashed since an unarmed young black man was shot and killed by a police officer on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of people gathered for peaceful vigils Thursday night in dozens of cities across the country from San Francisco to Boston to remember Michael Brown, the unarmed young black man shot and killed on Saturday by a police officer in Ferguson, Mo. In a move to restore calm, Gov. Jay Nixon of Missouri turned to a commander from the state’s highway patrol to oversee security efforts in Ferguson, where local and county police have clashed with protesters in recent days. The Times provided updates.

headline: Birkenstocks Are on the Move
abstract: Long beloved in the Bay Area, the sandal brand has surged in popularity on the Hudson ever since Céline showed a fur-lined version at its spring 2013 show.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers are sure putting the “stock” in Birkenstock.

lead_paragraph: When Katherine Nguyen and Vincent Todarello shared a 400-square-foot studio near Canal Street, they rented a storage unit for the overflow of their stuff. Five years ago, caught in the whirlwind of wedding planning, they decided to buy a suburban house.

headline: Checking In 20 Years After an Experiment With the American Dream
abstract: Twenty years ago, the Boston Globe journalist Farah Stockman worked at a camp for inner-city kids in Boston. Now she tracks some of her former campers down to see what their lives are like and what impact, if any, the camp made.
lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago, a group of classmates from Harvard started a summer camp for children from Mission Hill, Boston. Farah Stockman, now a writer at The Boston Globe, was one of the students. “We didn’t know it at the time, but we were watching an experiment that tested the validity of the American dream for Boston’s poorest children.” Now Ms. Stockman has written a series, with a video, exploring what happened to the kids who attended the camp:

headline: What Sells Better: Sexy or Empowered?
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Beauty (Concept)', 'Online Advertising', 'Social Media', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Two advertising campaigns use different marketing strategies. Is it better to make your audience feel empowered or inadequate?
lead_paragraph: Consider two advertising campaigns for women’s clothing: In one, a world-famous ballerina spins, jumps and stands tall on point, displaying her perfectly sculpted, athletic body; in the other, a faceless model — or rather, her derrière —  bends over a car door in a short, very revealing school-uniform-type skirt.

headline: Vitamin D Tied to Alzheimer’s Risk
abstract: Low vitamin D is associated with an increased risk for Alzheimer’s disease and other dementias, according to a new report.
lead_paragraph: Low vitamin D is associated with an increased risk for Alzheimer’s disease and other forms of dementia, according to a new report, though whether low vitamin D is a cause of the disorders remains unknown.

headline: Inside the Ballroom: Scenes From Baseball’s Election Battle
abstract: The three candidates seeking to succeed Bud Selig as commissioner stated their cases on Wednesday before the owners, and there were some contentious moments.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — The Hyatt Regency, a hulking hotel overlooking the harbor here, has a large ballroom on its second floor that, this week, has served as the epicenter for the 30 owners in Major League Baseball seeking to elect a new commissioner.

headline: 1964: U.N. Fails to Control Nicosia
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: The U.N. fails to control the crisis in Cyprus in 1964.
lead_paragraph: NICOSIA — United Nations Cyprus commander Gen. K.S. Thimayya today [Aug. 14] said the U.N. was unable to gain control of the situation in the tense capital city of Nicosia. Gen. Thimayya said he had received ‘‘assurances from both sides’’ that there would be no firing in the area of Kokkina, the only major port still dominated by the Turkish Cypriots. But, he said, he was ‘‘not happy about the situation in Nicosia, where I have been unable to get control of the situation despite all my efforts.’’ A U.N.- patrolled neutral zone (green line) through the city divides Greek and Turkish Cypriots. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 15, 1964

abstract: Starbucks announced the move to amend its scheduling practices after a New York Times article detailed the problems faced by an employee given erratic work schedules.
lead_paragraph: Starbucks announced revisions on Thursday to the way the company schedules its 130,000 baristas, saying it wanted to improve “stability and consistency” in work hours week to week.

headline: Gaza Conflict Is Just the Latest Round in a Long War
abstract: Israel’s real problem is the instability from the failure to negotiate a sovereign Palestinian state and finally fix its borders.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — As another round of warfare between Israel and Hamas may be ending, Israelis can feel as stuck, in different ways, as the Palestinians themselves. Because of course this is really just another round in the unresolved Arab-Israeli war of 1948-49.

headline: Engaging in Global Issues in the Classroom and Beyond
abstract: Thanks to the Internet, exposing students to global issues and to experts who work on them has never been easier, and it frequently leads to learning that extends far beyond the classroom.
lead_paragraph: Of the more than 8,000 class periods that I have taught, one stands out as my favorite — not only for what happened in the class but also for how it transformed my teaching. The class took place in the fall of 2004 and what strikes me about it now is how primitive it was by today’s technological standards. Indeed, the entire class consisted of the students sitting in a circle, staring at a speakerphone, and engaging in a dialogue about global health with a guest on the other end of the line. Fortunately for us, the guest was Dr. Paul Farmer, a path-breaking physician who co-founded the organization Partners in Health and who is the subject of a book the class had read, “Mountains Beyond Mountains.” For forty minutes, the students peppered Farmer with questions about Haiti, about how to best use one’s talents to address global health issues, and about how he had worked with Republicans and Democrats to ramp up global health funding.

headline: The California Exodus
abstract: A state that grew rapidly for much its history is now finding that many of its residents are picking up and moving on.
lead_paragraph: California has experienced rapid population growth for most of its history, but that trend has come to an end. California’s population grew by 2.9 percent over the last three years, only slightly above the nation’s 2.4 percent increase. Over the last few decades, millions of Californians have left the Golden State for opportunities elsewhere.

headline: Celebrating 30 Years of Def Jam
abstract: A box set of music and an anniversary concert in Brooklyn will mark the label’s 30th anniversary.
lead_paragraph: Lots of college-age music fans dream about starting their own record labels, and a few make a go of it. Rick Rubin was one: in 1984, he and Russell Simmons started Def Jam Recordings in Mr. Rubin’s dorm room at New York University, and it quickly became an influential hip-hop and urban music imprint. This fall, the label – now part of the sprawling Universal Music Group – is celebrating its three-decade run with a limited-edition retrospective box, “Def Jam 30,” to be released on LP and CD on Sept. 16, and a concert that will bring together some of the label’s stars, past and present, at the Barclays Center, in Brooklyn, on Oct. 16.

headline: A Chef in the Field | Okra
abstract: Paired with other seasonal ingredients — Jonah crabs and corn — okra makes for a delicious summery taco filling.
lead_paragraph: This series by the chef Jeff Schwarz and the photographer Greg Kessler traces the trajectory of seasonal food — from its original source to a place on your table.

The winners are nominated by schools and nonprofit performing companies, receive various amounts of money, depending on their needs, as well as a pin by the jewelry artist Alex Soldier. abstract: Deutsche Bank and Wells Fargo nixed a biotechnology I.P.O. six days after shares started trading. Their reasoning looks defensible but their due diligence beforehand less so, Robert Cyran writes for Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Exuberance over initial public offerings has ensnared Deutsche Bank and Wells Fargo. The two banks nixed a biotechnology I.P.O. last week — six days after the shares started trading. Their reasoning looks defensible but their due diligence beforehand less so.

headline: Paley Media Center to Offer Tributes to Williams and Bacall
abstract: The Paley Center for Media in Manhattan will recall Robin Williams and Lauren Bacall in programs this month.
lead_paragraph: The Paley Center for Media in Manhattan will pay tribute to Robin Williams and Lauren Bacall in programs this month. Mr. Williams, who died on Monday, will be commemorated in “Unruly Genius: Robin Williams on Television.” The overview will include his work on the sitcom “Mork & Mindy”; the 1978 HBO special “Robin Williams: Off the Wall”; and appearances on “The Larry Sanders Show,” “Homicide: Life on the Street” and “Louie.” The program, on Saturday and Sunday at 12 p.m., will also include a video of Mr. Williams’s appearance at the Paley Center last September.

lead_paragraph: In the United States, most of us fall for the movie version of Britain — horsy, obsessed with propriety and full of hard stares of unfulfilled longing between the genders. And then there is the Britain of Nick Davies’s “Hack Attack: The Inside Story of How the Truth Caught Up With Rupert Murdoch.”

headline: Despite Rescue, Iraq Airstrikes Will Continue, Obama Says

headline: Photographing on Ferguson’s Streets
abstract: Covering the unrest in Ferguson, Mo., has proved challenging as police restrict access and, in some cases, arrest journalists.

lead_paragraph: I moved to New York from the West Coast 20 years ago, but only this summer was I introduced to a little-known fact about the island of Manhattan: If you take the A train all the way to its northern terminus, you wind up in Seattle.

headline: Harry Potter Casts a Spell for Tolerance
abstract: Students who read and discussed a scene from Harry Potter in which the cruel Draco Malfoy calls Hermione a “filthy little Mudblood,” and her friends react with outrage reported more positive feelings about immigrants.
lead_paragraph: Parents often seek diversity in their children’s classmates and playmates, and with good reason: The most direct way to discover that members of other groups are people just like us is to spend time learning, playing and talking with them. But there’s an additional, more subtle way of getting the same message across, by cultivating what might be called a diversity of the imagination. We do it whenever we read the Harry Potter novels with our kids.

headline: Mini Golf as Career? She Gets Past the Obstacles
abstract: Olivia Prokopova, 19, took professional miniature golf by storm last year, making her a celebrity back home in the Czech Republic.
lead_paragraph: OCEANPORT, N.J. — She looked like nothing out of the ordinary, just another platinum blonde in baggy shorts hanging out at the miniature golf course. But in the rarefied, close-knit, hypercompetitive world of professional miniature golf, Olivia Prokopova is nothing short of legendary.

headline: Browsing for Beauty Services on the Road
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Mobile Applications', 'Spas', 'Beauty Salons', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: These sites and apps can help you find that spot for a facial or pedicure when you’re away from home.
lead_paragraph: It’s easy to book an appointment at your hotel spa. But what if you want something more casual (a blowout) or elaborate (shiatsu, Botox) than what your resort offers? Unlike flight and hotel booking, spa booking has not been aggregated by many companies. Happily, that’s changing.

headline: British Police Search Property of Cliff Richard Over Sex Abuse Claim

headline: Kinder Morgan Is Playing Tax Arbitrage With Itself

headline: Trusting the Police
abstract: How generational experience informs the reaction to the Ferguson fiasco.
lead_paragraph: A provisional thought on Ferguson, Missouri, the Saint Louis suburb where a black teenager was shot by a cop, which led to peaceful protests and then a burst of arson and looting, which in turn has led to the town spending the last few nights under what looks like a totally disastrous occupation by the county’s own heavily-armored, tank-driving, sniper-rifle-pointing, tear gas and rubber bullet firing, journalist-arresting, anti-American propaganda-creating police force.

headline: Obama, Pelosi and Rand Paul React to Ferguson
abstract: Barack Obama, Nancy Pelosi and Rand Paul all weighed in on the Michael Brown shooting.
lead_paragraph: National politicians have begun weighing in on the local disaster unfolding in Ferguson, Mo., where police shot to death an 18-year-old boy, touching off long, dark days of rioting, vandalism and what looks like the excessive application of police force.

headline: How Editing of Cuomo Article Resulted in a Kinder, Gentler Ending
abstract: A reader wonders why online editing took out a tougher anecdote about the governor’s trip to Israel.
lead_paragraph: I’m frequently asked about online editing changes that happen during the course of the publication cycle. I’ve written about it a few times, but in most instances I find them routine. Readers sometimes read deeper meaning into these changes than is warranted.

headline: Robin Williams Had Parkinson’s Disease, His Widow Says
abstract: Susan Schneider said that while he struggled with depression and anxiety, he was facing the early stages of Parkinson’s disease, “which he was not yet ready to share publicly.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Robin Williams was suffering from the early stages of Parkinson’s disease, his widow, Susan Schneider, said in a statement on Thursday. His suicide had provoked widespread speculation about his career, finances and mental condition.

headline: Hedge Funds Give Quarterly Snapshot of Their Portfolios
abstract: Four times a year, the secretive world of big hedge funds is briefly thrust into the spotlight when they are required to report changes to their stock holdings.

headline: How High-End Juices Extract Money From Consumers
abstract: Measured by the cost per calorie, it’s hard to find anything that is less of a bargain, but maybe that’s the idea.
lead_paragraph: I usually make my coffee at home. Otherwise, I resort to the machine in the nearest office kitchen that produces terrible espresso from those hermetically sealed ground-coffee pods. But every once in a while I yield to absurd Midtown Manhattan coffee prices and buy a delicious, extortionate latte.

headline: Cuomo Wraps Up Trip to Israel After Visiting Tunnel Near Gaza Border
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, on a tour to show support for Israel, visited a tunnel that was said to have been dug by the militant group Hamas.
lead_paragraph: KIBBUTZ EIN HASHLOSHA, Israel — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York was sweating, his shoes caked in dust. He had just climbed out of a tunnel near the Gaza border that Israel says was covertly built by Hamas, the militant group that dominates Gaza.

headline: All-Black Team Provides More Than a Little Hope
abstract: Players from Chicago-based Jackie Robinson West, who are competing in the Little League World Series, are bucking the trend of fewer black athletes playing baseball.
lead_paragraph: When Joseph Haley founded the Chicago-based Jackie Robinson West Little League in 1971, there were no grand plans of winning state championships or reaching the Little League World Series.

headline: New York State Students Post Slight Gains on Tests
abstract: Twenty-nine percent of students in New York City passed in reading, up from 27 percent; the passing rate for math rose by about four percentage points.
lead_paragraph: The percentage of New York State elementary- and middle-school students passing statewide math exams inched up in 2014 while reading scores remained flat, a mixed performance in the second year of a new, more difficult testing program, according to results released on Thursday.

abstract: Some of the best works in “Multiplicity,” a far-flung exhibition of art — from New York to Hong Kong — use video to highlight the idiosyncrasies of contemporary cities.

headline: Despite U.S. Claims, Yazidis Say Crisis Is Not Over
abstract: American assertions that the Islamist siege of Yazidis stranded on Mount Sinjar had been broken were disputed by a Yazidi leader and United Nations officials.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Yazidi leaders and emergency relief officials on Thursday strongly disputed American claims that the siege of Mount Sinjar in northern Iraq had been broken and that the crisis was effectively over, saying that tens of thousands of Yazidis remained on the mountain in desperate conditions.

lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission is examining whether Valeant Pharmaceuticals and Pershing Square Capital Management have broken any laws while pursuing a hostile takeover of Allergan, the maker of Botox.

headline: In Kenya, a Safari Program for Kids
abstract: The WildChild program at &Beyond’s Kichwa Tembo Tented Camp in Kenya has a range of activities for children between the ages of 5 and 12.
lead_paragraph: Most safari camps don’t allow children, but at &Beyond’s new Kichwa Tembo Tented Camp in Kenya’s Masai Mara National Reserve, kids between the ages of 5 and 12 are welcome with the WildChild program.

headline: Venezuela as a Distressed Seller
abstract: A drop in the value of heavy-oil assets makes it a bad time to sell Citgo, a refinery and pipelines operator in the United States. But Venezuela needs the $15 billion that a sale could raise, notes Christopher Swann of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Venezuela is digging its way to distressed seller status.

headline: Lisa Cooley Displays ‘Itself Not So’
abstract: A clever group show “Itself Not So” locates works that can be tied to the cognitive disorder aphasia, as an unlikely source of inspiration for its text-based conceptual art.
