abstract: Spring has more than 100 major retailer partners participating, including brands like Nicole Miller, Michael Kors and Levi’s.
lead_paragraph: Impulse buying just got a whole lot easier.

headline: The Signals From the High-Yield Bond Market
abstract: Stocks continued to set all-time highs through most of July, but high-yield bond prices were eroding. In 2007, the paths of stocks and high-yield bonds diverged, too. Are the current moves worrisome?
lead_paragraph: There’s a saying on Wall Street that the bond market is smarter than the stock market.

headline: In Slender Filaments, a Cosmos Distilled
abstract: “Planetarium,” a component of Sarah Sze’s “Triple Point” installation at the 2013 Venice Biennale, has been installed at the Bronx Museum of the Arts.
lead_paragraph: As the United States representative to last summer’s Venice Biennale, Sarah Sze orchestrated a masterly series of installations in the American pavilion. Insidiously undermining the pavilion’s grand Palladian architecture and its intimations of empire, her sprawling project “Triple Point” confused indoors with out: It opened up side entrances and hidden spaces, spread like kudzu along the building’s roof and crept into a storage closet in the rotunda. And like her previous works, it distorted the visitor’s sense of scale with dizzying agglomerations of tiny objects.

headline: Maliki Agrees to Relinquish Power in Iraq
abstract: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki said Thursday he had agreed to step down, conceding to pressure from within Iraq and the United States and Iran.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki said Thursday night that he had agreed to relinquish power, a move that came after days of crisis in which his deployment of extra security forces around the capital had raised worries of a military coup.

headline: Jerry Kearns: ‘Rrrgghh!!!’
abstract: In a style that he refers to as “psychological pop,” Mr. Kearns’s latest work is subtler and more unanswering, and, at the same time, it has gained in finish-fetish finesse.
lead_paragraph: JERRY KEARNS

headline: Love and Unhappiness, in Soft Shades of Gray
abstract: In Philippe Garrel’s “Jealousy,” emotional ambivalence and wayward passion span years among a group of struggling artists.
lead_paragraph: “Jealousy,” Philippe Garrel’s new film, begins in tears and proceeds through seasons of romantic melancholy, unfolding on Paris streets and in Bohemian apartments filmed in lovely shades of gray. The black-and-white images (captured by the great Belgian cinematographer Willy Kurant) seem to float free of time, accompanied by the disarmingly sweet tones of Jean-Louis Aubert’s music. The main character, a young actor named Louis, is based on Mr. Garrel’s father and played by his son (also named Louis). This tale of emotional ambivalence and wayward passion seems to be happening equally in the present, in the Nouvelle Vague era of the director’s young manhood, and at any other point in the long history of Gallic love trouble.

headline: Vigils Planned Nationwide Over Ferguson Shooting
abstract: As the unrest festers in Ferguson, Mo., various groups are planning vigils in 90 cities across the United States to honor victims of alleged police brutality.
lead_paragraph: After days of unrest in Ferguson, Mo. after the fatal shooting of an 18-year-old unarmed man, Michael Brown, organizers are planning vigils in more than 90 cities around the country to commemorate victims of police brutality.

headline: A Broadway Show Pitches to Investors Online
abstract: The lead producers of a revival of “On the Town” are soliciting equity investors online, the first time a Broadway production has done so.
lead_paragraph: The lead producers of this fall’s Broadway revival of “On the Town” are taking the unusual step of turning to the Internet to find investors for their $8.5 million musical. The producers, Howard and Janet Kagan, said on Thursday that they have created a website where any reader can learn about the show and, if they meet certain financial standards, can make an online investment for as little as $10,000 in return for an equity stake in it. To qualify, potential investors must have annual incomes exceeding $200,000 individually or $300,000 jointly, for instance, or have a net worth that exceeds $1 million.

headline: Health Officials Try to Quell Fear of Ebola Spreading by Air Travel
abstract: The organization reacted after Korean Airlines suspended flights to Kenya, which is not among the countries afflicted by the Ebola outbreak.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The World Health Organization on Thursday swiftly sought to quell fears that international air travel could become a conduit for spreading the deadly Ebola virus from Africa around the globe, emphasizing that such a risk was low.

headline: Leon Black’s Phaidon Buys Artspace, an Online Art Market
abstract: The acquisition will allow Phaidon, which already offers a collection of digital books and travel guide apps, to increase its online presence and give it more direct access to art collectors.
lead_paragraph: Leon D. Black is known for striking bold acquisitions through the private equity firm he runs, Apollo Global Management.

headline: No, Celebrity Deaths Do Not Come in Threes
abstract: Robin Williams and Lauren Bacall died this week, but despite the all-too-human desire to find patterns in life, the odds of another celebrity death haven’t changed.
lead_paragraph: It happens time and time again. Two celebrities — like Robin Williams and Lauren Bacall — die within a couple days of each other, and people start holding their breath. “Celebrities always die in threes,” they say, post and tweet. “Who’s next?”

headline: R. M. Fischer: ‘Life Force’
abstract: In his latest show, the sculptor borrows from folk and outsider art with the same slyness that he previously used with futurism.
lead_paragraph: R. M. Fischer is well into the second phase of his artistic career. The first occurred when he was a young, emerging artist affiliated with the Neo-Geo tendency of the 1980s, becoming known for jokey futuristic lamps and fountains made from metal rods, brass knobs and everyday objects like colanders and cooking pots. They reflected an inveterate tinkerer and bricolagist who re-emerged, softened, in the early 2000s with crudely stitched stuffed sculptures. Involving brightly colored vinyl and cannibalized parts of Mr. Fischer’s earlier work, these efforts were fierce and endearing, with a cartoonish, even monsterish mien.

headline: Matthew Ronay: ‘Wavelength’
abstract: The 30 gouaches in Mr. Ronay’s latest show compress the tableaus, natural forms and saturated colors of his sculptures and installations into buzzy, phosphorescent underworlds.
lead_paragraph: MATTHEW RONAY

headline: It’s All Just a Game, Now Take It Seriously
abstract: “Level Five” is a cerebral science-fiction adventure made in 1997 by the unconventional filmmaker Chris Marker.
lead_paragraph: Chris Marker, who died on his 91st birthday in 2012, was a filmmaker beyond category. It is often said that he transcended or defied the conventions of genre, but it might be more accurate to say that he operated in serene indifference to what other, less liberated souls took to be the rules. Most famous for “La Jetée,” his 1962 time-travel tour de force, 28 minutes long and composed almost entirely of still images, Marker also seemed to have freed himself from the strictures of time.

headline: When Your Longest Call Is the One to Correct the Bill
abstract: A doctor tells the Haggler that he spent 3 hours, 17 minutes trying to have AT&T adjust one month’s charges to his practice.
lead_paragraph: “Sorry,” Elton John sang years ago, “seems to be the hardest word.” The Haggler has always found this sentiment mystifying. “Sherbet.” Now there is a hard word. Everyone pronounces it “sherbert.” “Dilate” is a toughie. We all prefer “dialate” for some reason.

headline: Fantasy Football: Tight End Primer
abstract: While the Big 3 — Rob Gronkowski, Julius Thomas and Jimmy Graham — get most of the attention, the position has gotten much deeper.
lead_paragraph: The return of the New England Patriots’ Rob Gronkowski and the emergence of the Denver Broncos’ Julius Thomas have given fantasy owners three difference-making options (along with existing stud Jimmy Graham of the New Orleans Saints) to choose from at the tight end position. While the Big 3 get most of the attention, the position, in fantasy terms, has gotten much deeper, thanks to the same N.F.L. passing trends that have expanded the field of quality quarterbacks and wide receivers.

headline: Hybrids From a Fervid Iconoclast
abstract: A Lucas Samaras show at the Metropolitan Museum emphasizes the diversity of his artistic output, from Happenings to works in which he tinkered with his own image.
lead_paragraph: Despite its grand, somewhat romantic title, “Lucas Samaras: Offerings From a Restless Soul” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art demonstrates quite clearly that Mr. Samaras is at his best as an artist when he settles down — particularly with photography, the medium he’s most associated with. Unfortunately this show, drawn from the museum’s collection — particularly a cache of works bequeathed to the Met by Mr. Samaras’s art dealer, Arnold Glimcher, and Mr. Glimcher’s wife, Milly — is rather slim on photography. Instead, it tries to bolster Mr. Samaras’s status as a versatile artist, with negligible results.

headline: Cathedral of St. John the Divine Is a Gallery, Too
abstract: The Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, doubling as an arts space, is home to exhibitions like “Phoenix,” winged beasts from the artist Xu Bing.
lead_paragraph: The Miser still remembers turning the corner at Broadway and 112th Street, near Columbia, years ago and being stunned by his first glimpse of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine. In a city full of massive and historic structures, the building’s sheer scale and neo-medieval aura manage to stand out.

headline: Have I Told You Lately That You’re Crazy?
abstract: Who said friends have to be supportive of each other? The truth can have a bracing clarity.
lead_paragraph: Some years ago a woman I knew told me she could levitate. She had been doing a good deal of meditation, and this was something you could supposedly work up to if you were really good, like throwing someone over your shoulder in the Lindy Hop.

headline: Un-American, Some Said. But Not Unworthy.
abstract: Thom Andersen and Noël Burch’s film “Red Hollywood” makes a case for the quality of work by blacklisted filmmakers.
lead_paragraph: “Red Hollywood” may suggest the rivers of blood that flood our screens. But the red in the title of this fascinating essaylike movie refers to the home-front Communists and other American radicals — actual and accused — who once upon a Hollywood time made socially conscious movies that took on the world and its woes. These were true believers, like the fiery Abraham Polonsky who, with films like “Force of Evil” (1948), challenged reigning ideologies and at times cast pitch-black shadows over the scene to make class, race and sexual inequality all part of the big picture.

headline: Butler Greenwood’s Plantation Parlor Goes to New Orleans
abstract: The New Orleans Museum of Art has bought parlor furniture from the Butler Greenwood Plantation.
lead_paragraph: A PLANTATION’S PARLOR

headline: NBC Chooses Chuck Todd to Replace David Gregory on ‘Meet the Press’
abstract: Mr. Gregory will leave the network after a two-decade career. Ratings for “Meet the Press” have declined steadily during his tenure.
lead_paragraph: Confirming one of the longest-running and most tortuous rumors in the television business, NBC News announced on Thursday that David Gregory was being removed from his post as anchor of the network’s Sunday morning discussion program “Meet the Press” and would be replaced by Chuck Todd, NBC’s White House correspondent.

headline: Sins of a Father Visited Upon a Son
abstract: In “Moebius,” the South Korean director Kim Ki-duk tells a silent tale of a maddened mother who slices off her son’s penis in revenge for her husband’s infidelity.
lead_paragraph: Part grotesque comedy, part soft-core fetish curiosity, “Moebius” is, you hope, not seriously intended as much else. The South Korean director Kim Ki-duk throws down the gauntlet (and something else) with his opening setup, in which a maddened mother slices off her son’s penis in revenge for her husband’s infidelity. (That’s after trying her spouse first.) Love does not quite conquer all afterward, though it does eventually lead to an especially altruistic father-son transplant.

headline: We Were a Party of Two, but Never Quite Alone
abstract: He told me I was the one. What was it in me that couldn’t fully accept that?
lead_paragraph: During our four months of dating, he had asked me repeatedly to move in with him. Now, with a smile, he was asking again.

headline: Muscles and Testosterone Are Ready for Action
abstract: Sylvester Stallone heads a celebrity cast — Mel Gibson, Antonio Banderas, Wesley Snipes and more — in the explosion-packed film “The Expendables 3.”
lead_paragraph: Walking past Madame Tussauds after a preview screening of “The Expendables 3” on 42nd Street in Manhattan brought on a mysterious feeling of déjà vu, until I realized that both franchises share an operating principle: Cram a bunch of famous faces together and bank on the immediate joys of recognition.

headline: Grieving, With a Score to Settle
abstract: “The Word” centers on a businessman’s reaction to a cult’s ritual killing of his son.
lead_paragraph: Cloaking a routine vengeance scenario in a veneer of religious introspection, the low-budget drama “The Word” is a sort of faith-based “Death Wish”: a movie that questions the blood lust it’s selling just enough to avoid appearing intensely hypocritical. It centers on Tom Hawkins (Kevin O’Donnell), a Connecticut businessman grieving for his murdered child, who was kidnapped from a mall.

lead_paragraph: Updated, 6:27 p.m. |

headline: Them Dames
abstract: Jules Feiffer’s graphic novel is a tribute to film noir and detective fiction.
lead_paragraph: Oedipus gets all the buzz, but surely a daughter’s desire to vanquish her mother is even more elemental. Not because daughters want to sleep with their daddies (although they sometimes do, as long as they’re de facto daddies; see “Mildred Pierce”), but because it’s so darn hard to become yourself with Mother hovering. You want — no, need — to dance in the Trevi Fountain and there’s Mommy, holding your galoshes. Veda Pierce, come to think of it, had a similar complaint about Mildred: “I literally can’t open my mouth in a theater, or a radio studio, or anywhere, that she isn’t there, bustling down the aisle, embarrassing me before people.” Mother is omnipresent until she’s not, and then you hate her even more for daring to leave you.

headline: Abandon Ship!
abstract: In 1879, backed by a wealthy American newspaper magnate, 33 men embarked on an ill-fated expedition to the North Pole.
lead_paragraph: Ice. You remember ice. The stuff that forestalled so many polar explorers back before global warming and dreams of beachfront homes along the shores of Baffin Bay. But, as Hampton Sides reminds us in this first-rate polar history and adventure narrative, the notion of mildish weather in the Arctic did not begin with climate change. Just 150 years ago many believed that the Gulf Stream and its counterpart in the Pacific, the Kuroshio, reached all the way to the North Pole. Once a ship broke through a rim of ice circling the top of the globe, the thinking went, it would encounter an open polar sea and easy sailing to the pole.

headline: May Loves December
abstract: Lucinda Franks’s memoir of her marriage is a tribute to her husband.
lead_paragraph: The secret to a long and passionate union is to marry someone almost 30 years your senior. That seems to be the message of Lucinda Franks’s engaging memoir, “Timeless: Love, Morgenthau, and Me.” Of course it helps if that someone is Robert M. Morgenthau, scion of a historic family, on the cusp of an extraordinarily long-running career as Manhattan’s district attorney. But the real subject of this brave, highly personal account of the Morgenthaus’ shared life is the mysterious alchemy that forges an unlikely couple out of two dissimilar souls. This is also a love story in a political context: the great events in New York’s life in the last 40 years, observed by a sharp reporter from a privileged perch.

headline: Coke to Buy Stake in Monster Beverage for $2.15 Billion
abstract: A major rationale for the deal was Coca-Cola’s desire to find a replacement for carbonated soft drink sales.
lead_paragraph: For years now, analysts have suggested that the Coca-Cola Company acquire Monster Beverage, the energy drink company.

headline: On the Road Again, Riffing Over Pasta
abstract: A freewheeling jaunt along the Amalfi Coast, with literary touchstones, starring Rob Brydon and Steve Coogan in a sequel to their 2010 movie, “The Trip.”
lead_paragraph: Ah, to be famous or just funny enough for someone to pay for your freewheeling jaunt along the Amalfi Coast! You wouldn’t always know it from his compendium of lip twitches and often comic and sour asides, but Steve Coogan is one lucky man, as is Rob Brydon, his returning partner in clowning and mileage. As in “The Trip,” their 2010 excursion into British cuisine, the two have teamed up for a journey, ostensibly so that now they can review six Italian restaurants for The Observer of London. In other words, this is “The Trip” with pasta.

headline: Taking Wing in a Time of Extremis
abstract: The artist Jim Hodges is the subject of a career retrospective, “Give More Than You Take,” at the Institute of Contemporary Art in Boston.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — In the 21st century, we tend to talk about new art in terms of medium and style: Performance is back, painting is back, Pop is back, and so on. But for roughly a decade, from the late 1980s to the late 1990s, the emphasis was on ideas and emotions. As racial and gender politics navigated the culture wars, and the toll taken by AIDS grew overwhelming, content often trumped form. In a lesson learned from feminism, personal history and feeling were O.K. Even spirituality, which the New York art world handles with tongs, became an admissible subject.

headline: A Fib Will Do
abstract: Answers to those pesky questions about social manners.
lead_paragraph: My wife and I retired to a beautiful town on the coast of Maine. Many friends ask to visit, and most of their visits have been great. But one couple who came began negotiating with us as soon as they walked in the door: over dinner menus, the days’ activities, even our music selection. When they left, I told my wife: “Never again!” Now they’ve started asking for a return visit. I think we should tell them the truth: They were terrible guests. She disagrees. Any advice?

headline: How to Organize Thousands of Vinyl Records Using Seemingly Random Knick-Knacks
abstract: Zero Freitas, a Brazilian bus magnate and record collector, uses a quirky indexing system for his private collection of about 100,000 albums.
lead_paragraph: If you read Monte Reel’s article in the Aug. 10 magazine, you know that Zero Freitas, a Brazilian bus magnate and record collector, has a pretty big organizational problem on his hands. In Freitas’s warehouse in São Paulo are several million records that need to be indexed and stored in some way. It’s a project that will take decades, and that’s only if Freitas stops buying records, which seems unlikely.

headline: Behind the Enigma of a Cult-Favorite Film Auteur
abstract: In “Mr. X: A Vision of Leos Carax,” Tessa Louise-Salomé turns a documentary eye on a French filmmaker.
lead_paragraph: The mock-cliché title of “Boy Meets Girl,” Leos Carax’s debut feature, which he made in the 1980s when he was in his early 20s, belies its fresh, shooting-star romanticism and visual originality. These qualities streak throughout the work of Mr. Carax, who, as amply illustrated by “Mr. X: A Vision of Leos Carax,” gives the sense of discovering the art and romance of cinema anew with each film.

headline: Fantasies Taxiing for Takeoff
abstract: The musical “Finding Neverland,” about the creator of Peter Pan, is making test flights at the American Repertory Theater.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — As long-suffering authorities like the Wright Brothers and Icarus could have told you, becoming airborne is never easy. That’s the lesson being contemplated, on several levels, by “Finding Neverland,” the ever-evolving, highly determined Broadway-bound children’s musical that opened on Wednesday night at the American Repertory Theater here.

headline: They Want to Rock, but There’s More to Life
abstract: “We Are Mari Pepa” follows the summer of four Mexican teenagers with a rock band, especially the group’s leader, Alex.
lead_paragraph: For all its enthusiastic vulgarity and truly terrible punk rock, “We Are Mari Pepa” is a gently endearing portrait of four amiable Mexican teenagers feeling their way toward adulthood.

headline: Donations From the Family
abstract: An Institute for Justice lawyer says parents are entitled to spend what they wish on their child’s campaign.

headline: An Aging Beauty With Good Bones
abstract: “Dinosaur 13” looks at the famous find of a T. rex skeleton in South Dakota and the legal case that followed.
lead_paragraph: Life sure wasn’t easy for a dinosaur named Sue. As revealed by the skeleton, excavated in 1990 by the paleontologist Peter Larson and his team from the Black Hills Institute for Geological Research in South Dakota, Sue’s journey through the late Cretaceous period had been fraught by an unusual number of broken bones and other injuries. Almost 70 million years later, these magnificent remains — constituting the most complete Tyrannosaurus rex ever found — would embark on another journey, this time through a labyrinthine legal battle that would leave their caretakers equally scarred.

headline: A Recipe for Happiness
abstract: Can a meal be more than just a delicious coming together of fine ingredients? Can it alter your feelings in predictive ways? The Michelin-starred chef Joël Robuchon and his neuropharmacologist have created dishes to cure what ails you. Plus: A trout recipe that will make you happier.
lead_paragraph: Can a meal be more than just a delicious coming together of fine ingredients? Can it alter your feelings in predictive ways? The Michelin-starred chef Joël Robuchon and his neuropharmacologist have created dishes to cure what ails you.

headline: Go West, Democrats
keywords: ['Democratic National Convention', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Senator Sherrod Brown of Ohio makes the case for a 2016 Democratic convention in Columbus, Ohio.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Beauty of the Everyday
abstract: The subject of an exhibition at the Parrish Art Museum, William Glackens spent much of his time drawing and painting what was almost always immediately in front of him.
lead_paragraph: WATERMILL, N.Y. — Once derided as a slavish admirer of Renoir, the painter and illustrator William Glackens is among the most intriguing and underestimated participants in the first wave of 20th-century American modernism. That perception is confirmed by the enlightening and overdue, if still deficient, survey of his dappled canvases and dazzling drawings at the Parrish Art Museum here. It should be required viewing for anyone interested in the period.

headline: Inside a 16th-Century Naval Battle
abstract: “The Admiral,” starring Choi Min-sik, depicts a 1597 naval battle in which a Korean David fought a Goliath Japan.
lead_paragraph: A turgid, foursquare naval epic, the South Korean drama “The Admiral: Roaring Currents” memorializes the 1597 Battle of Myeongnyang, in which the military leader of the title, Yi Sun-shin (Choi Min-sik, from “Oldboy”), with a dozen ships, held off an encroaching Japanese army. The movie, directed by Kim Han-min, stages this David-and-Goliath pairing with a nationalistic fervor.

headline: As I.P.O. Nears, GoDaddy Tries to Show It’s More Than Just Domain Names
abstract: GoDaddy’s I.P.O. offering document shows that newer offerings grew more quickly than its domain registrar business.
lead_paragraph: As GoDaddy moves toward an initial public offering, the company faces a vexing problem: So many potential investors still think of it only as that place with the notoriously risqué ads where they can buy domain names.

headline: Protest March Bears Down on the Leader of Pakistan
abstract: The opposition leader Imran Khan and a cleric, Muhammad Tahir-ul Qadri, rallied their supporters to demand that Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif resign.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Thousands of Pakistanis rallied behind the former cricketer Imran Khan on Thursday as he led a motor cavalcade toward the capital, Islamabad, for a protest to demand the resignation of Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif and fresh elections.

headline: Why a Rule on Loan Losses Could Squeeze Credit
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: A requirement that banks report potential loan losses immediately after making the loan could lead banks to suspend lending to improve earnings.
lead_paragraph: No bank loses money on every loan, at least not if it is going to stay in business.

headline: Death Calls, but So Does the Environment
abstract: “A Will for the Woods” is a documentary about natural burial that focuses on a psychiatrist as he prepares for his death.
lead_paragraph: The advocacy documentary “A Will for the Woods” ostensibly focuses on natural burial, a way to minimize a burial’s impact on the environment. The closing credits even invite viewers to go online for further information. But the movie’s real subject may be facing death with equanimity.

headline: If You Want to Remember, You Have to Ask the Old Guy
abstract: Lois Lowry’s novel “The Giver” is adapted for film by the director Phillip Noyce.
lead_paragraph: By the time the sounds of the Von Trapp children warbling “Silent Night” drift through “The Giver,” you may find yourself wondering what fresh movie hell this is. In truth, the enervating hash of dystopian dread, vague religiosity and commercial advertising-style uplift is nothing if not stale. Adapted from Lois Lowry’s book for young readers, the story involves an isolated society that, with its cubistic dwellings, mindless smiles, monochromatic environs and nebulous communitarianism, seem modeled on a Scandinavian country or an old Mentos commercial.

headline: A Badge, a Car, a Vest and Most of the Rest
abstract: “Let’s Be Cops” brings together Damon Wayans Jr. and Jake Johnson as two characters who need a boost, and get one.
lead_paragraph: LET’S BE COPS

headline: Worldly Music Branching Out From a Single Root
abstract: The pianist Fabian Almazan took his “Rhizome” project to the Village Vanguard, explaining how all music, like people, has commonalities under the surface.
lead_paragraph: Around the midpoint of his first set at the Village Vanguard on Wednesday night, the pianist Fabian Almazan paused to explain the title of his most recent album, “Rhizome.” He touched on the botanical definition of the word, a rootstock from which multiple shoots typically emerge. Then he drew a parallel to humankind, saying that for all our differences, and “the violence in the world,” a core commonality lurks under the surface.

headline: Helping Prevent Foreclosures
abstract: Data shows that extensions of unemployment benefits helped prevent mortgage defaults more than government programs focused on reducing monthly payments.
lead_paragraph: A new study finds that the emergency extensions of unemployment benefits during the recession went a long way toward preventing mortgage defaults, even more than government programs meant to prevent foreclosures by focusing only on reducing monthly payments. Researchers from the Federal Reserve Board of Governors, in Washington, and the Kellogg School of Management, at Northwestern University, estimate that between July 2008 and December 2012, the $250 billion paid out in federally funded unemployment benefits helped prevent an estimated 1.4 million foreclosures.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Ukraine, Liberia, Gaza City and Spain.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Ukraine, Liberia, Gaza City and Spain.

abstract: In the news: Tinnitus, yoga and cordone sanitaire. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: In the news: Tinnitus, yoga and cordone sanitaire. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Carl Ostendarp: ‘Blanks’
abstract: The painter Carl Ostendarp is a master of comic minimalism and, in his new show, each of his paintings is a sofa-size canvas painted a single bright color.
lead_paragraph: The painter Carl Ostendarp is a master of comic minimalism, an oxymoronic genre. Minimalism is usually immune to humor, which is just what makes it worth teasing.

headline: Cutting Very Close to the Truth
abstract: “Abuse of Weakness,” based on the director Catherine Breillat’s own book, focuses on a woman entranced by a swindler.
lead_paragraph: It is hard to imagine that any other actress could muster the stubborn ferocity that Isabelle Huppert brings to the role of Maud, a successful French filmmaker recovering from a stroke in Catherine Breillat’s “Abuse of Weakness.” Like many of Ms. Huppert’s screen characters, Maud is an imperious, willful woman with a perverse drive to play with fire. She refuses to be stopped, even after her left side is paralyzed, and she is barely able to walk.

headline: Why SketchFactor Feels, Well…
keywords: ['Accidents and Safety', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Police', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Racial Profiling', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: When do safety apps work, and when do they lend themselves to becoming tools for racial profiling?
lead_paragraph: On Aug. 5, Mayor Bill de Blasio and NYC’s Economic Development Corporation President Kyle Kimball announced twenty finalists for the city’s annual Big Apps competition. Among them was SketchFactor, an app that offers users a map of their surroundings pinned with googly-eyed faces to indicate where a “sketchy” incident has been reported. A user can report an unpleasant occurrence or use the app’s directions feature to chart a non-“sketchy” route through a city.

headline: After Tigers and Flies, Now a Spider: Jiang Zemin
abstract: Images purporting to show the name of the former leader Jiang Zemin being taken down from public buildings have caused a stir, reflecting expectations that his influence must go to pave the way for President Xi Jinping’s program of change for China.
lead_paragraph: For months, the political conversation among China’s chattering classes has been of “tigers” and “flies,” the big and small officials who are victims of President Xi Jinping’s anticorruption-campaign-cum-political-purge that is taking down hundreds, possibly thousands of people, as he consolidates power.

headline: To Become Another Being
abstract: The Drive East festival of Indian dance and music at La MaMa takes audiences deep into the mystery of acting and identity.
lead_paragraph: At the current one-week Drive East festival of Indian dance and music at La MaMa, each artist or group has just one performance. Several of the performers are little known. You just have to go along, take a risk and learn from them all. The quality is high; the styles are varied. Some of the music has been even better than the dance — perhaps because almost all of the dance has been to taped music, whereas the recitals by instrumentalists, bands and singers have filled the act of music-making with delight and immediacy.

headline: His Girlfriend Is Dead (Shh, Don’t Tell Her)
abstract: Jeff Baena’s feature debut, “Life After Beth,” stars Aubrey Plaza as a lusty, undead girlfriend blissfully unaware that she’s past her expiration date.
lead_paragraph: Aubrey Plaza has large, intelligent eyes and a startlingly gorgeous smile — one that’s unleashed all too rarely in her role as a lovable misanthrope on “Parks and Recreation.” Sadly, playing a lusty, undead girlfriend in “Life After Beth” gives her even fewer opportunities to beam, but when she does, the whole film seems to slow down and soften.

headline: ‘37: A Final Promise’ Revolves Around Suicide
abstract: This film, directed by Randall Batinkoff, stars Mr. Batinkoff as a rock star with an approaching deadline.
lead_paragraph: This isn’t the best week to be promoting a film that revolves around suicide, but “37: A Final Promise” has other problems besides its accidental collision with real-life headlines. It’s an awkward mix of sentiment, underdeveloped relationships and rock ’n’ roll pretensions, and it never quite gels into the “Love Story” for the 21st century that it wants to be.

lead_paragraph: Proceeding in a tone of unrelieved misery, “Coldwater” is a punishing, predictable drama that’s almost rescued by strong acting and good intentions.

headline: Sexual Encounters and Meta Moments
abstract: Misdirections abound in Julián Hernández’s “I Am Happiness on Earth,” a film of dour, sexually explicit couplings and triplings.
lead_paragraph: It’s such a poetic title, “I Am Happiness on Earth,” but it’s also a purposeful con. On earth, in the Mexican director Julián Hernández’s artful vision, there’s not much happiness, at least not in the dour, sexually explicit couplings and triplings among the men and women in this film.

headline: Hailing the New York Cabdriver
abstract: More than 50,000 people drive yellow cabs in New York City. Samyukta Lakshmi’s photos offer a window into their lives on and off duty.
lead_paragraph: More than 50,000 people drive yellow cabs in New York City. Samyukta Lakshmi’s photos offer a window into their lives on and off duty.

headline: Robin Williams, the Vulnerable Showman
abstract: In the digital age, when trolls can make a piñata of even the most gifted performers, the pressure has never been greater.
lead_paragraph: Every writer fears the blank page. Every comedian dreads silence at the end of a punch line. Every creative soul quivers at the prospect of brush touching canvas or fingers reaching for keyboards and finding — nothing.

headline: The Power, and Process, of a Simple Solution
abstract: Mix salt, sugar and water. Add a decades long, strategic health crusade. Yield: about 50 million saved lives.
lead_paragraph: Khulna, Bangladesh — On a hot morning in southern Bangladesh, an hour from the port city of Khulna, parents with small children waited at a three-room clinic set amid bamboo groves and jackfruit trees. The children’s ailments ranged from coughs to eye infections, but none were there for diarrhea, even though it is the world’s second-largest killer of children under age five, after pneumonia.

headline: Chicago Fire Festival Theme: Renewal
abstract: The Great Chicago Fire Festival in October–with “fire sculptures” on the Chicago River–has the city’s historic renewal as its focus.
lead_paragraph: In conjunction with the city, Chicago-based Redmoon Theater, known for site-specific spectacles as well as interactive shows, will stage the first Great Chicago Fire Festival on Oct. 4, with the fire of 1871 as its subject and renewal as its theme.

headline: A Psychological Speed Limit
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Speed Limits and Speeding', 'Cameras', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Drunken and Reckless Driving', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: Cameras and social pressure slow drivers better than tickets.
lead_paragraph: ON average, vehicles seriously injure or kill someone in New York every two hours; last year, 173 pedestrians were killed. Last week Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo signed a bill allowing New York City to enact a citywide default speed limit of 25 miles per hour as part of its “Vision Zero” campaign to reduce traffic deaths to nil.

headline: For Merchants, Bitcoin Shows More Pop Than Potential
abstract: Merchants that accept Bitcoin are trying to attract virtual currency enthusiasts. And the number of merchants has been growing.
lead_paragraph: Jason Hand had more money in his Bitcoin wallet than in his savings account.

headline: Israel Braces for War Crimes Inquiries on Gaza
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'International Relations', 'Palestinians']
abstract: The broader struggle will be over what some experts describe as Israel’s “creative” interpretation of international law for dealing with asymmetric warfare in an urban environment.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The fighting is barely over in the latest Gaza war, with a five-day cease-fire taking hold on Thursday, but attention has already shifted to the legal battlefield as Israel gears up to defend itself against international allegations of possible war crimes in the monthlong conflict.

headline: The Mini Golf Master
abstract: Brad Lebo, a dentist from Pennsylvania, participates in 45 to 50 miniature golf tournaments a year. He has won 105 career events on the various putting tours.
lead_paragraph: Brad Lebo, a dentist from Pennsylvania, participates in 45 to 50 miniature golf tournaments a year. He has won 105 career events on the various putting tours.

headline: Times Names New Editor for Outreach
abstract: The New York Times appointed Alex MacCallum, a founding editor of The Huffington Post, an assistant managing editor for audience development.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times named a new editor to its leadership team on Thursday, creating a role within the newsroom to oversee expanding the paper’s audience and deepening its engagement with readers.

headline: The Forever Slump
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Interest Rates']
abstract: The United States should learn from Europe’s experience of raising interest rates too soon.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to believe, but almost six years have passed since the fall of Lehman Brothers ushered in the worst economic crisis since the 1930s. Many people, myself included, would like to move on to other subjects. But we can’t, because the crisis is by no means over. Recovery is far from complete, and the wrong policies could still turn economic weakness into a more or less permanent depression.

headline: Maliki Steps Aside in Iraq
abstract: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq agreed to end his legal challenge to the nomination of his replacement, Haider al-Abadi.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq agreed to end his legal challenge to the nomination of his replacement, Haider al-Abadi.

headline: Get the Military Off of Main Street
keywords: ['Police', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: We must end the federal programs that have militarized local police forces.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — FERGUSON, Mo., has become a virtual war zone. In the wake of the shooting of an unarmed black teenager, Michael Brown, outsize armored vehicles have lined streets and tear gas has filled the air. Officers dressed in camouflage uniforms from Ferguson’s 53-person police force have pointed M-16s at the very citizens they are sworn to protect and serve.

headline: Web Trolls Winning as Incivility Increases
abstract: Emotionally abusive comments are becoming more common online, and the consequences could include scaring away from the web those subject to attacks.
lead_paragraph: The Internet may be losing the war against trolls. At the very least, it isn’t winning. And unless social networks, media sites and governments come up with some innovative way of defeating online troublemakers, the digital world will never be free of the trolls’ collective sway.

headline: Samsung Acquires SmartThings, in Embrace of the Smart Home
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Home Appliances', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: The young company makes accessories that connect home appliances to the Internet and will help Samsung compete with Google and Apple.
lead_paragraph: In the face of slowing smartphone sales, Samsung Electronics has purchased SmartThings, a start-up that makes accessories that connect home appliances to the Internet.

headline: Lauren Bacall Photo With Harry Truman Was Selfie Gone Viral for 1945
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Photography', 'Social Media', 'Public Relations and Publicity']
abstract: In 1945, a press agent pulled off a publicity stunt. In 2014, a marketing content specialist tries to create a brand message that goes viral. They’re not so far apart.
lead_paragraph: MOST of the photographs that appeared with obituaries of Lauren Bacall, who died on Tuesday at age 89, showed her in scenes from her films like “To Have and Have Not,” “Written on the Wind,” “Murder on the Orient Express” and “The Mirror Has Two Faces.” But just about every article also included one of several photographs taken on Feb. 10, 1945, when, on a visit to the National Press Club in Washington to entertain servicemen, Ms. Bacall perched atop a piano being played by Vice President Harry S. Truman.

headline: Maliki and the Futility of Regime Change
abstract: When America has pushed for new leaders in global hot spots, it has often turned out badly. But that isn’t an argument for withdrawing from involvement abroad.
lead_paragraph: The saga of Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, currently approaching its denouement in Iraq, is a recurring theme in American foreign policy. Eight years ago, the United States worked to install Mr. Maliki as prime minister of Iraq in place of Ibrahim al-Jaafari, who was said to favor fellow Shiites over Sunnis or Kurds in the government. Today, Mr. Maliki is blamed for the same thing, and the resulting disunity is believed to be partly responsible for the ease with which jihadists are romping through Iraq.

headline: The Science in a Twinkle of Nighttime in the South
abstract: A firefly ritual of summer becomes part of a multiyear quest by researchers to measure whether urbanization threatens the insects.
lead_paragraph: GREENVILLE, S.C. — As dusk faded over the home of Jeremy Lyons and his sons on a recent evening here, one ritual of the Southern summer — the soft hiss of a can of mosquito repellent — signaled that the start of another was near.

headline: A Gay Chief Makes History as His Bank Goes Public
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Initial Public Offerings']
abstract: Openly gay chief executives are a rarity at the nation’s 1,000 biggest companies.
lead_paragraph: Trevor Burgess rang in the morning at the New York Stock Exchange on Thursday and became the first openly gay chief executive of a publicly listed bank.

headline: Traders Profit as Power Grid Is Overworked
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Electric Light and Power', 'Derivatives (Financial Instruments)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Trading linked to congestion on New York State’s electric grid, a market intended to protect power companies and ultimately benefit consumers, has made big profits for trading firms.
lead_paragraph: PORT JEFFERSON, N.Y. — By 10 a.m. the heat was closing in on the North Shore of Long Island. But 300 miles down the seaboard, at an obscure investment company near Washington, the forecast pointed to something else: profit.

headline: Elmos’ World
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio should remember that even furry monsters have a right to free speech.
lead_paragraph: The forces of civic order that drove the pimps, hustlers and drug dealers from Times Square never anticipated the Elmos. In the tourist-choked, franchise-cheesy, pedestrian-mall version of the Crossroads of the World, adults in character costumes — a lot of Elmos, but also Cookie Monsters, Mickey and Minnie Mice, SpongeBobs, Batmen, Statues of Liberty and others — are a fixture, practically an emblem.

headline: Inside the Dark, Lucrative World of Consumer Debt Collection
abstract: In the murky world of unpaid bills, a banker and an ex-con can make a fortune — if they don’t run into too many crooks.
lead_paragraph: In the murky world of unpaid bills, a banker and an ex-con can make a fortune — if they don’t run into too many crooks.

headline: In Nepal, a Better Life With a Steep Price
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: Plagued by endemic poverty, many young people in Nepal leave to work abroad. But the backbreaking labor they find there often results in death.
lead_paragraph: KATMANDU, Nepal — Picking up coffins at Tribhuvan International Airport here was once part-time work. Only a few arrived each week, not enough for a hearse driver to make a decent living.

headline: Pharmacies Turn Drugs Into Profits, Pitting Insurers vs. Compounders
abstract: Alarmed by a rapid increase in spending on compounded drugs, like a $1,600 baby balm, insurers and others are acting to control their use.
lead_paragraph: It may be the biggest thing in diaper rash treatment, a custom-made product to soothe a baby’s bottom at the eye-popping price of $1,600.

headline: Hamas Transactions Got Through in Error, Bank Says
abstract: The case against Arab Bank could set a precedent, opening up banks to liability for transactions linked to criminals, and giving victims a potent way to seek compensation.
lead_paragraph: The plaintiffs cited specific bank transactions: a 2001 transfer of $60,000 to a Hamas leader, as well as cash payments on behalf of a Saudi charity routed through Jordan, then Ramallah, and then sent out to Arab Bank branches.

headline: Bathrooms at 2 Lower Manhattan Churches: Packed by Tourists
abstract: Tourist numbers are exploding downtown but public facilities haven’t kept pace. Trinity Episcopal Church and St. Paul’s Chapel have found themselves de facto rest stops for many of the guests they welcome each year.
lead_paragraph: St. Paul’s Chapel, the tour guide explained to the guests in its sun-dappled churchyard on Monday, was built in 1766, making it the oldest building in continuous use in Manhattan. George Washington prayed there. When the twin towers of the World Trade Center collapsed across the street in 2001, the chapel suffered not even a broken window.

headline: Fight Brews on Changes That Affect Derivatives
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Derivatives (Financial Instruments)', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: While Wall Street is largely resigned to the regulators’ ultimately getting their way, it is nevertheless pressing for measures seen as protections in return.
lead_paragraph: Tensions are building in an enormous market that nearly brought Wall Street to its knees in 2008.

headline: Olympics? First, Small Goals
abstract: South Korea will host the 2018 Winter Olympics, but its men’s hockey team may face a daunting road to qualify for the 12-team tournament.
lead_paragraph: In the 1990s, Jim Paek harbored an unusual wish for a hockey player who had grown up in suburban Toronto; played in Oshawa, Ontario, and Muskegon, Mich.; and won two Stanley Cups with the Pittsburgh Penguins.

headline: The Search for Calm in Missouri
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Restoring a sense of justice will not be easy in a St. Louis suburb, but angry protesters should be able to vent peacefully, as is their constitutional right.
lead_paragraph: Higher authorities wisely stepped into the St. Louis suburb of Ferguson, Mo., on Thursday after a night that startled the nation with images of police overkill: flash grenades, rubber bullets and huge clouds of tear gas fired at demonstrators protesting the police shooting Saturday of an unarmed black teenager.

headline: An Original Power Couple
abstract: The marriage of Lucinda Franks, a Pulitzer Prize winner, and Robert M. Morgenthau, who was Manhattan’s district attorney for 34 years, represents a kind of glamour that seems to have lost some of its currency.
lead_paragraph: From the time of Ward McAllister to Dawn Powell to Candace Bushnell to Jay Z, the quintessential New York love story has been dependent on a certain kind of brand building. It involves something beyond simply the merging of two compatible spirits — that alone would be boring — and instead requires a shared exceptionalism, heightened ambitions, a mutual interest in power or at least significance on a grand scale.

headline: This Week’s Movies | Aug. 15, 2014
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “The Giver,” “Abuse of Weakness” and “Frank.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “The Giver,” “Abuse of Weakness” and “Frank.”

headline: Bonhams Auctions a Ferrari 250 GTO for $38 Million at Pebble Beach
keywords: ['Auctions', 'Antique and Classic Cars', 'Automobiles', "Pebble Beach Concours D'Elegance (Car Show)"]
abstract: A Ferrari GTO raced in the 1960s set a new record for a car sold at auction, though it fell short of some expectations.
lead_paragraph: CARMEL, Calif. — A Ferrari 250 GTO Berlinetta, one of 36 built in 1961-64, sold for $38.1 million at the Bonhams Quail Lodge Auction here on Thursday evening. The sale is one of many events taking place this week on the Monterey Peninsula of California in conjunction with Sunday’s Pebble Beach Concours d'Élégance.

headline: The Bacall Standard
abstract: With her steel spine, gutsy flirtation, and unmistakable presence, Lauren Bacall created a new film noir feminine ideal.
lead_paragraph: “I believe the really good people would be reasonably successful in any circumstance,” the detective writer Raymond Chandler wrote in his notebook in 1949. If Shakespeare came back today, “he would have refused to die in a corner.”

headline: Anonymous Hackers’ Efforts to Identify Ferguson Police Officer Create Turmoil
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers']
abstract: Members of the activist collective known as Anonymous falsely named the police officer who shot an unarmed 18-year-old black man on Saturday. The botched identification triggered rancor in the network.

headline: California: Police to Face Suit Over Killing of Unarmed Man

lead_paragraph: The family of Ezell Ford, an unarmed black man who was shot and killed by Los Angeles police officers on Monday evening, plans to file a wrongful-death lawsuit against the Police Department, a lawyer for the family said Thursday. The lawyer, Steven A. Lerman, who also represented Rodney G. King after he was beaten by Los Angeles police in the 1990s, said that he expected to file a complaint this week, and that the circumstances surrounding the shooting in South Los Angeles remained unclear. Police officials have said that Mr. Ford tackled an officer who had stopped him and lunged for the officer’s gun, which was secured in his holster. The officer’s partner then shot Mr. Ford and the first officer reached for a backup weapon to shoot as well. Mr. Lerman said that the police could have easily used less lethal options on Mr. Ford, whose family said he had a mental illness. “They could have used a Taser, they could have wrestled him to the ground, they did not have to shoot right away,” Mr. Lerman said. Cmdr. Andrew Smith, a police spokesman, said that Mr. Ford had continued to walk as the police tried to stop him and tried to conceal his hands. Residents who said they witnessed the shooting told local news media that they had seen no sign that Mr. Ford put up a struggle.

headline: Morning Views
abstract: Opinions on abusive police tactics in Ferguson, the U.S. strategy against ISIS, the “death tax” in Washington state, Saudi Arabia’s commitment to fighting terrorism and Airbnb in Canada.
lead_paragraph: After a “night that startled the nation with images of police overkill,” higher authorities “wisely stepped into” Ferguson, Missouri, says an editorial in The New York Times. The St. Louis suburb was rocked by an incident last Saturday, when a police officer shot Michael Brown, an unarmed 18-year-old. Residents held protests since the shooting, and were  “countered by aggressive street policing by officers outfitted in war gear who too often veered toward provocation more than protection.” The local authorities have refused to identify the police officer who shot the teenager. “Residents have a right to know whether the officer has a record of reckless behavior,” and whether the officer lives in the community. Missouri Governor Jay Nixon said the protesters should be given the right to demonstrate, and that Ferguson “would become known ‘as a community that pulled together to overcome’ violence.” Bringing back a “sense of justice” will not be easy in the town where the majority of residents are black while the leadership is white, the editorial says. The authorities are warranted in responding “forcefully” to violence, but the “unyielding use of military tactics and abusive behavior” have widened the gap between them and the town’s residents. “Once the tear gas has dissipated, Mr. Nixon and Mr. Obama have an obligation to ensure that a real dialogue begins in Ferguson and other racially segregated areas, in hopes of keeping armored vehicles off the streets of America.”

abstract: This season’s feeling of careless elegance doesn’t imply an inattention to detail. In fact, it requires it.

lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan, hoping to appease conservative supporters without closing the door on a hoped-for summit meeting with China’s leader, refrained from visiting a controversial war shrine in Tokyo on Friday, the 69th anniversary of the end of World War II, sending a cash offering instead.

headline: Fears of Renewed Instability as Fed Ends Stimulus
abstract: As the Fed feels its way, a former member of the Fed board said that investors may have to prepare for greater volatility.
lead_paragraph: After a nearly uninterrupted five-year rally in stocks and bonds, some investors seem to be getting nervous. On July 31, the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 317 points, wiping out the year’s gains. Last week, junk bond funds experienced record withdrawals and junk bond interest rates spiked.

headline: Secular Stagnation: The Book
abstract: Why we’re feeling (economically) depressed.
lead_paragraph: Ebook, actually: the invaluable VoxEU has a new ebook with contributions from a lot of good people — and also one from me — which is must-reading for anyone trying to keep up with current debates about our economic prospects.

headline: 1939: Anger Over Art Restoration
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Art experts condemned a robber who retouched a painting from the Louvre in 1939.
lead_paragraph: French art experts were enraged yesterday when they learned that an unknown painter, Serge Claude Bogousslavsky, had had the nerve to clean and restore Watteau’s famous painting ‘‘L’Indifferent’’ during the two months he held it after having stolen it from the Louvre. It was bad enough to steal the picture, they argued, but to return it fixed up according to his own ideas was almost a sacrilege. Yet not one of them was prepared to argue that Serge’s criticism of the work before he altered it was wrong. They only doubted that he was the man for the job. Meanwhile, the picture lies in a safe in the Louvre and in the days to come it will be studied by a group of specialists. It may be, as some believe, that Serge has harmed it to some extent, or, as others believe, that he improved it. That will take time to determine, but the Louvre publicly admits the painting is still worth its $100,000 assessment value. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 16, 1939

headline: Life After ‘Vida’: One Man’s Time to Heal
abstract: After an album (“Vida”) and a tour celebrating his recovery from cancer, the Long Island-born and Puerto Rico-raised Robi Draco Rosa is facing new challenges.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Last November’s Latin Grammy Awards ceremony seemed to be the culmination of a heartwarming comeback for the Puerto Rican singer-songwriter-guitarist-producer Robi Draco Rosa.  He received the album of the year honor for “Vida”; sang the hit single “Más y Más” with his boyhood pal and former Menudo bandmate Ricky Martin; and, as far as the audience knew, was finally free of the cancer that had been diagnosed in 2011.

headline: Drawing Noirish Worlds in Blood and Ink
abstract: The comics of the writer and artist Frank Miller have long been dark and violent, but they reached their apex in his “Sin City.”
lead_paragraph: He saved Marvel’s Daredevil from irrelevance, reinvented DC’s Batman as the darkest of knights and even imported samurai legend into mainstream American comics. But the comic book writer and artist Frank Miller found his truest, his deepest creative home in the stark noir of “Sin City.” In Mr. Miller’s underworld, as the troubled drifter Marv observes in the first “Sin City” graphic novel, “The Hard Goodbye” (1992), it’s always “a lousy room in a lousy part of a lousy town.”

headline: Purveyor of a Stylish Brutality
abstract: Frank Miller, an illustrator and author of “Sin City,” considers himself a cartoonist at heart, but he has also embraced Hollywood.
lead_paragraph: The world of Frank Miller’s “Sin City” is black and white in almost every sense. In these popular graphic novels and their film adaptations, Mr. Miller, the author, illustrator and filmmaker, presents a fictional metropolis as monochromatic in hue as in values: mean streets populated with trench-coated men and scantily clad women, ready to exchange bullets or bodily fluids when it is to their advantage.

headline: Jeff Baena Narrates a Scene From ‘Life After Beth’
abstract: The writer and director discusses his zombie romantic comedy.
lead_paragraph: With the comedy “Life After Beth,” the writer and director Jeff Baena sought to make a different kind of zombie movie. Rather than focusing on physical carnage, his film is more about the emotional carnage that is produced when a girl who dies mysteriously returns. In this video, he narrates a sequence featuring Dane DeHaan, Aubrey Plaza, John C. Reilly and Molly Shannon.

headline: If Chuck Todd Seems Comfortable on ‘Meet the Press,’ He Should
abstract: The most frequent guest on a Sunday morning political talk show will now be there even more often.
lead_paragraph: The most frequent guest on “Meet the Press,” the venerable Sunday morning political talk show on NBC, isn’t John McCain or John Kerry. It’s the show’s new host, Chuck Todd.

headline: Who Should Resist Arrest?
abstract: The police should show restraint in arrests.
lead_paragraph: Don’t resist arrest.

headline: Alibaba’s Deal Spree Turns From Romance to Thriller
keywords: ['ACCOUNTING AND ACCOUNTANTS', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: After the discovery of suspicious accounting at a film affiliate, investors in Alibaba’s initial public offering may be less confident about the company’s investment binge, writes John Foley of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Alibaba’s investment story has turned from romance to thriller. Its Hong Kong movie-making affiliate has uncovered “possibly noncompliant” accounting just four months after the Chinese e-commerce giant bought a 60 percent stake. It’s not clear whether Alibaba’s controls were flawed, but it certainly raises questions about the value of the company’s recent investment binge.

lead_paragraph: On the course with mini-golf's best professionals.

headline: Who Made That Paintball?
abstract: A game born of an argument over whether the urban capitalist or the canny outdoorsman has a better instinct for survival.
lead_paragraph: Sometime in the late 1970s, a Wall Street stock trader named Hayes Noel got into an argument with his friend Charles Gaines, a writer, fly fisherman and bodybuilder best known for his books “Stay Hungry” and “Pumping Iron.” The question the two men debated was this: Who had the better instinct for survival, the savvy urban capitalist or the canny outdoorsman? The argument might never have been settled had not a friend of Gaines’s come across an agricultural magazine advertising something called the Nel-Spot 007. Sold by the Nelson Paint Company, the gun used gelatin balls filled with oil-based paint as ammunition. It was used by foresters for marking timber and by ranchers to mark cows.

headline: Ryan Adams: ‘Weed Helps a Lot’
abstract: The singer-songwriter returns from a hiatus, with things back in balance.
lead_paragraph: The singer-songwriter talks to Dave Itzkoff about making amends with his record label, getting clean and bridging the gap between punk and metal.

headline: The Boy of Summer
abstract: I was 13 when a new friend joined me in the cornfield and in my home — and opened a door I hadn’t known was closed.
lead_paragraph: It was the summer I detasseled corn. That dreary, dead-simple job consisted solely of walking down mile-long rows of corn each morning and evening for a period of several weeks, pulling the tassels off every plant that was supposed to produce hybrid seeds. The idea was that the ears would then be fertilized by pollen from a different type of corn in the adjoining row, thus creating a hybrid. The year I was 13 my parents said that yes, I could have a horse if I earned the money to buy it, so I took on three acres, for $30 each.

abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: THE KIDS WHO BEAT AUTISM

headline: Should Unwitting Victims Be Informed of the Crime?
keywords: ['Ethicist, The (Times Column)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Ethics (Personal)', 'Women and Girls', 'Photography']
abstract: Weighing the risk of trauma against the right to know.
lead_paragraph: It was recently announced that Johns Hopkins Hospital will pay a $190 million settlement to more than 8,000 women who were potentially photographed and/or videotaped during gynecological exams by Dr. Nikita Levy. While it is obvious that a horrendous crime was committed against these women, I wonder what ethical obligation the investigators had to make their findings public in a case in which the victims were unaware a crime had occurred. The crime is such that knowledge of it will cause a great deal of emotional trauma. It would be hard (and probably unconstitutional) to prosecute the perpetrator while keeping the details of his crimes private. In general, should the victims be informed despite the trauma it will cause? What is the ethical obligation to the public at large? ARLO LYLE, MINNEAPOLIS

headline: A Mother’s Journey Through the Unnerving Universe of ‘Unboxing’ Videos
keywords: ['Containers and Packaging', 'Children and Childhood', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: What could possibly explain the crazy popularity of strangers’ opening things on camera?
lead_paragraph: A few months ago, I exchanged emails with a woman who told me her name was Melissa Lima. She said she was 21, a native of Brazil who now lived in Westchester County, N.Y., and that she was childless, because, after all, she was only 21.

headline: How a Pair of Twins Redrew an Iconic Photograph With Camera-Like Precision
abstract: With the help of a 30-pound “concave easel,” Trevor and Ryan Oakes are creating a handmade version of an Edward Steichen original.
lead_paragraph: When Edward Steichen took his iconic photograph of the Flatiron Building in New York in 1904, the structure itself was only two years old, one of the tallest in the city and the very epitome of modernity. So it seemed the perfect challenge for the identical-twin artists Ryan and Trevor Oakes earlier this summer, a sidelight to the retrospective of their work I curated at the Museum of Mathematics, just up the road at 11 East 26th Street, open daily through Sept. 14. The brothers, who have been engaged in a deep colloquy on the nature of bifocal vision since toddlerhood, have recently developed one of the most intriguing breakthroughs in the depiction of physical reality since the Renaissance: They have come up with a method for tracing camera-obscura-exact renderings of the world before them onto a concave grid with no other optical equipment (no lenses, no pinholes) except their own unaided eyes. Lawrence Weschler

headline: Keep Vollmann Weird
abstract: William T. Vollmann once said: “The world doesn’t owe me a living, and if the world doesn’t want to buy my books, that’s my problem.”
lead_paragraph: For those who fear that writers have been defanged by the clubby demands of social media, or had their edges sanded off in M.F.A. workshops, there is always the eternally unusual William T. Vollmann. His latest collection, “Last Stories and Other Stories,” is reviewed this week by Kate Bernheimer.

headline: Dead Souls
abstract: In their exploration of mortality and desire, William T. Vollmann’s stories often inhabit supernatural realms.
lead_paragraph: “This is my final book.” So begins “Last Stories and Other Stories,” by William T. Vollmann, and, if you take the claim at face value — since Vollmann offers no reason not to — so ends the miraculous career of a leading fabulist.

headline: 1964: Vietnam Presidency to Khanh
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: South Vietnam gets a new head of state in 1964.
lead_paragraph: CAP ST. JACQUES, South Vietnam — In a major revision of South Vietnam’s governmental structure, the military revolutionary council today [Aug. 16] ousted Maj. Gen. Duong Van Minh as chief of state and gave Premier Nguyen Khanh sweeping new powers by electing him to the newly created post of president. The council, meeting at this seaside resort about 40 miles east of Saigon, also promulgated a new national charter similar to a provisional constitution. This action clears the way for the establishment of an appointed provisional national assembly within one month. There has been no assembly or post of president since President Ngo Dinh Diem was overthrown last November. The council blocked Gen. Khanh’s bid for a one-man rule during the previously declared state of emergency and insured that final authority would rest with the council as a whole. Gen. Khanh retains the position of council chairman and commander in chief of the armed forces. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 17, 1964

lead_paragraph: In a sport known for fast laps and quick tempers, the six-time Sprint Cup champion Jimmie Johnson may be the most even-keeled competitor. But even Johnson has had his moments.

headline: Frayed Ties
abstract: Richard Bausch’s novel, about a relationship under strain, mixes personal and public horrors.
lead_paragraph: Marriages, divorces, rebound affairs, second marriages, adulterous liaisons, thwarted desires, unhappy celibacy, empty intercourse, rape: “Before, During, After” is awash in romantic turmoil and sexual predation. At the center of a landscape of almost unrelieved alienation, of relationships not so much broken as revealed as conceits, are Michael Faulk and Natasha Barrett, hurtling toward matrimony. The title of Richard Bausch’s 20th work of fiction refers to the fractured trajectory of their relationship as well as to the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, 2001, which provide the novel with both elements of plot and an ever-present threat of annihilation that amplifies how his characters strive, and fail, to connect.

headline: Still Made in the U.S.A.
abstract: The American furniture maker who battled Wall Street, Chinese competition and his own relatives to keep his company going.
lead_paragraph: It is impossible to read Beth Macy’s “Factory Man” without casting the inevitable movie version to come. Picture an updated “Norma Rae” in which the hero isn’t an oppressed factory worker but a desperate factory owner battling scheming relatives, callous Wall Street bankers and ruthless Chinese competitors — all to save his workers’ jobs and his family’s bricks-and-mortar legacy, a furniture business in a speck of a town in south central Virginia. Who would play the black sheep turned white knight, John D. Bassett III? George Clooney or Tom Hanks? How about ­Meryl Streep or Blythe Danner as the family matriarch, Pocahontas Hundley Bassett, a.k.a. Miss Pokey? And what tough-­talking star — Ted Danson, perhaps? — would take on the role of the devious brother-in-law, Bob Spilman, who, by Macy’s account, snatched control of the family business away from the rightful heir, the aforementioned “JBIII”? And what of the book’s villain, Larry Moh, the Chinese übercapitalist seemingly bent on putting American furniture makers out of business? Or the fancy lawyers who wind up making more money than anybody else? “Factory Man” is so thick with rich characters, family secrets and backwoods wisdom that this very abundance becomes its one flaw.

headline: Captivity Narrative
abstract: Chelsea Cain’s new heroine can’t escape her past.
lead_paragraph: There are echoes of Lisbeth Salander, Stieg Larsson’s steely heroine, in Kick Lannigan, the protagonist of Chelsea Cain’s unsettling new thriller, which delves into the bleak and disturbing subject of child abduction and pedophilia. Like Salander, Kick is both tough and dangerous. A student of taekwondo, the Korean martial art, she can also box and do a great deal of damage with knives. She’s expert at escaping from confined spaces and can pick locks like the most adept safecracker. But she’s a far more human and likable protagonist than Lisbeth Salander could ever be.

headline: Written in the Stars
abstract: Children are raised to become soul mates in this novel.
lead_paragraph: Lydia Netzer’s second novel, the antically inventive, often outrageously funny “How to Tell Toledo From the Night Sky,” is set in a world that’s pretty different from ours. In it, narwhals frolic in Lake Erie; a girl “raised mute” communicates with her father by birdlike warble; and Toledo is home to an internationally renowned astronomy institute, replete with a supercollider, a simulacrum of “ancient temple ruins” and a gaggle of graduate students called the Daughters of Babylon.

headline: The Leftovers
abstract: A tragedy tears away at a mixed-race family in 1970s Ohio.
lead_paragraph: Celeste Ng’s debut novel, “Everything I Never Told You,” is a literary thriller that begins with some stock elements: a missing girl, a lake, a local bad boy who was one of the last to see her and won’t say what he knows. The year is 1977, the setting, a quiet all-American town in Ohio, where everyone knows one another and nothing like this has ever happened before.

headline: Big Mess in Texas
abstract: James Lee Burke’s sprawling novel connects an encounter with Bonnie and Clyde to the Battle of the Bulge and the oil boom.
lead_paragraph: Here in the Lone Star State, we have a subgenre of the Great American Novel we like to call the Novel as Big as Texas. A representative N.A.B.A.T. features lots of pages crowded with multiple generations of characters fighting Comanches, driving cattle, bringing in oil wells, eating Mexican food, settling ancestral grudges and brooding about the pitiless immensity of the Land. The category arguably began with Edna Ferber’s “Giant” and has proven elastic enough to encompass not just earnest cycloramic texts like James Michener’s “Texas” but also literary benchmarks as varied as Larry McMurtry’s “Lonesome Dove,” Cormac McCarthy’s Border Trilogy and Philipp Meyer’s recent epic, “The Son.”

headline: In the Rearview Mirror
abstract: A history of the automobile and the boom-and-bust industry it fostered.
lead_paragraph: General Motors was hemorrhaging cash and couldn’t get any more loans to pay its debts. Finally, after a plea from the head of its Cadillac division, the company was thrown a financial lifeline, under the condition that it be controlled by a group of trustees.

headline: Best Way to Brush Your Teeth? Experts Disagree
abstract: A review of the dental literature found no randomized trials of brushing technique, and very little agreement on how to go about cleaning teeth.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to the best way to brush your teeth, experts do not agree.

headline: Lehman’s Unsecured Creditors to Receive $4.6 Billion
abstract: The planned distribution for unsecured creditors, which include former employees, banks, asset-management firms and pension funds, represents 17 percent of the value of their claims.
lead_paragraph: Former employees, trading partners and others with claims against Lehman Brothers are set to receive $4.62 billion under a plan announced on Friday by the trustee overseeing the firm’s liquidation.

headline: How ​New York Schools Fared on Tests
abstract: Statewide, nearly 36 percent of students passed the math exam and 31 percent passed the reading exam, according to the New York State Education Department. Results can be viewed by school.
lead_paragraph: Statewide, nearly 36 percent of students passed the math exam and 31 percent passed the reading exam, according to the New York State Education Department. Results can be viewed by school.
