lead_paragraph: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: Lower Your Car Insurance Bill, at the Price of Some Privacy
keywords: ['Automobile Insurance and Liability', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Privacy', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Usage-based insurance programs monitor your driving habits to see if you qualify for lower rates. The disadvantages are not insignificant, however.
lead_paragraph: An increasing number of the nation’s auto insurance companies have a new proposition: Let them track every second of your driving in exchange for an annual discount that can reach into the hundreds of dollars if you behave yourself on the road.

headline: Black and White
abstract: In 1928, two brothers head to Africa to collect film footage.
lead_paragraph: Donald Bogle’s seminal history of African-Americans in film, “Toms, Coons, Mulattoes, Mammies, and Bucks,” starts like this: “In the beginning, there was an Uncle Tom. A former mechanic photographed him in a motion picture that ran no longer than 12 minutes. And a new dimension was added to American movies. . . . Uncle Tom himself. He was the American movies’ first black character.” Thus the fraught, complex and sometimes heartbreaking relationship between blacks, whites and moviemaking began.

headline: The Cheat
abstract: An unfaithful artist attempts to win back his wife’s affection.
lead_paragraph: The protagonist of Courtney Maum’s debut novel, “I Am Having So Much Fun Here Without You,” is really, truly hard to like. Richard Haddon is a British artist living in Paris, and when we meet him we learn quickly that he has just compromised his artistic principles to sell palatable, décor-friendly paintings, and that he has recently cheated on his beautiful French wife, Anne-Laure, with whom he has a relatively happy marriage and a young daughter. Richard’s affair — not a one-off drunken mistake, but rather a serious monthslong “I wish I could leave my wife for you” kind of thing — ended only because she left him.

headline: Imperial Son
abstract: A study of Winston Churchill’s contradictions and passions and his long relationship with empire.
lead_paragraph: “To paraphrase Winston Churchill,” Ronald Reagan said in his first Inaugural Address, “I did not take the oath I’ve just taken with the intention of presiding over the dissolution of the world’s strongest economy.” If it was curious that an American president should cite an English politician, what made it odder was the line he chose to adapt.

headline: Grudge Match
abstract: An attempt to save a marriage proves fatal.
lead_paragraph: Punishment and penance for marital infidelity can take many forms, and on the face of it, the means by which a painter named Gus (short for Augusta) Edelman, the narrator of Robin Black’s first novel, is paying for the sin of cheating on her husband — a retreat to an isolated house in the country — has a certain amount of appeal, at least to creative types like them. It’s Yaddo with no company but their own.

headline: Kennedy, L.B.J. and a Disputed Deer Hunt
keywords: ['Hunting and Trapping', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Firearms', 'Deer', 'Gun Control']
abstract: The outing foreshadowed the differing attitudes of Americans regarding hunting and other recreation involving firearms.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, Nov. 17, 1960, before dawn, at the L.B.J. Ranch near Johnson City, Tex., Vice President-elect Lyndon Johnson had his houseguest, President-elect John F. Kennedy, woken up to go deer hunting.

headline: Some Assimilation Required
abstract: As a Ukrainian family adapts to life in Brooklyn, memories of the old country linger.
lead_paragraph: Yelena Akhtiorskaya’s impressive debut novel, “Panic in a Suitcase,” considers the precarious position of émigrés ­trying to build a life in America — specifically, Ukrainian émigrés trying to build a life in Brooklyn’s Brighton Beach. Set there and in Odessa, Ukraine, the novel spans 15 years in the lives of the Nasmertov family. It opens in 1993 as Pasha, the only remaining family member in Odessa, visits Brighton Beach to see his cancer-stricken mother, the matriarch of the family. Pasha — sometimes called “the greatest poet not just in Odessa and not in all of Ukraine but in all of Russia” — is a beacon for his family, much to the curiosity of his young niece, Frida. Though the first half of the novel centers on the family’s attempt to coerce Pasha into moving to America, this beautifully drawn portrait of a splintered ­immigrant family is also about young ­Frida and her struggle to assimilate. Akhtiorskaya layers the novel with equal parts humor and anxiety, and expertly highlights the unease of having one foot in and one foot out of the old country.

headline: The Buddy System
abstract: For some New Yorkers, sharing an apartment with others is a choice, not a necessity.
lead_paragraph: For the eight years that she was based in Chicago, Katie Kirby happily lived by herself. When she moved to Manhattan three years ago, there didn’t seem to be any reason for a different domestic arrangement, and she contentedly signed on for a one-bedroom on the Upper West Side.

headline: J.Crew Introduces a New Suit Style for Athletic Guys
abstract: Next week, the brand will introduce the Crosby, shown here on members of the New York Knights. Meant for gym goers, it offers a roomier fit than the brand’s popular Ludlow.
lead_paragraph: In 2008, when slim rocker chic was all the rage, J.Crew debuted the Ludlow, a narrow, downtown-savvy suit priced in the neighborhood of $500. Lately, though, “guys have been asking us for a roomier fit,” says Frank Muytjens, J.Crew’s menswear director. “When I get a chance, I go to events in the stores and help some guys find a suit. Most of the guys I helped fit the Ludlow really well, but some who were a little bigger had trouble, especially in the shoulder and the upper arm.” With them in mind, J.Crew introduces the Crosby, a roomier, more athletic style shown off here by members of the New York Knights, the city’s combatants in the American National Rugby League.

headline: Way to a Man’s Heart
abstract: A British housewife kills her husband. Then she eats him.
lead_paragraph: “Handy to have a good, sharp fruit knife for skinning fiddly bits.” This is just one of the many practical cooking tips proffered by Lizzie Prain, the disconcertingly resourceful kitchen whiz at the crux of Natalie Young’s novel “Season to Taste.”

headline: Anybody Home?
abstract: A family struggles to cope after its take-charge daughter flees.
lead_paragraph: Mary Lawson’s story of a dysfunctional family in a northern Ontario logging town is told in scenes that are as palpably tender and surprising as they are quietly disturbing. “Road Ends,” her formidable third novel, uses the frozen landscape as a metaphor for the numb, spiritless lives her people shuffle through uneventfully, stuck in their circumstances. But there is a deeper drama that propels the book forward, and that sets up a vivid, evocative tale of rural and domestic angst laced with calamity.

headline: No Safe Haven
abstract: In Rennie Airth’s “The Reckoning,” a former Scotland Yard detective comes out of retirement to assist in the investigation of killings committed with the same pistol.
lead_paragraph: Rennie Airth opens his new police procedural, THE RECKONING (Viking, $26.95), with a thoughtful character study of Oswald Gibson, an inoffensive worm of a man, a recent widower on the threshold of old age, who has only now dared to indulge his passion for fly-fishing. After setting this pathetic soul down on the banks of a quiet stream, contentedly humming a Gilbert and Sullivan tune, Airth kills him off.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: COUNTDOWN: Our Last, Best Hope for a Future on Earth? by Alan Weisman.  (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $18.) In “The World Without Us” (2007), Weisman contemplated what would happen to the planet should human beings suddenly vanish. In this rousing sequel — a tour of our overpopulated, overexploited world — he interviews scientists, religious leaders and public-health experts in more than 20 countries, asking: How many humans can the planet hold without capsizing?

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Lev Grossman’s “The Magician’s Land,” which debuts at No. 1 on the hardcover fiction list, owes a debt to “Brideshead Revisited.”
lead_paragraph: Not Hogwarts: With the publication of “The Magician’s Land,” which debuts at No. 1 on the hardcover fiction list this week, Lev Grossman’s fantasy trilogy comes to a close — for now. In a letter to his fans (written as a mock alumni letter sent by Brakebills, the wizarding college in the series), Grossman writes, “People have been asking me whether ‘The Magician’s Land’ is really the last Magicians book, and the answer to that is a resounding probably.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: COLORLESS TSUKURU TAZAKI AND HIS YEARS OF PILGRIMAGE,  by Haruki Murakami. Translated by Philip Gabriel. (Knopf, $25.95.) A novel of a man’s traumatic entrance into adulthood and the shadowy passages he must then negotiate.

headline: Pioneer in France and on the Frontier
abstract: With “Paris Blues” and “Duel at Diablo,” Sidney Poitier stepped slightly away from the reassuring roles that put him on the map.
lead_paragraph: “Sidney Poitier has been one of the best reasons for going to the movies these last two decades,” Pauline Kael noted in a 1969 review of “The Reivers.” Her comment, made parenthetically while discussing a film in which Mr. Poitier did not appear, suggests that the actor’s existence alone improved American movies, specifically and in general.

headline: That ‘@’ in Your Password for Better Security? Useless
keywords: ['Computer Security', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers']
abstract: Some people are arguing that security problems on the web go way beyond whether you put that extra number in your password.
lead_paragraph: If you rushed to change your password last week on the heels of news that Russian hackers might have gotten their hands on an enormous amount of login information, go ahead and keep on panicking. Robert McMillan at Wired warns that even your weirdest-looking, hardest-to-type passwords may not keep you safe.

headline: A Director Takes Direction
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Theater']
abstract: Trip Cullman, the Off Broadway theater director, lives in a large loft decorated with help from his mother, Elissa Cullman.
lead_paragraph: Trip Cullman, the prolific Off Broadway theater director, compares decorating his apartment to conceiving the set for a play. “Every decision is vetted through me, but in the happiest circumstances, it’s a creative collaboration,” he said.

headline: T Time | Emily Sundblad
abstract: The artist, performer, and co-founder of Reena Spaulings Fine Art on her Whitney Biennial entry, Dolly Parton and why she loves the Frick Collection.
lead_paragraph: The artist, performer, and co-founder of Reena Spaulings Fine Art on her Whitney Biennial entry, Dolly Parton and why she loves the Frick Collection.

lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Frank.”

headline: A Rabbi’s Departure Manifests a Challenge for Jews in America
abstract: The departure of Rabbi Andy Bachman, who is leaving his Brooklyn synagogue to help the poor, highlights vexing issues at the center of Judaism’s future in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Leafy, affluent Park Slope, Brooklyn, embodies the challenge facing modern American Jewry: Though many Jews live there, few are observant. So it was no small feat when Rabbi Andy Bachman took the helm of Congregation Beth Elohim in the neighborhood eight years ago and began attracting a vibrant congregation of Jewish atheists and agnostics, as well as the more traditionally religious.

headline: How Does a 2-Year-Old Wear Glasses? (Not) Very Carefully.
abstract: I wasn’t happy when the pediatric ophthalmologist ordered up glasses for my toddler. But it wasn’t supposed to be about me.
lead_paragraph: At first, it was so subtle that my husband and I ignored it. My son Jordan, 2 years old at the time, would cross his eyes while watching TV or staring at something across the room. But when the crossing became too hard to ignore, we took him to his doctor, who recommended a pediatric ophthalmologist.

headline: Obama to Visit Estonia to Reassure Baltic Allies
abstract: The president will meet with the leaders of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania concerning the conflict in Ukraine and the administration’s commitment to NATO.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will travel to Estonia during the first week of September to reassure Baltic allies that they have the support of the United States, the White House said, as tensions rise over Russian intervention in Ukraine.

headline: Aug. 15 Updates on Police Shooting in Missouri
abstract: The New York Times is providing regular updates in the aftermath of a police shooting in Ferguson, Mo. that has sparked unrest.
lead_paragraph: The police chief in Ferguson, Mo., identified the officer who was involved in the fatal shooting of Michael Brown, an unarmed 18-year-old black man who was killed on Saturday. The Justice Department is investigating the shooting, which prompted protests in the St. Louis suburb and a robust debate about the militarization of local police departments around the country.

headline: Pervasive Medicare Fraud Proves Hard to Stop
keywords: ['Medicare', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Government Contracts and Procurement']
abstract: Only a fraction of an estimated $60 billion in fraud and overcharging was recovered last year, and the system to combat fraud may be largely to blame.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — The ordinary looking office building in a suburb of Baltimore gives no hint of the high-tech detective work going on inside. A $100 million system churns through complicated medical claims, searching for suspicious patterns and posting the findings on a giant screen.

headline: Dual Threat Has Mainstream Syrian Rebels Fearing Demise
abstract: Western-backed insurgents are expressing frustration that the United States has not aided them as a mutual ally against both the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria and President Bashar al-Assad.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Far from being depleted by its recent sweep into Iraq, the extremist Islamic State in Iraq and Syria is pressing deeper into Syria, regaining territory it had lost to the mainstream Syrian insurgents just as the Syrian Army has come within five miles of encircling the insurgent-held section of Aleppo, Syria’s largest city.

headline: Ferguson Police Department Incident Report
abstract: The incident report of the convenience store robbery released Friday by the Ferguson Police Department.
lead_paragraph: The incident report of the convenience store robbery released Friday by the Ferguson Police Department.

keywords: ['Collectors and Collections', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Music']
abstract: Peter Dilg, who has one of the largest private collections in the country of windup phonographs and gramophones, enjoys playing them on his deck on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: Peter Dilg motored his 13-foot skiff up to a one-room house sitting on stilts in the middle of Hempstead Bay, on Long Island’s South Shore, then carried an old record player onto its deck.

headline: Home Sales Around the Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Greta Gerwig, Marcus Samuelsson and Others Tell Stories About Beloved Garments
abstract: The items are part of “Worn Stories,” the debut book by Emily Spivack, which collects various odes to articles of clothing by the people who wear them.
lead_paragraph: The artist, writer, teacher and editor Emily Spivack is a special kind of storyteller. The protagonist in her tales is always old, a little tired-looking and usually slightly beat-up: a used item of clothing. A year ago, Spivack lined the walls of the Philadelphia Art Alliance with garments she found on eBay. Each piece in the installation, “Sentimental Value,” was accompanied by an excerpt from the seller’s tale in the eBay listing.

headline: Cool Summer Fish
abstract: These refreshing summer dishes include two kinds of escabeche. You can cook fish like sardines, petrale sole and Pacific cod, then allow it to cool and serve it with a robust sauce or a marinade.
lead_paragraph: Fish can be challenging. We’re told to eat it twice a week because it’s such a lean, high-protein, high-omega-3 animal, but we’re also told to avoid certain fish like swordfish and large tuna because of high mercury content, other types like Atlantic cod (or what’s left of it) because of overfishing and farmed salmon because of ecological considerations.

headline: Mapping the Spread of the Military’s Surplus Gear
abstract: Most U.S. counties have received at least some military equipment through a free Pentagon surplus program.
lead_paragraph: Most U.S. counties have received at least some military equipment through a free Pentagon surplus program.

abstract: Sizing up new albums from Eric Harland’s Voyager, Cyrille Aimée, the Enrico Pieranunzi Trio, Bobby Broom and Hildur Gudnadottir.
lead_paragraph: Eric Harland’s Voyager

headline: Dinner and Drinks on the Battlefield
abstract: The Pavilion opened in Union Square Park after years of controversy over the city’s willingness to sacrifice some public recreational space for a private restaurant.
lead_paragraph: When the city began plans to allow a restaurant in the 1928 Greek Revival-style pavilion at the north end of Union Square Park, some neighbors and park supporters objected, saying the area had plenty of bars and restaurants, but too little park space. That was 12 years ago. This spring, after lengthy court battles, the chow finally hit the tables. Let the kale chips fall where they may!

headline: Thousands of Miles, Seven Days
abstract: The new Express Excursions program at Mountain Travel Sobek offers one-week trips to destinations like Nepal and Cambodia.
lead_paragraph: The pioneering adventure travel outfitter Mountain Travel Sobek is best known for its remote adventures in wilderness destinations that, by virtue of location, require a fair investment of time to reach, let alone explore.

headline: The Addict Down the Hall
abstract: Substance abuse is not uncommon among seniors in nursing homes. A novel rehab program aims to address that.
lead_paragraph: Later this month, new residents will arrive at a nursing home in the Bronx. Like others coming to Jewish Home Lifecare, they will be recuperating from hospitalization for cardiac surgery, strokes, fractured hips — the whole panoply of senior ills.

headline: Upright Citizens Brigade Will Invite the Audience to Help Write ‘Blank! The Musical’
abstract: Audience members will use an app to suggest a title, write dialogue or offer musical notes.
lead_paragraph: The Upright Citizens Brigade Theater, a troupe that specializes in sketch comedy and improvisation, is planning to present “Blank! The Musical,” a new immersive work that will be composed afresh nightly, with the audience’s help. The production, which opens at New World Stages on Nov. 1, and is expected to run six weeks, will use Internet technology to put some of the script decisions in the audience’s hands.

headline: As Europe’s Economy Stumbles, Britain Offers Some Glimmer of Hope
keywords: ['Recession and Depression', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Gross Domestic Product']
abstract: The eurozone is flirting with recession while the British gross domestic product grew 3.2 percent. But weaknesses lurk in the numbers, analysts say.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain, once described as the “sick man of Europe,” now looks like the region’s bright spot.

headline: Ebola Epidemic Most Likely Much Larger Than Reported, W.H.O. Says
abstract: More than 1,100 deaths have been reported in four African nations, but the World Health Organization said the actual number is almost certainly higher.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — West Africa’s deadly Ebola epidemic is probably much worse than the world realizes, with health centers on the front lines warning that the actual numbers of deaths and illnesses are significantly higher than the official estimates, the World Health Organization said.

headline: Ford Recalls 160,000 Turbocharged Vehicles
abstract: Ford issued the recall because of a stalling problem on 2-liter turbo-power Escape crossovers and Fiesta ST hatchbacks.
lead_paragraph: Ford is recalling about 160,000 Focus ST hatchbacks and Escape crossovers from the 2013-14 model years because the turbocharged, 2-liter 4-cylinder engine may lose power or stall, the automaker said Friday. The action includes about 133,000 vehicles in the United States and 25,000 in Canada.

headline: By Using Language Rooted in Andes, Internet Show’s Hosts Hope to Save It
abstract: Streaming from a Bronx apartment, it is perhaps the only radio show in the U.S. to broadcast in the fading Ecuadorean language of Kichwa.
lead_paragraph: Segundo J. Angamarca, half-hidden in a thicket of electronic equipment on a recent Friday evening, put on his headphones and glanced around the room, a makeshift Internet radio station in his apartment in the Bronx.

headline: Can Statins Help Treat Ebola?
abstract: Experimental treatments are in short supply, but affordable and widely available drugs may work.
lead_paragraph: THIS week, the World Health Organization endorsed the use of experimental drugs in the fight against the Ebola epidemic in West Africa. That is the right decision. There is no proven vaccine or treatment for Ebola, and in light of the severity of the current outbreak, experimental treatments that have not been tested on humans should be an option.

headline: Feta-Stuffed Grilled Flatbread
abstract: Melissa Clark shows flatbread at its best: grilled and stuffed with fresh oregano and feta cheese.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark shows flatbread at its best: grilled and stuffed with fresh oregano and feta cheese.

lead_paragraph: Does the house go with the Rolls-Royce, or does the Rolls-Royce go with the house?

headline: The Stuff of Great Grilled Flatbreads
abstract: Get the dough out of the way, and you have the fun part: choosing the fillings.
lead_paragraph: A grilled flatbread is an excellent thing. But a grilled stuffed flatbread is even better.

headline: Outside Lisbon, a Verdant World of Castles and Palaces
abstract: Sintra, about 20 miles west of the capital, is one of Portugal’s crown jewels.
lead_paragraph: No matter how well it begins or ends, every fairy tale has a villain. In my storybook adventure in Sintra, a Portuguese town about 20 miles west of Lisbon, it was the hands of the clock. Roaming the pristine grounds of castles high in the hills, I wished that time would stand still.

headline: On an Island Hunt for Pieces of My History
abstract: Seeking to patch holes in her family history, the author travels to Aruba, her father’s childhood home.
lead_paragraph: We had been in the lobby of our hotel in Oranjestad, Aruba’s capital, for only a few minutes when the Dutch territory’s Arcadian “One Happy Island” front was shattered by a desk clerk whose petulance hit me like a left hook straight to the temple. As she delivered the rules and regulations like a stern lecture, scolding my daughter and me for the simple offense of standing before her, my mind drifted back home to New York City. There I was, at Mendez Boxing gym, and there she was, standing in place of my favorite heavy bag.

headline: A One-Shake, Two-Straws Kind of Place
abstract: Despite changing ownership and locations several times since its opening in 1932, Egger’s Ice Cream Parlor, on Staten Island’s north shore, remains a great beacon of the classic cone.
lead_paragraph: Most summer afternoons at Egger’s Ice Cream Parlor on Staten Island’s north shore unfold in the same way. Spoons clank against ice cream bowls, customers chat about birthday parties and coming T-ball games, and the heady scent of hot fudge perfumes the place. In a city of $7 milkshakes and extravagant flavors like black sesame seaweed or tarragon pink pepper, Egger’s remains a great beacon of the classic cone.

headline: Taking a Spin: How Democrats Could Keep Their Majority
abstract: In this week’s randomly generated Senate election simulation, some surprises along the way.
lead_paragraph: Democrats hold on to the Senate by the skin of their teeth by winning Arkansas in this week’s spin of Leo’s Senate wheels. Every week we generate random election scenarios based on the probabilities from the Upshot’s Senate elections forecasting model.

headline: A Food Scene Grows in Sioux Falls, S.D.
abstract: In recent years, new spots have burnished this Midwest city's culinary reputation.
lead_paragraph: A city where chain restaurants rule when it comes to going out, Sioux Falls, S.D., has never been known for impressive dining. The cold winters and the three-tiered waterfall that inspired its name, yes, but not the food. Now, that’s finally changing: In recent years, locals as well as transplants have opened noteworthy restaurants, cafes and bakeries that are giving this Midwest metropolis of about 166,000 a newfound culinary fame.

headline: Portraits of Loved Ones, in Three Galleries on Three Continents
abstract: Curated by the photographer Lindley Warren, the exhibition of candid images opens concurrently in Brisbane, Vienna and Des Moines.
lead_paragraph: True to its name, “The Ones We Love” is an exhibition, website and book devoted to images shot by international photographers of their loved ones. Curated by the Des Moines, Iowa-based photographer Lindley Warren, who also edited the book, the show opens this week in three art galleries on three continents. “I’ve always been the type of person who is more interested in what’s underneath the surface,” says Warren, 26. “It’s about a deeper sense of connection.”

headline: When the Beach Is a Long, Long Trip
abstract: Four products meant to reinvigorate the skin as they keep it hydrated may help you beat the heat.
lead_paragraph: Looking for a fashionable way to cool down this August? These four beauty products may help you beat the heat.

headline: Tracking Alibaba’s Buying Spree
abstract: Investors may wonder if the Chinese e-commerce giant has done all its homework in its recent buying spree.
lead_paragraph: With the disclosure of accounting irregularities at the Alibaba Pictures Group — formerly known as the ChinaVision Media Group — potential investors may now wonder whether the company has done thorough due diligence in its race to snap up what it deems as strategic assets.

headline: Checking Accounts for Marijuana Businesses
abstract: Because marijuana remains an illegal substance under federal law, few banks have been willing to provide financial services to those growing and selling the drug.
lead_paragraph: Marijuana entrepreneurs in states that have legalized the drug for either medical or recreational purposes have had trouble finding banking partners. Because marijuana remains an illegal substance under federal law, few financial firms have been willing to provide checking accounts and other services to those growing, processing and selling the drug.Previously it was difficult to know the exact scope of this problem. But earlier this week a federal official involved in policing financial crimes offered some details: just 105 institutions in more than one-third of states are “engaged in banking relationships with marijuana related businesses,” Jennifer Shasky Calvery, the director of the Financial Crimes Enforcement Network, said in a speech. (In addition to Colorado’s and Washington’s policies allowing recreational use, 35 states have legalized some form of marijuana consumption for medical purposes.) Ms. Calvery also said that financial firms had made 475 filings alerting regulators to the fact that they had terminated relationships with marijuana businesses as of Aug. 8 “in order to maintain an effective anti-money laundering compliance program.”

headline: Answering a Question About a Tale of Human Sacrifice to a Tree
abstract: The tree never lived, but the story, dating to April 26, 1874, just would not die.
lead_paragraph: Q. What can you tell me about a New York newspaper hoax involving a man-eating tree?

headline: Nigel Farage Picks District to Make Run for British Parliament
abstract: The leader of the U.K. Independence Party, which seeks Britain’s withdrawal from the European Union, said he would run next year in Thanet South.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Nigel Farage, leader of Britain’s populist U.K. Independence Party, on Friday confirmed plans to run for a seat in Parliament in next year’s general election, identifying Thanet South, in the south of England, as the constituency he hopes to represent.

headline: An Eclectic Lineup for the Queer New York International Arts Festival
abstract: The festival, now in its third year, will run from Sept. 17 to 28.
lead_paragraph: Among the highlights of the 2014 Queer New York International Arts Festival are the United States premieres of Marissa Perel’s “More Than Just a Piece of Sky,” a deconstruction of the Isaac Bashevis Singer story “Yentl”; and the Croatian experimental theater director Branko Brezovec’s “Confusions,” a work based on Robert Musil’s 1906 novel, “The Confusions of Young Törless.”

headline: A Multimillion-Dollar Estate, for Sale by Owner
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Personal Finances', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: Bob Fisher learned many lessons when he decided to sell his 50-acre mountaintop estate in North Carolina by himself for $18 million to $25 million.
lead_paragraph: BOB FISHER had an idea that seemed as if it would either work out brilliantly or fail miserably: He was going to sell his 50-acre estate on a mountaintop in North Carolina by himself, and he was going to do it in a few months.

lead_paragraph: The young minister mixes her preaching with singing at the Brown Memorial Baptist Church in Brooklyn.

lead_paragraph: At her gallery, Reena Spaulings Fine Art, the painter and performer Emily Sundblad is reviving the artistic spirit of downtown New York through creative collaboration — and a resistance to the cult of self-promotion.

headline: At This Academy, the Curriculum Is Garbage
abstract: A new class of sanitation workers learns how to drive garbage trucks and grapple with snow chains, and why trash bags are best held at arm’s length.
lead_paragraph: Rose-gold light was falling onto Jamaica Bay and sea gulls passed overhead on another beautiful morning at Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn, a far reach of New York City mostly devoid of New Yorkers and cars.

headline: Coke Finds Right Formula in Monster Deal
abstract: Buying a piece of Monster is a capitulation of sorts, though Coca-Cola hasn’t caved in financially, Kevin Allison of Reuters Breakingviews writes.
lead_paragraph: Coca-Cola, the $180 billion soda giant, is paying $2.2 billion for 17 percent of Monster Beverage, a maker of trendy energy drinks. It goes to show how even a global powerhouse with significant distribution and marketing advantages can struggle to keep ahead of upstart rivals. At least Coke got the deal formula right.

lead_paragraph: A scene from Catherine Breillat’s film.

headline: Mapping Migration in the United States
abstract: An interactive map showing nationwide migration patterns in the United States since 1900.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, we published a series of interactive charts showing how Americans have moved between states since 1900. The charts show striking patterns for many states: You can trace the rise of migrant and immigrant populations all along the Southwest, particularly in Texas and Arizona; the influx of New Yorkers and other Northeasterners into Florida starting in the 1970s; and the growth in the Southern share of the Illinois population during the Great Migration.

headline: Driven | 2015 Cadillac Escalade ESV

lead_paragraph: Because A-listers don’t roll in a Suburban.

headline: Sorry, Fans. Discovery Has Jumped the Shark Week.
keywords: ['Environment', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'News and News Media', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Science and Technology', 'Sharks']
abstract: Discovery’s Shark Week blurs fact and fiction, and trusting viewers are taking the bait.
lead_paragraph: Shark Week is an annual, weeklong block of programming that airs on the Discovery Channel – and as the name suggests, it’s all about the ocean’s toothiest predators. It was first broadcast in July 1988, and since then, has become a veritable network cash cow.

headline: Oxford Dictionary Recognizes: YOLO, Amazeballs and Hot Mess
abstract: The online dictionary added new terms inspired by popular culture and online usage.
lead_paragraph: The Oxford Dictionaries will include YOLO – an acronym for “you only live once,” popularized by Drake in his 2011 song, “The Motto” – in the quarterly update of its online dictionary, released this week. And though the list is heavy with science and technology terms – clickbait, listicle and pharmacovigilance (monitoring drugs after they are approved for use) – several entries are arguably arts-related.

headline: Together on the Road to Divorce
abstract: Valerie and Clark Tate’s wedding took place in 2000, and while they “unhitched” in 2007, they remain legally married, share a home and are raising their son together.
lead_paragraph: Valerie and Clark Tate’s wedding took place in 2000, and although they “unhitched” in 2007, they remain legally married, share a home and are raising their son, Jonah, together. Both have other romantic relationships. With their rabbi, they are preparing for a Jewish divorce in the fall that they view as a “spiritual divorce.” Both acknowledge a legally binding divorce may be ahead.

headline: Amazon, Its Friends and Critics
abstract: The dispute between Amazon and Hachette has caused the usually reticent retailer start talking but made the publisher shut up. Some of the best commentary is coming from authors in the middle.
lead_paragraph: The exact nature of the conflict between Amazon and Hachette is somewhat veiled. The parties confirm that it is over e-book prices, and Amazon obviously wants more money from the sale of e-books than Hachette is willing to give. But Hachette has been circumspect, while Amazon has been forceful if not always accurate.

headline: Video: A New Cadillac Escalade, Still Large and in Charge
abstract: Although some doubted that the Escalade would ever be much more than a dressed-up Tahoe, it has evolved since 1999 to become a pop culture staple.
lead_paragraph: Cars and S.U.V.s are not solely about transportation. If that were the case, we’d all be driving old Honda Civics and Ford Explorers. People want to drive their personalities, and because of that, the Cadillac Escalade looms large in pop culture. And if merely big isn’t big enough, Cadillac offers the ESV model that I recently tested, with a wheelbase 14 inches longer than the standard model’s.

headline: Bring Friends, Bring Checkbooks, Bring Both
abstract: It takes all types to raise the money for a Broadway show.
lead_paragraph: The Bundler

headline: I Want to Be a Producer (Me, Too!)
abstract: When a Tony Award is announced, the stage fills with a show’s many producers, illustrating just how drastically the financing of Broadway productions has changed.
lead_paragraph: They couldn’t get to the stage fast enough.

headline: A Year After Drug Deaths, the Electric Zoo Music Festival Tries Again
abstract: Mike Bindra and Laura de Palma, who run the festival, where two attendees died in drug-related episodes last year, are in the middle of a discussion within the world of electronic dance music about how to stem the tide of drugs.
lead_paragraph: With three weeks left until thousands of raver babies dressed in neon spandex descend on Electric Zoo, New York’s largest dance music festival, Mike Bindra and Laura de Palma were running through their checklists in a state of high anxiety. The load-in for their giant show was about to begin. In a few days’ time, six performance stages — the biggest serving 30,000 fans — would spring up in a field on Randalls Island. Crates of pyrotechnics, trucks of LED screens and a stadium’s worth of subwoofers would soon be coming in.

headline: For Tiina Laakkonen and the Elder Statesman, Blue Is the Warmest Color
abstract: The stylist and owner of the Amagansett boutique Tiina is debuting limited editions of four of the knitwear brand’s styles in striated shades of natural indigo.
lead_paragraph: As anyone familiar with her styling work, her Amagansett, N.Y., boutique, Tiina, or her nearby home already knows, Tiina Laakkonen really, really loves indigo. “Blue is my favorite color and indigo is the most natural, alive version of it,” she says. “I used to live in black clothes when I lived in New York, but they seem too hard in both the light and the life out East.”

headline: So You’d Like to Invest in Broadway?
abstract: If you’re thinking about helping with the finances of a Broadway production, here are some rules to keep in mind.
lead_paragraph: Broadway shows often rely on dozens of investors to finance their costly budgets. “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder,” for example, had 130 investors providing between $25,000 and $850,000 for a total capitalization of $7.5 million.

headline: Super Moonshine: Where Astronomy Meets Alcohol
abstract: In honor of a celestial phenomenon, a modern take on moonshine.
lead_paragraph: This week, the full moon hung the lowest, brightest and largest it will all year, looming 14 percent closer to Earth and 30 percent brighter than other full moons, according to NASA.

headline: Barbershop Goes Bollywood
abstract: “The Fabulous Lipitones,” a song-stuffed comedy, is having its New York debut at the Penguin Rep Theater in Stony Point in Rockland County.
lead_paragraph: When a genial, appealing quartet of old-timers called Benchmark made it to the finals of the 2011 season of “Australia’s Got Talent,” the group’s tenor told viewers that even though they hadn’t won, they had achieved their goal: demonstrating “that singing a cappella music in the barbershop style is cool.”

headline: A Bit More City on City Island
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Building (Construction)']
abstract: New condo developments on City Island aren’t proposed often, and residents of this 230-acre island have a history of being tough to please.
lead_paragraph: New condo developments on City Island, which hugs the eastern edge of the Bronx, aren’t proposed often, and residents of this 230-acre island have a history of being tough to please.

headline: Surveillance Footage of Ferguson Robbery
abstract: The Ferguson, Mo., police released surveillance camera video that officials said showed the convenience store robbery shortly before the shooting of Michael Brown.
lead_paragraph: The Ferguson, Mo., police released surveillance camera video that officials said showed the convenience store robbery shortly before the shooting of Michael Brown.

headline: The Student Taught, the Teacher Learned
abstract: Ted Gibson and Jason Backe met 20 years ago, and say they wed for love and money.
lead_paragraph: With his hair, eyebrows and goatee dyed a flaming red, Jason Backe was hard to miss. But it wasn’t his looks that first caught Ted Gibson’s attention back in 1994. Nor was it Mr. Backe’s easy laugh or impish charm, or that Mr. Backe, a student at the time at the Horst Education Center, a beauty school in Minneapolis, had twice walked out on the Highly Textured Hair class Mr. Gibson was teaching.

headline: In Idaho, Tracing What Remains After the Flames
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Wildfires', 'Fires and Firefighters', 'Roads and Traffic']
abstract: Exploring the scenic central part of the state and pondering the mosaic of destruction and renewal left by wildfires.
lead_paragraph: As we neared Stanley, Idaho, a hamlet carved by creeks and framed by mountains with spiky peaks that reminded me of a punk rocker’s hair, the landscape surrounding the winding highway on which we’d climbed 7,000 feet gave way from rugged canyon to flat expanse of grass speckled by lodgepole pine and aspen. We were on the northern edges of the Sawtooth National Recreation Area, three hours from Boise, when scars from an old fire came into view.

headline: Under Cover: The Dark Shadows of Debt Collection
abstract: To illustrate Jake Halpern’s deep dive into the shadowy underworld of debt collection for this week’s cover, the magazine turned to Francesco Francavilla, a comic-book illustrator based in Atlanta.
lead_paragraph: To illustrate Jake Halpern’s deep dive into the shadowy underworld of debt collection for the Aug. 17 cover, the magazine turned to Francesco Francavilla, an artist based in Atlanta who has illustrated a range of comic books, including “Guardians of the Galaxy” for Marvel Comics and “Batman” for DC Comics. He recently discussed the steps he took to bring the seedy world of debt collection into full color.

headline: For a Raw Voice, the Balm of Serendipity
abstract: When he was 13, the first record Benjamin Booker ever bought was “Elephant” by the White Stripes. The singer-guitarist, now 25, is the opening act on Jack White’s current tour.
lead_paragraph: The first record Benjamin Booker ever bought was “Elephant” by the White Stripes, which came out when he was in eighth grade. “When I was 13 it was, like, the coolest,” he recalled. Now 25, Mr. Booker, the singer-guitarist, was recently plucked to be the opening act on Jack White’s current tour, though he had only written 12 songs in his entire life. It’s just part of the dizzying whirlwind that’s enveloped Mr. Booker this summer — from TV appearances with David Letterman and Conan O’Brien to being named one of the “most refreshing” rock acts at Lollapalooza by Rolling Stone — ahead of the release of his self-titled debut album, due out Tuesday on ATO Records.

headline: Educators in Their Virtuoso Years
abstract: Doremi issues a three-CD set of live Leonard Shure performances, while Albany Records has a six-disc collection of Howard Karp in concert.
lead_paragraph: Playing the piano beautifully is a demanding artistic endeavor. But to have a career as a touring pianist takes an extra measure of mental, emotional and physical stamina. The great Arthur Rubinstein was the model of an artist who thrived on the concert stage. He simply loved playing for people and did it splendidly right through his 80s. Not so Vladimir Horowitz, an astounding pianist who gave many phenomenal performances but was a nervous type who agonized about playing concerts, even in the early years, when he was the most dazzlingly brilliant young virtuoso of the day.

lead_paragraph: “Should we eat this next?” asked my dining companion as he gestured toward the wildflower bouquet on our table at Blue Hill at Stone Barns. It wasn’t a surreal question. We had already had a serving of “weeds” that ranged from pleasantly bitter to intensely sweet, a drink made with nasturtium, a pot of pea shoots brought to the table with scissors and instructions to cut the greens and drag them through an accompanying tarragon pesto.

headline: Rummaging in the Marquee Dustbin
abstract: The tradition of renaming movies is alive and well, as four summer releases attest.
lead_paragraph: “Not Tonight, Josephine.” “It Had to Be Jew.” “Everybody Comes to Rick’s.” All three count among the most notable American films of all time. Don’t sound familiar? That’s because in the end their titles became “Some Like It Hot,""Annie Hall” and “Casablanca,” respectively. Changing a film title, be it at the behest of a studio chief or because of audience feedback at screenings, is an enduring Hollywood tradition that came to the fore this summer, when these releases shed their original names:

headline: Resisting Nazis, He Saw Need for Israel. Now He Is Its Critic.
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Palestinians', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Civilian Casualties']

lead_paragraph: THE HAGUE — In 1943, Henk Zanoli took a dangerous train trip, slipping past Nazi guards and checkpoints to smuggle a Jewish boy from Amsterdam to the Dutch village of Eemnes. There, the Zanoli family, already under suspicion for resisting the Nazi occupation, hid the boy in their home for two years. The boy would be the only member of his family to survive the Holocaust.

headline: Time to Focus on a Jazz Stalwart
abstract: The pianist George Cables, a first-call jazz sideman in the ’70s and ’80s, will lead the bassist Essiet Okon Essiet and the drummer Victor Lewis at the Village Vanguard.
lead_paragraph: Being great within a tradition for a long time can lead to being overlooked, and the jazz pianist George Cables has some experience with that. Mr. Cables, Brooklyn-born, now 69, was a first-call jazz sideman in the ’70s and ’80s, with groups led by Art Blakey, Woody Shaw, Joe Henderson and Art Pepper, among others; he’s long been a presence, though not often a high-visibility one. This year he made a deeply beautiful record as a leader, “Icons and Influences” (HighNote), which recognizes some old masters and some old friends, including Mulgrew Miller and Cedar Walton, who both died last year. But it also makes a case for Mr. Cables himself as a significant leader and arranger of the jazz trio. Time to focus on him. He made a memorable live record at the Village Vanguard as Pepper’s pianist in 1977; from Tuesday to Sunday he’ll work at that club as a leader, with the bassist Essiet Okon Essiet and the drummer Victor Lewis. (178 Seventh Avenue South, West Village; villagevanguard.com.)

It’s “Rachael vs. Guy: Kids Cook-Off,” and it looks, sounds and presumably smells and tastes a lot like many other kitchen competition shows, but the contestants are all 12 or younger.

abstract: Great Muscadet can be a complex treat, offering an almost tactile expression of the earth in which the grapes were grown.
lead_paragraph: GORGES, France — The gently rolling green hills paint a picture of pastoral simplicity here in Muscadet country, about 15 miles southeast of the city of Nantes, near to where the Loire empties into the Atlantic. The placid surface belies the complex clash of soils underneath, where multiple forms of granite, clay, schist and metamorphic descendants of granite (like gneiss and orthogneiss) turn most discussions with grape growers into detailed geology lessons.

headline: Generation Nice
keywords: ['Age, Chronological', 'Youth', 'Careers and Professions', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: The millennials are emerging as a dominant demographic force. What does that mean for the rest of us?
lead_paragraph: Suddenly, as you may have noticed, millennials are everywhere. Not that this group of people born after 1980 and before 2000 — a giant cohort now estimated to number at least 80 million Americans, more than the baby boom generation — was ever invisible. What’s changed is their status. Coddled and helicoptered, catered to by 24-hour TV cable networks, fussed over by marketers and college recruiters, dissected by psychologists, demographers and trend-spotters, the millennial generation has come fully into its own. The word “millennial,” whether as noun or adjective, has monopolized the nonstop cultural conversation, invariably freighted with zeitgeisty import.

headline: There’s No Off in This Season
keywords: ['Athletics and Sports', 'Children and Childhood', 'Education (K-12)', 'Parenting', 'Families and Family Life', 'Exercise']
abstract: For American children, team sports have become an untamed behemoth, gradually colonizing weeknights, weekends, religious holidays and now vacations.
lead_paragraph: When my daughters were young, they had a book we all loved called “Jump into January.” Every month was illustrated with a search-and-find painting filled with seasonal items. August’s was “Sail into August / come along with me / That sand is soft, the sea is warm / What can you see?” Items included a sailboat, shovel, crab, hammock, surfboard and sand castle.

headline: Embracing Fantasy to Live the Dream
abstract: Porter Robinson, a 22-year-old D.J. from Chapel Hill, N.C., is reaching past electronic dance music in his first full-length album.
lead_paragraph: In 2010 an 18-year-old unknown named Porter Robinson began turning heads on the electronic dance scene for his spastic, high-octane production. Now Mr. Robinson is a star of electronic dance music, or E.D.M., but the sounds that appear on his first full-length album, “Worlds” (Astralwerks), released on Tuesday, would no doubt be puzzling to many of his fist-pumping boosters. After several years of performing at bacchanalian festivals like Ultra and Electric Daisy Carnival, Mr. Robinson has rejected that mind-set and the head rush of adrenaline that currently dominates the scene. On “Worlds,” he has opted instead for washes of gorgeous textures, contemplative storytelling and remarkably sharp melodies.

headline: Taking City Moves From the Street to the Lawn
abstract: Wave Hill was the al fresco setting for contemporary dance in a performance of “Dancing Through the Bronx” on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: James Colter, who long ago earned the sobriquet Cricket, is an amazing dancer. A master of several styles of hip-hop, he is supple and explosive. But when he appeared on Wednesday evening at Wave Hill, the public garden in the Bronx, sparks flew, yet nothing caught fire. That was true not only of his segment, but also of the contributions by Ni’Ja Whitson Adebanjo and Larry Keigwin, all part of “Dancing Through the Bronx,” a series of site-specific performances presented by Dancing in the Streets.

lead_paragraph: The main purpose of DanceMotion USA, a cultural diplomacy program run by the Brooklyn Academy of Music for the State Department, is to send American troupes abroad. These visits have proven illuminating, even if the arranged artistic alliances haven’t always gelled.

headline: Supervalu Discloses a Data Breach

headline: A Contrast of Kings: Ubiquitous and Rare
abstract: The Stratford Festival presents an opportunity to relate the themes of Shakespeare’s seldom-staged history play “King John” to those of “King Lear.”
lead_paragraph: STRATFORD, Ontario — “King Lear” and “King John” reside at opposite ends of the Shakespeare canon. One is at the pinnacle, considered by many his greatest masterwork and produced about as frequently as any of his plays. The other scuttles around furtively somewhere far beneath, poking its oddly shaped head up for public consideration only rarely. (I probably don’t need to tell you which is which.)

headline: Meredith Monk: Tune Body and Voice. Feed the Tortoise.
abstract: On Sundays, Ms. Monk, the composer, singer, director and choreographer, spends some time rehearsing, but also makes time for family and her box tortoise.
lead_paragraph: Meredith Monk, the composer, singer, director, choreographer, Buddhist practitioner and inveterate boundary pusher, will celebrate the 50th anniversary of her career this fall with performances at the Brooklyn Academy of Music and Carnegie Hall. A taste of what’s to come is offered on Aug. 23 at Guild Hall in East Hampton, Long Island, where she will perform with her Grammy-nominated Vocal Ensemble. When Ms. Monk, 71, moved into her West Broadway loft 42 years ago, visitors had to call from a pay phone, after which she would toss down a sock with a key in it. These days she has a buzzer and an elevator.

headline: Revisiting the Nightmares of World War I

The only thing missing in this gallery, devoted to the Battle of the Somme at the Imperial War Museum here, is the ability to conceive of 20,000 British dead and 37,000 wounded or missing in the first day of fighting, and more than a million casualties over all during five months.

headline: Failure, Writing’s Constant Companion

O.K., minute-to-minute. Measured against your ideal of yourself.

President Jefferson Davis, who thought they were unethical and cowardly weapons, was opposed to using them in almost every context. But many of his advisers felt otherwise, and as the Confederate war effort grew more dire in 1864, their calls became louder.

headline: A Painfully Slow Ebola Response
abstract: With the outbreak in West Africa appearing more out of control than ever, help is finally arriving to assist the local governments in fighting the epidemic.
lead_paragraph: The outbreak of the Ebola virus in West Africa appears more out of control than ever. By Friday, the virus had infected more than 2,000 people in four countries and had killed more than half of them. The World Health Organization, which snoozed on the sidelines for months after the outbreak was first identified in March, has issued increasingly frantic warnings in recent days. On Aug. 8, it declared the spread of the virus “a public health emergency of international concern.” On Thursday, it warned that the reported numbers of people killed or sickened by the virus may “vastly underestimate the magnitude of the outbreak” because many sick people escape detection. The next day, it said that patients flooding into newly opened treatment centers were filling beds faster than they could be provided.

headline: With Ebola Cases Still Few, Populous Nigeria Has Chance to Halt Its Outbreak
abstract: Health officials are watching Lagos, the metropolis where all of Nigeria’s Ebola cases have been reported, with intense interest.
lead_paragraph: Health workers have fought the Ebola outbreak to a tentative standstill in Nigeria, Africa’s most populous nation, offering at least a chance to eradicate the disease there before it spins out of control, as it has in Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone, where a sluggish response failed to halt it early.

headline: Tanaka May Return, but Perhaps Not to a Playoff Race
abstract: Masahiro Tanaka is scheduled to throw in the bullpen, but it may be too late to make a difference for the Yankees, whose postseason prospects grew worse with a fifth straight loss.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Masahiro Tanaka continues to make progress in his rehabilitation from a torn ligament in his right elbow, but even if he can return in September, it may be too late for him to make a difference in the Yankees’ pursuit of a postseason berth.

headline: Agencies Issue Warnings Over Bogus Ebola Cures
abstract: The World Health Organization and the Food and Drug Administration warn some makers of dietary supplements to stop claiming their products will heal Ebola victims.
lead_paragraph: Panic over Ebola has the makers of dietary supplements aggressively targeting Africans, claiming to have a cure for the lethal virus.

headline: Hospitals in the U.S. Get Ready for Ebola
abstract: Some doctors say outfits worn by caregivers need to be more protective than what the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends.
lead_paragraph: Hospitals nationwide are hustling to prepare for the first traveler from West Africa who arrives in the emergency room with symptoms of infection with the Ebola virus.

headline: The Cormorants of East Sand Island
abstract: Scientists studying the cormorant colony in Oregon are looking for the best way to remove most of the birds.
lead_paragraph: Scientists studying the cormorant colony in Oregon are looking for the best way to remove most of the birds.

abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, August 16, 2014.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) 2 GUNS (2013) A couple of bad guys (Denzel Washington and Mark Wahlberg) find themselves on the lam after failing to infiltrate a Mexican drug cartel — only to discover that each is an undercover agent — in what Manohla Dargis, writing in The New York Times, called a “slick, slippery thriller” from the director Baltasar Kormakur. Edward James Olmos plays a drug lord with $3 million for the taking, Paula Patton is a Drug Enforcement Administration operative, Bill Paxton is a Central Intelligence agency whack job, and James Marsden and Fred Ward do business for the Navy. “Working with an editor, Michael Tronick, who doesn’t step on the sometimes wittily choreographed action by overcutting, Mr. Kormakur sets and keeps up a fast rather than frantic pace that never runs the movie off the rails even when the story nearly does,” Ms. Dargis wrote. “Much as he did in his last movie, ‘Contraband,’ another thriller with Mr. Wahlberg, Mr. Kormakur has put his imprimatur on a pulp fiction that easily could have become another generic diversion instead of a fine genre one.”

headline: Modern Technologies and the Ebola Fight
abstract: How some modern technologies — from airport screening to cellphones — may help in the fight to contain the Ebola virus.
lead_paragraph: How some modern technologies — from airport screening to cellphones — may help in the fight to contain the Ebola virus.

headline: Midnight Curfew in Effect for Ferguson
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Curfews', 'Police']
abstract: Gov. Jay Nixon ordered the curfew as protests continued over the police shooting of an unarmed black teenager, Michael Brown, and after incidents of looting Friday night.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — Gov. Jay Nixon of Missouri on Saturday imposed a midnight to 5 a.m. curfew in this small city, declaring a state of emergency as violence flared anew after a week of street protests over the killing of an unarmed black teenager by a white police officer.

headline: Papal Visit That Thrills Catholics Is Unsettling to Protestants in South Korea
abstract: Hundreds of thousands cheered the pope in downtown Seoul, but not everyone has welcomed him to a country where the church has vied for followers with Protestant groups.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — In a symbolic moment for the Vatican and South Korea’s 5.1 million Catholics, hundreds of thousands of people cheered as Pope Francis rode through central Seoul on Saturday to lead a Mass to beatify 124 martyrs directly in front of the palace of the old Korean dynasty that killed them more than a century ago.

headline: Senator Brian Schatz Wins Closely Fought Democratic Primary in Hawaii
keywords: ['Primaries and Caucuses', 'Elections, Senate', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Mr. Schatz defeated Representative Colleen Hanabusa by fewer than 1,800 votes on Friday, bringing their long, acrimonious contest to an apparent end.
lead_paragraph: PUNA, Hawaii — After nearly two years of campaigning, millions of dollars spent and one tropical storm that delayed voting in this easternmost corner of Hawaii for nearly a week, Senator Brian Schatz won the Democratic nomination for his seat on Friday, bringing one of the longest and most acrimonious primary contests in the state’s history to an apparent end.

headline: Analytics: How Readers Reacted to Our Cover Story on Autism
abstract: Ruth Padawer’s cover story about children who shed their autism symptoms received more than 450 responses online. Here’s what they said.
lead_paragraph: The following pie chart appears on the Reply All page in the Aug. 17 issue of the magazine.

abstract: A reader responds to “Oversize Expectations” (Aug. 10) a look at the Airbus double-decker A380.
lead_paragraph: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: LiketoKnowit Lets You Shop Looks on Instagram
abstract: LiketoKnowit plugs into Instagram and gives people a way to browse the items that they view in their Instagram feeds and may want to buy.
lead_paragraph: I’ve long reported on the many ways that Instagram is quickly becoming a shopper’s delight, like the boutiques and entrepreneurs that use the mobile application to tempt buyers with luscious photos of their colorful goods.

headline: A Menagerie of Ideas, Unlocked in Odd Jobs
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Writing and Writers', 'Careers and Professions']
abstract: Yes, work can be confining — even stifling. But within a creative mind, it can spin into endless possibilities.
lead_paragraph: From the ages of 18 to 36 — when I began to teach creative writing — I worked variously as a house cleaner, house painter, landscaper, masseuse, editor and secretary. I worked as a tree planter in Zambia for a half-year when I was 19, then as a produce worker at a co-op grocery store in San Francisco, where I grew up. My first salaried job was going door to door, raising money for Salvadoran refugees fleeing civil conflict and death squads.

headline: Hesitating on the High Board of Investing
abstract: Should you tiptoe into stocks, or take the plunge? So long as you’ve diversified, a big splash is often the best bet.
lead_paragraph: You have arrived at a pool for a swim: Do you plunge right in or just dip in a toe until you’re comfortable?

headline: Narinder Singh of Topcoder: Is It the Cards, or How You Play Them?
abstract: An executive says that if you’ve played your cards badly, “you need to think about how to make sure that doesn’t happen again.”
lead_paragraph: This interview with  Narinder Singh, president of Topcoder, which administers computer-programming competitions, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: The Mystery of Lofty Stock Market Elevations
abstract: By one gauge, stock prices have been lofty for years. But that doesn’t mean they’ll stay there.
lead_paragraph: The United States stock market looks very expensive right now. The CAPE ratio, a stock-price measure I helped develop — is hovering at a worrisome level.

headline: Your 401(k) Is Healthy. So Maybe You Are, Too.

lead_paragraph: Before you suggest that friends or family members start to exercise or improve their diets, you might first want to ask a question: Are they saving for retirement?

headline: Aug. 16: Scenes on Twitter From Ferguson, Mo., Overnight
abstract: Scenes from the streets of Ferguson, Mo., where peaceful protests turned violent overnight.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague, Alan Blinder reports from Ferguson, Mo., protesters looted stores and clashed with the police overnight amid renewed tension over the fatal shooting of Michael Brown by a police officer a week ago.

headline: 3 Liberian Health Workers With Ebola Receive Scarce Drug After Appeals to U.S.
abstract: Liberian officials requested the ZMapp serum for three health workers after it was provided to two Americans who contracted Ebola while working at a hospital near Monrovia.
lead_paragraph: Three Liberian health care workers who have contracted Ebola received an extremely scarce experimental serum on Friday at a hospital outside the national capital, Monrovia, a Liberian health official said Saturday.

headline: In a Bank Settlement, Don’t Forget the Bulldozers
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Abandonment (Property)', 'Demolition', 'Mortgages', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Foreclosures']
abstract: If it provides hard cash for demolishing abandoned homes, an impending settlement by Bank of America could help many forgotten victims of the mortgage crisis.
lead_paragraph: A win-win. That’s how people on both sides of the negotiating table will undoubtedly characterize the long-awaited, $16 billion-plus mortgage settlement that Bank of America is expected to reach with the Justice Department this week. For federal and state governments, the deal will mean billions in cash and borrower assistance. For the bank, the agreement will help it get past its mortgage woes, many emanating from its 2008 purchase of Countrywide Financial, a truly toxic lender.

headline: Authenticity, Repurposed, in a Mason Jar
keywords: ['Glassware', 'Containers and Packaging', 'Canning and Preserving', 'Food', 'Cooking and Cookbooks']
abstract: The simple and sturdy Mason jar, a 19th-century staple, has been embraced by companies trying to reach a new generation of consumers.
lead_paragraph: Maybe you’ve sipped a beer from a Mason jar. Or fished out a pickle swimming in brine from one. Or dined under illuminated clusters of them, dangling in chandelier formation, at a restaurant — especially if you dined in Brooklyn.

headline: Everyone Gets a Share, of Everything
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Mobile Applications', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: The success of operations like Airbnb in room rentals has spawned businesses related to recreation, dining and transportation.
lead_paragraph: The sharing economy — or the prospect of what’s mine is yours, for a price — has hit nearly every sector of the travel market. The success of operations like Airbnb in room rentals has spawned businesses related to recreation, dining and transportation.

lead_paragraph: Ask Real Estate is a weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: Steps and the City (Fairly Trivial)
abstract: Sprawl, behavior, and the failure of neoclassical economics.
lead_paragraph: Emily Badger tells us that sprawl is bad for your health; so are movie theater concession counters, reports Sarah Kliff, which is why Tom Harkin and Rosa DeLauro want to include popcorn under the rules requiring calorie disclosure. (At the risk of sounding whiny, they aren’t exactly “coming after” your popcorn; you’d be free to buy it, it’s just that the cinema would have to tell you how many calories you’re about to consume.)

headline: Tug of War Between Republicans Seeking Same Base Support
abstract: Gov. Rick Perry and Senator Ted Cruz spoke at the RedState Gathering in Fort Worth this month and both received enthusiastic support from attendees, highlighting a growing tension in Texas politics.
lead_paragraph: FORT WORTH — One week before a grand jury in liberal Travis County indicted Gov. Rick Perry on two felony counts, he and United States Sen. Ted Cruz were in friendlier territory, speaking at a conference hosted by a conservative blog here in the largest reliably Republican community in Texas.

headline: Acclimating to Stardom and a New Coach
abstract: The Warriors’ Stephen Curry heads into the season with high hopes after last season’s 51 victories.
lead_paragraph: After being underrecruited in high school, undervalued in college and underappreciated in the N.B.A., Golden State Warriors guard Stephen Curry is getting used to being a star. In June, he earned a place on the all-N.B.A. second team, and he has spent this summer training to represent the United States in the FIBA World Cup, which begins Aug. 30.

headline: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
abstract: Come groan and get mixed up with Mel Taub’s Puns and Anagrams.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — Puns and Anagrams, or PandAs as they are affectionately called by some, are the reward we get for a sturdy week of straight crossword puzzle-solving. Yes, it’s still basically a crossword puzzle, but when was the last time you guffawed or slapped your forehead and groaned out loud while doing a Saturday crossword puzzle? PandAs are silly, and they’re a nice relief after the tough, late-week puzzles. At least I think so.

headline: As (Very) Fast Friends, Two Young Americans Balance at Sport’s Peak
abstract: Missy Franklin and Katie Ledecky will lead the United States women’s team at the Pan Pacific Swimming Championships this week.
lead_paragraph: IRVINE, Calif. — They are USA Swimming’s dynamic duo, but there is one competition that neither Missy Franklin nor Katie Ledecky can win: the popularity contest to anoint a single chlorine queen. It is a losing proposition for both Franklin, a six-time gold medalist at last summer’s world championships, and Ledecky, who will go into this week’s Pan Pacific Swimming Championships poised to win as many as five gold medals.

headline: In the Sharing Economy, Workers Find Both Freedom and Uncertainty
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Mobile Applications', 'United States Economy', 'Working Hours']
abstract: Workers are their own bosses in the so-called sharing economy, but that flexibility also brings much uncertainty — and few of the protections of full-time work.
lead_paragraph: Just after 4 a.m. on a recent Friday, while most of the neighbors in her leafy Boston suburb were still asleep, Jennifer Guidry was in the driveway of her rental apartment, her blond hair pulled back in a tidy French braid, vacuuming the inside of her car. The early-bird routine is a strategy that Ms. Guidry, a Navy veteran and former accountant, uses to mitigate the uncertainty of working in what’s known as the sharing economy.

headline: In China’s Shadow, U.S. Courts Old Foe Vietnam
abstract: Increasingly at loggerheads with China, the United States now envisions Vietnam as a new partner that will acquire American weapons and help offset China’s power.
lead_paragraph: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam — The chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Martin E. Dempsey, courted Vietnam over the past several days. He was the first chairman in more than 40 years to visit the old enemy of Washington, now envisioned as a new partner that will acquire American weapons and help offset the power of China.

headline: Brokers of the Sharing Economy
abstract: A few popular or up-and-coming service platforms in the sharing economy.
lead_paragraph: Start-up companies in what is known as the sharing economy are gaining traction with consumers, freelance workers and investors alike. The companies are able to offer competitive prices to consumers in part by acting as labor brokers, rather than as employers who offer costly employee benefits.

headline: Plotting Lassie’s Future
abstract: In 2012, DreamWorks Animation acquired the rights to Lassie. The studio is slowly reintroducing the character, once a big Hollywood star, through public media appearances.
lead_paragraph: In 2012, DreamWorks Animation acquired the rights to Lassie. The studio is slowly reintroducing the character, once a big Hollywood star, through public media appearances.

headline: Floods and Landslides Kill Dozens and Leave Scores Missing in Nepal
abstract: More than 50 people died and scores are missing after three days of continuous monsoon rains contributed to floods and landslides near the Indian border.
lead_paragraph: KATMANDU, Nepal — More than 50 people died and scores are missing after three days of continuous monsoon rains set off multiple floods and landslides in Nepal’s low-lying plain near the Indian border, officials said Saturday.

headline: Lassie as Salesdog: One More Trip to the Well
abstract: Lassie’s new owners at DreamWorks Animation are using a series of publicity stunts to remake the classic American dog as a merchandising superstar.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Maybe it was the three publicists in tow. Maybe her hairdo was wilting under the hot television lights. Maybe a dog, even a showbiz one, was just not meant to be a meteorologist.

headline: In Push to Shorten Games, There’s No Time to Waste
abstract: One of the main problems facing Major League Baseball and its next commissioner, Rob Manfred, is that attention spans are getting shorter while games are getting longer.
lead_paragraph: The fundamental problem facing Major League Baseball and its next commissioner, Rob Manfred, is that attention spans are getting shorter while games are getting longer. Confronting these clashing realities may be Manfred’s top priority when he takes office in January. It will be the first transition at the top of baseball’s hierarchy since Bud Selig replaced Fay Vincent in 1992.

headline: Plight of Iraqi Minorities Worsens With Forced Conversions and Killings
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Yazidi (Religious Sect)', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Scores of people are thought to have been killed by extremist gunmen in one village in northern Iraq after refusing to convert to Islam, an incident likely to heighten international concern about the plight of Iraq’s Yazidi minority.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The gunmen had surrounded the village for more than a week, refusing to let residents leave and saying they had limited time to save themselves by converting to Islam.

headline: Deep Tensions Rise to Surface After Ferguson Shooting
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Racial Profiling', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: The origins of Ferguson’s complex racial history run deep, and the residents of the largely black city with a white power structure say that most tensions have to do with an overzealous police force.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — Garland Moore, a hospital worker, lived in this St. Louis suburb for much of his 33 years, a period in which a largely white community has become a largely black one.

headline: Smashing a Ceiling and a Lot of Egos
abstract: Michele A. Roberts, the new leader of the N.B.A. players union, said her past was “littered with the bones of men” who underestimated her.
lead_paragraph: Last month, inside a grand ballroom at the Aria Resort & Casino in Las Vegas, Michele A. Roberts stood before 117 N.B.A. players — towering international celebrities with millions in their bank accounts — and declared that she should be their leader.

headline: Best Shortstop on the Cubs? Scan the Field
abstract: Amid the Cubs’ surplus of shortstops, Javier Baez has shown flexibility in a variety of spots on the field. Other young Chicago shortstops have switched positions, too.
lead_paragraph: Just before the start of Javier Baez’s senior season at Arlington Country Day School in Jacksonville, Fla., the baseball team’s starting shortstop sustained a season-ending injury that prompted a major shift of the defensive alignment. The maneuvering ended with Baez, the team’s catcher, moving to shortstop.

headline: Amid Debate Over Who Overstepped, Perry Calls Indictment a ‘Farce’
abstract: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas called the indictment charging him with trying to pressure a Democratic prosecutor to step down a “political” prosecution and pledged to stay in office until the end of his term in January.
lead_paragraph: A defiant Gov. Rick Perry on Saturday vowed to fight his indictment on charges of abuse of power, calling it a “farce” and a “political” prosecution.

headline: No Longer an Impact Player, a Giant Finds a Way to Deliver a Kaboom
abstract: Israel Idonije is hoping to spend his 12th N.F.L. season as a defensive lineman with the Giants, but he also has a promising career as the creator of a comic book series.
lead_paragraph: The 12th season of Israel Idonije’s N.F.L. career finds him in New York, and this protagonist is worn down, fighting his body’s aches and scrambling to catch on at the end of the roster for the Giants, his third team in three years.

headline: Licia Albanese, Exalted Soprano, Is Dead at 105
abstract: One of the most admired operatic sopranos of the mid-20th century, she was revered for a soaring top range and a passionate intensity on the stage.
lead_paragraph: Licia Albanese, an Italian-born soprano whose veneration by audiences worldwide was copious even by the standards of operatic adulation, died on Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 105.

headline: Is Summer Different Now?
abstract: Do children have more responsibility and less freedom than in the past?
lead_paragraph: WE like to remember a child’s summer as a season of no responsibility, unfettered by parental supervision, a time to indulge and explore. And we like to complain that summer has changed; that children have more responsibility, less freedom, fewer indulgences.

headline: Couple Sexually Abused Amish Sisters, Officials Say
abstract: Stephen Howells II and Nicole Vaisey, who have been charged in the kidnapping, had a motive to “inflict physical injury,” according to a criminal complaint.
lead_paragraph: The two young Amish sisters who were kidnapped from their farm in upstate New York last week were sexually assaulted, the authorities said on Saturday.

lead_paragraph: Readers write eloquently about “America’s cathedral” and argue against its “desecration.”
