abstract: Why do the president and the attorney general praise the First Amendment while they push to imprison truth?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — JIM RISEN is gruff.

headline: China Confronts Its Coal Problem
abstract: If done right, Beijing’s strategy could have a meaningful effect on local air quality and the planet as a whole.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese government has indicated a strong desire — and made some specific proposals — to reduce its reliance on coal, a step that would be a welcome development for the Chinese people and the planet as a whole. But there is a lot we don’t know yet about Beijing’s strategy and whether it will be bold enough to have a meaningful effect on local air quality and climate change.

headline: Strutting Back With a Vengeance
abstract: The comeback of the wild turkey appears to be complete.
lead_paragraph: Whatever happened to Giuliani? No, not the ex-mayor with the comb-over. Giuliani the urbane wild turkey, the bold bird that drew raves from shocked city dwellers when she arrived at Manhattan’s Riverside Park 11 years ago to strut imperiously, residing in plain sight, deigning to tolerate handouts and a nickname. Giuliani was studied like an extraterrestrial by crowds more mindful of wild turkey as a libation — not the dominant roaming bird of colonial days that was nearly driven to extinction as settlers fed off the flocks and urban landscapes exploded.

headline: Sister Acts
abstract: Instead of investigating and mocking nuns, we’d be better off if we spent more time emulating them.
lead_paragraph: IN an age of villainy, war and inequality, it makes sense that we need superheroes. And after trying Superman, Batman and Spider-Man, we may have found the best superheroes yet: Nuns.

headline: Fixing Immigration in the Field
abstract: The policies in Washington, however good they may be, are useless if they are not enacted where it counts.
lead_paragraph: President Obama is looking to give some unauthorized immigrants a temporary path out of the shadows, a legal way to stay and work. He promised to act by the end of summer if Congress didn’t. Though a debate has raged about the legal and political restraints on Mr. Obama’s executive authority to do this, the real question is how many of the unauthorized population, totaling about 11 million, will be lucky enough to win a temporary reprieve from deportation.

headline: Playing Soldier in the Suburbs
keywords: ['Police', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: How warrior policing found its way to Ferguson, Mo.
lead_paragraph: TO understand what’s been happening in Ferguson, Mo., where protests and violence following a cop’s shooting of an unarmed teenager summoned up a police response that looked more like a military invasion, it helps to flash back to the heyday of the Symbionese Liberation Army.

headline: A Battleground and Bellwether
abstract: With several tight, emblematic races, Colorado is a major 2014 player.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — GIVEN all of the smoky talk about Colorado and marijuana, you arrive here with the feeling that you’re stepping into some freaky, one-of-a-kind laboratory.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Aug. 16
abstract: Gov. Jay Nixon of Missouri will make the rounds on the Sunday network shows to discuss the unrest in Ferguson after the shooting of an unarmed black teenager.
lead_paragraph: For a week, protesters filled the streets of Ferguson, Mo., a suburb of St. Louis, where an unarmed black teenager, Michael Brown, was shot and killed by a police officer. After several days of unrest and reports of excessive force by the police, Gov. Jay Nixon on Thursday had the state highway patrol take over security operations from the city police.

headline: With Aid Doctors Gone, Ebola Fight Grows Harder
abstract: The departure of many Western development workers from the West African countries hit hardest by Ebola has further weakened the region’s decrepit, understaffed health systems.
lead_paragraph: When people started dying of Ebola in Liberia, Clarine Vaughn faced a wrenching choice: Should she send home, for their own health and safety, four American doctors working for Heartt, the aid group she led there? Or should she keep them in the country without proper supplies or training to fight the virulent, contagious disease, which was already spreading panic?

headline: Medicare to Start Paying Doctors Who Coordinate Needs of Chronically Ill Patients
abstract: Starting in January, Medicare will pay monthly fees to doctors who manage care for patients with two or more chronic conditions like heart disease, diabetes and depression.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a policy change, the Obama administration is planning to pay doctors to coordinate the care of Medicare beneficiaries, amid growing evidence that patients with chronic illnesses suffer from disjointed, fragmented care.

headline: On a Helicopter, Going Down: Inside a Lethal Crash in Iraq
abstract: Alissa J. Rubin, a veteran Times foreign correspondent, was injured Tuesday in a helicopter crash in Kurdistan and dictated this article from her hospital bed in Istanbul.
lead_paragraph: Alissa J. Rubin, a veteran Times foreign correspondent, was injured on Tuesday in a helicopter crash in Kurdistan and dictated the following article from her hospital bed in Istanbul, where she was evacuated from Iraq. She suffered broken bones and a fractured skull but was in stable condition, and was scheduled to be taken by air to the United States on Sunday.

headline: The Disappearing Volunteer Firefighter
keywords: ['Fires and Firefighters', 'Volunteers and Community Service', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The allure of the life fades as fund-raising and medical calls intrude on the primary duty: Putting water on fire.
lead_paragraph: IN most places in America, when a fire breaks out, a volunteer shows up to put it out.

headline: Teaching Is Not a Business
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Tests and Examinations', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: Reformers misunderstand how central human relationships are to the educational process.
lead_paragraph: TODAY’S education reformers believe that schools are broken and that business can supply the remedy. Some place their faith in the idea of competition. Others embrace disruptive innovation, mainly through online learning. Both camps share the belief that the solution resides in the impersonal, whether it’s the invisible hand of the market or the transformative power of technology.

headline: Leonard Fein, Provocative Writer on Jewish Affairs, Dies at 80
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Mr. Fein wrote voluminously about contemporary Jews, Judaism and “the often stormy relationship between Jews and Judaism,” and founded groups to combat hunger and illiteracy.
lead_paragraph: Leonard Fein, an intellectual and activist who wrote voluminously about contemporary Jews, Judaism and, in his words, “the often stormy relationship between Jews and Judaism,” and who founded a magazine and organizations to combat hunger and illiteracy, died late Wednesday or early Thursday in Manhattan. He was 80.

headline: Nadya Tolokonnikova
abstract: A member of the band Pussy Riot on her taste for Doris Day, Rachmaninoff and “House of Cards.”
lead_paragraph: Nadya Tolokonnikova is a member of the Russian punk rock protest band Pussy Riot. She served a 21-month jail sentence on a charge of “hooliganism” following a 2012 performance that criticized President Vladimir V. Putin.

headline: An SEC Partisan on Rooting for Greatness
abstract: Paul Finebaum discusses his book “My Conference Can Beat Your Conference” and what lies ahead for the Southeastern Conference.
lead_paragraph: Originally a newspaper reporter, Paul Finebaum found himself on the business end of a microphone 30 years ago when he began hosting a Birmingham, Ala.-based sports radio show called “Fussin’ With Finebaum.”

headline: More Latinos on Farms Move From Fields to Office
abstract: American farm ownership is still dominated by whites, but a growing number of farms are owned and operated by Latinos, many of whom worked their way up from the fields.
lead_paragraph: WATSONVILLE, Calif. — When he was 15, an immigration raid at a Japanese flower nursery turned Arturo Flores’s life around.

headline: A Choice Between Boredom and Blood
keywords: ['Malaysia Airlines Flight 17', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: How repressive Russian regimes keep their people in line.

lead_paragraph: LA PAZ and EL ALTO, Bolivia — In these two cities, geography and rank stand in inverse relation. La Paz — the seat of government, old money and a lighter-skinned elite — sits in a valley. Above it on a high plateau is the frenetic city of El Alto: poorer, younger and generally darker-skinned. La Paz has always looked down on its upstart younger sibling above.

headline: The Wisdom of the Exile
abstract: Uprooting, if we survive it, can be a philosophical gift.
lead_paragraph: At one point in its history, the tango was popular in the world of Buenos Aires’s brothels. Toward the end of the 19th century, young immigrants — single, male, working class — who had come to Argentina to try their luck would seek comfort in the drink, entertainment and female companionship there. Argentines as distinguished as Jorge Luis Borges have insisted that the tango was born in these brothels. Others vehemently deny it. But the fact remains that the tango has preserved something of the anguish of the young and uprooted who danced it there.

lead_paragraph: President Obama owes Mikey Dickerson two debts of gratitude. Mr. Dickerson was a crucial member of the team that, in just six weeks, fixed the HealthCare.gov website when the two-year, $400 million health insurance project failed almost as soon as it opened to the public in October.

headline: 1914: British Committee Helps Visitors in Paris
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: In Paris in 1914, a British committee provides assistance to visitors arriving at the main train stations.
lead_paragraph: Thanks to the organization of the Information Committee of the British colony, several parties of British travellers arriving in Paris at the principal terminal stations were given valuable advice and help yesterday. In one case a party of thirteen Canadians was aided, and in many cases boarding-houses were recommended. Some English dancing girls who, owing to the present circumstances, had found themselves without help or employment, were looked after. The British Committee in Lucerne has been communicated with by telegraph and the services of the British Colony Committee, Paris, placed at its disposal as regards help to be extended to British visitors or residents arriving in Paris from that district. — The New York Herald, European Edition, August 18, 1914

headline: In the Bronx, an Unlikely Sanctuary for Birds, and People
abstract: A lot once thick with garbage and weeds has become the Dred Scott Bird Sanctuary, an oasis of green space in the neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: Troy Lancaster lives in exile. In the Bronx. His relatives won’t visit him, he says, because like a lot of folks with roots in the South, they are not keen on concrete, noise and narrow streets. He felt the same way in the 1980s when he moved to a stretch of Grant Avenue that had been reduced to an open-air drug market along a weed-choked street.

headline: 1939: Tate Gallery Refuses Portrait by John Singer Sargent
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: In 1939, the Tate Gallery in London refuses a portrait of the Duke of Windsor as the Prince of Wales.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Art circles in London sought to discover today [Aug. 16] whether political motives lay behind the Tate Gallery’s refusal to accept the late John Singer Sargent’s charcoal portrait of the Duke of Windsor as the Prince of Wales, a bequest to the museum by Sir Philip Sassoon, wealthy art patron and former First Commissioner of Works, who died in June. Although the Gallery trustees turned down the Windsor picture a week ago, they accepted Sassoon’s offer of another Sargent work, a portrait in oil of Sir Philip himself. Dr. John Rothenstein, director and keeper of the Tate Gallery, stoutly maintained today that the trustees’ decision was the result of consideration of the charcoal drawing ‘‘purely on its merits as a work of art.’’ He said it was not considered ‘‘a good example of the artist’s work.’’ ‘‘Any suggestions that there was a prejudice against the personality or that there was an extraneous reason is entirely untrue,’’ he said. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 17, 1939

headline: Drawing the Line Between Soldier and Cop

abstract: The events in Ferguson, Mo., have caused many to question what is seen as the worrisome militarization of our local police departments.
lead_paragraph: “Ferguson, Mo., has become a virtual war zone,” write Elizabeth R. Beavers and Michael Shank in an Op-Ed for The New York Times. “In the wake of the shooting of an unarmed black teenager, Michael Brown, outsize armored vehicles have lined streets and tear gas has filled the air. Officers dressed in camouflage uniforms from Ferguson’s 53-person police force have pointed M-16s at the very citizens they are sworn to protect and serve.”

(Mr. Maazel died in July; Mrs. Maazel has succeeded him as artistic director.)

headline: United by Their Rough Edges

But in 2014, he is merely a galaxy-size cult favorite, a 41-year-old white rapper far from the center of pop culture, leaning heavily on reputation and largely failing to innovate.

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10:05 P.M. (Showtime 2) THE CANYONS (2013) This low-budget, famously trashy film was supposed to herald the return of Lindsay Lohan (above, with James Deen) to respectability, or at least bankability. It didn’t. But it was interesting. Written by the novelist Brett Easton Ellis (“Less Than Zero,” “American Psycho”) and directed by Paul Schrader (who wrote “Taxi Driver” and “Raging Bull” and directed “American Gigolo”), the movie is a dark, half-incoherent story about sex, movies and meaninglessness in Los Angeles. “Every so often,” wrote Manohla Dargis in The New York Times, “Mr. Schrader manages to deliver a jolt, an image, a line reading and even a scene — like a narratively decisive down-and-dirty sexual four-way — that fleetingly lifts ‘The Canyons.’ But his struggle is as palpable as his budgetary limitations.”

headline: Experts Say a Second Work in Munich Was Looted
keywords: ['Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Art', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: A Max Liebermann painting was wrongfully taken by the Nazis from the collection of its Jewish owner, a team of international experts has determined.
lead_paragraph: “Two Riders on the Beach,” above, a Max Liebermann painting found in the private collection of Cornelius Gurlitt, who died in early May, was wrongfully taken by the Nazis from the collection of its Jewish owner, a team of international experts has determined. Using archival material and other sources, the experts ascertained that the Liebermann painting rightfully belonged to the descendants of the industrialist David Friedmann, they said in a statement on Sunday. The work is only the second of 458 disputed paintings, prints and drawings in the collection, known as the Munich Art Trove, that the panel of experts, convened by the German government, has determined was looted. The other, a Matisse, was found in June to have been stolen from the collector Paul Rosenberg. Yet the Matisse has not been returned to Mr. Rosenberg’s heirs, and the Liebermann is sure to face a similar fate, because of the legal limbo surrounding Mr. Gurlitt’s collection following his death. Although Mr. Gurlitt, the son of an art dealer who worked for the Nazis, left his collection to the Kunstmuseum Bern, it has not yet decided whether to accept the gift. An agreement signed between Mr. Gurlitt and German authorities binds the new owner to restitute any looted works, but that cannot happen until the gift is accepted. David Toren, a great-nephew of Mr. Friedmann’s who lives in New York, filed a lawsuit against the German government in hopes of speeding the return of his family’s art work. “This is a very important first step in returning the painting to its rightful owners and we hope that the German government will not further delay returning the painting,” Mr. Toren’s attorney, August J. Matteis Jr., said in a statement.

headline: Emmys Go to Fallon, ‘Orange’ and, Yes, HBO
abstract: HBO assumed its familiar role as the early leader in the Emmys race after taking home 15 Creative Arts awards.
lead_paragraph: HBO assumed its familiar role as the early leader in the Emmys race after taking home 15 Creative Arts awards this weekend, but a few new faces garnered notable wins as well. The Academy of Television Arts & Sciences bestowed the awards in a ceremony in Los Angeles on Saturday in categories like casting, editing, and animation. The ceremony precedes the major Emmys broadcast, which airs Aug. 25 on NBC. “Game of Thrones” and “True Detective” earned four awards apiece for HBO, but the most decorated show of the night was NBC’s “Saturday Night Live,” which won half of that network’s 10 awards. An episode hosted by Jimmy Fallon, below, was responsible for four of the trophies, including a win for Mr. Fallon as guest actor in a comedy series. Other guest acting awards went to Joe Morton in ABC’s “Scandal,” Allison Janney in Showtime’s “Masters of Sex” and Uzo Aduba, who took home one of the first three trophies for Netflix’s series “Orange Is the New Black” for her breakout role as the inmate Suzanne Warren, known as Crazy Eyes. Zach Galifianakis’s “Between Two Ferns” series on the comedy website Funny or Die won best short-format, live-action entertainment program for an episode in which Mr. Galifianakis interviewed President Obama.

headline: Carnegie Hall Executive to Run Symphony Space
abstract: Symphony Space, the miniature arts center on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, is expected to announce on Monday that it has appointed Andrew Byrne as its artistic director.
lead_paragraph: Symphony Space, the miniature arts center on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, is expected to announce on Monday that it has appointed Andrew Byrne as its artistic director. The space has been without a director since January, when the composer Laura Kaminsky left the post in a disagreement over programming. Mr. Byrne takes over on Sept. 15. Mr. Byrne, a 48-year-old Australian who came to New York in 1993 on a Fulbright Scholarship to complete his doctorate in music at Columbia University, has worked at Carnegie Hall for 10 years, eight of them as the director of festivals and special projects. “It’s a different model,” Mr. Byrne said on Friday, obliquely acknowledging that Symphony Space gives him a smaller palette than Carnegie Hall. “But we have performing arts, film and education programs within the house. What attracts me to Symphony Space is the opportunity not only to shape the full season, but also to shape the profile of the institution.”

headline: The Verdict on a Troublesome Carcinogen
abstract: New reports confirm that formaldehyde can cause cancer, but it’s still widely used in consumer products and industrial processes.

A panel of experts convened by the National Academy of Sciences found sufficient evidence from human studies to declare formaldehyde “a known human carcinogen” that causes nasopharyngeal cancer, sinonasal cancer and myeloid leukemia. It also cited evidence from studies of animals and of carcinogenesis suggesting that formaldehyde may cause a much wider array of cancers than just those three.

headline: What’s On TV Today

(Starz Cinema) RUST AND BONE (2012) Ali (Matthias Schoenaerts), a former prizefighter fleeing with his young son (Armand Verdure) from a bad situation, arrives in Antibes on the Côte d’Azur and becomes a bouncer at a nightclub, where he meets Stéphanie (Marion Cotillard, above, with Mr. Schoenaerts), a trainer for a Sea World-like park. Then she loses her legs in an accident with a killer whale and calls Ali, thinking he might rouse her from her despair. “The removal of Ms. Cotillard’s legs — including in scenes in which she wears a bathing suit or nothing — is surely one of the most impressive special-effects feats of the year, and a reminder that digital cinema is not all about accessorizing wizards, monsters and superheroes,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “But the greater marvel is Ms. Cotillard herself, an actress of limitless bravery and supernatural poise, who is both beauty and beast. Mr. Schoenaerts is her perfect foil and complement, as large and coarse as she is small and delicate, and also as tender as she is tough.”

headline: 1914: Lord Kitchener Sends Messages
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Lord Kitchener sends out a message to soldiers in 1914.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The following instructions have been issued by Lord Kitchener to every soldier in the expeditionary army: — “You are ordered abroad as a soldier of the King to help our French comrades against the invasion of a common enemy. You have to perform a task which will need your courage, your energy, your patience. Remember that the honor of the British army depends on your individual conduct. … In this new experience you may find temptation, both in wine and women. You must entirely resist both temptations, and, while treating all women with perfect courtesy, you should avoid intimacy. Do your duty bravely. Fear God; honor the King.” (Signed) KITCHENER. Field Marshal. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Aug. 19, 1914

headline: Getting Groovy With Reactive Android
abstract: Mohit Pandey explains the reactive functional programming we are focusing on for our Android redesign.
lead_paragraph: “Slow,” a word no one ever wants to see associated with their app. Delay and lag of as little as 100–200 milliseconds will be perceived by users as poor, slow performance. Keeping long running tasks on the main thread will result in that perception, the dreaded “Application Not Responding” (ANR) and a bad user experience. This leaves us developers one choice: concurrent execution of code. The recent growth in popularity of functional programming is well deserved. As things become more asynchronous, the functional model really fits well. Being able to sequence, chain and transform asynchronous operations can be considered a must. However, the mechanisms for asynchronous programming provided in Android leave much to be desired, especially when compared to the web development realm. Many of the ideas and techniques from “enterprise” Java frameworks have not yet migrated to the Android world. Practices that some would consider table stakes for web development on the JVM have just begun to trickle in on Android; dependency management and a modern build system, for example. We can even dream of one day receiving proper support for unit tests.

Before the race, Power estimated that he would have to win two of the remaining three races this season to clinch the title. The races remaining include one in Sonoma, Calif., on Sunday and another on Aug. 30 in Fontana, Calif. Power has a 39-point lead over Helio Castroneves in the standings.

headline: The Richard III Diet: Wild Birds, Frequent Feasts and Plenty of Wine
abstract: New evidence from an analysis of Richard III’s bones suggest that he lived like a king — a wealthy one.
lead_paragraph: It is good to be king, even if only for two years. British researchers analyzing the bones of Richard III have found that Shakespeare’s most nefarious royal lived high on the hog after taking the throne, at age 30, in 1483. Even by the lofty standards of the nobility, he dined sumptuously and drank lavishly, judging by chemical traces left in his skeleton and examined, using multi-isotope techniques, by scientists at the British Geological Survey and the University of Leicester. Their findings were posted online by the Journal of Archaeological Science.

They were the Confederate Army’s most persuasive and effective recruitment officers, shaming anyone who shirked his duty to fight. A young English immigrant in Arkansas enlisted after being accosted at a recruitment meeting. “If every man did not hasten to battle, they vowed they would themselves rush out and meet the Yankee vandals,” he wrote of Southern women. “In a land where women are worshipped by men, such language made them war-mad.”

These days, European after-dinner conversation tends to be dominated by discussion of the latest episode of “House of Cards” or “Homeland” or “Mad Men.” A French diplomat told me that every meeting he attended at the White House during his tour in Washington ended with one of his party asking if it might be possible to see the West Wing. They exchange letters and plot an escape from their dreary worlds. I ordered a $5 malbec one day and a $10 chardonnay the next, delivered by bike courier for a modest fee. Already, San Francisco was crawling with bikes, inching up the hills, shuttling sushi and groceries and new clothes, all summoned with the tap of a finger. But Rewinery was the first of the delivery start-ups that made me feel the way I felt back in 2000, when I could order a video and a pint of ice cream to my doorstep from Kozmo.com. Rewinery felt too good to be true.

headline: Morning Agenda: Dollar Store Deal Frenzy

lead_paragraph: When Dollar General offered on Monday to buy Family Dollar Stores for $8.9 billion, it was hoping not only to break up Family Dollar’s merger with Dollar Tree but also to strengthen its share of the low-end retail market, Michael J. de la Merced and Nelson D. Schwartz write in DealBook. “Prices at Family Dollar are kept low and its breadth of products is limited to items it can sell cheaply,” they write. “But the retailer’s success has become a symbol of the rush to cater to the working poor.”

headline: Daily Report: Delivery Start-Ups Are Back Like It’s 1999
abstract: Something is in the air lately, making many entrepreneurs forget the demise of services like Webvan and Kozmo during the last dot-com boom.
lead_paragraph: In the tech crash of the early 2000s, on-demand delivery services like Kozmo and Webvan weren’t just among the most colossal failures. They also became a sort of grim joke, symbolizing the excess that portended the bust. Afterward, conventional wisdom hardened: Web-enabled delivery was not a good business. Warehouses were too costly to build. There was too little opportunity to recoup expenditures in delivery fees. And people will pay only so much for toilet paper to be delivered before they decide to fetch it themselves.

But the most telling move came in Cairo, where Israel yanked its team from talks aimed at a more durable truce.

headline: 1889: Express Wrecked on Tracks
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: A train crashed in Ryhope in 1889.
lead_paragraph: SUNDERLAND — The Leeds express met with a serious accident to-night [Aug. 19] at about eight o’clock on the North Eastern Railway at Ryhope station, about three miles from here. This train travels from Newcastle and calls at Sunderland on its journey. To-night the train seems to have run harder and faster than usual, indeed passengers were alarmed some minutes before the smash took place. All the coaches, except the last one, were thrown off the metals, and soon a scene of great confusion ensued. Strange to say, there was but one death, that of a child; but there were several injured severely. — The New York Herald, European Edition, August 20, 1889

headline: The Discreet Charm of Clinton Hill, Brooklyn
abstract: Francesca Amfitheatrof’s lovely, low-key neighborhood makes for perfect weekend wandering. Here, a few cultural highlights.
lead_paragraph: In “Brunch at Tiffany’s” in T’s Fall 2014 Women’s Fashion Issue, the new Tiffany & Company design director Francesca Amfitheatrof reveals the ways in which her work is influenced by her relaxed life and eclectic home in Brooklyn’s Clinton Hill neighborhood. Once a fashionable suburb for Gilded Age families, the historic district features some of the city’s loveliest, most low-key blocks, making it perfect for weekend wandering. It has also shaped some of the borough’s artistic luminaries: Patti Smith and Robert Mapplethorpe were roommates on Hall Street, a block away from where Walt Whitman wrote “Leaves of Grass” on Ryerson Street; the rapper Biggie Smalls grew up on nearby St. James Place. Here, a few local highlights.

headline: Back Spasms Trouble Missy Franklin

She was to have made her final tuneups for a program that includes a 200-meter freestyle/100-meter backstroke double on Thursday, the opening session of the four-day meet.

headline: Should Red Wolves Be Allowed to Mate With Coyotes?
abstract: There is a debate over whether or not Red Wolves should be permitted to mate with Eastern coyotes. Is it better to leave genetic diversity to nature or should we try to preserve endangered species?
lead_paragraph: In the past century, a new medium-size predator has appeared in the Northeast. Some call it the coywolf; others prefer ”Eastern coyote.” In times past, the animal was called ”coydog.” All monikers are somewhat correct: The most recent genetic analysis suggests that the animal is roughly one-quarter wolf and two-thirds coyote. The remainder of its genome comes from dogs.

headline: Unknown Dylan Songs Get Music by Elvis Costello, Marcus Mumford and Others
abstract: Twenty songs with lyrics written by Bob Dylan decades ago will be released with music written by five other artists.
lead_paragraph: Bob Dylan’s Basement Tapes have always fascinated the singer’s fans. Some of these informal recordings, which Mr. Dylan made with the Band in 1967, while recovering from injuries sustained in a motorcycle accident the previous year, turned up on one of the earliest rock bootlegs, “Great White Wonder,” in 1969, and two dozen of them were released officially on the “The Basement Tapes” in 1975 (with a few more songs turning up on Mr. Dylan’s “Bootleg Series” compilations). Bootleg collectors have another 10 CD’s worth of material, including original songs, covers and blues and folk tunes.

headline: How to Keep Score: However You Like
abstract: Unlike baseball, tennis has no generally accepted way to keep score, so each reporter’s notebook has a language all its own.
lead_paragraph: North of the Mets-Willets Point stop of the No. 7 subway line and the Long Island Rail Road, there is a standard written language: When the second baseman, the shortstop and the first baseman combine for a double play at Citi Field, reporters in the press box and fans in the seats write “4-6-3” on their scorecards. If the next batter strikes out swinging, a “K” tells the story.

headline: And Then The Dog Died: Things You Can’t Plan for When Planning a Move
abstract: I thought I’d planned for all the changes coming our way when my family moved to a new city. Then — silly me — I realized you can’t plan for the unexpected.
lead_paragraph: When planning my family’s move to Nashville from Atlanta, one of the things I put a lot of thought into was creating a sense of consistency in order to manage how much change and disorder our children would experience this summer. I read somewhere that children need to know they can rely on some things to stay the same, even when a big transition comes along.

headline: When Technology Makes Work Worse
abstract: Some people worry about robots taking jobs from humans, but others are looking at the ways company software and hardware might be changing how humans work — sometimes for the worse.
lead_paragraph: When we talk about robots taking people’s jobs, we often mean it almost literally — we envision if not the humanoid androids of science fiction, then at least machines programmed to do tasks once done by humans. But technology may also be altering Americans’ working lives in another way, via the software and hardware that companies use to determine when and how they work.

headline: I Tried to Work Out Like a Pro Wrestler and Failed
abstract: Among Diamond Dallas Page’s dozen or so workouts, there was one that I steered clear of: the “Psycho Extreme Workout.” The other day, however, boredom and curiosity got the best of me.
lead_paragraph: Much of the discussion in my recent profile of Diamond Dallas Page, the former-wrestler-turned-fitness-guru, centered on the therapeutic uses of DDP Yoga. Page created the program after rupturing a disc between his fourth and fifth lumbar vertebrae during a wrestling match. A handful of back specialists told Page he’d never wrestle again — he was in his early 40s, after all. But he devised his own form of yoga using exercises that he learned during physical therapy, traditional calisthenics and something Page calls “dynamic resistance” — the “secret sauce” of DDP Yoga.

headline: 1964: Saigon Moves U.S. Monument
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: A Kennedy memorial in Saigon was taken down overnight in 1964.
lead_paragraph: SAIGON — The South Vietnamese government quietly hauled down a monument honoring President Kennedy under cover of curfew before dawn today [Aug. 19]. Official sources said the large concrete slab and plaque was removed from one of Saigon’s main squares with the concurrence of the U.S. embassy. Officials apparently believed the monument for an American president was an irritant to certain sectors of the Vietnamese public and was a source of propaganda for the Communists in their claim that the country is a puppet of Washington. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 20, 1964

Holder Jr. holding a news conference to proclaim that a “too big to fail” bank had been brought to justice for its reprehensible behavior in the years leading up to the 2008 financial crisis. All things considered, it was fine theater with the obvious caveat that nothing even remotely close to justice had been served.

headline: Weekly Quandary: Should Siblings Spectate?
abstract: Is sibling attendance at a brother or sister’s sports or other events part of being a supportive family, or “dragging them along?”
lead_paragraph: In the Weekly Quandary, we pull a question from the comments, the weekly open thread or email that we know (or at least suspect) plagues more than one parent. You — the readers — provide the advice: How have you made this work better in your family? This week’s quandary comes from a comment that surprised me on a recent blog post, “When Sports and Family Time Conflict, Speak Up.”

headline: Monsters, Inc.
abstract: The costumed characters of Times Square held a news conference.
lead_paragraph: When you belong to a lowly regarded, often abused, all-but-anonymous segment of New York City society, how do you assert your rights and dignity? You organize and demand them. In Times Square at noon on Tuesday, a couple dozen costumed characters held a news conference to defend themselves and their right to work (posing for photos with tourists and soliciting tips), and to denounce what they said was routine police harassment. The group calls itself NYC Artists United for a Smile, a jaunty name that matched the performers’ mood as they cheered and applauded themselves and yelled “Si, se puede,” the yes-we-can chant of immigrants and the working poor. Except for Batman, who glowered as usual as he passed out handbills at the edge of the crowd.

lead_paragraph: Louis Garrel doesn’t have to rely on fashion to be stylish. The Paris-born son of bohemian artists (the director Philippe Garrel and the actress Brigitte Sy) was born that way. The actor, best known for his role in Bernardo Bertolucci’s 2003 sex-charged drama “The Dreamers,” says that his wardrobe is a patchwork of loaners from friends and collaborators. “I really don’t buy clothes,” the 31-year-old insists. Of course, sometimes he does, but not from the gilded boutiques on rue Saint-Honoré; he prefers hidden-gem shops with little signage and fewer brand names. It’s an unexpected revelation from a guy who has been shot by Bruce Weber and styled by Carine Roitfeld, appeared on the cover of European fashion bibles and been the face of Valentino’s Uomo fragrance since last year.

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 7 A.M. (Cinemax) MUNICH (2005) Steven Spielberg ventures beyond this story’s historical impetus — the 1972 Olympics, at which 11 Israeli athletes and coaches were killed by members of a Palestinian group known as Black September — to create a philosophical thriller about its aftermath: Israel’s apparent campaign of vengeance, using five agents who crisscrossed Europe to hunt suspects for years. Eric Bana (above, second from right, with Geoffrey Rush) portrays the film’s moral center, a former Mossad agent sent on a mission to eliminate those responsible for the deaths. Daniel Craig, Ciaran Hinds, Hanns Zischler and Mathieu Kassovitz play his team. Tony Kushner and Eric Roth wrote the screenplay, based on a book by George Jonas. “An unsparingly brutal look at two peoples all but drowning in a sea of their own blood, ‘Munich’ is by far the toughest film of the director’s career and the most anguished,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. But more than anything, she added, “ ‘Munich’ is a slammin’ entertainment filled with dazzling set pieces and geometric camerawork.”

headline: A U.S. Open to Remember: Navratilova and Evert Look Back
abstract: The archrivals Chris Evert and Martina Navratilova talk about their legendary 1984 match, which might have changed the course of women’s tennis.
lead_paragraph: Within the bounds of a singles tennis court, Chris Evert and Martina Navratilova knew each other very well. Between 1973 and 1988, the two 18-time Grand Slam champs faced each other 80 times, with Navratilova holding a slight advantage, 43 to 37. Yet remarkably, despite their monumental rivalry, they were close friends off the court. Having so frequently found themselves alone together at the end of a tournament, Evert and Navratilova formed a bond that is difficult to imagine today between champions: They practiced together, helped tune each other’s strokes and hung out regularly. They even won Wimbledon and the French Open as doubles partners.

headline: 1889: Wandering Cricketer Dies

lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — Charles A. Absolom’s wasted life is ended. The famous Cambridge cricketer’s body lies at the port of Spain, Trinidad, far from the land he loved so well. For upwards of ten years he had lived in America. When he broke loose from associations which bound him to England he bought a rifle and dog and buried himself in the heart of the Rocky Mountains. The reasons for this he never gave. Some said it was a love affair, and that explanation was generally accepted. Wherever he was known, there is deep regret that a life began under such favourable auspices should have ended so sadly. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Aug. 21, 1889

Pius X. then said : ‘‘May God’s will be done: it is the end.’’ At 1.22 a.m. the Pope murmured some incomprehensible words, and thirteen minutes later Mgr. headline: 36 Hours in Glasgow
abstract: Whether you’re looking for art or music, shops or nature, a cup of tea or a dram of whisky, you can find it during a weekend in this city in western Scotland.
lead_paragraph: Since 2008, the year Glasgow gained Unesco status as a “city of music,” this reinvented industrial center in western Scotland has solidified its reputation as a night-life and cultural hub. On any given night, you can wander through the West End near the university or later in the center’s Merchant City, and find lounges pulsing with electronica, pubs with traditional Gaelic music, sleek restaurants, dive bars and fringe theaters, a melting pot for every taste. This year — referendum for Scottish independence aside — Glasgow is stepping further into the spotlight. A few weeks ago, the Commonwealth Games drew thousands of athletes and visitors; next month the Ryder Cup comes to the Gleneagles resort in Perthshire, northeast of town. The vibrant student life that radiates from the gorgeous campus of the centuries-old University of Glasgow, the rich collections of art in the city museums, the concentration of small shops and vintage treasure troves, and unexpected leafy enclaves are only a few of the city’s charms. But ultimately it’s the openhearted, hospitable and occasionally irreverent people who live here that create such a welcoming city.

headline: The Conservative Divide Over Ferguson
keywords: ['Crime and Criminals', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: And its implications for the politics of criminal justice reform.
lead_paragraph: We’re used to just about every American controversy polarizing swiftly along right-left lines, but the discussion of events in Ferguson has been a striking exception thus far. Within the commentariat, the most interesting division has opened within American conservatism, where a large group of conservative and libertarian writers have been much less inclined than perhaps they/we would have been thirty years ago to give the police the benefit of the doubt. More interesting still is the breadth and diversity of this group: It’s not only the predictable police skeptics, the Cato Institute and Reason types; you also have elite-media squishes like myself, fiercer polemicists like Kevin Williamson and Mark Steyn, and the populist crew at RedState (Erick Erickson, Leon Wolf) raising similar questions about police conduct, along with many other writers (and, of course, Rand Paul) as well.

Now the site-specific theater company Sister Sylvester has decided to lend a mike and a soundtrack to a seething, internecine set of characters inspired by “Look Back in Anger,” John Osborne’s 1956 drama of high-volume hostility and social alienation. Directed by Kathryn Hamilton, this multimedia riff opens on Aug. 29 at the East Village bar Sing Sing Karaoke under the promisingly disaffected title “Dead Behind These Eyes.” (Previous pieces from Sister Sylvester, which creates dialogues with other works of art, include “Werner Herzog on Wrestlemania.”) Prepare for a night of off-key confessions, slurred lyrics, documentary video projections of a world in strife and bottomless shot glasses. headline: Classical Playlist: Mozart, Schubert, Goffredo Petrassi and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: MOZART: Piano Concertos No. 25 in C (K. 503) and No. 20 in D minor (K. 466)Martha Argerich, pianist; Claudio Abbado, conductor; Orchestra Mozart(Deutsche Grammophon 4379 1033)The only problem with the artistry of Martha Argerich, one of the most brilliant pianists of modern times, is her occasional wild streak, something that has come out especially in solo repertory. But with the right colleagues in chamber music and the right conductor in concertos, reined in just a bit, Ms. Argerich is often incomparable. She has an ideal colleague in the conductor Claudio Abbado, who recorded two Mozart concertos with her live last March at the Lucerne Festival, now issued as a recording. The performances of the Concerto No. 25 in C and No. 20 in D minor are phenomenal, with Ms. Argerich’s vibrant, colorful, imaginative playing held in check just enough by the masterly conducting of Abbado, who draws exciting playing from the festival’s Orchestra Mozart. That Abbado died in January makes the recording even more special. (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: Elisabeth Moss, Mark Duplass and Charlie McDowell on ‘The One I Love’

lead_paragraph: Mark Duplass and Elisabeth Moss star in “The One I Love,” a movie (out Friday) that at first appears to be a talky low-budget indie about a couple who heads to a weekend retreat to repair their marriage. But when it premiered last January at the Sundance Film Festival, audiences were blindsided by a plot twist that takes place 20 minutes into the film and turns the familiar premise on its head. “The biggest thing I got was, ‘Thank God I saw this here before everyone ruins the story,’” Duplass says of the audience’s reaction. “And they were like, I hope there’s some way that you can not tell everyone what happens.” At the time, that seemed impossible, and the film’s cast and the first-time director Charlie McDowell expected their secret to be spoiled on social media and in reviews. Remarkably, that hasn’t happened, and the movie’s distributor latched onto the twist as the linchpin for its marketing campaign. Recently, Moss, Duplass and McDowell joined T for lunch at the Mondrian Soho to discuss how their movie came to be, their own relationships and the art of keeping a secret in an age of oversharing.

headline: Rebellious Diversity in Song

lead_paragraph: Gordon Voidwell favors brightly patterned sweaters over ripped plaid pants, basketball caps instead of a mohawk. His electro-R&B mixtape “Bad Études” layers glossy falsetto harmonies and futuristic synths, not harsh guitar distortion and rude epithets about the queen. His style is just one example of the contrarian spirit in New York’s growing Afropunk scene. “When we think of what punk is, there’s such a specific branding — the Ramones, the Sex Pistols — but the idea of punk is just to be counterculture, to take what we all perceive as the norm and revolt against it,” said Mr. Voidwell, 30, who grew up in the Bronx. “Afropunk is about fracturing the idea of what black arts are, what black music is.”

Ms. Mccuaig indulged in the uncharacteristically sunny weather by pairing a white children’s tank top (admittedly borrowed from her little sister) and a black pencil skirt with flowers embroidered on the waist. She cites her grandparents’ wardrobe, old movies and local street style as her main inspirations. This interview has been edited and condensed.

headline: What Is So Special About Iyengar Yoga?

lead_paragraph: This week, the international yoga community said goodbye to a beloved teacher, B.K.S. Iyengar, who died at 95. He is credited with bringing yoga to the Western world and making it accessible to every age and walk of life. To learn more about what makes Iyengar yoga so special to those who practice it, I spoke with Carrie Owerko, a teacher at the Iyengar Yoga Institute of Greater New York. She was also a student of B.K.S. Iyengar, studying with him in India in February. Here’s an edited version of our conversation.

headline: Casting Call: Rethink Family Dinner With Jenny Rosenstrach
abstract: During the week of Sept. 8, we’ll be coaching a real family through real family dinners in real time – seven new meals in seven days – and we hope that you’ll cook along with us.
lead_paragraph: My friend Sarah is what you might call capable. She’s an emergency room surgeon in Salt Lake City; she’s the mother of a 5-year-old; and she has just completed her ninth marathon in as many years. On a Friday last February, while my husband and I sat in her ridiculously organized kitchen, she poured each of us a glass of wine as we asked her a million questions about her day. She seemed shocked that we were so interested in hearing her E.R. stories. Removing appendixes, stabilizing car accident victims, saving lives — all in a day’s work. She put up with all of our questions, and then said something I’ll never forget.

headline: Flattering the Other Flowers
abstract: Salvias like Hot Lips and Lady in Red make everything around them look better.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes when I am weeding in the late afternoon, I hear the vibrating wings of the ruby-throated hummingbird before I see it dipping its beak into the long tubular flowers of the blue anise sage (Salvia guaranitica) called Black and Blue for its cobalt-blue petals and near-black calyxes at the base of the flowers. Hummingbirds are shy, but if I remain perfectly still, it is usually so intent on the nectar inside those deep blue trumpets that I can admire it out of the corner of my eye as it backs out of one flower and moves on to another. Then, in a flash of iridescent green and red, it is gone.

headline: More People Going to Switzerland for Assisted Suicide, Study Finds
abstract: A study found that the number of people arriving in Switzerland from other countries for help with suicide increased steadily from 2009 to 2012.
lead_paragraph: Switzerland has long had a permissive law on assisted suicide, and a new study has found an increase in the number of people from other countries traveling to Switzerland to end their lives under the auspices of right-to-die organizations. The study, published in The Journal of Medical Ethics, looked at assisted suicides in Zurich, where Dignitas, the most prominent right-to-die organization, is based. The researchers found that 611 people from 31 countries had committed assisted suicide from 2008 to 2012. Since 2009, the number of those arriving from other countries for help with suicide has increased steadily, to 172 in 2012. Nearly half of all cases involved people with neurological disorders, like Parkinson’s disease and multiple sclerosis, diagnoses that are generally not terminal. Nearly 60 percent of the 611 were women. People committing assisted suicide came largely from Germany, Britain and France. Twenty-one arrived from the United States: five in 2010, nine in 2011, and seven in 2012.

headline: Toiling to Succeed: First in the Pool, Then at the Bank

headline: The Facts and Figures Behind Vogue Magazine

lead_paragraph: The glossy has spawned an industry of imitators, two documentaries, a major Hollywood film and, perhaps most enduringly, a modern dance craze. It’s also gone through some serious changes over the course of its 121 years in print. (See the 10 most groundbreaking covers in the history of Vogue here.) In recent years, the fashion bible has traded willowy models for celebrities of all kinds, a trend that reached its apex in April when the left-leaning, Chanel-shaded Brit Anna Wintour (the magazine’s seventh editor in chief) decided to put — gasp! — a reality star on its cover. But even with young upstarts nipping at its Manolos, the periodical that popularized tights and the L.B.D. continues to thrive under its time-tested principle. That is, while other magazines teach women what’s new in fashion, Vogue teaches them what’s in vogue. Here, a look at the facts and figures behind fashion’s foremost franchise.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 4:45 P.M. (Showtime 2) KIDNAPPED FOR CHRIST (2014) Kate Logan was a young evangelical when she traveled to the Dominican Republic to document life at a Christian boarding school, now defunct, called Escuela Caribe, one of hundreds of small schools to which American parents send their supposedly troubled teenagers. Once there, Ms. Logan (above right, with Tai, a student) hoped to make a record of young lives changing for the better. Instead, she met Beth, a 15-year-old who was punished with beatings and stints in solitary confinement, and a gay teenager named David, whose parents arranged for his midnight abduction from his home in Colorado and his relocation to the school, where they hoped strict discipline and aggressive Christianity might change his sexual orientation. The resulting documentary is important, if imperfect, Neil Genzlinger wrote in The New York Times. “Ms. Logan makes the young-filmmaker mistake of injecting herself into the story,” he said. “It’s not necessary; the students’ tales are what’s important.”

headline: Eugenie Bouchard Could Be Tennis’s Next Big Shot
abstract: After years grinding on the junior circuit, the 20-year-old is poised to be one of the sport’s next big stars. Now she just needs that breakthrough win.
lead_paragraph: The sun was just starting to fade on the evening of Aug. 5 when Eugenie Bouchard, the eighth-ranked women’s tennis player in the world, walked onto center court at the Rogers Cup tournament in Montreal. Immediately the audience rose to its feet and roared. Bouchard, who grew up five miles from the stadium, approached her chair, eyes trained on the ground. As she put down her tennis bag and took out her racket, the audience continued clapping, cheering and whistling. She arranged a towel across the seat of her chair and another across its back, and still the ovation went on. Finally, when it became clear that Bouchard did not intend to acknowledge the frenzy with so much as a wave, the crowd sat, reducing its din to the usual prematch hum. Bouchard’s composure and focus, for which commentators in countless languages have praised her, was partly what drew 11,000 fans to fill the stands for a second-round match. She would smile, maybe, when she won.

The accord would be the biggest government settlement by a company in American history. Prosecutors are also preparing a separate civil case against Angelo Mozilo, the man who came to embody the risk-taking for which Bank of America is now paying dearly, a rare move against a senior executive at the center of the financial crisis.

headline: Till Real Estate Do You Part
abstract: John Lithgow and Alfred Molina star in “Love Is Strange” as Manhattan men who marry but are forced to live separately.
lead_paragraph: From the first moments we see them together — waking, washing and dressing in the Manhattan apartment they have shared for decades — it is clear that Ben (John Lithgow) and George (Alfred Molina) are a walking illustration of the phrase “old married couple.” They know each other so well and have adapted, graciously and sometimes a little fractiously, to each other’s peculiarities. State law, at long last, has caught up with the reality of their relationship: The first scenes in Ira Sachs’s “Love Is Strange” take place on the morning of George and Ben’s marriage, which is solemnized in an alfresco ceremony followed by a relaxed and lively party at home.

headline: The True Price of Customer Service
keywords: ['Customer Relations', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Small Business', 'Working Hours']
abstract: With business getting better, the stress level from working overtime has increased, and I am starting to experience something I might call “value conflict.” We want to give the customers great service, but we also don’t want to burn out our people.
lead_paragraph: When I started my custom picture framing company 36 years ago, I was one of the first to offer a one-week turnaround in an industry that was used to making people wait anywhere from weeks to months for their framing to be completed. This required carrying a good inventory, having a flexible staff, and maintaining the systems and commitment to do so.

headline: The 10 Most Groundbreaking Covers in the History of Vogue
abstract: The magazine’s choices have always served as conversation starters. Here, a slideshow of the most memorable.
lead_paragraph: The conversation that follows the release of each new issue of Vogue is often less about what’s inside its pages than it is about what — or who — is on its cover. Over its 121 years in print, the title that Anna Wintour once called “a glamorous girlfriend” has served as the ultimate stamp of approval for the fashionable and famous, with models and film starlets (and occasionally, men) posing for the world’s most famous photographers. And while changing times have dictated a shift in philosophy — in particular, a move away from the supermodels of Diana Vreeland’s Vogue in favor of buzzy millennials like Lena Dunham and Lupita Nyong’o — the glossy’s ability to move the cultural needle remains intact. Here, a look back at 10 of the most important covers from Vogue’s celebrated history.

An artist herself, as well as a museum curator with considerable financial resources, she had been a zealous supporter of his career. But they’d broken up a decade earlier and hadn’t seen each other since.

headline: 1889: President Carnot Leaves Paris
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: French president is waved goodbye as he leaves for vacation in 1889.
lead_paragraph: President Carnot left Paris for Fontainebleau yesterday afternoon by the Gare de Lyon, where a few hundred persons were waiting in the drenching rain to wish him and his wife bon voyage and a pleasant fortnight’s holiday. The directors of the railway company had a waiting room specially arranged, and presented to Mme. Carnot a magnificent bouquet. President Carnot, on his way to the station, happened to come across a large body of English tourists. The Britishers, who heard that the President was coming, raised a real English ‘‘Hip, hip, hip, hurrah!’’ that nearly raised the roof off the Presidential carriage. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Aug. 22, 1889

headline: Alone Again, Unnaturally
abstract: Elisabeth Moss and Mark Duplass star in “The One I Love,” about a couple sent on a mysterious retreat to help their marriage.
lead_paragraph: Alfred Hitchcock liked to distinguish between surprise and suspense, between the bombs that shock us (boom!) and those that put us on edge (tick, tick, tick). The modestly sized puzzler “The One I Love” — a cunning, twisty tale about a marriage that has gone sour and is about to go pretty strange — detonates a few bombs, but also keeps a few ticking until the end. The unpromising setup is as banal as someone else’s shrink session. What quickly pulls you in, though, are the appealing stars and mysterioso circumstances that their characters — like the viewer — are sucked into as the story morphs into a quagmire of narrative uncertainty, marital gamesmanship and speculative foolishness.

headline: More Dances for an iPhone, Inspired by Sondheim
abstract: The choreographer Richard Daniels will soon release a fourth installment of his iPhone app, with dances set to music by Stephen Sondheim.
lead_paragraph: For dance aficionados, Richard Daniels’s series of iPhone apps have been a source of enlightenment and entertainment ever since Dances for an iPhone – a collection of six short dance films, with choreography by Mr. Daniels, that you watch in the palm of your hand – was released. Since then, Mr. Daniels has created two more installments, and on Sept. 1 he will release Dances for an iPhone, Vol. 4, a collection of dances set to the music of Stephen Sondheim, compiled with Mr. Sondheim’s blessing.

headline: Iran Frees Photojournalist
abstract: The Iranian-American photojournalist, a woman with dual citizenship, was detained last month along with a reporter for The Washington Post and his wife.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — An Iranian-American woman with dual citizenship, who had been working in Iran as a photojournalist officially accredited by the authorities, was released on Thursday after having been held at an unidentified location since July 22, her relatives said. They refused to reveal her identity.

headline: Liberian Boy Dies After Being Shot During Clash Over Ebola Quarantine
abstract: The boy, Shakie Kamara, 15, died of bleeding and hypothermic shock after being shot in the legs when soldiers fired into a crowd trying to leave a quarantined area in Monrovia, Liberia.
lead_paragraph: MONROVIA, Liberia — A teenage boy who was wounded on Wednesday during clashes at an Ebola-stricken neighborhood in Monrovia, Liberia, died of hypovolemic shock after being shot in his legs, said Dr. Mohammed Sankoh, the medical director of Redemption Hospital.

headline: Staying Safe, Exploring Sassy
abstract: On Ariana Grande’s new album, “My Everything,” the young pop star strikes a balance between sweet and sultry.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The building on the quiet Los Angeles block with a plate on the door that reads “Believe” — here are the offices of Scooter Braun, Svengali to Justin Bieber. Upstairs in the back is a room filled with old arcade games and the full gamut of Bieber accolades, including a piece of paper taped to the wall identifying him as Gossip Bang Chinese Fans’ Choice Male Hottie 2013, whatever that might be.

headline: Fernand St Germain, Legislator Tied to S.&L. Crisis, Dies at 86
abstract: The Rhode Island Democrat’s legacy was marred when savings and loan associations, emboldened by deregulation he sponsored, became overextended and went under, at a huge cost to taxpayers.
lead_paragraph: Fernand St Germain, a 14-term Rhode Island congressman who was chairman of the House banking committee before the savings and loan crisis exploded, and who lost his seat after drawing attention for his ties to the industry he had helped deregulate, died on Saturday at his summer home in Newport, R.I. He was 86.

headline: New Owner to Renovate and Upgrade Quad Cinema
abstract: Charles S. Cohen, a real estate executive, plans to improve the theater but not to change the name.
lead_paragraph: Charles S. Cohen, the president and chief executive of the Cohen Brothers Realty Corporation, has bought the Quad Cinema, the Greenwich Village theater that has for decades been a hybrid art-house and first-run theater. The sale was completed on Wednesday, Daniela Sapkar, a spokeswoman for Mr. Cohen, said.

headline: Dr. Kent Brantly Recovers From Ebola
abstract: Dr. Brantly, an American missionary and doctor who contracted Ebola in Liberia, was discharged from Emory Hospital in Atlanta after making a full recovery from the disease.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Brantly, an American missionary and doctor who contracted Ebola in Liberia, was discharged from Emory Hospital in Atlanta after making a full recovery from the disease.

headline: More Comments Invited for Proposed Bitcoin Rules
abstract: New York’s financial regulator said those interested in submitting comments on new rules for virtual currencies will have until Oct. 21 to do so.
lead_paragraph: New York’s Department of Financial Services said on Thursday that it would extend by 45 days the comment period for its proposed virtual currency regulations. Those interested in submitting comments on the new rules will now have until Oct. 21.

headline: Why We Love Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Cartoons and Cartoonists', 'Comic Books and Strips', 'Fear (Emotion)', 'Genetic Engineering', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Movies', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Turtles and Tortoises', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: They are far from the first mutant characters to captivate audiences, and they can tell us a lot about the kinds of stories we care about.
lead_paragraph: The Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles are clearly unique. As Megan Garber of The Atlantic puts it, they are “turtles who are also mutants — the result of exposure to a mutagen ooze — who are also ninjas.” It’s hardly a common formulation.

headline: States Given a Reprieve on Ratings of Teachers
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Performance Evaluations (Labor)', 'Tests and Examinations']
abstract: Arne Duncan said that testing issues are “sucking the oxygen” out of classrooms, and that teachers should have another year to adjust to new standards and practices.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of Education Arne Duncan announced on Thursday that states could delay the use of test results in teacher-performance ratings by another year, an acknowledgment, in effect, of the enormous pressures mounting on the nation’s teachers because of new academic standards and more rigorous standardized testing.

headline: The Bauble With the Picture, and Vice Versa
abstract: “Multiple Exposures: Jewelry and Photography,” at the Museum of Arts and Design, displays works that unite the two forms.
lead_paragraph: The common perception of photography is that it is something to be mounted on a wall, printed in a book or viewed on a screen. But people have been wearing and handling photographs practically since their invention. “Multiple Exposures: Jewelry and Photography,” an exhibition of 170 objects by 80 artists at the Museum of Arts and Design, offers some striking historical and contemporary examples.

headline: The Pigeons Are Clay and Play Hard to Get
abstract: At a shooting ground in Dover Plains, N.Y., a writer tries her hand at a sporting clays course — “golf with shotguns” — with friends.
lead_paragraph: ONE thing was clear: I am not my mother’s daughter.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
abstract: In the news: CrossFit, assisted suicide and working out with your dog. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: In the news: CrossFit, assisted suicide and working out with your dog. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Sprint, With Marcelo Claure at Helm, Aims for Comeback With Price Cuts
abstract: Sprint’s new chief executive just started work last Monday and the company got straight to cutting prices.
lead_paragraph: Sprint’s new chief executive, Marcelo Claure, just started work last week and the company got straight to cutting prices.

headline: ‘Ice Bucket Challenge’ Donations for A.L.S. Research Top $41 Million
abstract: Contributions to the A.L.S. Association have surged since the challenge started trending online in late July.
lead_paragraph: With everyone from former President George W. Bush to Justin Bieber and Shakira posting online videos of themselves dumping buckets of ice over their heads in the name of charity, the viral “Ice Bucket Challenge” continues to dominate social media and has now raised more than $40 million for amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, commonly known as Lou Gehrig’s disease.

headline: It’s Still Popular Being Green
abstract: “Wicked” evinces little sign of box office fatigue.
lead_paragraph: There’s a straightforward strategy for turning a hit musical into a long-running smash: Don’t mess with success.

headline: Full of Character for a Lot Less Rent in Bayonne, N.J.
abstract: Angela Putman and Matt Jackson went looking for a two-bedroom to rent in Manhattan and wound up in Bayonne, N.J.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, Matt Jackson returned to New York for work. After 14 years in Dallas, he was unprepared for the high rents, small spaces and quick turnaround. “Apartments turn over within hours,” he said.

headline: Jane Austen Artifacts at the Morgan Library and in England
abstract: There has been a surge of interest in all things Austen since the 200th anniversary last year of the release of “Pride & Prejudice.”
lead_paragraph: AUSTEN AND ARTIFACTS: A POPULAR COMBINATION
