keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)', 'Attacks on Police']
abstract: Senator Bernard Sanders of Vermont and others respond to the racial unrest in Ferguson, Mo.

headline: Summer Salute to Charlie Parker
abstract: The Charlie Parker Jazz Festival shares his legacy on stages across Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: It’s not impossible to imagine the jazz legend Charlie Parker putting the musical primitivism of punk rock into perspective with one of his eloquent and pungent zingers. On the other hand, were he here this weekend to see the AfroPunk Festival, a free outdoor concert in Brooklyn, the Miser wonders whether he wouldn’t sense some common ground with acts like Meshell Ndegeocello, Shabazz Palaces or Valerie June, who also build vanguard sounds from blues roots.

headline: Cindy Sherman’s Wigs
abstract: A stop-motion animation consisting of 156 wigs shot in the artist’s New York City studio.
lead_paragraph: These 156 wigs were shot in the artist’s New York City studio. See them all in 24 seconds in this stop-motion video.

headline: A Risky, Chilly Climb to the Top
abstract: “K2: Siren of the Himalayas” chronicles an attempt to reach the peak of the second-highest mountain in the world in 2009.
lead_paragraph: K2

headline: U.S. General Says Raiding Syria Is Key to Halting ISIS
abstract: Gen. Martin E. Dempsey was circumspect in describing the sort of broad effort that would be required to roll back ISIS in Syria and Iraq.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Islamic State in Iraq and Syria cannot be defeated unless the United States or its partners take on the Sunni militants in Syria, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff said Thursday.

headline: He’s Battled N.B.A. Players. Now He’ll Play for Kentucky.
abstract: Against Team USA, the 18-year-old basketball prodigy from New Jersey has already tested his skills against N.B.A. players.
lead_paragraph: When Karl-Anthony Towns checked into the game for the Dominican Republic’s national team at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night against the American team of N.B.A. stars, he stepped figuratively onto the crossroads of his 18-year-old life.

headline: 10 Questions for the Iowa Senate Candidates
abstract: The Times’s John Harwood interviewed the two candidates, Bruce Braley, a Democrat, and Joni Ernst, a Republican, vying to succeed Tom Harkin in the Senate.
lead_paragraph: The Iowa Senate race is one of a handful that will decide whether Republicans or Democrats control the Senate for the last two years of President Obama’s tenure. The race to succeed retiring Senator Tom Harkin, a Democrat, pits Bruce Braley, a Democrat who is currently in the United States House, against Joni Ernst, a Republican state senator.

headline: Abduction Case Tests Limits of Amish Ties to Modern World
abstract: The kidnapping of two girls in Oswegatchie, N.Y., highlighted the challenges the Amish face by adhering to a 19th-century lifestyle in a 21st-century world.
lead_paragraph: OSWEGATCHIE, N.Y. — The two sisters were missing, apparently abducted from the roadside vegetable stand in front of their house in this rural town near the Canadian border. The police needed photos of the girls to issue an alert, but the family had none: They were Amish, a community that generally prohibits photographs partly based on the biblical injunction against likenesses.

headline: Inspection of Russian Trucks at Ukraine Border Begins
abstract: Teams from Russia, Ukraine and the International Red Cross began checking the convoy that is said to be carrying humanitarian aid.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Russia — Inspectors from Russia, Ukraine and the International Red Cross on Thursday began checking trucks to confirm that they are carrying humanitarian aid destined for eastern Ukraine, a Red Cross spokesman said.

headline: In Bordeaux, Château Palmer Dares to Experiment
abstract: A leading estate moves decisively into the 21st century even as it still dabbles in the 19th.
lead_paragraph: MARGAUX, France — Contrary to its image, Bordeaux is not necessarily an old-fashioned, humorless place. Yes, the chateaus that adorn the Médoc landscape connote a sense of stately permanence, just as the corporate marketers in their Hermès ties and Gucci loafers exude single-minded commerce.

headline: Holder Vows to Stand With Ferguson
abstract: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr., who met with the family of Michael Brown during his trip to Ferguson, Mo., said that mistrust exists between the police and the people they are meant to serve.
lead_paragraph: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr., who met with the family of Michael Brown during his trip to Ferguson, Mo., said that mistrust exists between the police and the people they are meant to serve.

headline: Afropunks, Come as You Are
abstract: Phil Knott’s portraits of the Afropunk scene show “the other black experience” among fans of alternative music.
lead_paragraph: Phil Knott’s portraits of the Afropunk scene show “the other black experience” among fans of alternative music.

headline: Regulators Struggle With Conflicts in Credit Ratings and Audits
keywords: ['Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies', 'ACCOUNTING AND ACCOUNTANTS', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Two industries with obvious conflicts of interest are having trouble adjusting to government regulation, and regulators are having trouble deciding what to do about them.
lead_paragraph: Few businesses have more obvious conflicts of interest than those that involve the issuing of “objective” and “independent” reports and opinions about companies that pay for those reports and opinions.

headline: With Extra Pep, McCarthy Prevents Sweep With a Shutout
abstract: The late-season acquisition shut out the Houston Astros in a victory that kept the Yankees from being swept at home by one of the worst teams in baseball.
lead_paragraph: After the fifth inning Thursday, Yankees starter Brandon McCarthy began to feel tired.

headline: Despite ISIS Horror, Congress Is Wary of U.S. Military Expansion
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The execution of James Foley has drawn emotional reactions from Capitol Hill, but even those criticizing President Obama for not doing more have not specified what to do.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For weeks, Capitol Hill has tried to keep America’s military engagement in Iraq at arm’s length: Democrats and Republicans warily backed President Obama’s limited airstrikes against Sunni militants, but nobody — aside from Senator John McCain and a few fellow hawks — demonstrated an appetite for deeper involvement.

headline: Readers Respond: Alone Again, Naturally
abstract: Readers dissected the Obama presidency with waves of disappointment, civic despondency and Democratic party solidarity in comments on Maureen Dowd’s column, “Alone Again, Naturally.”
lead_paragraph: Readers dissected the Obama presidency with waves of disappointment, civic despondency and Democratic party solidarity in response to Maureen Dowd’s column Wednesday about President Obama’s man-apart style, “Alone Again, Naturally.”

headline: Midtown Manhattan Wouldn’t Be the Same
abstract: “Times Square, 1984: The Postmodern Moment,” at the Skyscraper Museum, displays attempts to reimagine Manhattan’s central neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: The hardworking Skyscraper Museum, in the belly of a condo complex on Battery Place, doesn’t have much space or much of a budget, but with admirable frequency its director, Carol Willis, stages smart shows that uncover telling moments of New York skyscraper lore and architecture history. The museum has just opened “Times Square, 1984: The Postmodern Moment,” about the battle 30 years ago for the soul of Times Square and the profession.

headline: Hallberg, Healing, Keeps Balletomanes Up to Date
abstract: The dancer David Hallberg has been sharing updates about his recovery from surgery with fans.
lead_paragraph: It was the kind of post you might see on a friend’s Instagram account — a quick note Thursday that the ankle surgery went well, lasted a good four hours, and that his foot “must be elevated for over a week so I’ll have time to read and watch god knows what on YouTube.”

headline: Cooking Techniques: Cutting a Mango
abstract: Learn how to cut and pit a mango.
lead_paragraph: Learn how to cut and pit a mango.

headline: Tim Howard Taking One-Year Break From U.S. National Team
abstract: Tim Howard says he is not retiring, and hopes to return and compete for his job as the Americans’ No. 1 goalkeeper in September 2015.
lead_paragraph: Tim Howard, whose superlative shot-stopping nearly carried the United States national team to the quarterfinals of the World Cup this summer in Brazil, announced on Thursday that he would be taking a break from international play until next fall.

headline: Back Off, Sis
abstract: Answers to questions about unwanted sisterly attention, parking etiquette, correspondence and social media.
lead_paragraph: I am a middle-age woman and reasonably satisfied with my appearance. I have a good haircut and wear age-appropriate clothing, but I’m not much interested in makeup or accessories. Several women in my family think of me as a great candidate for “What Not to Wear.” A family wedding is approaching, and my sister offered to pay for a makeup and hairstyling session — just for me. Other family members don’t need the help, she said, because they do fine on their own. I feel humiliated. Should I swallow my pride and accept her offer?

headline: A Ferguson Story on ‘Conflicting Accounts’ Seems to Say ‘Trust Us’
abstract: Readers object to sourcing and balance issues in a story about the fatal shooting in Missouri.
lead_paragraph: Note to readers: I reconsidered the conclusions in this post on March 23, 2015.

headline: Tear-Gassed in Ferguson
abstract: A national reporter recounts being caught between police and protestors in the violence in Missouri.
lead_paragraph: Alan Blinder reported on the unrest in Ferguson, Mo. He has now returned to The Times’s bureau in Atlanta.

headline: Natural Gas Production Falls Short in China
abstract: The nation, facing severe pollution from coal and a rising dependence on energy imports, has had limited success in extracting natural gas from coal and shale.
lead_paragraph: SHOUYANG, China — Jin Peisheng, a drilling rig foreman, knows the challenges of trying to extract natural gas from a coal seam under the cornfields here in north-central China.

headline: And All That Time You Thought You Were Just Playing
abstract: For New Yorkers who miss their childhood Slip ’N Slides, there are classes in Midtown Manhattan that recreate the experience.
lead_paragraph: DURING the humidity-induced haze of midsummer, I dreamed of how refreshing it would feel to flop, arms and legs outstretched, onto a garden-hose-soaked bright yellow Slip ’N Slide.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Your nightly briefing is ready for you.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know from NYT Now:

headline: When Flushing Was Awash With Wonders
keywords: ["World's Fair of 1964-65 (NYC)", 'Memorabilia and Souvenirs', 'Collectors and Collections']
abstract: “Behind the Curtain” at the Queens Museum brings together memorabilia of the World’s Fairs of 1939 and 1964 from personal collections.
lead_paragraph: QUEENS is not the borough to hog center stage, but every once in a while, the spotlight turns its way. It happened, in spectacular fashion, 75 years ago. Out in Forest Hills, Bobby Riggs, fresh from victory at Wimbledon, defeated Welby Van Horn to take the singles title at the United States National Championships, while the incomparable Alice Marble repeated as women’s champion by putting away Helen Hull Jacobs. And over in Flushing Meadows, thousands of visitors were getting a glimpse of the “world of tomorrow” at the New York World’s Fair.

headline: How Mitch McConnell Would Rule the Senate
abstract: The minority leader gave the country a glimpse of confrontations to come.
lead_paragraph: Senator Mitch McConnell gave the country a glimpse this week of what Republican control of the Senate would look like. If it produces a familiar depression, it’s because we’ve seen what happens when Republican leaders in the House have used the identical tactics, and most people have little interest in seeing Washington return to battle stations.

headline: Smaller Hill for Federer to Climb at the Open
abstract: Roger Federer, the No. 2 seed, has an easier route to the men’s final than No. 1 Novak Djokovic, who could face Stan Wawrinka and Andy Murray.
lead_paragraph: No matches have been played yet at the United States Open, which does not kick off until Monday, but as the draw unfolded Thursday, Roger Federer must have felt as if he had already won something.

headline: Sounds Like a Great Place, but Can We Get There by Shoe?
abstract: Believing you can fix a shoe is like believing you can fix a man. It does not work.
lead_paragraph: If I were one of those mystics who lives on top of a mountain, dispensing wisdom to people who hauled themselves up, the first thing I would tell them is: Never shop for shoes when you are tired.

headline: Fewer Pass High School Exams, and Some in England Cheer
abstract: Traditionalists are pleased with what they see as a reversal of decades of slackening standards in education.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — After years of complaints about declining standards for high school exams, the British government has made them harder to pass: The latest results show the first drop in the passing rate in three decades. And in a nation where education has long been a political battleground between progressives and traditionalists, the changes are an emphatic victory for the old school.

headline: In the Shadows, With Their Physical and Moral Impairments
abstract: A criminal enforcer ends up working with an assassin’s blind sister in the Italian film “Salvo.”
lead_paragraph: A soulful romance, an existential action flick and something of a miracle movie — the appealing slow-burner “Salvo” hovers at the crossroads of genre. Its story pulls in all directions, and its mood, tone and backdrop are as serious as a Mafia hit. Yet its setup has the makings of a comedy sketch: A Sicilian mobster, Salvo (Saleh Bakri, holding every inch of screen), meets a blind woman, Rita (Sara Serraiocco), who soon after begins to see the light. It’s a moment that summons the New Testament prophecy about the blind seeing, but it’s also old-fashioned movie-made hokum.

headline: Charting Love, Longing and Loss
abstract: Matthew Thomas’s devastating debut novel, “We Are Not Ourselves,” is a starkly honest, intimate family story with the power to rock you to your core.
lead_paragraph: Matthew Thomas’s devastating debut novel, “We Are Not Ourselves,” does not trumpet the fact that it’s an honest, intimate family story with the power to rock you to your core. It begins on a modest note. “Instead of going to the priest,” its opening sentence says, “the men who gathered at Doherty’s Bar after work went to Eileen Tumulty’s father.” But if Eileen, the book’s wrenchingly credible main character, had not been raised by such a secular Irish-born strongman (and an alcoholic mother as tender as an ice cube), her life would never have followed the path it did.

headline: A Spiritual Seeker Seeks Close to Home
abstract: “Kabbalah Me” portrays one man’s journey into the world of Jewish mysticism.
lead_paragraph: KABBALAH ME

headline: The Yankees’ No. 6 Looks Back
abstract: The Yankees retired Joe Torre’s number in a ceremony at Yankee Stadium. The New York Times’s Tyler Kepner recently interviewed Torre about his long baseball career.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees retired Joe Torre’s number in a ceremony at Yankee Stadium. The New York Times’s Tyler Kepner recently interviewed Torre about his long baseball career.

headline: Hail, the Postwar Avant-Garde
abstract: “The Art of Zero,” at the Neuberger Museum in Purchase, N.Y., is a survey of the international postwar artists who called themselves the Zero Group.
lead_paragraph: PURCHASE, N.Y. — About halfway through the 20th century, the international postwar artists who called themselves the Zero Group tried to hit the reset button. As they saw it, modern art had been irretrievably damaged by two world wars. The only thing to do was start over.

headline: A Crackdown on Law Firms
abstract: A recent suit found borrowers involved in “mass joinder” lawsuits against mortgage lenders were duped by law firms.
lead_paragraph: At least 1,000 borrowers who signed on to “mass joinder” lawsuits against their mortgage lenders were allegedly scammed by two law firms that claimed to be acting on their behalf, according to a suit filed by attorneys general in Connecticut and Florida.

headline: One Expressive Evening
abstract: The Mostly Mozart Festival featured the violinist Joshua Bell on Wednesday evening.
lead_paragraph: Musical lines are like sentences, and their character can vary as much as sentences do. Some players will produce a given passage plainly, like a quotation from John Grisham. But on Wednesday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, with the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra under David Zinman, the star violinist Joshua Bell was like a Henry James in tone.

headline: Four Days That Inspired Torre’s Four Rings
abstract: The intersection of personal and professional factors — along with the right players — made him the right person to lead the Yankees. On Saturday, the team will retire his number.
lead_paragraph: We measure greatness by championships, so the four that Joe Torre won as the manager of the Yankees are the cornerstones of his career, which the team celebrates on Saturday by retiring his No. 6 and unveiling a plaque in Monument Park.

headline: Sisters Fight (It Keeps Them Together)
abstract: “See You Next Tuesday,” an indie film by Drew Tobia, finds a family in its painful and funny glory.
lead_paragraph: SEE YOU NEXT TUESDAY

headline: Where Are the National Democrats on Ferguson?
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: There is an opening for an ambitious candidate to push the party on issues like police abuses and racial injustice, but it hasn’t happened yet.
lead_paragraph: There is something very strange about the national political reaction to the protests in Ferguson, Mo., (and nationally) over Michael Brown’s shooting. The protesters are angry, and they’re not aimlessly angry. They have a specific set of policy grievances about policing and criminal justice that are shared by a large slice of the electorate, particularly the Democratic primary electorate.

headline: Two Silent Men, Deep in Conversation
abstract: In “Men in Armor” at the Frick Collection, a portrait by El Greco and another by Scipione Pulzone hang side by side, creating a discussion about competing views of art.
lead_paragraph: The quadricentennial celebration of the death of El Greco, the great painter of the Spanish Renaissance, will eventually include six East Coast museums this fall, but it is already off to a roaring start with a mouse-size exhibition at the Frick Collection. “Men in Armor” brings together only two canvases, both portraits of bearded Italian gentlemen wearing gleaming cuirasses, as upper-body armor has been called since the time of the Romans. One is a stalwart of the Frick’s collection by El Greco, purchased in 1913, when Henry Clay Frick was building the Fifth Avenue mansion that was ultimately intended to become a museum for his extensive collection. The other painting, on loan from a private collection and rarely exhibited, is by El Greco’s Roman contemporary, Scipione Pulzone.

headline: ‘We Pledge Allegiance ... ’
abstract: Sometimes staying together is just about pragmatism.
lead_paragraph: A friend of mine believes a king-size bed leads to a divorce. Her parents had a king-size bed, and when she was in college her father confessed to having an affair. He blamed the ensuing divorce on a lack of intimacy, but my friend blamed it on her parents’ too-big bed.

headline: In Limbo, and in Love
abstract: “If I Stay” hits the audience with a series of tragedies that ripple out from a car accident on a snowy Oregon road.
lead_paragraph: This summer has been bookended by two movies, both based on young adult best sellers and starring gifted and ambitious actresses, about smart, independent-minded teenage girls finding love in the shadow of death. It is hard to avoid comparing “If I Stay,” which opens on Friday, with “The Fault in Our Stars,” but there is also no reason to choose between them. Each one is a cleanly directed, credibly acted machine for the production of tears.

headline: In Praise of Hindu Gods, With Sharp Turns and Barefoot Rhythms
abstract: Seven classic forms of Indian dance were performed at the Erasing Borders Festival in Battery Park City Wednesday evening.
lead_paragraph: Krishna was evoked, Ganesha was praised, the 10 avatars of Vishnu were illustrated, seven of the eight classical dance forms of India were demonstrated — and the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island were on the horizon throughout. Passing runners and cyclists slowed down to gawp at the costumes, steps and gestures. Even yachts in the harbor veered in their course to get a better view.

headline: Ferguson and A.L.S. Give Rise to the Bullet Bucket Challenge
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Social Media']
abstract: The two social media phenomenons have crossed in a new video where actor Orlando Jones challenged himself to “reverse the hate.”
lead_paragraph: Over the past three weeks, we’ve had our Facebook news feeds flooded with videos of friends and celebrities — from Bill Gates to George W. Bush to Anna Wintour — pouring buckets of ice and water on their heads, all to raise awareness of the degenerative condition A.L.S., known as Lou Gehrig’s disease. As of Thursday, donations to the A.L.S Association topped $41 million.

headline: Sex and the Single Sister
abstract: A woman looks for the secrets behind her sibling’s death in Bangkok in “Cam2Cam.”
lead_paragraph: You would think that a movie involving sex websites, attractive young bodies, decapitations and Bangkok should easily deliver what its target audience wants: sleaze, gore, some low-grade thrills.

headline: 100 Years of Gratitude
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'World War I (1914-18)', 'Series', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Cemeteries']
abstract: A century later, exploring America’s contribution to World War I in a country that’s still thankful for it.
lead_paragraph: We forgot.

headline: A Kaleidoscope of Racial Imagery
abstract: “Through a Lens Darkly” explores how black people have been portrayed in images since the invention of photography and how black photographers have seen and captured the world.
lead_paragraph: The phrase “so wrong in so many ways” could easily have been invented to describe the picture that flits by about four minutes into “Through a Lens Darkly: Black Photographers and the Emergence of a People.” It’s a print advertisement from the 1940s that shows a smiling black boy with a big slice of watermelon, under the headline, “It’s sweeter because of petroleum.” The copy below, promoting Shell, suggests that buying gas makes the earth more bountiful. Racial stereotyping and petrochemical addiction, advanced in a single image.

headline: Rumblings of Volcanic Activity in Iceland
abstract: Airlines have been armed about a possible eruption of the Bardarbunga volcano in Iceland.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 1:14 p.m. | Officials in Iceland closed the airspace over Bardarbunga volcano south east of Reykjavik Saturday afternoon after seismic activity data indicated that an eruption had occurred beneath the surface of the Vatnajokull glacier, under which the volcano sits.

headline: Catch Me if You Can, Satan
abstract: “The Possession of Michael King” centers on a documentary maker who challenges supernatural forces to do their worst to him.
lead_paragraph: Dim in wits and lighting, “The Possession of Michael King” strains our eyes, spits on our intelligence and saps our generosity of spirit. Relatively untaxed, however, is the part of the brain that processes new experiences: There’s scarcely a shot or an idea in this first feature from David Jung that we haven’t seen many times before.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Gaza City and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Gaza City, Ukraine, Indonesia and China.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Gaza City, Ukraine, Indonesia and China.

headline: Savoring the Agony of Defeat
abstract: “When the Game Stands Tall” recounts how a high school football team with a record-breaking winning streak handled losing.
lead_paragraph: You get Bible verses. You get platitudes. And in the football movie “When the Game Stands Tall,” you get an overeager Foley artist who makes every physical contact on the gridiron sound like an explosion. On the other hand, you get Jim Caviezel, who, from time to time, makes you want to be a high school coach in your next life.

headline: Botox Maker Allergan’s Suit Against Valeant Won’t Delay Special Meeting
abstract: A federal judge in California ruled against Allergan, which was hoping its lawsuit against Valeant and Pershing Square Capital Management might prevent its shareholders from calling a special meeting until the case was resolved.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:00 p.m. | When Allergan, the maker of Botox, sued Valeant Pharmaceuticals and Pershing Square Capital Management this month in a federal court in California, claiming insider trading, its opponents said the suit was an attempt to prevent shareholders from calling a special meeting until the case was resolved. Pershing Square, Allergan’s largest shareholder, is pressing for a special meeting as it pursues a hostile takeover of the company with its partner, Valeant.

headline: Mighty Women Wielding Words (and Swords)
abstract: The Mei Lanfang Jingju troupe celebrates the 120th anniversary of the birth of the genre’s master, Mei Lanfang, at the David H. Koch Theater.
lead_paragraph: During the climactic episode of “Farewell My Concubine,” one of the seminal works of Mei Lanfang, the acknowledged master of the genre of Peking Opera, the beloved concubine of the King of Western Chu entertains her man with a dizzying sword dance. On Wednesday night at the David H. Koch Theater, to open a four-day run of performances to commemorate the 120th anniversary of Mei’s birth, a theater troupe from Beijing performed a trimmed version of this work, starring the captivating Shang Wei as the devoted concubine. During that sword dance, a delighted audience kept breaking into applause as Ms. Shang twirled around in her stunningly colorful costume and headdress, thrusting her sword, tossing it skyward, catching it behind her back, never losing composure, always the picture of stoic, stylized beauty.

headline: Video Nominees Wear Pride (Hats, Too)
keywords: ['MTV Video Music Awards', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Music', 'Television']
abstract: The MTV Video Music Awards’ video of the year nominees have revealing moments about their identities in their work.
lead_paragraph: A LTHOUGH MTV years ago abandoned music videos for reality shows, its annual Video Music Awards remains a barometer of mainstream pop. This year, Beyoncé leads the field with eight nominations, followed by Eminem and Iggy Azalea with seven each. The show, now in its 30th year, will be broadcast from the Forum in Inglewood, Calif., on Sunday at 9 p.m. and will feature performances by Beyoncé, Taylor Swift and Maroon 5. Spontaneous moments in the show have often upstaged the videos. Remember Kanye West interrupting Ms. Swift in 2009 or Miley Cyrus gyrating on Robin Thicke last year? But the five nominees for video of the year (four feature women) each have moments that subtly reveal the musicians’ larger artistic identities.

lead_paragraph: The preservation movement may have been born when Penn Station was demolished in 1963, but it had a long period of gestation. Probably the most regretted structure to be taken down in the years before the station fell was George B. Post’s colossal New York Produce Exchange, on the east side of Broadway, opposite Bowling Green.

lead_paragraph: A Chinese swords-and-martial-arts adventure that takes place during the Ming dynasty, “14 Blades” reframes the wuxia epic as another genre peopled by antiheroes with personal codes of honor: the spaghetti western. It’s not a bad fit.

headline: A Final Frontier in Playful Celebrity Activism
abstract: George Takei, a child of internment camps, the original Mr. Sulu of “Star Trek” and a gay-rights supporter, is profiled in “To Be Takei.”
lead_paragraph: Like other pop culture figures, George Takei — a.k.a. Mr. Sulu on “Star Trek” — cultivated a loyal fan base and became politically engaged. But fleshing out his timeline, as he does in Jennifer M. Kroot’s “To Be Takei,” uncovers something more surprising and even moving: a childhood in a Japanese-American internment camp during World War II; many years in entertainment lived as a closeted gay man; and, more recently, an outspoken stint as a marriage rights activist.

abstract: “Kink,” a documentary directed by Christina Voros, profiles the pornography provider Kink.com.
lead_paragraph: “We don’t fake anything,” a friendly director tells us in “Kink,” a fascinating profile of the online pornography provider Kink.com, the go-to destination for bondage and sadomasochism enthusiasts. But the authenticity of the orgasms is only one of the company’s distinguishing features; in an industry not known for its respectful treatment of performers (known here as “models”), Kink offers a safe, consensual workplace where the submissives are in charge.

headline: Under Cover: Eugenie Bouchard’s Big Moment
abstract: Ruven Afanador photographed Eugenie Bouchard in a studio in Montreal earlier this month. He recently spoke about how he caught Bouchard’s youth and beauty in a single, leaping shot.
lead_paragraph: Eugenie Bouchard is “a player on the brink,” as Susan Dominus puts it in this week’s cover story. To capture the 20-year-old Canadian tennis player in pictures at this moment of promise, the magazine turned to Ruven Afanador. The Colombian-born photographer has previously shot a number of women for the magazine, including Twyla Tharp, Tyra Banks, Anna Netrebko and Ruth Bader Ginsburg. Kathy Ryan, the magazine’s director of photography, calls him a “great portraitist who knows how to bring out the elegance of shape in a photograph.” Recently he spoke about photographing Bouchard in a Montreal studio earlier this month.

The Army Corps of Engineers, which will direct the federally financed project, says it will stabilize Fire Island and reduce the storm surge hazard for the mainland.

headline: An Inky World of Damaged Souls and Demented Evil
abstract: “Frank Miller’s Sin City: A Dame to Kill For” revisits damaged and deadly souls in this stylized marriage of comic-book panels and hard-boiled dialogue, now in 3-D.
lead_paragraph: It has been almost a decade since “Sin City” heaved itself on to our movie screens, a dark parade of ugly mugs and uglier behavior. Back in 2005, the film’s worshipful, impeccable realization of Frank Miller’s graphic novels was divertingly original, even if none of its characters looked quite human or breached two dimensions.

headline: This Is Definitely Not Madison Avenue
abstract: Matthew Weiner’s movie about a playboy weatherman and his pal, “Are You Here,” is nothing like his most familiar work, “Mad Men.”
lead_paragraph: When it played at last year’s Toronto International Film Festival, “Are You Here” was called “You Are Here.” That a statement could become a question — one so tentative it apparently didn’t need a question mark — suggests the uncertain aims of the film, the second feature directed by the “Mad Men” creator Matthew Weiner and the first to receive a theatrical release.

lead_paragraph: According to a recent report in The Times, there is dissent at the Fed: “An increasingly vocal minority of Federal Reserve officials want the central bank to retreat more quickly” from its easy-money policies, which they warn run the risk of causing inflation. And this debate, we are told, is likely to dominate the big economic symposium currently underway in Jackson Hole, Wyo.

headline: A Fast-Food Symbol of America Falls in Moscow
abstract: Many Muscovites believe the Russian government’s decision to close four McDonald’s locations, ostensibly for sanitary reasons, was a political move related to the conflict in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Sanat Parmanova arrived at Moscow’s flagship McDonald’s just off Pushkin Square on Thursday evening as a woman on a mission. Her friend Svetlana Toktorbayeva was carrying a takeout bag of wings from KFC, but Ms. Parmanova had a different dinner in mind: a double cheeseburger, country-style fries, cheese sauce and a medium Coke, no ice.

headline: Marketers Are Sizing Up the Millennials
abstract: Marketers, manufacturers and retailers are recognizing the group’s potential as the consumers who will drive the economy in the decades ahead.
lead_paragraph: Millennials have been called a lot of names. Narcissistic, lazy, indecisive. They have been labeled the boomerang generation for the many unable or unwilling to leave their parents’ home, or even more negatively, the Peter Pan generation because they supposedly won’t grow up.

headline: Get Predatory Colleges Out of Job Training
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Vocational Training', 'For-Profit Schools', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: State and federal labor officials need to monitor more aggressively training institutions that leave students with heavy debts and few prospects for employment.
lead_paragraph: For-profit educational institutions that leave students with heavy debts and worthless credentials do not belong in the nation’s job-training system. Yet institutions like Corinthian Colleges, which reached an agreement last month with the Department of Education to sell or shut down its campuses, have been ripping off students and taxpayers for years by making false promises and cashing in on federal job-training programs. Regulators and lawmakers have been slow to catch on.

headline: In Steps of Grandfather, a German Soldier in France
abstract: A reporter’s grandfather was among the multitudes of German soldiers who stormed into France and Belgium and left some 27,000 French soldiers dead 100 years ago.
lead_paragraph: MERCY-LE-HAUT, France — Most of the buildings in this tiny village in northeastern France are hidden behind trees that were not here a century ago. But the bell tower of the 150-year-old church of St. Salvin is still visible from a gentle rise about a half-mile away, where more than 6,000 German soldiers aimed their guns across a wheat field on the morning of Aug. 22, 1914.

headline: Police, Protesters and Reporters Form Uneasy Cast for Nightly Show in Ferguson
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'News and News Media']

headline: Drought Said to Claim Trillions of Gallons
abstract: About 63 trillion gallons of groundwater have been lost across the West since the start of last year because of a severe drought, a study found.
lead_paragraph: About 63 trillion gallons of groundwater have been lost across the West since the start of last year because of a severe drought, a study found. The loss is not only forcing farmers to drill deeper wells, it has caused the crust of the earth in the region to rise. A study from the Scripps Institution of Oceanography at the University of California, San Diego, found that the earth’s crust, which is normally weighed down by groundwater, had risen 0.15 inches over the last two years. The rise was most drastic in the California mountains, which have risen more than half an inch. The study was first published in the journal Science on Thursday.

headline: Saudi Arabia: Executions Draw Rebukes
keywords: ['Capital Punishment', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Saudi Arabia’s judicial authorities have beheaded at least 19 convicted criminals since Aug. 4, nearly half of them for nonviolent offenses, including one for sorcery, Human Rights Watch said Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia’s judicial authorities have beheaded at least 19 convicted criminals since Aug. 4, nearly half of them for nonviolent offenses, including one for sorcery, Human Rights Watch said Thursday, calling the spate of executions “particularly egregious.” In a report on its website drawn from Saudi government news dispatches, Human Rights Watch said seven convicts were beheaded for drug smuggling, including four in the southeast city of Najran this week. Amnesty International, which also reported on the Najran beheadings, said the four had been forced to confess under torture. Saudi Arabia has executed at least 34 people this year, Amnesty International, said, and it executed at least 79 in 2013. The country has historically rejected international standards for offenses deemed insufficient for capital punishment, applying it to crimes that include adultery, armed robbery, apostasy, drug trafficking, rape and witchcraft.

I don’t think it’s fair to assume that at all. I’m Jewish, so I’m predisposed to assume there’s no chance in hell that’s going to happen.

headline: Serena Williams’s Secret Weapon
abstract: The most important hitting partner in tennis steps out of the shadows.
lead_paragraph: Sascha Bajin — Big Sascha, as he’s known in tennis circles — figures that he spends about 330 days a year with Serena Williams. Usually, when he takes time off, he says, “I tell her not to call me, not to text me, not to contact me at all.” But this summer was different. After a disappointing Wimbledon, in which Williams lost in the third round in singles and retired from a doubles match with her sister Venus, Bajin whisked her away to Croatia for two weeks. When she returned to competition, Williams won the first tournament she played. Accepting the trophy, she dedicated the victory to the 29-year-old Bajin — her longtime hitting partner, a man with perhaps the most specialized job in all of tennis.

headline: Can U.S. Men’s Tennis Rise Again?
abstract: A new generation of juniors might be able to get America back to the top — if they receive the right push.
lead_paragraph: For an American growing up today, it can be difficult to imagine that the United States once dominated the men’s professional tennis circuit. “It would be nice if America actually had a famous tennis player,” said Noah Rubin, an 18-year-old who will make his first appearance in the United­ States Open this week. In 2003, the last year an American man won a Grand Slam tournament — Andy Roddick at the U.S. Open — Rubin was just starting second grade on Long Island. “Any of my friends who aren’t huge tennis fans have barely heard of Andy Roddick,” he said the other day at the club where he trains on Randalls Island. “They’re like, ‘Wasn’t he a male model?’ ” (Close, Rubin’s father said: Roddick is married to a model, Brooklyn Decker.)

headline: Forgotten Postcards From Mexico City
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Deportation', 'Communism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Toys', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: My grandfather’s letters reveal something of the man who never got home.
lead_paragraph: On a handful of Sundays each year, my parents would pack my brother and me into the car with coloring books and crayons and shuttle us to visit my father’s family at his older sister’s home 30 minutes away in the woods of Connecticut. I loved going there, and one reason was the model-train set in the basement. After dutifully sitting with the adults for a while, we’d scramble down the stairs to gather around the oval track, which lay sprawled on a large table. The set had working lights, crossing signals and gates, and telephone wires were strung between poles. The train’s motor whirred as it sped around the tracks — ambling across a field, over a bridge and through a tunnel — and its steady pace always lulled me into a daydream about some future, far-off journey of my own.

headline: Who Made Those Bluejeans?
abstract: Work pants meet horse blankets.
lead_paragraph: In the beginning, there were Levi’s. In 1853, during the heart of the gold rush, a Bavarian émigré named Levi Strauss arrived in San Francisco from New York, looking to expand his family’s East Coast dry-goods business. Among his wares were blankets, cloth by the yard and durable work pants, sometimes called “jeans pants.” Then in 1872, one of Strauss’s customers, a tailor named Jacob Davis, made him the offer that would change his fortunes — and the way Americans dressed — forever. Davis had been buying Strauss’s blue denim and duck cloth to sew “waist-overalls” and had perfected a method of reinforcing them with the same copper rivets he used on horse blankets. Unwilling to put up the $68 necessary to patent his creation, he suggested that Strauss pay the fee in exchange for a half-interest in the business.

headline: My Parents Paid for My Education — Does That Mean I Need to Take a Soul-Crushing Job?
keywords: ['Ethicist, The (Times Column)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Privacy', 'Parenting', 'Student Loans', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Censorship']
abstract: A recent graduate seeks advice; a volunteer committee chair questions the ballots.
lead_paragraph: Thanks to the full financial support of my parents, I recently graduated from an expensive private college in the Northeast with no student debt. After graduation I secured a salaried job with benefits at a large publishing house. I found the work thoroughly soul-crushing, so I quit and began working a number of minimum-wage jobs that do not set me up for any sort of “future.” While I enjoy my current lifestyle, I fear I might be violating an obligation to my parents, since my college degree is irrelevant to these jobs. Do I have an ethical duty to find a better job even if I’m unhappy with the work? NAME WITHHELD, BOSTON

headline: 1914: France Plans to Free Brussels

The Government of the Republic has deemed it right to affirm that the sufferings of the Belgians are also our own. From the day when German soldiers entered Belgian territory, when Belgian blood was shed to resist their passage, the causes of the two countries became indissolubly associated and henceforward they are one and the same. France is resolved to do her utmost to liberate the territory of her ally. She considers that her duty will not be entirely accomplished until there is not a single German soldier left in Belgium. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Aug. 23, 1914

headline: 1939: Franco Gathers Spanish Art
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: General Franco tries to reassemble Spanish art.
lead_paragraph: Art lovers the world over, and especially in France, are watching the progress of one of the biggest jobs the Spanish war left for General Franco to tackle: the reassembling of the dispersed Spanish art treasures. During the war, both sides made efforts to prevent the destruction of works of art in churches, museums and private collections. During the early phases of the struggle, anarchist fanatics defaced many sacred paintings, such as “Jesus and the Virgin,” by Roger Van der Weiden, in the St. Cruz Hospital in Toledo. The Republican authorities took pains to stop this destruction. As Franco’s troops occupied the country’s territory, the authorities immediately organized a service for the protection and reassembling of works of art. These services, directed by Eugenio d’Ors, now are engaged in checking losses and putting together the famous collections which have been dispersed. Some priceless antiques and works of art are definitely lost. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Aug. 23, 1939

headline: Core Success
abstract: Another Keynesian concept that worked.

The truth, as I’ve often tried to explain, is nearly the opposite — at least for those of us who didn’t forget Keynes, and took a more or less IS-LM-is model seriously. We’ve actually had a very good run, successfully predicting the quiescence of interest rates despite huge budget dheficits, the quiescence of inflation despite huge increases in the monetary base, and the adverse effects of harsh austerity policies.

lead_paragraph: By many measures, Jeff Huston and his wife, Lisa Medvedik-Huston, arrived late to Williamsburg, Brooklyn. They weren’t among the first waves of artists and hipsters in the early-to-mid ’90s to cross the East River in search of cheaper, grittier confines. headline: Vegetarian Taco Night
abstract: Summer produce and corn tortillas combine for a bounty of meatless tacos.
lead_paragraph: Taco night is nothing new, but over the last five days, we’ve had taco week. The markets are piled high with irresistible produce — summer squash, tomatoes, green beans, corn, peppers and chiles, greens and herbs – and corn tortillas are a great vehicle for them.We’ve seen enough taco trucks, especially here in Los Angeles, the home of the Korean taco, to know that you can wrap a warm tortilla around just about anything and call it a taco. I leave the kimchi out of my own (though I did make one unconventional filling with tofu, a sort of picadillo cooked and mashed in a salsa ranchera that proved to be irresistible) and stick to the Mexican seasonings I love: chiles and cilantro, cumin and chili powder and salsas. Vegetables were the focus of each filling, and all of this week’s tacos are vegetarian. I combined sweet corn and green beans in one, and roasted peppers, squash and potatoes seasoned with cumin and chile powder in another. I grabbed chard from my garden for a few of the fillings, and made use of this summer’s bounty of squash.I love the flavor of corn tortillas, and they’re a godsend for friends who have trouble with gluten. I buy them in packs of three dozen, then divide the packages so I can freeze them by the dozen because I usually don’t use 36 tortillas in a week (though this week, I did). As for how much filling to count on for each taco, I follow Rick Bayless’s advice and use about a quarter cup. As he says, tacos are as much about the tortilla as they are about the filling, and you wouldn’t want to overwhelm the tortilla any more than you’d want to overwhelm pasta with too much sauce.

headline: A Night Packed With Boulez
abstract: Taka Kigawa, a gifted and daring pianist, will take on the music of Pierre Boulez, the doyen of complexity and kaleidoscopic colors.
lead_paragraph: If anything can cut through the late-August humidity, it’s the bracing music of Pierre Boulez, the doyen of complexity and kaleidoscopic colors. Taka Kigawa, a gifted and daring pianist who specializes in 20th-century and contemporary music, takes on not just some Boulez, but all Boulez: the complete solo piano works, at least, which stretch from the 1940s to the past decade. The program on Monday will include “12 Notations,” “Incises,” “Une Page d’Éphéméride” and all three sonatas, including the fearsomely difficult second, from the late ’40s, with which the pugnacious Mr. Boulez, now 89, aimed to destroy the traditional sonata form. “Sigle,” a rarely performed fragment associated with the third, will be a treat for completists. (7:30 p.m., Le Poisson Rouge, 158 Bleecker Street, near Thompson Street, Greenwich Village; 212-505-3474, lepoissonrouge.com.)

abstract: A summer of trying classical music streaming services meant wonderful music despite some technological complexity.

headline: A 6-Year-Old Shouldn’t Inherit a Stiff Upper Lip
abstract: My mother was sent away from her mother during the Blitz. She was expected to be stoic, and she expected the same from me. Now, I’m trying not to pass her dismissal of all fears on to my daughter.
lead_paragraph: I was slow to see her. But there she was, sobbing, holding on to the hand of a teacher’s aide.

abstract: The New York Times film critics review “Sin City: A Dame to Kill For,” “If I Stay” and “The One I Love.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “Sin City: A Dame to Kill For,” “If I Stay” and “The One I Love.”

keywords: ['Emmy Awards', 'Hamsters', 'Automobiles', 'Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks']
abstract: Kia unveils a new video ad for the 2015 Soul E.V. featuring a shapely she-hamster; Audi releases a star-studded promo for the Emmy Awards.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Emmys 2014: Tunnel Vision vs. Industry Buzz
abstract: Emmy Awards voters describe their approaches to sizing up a vast field of nominees.
lead_paragraph: To people working in television, the Emmy Awards are what street punks were to Charles Bronson movies: the perfect excuse for a little revenge. The 66th annual ceremony, which takes place Monday in Los Angeles, is the TV industry’s one chance each year to strike back at its critics by rewarding itself for a job well done.

headline: In the Style of Transitional Me
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)']
abstract: Leandra Medine, the creator of the blog and website “Man Repeller,” lives with her husband in a rental apartment in the East Village.
lead_paragraph: Nearly three years ago, when Leandra Medine got married and moved out of her parents’ apartment on East End Avenue, she made a vow, a codicil of sorts to the “for richer, for poorer, in sickness and in health” promises that are part and parcel of the wedding package.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘Sin City: A Dame to Kill For,’ ‘If I Stay’ and ‘The One I Love’
abstract: Times critics on “Sin City: A Dame to Kill For,” “If I Stay” and “The One I Love.”
lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, Times critics review “Sin City: A Dame to Kill For,” “If I Stay” and “The One I Love.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: Cooking Techniques: Zesting Citrus Fruit
abstract: Zest lemons, limes, oranges and other citrus fruits to add a floral note to recipes.
lead_paragraph: Zest lemons, limes, oranges and other citrus fruits to add a floral note to recipes.

headline: New York’s Top Jail Investigator Resigns After Inquiry on Rikers Brutality
abstract: Florence L. Finkle’s resignation is the first of many changes expected in response to a federal inquiry that found a “culture of violence” at Rikers Island.
lead_paragraph: The top investigator at the New York Correction Department resigned on Friday under pressure from city leaders who are facing a federal mandate to regain control of the Rikers Island jail complex, where widespread brutality and corruption by guards routinely go unpunished.

headline: Keeping It Green, and Suitable for Ninja Turtles
abstract: The rapper Wiz Khalifa talks about his current projects.
lead_paragraph: As his fans might expect, the rapper Wiz Khalifa was quite pleased to be in Denver, where recreational marijuana is legal and readily available. “I am really excited about it,” he said on Monday, a day before his album release show there. “I brought my own, because I like to smoke what I smoke. But it’s good.”

headline: Facts & Figures: Presidents on Vacation
abstract: So far, President Obama has taken about 150 days off. His predecessor took 879 over four years.
lead_paragraph: President Obama has been criticized for remaining on vacation despite the trouble in Ferguson, Mo., and the news of James Foley’s execution. But compared with other presidents, Mr. Obama hasn’t taken much time off.

headline: Have You Played on an Unusual Tennis Court?
abstract: Have you played on an historic court, a hidden court, or courts located in a surprising or breathtakingly beautiful place
lead_paragraph: Have you played on an historic court, a hidden court, or courts located in a surprising or breathtakingly beautiful place

headline: A Brash Style That Filled Pews, Until Followers Had Their Fill
abstract: Accused of bullying and other abuses, Mark Driscoll, a celebrity in conservative Christianity, is being urged to leave the Seattle megachurch he founded.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Mark Driscoll has long been an evangelical bad boy, a gifted orator and charismatic leader who built one of the nation’s most influential megachurches despite, or perhaps fueled by, a foul mouth, a sharp temper and frank talk about sex.

headline: Richard Handler of Leucadia to Join Board of Ex-SAC Executive’s New Fund
abstract: Richard Handler is joining the board of Folger Hill Asset Management, which was started by Solomon Kumin and Leucadia National.
lead_paragraph: Richard B. Handler, the chief executive of the Leucadia National Corporation, will join the board of a new hedge fund company run by a former executive of SAC Capital Advisors, according to a regulatory filing on Friday.

abstract: The Times critic Jeannette Catsoulis reviews “Sin City: A Dame to Kill For.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Jeannette Catsoulis reviews “Sin City: A Dame to Kill For.”

lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “The One I Love.”
