lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “If I Stay.”

headline: Ai Weiwei and the Apocalypse
abstract: Despite inflated budgets and egos, the art provocateur makes his film acting debut.
lead_paragraph: Jason Wishnow’s short film “The Sand Storm,” starring Ai Weiwei, in its entirety.

headline: Android Phones Hit by ‘Ransomware’
abstract: Hackers have figured out how to lock people out of their Android devices and demand money in exchange for letting them back in.
lead_paragraph: You are guilty of child porn, child abuse, zoophilia or sending out bulk spam. You are a criminal. The Federal Bureau of Investigation has locked you out of your phone and the only way to regain access to all your data is to pay a few hundred dollars.

headline: The Virtues of Green Bell Peppers
abstract: Other cooks are welcome to banish green peppers from the plates. For me, they will always taste of the languor of long summer days and the occasional comfort of small things.
lead_paragraph: Most cooks I know despise green bell peppers. They deride them as bitter, virtually inedible versions of their older, sweeter red or yellow or orange selves. In fact, an article in this very space some five years ago chronicled the one-sided tug of war between the many detractors and few fans of these savory peppers.

headline: Washington Post Editorial Board Joins Other Groups in Not Using ‘Redskins’
abstract: The Post’s editorial board joined newspapers in Seattle, San Francisco and Detroit in refusing to use the football team’s name in its writing.
lead_paragraph: The editorial board of The Washington Post became the latest news group to abstain from using the name Redskins.

headline: Pirouettes at the Tap of a Keyboard
abstract: The Internet abounds with sites offering dance on video. Four critics for The New York Times pick their favorites.
lead_paragraph: The dancegoer of the 21st century no longer needs to go to the dance. Thanks to YouTube, Vimeo and other websites, we have dazzling access — at the touch of fingers or thumbs, on screens held in the palm, on the lap or at the desk — to performances that were unavailable, and to technological treatments that transform dance. No, it’s not the same as being in the same space and moment: The camera’s single eye reduces the spatial complexity of movement, and separate takes chop up its continuity. Here, the dance critics of The New York Times write about a few of the many performances captured in videos.

headline: Lesson From Old India: When an Economy Just Doesn’t Get Better
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Recession and Depression', "Great Depression (1930's)", 'United States Economy', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: The Industrial Revolution left an economic giant in the dust. Today, trade shocks could do the same to some Western countries.
lead_paragraph: Commentators have often compared the recent Great Recession of the United States and Europe to the Great Depression of the 1930s. In both cases, asset prices tumbled, financial systems turned insolvent and demand plummeted. One difference is that in the recent case, we mounted a swifter rescue effort than we did in the 1930s; for instance, Ben S. Bernanke, as chairman of the Federal Reserve in the recent crisis, drew upon his academic research in supporting bailouts and reflating the economy.

headline: A Hoofer for the Ages
keywords: ['Dancing', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: All footage of the great tap- dancer Baby Laurence is rare. But a 1967 TV appearance can be found on YouTube.
lead_paragraph: All footage of the great tap- dancer Baby Laurence is rare. Though he was hugely influential in the 1940s, adapting tap to bebop, this Charlie Parker of the feet was never very famous. Apart from a documentary filmed shortly before his death in 1974, the best and only surviving documentation of his art is an astonishing album he recorded in 1959 — the only documentation, that is, besides a clip you can find on YouTube.

headline: Movement That Streams
keywords: ['Dancing', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: In this age of multitasking, a great virtue of live performance is that you can’t fast-forward.
lead_paragraph: Have you ever tried watching an hourlong dance performance online, start to finish, without interruption? It’s not easy, at least for anyone mildly distractible. As the choreographer Annie-B Parson recently wrote in a Facebook post, “Watching one minute of anything on YouTube feels equivalent to an hour in the three-dimensional world.”

headline: Mixing Body and Lens
keywords: ['Dancing', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Celia Rowlson-Hall’s brand of dance is quirky and unpretentious, the opposite of the hyper-sexualized choreography found in many music videos.
lead_paragraph: The moment the choreographer Celia Rowlson-Hall stepped onto the set of her first music video in 2007, she knew she was home. “Here were all of my loves: of image, of photography, of fashion,” she said. Even though she enjoyed working in the theater, she was inspired. “I thought, ‘Why don’t I bring my dance to film?' ”

headline: Chrysler Owners Sound Off on a Power Defect
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Automobiles', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Stalling, failure to start and inadvertent operation of accessories are among the problems linked to Chrysler’s Totally Integrated Power Module.
lead_paragraph: Before Jeff Marlow bought a 2009 Dodge Journey, he had never heard of anything called a Totally Integrated Power Module. But now, like many consumers, he’s unhappily familiar with the device, which distributes electrical power in the vehicle.

headline: Dieppe After the Battle
abstract: Graphic newsreel footage shot by German soldiers of the aftermath of the Dieppe Raid on August 22, 1942.
lead_paragraph: Graphic newsreel footage shot by German soldiers of the aftermath of the Dieppe Raid on August 22, 1942.

headline: Letters: ‘A Troublesome Inheritance’
abstract: Nicholas Wade responds to a recent letter about his book “A Troublesome Inheritance.”
lead_paragraph: ‘A Troublesome Inheritance’

headline: Where We Enter
abstract: Jacqueline Woodson’s memoir in verse offers poems about sibling rivalry, parents and the friends who help you through.
lead_paragraph: I was 14 years old when I first read Nikki Giovanni’s masterly collection of poetry, “Cotton Candy on a Rainy Day.” As with most everything I read between the ages of 12 and 16, there was so much I didn’t understand. I was the first-­generation daughter of people who came from a small country, a country so small that I had yet to meet someone from there who could not connect the dots to my family in five seconds flat. I didn’t know a thing about Jim Crow, the American South, soul food or classic rhythm and blues. Yet like most kids who love to read, I understood the feeling behind the words, if not all of the meaning of the words. So when Giovanni wrote:

headline: Gateways to the Classical World
abstract: A variety of inventive apps are devoted to Greek, Latin and the history of Greco-Roman civilization.
lead_paragraph: Modern technology has been kind to ancient history. Scholars with iPads and other mobile gadgets can now leave the heavy books at home, opting for a variety of apps devoted to classical studies — Greek, Latin and the history of Greco-­Roman civilization — saving time and money in the process.

headline: ‘For the Common Good of Humankind’
abstract: As portrayed by David Bromwich, Edmund Burke was tolerant and humane.
lead_paragraph: Edmund Burke is enjoying a remarkable revival for a British statesman who has been dead since 1797. The last 18 months or so have brought books by Jesse Norman, Yuval Levin and Drew Maciag — a member of Parliament and two American scholars — placing him in the context of political traditions that endure to this day. Their subtitles tell the story: Burke is “The First Conservative” (Norman) or “The Father of Modern Conservatism” (Maciag) or present at “The Birth of Right and Left” (Levin).

headline: The Mind
abstract: New books by Joseph T. Hallinan, Clifton Crais, Jason Padgett and Maureen Seaberg, Jennifer Ouellette, and Jonathan Rottenberg.
lead_paragraph: KIDDING OURSELVES  The Hidden Power of Self-Deception  By Joseph T. Hallinan  Crown, $25.

headline: Must Love Dogs
abstract: Some are prim and petite, while others are stout and slobbery. But one way or another, these canine characters come out on top.
lead_paragraph: I had trouble sitting down to write this review of three funny and appealing picture books about dogs because my cat refused to get off the keyboard. Even now she sits too close for comfort, flicking her tail resentfully across the screen.

headline: Where the Wicked Things Are
abstract: Two girls (one rich, one poor) trade places on their way to visit the czar in St. Petersburg.
lead_paragraph: Among the many magical or potentially magical objects in Gregory Maguire’s latest novel, “Egg & Spoon,” is a Fabergé egg. Look at one side of the egg and you see the hut of Baba Yaga. Give it a turn and an ancient ice dragon comes into view. Turn it once more and the legendary Firebird is revealed. Each rotation requires a shift in focus, and one story can be viewed only at the exclusion of the others.

headline: Solo Acts
abstract: In three picture books, dancers who prefer to practice alone learn to share their talents with others.
lead_paragraph: Some people are natural performers. Give them a wedding D.J. or a karaoke mike and brace yourself, bystanders: It’s “Love Shack” to the max. Other people, even if they’re secretly talented, need coaxing. The bathroom-shower soprano clams up in public. The dude who rocks the funky chicken behind closed doors folds up his wings and refuses to boogie. The risk of humiliation is simply too great: People may judge. People may laugh. And how do we know that? Because at some point along the way, perhaps when we were very young, someone did judge, or did laugh — and the reflexive urge we felt to shake, rattle and roll? Poof! Extinguished.

headline: On the Syllabus
abstract: Reporters at The Times share their favorite books about education.
lead_paragraph: This week, we ask where the summer went, memorize our new locker combinations and turn our attention to books about the classroom. I asked a few reporters who cover education for The Times to recommend their favorite books about school.

headline: A Unified Theory
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Vikram Chandra, novelist and computer programmer, traces the connections between these two worlds of art and technology.
lead_paragraph: For the last half-century we’ve had a popular notion that our intellectual culture is sundered in two — the literary and the scientific. “The two cultures” is the bumper-sticker phrase for this view. It dates back to a hugely influential 1959 lecture, also published in book form that year, by C. P. Snow — “a moderately able research chemist who had become a successful novelist,” in the historian Lisa Jardine’s not very adulatory description. According to Snow, on one side were the humanists, on the other the scientists, and between them lay a shameful “gulf of mutual incomprehension.”

headline: Publish and Cherish
abstract: The decade-long battle to overcome the ban against James Joyce’s “Ulysses” in America extended the definition of free speech.
lead_paragraph: “O, rocks! she said. Tell us in plain words.” So goes Molly Bloom’s plea to Leo­pold to explain metempsychosis, the transmigration of souls.

headline: To Be Young Again
abstract: Galileo. Newton. Salk. Curie. Science can change the world, but has Ellie’s grandfather gone too far?
lead_paragraph: Who doesn’t enjoy a well-drawn curmudgeon? Children’s books are rife with them. From dour Eeyore moping about the Hundred Acre Wood to the irritable Mary Poppins, they come in all shapes and species. Proudly singular, such cantankerous characters are invariably exasperating, endearing and entertaining all at the same time. And now along comes Jennifer L. Holm with a doozy. Best known for her works of historical fiction, three of which have won Newbery Honors (“Our Only May Amelia,” “Penny From Heaven,” “Turtle in Paradise”), and the graphic novel series “Babymouse,” Holm uses a surprising twist to bring us a particularly memorable grouch in her latest, “The Fourteenth Goldfish.”

headline: The New School
abstract: Two books assess the state of public education and the realities facing instructors today.
lead_paragraph: “Education is not the filling of a pail, but the lighting of a fire.” The greeting-card pithiness of this maxim obscures what is in fact a useful metaphor, and in “Building a Better Teacher,” Elizabeth Green introduces us to educators who stick to their kindling. Her project is both a history of the research on effective teaching as well as a consideration of how that research might best be implemented. What emerges is the gaping chasm between what the best teachers do and how we go about evaluating what they’ve done.

headline: Who Are They Kidding?
abstract: The characters in three books for early readers are propelled by their self-deception and passion.
lead_paragraph: From Amelia Bedelia’s cheery misinterpretations to “Don’t Let the Pigeon Drive the Bus” and its impertinent bird hoping against hope for the impossible, delusions fuel a certain stripe of hero. Early chapter books — and here we have three by much-lauded children’s book authors — offer the perfect bridge between the freewheeling dreams of picture books and the serious narratives of longer fiction. These characters come by their delusions honestly and do not force the issue. And the more we indulge in their scattershot dreams, the more we want to believe in them too.

headline: On the Road
abstract: Raina and her younger sister work out their sibling rivalry on a long and eventful car trip to a family reunion.
lead_paragraph: In “Sisters,” the latest graphic memoir by Raina Telgemeier, it is the summer before high school and Raina is stuck between a squirrelly little brother and a volatile younger sister in a van without air conditioning. They are on a weeklong drive from their home in San Francisco to a family reunion in Colorado Springs, and as temperatures rise, so do tempers. Raina and her sister, Amara, argue over everything, from what to do about a snake on the loose (“What if we shut him in a suitcase till we’re home?”) to their parents’ relationship (“You don’t think Mom and Dad are gonna split up . . . do you?”). Memories of improbable pet deaths, their father’s unemployment and the difficulties of coexisting in a small apartment are woven into the tale of their emotional and sometimes tense journey through the American West.

headline: In Providence
abstract: Memories of Brown University to mark its 250th anniversary.
lead_paragraph: Every kid should have the chance to go to college: America’s future depends on our youth having four years to immerse themselves in experimental literature, plan campus protests, mainline coffee and make out with strangers.

headline: Progress Report
abstract: Dana Goldstein surveys the history of American public education and offers suggestions for its reform.
lead_paragraph: America loves to dream an impossible dream when it comes to education. We see our public schools as the bedrock of the equal-opportunity society we wish to be, the land where a poor boy in a log cabin — or a bungalow in Honolulu — can grow up to be president. And teachers are the angel-magicians who make it all happen.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: KILL MY MOTHER: A Graphic Novel,   written and illustrated by Jules Feiffer. (Liveright, $27.95.) The renowned cartoonist’s terrific tribute to film noir and detective fiction is also a meditation on female identity and the morality of murder.

headline: Of Two Minds
abstract: Joshua Wolf Shenk challenges the notion of the lone genius.
lead_paragraph: The pair is a precious unit — private, generative, even holy. We can explore a couple’s inner workings if we have an invitation to do so. Otherwise, we must use any available external means: letters in archives, revealing anecdotes, loose-lipped quips in interviews. In order to understand creativity, we must learn from couples, Joshua Wolf Shenk argues in his new book, “Powers of Two.” Defying the myth of the lone genius, he makes the case that the chemistry of creative pairs — of people, of groups — forms the primary (albeit frequently hidden) structural basis of innovation.

headline: Not Giving an Inch
abstract: Most of the world is on the metric system; why isn’t America?
lead_paragraph: In the 1970s, children across America were learning the metric system at school, gas stations were charging by the liter, freeway signs in some states gave distances in kilometers, and American metrication seemed all but inevitable. But Dean Krakel, director of the National Cowboy Hall of Fame in Oklahoma, saw things differently: “Metric is definitely Communist,” he solemnly said. “One monetary system, one language, one weight and measurement system, one world — all Communist.” Bob Greene, syndicated columnist and founder of the WAM! (We Ain’t Metric) organization, agreed. It was all an Arab plot “with some Frenchies and Limeys thrown in,” he wrote.

headline: Sonic Youth
abstract: Making new friends at school can be tough, but doing so while wearing a bulky hearing aid? That requires superpowers!
lead_paragraph: In this appealing graphic memoir by the children’s book author and illustrator Cece Bell, young Cece is only 4 when she comes down with meningitis. She survives, but her hearing doesn’t. At first, like any newly and suddenly deafened person, she retreats into herself, scared and confused (“I stay close to Mama, no matter where she is”).

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE RESIDUE YEARS,  by Mitchell S. Jackson. (Bloomsbury, $17.) Told in chapters that alternate between mother and son, Jackson’s raw, autobiographical novel describes a black family in Portland, Ore., struggling with the cycles of poverty and addiction. Grace, just out of rehab, is determined to get her kids back. Her eldest, Champ, is in college but deals crack, convinced it’s the only way to achieve his dream.

headline: Learning Democracy
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: A professor surveys youth uprisings in the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: It isn’t easy to track down a positive word about the Middle East these days. Then again, Juan Cole is not your typical observer. A professor of history at the University of Michigan, he is also a prolific and popular blogger on current affairs. An American, he spent part of his childhood in France and Ethiopia. A left-leaning idealist, he comes across as far more optimistic than the dour Occupy crowd. A cosmopolitan in constant touch with 20-somethings, he seems to be addressing boomers in his latest book, “The New Arabs,” which is replete with explanations that digital natives would never need. (Don’t know what the “meatspace” is? Read on.)

headline: Uncram
abstract: Drudgery may not be the key to success, research shows.
lead_paragraph: A spate of recent best sellers has trumpeted a supposedly surprising secret to success, both in school and in life. It’s called hard work.

headline: Wild on the Inside
abstract: In this young adult novel, a teenager indulges a rebellious streak lurking beneath her “apple pie” appearance.
lead_paragraph: Fifteen-year-old Anika Dragomir throws her arms around us and draws us in from the very ­beginning of Andrea Portes’s “Anatomy of a Misfit”: “You’re never gonna believe what happened,” she announces.

headline: Bookshelf: Back to School
abstract: New picture books include Adam Auerbach’s “Edda: A Little Valkyrie’s First Day of School.”
lead_paragraph: New picture books include Adam Auerbach’s “Edda: A Little Valkyrie’s First Day of School.”

headline: Big Ticket | A San Remo Record for $26.4 Million
keywords: ['Luxury Goods and Services', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: A combined unit with prime Central Park views at the venerable San Remo was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.
lead_paragraph: A rambling combination unit with prime Central Park vistas at the venerable San Remo, a 1929 showpiece designed by Emery Roth and lauded as the city’s first twin-tower residential high-rise, sold for $26.4 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Restaurant Report: Travail Kitchen & Amusements in Robbinsdale, Minn.
abstract: At this spot, where a co-owner has appeared in a chicken suit and cooks sometimes sing, the playful spirit also finds its way to the plate.
lead_paragraph: As Styx’s “Mr. Roboto” filled the dining room, a man in a full-bodied yellow chicken suit, with only his face showing, pushed out a small chariot-like vehicle; in it was a man dressed in a robot suit tossing bags of popcorn to waiting hands. The chicken clucked into a microphone and held it toward diners sitting at long communal tables, who clucked back with enthusiasm.

headline: Dollywood: A Little Bit Country, a Little Bit Gay
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Travel and Vacations', 'AMUSEMENT AND THEME PARKS']
abstract: Views of Dolly Parton’s wildly popular theme park in Tennessee can differ significantly depending on one’s lens.
lead_paragraph: At Dollywood, the place on a Venn diagram where gay camp and Southern camp overlap, cinnamon rolls might be the great equalizer.

headline: Readers Respond: On European Anti-Semitism
abstract: A new wave of anti-Semitic incidents in Europe and a recent surge in global anger at Israel’s military action in Gaza inspired wide-ranging debates about global Jewish identity and the Israeli state.
lead_paragraph: A new wave of anti-Semitic incidents in Europe and a recent surge in global anger at Israel’s military action in Gaza inspired wide-ranging debates about global Jewish identity and the Israeli state in reader responses to two recent Op-Ed articles.

headline: Dynegy’s Deals Mark Return of Ambition
keywords: ['Electric Light and Power', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Dynegy’s deals look sensible, says Christopher Swann of Reuters Breakingviews, but the lesson from their bankruptcy is to avoid getting carried away.
lead_paragraph: Dynegy only got out of bankruptcy two years ago. Now two deals worth $6.25 billion, announced on Friday, mark a return of ambition for the power company. It once tried to buy Enron and eventually went bust after a spat involving activist Carl C. Icahn. The purchases look sensible, but the lesson from Dynegy’s past is to avoid getting carried away.

headline: Blamed for Rise of ISIS, Syrian Leader Is Pushed to Escalate Fight
abstract: Accused of allowing ISIS to amass territory in Syria, President Bashar al-Assad is now being pressed by his own supporters to make defeating the jihadist group a priority for his forces.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The extremist militants of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria have attacked Syrian troops with new ferocity in recent weeks, taking over three northeastern military bases, beheading scores of soldiers and seizing new territory.

headline: Records Smashed as Usual, but Surprises as Well
keywords: ["Pebble Beach Concours D'Elegance (Car Show)", 'Antique and Classic Cars', 'Auctions', 'Automobiles']
abstract: Few things played out exactly as expected during classic-car week at Pebble Beach, like a post-World War II car winning Best of Show. Still, auction results hit a record.
lead_paragraph: PEBBLE BEACH, CALIF. — Whispers and educated guesses dominated conversations among classic-car followers for much of this summer: How much would it bring?

headline: Show-Stoppers
abstract: The auctions held during Pebble Beach week brought in a record $430 million, topped by the $38 million paid for a Ferrari 250 GTO.
lead_paragraph: The auctions held during Pebble Beach week brought in a record $430 million, topped by the $38 million paid for a Ferrari 250 GTO.

headline: Administration Proposes New Health Rules Addressing Religious Objections
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Religion-State Relations', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Family Business']
abstract: The Obama administration on Friday offered compromises intended to address objections by some nonprofit groups and private companies over providing contraceptive coverage.
lead_paragraph: EDGARTOWN, Mass. — The Obama administration on Friday proposed new regulations intended to address the religious objections that some nonprofit organizations and private companies have to providing contraceptive coverage for their employees.

headline: Is the Player Nervous? Just Ask His Shirt
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Wearable Computing', 'Tennis', 'United States Open (Tennis)', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Ball boys at the United States Open will try out T-shirts with conductive threads that can monitor their breathing and heart rate.
lead_paragraph: TENNIS HAS an emotional impact that isn’t confined to the court. Consider the ball boy, who speeds the game along by retrieving stray balls for the players.

headline: Pie-in-the-Sky Flying Cars From the Past
abstract: Tinkerers have tried to make cars fly since the early 20th century, with mixed results. Here are a few of them.
lead_paragraph: Wizards and tinkerers have labored to make cars fly since the early 20th century, with mixed results. Some designs had detachable wings and tail ends for highway cruising; others used mechanisms to fold the wings for driving. Here is sampling of some noteworthy creations:

headline: Vaylon Pegase
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Inventions and Patents', 'Gliders, Hang Gliding and Paragliding']
abstract: The Pegase mates a paraglider with a lightweight off-road vehicle.
lead_paragraph: Infiltration, extraction, recognition and rescue may not be the first words that flying cars bring to mind, but Jérôme Dauffy, founder of Vaylon in Strasbourg, France, is taking a pragmatic approach to marketing the Pegase. Though the Pegase, which mates a paraglider with a lightweight off-road vehicle, might seem to appeal to thrill-seekers like mountain climbers trying to reach remote peaks, Mr. Dauffy has played up its strategic capabilities to attract military and security business.

headline: Terrafugia Transition
abstract: The current version of the two-seat Transition has been in flight and road testing for two years. Its fuel-injected 4-cylinder Rotax 912iS engine produces 100 horsepower.
lead_paragraph: The ideal flying car might take to the roads and the skies with equal aplomb, but Carl Dietrich, a co-founder of Terrafugia in Woburn, Mass., is unapologetic about the raison d’être of his company’s Transition. “We think of it as a street-legal airplane,” he said.  “It’s an airplane that has the capability of driving safely on roads and highways and parking in a single-car garage.”

headline: Wheels and Wings
abstract: The quest to create a flying car is almost as old as the airplane and automobile.
lead_paragraph: The quest to create a flying car is almost as old as the airplane and automobile.

headline: Why We’re Not Driving the Friendly Skies
abstract: The dream of creating a flying car has reduced many would-be inventors to despair as they grasped the immensity of the engineering and design challenges of the divergent natures of airplanes and cars.
lead_paragraph: A number of us can thank a cartoon character from the future, George Jetson, for instilling our longing. Students of aviation history might look for inspiration to the Autoplane prototype built in 1917 by the flight pioneer Glenn Curtiss. And tens of millions of motorists who have been stuck in traffic jams stretching toward the horizon must also feel a need to know: Where are the flying cars?

headline: Aeromobil 2.5
abstract: A flying car from Czechoslovakia has been gestating since 1990.
lead_paragraph: In 1989, the Velvet Revolution deposed Czechoslovakia’s Communist government. The founders of the Slovakian company Aeromobil, who grew up behind the Iron Curtain dreaming of freedoms in the West, say their flying car offers the possibility of further liberation. “Currently we are in the very same situation when it comes to traffic,” said Stefan Vadocz, the company’s head of communications. “We are trapped in traffic, and we think traffic needs a revolution.“

headline: U.S. Finds ‘Backoff’ Hacker Tool Is Widespread
abstract: The Department of Homeland Security said on Friday that more than 1,000 businesses had been infected with the cash register malware used in the Target data breach and others, leading to the theft of data from millions of customers’ payment cards.
lead_paragraph: More than 1,000 American businesses have been affected by the cyberattack that hit the in-store cash register systems at Target, Supervalu and most recently UPS Stores, the Department of Homeland Security said in an advisory released on Friday.

headline: The Sinister Sinks Deeper Into the Fun
abstract: The revival of “Pippin” has evolved into a warmer, giddier show, but the darkness is still there, beneath the surface.
lead_paragraph: The acrobats still dazzle, the music still swells, but the chill has gone out of the room, and the menace is harder to find. Diane Paulus’s dynamic, high-flying revival of “Pippin” has become a warmer, giddier show in its 16 months at the Music Box Theater, and that’s really not a bad thing at all.

headline: Beyond Potluck: A Bean Salad Worth the Shucking
abstract: A harmonious bean salad delicately dressed in a Japanese-inspired vinaigrette.
lead_paragraph: I have had a lifelong fling with beans. It all began with green beans “almondine.” At our house, fresh-frozen French-cut beans, cooked to the perfect shade of bright green, were heaped with slivered almonds sizzled in margarine, That was a little bit of heaven.

headline: Revisit the Golden Days of Long-Form With Lewis Lapham
abstract: The legendary writer and editor shares stories about the Beatles in India, the inept White House press corps under President Johnson and the future of the written word.
lead_paragraph: In a recent podcast for Longform.org, Evan Ratliff of The Atavist spoke to the American journalism legend Lewis Lapham about the golden days of long-form, playing the piano for Thelonious Monk and his accidental career transition from writer to editor.

headline: A Porsche Reunion With a Personal Connection
keywords: ['Antique and Classic Cars', "Pebble Beach Concours D'Elegance (Car Show)", 'Automobiles']
abstract: A reporter’s 1958 Porsche Speedster that he raced decades ago turned up this month, restored, in California during Pebble Beach week.
lead_paragraph: CARMEL, CALIF. — A whole new world, one that included learning the difference between a racing driver and a driver of racing cars, came full circle here on the Central Coast last week, where I was reintroduced to my 1958 Porsche Speedster after more than half a century.

headline: Dangers Abound for Thousands Taking to the Ocean in Search of Safety
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Rohingya (Ethnic Group)', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Tens of thousands of people seeking refuge are fleeing by boat across the Indian Ocean, risking death, malnutrition and brutal treatment, the United Nations says.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The United Nations refugee agency sounded the alarm on Friday over tens of thousands of people, many of them Muslim Rohingyas from Myanmar, who are fleeing by boat across the Indian Ocean in search of asylum and in the process facing death, malnutrition and brutal treatment at the hands of traffickers, and often ending in detention in South East Asian countries or Australia.

headline: Julien Farel: Hair Today, Hair Tomorrow
abstract: Mr. Farel, a hairstylist who is running a pop-up salon for athletes at the United States Open, spends his Sundays with his wife and daughters at their East Hampton home.
lead_paragraph: The hairstylist and entrepreneur Julien Farel owns four salons, including the 10,000-square-foot flagship at the Loews Regency Hotel on Park Avenue, which opened in April. For the United States Open, which begins tournament play on Monday, there is a fifth salon, albeit temporary, at Arthur Ashe Stadium, where participants can have their hair cut, braided, pulled back or trimmed — whatever they need to be court- and camera-ready. Boldface names like Novak Djokovic and Victoria Azarenka are tended to personally by Mr. Farel. When New York’s Grand Slam event is not in session, Mr. Farel, 45, a native of France, and his wife, Suelyn, 45, the chief executive of the Julien Farel Group, retreat on weekends to their East Hampton home with their daughters, Chloe, 8, and Manon, 6.

headline: Red Hook’s Cutting-Edge Wireless Network
abstract: In an isolated Brooklyn area that was hit hard by Hurricane Sandy, a nonprofit group is working on a digital network that residents can use whether or not Internet service is available.
lead_paragraph: Robert Smith, a 19-year-old in a gray T-shirt and camouflage pants, climbed the stairwell of the Joseph Miccio Community Center in Red Hook, scaled a ladder at the top floor and jumped onto the roof. He soon found what he was looking for: bright, white plastic boxes, each about the size of a brick, some with little antennas sticking out. Mr. Smith pulled a laptop from his backpack and got to work, tending to the nodes of the Red Hook mesh, an ambitious plan to link up a local wireless digital network across the neighborhood.

abstract: I Am a Boys Choir swims with the orcas, sort of, in “So Long, Willy (Let’s Go Home).”
lead_paragraph: Anything can inspire a work of art, but two copulating orcas — one inflatable, the other an actual person wearing a whale suit — seem like a joke that hardly bears repeating. Nevertheless, the idea for the performance work “So Long, Willy (Let’s Go Home)” began after Adam Rigg, a director of the interdisciplinary group I Am a Boys Choir, came across a clip on the Internet of a person in an orca suit delicately grinding against an inflatable orca. headline: Unrest in the Midwest
abstract: How pro-Confederate conspiracies in the 1864 Midwest helped win the elections for the Republicans.
lead_paragraph: On Aug. 20, 1864, Oliver P. Morton, the governor of Indiana, received an anonymous letter in his Indianapolis office. The letter, postmarked from Buffalo, tipped him off to the arrival of arms and ammunition shipped secretly from the East Coast. The guns were intended, it said, for “antagonists of our Govt” who planned to foment unrest before the coming presidential election. The informer gave details about the whereabouts of shipments from a New York City arms dealer in boxes marked “stationary” [sic].

headline: T Women’s Fall Fashion Issue
abstract: In our fall women’s fashion issue, T celebrates the quiet rebels leading the way in fashion and the culture at large.
lead_paragraph: In our fall women’s fashion issue, T celebrates the quiet rebels leading the way in fashion and the culture at large. We start with Sarah Burton, the shy and unassuming designer who is embracing her independent streak four years after the death of her mentor and close friend, Alexander McQueen. We remember the French icon Loulou de la Falaise, whose effervescent personality and inimitable style brought out the best in her close collaborator Yves Saint Laurent, and manifested in her own designs too. We visit Federico Forquet at home in Tuscany, where the former couturier long ago put fashion in the rearview to focus on a career in interior design and gardening. And in Elena Ferrante, a novelist so elusive that no one knows what she — or he, as the case may be — even looks like, we examine the nature of literary stardom and the value of unbiased self-reflection. Elsewhere, Claire Messud visits the provocative South African-born painter Marlene Dumas at her studio in Amsterdam; T’s critic-at-large Jody Rosen heads into the Mojave Desert to investigate the Integratron, a U.F.O.-like structure that serves as a Mecca for spiritual seekers; Jenna Lyons and Courtney Love rock out to Beats and try on the latest Dior heels; and a new generation of female directors step out from behind the camera, revealing the personal experiences and passion for original filmmaking that led them to take on the Hollywood status quo. See all stories from the issue >>

headline: Saudis Must Stop Exporting Extremism
abstract: We would not face the barbarism of ISIS without their sponsorship of Salafi Islam.
lead_paragraph: ALONG with a billion Muslims across the globe, I turn to Mecca in Saudi Arabia every day to say my prayers. But when I visit the holy cities of Mecca and Medina, the resting place of the Prophet Muhammad, I am forced to leave overwhelmed with anguish at the power of extremism running amok in Islam’s birthplace. Non-Muslims are forbidden to enter this part of the kingdom, so there is no international scrutiny of the ideas and practices that affect the 13 million Muslims who visit each year.

(Sundance) BLUE VELVET (1986) The director David Lynch uncovers savagery and perversity behind the bland facades of a small town in this film, for which Mr. Lynch received a best director Oscar nomination. Kyle MacLachlan plays Jeffrey Beaumont, a dull American teenager who discovers a severed ear and sets out to find its owner. Along the way, he witnesses terrible and beautiful things — including Dennis Hopper, at his most unhinged, and Dean Stockwell, deranged and in pancake makeup, lip syncing Roy Orbison’s “In Dreams” into a table lamp. Isabella Rossellini, above, smolders as the abused nightclub singer who becomes the object of Jeffrey’s desire. “For those with the temerity to follow it anywhere, ‘Blue Velvet’ is as fascinating as it is freakish,” Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. “It confirms Mr. Lynch’s stature as an innovator, a superb technician and someone best not encountered in a dark alley.”

He and his team at the University of Texas Medical Branch in Galveston are currently working on developing vaccines to treat these diseases, which have mortality rates as high as 90 percent.

headline: The Debate on Salty Foods, Continued
abstract: The question now is whether too little sodium is putting people at risk.
lead_paragraph: For years, there have been contentious debates over reducing the amount of salt in the American diet. Now warring studies in The New England Journal of Medicine have brought new evidence to bear.

headline: The Golf Address
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Kidnapping and Hostages', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: From the great battlefield of Farm Neck Golf Club in Martha’s Vineyard, a few words of national import.
lead_paragraph: FORE! Score? And seven trillion rounds ago, our forecaddies brought forth on this continent a new playground, conceived by Robert Trent Jones, and dedicated to the proposition that all men are created equal when it comes to spending as much time on the links as possible — even when it seems totally inappropriate, like moments after making a solemn statement condemning the grisly murder of a 40-year-old American journalist beheaded by ISIL.

headline: Order vs. Disorder, Part 3
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States International Relations', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: The inequality of freedom is causing instability and chaos as it expands around the world.
lead_paragraph: THE United States is swamped by refugee children from collapsing Central American countries; efforts to contain the major Ebola outbreak in West Africa are straining governments there; jihadists have carved out a bloodthirsty caliphate inside Iraq and Syria; after having already eaten Crimea, Russia keeps taking more bites out of Ukraine; and the U.N.’s refugee agency just announced that “the number of refugees, asylum-seekers and internally displaced people worldwide has, for the first time in the post-World War II era, exceeded 50 million people.” If it feels as though the world of disorder is expanding against the world of order, it’s not your imagination. There’s an unfortunate logic to it.

headline: Dealing With Digital Cruelty
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Cyberharassment', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Writing and Writers', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)']
abstract: The web encourages bad behavior, and it’s part of our nature to focus on the negative. But there are smart ways to respond.
lead_paragraph: ANYONE who has ever been online has witnessed, or been virtually walloped by, a mean comment. “If you’re going to be a blogger, if you’re going to tweet stuff, you better develop a tough skin,” said John Suler, a professor of psychology at Rider University who specializes in what he refers to as cyberpsychology. Some 69 percent of adult social media users said they “have seen people being mean and cruel to others on social network sites,” according to a 2011 report from the Pew Research Center’s Internet and American Life Project.

headline: Bug Love
abstract: Only a very small percentage of insects are pests, and most are quite beneficial.
lead_paragraph: LARAMIE, Wyo. — IT’S summertime, the season of insects, and if you spend any time outdoors (or even indoors), you’ve probably been swatting and stomping your way toward fall. Mosquitoes and midges dance over ponds, butterflies and bumblebees tussle on daisies, crickets and katydids trill melodies, moths zigzag around lights leaving dusty trails.

headline: My Daughter, Her Rat
abstract: A rodent helped calm my teenager’s anxiety.
lead_paragraph: Somehow, we have to get Eden, my daughter’s pet rat, from Brooklyn to Portland, Ore., where Olivia will start college next month. Like E. B. White’s Stuart Little, Eden has become part of our family, a kind of miniature sibling to my only child, who is about to leave home. Eden is one of a klatch of pet rats we know (picture three young women and their animals at our kitchen table, eating tacos, our two cats asleep in a corner). According to Robert Sullivan’s book “Rats,” “fancy” descendants of the homely gray Rattus norvegicus had an earlier moment as women’s companions during the Victorian era. Is Eden part of a revival zeitgeist thing, a moment soon to be documented by pop culture media?

headline: Why Interest Rates Need to Stay Low
abstract: The economy still doesn’t have the growth and jobs to justify a rate increase.
lead_paragraph: A sharp debate within the Federal Reserve over when to raise interest rates was publicly aired last week at the annual central bankers’ conference in Jackson Hole, Wyo. On one side is a small yet vocal minority of Fed officials who want to head off inflation by raising rates sooner rather than later. On the other is a majority that thinks a near-term rate hike would stifle growth and, with it, any chance of restoring health to the labor market. That group includes Janet Yellen, the Fed’s chairwoman, and most members of the Fed’s policy committee.

headline: On Not Writing
abstract: Just as the body needs time to rest, so too does an essay, or a book.
lead_paragraph: I started writing this essay five years ago, and then I stopped. That I was not able to finish the piece did not strike me at the time as ironic but as further proof that whatever I once had in me — juice, talent, will — was gone. In any case, completing it would have made moot the very point I was attempting to make: Not writing can be good for one’s writing; indeed, it can make one a better writer.

headline: Underdogs Who Make the Most of a Chance
abstract: Matt Shoemaker of the Los Angeles Angels was not drafted out of Eastern Michigan University, but he represents the kind of surprise contributor most winning teams need to have.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles Angels arrived at Fenway Park on Monday in a tie with the Oakland Athletics atop the American League West. After four victories in a row, they left on Thursday alone in first place before their weekend matchup at Oakland. But they also left without Garrett Richards, their most reliable starting pitcher.

headline: Populist’s Brash Tactics Stir Fears of Crisis in Pakistan
abstract: Imran Khan, the former cricketer turned opposition leader, led thousands of supporters to the capital a week ago, but his protest movement has been messy and inconclusive.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Only last year, Imran Khan was casting himself as the savior of Pakistani politics: a playboy cricketer turned opposition leader who enjoyed respect and sex appeal, filling stadiums with adoring young Pakistanis drawn to his strident attacks on corruption, American drone strikes and old-school politics. When Mr. Khan promised that he would become prime minister, many believed him.

headline: Pakistan and India Trade Fire
abstract: The volume of shelling has increased in recent days along the border in the Jammu region, forcing villagers to flee their homes.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Indian and Pakistani forces exchanged heavy fire along the border in the region of Jammu early Saturday, resulting in reported deaths of civilians on both sides, and forcing villagers to flee their homes.

headline: A Driving School in France Hits a Wall of Regulations
keywords: ['Drivers Licenses', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Tests and Examinations', 'Drivers Education']
abstract: Experts say the struggle of two entrepreneurs highlights how the myriad rules governing driving schools — and 36 other highly regulated professions — stifle competition and inflate prices in France.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Alexandre Chartier and Benjamin Gaignault work off Apple computers and have no intention of ever using the DVD player tucked in the corner of their airy office. But French regulations demand that all driving schools have one, so they got one.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Aug. 24
abstract: James Foley’s execution at the hands of Islamic militants set off a firestorm in the United States. The American response to I.S.I.S. will dominate the Sunday conversations.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, James Foley, an American journalist, was executed at the hands of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria. President Obama said the entire world was “appalled” by Mr. Foley’s beheading, as American warplanes conducted more than a dozen airstrikes in Iraq.

keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Demonstrators on Staten Island protested the chokehold death of an unarmed black man who was in the custody of police officers trying to arrest him for selling loose cigarettes.
lead_paragraph: Demonstrators on Staten Island protested the chokehold death of an unarmed black man who was in the custody of police officers trying to arrest him for selling loose cigarettes.

headline: China Denies Confrontation With U.S. Surveillance Plane
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Military Aircraft']
abstract: The Chinese government rejected the Pentagon’s claim that a People’s Liberation Army fighter jet had buzzed dangerously close to an American surveillance plane in international air space on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Chinese government rejected the Pentagon’s claim that a People’s Liberation Army fighter jet had buzzed dangerously close to an American surveillance plane in international airspace, and it warned that frequent surveillance flights were risking an accident near the Chinese coast.

headline: Cavaliers Complete Deal to Acquire Kevin Love From Timberwolves
abstract: LeBron James got a superstar teammate, and Minnesota received Andrew Wiggins and Anthony Bennett.
lead_paragraph: When LeBron James decided to rejoin the Cleveland Cavaliers this summer, it was a foregone conclusion that the move would have an enormous effect on the N.B.A. for years to come. Such is the power that James wields, and as the start of training camp approaches — a little more than a month from now — the ripples continue to lap at the league’s shores.

headline: Dozens Rally for Officer in Ferguson Killing as Funds Are Raised Online
keywords: ['Crowdfunding (Internet)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Supporters of Officer Darren Wilson gathered on Saturday in St. Louis as a campaign to raise money for his relocation and legal expenses surpassed $300,000.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — An online fund-raising drive for the Ferguson, Mo., police officer who shot an unarmed African-American teenager to death on Aug. 9 surpassed $300,000 by Saturday afternoon, as dozens of people gathered at a St. Louis pub to rally on the lawman’s behalf.

headline: On Staten Island, Thousands Protest Police Tactics
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: A demonstration on Saturday was, as planned, a peaceful response to the killings of Eric Garner and Michael Brown.
lead_paragraph: They came by ferry from Manhattan, in caravans from Brooklyn and New Jersey or on foot from the gritty neighborhood in northeast Staten Island where an unarmed black man, Eric Garner, died last month after an encounter with the police.

headline: Gay-Themed Events Part of the Game
abstract: Gay-themed sporting events were once considered political statements and occasionally drew protests, but they have now become a seasonal staple, particularly in baseball.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Friday night was not much different from most others at Dodger Stadium. An actor, Jesse Tyler Ferguson, threw out the ceremonial first pitch. A recording artist, Mary Lambert, sang the national anthem. And there was not much more hand-holding than usual among couples during the postgame fireworks show.

headline: John F. Akers, 79, Dies; Led IBM as PCs Ascended
abstract: Mr. Akers became chief executive in 1985, as smaller, less expensive computers started to undercut the company’s lucrative mainframe computer business.
lead_paragraph: John F. Akers, the chief executive and chairman of IBM during a turbulent time when the rise of the personal computer undercut the profitability of the mainframe computer business, died on Friday in Boston. He was 79.

headline: After Joe Torre Is Honored, the Yankees Gain a Win
abstract: Torre became the 18th person to have his number retired by the Yankees on Saturday, and the team followed up the ceremony by beating the Chicago White Sox.
lead_paragraph: It was just before the start of the 1996 baseball season, and Joe Torre, who had just been hired to manage the Yankees, needed a new uniform number.

headline: A Challenging Dinner, Layer by Layer
abstract: Jean Paul Lourdes, who trained as a biochemist in France and then worked as a perfumer in Switzerland before he became a chef, is close to creating a world-class eating experience at Restaurant Latour in Sussex County, N.J.
lead_paragraph: About a half-mile away from a restaurant called “That Italian Joint,” and down the road from the disaster-courting Action Park, sits Restaurant Latour, a rarefied establishment where matcha green tea cocktails are served with yuzu bubbles and local pickled elderflowers grace buttermilk granita.

headline: Venturing Beyond the Usual Bar Food
abstract: Little Pub, which opened in June 2009 in Ridgefield, is true to its name in size and ambience, and its menu is full of flavorful surprises.
lead_paragraph: When Douglas and Daneen Grabe named their new restaurant Little Pub, they were not kidding about the size. This Ridgefield restaurant, which opened in June 2009, is tiny, seating a mere 25 to 35 diners inside, giving it a built-in noisiness. The good news is that an attached screened porch (seating 35 to 40) makes conversation possible while dining.

headline: A Bit of the Bosporus
abstract: Turkuaz Grill, a four-year-old restaurant in Riverhead, serves Mediterranean cuisine at modest prices in a region almost entirely bereft of authentic ethnic food.
lead_paragraph: Of restaurants on the East End, few have better word of mouth than Turkuaz Grill, a four-year-old establishment serving Mediterranean cuisine in the revitalized town of Riverhead. Locals speak of it with reverence; the superlatives can get a little mushy. At the same time, this is a land almost entirely bereft of authentic ethnic food, and its inhabitants are desperate for menu options beyond “grilled” or “blackened.”

headline: TV Chief Takes 2-by-4 to a Proposed Cable Merger
abstract: Patrick Gottsch, the chairman of the Rural Media Group, has become one of the most vocal critics of Comcast’s proposed $45 billion purchase of Time Warner Cable.
lead_paragraph: MEDINA, Minn. — As the oom-pah-pah oom-pah-pah of the band fades, Patrick Gottsch makes his way through silver-haired couples circling the dance floor at “The Mollie B Polka Party” in this quiet Midwestern town.

headline: Second Shift
abstract: Thank goodness. After the Saturday madness, a Patrick Berry puzzle that makes sense.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — I don’t know about you, but it was a huge relief to do Patrick Berry’s puzzle after the Saturday puzzle where I thought I was losing my mind. I feel like I have my sanity back and all is right with the world. Heaven knows what Will Shortz and his constructing cabal have in store for us next week.

headline: Best Woman to Ever Play Chess Retires From Competition
abstract: Judit Polgar of Hungary announced that the Chess Olympiad, which ended last week in Norway, would be her last tournament as a professional.
lead_paragraph: The best woman to ever play chess has called it a career.

headline: The Flow of Money and Equipment to Local Police
abstract: Following two weeks of images from protests in Ferguson, Mo., where police officers deployed military gear and equipment to quell unrest, President Obama ordered a review of several federal programs that provide money and equipment to local police.
lead_paragraph: Following two weeks of images from protests in Ferguson, Mo., where police officers deployed military gear and equipment to quell unrest, President Obama ordered a review of several federal programs that provide money and equipment to local police.

headline: Papier-Mâché Heads and a Surprise Guest
abstract: In the first of a three-night stand at Barclays Center on Friday, Arcade Fire hit high marks with durable standards, and an arch shrug and wolfish grin toward some critics.
lead_paragraph: Misdirection, the essential tool of magicians and hustlers, served no less tactical a purpose for Arcade Fire in Brooklyn on Friday, in its first of three nights at the Barclays Center. At the top of the encore, a fake four-piece band calling itself the Reflektors — in oversize papier-mâché heads, suitable for a carnival — popped up on a platform in the middle of the arena to mime a version of “Personality Crisis,” by the New York Dolls.

headline: Response to Attack Reflects Iraq’s Sectarian Divide
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Sunni Muslims', 'Shiite Muslims', 'Legislatures and Parliaments']
abstract: Sectarian rifts have grown so deep in Iraq that they could prevent the formation of a new government, a move seen as a vital step toward halting the advance of ISIS.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Iraq’s politicians were struggling to meet the constitutional deadline to form a new government when, in an isolated village, two masked men stepped into a Sunni mosque and opened fire on Friday, killing dozens of worshipers.

headline: Thousands in Texas Lose Cars Amid Calls for Loan Restrictions
abstract: A lack of statewide regulation on so-called payday and auto-title loans is being acutely felt by low-income borrowers.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN — Tiffany Richardson had a job as a nurse, money in savings and no reason to imagine she would ever need to swap her car title for a quick loan.

headline: A Waste Solution May Lean Again on a Low-Income Area
keywords: ['Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Recycling of Waste Materials']
abstract: Many of Houston’s waste facilities are in predominantly minority neighborhoods, and critics of a city proposal for sorting waste say it could land on a familiar spot.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The McCarty Road Landfill is an unwelcome mountain in this flat city: The giant mound covered by sand and grass towers over the Settegast neighborhood of Houston.

headline: Israeli Strike Destroys Apartment Tower in Gaza
abstract: The attack signaled Israel’s willingness to take more audacious military action in Gaza, as Palestinian militants continued to fire barrages of rockets and mortar rounds into Israel.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — An Israeli missile strike on an 11-story apartment tower in Gaza City brought the entire building crashing down on Saturday, soon after its residents were told to evacuate, according to residents and the military. The attack signaled Israel’s willingness to take more audacious military action in Gaza, as Palestinian militants continued to fire barrages of rockets and mortar rounds into Israel.

headline: County Casts Long Shadow, Even to Perry
abstract: Travis County, Tex., with its authority to police state officials, has gone after some of the state’s most powerful figures, most recently Gov. Rick Perry, and been accused to confusing crime and politics.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: An Opera Comes to El Paso by Way of Bhutan
abstract: An unusual production of Handel’s English-language opera “Acis and Galatea” represents the latest expression of a century-old link between the University of Texas at El Paso and the Himalayan kingdom.
lead_paragraph: When the University of Texas at El Paso stages its free performance of Handel’s English-language opera “Acis and Galatea” this Saturday, it will mark the latest expression of a century-old connection between El Paso and Bhutan.

headline: Homage to the Flavors of Far Southern Italy
abstract: The menu at Massa’ Coastal Italian Cuisine in Mamaroneck is organized in a way that pays homage to the Italian homeland of the co-owners and co-executive chefs, Pasquale Coli and his son Francesco Coli.
lead_paragraph: It’s exciting to find an Italian restaurant with a menu that promises to deliver the rich flavors of Southern Italy, specifically Puglia’s Salentine Peninsula, the area at the heel of Italy’s “boot.” The kitchen of Massa’ Coastal Italian Cuisine in Mamaroneck is influenced by the produce from the peninsula’s inland farmsteads (or masserias) and by the plentiful seafood fished from the adjoining Adriatic and Ionian Seas.

headline: The New Man Bringing the Bard to Boscobel
abstract: Davis McCallum, the new artistic director of the Hudson Valley Shakespeare Festival, has been immersing himself in the company and its work.
lead_paragraph: Davis McCallum just happened to be in the neighborhood, on the western fringes of Manhattan’s theater district. He had a design meeting that morning at Playwrights Horizons about “Pocatello,” a new play by Samuel D. Hunter, which Mr. McCallum described as being set entirely in an Olive Garden restaurant. But that was not what he had come to talk about.

headline: After His Mother Gives Him a Lift to the Course, a Player Makes a Leap
abstract: A year after a collapse at the Barclays, Morgan Hoffmann drew support from his friends and his mother as he spent the week in the area where he grew up in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: PARAMUS, N.J. — By the time Morgan Hoffmann made his way up the 17th fairway, looking at a birdie putt for a share of the lead, a sizable crowd had begun to form and people were already whispering to one another, “You know he’s from Wyckoff?”

Four years ago, a late rush by a horse named Fly Down looked to have caught Jerkens’s colt Afleet Express at the finish line.

headline: 1889: Sarah Bernhardt’s Courage in Real Death Scene
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: The actress Sarah Bernhardt faces the funeral of her husband in 1889.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Bernhardt, who has so wonderfully impersonated death in all its phases, has just had a painful experience of its dread reality on the occasion of the funeral of her husband, M. Damala. A report was spread by the Rappel to the effect that when the body was carried down to the ground floor of the house, the coffin was found to be too small, and it took an hour to make it large enough. During this operation, said the report, the body was placed in an armchair, and Mme. Bernhardt had the courage to support the head on her shoulder the whole time. The sight was blood curdling, and created a sad impression on those present. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Aug. 25, 1889

headline: In a Stepfamily, Whose Fairness Wins Out?
keywords: ['Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Families and Family Life', 'Parenting']
abstract: In my new husband’s family, what was “fair” in family life was governed by seniority. I preferred to rely on egalitarian turn taking. “Fair” turns out to be subject to interpretation.
lead_paragraph: Years ago, when Bob (now my husband) and I were cohabiting but not yet married, we started taking our children to Florida over April vacation to take advantage of my mother’s unused timeshare week. My daughter, Katy, was around 7 at the time, and Bob’s two youngest girls, Whit and Hilly, were teenagers. The layout of our condo featured, on the beach side, a spacious master suite with a king-size bed and a balcony. Its distinct Yin, at the other end of the unit, was a rayless chamber with twin beds and a view of the parking lot. Per my advance request, the housekeeping crew had stuffed a rollaway bed into the room before we arrived. The three girls were squeezed together like industrially farmed piglets.

headline: 1964: Paris Celebrates 20th Anniversary of the Liberation
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: In 1964, Paris celebrates the 20th anniversary of its 1944 liberation.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — ‘‘Why are the bells ringing, Herr General?’’ a young German secretary asked Dietrich von Choltitz, commander of German forces in Paris, 20 years ago tonight. Turning to his guest at the final dinner of the German headquarters staff in the Hôtel Meurice, on the Rue de Rivoli, Gen. Choltitz replied: ‘‘They are tolling for us. They are announcing the arrival of the enemy armies in Paris.’’ Led by the 13-ton bell of Notre Dame Cathedral, church bells in Paris resounded again in unison tonight as they did on Aug. 24, 1944, after four years of silence under the German occupation. In the continuing ceremonies marking the anniversary of the liberation, Parisians again gathered tonight on the Place de la Concorde. The program included a giant fireworks display. Two orchestras provided music for dancing until dawn. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, August 25, 1964

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 4:30 P.M. (Starz) BLUE JASMINE (2013) Woody Allen’s film about a Manhattan socialite brought low is his “most sustained, satisfying and resonant film since ‘Match Point,’ ” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. The socialite is Jasmine (Cate Blanchett, whose performance won her an Oscar for best actress), an Upper East Sider whose husband, Hal (Alec Baldwin), had been sent to prison for financial crimes. Jasmine, suddenly penniless, seeks shelter and comfort with her sister (Sally Hawkins, above center, flanked by Ms. Blanchett and Andrew Dice Clay) in San Francisco. Slowly, in flashbacks, Mr. Allen reveals why Hal went to prison, what happened to him and who’s been most victimized. The more you learn about the people on screen, the worse you feel for them.

headline: The Death of the One-Handed Backhand
abstract: One of the most beautiful strokes in tennis is in danger of disappearing entirely.
lead_paragraph: Back in January, when Stan Wawrinka won the Australian Open, it was the first time in more than four years that someone not named Federer, Nadal, Djokovic or Murray captured a grand-slam championship. This was heartening for tennis fans, who have grown tired of watching the so-called Big Four dominate the sport for the last decade. But for a small and perhaps dwindling set of tennis aesthetes, it was noteworthy for a less obvious reason. Wawrinka, a 29-year-old Swiss player, uses one of the prettiest strokes in tennis: a singular display of agility, balance and precision timing known as the one-handed backhand. It is far superior for slice, or underspin; it is also much better for drop shots and volleys and for retrieving difficult-to-reach balls. Good players can conjure exquisite angles with it.

headline: Strokes of Genius: The Best of the Men
abstract: In a poll of leading coaches, players and analysts on the best strokes in men's tennis, the usual suspects were all there, but so were some outsiders.
lead_paragraph: Determining the best players in tennis seems a straightforward matter of consulting the rankings and the tournament results. Determining the best strokes in tennis remains a more subjective affair even with the recent growth in statistics and analytics. More than two dozen leading coaches, players and analysts were asked to list at least three top men and women in each category. Extra weight was given to those with firsthand experience. For example, Ivo Karlovic, one of the world’s best servers, seems particularly well qualified to determine top returners. The men who have hoarded Grand Slam titles over the past decade dominated these rankings, and though this is far from Serena Williams’s finest season, she made a strong showing in many categories.

headline: Beijing Film Festival Is Shuttered Again
abstract: The 11th edition of an independent film festival set to begin on Saturday in Beijing was shuttered before the cinema doors were even open.
lead_paragraph: The 11th edition of an independent film festival set to begin on Saturday in Beijing was shuttered before the cinema doors were even open. The Chinese authorities confiscated documents and films and briefly detained organizers of the Beijing Independent Film Festival, The Associated Press reported. The festival has faced numerous hurdles over the years, including a power failure in 2012 that organizers attributed to the government. This year, however, was different, Wang Hongwei, the festival’s artistic director, told The A.P. “In the past few years, when they forced us to cancel the festival, we just moved it to other places, or delayed the screenings,” he said. “But this year, we cannot carry on with the festival. It is completely forbidden.” Mr. Wang and Li Xianting, the founder of the festival’s organizing group, were arrested on Saturday night but later released.

headline: Martha Graham Dance Announces Season
abstract: Architectural influences will provide the framework of the Martha Graham Dance Company’s 2014-15 season, organizers announced on Sunday
lead_paragraph: Architectural influences will provide the framework of the Martha Graham Dance Company’s 2014-15 season, organizers announced on Sunday. Titled “Shape&Design,” the company’s two-week season at the Joyce Theater (Feb. 10-22) will explore the structural aspects of works by Graham and others. Highlights include new commissions by Kyle Abraham, Michelle Dorrance, Liz Gerring and Sonya Tayeh. In honor of the 85th anniversary of Graham’s “Lamentation,” each choreographer will contribute a work for “Lamentation Variations,” a series that began in 2007 and features pieces inspired by Graham’s signature solo. The season also plans to feature works exemplifying Graham’s collaborations with the sculptor Isamu Noguchi. In addition to the Joyce season and a 20-city tour, the troupe is scheduling performances at various New York locations throughout the fall and winter. The Graham Deconstructed series, which takes audiences behind the scenes, begins with Peter Sparling’s look at the 1953 piece “Voyage” (Sept. 16 and 17), followed by a company performance of “Appalachian Spring” (Oct. 30) to celebrate the 70th anniversary of its premiere; both will be at the Martha Graham Studio Theater in the West Village. The Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology will host a performance on Oct. 28 in conjunction with its “Dance and Fashion” exhibition, which includes several Graham Company costumes. And from Dec. 10 through 13, Hauser & Wirth will host the dancers as part of that Chelsea gallery’s Thomas Houseago exhibition. More information is at marthagraham.org.

headline: Soho Rep Plans Varied Productions
abstract: Soho Rep will take audiences from a South African kitchen to a Brooklyn laundromat in its 2014-15 season.
lead_paragraph: Soho Rep will take audiences from a South African kitchen to a Brooklyn laundromat in its 2014-15 season, the theater is to announce on Monday. The season will open with the United States premiere of Debbie Tucker Green’s “Generations” (Sept. 30-Oct. 26), a coproduction with the Play Company that centers on three generations of a South African family preparing a meal. The play will reunite Ms. Tucker and Leah C. Gardiner, the writing-directing team behind the Obie-winning 2011 production of “Born Bad.” The new year will begin with “Winners and Losers” (Jan. 2-Feb. 1), directed by Chris Abraham. The work is about two friends — portrayed by the play’s creators Marcus Youssef and James Long — who are forced to take a frank look at their lives through a made-up game. In May, Soho Rep will welcome the world premiere of Anne Washburn’s “10 Out of 12.” Directed by Les Waters, the production is about making a play and about how work shapes us. The season will wrap up with “Washeteria,” taking place in an unused storefront in South Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Created by Louisa Thompson, with Sarah Benson and Adrienne Kapstein, the play is a compilation of episodes created by cast members and a team of second-graders, with each story lasting about the length of a wash cycle. More information is at sohorep.org.

headline: 1939: Roosevelt Sends Peace Appeals
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Roosevelt insists he doesn’t consider the war imminent in 1939.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In an ultimate attempt to use his influence for peace, President Roosevelt addressed peace appeals early this morning [Aug. 25] to Chancellor Adolf Hitler and President Ignace Moscicki of Poland. The messages, which were not identical, suggested three possible methods of arriving at a peaceful solution of the dispute between the two countries: direct negotiation, submission of the dispute to neutral arbitration, agreement to solve the controversy through the procedure of conciliation. The President suggested that the parties select as conciliator or mediator a national of one of the traditionally neutral states of Europe or of the American republics. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Aug. 26, 1939

It’s modeled on an authentic Middle Eastern tabouli, which should be all about the parsley, with just a small amount of bulgur. I add just one cup of cooked farro or spelt to a generous mix of chopped parsley, mint, arugula and other herbs like basil or dill. headline: Long-Simmered Eggplant Stuffed with Farro or Spelt
abstract: This take on imam bayildi becomes more of a stuffed eggplant dish when cooked farro is added to the tomato-onion mix. Make it a day ahead of time for best results.
lead_paragraph: This is a riff on imam bayildi, the long-cooking eggplant dish bathed in tomatoes and onions that is one of the great achievements of Turkish cuisine. I added cooked farro to the tomato-onion mix, making this more like a stuffed eggplant dish. The active cooking time is minimal, but the smothered eggplant must simmer for about 1 1/2 hours to achieve the intense, syrupy sauce and deep, rich flavor that make this dish such a wonder. Make it a day ahead for best results, and serve at room temperature on a hot night.

The cooked farro or spelt should be soft, so make sure to simmer until the grains splay.

Sitting in the back room of the pop-up Nike Court in TriBeCa, the 44-year-old tennis icon is all cool, effortless swagger. “It feels full circle,” Agassi says of re-signing with Nike in late 2013 after an eight-year hiatus. “It feels like I’m coming home.” Since becoming a brand ambassador for the company, Agassi has brought back his signature sneaker, the Air Tech Challenge, and partnered on the Designed to Move initiative, which seeks to get kids motivated to exercise.

headline: A Frog That’s a Living, Breathing Pac-Man
abstract: The South American horned frog has a powerful tongue with which it can pull in more than its body weight. The tongue’s structure intrigues scientists.
lead_paragraph: The South American horned frog is a sit-and-wait predator. It huddles close to the ground or partly buried, well camouflaged, and waits until a juicy cricket or other prey wanders too close.

headline: Yellen, Wages, and Intellectual Honesty

It found a new home in May when St. Mark’s Church in-the-Bowery offered its space starting in September. The company has lately been fitting the space with offices, dressing rooms, a sprung floor, mirrors, barres and a lobby, and on Monday it announced that its educational arm, Ballet School NY, would offer an expanded schedule of classes for both adults and children, starting Sept. 15. The company also announced its 2014-15 season, which as in past seasons, has it performing in several spaces around town.

headline: Ryan McGinley Shoots a Short Film for Monique Péan

lead_paragraph: Each season, the designer Monique Péan visits a different destination to source materials and ideas for her fine-jewelry collection. The latest line out this fall, titled “Lahnse,” had its genesis in Norway and Iceland, whose rugged landscapes provided both stones (such as labradorite) and inspiration for the pieces’ geometric shapes. When Péan won a CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund contest — for which Kate Spade New York partnered with the designer to produce a campaign to appear in the September issue of Vogue — she enlisted the artist Ryan McGinley, who “is amazing at shooting in nature,” she says. “The sense of exploration captured in Ryan’s work aligns with my design process of traveling the world.” The black sand and rock formations at Iceland’s Vík Í Myrdal beach, one of the shoot locations, also made their way into an accompanying short film, which, like the campaign, features the model Liya Kebede. (The location also figured prominently in the recent indie film “Land Ho!,” whose directors shared a travel diary with T.) Here, a first look at the clip.

Amid promises to admit more poor students, top colleges educate roughly the same percentage of them as they did a generation ago. This is despite the fact that there are many high school seniors from low-income homes with top grades and scores: twice the percentage in the general population as at elite colleges.

headline: A New Boutique in New Orleans Co-Owned by Solange Knowles
abstract: The colorful fashion and design emporium Exodus Goods, which has been flying under the radar since it opened in April, launches e-commerce this week.
lead_paragraph: Though it opened its doors in April, the only thing the New Orleans boutique Exodus Goods has done to announce its existence until now is hang a colorful wooden sign outside its French Quarter storefront. The sisters Darlene and Lizzy Okpo, along with the co-owner Armina Mussa, have deliberately managed to keep word of their project confined mostly to their cult Instagram following — despite the fact that the store’s fourth partner and creative director is Solange Knowles. Chalk it up to being in New Orleans, where “the pace of life is slower,” Lizzy Okpo explains. “We’ve developed a feeling of building things organically until they’re right.” Now, however, with the launch this week of Exodus Goods’ new e-commerce site, the secret is out.

headline: Sales Droop for ‘Hedwig’ After Harris Departs
abstract: Ticket sales fell (to a still-healthy level) after Andrew Rannells replaced Neil Patrick Harris in “Hedwig and the Angry Inch.”
lead_paragraph: Ticket sales came back to earth last week for the Broadway musical “Hedwig and the Angry Inch,” which had been breaking box office records at the Belasco Theater this summer thanks to the drawing power of Neil Patrick Harris, who won a Tony Award in the title role. Mr. Harris’s run in the show ended Aug. 17 and Andrew Rannells, an original star of “The Book of Mormon” who is also known from the HBO series “Girls,” has taken over as Hedwig. For Mr. Rannells’ first week, the musical grossed $648,738 – a healthy amount, though far less than the $1,139,903 for the previous week with Mr. Harris. Mr. Rannells is scheduled to star through Oct. 12.

headline: Haunting Atmosphere of Whispers and Enigma
abstract: As part of the Mount Tremper Arts Summer Festival, the dancer and choreographer Mina Nishimura offered two new works inspired by the words of Tatsumi Hijikata.
lead_paragraph: MOUNT TREMPER, N.Y. — We tend to think of dance as nonverbal, but what about the words that go into passing it from person to person, generation to generation? Tatsumi Hijikata, who founded the Japanese movement art Butoh in the 1960s, left behind a wealth of words when he died, in 1986, texts that can be as unsettling to read as Butoh is to watch. In an essay, the filmmaker and critic Nanako Kurihara describes the “strange, equivocal” images that populated his writings: “rotting space,” “dribbling candy.” A corporeal response to the emotional wreckage of postwar Japan, Butoh channeled those images through the flesh.

headline: Fungus Turns Ants Into Zombie Booby-Traps
abstract: A fungus uses the carpenter ants it kills to get at other potential victims in the colony.
lead_paragraph: A fungus compels infected ants to die near their colonies, ensuring access to a steady stream of new victims, researchers say in PLOS One. Before killing a carpenter ant, the fungal parasite prompts it to climb vegetation in rain forests. After the ant dies, it stays attached to the leaf, from where the fungus can drop spores on unsuspecting passers-by.
