headline: Rashaad Newsome Marries Voguing With Art History
abstract: The artist hosted an event in Riverside Park in Manhattan that asked dancers to evoke seminal artistic periods, from the Renaissance to Abstract Expressionism.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday, the artist Rashaad Newsome hosted the second edition of the King of Arms Art Ball in Riverside Park in Manhattan. The event consisted of a series of performances that married the elements of a vogue ball with art historical moments. In one segment, dancers were asked to show their moves while wearing looks inspired by the drapery seen in Renaissance painting; in another, they were challenged to embody the qualities of Abstract Expressionism. An all-star jury that included ballroom legends like Meeka Prodigy and Héctor Xtravaganza awarded prizes. The photographer Dina Litovsky was on hand to capture the action.

lead_paragraph: It was a tale of neighborliness and of a New York as many New Yorkers wish it to be. On a Friday evening in August 1997, Nick Drakides was walking home from work. When he arrived at his apartment building at 124 East Fourth Street in the East Village, he found Laraine Goodman, a neighbor he barely knew, tap-dancing on the sidewalk out front. She knew he had a big music collection, and she asked him to provide some accompaniment. He brought out CDs, a microphone and an amplifier and started crooning Frank Sinatra songs. A crowd began to gather.

headline: The Many Looks of Afropunk Festival 2014
abstract: From the sounds to the faces to the clothes, diversity ruled the day at the Brooklyn music and arts event.
lead_paragraph: Ten years ago, the first Afropunk Festival hosted a free concert to 100 or so revelers at BAMcafé in Fort Greene, Brooklyn. Now, the event has grown into one of New York’s biggest and most spirited summer happenings. This past weekend, acts such as SZA, Sharon Jones & the Dap-Kings and D’Angelo drew crowds in the tens of thousands to Commodore Barry Park, near the Navy Yard. Diversity ruled the day, from the sounds onstage to the faces in the crowd to the wildly styled looks on parade. As expected, fairgoers brought their fashion A game, sporting elements of Africana, hip-hop, punk rock and sportswear — often all together in a single outfit. The photographer Daniel Lord was on hand to capture the action.

headline: Oklahoma: Suit Seeks Reporting Access at Executions
keywords: ['Capital Punishment', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Witnesses']
abstract: Reporters should have the right to witness executions in Oklahoma from start to end, a federal suit filed in Oklahoma City on Monday by the American Civil Liberties Union contends.
lead_paragraph: Reporters should have the right to witness executions in Oklahoma from start to end, a federal suit filed in Oklahoma City on Monday by the American Civil Liberties Union contends. The suit was prompted by the bungled execution of Clayton D. Lockett on April 29, where witnesses were not allowed to watch as officials spent 51 minutes struggling to insert catheters into Mr. Lockett’s veins and where witnesses had their view blocked again after Mr. Lockett began to writhe and moan. “At the moment when public oversight was most important,” the suit states, citing the First Amendment and Oklahoma law, “the state unlawfully shrouded its execution proceedings in secrecy.”

headline: E-Cigarette Use Said to Rise Among Tobacco-Free Youths
abstract: The number of middle school and high school students in the United States who say they have tried e-cigarettes but not traditional cigarettes increased by about 60 percent from 2012 to 2013.
lead_paragraph: The number of middle school and high school students in the United States who say they have tried e-cigarettes but not traditional cigarettes increased by about 60 percent from 2012 to 2013, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said Monday. An estimated 263,000 middle and high school students used e-cigarettes but had never smoked regular cigarettes, up from about 160,000 in 2012 and about 79,000 in 2011. Youth smoking rates dropped by half from 1997 to 2011, according to federal data, but the pace of the decline has slowed. Many health advocates worry that e-cigarettes may lead teenagers to use conventional cigarettes.

headline: Scotland: Rivals Clash Again in Independence Debate
abstract: The leading rivals on the issue of whether Scotland should vote for independence from the United Kingdom clashed Monday in their second and final televised debate ahead of next month’s independence referendum.
lead_paragraph: The leading rivals on the issue of whether Scotland should vote for independence from the United Kingdom clashed Monday in their second and final televised debate ahead of next month’s independence referendum. During an acrimonious 90-minute exchange, Alex Salmond, the first minister of the Scottish government and a longtime proponent of independence, appeared to gain the upper hand over his opponent, Alistair Darling, a former chancellor of the Exchequer and a member of the Labour Party, accusing him of siding with the austerity policies of the conservative government in London: “You’re in bed with the Tory Party,” Mr. Salmond said. The question of which currency an independent Scotland would use if Britain refused to share the pound again featured prominently, and Mr. Darling repeatedly challenged Mr. Salmond to reveal his “Plan B.” Mr. Salmond, who had been on the defensive on this point during the first debate, was better prepared this time. Refusing to be drawn in a debate over an alternative, he said that it was in the best interests of Scotland to continue to use the pound and that he wanted a mandate from the Scottish people to negotiate a currency union after a vote for independence.

Founded by the Noma chef Rene Redzepi and his team in 2011, the annual gathering has matured from a party for like-minded chefs to a themed conference that informs conversations in kitchens worldwide. Last year’s theme, “Guts,” was co-curated by Momofuku’s David Chang and saw a roster of international presenters speak, both metaphorically and literally, about the subject. headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10:05 A.M. (Flix) THE DANGEROUS LIVES OF ALTAR BOYS (2002) In Jeff Stockwell’s screen adaptation of Chris Fuhrman’s novel, directed by Peter Care, the teenage friends Francis Doyle (Emile Hirsch) and Tim Sullivan (Kieran Culkin) cope with the anxieties of education, puberty and first love by writing a series of superhero comics. “The masterstroke of this small, heartfelt directorial debut,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times, “is its integration of animated sequences (by Todd McFarlane) in which action-adventure caricatures of the comic book characters parallel or comment on events in the boys’ lives.” Those lives are darkened as the film progresses, most affectingly by a story of familial abuse shared by Francis’s new girlfriend, Margie Flynn (Jena Malone). Jodie Foster plays Sister Assumpta, an especially reviled teacher at the boys’ Roman Catholic school. Mr. Holden wrote: “Ms. Foster, who seems to grow primmer with each film, locates the compassion beneath her character’s grim, authoritarian surface. Like tiny ripples on a pond, her face registers the concerns of a caring surrogate parent committed to practicing an austere form of tough love.”

headline: A Design Lover’s Guide to the Modern Jaipur
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: The 19th-century city has spawned numerous 21st-century pleasures, from sumptuous design objects to gorgeous, laboriously produced rugs to a one-of-a-kind resort.
lead_paragraph: Jaipur is like the elusive mistress you can’t get enough of. Considered to be India’s first planned city, it was painted an autumnal shade of pink to coincide with the visit of the Prince of Wales (King Edward VII) in 1878. But time and traffic have turned the pink into a shade of sandstone orange, and today, the city straddles eras. Run-down palaces pop up at random street corners. Ornately carved domes rise up against glass monoliths. Global ideas mingle with generations-old handicrafts, from block printing to brass beating. A stroll around the 18th-century Palace of the Winds (Hawa Mahal), which overlooks the city’s main arterial road, gives you a sense of the throbbing cosmopolis Jaipur has become. Here, the top spots to visit in all directions.

There are, for example, frequent police raids on homes of suspected Uighur insurgents and executions of those found guilty by courts of “terrorist activities.” There was also a recent proposal by President Xi Jinping to move more Uighurs to parts of China dominated by the Han, the nation’s main ethnic group, so the mostly Muslim Uighurs could be better assimilated into Chinese society.

headline: 1964: Goldwater Fishing in Pacific
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Senator Goldwater took days off by the sea before entering the presidential race in 1964.
lead_paragraph: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif. — Sen. Barry Goldwater arrived here last night [Aug. 26] for six days “to fish and not shave and have a good time.” Within two hours, the Republican presidential nominee, his wife and two other couples were at sea aboard the converted PT boat Sundance for a “no politics” pre-campaign holiday off the California coast. The senator was hardly at sea, however, before his boat returned to the harbor off Santa Catalina island for a waterborne news conference. Sen. Goldwater said that no peace negotiations which involve the United States “directly or indirectly” in Vietnam should be held until the military situation improves. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Aug. 27, 1964

abstract: Climate science homes in on the oceans’ role in driving wiggles in global warming.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 6:30 p.m. | Earth’s climate is shaped by the interplay of two complicated and turbulent systems — the atmosphere and oceans. (The photo above is from the two years I spent at that interface as crew on ocean-roaming sailboats.) The oceans hold the majority of heat in the system, are full of sloshy cycles on time scales from years to decades and, despite an increase in monitoring using sophisticated diving buoys, remain only spottily tracked.

The attackers were believed to belong to the Kurdistan Workers’ Party, a militant group known as the P.K.K. It has waged an insurgency for decades against the Turkish state but has more recently been engaged in peace talks with it. Xinhua, the Chinese state news agency, said the engineers appeared to have been working Sunday evening at a thermal power plant belonging to a private company in Sirnak Province, near the Iraqi border, when the attack occurred. The P.K.K., which the United States, Turkey and the European Union consider a terrorist group, is based in northern Iraq, and has recently joined forces with Kurdish pesh merga fighters in their struggle against extreme Islamic militants gaining ground in Iraq.

headline: South Sudan: U.N. Helicopter Goes Down, Killing Three in Crew
abstract: A United Nations helicopter carrying cargo in South Sudan crashed on Tuesday, killing three of its four Russian crew members, the United Nations Mission in South Sudan reported.
lead_paragraph: A United Nations helicopter carrying cargo in South Sudan crashed on Tuesday, killing three of its four Russian crew members, the United Nations Mission in South Sudan reported. The aircraft, a Russian Mi-8 used by the United Nations under a contract with a Russian company, was lost near Bentiu, in oil-rich Unity State, where rebels and government forces have been fighting. United Nations officials said they were investigating and had no immediate comment on a rebel commander’s assertions that his fighters had shot down the helicopter with a rocket-propelled grenade. News of the crash came a day after representatives of both sides signed an agreement in Ethiopia committing them to work toward a cease-fire and a national unity government, a step that was welcomed by Secretary General Ban Ki-moon. South Sudan has been in turmoil since December because of fighting between government soldiers loyal to President Salva Kiir and rebels loyal to former Vice President Riek Machar.

headline: Nebraska: Ex-Federal Official Guilty in Pornography Case

lead_paragraph: Timothy DeFoggi, the former acting director of cybersecurity for the Department of Health and Human Services, was convicted in Nebraska on Tuesday on federal child pornography charges. Mr. DeFoggi, 56, was arrested as part of a continuing investigation into three child pornography websites, on one of which he registered as a member. Evidence showed he gained access to and solicited child pornography and wrote of his interest in the rape and murder of children, once suggesting meeting another member to fulfill that fantasy. Mr. DeFoggi is scheduled to be sentenced in November.

lead_paragraph: Capt. Walter F. Mazzone played a pivotal role in two underwater Navy exploits during the 20th century. In World War II, he kept a waterlogged submarine from going belly up while it was carrying 40 Americans rescued from the Philippines. Twenty years later he helped organize the first Sealab tests of human endurance at crushing ocean depths — conducting the first tests on himself — which established the deepwater diving protocols still used by military and commercial divers today.

The cruiser had gone to the rescue of the Union-Castle liner Galician, from The Cape, which had been captured about ten days ago by the Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse off Ferro, Canary Islands, as a result of a trick.  — The New York Herald, European Edition, Aug. 28, 1914

Under it, they produce provocative and modern images for commercial and editorial clients spanning from Gucci and DeBeers to Vice magazine. Last year the pair created their first issue of Herring & Herring magazine, a text-free monograph devoted to fashion photography, which they published under the title “Fit to Print” and sent out to industry colleagues and friends.

headline: André 3000 Is Moving On in Film, Music and Life
abstract: With a starring movie role and Outkast anniversary appearances, André 3000 has not been as reclusive as it might have seemed.

And on Sept. 26, he’ll star, under his original name, André Benjamin, as Jimi Hendrix in “Jimi: All Is by My Side,” a biopic about the year just before Hendrix’s breakthrough, when he moved to London, underwent a style transformation and squared off against Eric Clapton.

headline: 1939: Lights of Rome Darkened
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Italy prepares for war in 1939.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Dim lights on alternate lampposts and a sharp falling off in the number of private automobiles on the streets gave Rome this evening [Aug. 27] its first outward signs of war preparations. Apart from this, the Italian capital was still conspicuous among the great cities of Europe for the unchanged tempo of its life. Thousands of citizens are away for their annual month’s vacation and have not come back. Thousands of others passed the day sunning themselves on the beach of Ostia, Rome’s seaport and bathing resort. Beneath this tranquil surface, however, both military preparations and diplomatic activity are proceeding. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Aug. 28, 1939

headline: Looking to the Future of Data Science

headline: Painting Partners
abstract: Two new books present the artists Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera in striking ways.
lead_paragraph: If they hadn’t existed in real life, Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera might well have been dreamed up by a writer of children’s books. There was Diego, round and enormous, sought out by world leaders and captains of industry for his equally outsize talent, able to sit on a scaffold for 36 straight hours painting murals intended to change the course of history. There was Frida, tiny and broken-bodied, enduring physical agony to paint the story of her inner life with a sensuous fury that brought her international renown. Then there was their love and marriage, as passionate and treacherous as any romance between two Greek demigods.

headline: In Dublin, Shopping Away From the Crowds
abstract: Drury Street is just blocks from the city’s main shopping avenue, but the comparatively smaller strip has less congestion and a more authentic feel.
lead_paragraph: Drury Street in the heart of Dublin is just a few short blocks from Grafton Street, the city’s main shopping avenue, but the comparatively smaller strip has a more authentic feel. Instead of international chain stores and tourist-heavy congestion, there are fewer crowds and a diverse mix of locally owned boutiques housed in low brick buildings and selling everything from home goods to Irish art. It’s a favorite destination for locals who come for the far from ho-hum finds.

headline: A Taste for Lunch in Ashland, Ore.
abstract: In this southern Oregon town, which draws at least 300,000 visitors each year, some restaurants are focusing on the midday meal.
lead_paragraph: On a recent summer afternoon, it was a busy scene outside the Ashland Food Co-op, where the lunch menu is the biggest draw. On a small triangle of grass a barefooted young woman in a grass skirt did a rather frantic and awkward hip dance while her shirtless tattooed partner played the bongos. Two gray-haired men wearing button-downs ate salad at an outdoor table and argued about Richard Blanco, the Inaugural poet in 2013 who gave a reading here last year.

headline: Medicare: Not Such a Budget-Buster Anymore
abstract: Estimates of future medical spending keep falling. The changes are projected to save taxpayers hundreds of billions of dollars.
lead_paragraph: You’re looking at the biggest story involving the federal budget and a crucial one for the future of the American economy. Every year for the last six years in a row, the Congressional Budget Office has reduced its estimate for how much the federal government will need to spend on Medicare in coming years. The latest reduction came in a report from the budget office on Wednesday morning.

headline: Kevin Spacey to Sing in Benefit Concert

You might also have caught his performance of “Mind Games” in “Come Together: A Night for John Lennon’s Words and Music,” a 2001 television tribute taped at Radio City Music Hall. There is, apparently, plenty more where that came from: Mr. Spacey plans to set aside his current Washington persona, as the nefarious Frank Underwood on “House of Cards,” and sing a full concert there on Sept. 29 at Shakespeare Theater’s Harman Hall.

headline: A Proenza Schouler Alum Launches a Line Made From Traditional Guatemalan Textiles
abstract: Harare, designed by Caroline Fuss, is the latest fair-trade label to combine indigenous craft with contemporary design.
lead_paragraph: Caroline Fuss had just completed a Proenza Schouler design internship when she visited Guatemala for the first time in 2011. Impressed by the quality and intricacy of the weavings in the village markets she visited, the Australian-born, New York-based designer set out to build a sustainable fashion line that would utilize and promote what she saw as an untapped textile resource. The result is Harare, named after the Zimbabwean town where Fuss’s mother and grandmother were raised. Almost every piece in the line is comprised of fabric woven by small groups of Guatemalan artisans, many of whom are the tenth generation to practice their trade; the garments are sewn or knitted in New York or Los Angeles.

headline: 36 Hours in Charlotte, N.C.
abstract: Explore the “Queen City,” where downtown is Uptown, the Old South is new and the attractions range from bike routes to the Nascar Hall of Fame.
lead_paragraph: In 1755, the Pennsylvania homesteader Thomas Polk settled at the intersection of two trading paths used by North Carolina’s Catawba Indians. Thirteen years later, the settlement that sprang up was named for Charlotte Sophia, the wife of England’s King George III. But it wasn’t until 1799 that Charlotte’s emergence as a financial center began, with the discovery of a 17-pound gold nugget in the northern woods, sparking the nation’s first gold rush. In the years since, Charlotte has endured war, poverty, racial strife and financial crisis on its way to becoming a global banking powerhouse. Today, Polk’s original crossroads lies in the shadow of the Bank of America tower in the heart of an eminently walkable downtown, which Charlotteans call Uptown. In the last decade, escapees from jobs in the corporate world have revitalized nearby enclaves like Dilworth, NoDa and Plaza Midwood, leaving galleries, breweries and farm-to-table enterprises in their wake — all increasingly linked by greenway, bike route and light rail. The “Queen City” is smaller and easier to navigate than, say, Atlanta, and is an excellent place to soak up the new Old South.

headline: Leaving Money and Privacy on the Table
abstract: Adam Tanner’s “What Stays in Vegas” looks at online data mining, how companies collect personal information to remain competitive and where invasion of privacy begins.
lead_paragraph: “What Stays in Vegas” is a very far cry from what it promises to be. Adam Tanner’s ostensible objective is to reveal big secrets about how Las Vegas casinos, notably those owned by Caesars Entertainment, collect and use data that customers drop when they visit, just as they drop money. Surely, there’s something sexier about this than there is about the way Amazon analyzes you based on your purchases. Surely there’s something about gambling that makes it different from surfing the web. Not exactly. Mr. Tanner, a fellow at the Institute for Quantitative Social Science at Harvard and a former Reuters bureau chief, spends a lot of time covering familiar ground. And not all of it is in Nevada. He starts at Harvard Business School, where Gary Loveman joined the faculty at 29 and became known for an article about the financial value of customer satisfaction. As part of his job, he trained executives from Harrah’s, the casino giant. A few years later, he left academia to become Harrah’s chief operating officer and moved to Las Vegas. He may have been the only guy in town who used words like “stochastic” and “vitiate” in conversation.

headline: A Scandal at the C.I.A. Maybe.
keywords: ['Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Cold War Era', 'Freedom of Information Act']
abstract: People drop dead in hallways all the time. But suspicion makes for a much better story.
lead_paragraph: The green metal file box was about the size and shape of an ammunition case. It was scuffed and serious-looking and packed tight with personal letters and papers that had belonged to my grandfather, who died in 1989. The line in the family had always been that he “did intelligence work in Washington after the war.” This file box gave up a better story: My grandfather was an operations officer with the C.I.A. from January 1948 to August 1951. But that revelation brought up another question: Why only three years? I went back through the brittle and yellowing letters in the file box, looking for anything that might explain the brevity of my grandfather’s spying career. I wouldn’t need much; I have a fertile imagination.

headline: Russia: 3 McDonald’s Shut for 90 Days
abstract: Russian courts ordered three McDonald’s restaurants in Moscow shuttered for the maximum period of 90 days over sanitary code violations, Russian news agencies reported.
lead_paragraph: Russian courts ordered three McDonald’s restaurants in Moscow shuttered for the maximum period of 90 days over sanitary code violations, Russian news agencies reported, including one facing the Kremlin walls. The rulings confirmed an earlier temporary closing ordered by the country’s food safety organization. McDonald’s issued a statement vowing to fight the court orders and to reopen all six restaurants it said had been closed nationwide. The closings and a rash of inspections of the chain across Russia, where it has more than 400 restaurants, are widely seen as retribution for McDonald’s shutting its three restaurants in Crimea after the peninsula was annexed by Russia in March. Government officials deny any such link.

Russell. Pat wants to tackle the world and reclaim his estranged wife, Nikki, who took out a restraining order against him, through a physical and psychological regimen he created while locked away. Then he meets Tiffany (Jennifer Lawrence, above with Mr. Cooper), a heartbreaker who persuades him that she can circumvent the law by passing a letter from him to Nikki, if only he’ll enter a dance contest with her. Soon, she is leading, and he is following. “For all its high-flying zaniness, the movie has the sting of life, and its humor feels dredged up from the same dark, boggy place from which Samuel Beckett extracted his yuks,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times about this best picture Oscar nominee, which also earned nominations for Mr. Cooper, Ms. Weaver and Mr. De Niro, and a win for Ms. Lawrence. “These are characters who get in one another’s faces and occasionally punch a loved one right in the kisser. They must go on, they can’t go on, but together they do.”

headline: The Other Big Mac Index
abstract: By going after McDonald’s, the Kremlin is once again turning the restaurant chain into a symbol of openness.
lead_paragraph: The first time I stood in line to enter Moscow’s first McDonald’s — then the largest McDonald’s in the world — was in the spring of 1991. The country was still called the Soviet Union, and that McDonald’s on Pushkin Square, though it had been open for a year, was still a unique place in several ways: It was a public space where ordinary people could have a private conversation while eating food they could afford, sold to them by polite staff. The few other existing cafes and restaurants in the city offered either an exorbitantly priced experience or a humiliating one.

lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The World Health Organization said on Thursday that the Ebola epidemic was still accelerating and could afflict more than 20,000 people — almost seven times the current number of reported cases — before it could be brought under control.

headline: 1939: France Imposes Censorship
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: France begins to censor the press and communications in 1939.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — With Adolf Hitler greatly aggravating the crisis by raising his demands on Poland to include the Corridor as well as Danzig, France yesterday glided into a regime of war. A government censorship over the press, radio and cinema was set up. The eminent French dramatist, Jean Giraudoux, who was recently appointed French propaganda chief, was placed as the head of the censors’ bureau, which is being established at the Hotel Continental, near the Place Vendôme. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Aug. 29, 1939

headline: A Modern Heroine Returns to Center Stage

There are the downtrodden lovelorn women, such as Violetta and Mimì; the bold but doomed leaders, like Carmen and Norma; and the vociferous helpmeets, like Brünnhilde and Isolde, belting out heavy lyrics as the world about them lies in ruin.

headline: The Dawn of the Post-Clinic Abortion
abstract: Some activists like Rebecca Gomperts are now imagining the unthinkable: a future where most abortions happen at home.
lead_paragraph: In June 2001, under a cloud-streaked sky, Rebecca Gomperts set out from the Dutch port of Scheveningen in a rented 110-foot ship bound for Ireland. Lashed to the deck was a shipping container, freshly painted light blue and stocked with packets of mifepristone (which used to be called RU-486) and misoprostol. The pills are given to women in the first trimester to induce a miscarriage. Medical abortion, as this procedure is called, had recently become available in the Netherlands. But use of misoprostol and mifepristone to end a pregnancy was illegal in Ireland, where abortion by any means remains against the law, with few exceptions.

headline: Under Cover: Opening Up the ‘Abortion by Mail’ Cover
abstract: To illustrate Emily Bazelon’s cover story about activists working to give women access to abortions at home, we knew that we wanted to show a package of pills received by mail.
lead_paragraph: To illustrate Emily Bazelon’s cover story about activists working to give women access to abortions at home, we knew that we wanted to show a package of pills received by mail. As Jake Silverstein, the magazine’s editor in chief, noted, what was new about Bazelon’s article was not that women could use pills to have an abortion, but that women who would otherwise be denied access to an abortion could get those pills through the mail.

headline: An Inspiring Fashion Collective Springs From Peru’s Prison System
abstract: From designing to hand stitching, inmates from three different institutions collaborate on the Project Pietà label.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, the French-born, Peru-based textile specialist Thomas Jacob accompanied a friend on a trip to the San Jorge prison in Lima. “I was struck by the dignity of the inmates,” the 27-year-old recalls. “They didn’t have a mind for pain, they just accepted their fate with sobriety and humility.” He located two similar correctional facilities near the country’s capital — Santa Monica in Chorrillos and San Pedro in Lurigancho — and established a system that would enable the inmates at each to work together making clothes. The nascent fashion collective took its name, Project Pietà, from a masterpiece by Michelangelo.

headline: David Lynch, Who Began as a Visual Artist, Gets a Museum Show
abstract: The filmmaker David Lynch, who was first a painter, has his first United States retrospective, at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — David Lynch’s rooftop painting studio, perched high in the Hollywood Hills, is littered with the byproduct of work. Paintings with crude, childlike figures doing menacing things lean up against the walls, unfinished drawings are strewn over his huge desk, and the floor is carpeted with cigarette butts. While the dark visual sensibility of his film work — “Eraserhead” (1977), “The Elephant Man” (1980), “Blue Velvet” (1986), “Wild at Heart” (1990), “Mulholland Drive” (2001), and his TV series “Twin Peaks” (1990-91) — has permeated the public consciousness and widely influenced other filmmakers, writers and artists (including Cindy Sherman and Gregory Crewdson), Mr. Lynch’s own visual art is almost unknown. Yet painting is where he started, enrolled as an advanced student at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts in Philadelphia in 1966 and ’67, and it is the medium he continues to work in most actively. His first United States museum retrospective, “David Lynch: The Unified Field,” opens at the Pennsylvania Academy on Sept. 13.

headline: ZZ Top Cancels Shows After Bassist Is Injured

lead_paragraph: In the second rock band tour bus accident of the summer, Dusty Hill, the bassist for ZZ Top, slipped and fell on the band’s bus on Tuesday evening, and sustained unspecified injuries that have forced the band to cancel some of its dates. The accident follows an accident in which Nick Followill, the drummer for the Kings of Leon, broke his ribs when the group’s tour bus stopped to avoid hitting a pedestrian, and canceled several weeks of concerts.

headline: $13.2 Million in Gifts for the Minnesota Orchestra

The board announced on Wednesday that the ensemble had received four gifts totaling $13.2 million during the summer.

headline: ISIS Said to Kill 150 Syrian Captives in 2 Days, Videotaping the Horror

Video images posted online appeared to show the men being marched through the desert in their underwear by the extremists and then lying dead in the sand.

headline: How to Complain to Medicare
abstract: Revealed: the semi-secret phone numbers that beneficiaries are supposed to use to complain to Medicare.
lead_paragraph: How Medicare handles complaints and appeals is no trivial matter — the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services says it reviews more than 100,000 of them a year. Beneficiaries file roughly 16,000 annually related to hospital care (mostly contesting discharges) and 18,000 about nursing homes, home health services and hospice programs. And 30,000 other complaints and appeals concern Medicare Advantage programs.

headline: In Plastics and Cans, a Threat to Women
abstract: BPA worries scientists for a number of reasons, but evidence is gathering for one concern in particular: infertility.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, Jodi Flaws, a bioscientist at the University of Illinois, began testing a theory about the risks to women posed by the widely used industrial compound bisphenol A, or BPA.

headline: Economic Data Points to Upward Trajectory
abstract: The Commerce Department said the economy grew at a 4.2 percent rate, but businesses still seem to be benefiting more than consumers.
lead_paragraph: The United States economy grew faster than first thought last quarter, the Commerce Department said on Thursday, the latest in a series of signals that point to a period of sustainable growth ahead.

headline: The Pride of Cold Spring, Minn.
abstract: Jets receiver Eric Decker was a three-sport star in high school and a product of the schools and ball fields of Cold Spring, Minn.
lead_paragraph: Jets receiver Eric Decker was a three-sport star in high school and a product of the schools and ball fields of Cold Spring, Minn.

headline: Jets’ Big-Time Receiver Nourished by Small-Town Roots
abstract: Eric Decker, the Jets’ off-season acquisition via the Broncos and Cold Spring, Minn., comes to New York with a country-music-singing wife, a reality TV show and a three-sport past.
lead_paragraph: COLD SPRING, Minn. — His friends would call his house on summer days, and if Eric Decker was not around, they knew where to find him.

headline: Joan Rivers Hospitalized in New York
abstract: The comedian was transported to Mount Sinai Hospital after going into cardiac arrest, the police said.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 12:59 p.m. | Joan Rivers was hospitalized in New York on Thursday morning after she was unconscious and unresponsive and had gone into cardiac arrest, law enforcement officials told The New York Times. Ms. Rivers, 81, the brassy, pioneering comedian and host of the E! series “Fashion Police,” was brought to Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan by emergency workers who responded at 201 East 93rd Street at 9:40 a.m.

headline: 1963: The Beatles Get a Headline
abstract: The Times’s headline on its first mention of the Beatles might have been puzzling, but not for long.
lead_paragraph: This feature looks at the first time famous names or terms appeared in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Send a suggestion in the comments section.

headline: In First Year of Pre-K Expansion, a Rush to Beat the School Bell
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio announced that 50,407 children had been enrolled in prekindergarten for this fall, and many pieces will have to fall into place by Sept. 4 for the program to go smoothly.
lead_paragraph: Shanté Jones walks around central Brooklyn for hours every day, visiting playgrounds, lingering outside public pools, trolling the cereal aisles in supermarkets — anywhere she thinks she might find small children and their parents.

headline: Today in Small Business: Independent Contractors
abstract: Thanks to protesting workers, the president of a family supermarket gets his job back. Section 179 deductions are changing. Do you recline in your airline seat?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: After Quick Rise, Halep Savors Seed, and a Hot Dog on Every Corner
abstract: The No. 2 seed at the United States Open, Halep, a 22-year-old Romanian, is enjoying New York’s shops and hot-dog stands.
lead_paragraph: Simona Halep, a 22-year-old Romanian, has had a meteoric rise from outside the top 60 in May 2013 to being the No. 2 seed at this year’s United States Open. In that span she has won eight WTA titles and was runner-up at the French Open in June. After her second-round victory over Jana Cepelova on Wednesday, Halep spoke to The New York Times about life and tennis in New York, and the pluses and minuses of newfound fame. BEN ROTHENBERG

headline: In Tuscany, Working the Harvest at a Farm Owned by Sting and Trudie Styler
abstract: Travelers can participate in grape and olive harvests at a property in Tuscany owned by Sting and his wife, Trudie Styler.
lead_paragraph: The singer Sting and his wife, the actress and producer Trudie Styler, are opening their home in Tuscany, called Il Palagio, for the first time this fall to travelers interested in participating in the estate’s grape and olive harvests.

headline: Bundesliga and Premier League Teams Collide in Champions League Draw
abstract: Thursday’s draw for the group stage of the UEFA Champions League featured familiar collisions of German and English contenders.
lead_paragraph: A top-heavy UEFA Champions League increasingly dominated by the same top clubs from the same top leagues is finding it increasingly hard to keep them away from one another.

headline: Conservative Party Lawmaker Defects to Anti-Europe Party in Britain
abstract: The legislator, Douglas Carswell, left Prime Minister David Cameron’s party for the United Kingdom Independence Party and will run for his old seat in Parliament.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A British lawmaker with strongly anti-European views defected from the governing Conservative Party on Thursday to join the U.K. Independence Party, dealing an embarrassing blow to Prime Minister David Cameron.

headline: When a Customer Has Two Reasons to Say Ouch
keywords: ['Customer Relations', 'Hair', 'Laser (Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation)']
abstract: A reader seeks the Haggler’s help in getting a refund on a $3,000 hair-removal treatment plan.
lead_paragraph: As a fictional construct, the Haggler does not have worries associated with the corporeal world. Like body hair. Sometimes this can seem like a very lucky break.

headline: A Book for Children, and Others, by Bruce Springsteen
abstract: “Outlaw Pete,” based on a song of the same name, is for “for anybody who loves a good Western,” said his publisher.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Springsteen has joined what is by now a long parade of rock stars (including Keith Richards, three of the Beatles, and Jimmy Buffett) who have written children’s books – or at least, what look like children’s books.

headline: No Invitation Necessary
abstract: New York’s one restaurant devoted to the cooking of Moldova offers genuine details and food, and can make even a wedding crasher feel welcome.
lead_paragraph: Branches twine above. Balkan folk-punk pulses below. The mural on the back wall is a postcard writ large, of a cave monastery a millennium old, transplanted from the cliffs along the Dniester River to a utilitarian strip of Midwood, Brooklyn. The tablecloths are red and the chairs hooded in brocade, and every table seems to seat at least eight.

headline: New Study Offers Clues to Swift Arctic Extinction
abstract: A study seems to rule out assimilation as the reason for the sudden disappearance of the Paleo-Eskimo population that thrived alone for more than 4,000 years.
lead_paragraph: Seven hundred years ago, the Dorset people disappeared from the Arctic. The last of the Paleo-Eskimos, the Dorset had dominated eastern Canada and Greenland for centuries, hunting seal and walrus through holes in the ice and practicing shamanistic rituals with ornate carvings and masks.

headline: Horror Is a Constant, as Artists Depict War
keywords: ['War and Revolution', 'Art', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: “The Disasters of War, 1800-1914,” a French museum show, illustrates how depictions of war have changed through the centuries.
lead_paragraph: LENS, France — The nightmare images come one after another: Three women, half-clothed, one with her legs spread open, lie on the floor, apparently raped; the naked body of a decapitated man hangs from a tree branch, his severed head stuck on a shorter branch; a man hauls a dead woman by her legs, her dress flipped up, exposing her underwear.

headline: Will a Gun Retailer Get Away With Negligence?
abstract: Dawn Nguyen purchased weapons for a felon, William Spengler, who then killed two firefighters.
lead_paragraph: Dawn Nguyen was scheduled to be sentenced today in federal court for knowingly acting as a straw purchaser of assault weapons that were used in 2012 to kill two firefighters and wound two others, among other victims, in Webster, N.Y.  But late yesterday, her lawyer argued successfully for a delay to challenge the prosecution’s request for a stiffer sentence than the 18 months to two years called for by federal guidelines.

headline: In Sickness and in Health
abstract: People make sacrifices for each other when it comes to health, just as they do with family and careers. When both partners develop cancer, it is no exception.
lead_paragraph: He was already sitting on the examination table when I walked into the room, and he looked smaller than I had ever seen him. Perhaps it was the way he held his shoulders, or how he didn’t quite meet my gaze. I took his nonverbal cues and greeted him quietly.

headline: Outbreak in Sierra Leone Is Tied to Single Funeral Where 14 Women Were Infected
abstract: An explosion of cases in early summer seems to stem from a traditional healer’s funeral at which 14 women were infected, according to scientists.
lead_paragraph: Sierra Leone’s explosion of Ebola cases in early summer appears to stem from one traditional healer’s funeral at which 14 women were infected, according to scientists studying the blood of victims.

headline: The Playful God of a Manic Valhalla
abstract: “What’s Up, Doc? The Animation Art of Chuck Jones” brings Bugs Bunny, Daffy Duck, Wile E. Coyote and others to life at the Museum of the Moving Image.
lead_paragraph: You may not know the name Chuck Jones, but you surely know his progeny Wile E. Coyote, the Road Runner and Elmer Fudd. And you certainly know the antic creatures fathered by others whom Jones adopted, including Bugs Bunny and Daffy Duck. One of the great creators of animated cartoons in the predigital era, Mr. Jones is the subject of “What’s Up, Doc? The Animation Art of Chuck Jones” at the Museum of the Moving Image.

headline: Even Amid Swirling Winds, Serena Williams Coasts Into Third Round
abstract: Williams beat Vania King in the second round on Thursday, while eighth-seeded Ana Ivanovic was eliminated. On the men’s side, Novak Djokovic, John Isner and Sam Querrey won in straight sets.
lead_paragraph: It became apparent early in Serena Williams’s second-round match Thursday at the United States Open that she was not going to be yielding the title of top American anytime soon. As Williams battled the swirling winds of Arthur Ashe Stadium, growing annoyed with the conditions and occasionally with herself, the young American on the other side of the net remained less bothersome than a speed bump.

headline: Uber and Lyft Have Become Indistinguishable Commodities
abstract: Though Uber and Lyft have become bitter enemies recently, in many places, they both offer ubiquitous, cheap and mostly high-quality service.
lead_paragraph: If you need a ride, pull out your phone and load up the Lyft app. Or try Uber. Really, it doesn’t matter which you pick.

headline: Shell Submits a Plan for New Exploration of Alaskan Arctic Oil
abstract: The company, which had experienced setbacks in its efforts in recent years, said it had not yet made a final decision on whether to drill next summer.
lead_paragraph: Royal Dutch Shell submitted a plan to the federal government on Thursday to try once again to explore for oil in the Alaskan Arctic, following years of legal and logistical setbacks as well as dogged opposition from environmentalists.

headline: Erdogan Is Sworn In as President of Turkey
abstract: Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the former prime minister who has governed Turkey for more than a decade, is expected to continue to exercise power for at least another five years.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Turkey’s former prime minister, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, was sworn in Thursday as the country’s first directly elected president, a position from which he is expected to continue to exercise power for at least another five years.

headline: Charlie Palmer Rethinks His Empire
abstract: The chef and restaurateur is spreading out in Midtown.
lead_paragraph: For 26 years, the chef and restaurateur Charlie Palmer has kept his flagship Aureole a success, even after he moved it from the Upper East Side to Midtown in 2009. During that time, he also planted his flag across the land, on properties from the California wine country and the gambling meccas of Nevada to Dallas and Washington, D.C.

headline: Drug-Selling Charges Dropped Against Man Arrested in Philip Seymour Hoffman Case
abstract: Robert Aaron, a musician and a friend of Mr. Hoffman’s, had been charged with intent to sell heroin just days after his fatal drug overdose in February.
lead_paragraph: The Manhattan district attorney on Thursday dropped all charges related to the sale of drugs against Robert Aaron, a musician and a friend of the actor Philip Seymour Hoffman who had been arrested and charged with intent to sell heroin just days after Mr. Hoffman’s fatal drug overdose in February.

headline: Fantasy Football: Analyzing Draft Tiers With Advanced Statistics
abstract: By comparing last year’s player ranking tiers to this season’s, you can learn how to better approach your fantasy drafts.
lead_paragraph: Applying a clustering algorithm called the Gaussian mixture model to an aggregation of expert ranking data provided by Fantasypros.com, the algorithm finds natural tiers and clusters within the data. See the charts here.

headline: As Ebola Grips Liberia’s Capital, a Quarantine Sows Social Chaos
abstract: Monrovia has become, in a few short weeks, a major focal point of the epidemic, with the outbreak overwhelming the government of President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf.
lead_paragraph: MONROVIA, Liberia — Some people are swimming in and out of the Ebola quarantine zone in this seaside capital. One man slips out every day to reach his job at a Western embassy. Another has turned his living room into a tollbooth, charging others to escape through his apartment at the edge of the cordoned area. Countless others have used a different method: bribing their way out with fees that soldiers determine according to a person’s appearance, circumstances and even gender.

headline: The Stuff of Life, Urgently Altered
abstract: Bethany Collins, Kevin Beasley and Abigail DeVille display their works in “Material Histories: Artists in Residence 2013-14” at the Studio Museum in Harlem.
lead_paragraph: David Hammons’s “African American Flag” — with its Pan-African red and black stripes and green field of black stars — floats high over the sidewalk outside the Studio Museum in Harlem. Originally created nearly a quarter-century ago, it has become an identifying emblem for a museum dedicated to nurturing the careers of artists of African descent.

headline: Accounting for the Expanding Carbon Shadow From Coal-Burning Plants
keywords: ['Air Pollution', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Coal', 'Electric Light and Power', 'Energy and Power', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Natural Gas']
abstract: A pitch for considering a lifetime’s worth of carbon dioxide emissions when examining power plants in the context of climate change.
lead_paragraph: Steven Davis of the University of California, Irvine, and Robert Socolow of Princeton (best known for his work dividing the climate challenge into carbon “wedges”) have written “Commitment accounting of CO2 emissions,” a valuable new paper in Environmental Research Letters showing the value of shifting from tracking annual emissions of carbon dioxide from power plants to weighing the full amount of carbon dioxide that such plants, burning coal or gas, could emit during their time in service.

headline: Taking the Crown, Then Taking Orders
abstract: Former Miss America Kate Shindle’s favorite haunts include Artie’s Delicatessen, the Glass House Tavern and the Campbell Apartment.
lead_paragraph: BACK when I still watched the Miss America pageant, I saw Kate Shindle win in September 1997. She was a student at Northwestern University who competed as Miss Illinois on the platform of AIDS education — a dynamo, burning with smarts and passion.

headline: Questions for IBM’s Watson
abstract: IBM’s Watson keeps adding new features. But can it make money?
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, figuring out the right question is harder than finding the answer. Just ask Watson.

headline: Forming Attachments Near and Far
abstract: An unforeseen benefit of living with cancer is the intimacy it creates with individuals we barely know.
lead_paragraph: One of the most unforeseen benefits of living with cancer is the intimacy it creates with individuals we barely know. Affections spring up with surprising force.

headline: Missing American’s Body Found Near Jerusalem, Israeli Police Say
abstract: The police said they had identified the body of Aaron Sofer, 23, from New Jersey. There were no immediate signs of foul play.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Israeli police said a body found on Thursday in a forest on the outskirts of Jerusalem was that of an American student who went missing while hiking in the area last Friday.

headline: New Cycle Begins as Klinsmann Picks U.S. Team
abstract: The United States men’s national team will play its first match since the World Cup in Brazil, at the Czech Republic, on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Coach Jurgen Klinsmann on Thursday picked 22 players for the United States’ men’s national team’s first game since the World Cup in Brazil — a match against the Czech Republic in Prague on Wednesday (2:15 p.m., Eastern, NBC Sports Network).

headline: Vivendi Looks Out for Its Shareholders in Talks for Its Brazil Unit
abstract: Vivendi seems to have chosen the surest exit for its shareholders and Telefónica doesn’t seem to be overpaying in the latest talks over Vivendi’s Brazilian business, GVT, Fiona Maharg-Bravo and Neil Unmack write for Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Vincent Bolloré, Vivendi’s chairman, is doing right by his shareholders. Vivendi says it has entered exclusive talks with Telefónica on its 7.5 billion-euro ($9.8 billion) bid for Vivendi’s Brazilian business, GVT. The French conglomerate spurned a lower bid from Telecom Italia. It might have squeezed a bit more from Telefónica, but has chosen the surest exit. That leaves Telecom Italia facing an uncertain future.

headline: A Brooklyn Dining Institution With Roots in Both Italy and a Great Love
abstract: As with most great restaurants, the backstory behind Park Slope’s Al di Là is a savory and sweet one.
lead_paragraph: The writer Charlotte Druckman and the photographer Melanie Dunea spend Sunday evenings at New York City dining establishments to find out what’s new with the people behind them.

headline: At Peabody Essex, 300 Years of Indian Chintzes
abstract: A collection of Indian chintzes, newly acquired by the Peabody Essex Museum in Salem, Mass., reveals centuries of changing habits.
lead_paragraph: AN EXOTIC FABRIC THROUGH THE AGES

headline: Two Roosevelts and Their Legacies
abstract: The Theodore Roosevelt Birthplace National Historic Site is free and open to the public, and a photo exhibition the Public Policy Institute at Hunter College pays tribute to Franklin Roosevelt.
lead_paragraph: The loss of Robin Williams was especially poignant for the Miser household, whose members happen to be big fans of Ben Stiller’s “Night at the Museum” franchise, in which Mr. Williams played an equestrian statue of Theodore Roosevelt come to life, serving as guide and foil to Mr. Stiller’s security guard protagonist.

headline: N.F.L. Domestic Violence Policy Toughened in Wake of Ray Rice Case
abstract: The N.F.L. commissioner said that league employees would be suspended without pay for six games for a first offense involving domestic violence.
lead_paragraph: In a rare mea culpa, N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell said Thursday that he had mishandled the Ray Rice case, in which the Baltimore Ravens running back was suspended for two games after being accused of assaulting his fiancée.

headline: Judge’s Ruling Could Affect Bondholders in Corporate Bankruptcies
abstract: A judge’s order in a bankruptcy case brings up the question of whether bondholders must get a “make whole” payment to get paid in full, Stephen J. Lubben explains in his latest In Debt column.
lead_paragraph: A federal bankruptcy judge’s ruling in a closely watched corporate case seems to have made the distressed debt market a bit unhinged.

headline: Critics Question High Ratings on New York State Teacher Evaluations Amid Poor Test Scores
abstract: For the first time, parents and administrators can assess the effectiveness of teachers at the county, district and, in some cases, the school level.
lead_paragraph: New York State released teacher and principal evaluations on Thursday that for the first time allow parents and administrators to assess the effectiveness of local teachers at the county, district and, in some cases, the school level.

headline: A Long Life Lived in the Shadow of Others
abstract: “Theresa Bernstein: A Century in Art” aims to make a case for this artist’s place in a history dominated by male painters.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Since the publication of Linda Nochlin’s groundbreaking 1971 essay, “Why Have There Been No Great Women Artists?,” feminist art historians have worked hard to rescue forgotten female figures from oblivion. One interesting candidate for recovery is offered by a traveling exhibition now at the Woodmere Art Museum here. “Theresa Bernstein: A Century in Art” presents more than 50 paintings dating from 1912 to 1972. It’s the first retrospective ever dedicated to Ms. Bernstein (1890-2002), who came of age during the heyday of early-20th-century American realism.

headline: A Woman’s Journey From Vienna, and the Nazis, and Back
keywords: ['Movies', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: “Shadows From My Past” explores the Holocaust with personal testimony and interviews with public figures.
lead_paragraph: The documentary “Shadows From My Past” grew out of an earlier project in which Gita Weinrauch Kaufman, who directed with her husband, Curt Kaufman (he died in 2011), shared letters from family members, many of whom were killed by the Nazis. As a young girl, Ms. Kaufman escaped Vienna for New York. In “Shadows From My Past,” she returns to Austria to see what has changed.

headline: A New American Oil Bonanza
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Shale', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: United States refinery production in recent weeks reached record highs and left supply depots flush, cushioning the impact of all the instability surrounding traditional global oil fields.
lead_paragraph: THREE RIVERS, Tex. — Whenever overseas turmoil has pushed energy prices higher in the past, John and Beth Hughes have curbed their driving by eating at home more and shopping locally. But the current crises in Ukraine and Iraq did not stop them from making the two-hour drive to San Antonio to visit the Alamo, have a chicken fried steak lunch, and buy fish for their tank before driving home to Corpus Christi.

headline: A Japanese Fable Hinges on 180 Degrees of Separation
abstract: In “Patema Inverted,” a Japanese animated tale, two teenagers come together from worlds with opposite laws of gravity.
lead_paragraph: An orphaned girl and a fatherless boy bridge opposing societies in “Patema Inverted,” a delightful animated fable from Yasuhiro Yoshiura.

headline: Eric Decker High School Highlights

lead_paragraph: A compilation of highlights from Decker’s playing days at Rocori High School, courtesy of the team’s coach, Joel Baumgarten.

headline: Law Boosts Oversight of Use of Solitary Confinement at Rikers Island
abstract: The legislation will require the Correction Department to publish quarterly reports on the inmates in solitary confinement, but does not include provisions that will scale back its use as punishment.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of growing criticism over conditions at Rikers Island, Mayor Bill de Blasio enacted legislation on Thursday to boost oversight of the use of solitary confinement at the jail.

headline: Come to Granny. On Second Thought, Better Not.
abstract: “The Damned,” by Victor García, takes place in a rural Colombian hotel that harbors a witch.
lead_paragraph: THE DAMNED

headline: Waiting Patiently for the Wall to Crumble
abstract: If we didn’t marry, even after decades together, we could still keep everything light.
lead_paragraph: I met him on the bus. The No. 9 was my daily commute from the University District of Seattle to the Rainier Valley, where I worked in an overcrowded elementary school. Because I got on early in the route, I always settled in the back, a prime people-watching spot as we traveled through Seattle’s varied neighborhoods.

headline: On Flings and Friends
abstract: Answers to questions about friendships, advice and wedding gifts.
lead_paragraph: An old friend has a perennial problem being faithful to girlfriends. His current mate, whom he met while cheating on his former girlfriend, recently discovered a number of his dalliances. She decided to stay with him, but asked me to stop being friends with one of the women he cheated with. (I was not aware of the affair while it was going on, if that matters.) Trouble is, I am not that close with the girlfriend, but I’ve become quite friendly with the woman I’ve been asked to drop. Thoughts?

headline: Trailing an Artist Who Lost His Way
abstract: In Louise Penny’s “The Long Way Home,” a battered former detective retreats to an idyllic town, but gets drawn into the mystery of a neighbor’s missing husband.
lead_paragraph: Chief Inspector Armand Gamache, the brooding, wounded protagonist in Louise Penny’s splendid series of mystery novels, has officially shed his professional title in her latest book, “The Long Way Home.” He has left the Montreal police force after an (almost literally) explosive confrontation with corrupt elements that had been poisoning the force from within. Gamache emerged triumphant, but not unbloodied, in Ms. Penny’s last book, “How the Light Gets In,” which was perhaps her most sensationally plotted, reaching its climax in the foiling of a terrorist act that would have claimed thousands of lives.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Your nightly briefing is ready for you.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know from NYT Now:

headline: In Season of 63 Losses So Far, Yankees Find Few as Agonizing as This One
abstract: Victor Martinez scored on Alex Avila’s two-out shot off the wall in right in the ninth and the Tigers beat the Yankees on Thursday afternoon.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The Yankees sat in silence, eating their postgame meals or sitting at their lockers, staring at their phones, perhaps searching for solace. For several minutes, though, after an agonizing loss, they seemed as inconsolable as they had been all season.

abstract: Photos from Ukraine, China, Malta and India.

headline: Two Viewers, Two Countries, Two Points of Focus
abstract: “Bruce Davidson/Paul Caponigro: Two American Photographers in Britain and Ireland,” at the Yale Center for British Art, is a strange but memorable pairing.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — “Bruce Davidson/Paul Caponigro: Two American Photographers in Britain and Ireland,” at the Yale Center for British Art, is a strange but memorable pairing. It joins the Magnum photojournalist Bruce Davidson, best known for his aggressive New York street and subway photography, to a spiritually minded landscape photographer in the mold of Ansel Adams and Minor White. And although its title suggests some shared expatriate experience, a split quickly develops.

headline: Obama Urges Calm in Face of Crises in Ukraine and Syria
abstract: President Obama confronted two volatile crises with restraint Thursday, saying he was not close to authorizing airstrikes in Syria and playing down an escalation of Russia’s intervention in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama confronted a pair of volatile international crises with restraint on Thursday as he said he was not close to authorizing airstrikes against Islamic extremists in Syria and played down the latest escalation of Russia’s military intervention in Ukraine.

abstract: “Football: Great Writing About the National Sport” is among the new books on the game to greet the season.
lead_paragraph: The first hardcover book I bought with my own money was “Fighting Back: The Rocky Bleier Story” (1975), published the week I turned 10.

abstract: In “Jamie Marks Is Dead,” a dead student intrudes on the life of another teenager, who accepts it, for a while.
lead_paragraph: JAMIE MARKS IS DEAD

abstract: Chef Jeff Schwarz teaches how to clean and cook the strange, seasonal little vegetables, which he recently learned don’t always come from California.
lead_paragraph: This series by the chef Jeff Schwarz and the photographer Greg Kessler traces the trajectory of seasonal food — from its original source to a place on your table.

headline: Standout Wine Lists in New York City
abstract: Here are 10 of New York City’s most surprising wine lists, in alphabetical order.
lead_paragraph: Great wine lists don’t need to be epic length. They don’t require classic, expensive bottles. And they don’t appear only in conventional places; some of the best, in fact, show up where you least expect them.

keywords: ['Privacy', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The commissioner will be responsible for protecting the rights of those who use technology services outside the United States, including many users of Facebook, LinkedIn and Apple.
lead_paragraph: In the coming weeks, an Irish government committee is set to pick the country’s new data privacy regulator, a relatively obscure position but one with global sway.

headline: Juggling Worlds
abstract: In David Mitchell’s “The Bone Clocks,” a 15-year-old girl runs away from home in 1984 and becomes entrapped in an otherworldly battle between good and evil that will follow her for 60 years.
lead_paragraph: “I don’t summon anything up,” protests Holly Sykes, the down-to-earth protagonist of “The Bone Clocks,” David Mitchell’s latest head-spinning flight into other dimensions. “Voices just . . . nab me.” She’s trying to explain to a skeptical, curmudgeonly English writer how she occasionally falls out of time and sees what’s going to happen next. Embarrassed about her gift — she’s just a regular daughter of the owner of the Captain Marlow pub in Gravesend, Kent — and reluctant to credit such way-out ideas as precognition, she goes on, “Oh, Christ, I can’t avoid the terminology, however crappy it sounds: I was channeling some sentience that was lingering in the fabric of that place.”

headline: A Setting Sun at the End of the Dock
abstract: Patricia Clarkson stars in “Last Weekend” as an affluent woman who takes stock of her charmed life and grapples with whether to let go of a family estate on Lake Tahoe.
lead_paragraph: A Chekhovian spirit hovers over “Last Weekend,” about a Labor Day family gathering at a vast estate on Lake Tahoe in California. Celia (Patricia Clarkson) and Malcolm (Chris Mulkey) are parents to Theo (Zachary Booth), a gay screenwriter, and Roger (Joseph Cross), a caustic financier. Theo bickers with his boyfriend, Luke (Devon Graye), while Roger tangles with his wife (Alexia Rasmussen) over an office scandal. Theo has also invited another couple and a TV star (a skillful Jayma Mays, from “Glee”), who dallies with Roger.

headline: Oklahoma Loses Waiver From No Child Left Behind Provisions
abstract: The move comes as a result of the state’s retreat from Common Core, a set of reading and math standards adopted by more than 40 states.
lead_paragraph: As a result of its retreat from Common Core, a set of reading and math standards adopted by more than 40 states, Oklahoma was notified Thursday that it lost its waiver from key provisions of No Child Left Behind, the signature Bush-era education law.

headline: The Delusions We Deserve
abstract: A psychiatrist and his philosopher brother discuss how mental illness reflects culture.
lead_paragraph: Joel Gold first observed the Truman Show delusion — in which people believe they are the involuntary subjects of a reality television show whose producers are scripting the vicissitudes of their lives — on Halloween night 2003 at Bellevue Hospital, where he was the chief attending psychiatrist. “Suspicious Minds,” which he wrote with his brother, Ian, an associate professor of philosophy and psychology at McGill University, is an attempt to use this delusion, which has been observed by many clinicians, to pose questions that have gone out of fashion in psychiatry over the last half-century: Why does a mentally ill person have the delusions he or she has? And, following the lead of the medical historian Roy Porter, who once wrote that “every age gets the lunatics it deserves,” what can we learn about ourselves and our times from examining the content of madness?

headline: White-Hot, Illicit Passion and All the Trouble It Causes
abstract: Kieron Barry’s “Tomorrow in the Battle,” at Stageworks/Hudson, follows powerful, self-destructive Londoners in a romantic triangle.
lead_paragraph: HUDSON, N.Y. — Ah, the sudsy thrill of watching shallow people drowning in deep waters! This dubious pleasure is one I associate with summer — with glossy movies viewed furtively in air-conditioned theaters and books about the randy rich read through sunglasses on beach towels.

headline: Editor’s Note: How We Thought About Our Photo Essay on Israel and Gaza
abstract: As any depiction of the conflict between Israel and Gaza has the potential to stir controversy and raise questions, Jake Silverstein, editor in chief, offers this note as a window into some of the thinking behind the photo essay by Paolo Pellegrin and Peter van Agtmael in the Aug. 31 issue of The New York Times Magazine.
lead_paragraph: As any depiction of the conflict between Israel and Gaza has the potential to stir controversy and raise questions, I offer this note as a window into some of the thinking behind the photo essay by Paolo Pellegrin and Peter van Agtmael in the Aug. 31 issue of The New York Times Magazine. Toward the end of July, we began talking to Paolo and Peter about going into Gaza and Israel, respectively, to make some pictures. We had noticed that during this summer’s outbreak of violence, the prevalence of cellphone cameras and social media led to many more images of Gaza than in previous iterations of this long-running conflict. This imagery made the cost of war visually appreciable in a way that it had not been even as recently as 2009. Yet as powerful as these photos were, the speed and fervor of their dissemination tended to bring them to us isolated from context. Paolo and Peter, working more slowly, could try to capture a deeper and more narrative sense of the texture of life on the ground.

headline: Troubled Children, Baring Their Psychic Pain
keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Children and Childhood', 'Psychiatry and Psychiatrists']
abstract: “The Naked Room” presents an up-close view of children grappling with emotional trauma in a psychiatric hospital in Mexico City.
lead_paragraph: The title of “The Naked Room” (“El Cuarto Desnudo”) doesn’t lie: This documentary from Nuria Ibáñez takes place almost entirely in an office at a children’s psychiatric hospital in Mexico City. Nearly all of what we see consists of patients, typically framed in head-and-shoulders shots, sharing their thoughts. Asking persistent questions, the doctors remain unseen. Parents occasionally appear but mostly speak from off camera.

headline: Enduring War and Adults’ Cruelty
abstract: “The Notebook (Le Grand Cahier),” based on a novel by Agota Kristof, is a flinty parable of brutality and resilience: World War II seen through the eyes of twin boys.
lead_paragraph: There is something irresistible — and also something questionable — about the artistic impulse to filter fictional accounts of real-world horror through the eyes of children. The juxtaposition of innocence and cruelty, of a naïve ignorance of political causes with a vivid understanding of their human effect, can refresh and deepen our perception of past atrocities. But there are risks, too: of sentimentality, of vagueness and of a wide-eyed naïveté that mystifies events we have an ethical duty to see as clearly as possible. For every “Pan’s Labyrinth,” which mines archetypes and fairy tales to unearth the hidden truth of Spanish fascism, there is “The Boy in the Striped Pajamas,” which turns the Holocaust into maudlin kiddie-kitsch.

headline: Daniel Schechter Narrates a Scene From ‘Life of Crime’
abstract: The director Daniel Schechter discusses a moment from “Life of Crime,” the film adaptation of the Elmore Leonard novel “The Switch.”
lead_paragraph: In this video, the director Daniel Schechter discusses a moment from “Life of Crime,” the film adaptation of the Elmore Leonard novel “The Switch.” The scene — which features Jennifer Aniston, Will Forte, John Hawkes and Yasiin Bey (previously known as Mos Def) — involves a kidnapping that is interrupted by a romantic gesture.

headline: Always Let Them See You Sweat
abstract: The Swiss actress Carla Juri, 27, talks about her breakout role as a rebellious teenager in “Wetlands,” a comedy based on Charlotte Roche’s notorious novel.
lead_paragraph: “Overshare” doesn’t begin to cover the behavior of Carla Juri’s teenage character, Helen, in Wetlands.” Within minutes, we learn about Helen’s body odor, a raunchy snack-stand tryst and her unusual approach to public toilet seats. The coming-of-age comedy, which adapts Charlotte Roche’s scatological memoirlike novel, is a mother’s nightmare, but Ms. Juri brings a fresh sense of mischief and a touching vulnerability to the role.

headline: ‘Alice’ in All Its Teenage Subconscious
abstract: The National Ballet of Canada will perform Christopher Wheeldon’s “Alice” at David H. Koch Theater.
lead_paragraph: Just a few years back, it seemed as if evening-length ballets with detailed story lines were a thing of the past, a relic of the pre-postmodern imagination. Athleticism and abstraction were in; plot points and well-defined characters were out. Thus, the announcement, in 2010, that the Royal Ballet, with the National Ballet of Canada, had commissioned Christopher Wheeldon to create a new ballet based on “Alice in Wonderland” was greeted with a flurry of interest, and some eye rolling.

headline: A Swordsman to the End
abstract: Kevin Kline plays the swashbuckling actor Erroll Flynn in his waning years in “The Last of Robin Hood.”
lead_paragraph: “The Last of Robin Hood” takes place during the final two years of Errol Flynn’s life, when his stardom and health had waned, but his ardor for girls had not. As played by Kevin Kline with an almost disconcerting low-key openness, Flynn trades on his name recognition with an earnest, self-deprecating manner, though that is itself a form of entitlement. A go-between reaches out first to 15-year-old Beverly Aadland (Dakota Fanning), who is invited to a play audition in a country house borrowed for the purpose, which is not to audition. (In 1943 Flynn was acquitted of statutory rape in a case whose notoriety stuck.)

headline: A Miracle Drug or Quackery?
abstract: Eric Merola’s documentary “Second Opinion: Laetrile at Sloan-Kettering” examines a disputed drug.
lead_paragraph: When your public relations guy starts describing you as diabolical, there’s a problem. Ralph W. Moss, the center of Eric Merola’s documentary “Second Opinion: Laetrile at Sloan-Kettering,” was that guy, working in Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center’s public affairs department in the 1970s. headline: The Robin Hoods of Ancient Korea
abstract: A motley band of outlaws preys on the rich to help the poor in the Korean period drama “Kundo: Age of the Rampant.”
lead_paragraph: With its swooping close-ups, Ennio Morricone-lite score and horseback riders heading into a sunset, “Kundo: Age of the Rampant” could be a western. But it’s a martial arts spectacle, set in 1859 and loaded with familiar elements, including a corrupt ruler, a motley bandit gang stealing from the rich to feed the poor, and, of course, a revenge story. But the movie looks great, its visual details bearing a dusty polish.

headline: Carmen Fariña: An Old-School Abuela
abstract: On weekends, Ms. Fariña, chancellor of the New York City Education Department, is first and foremost an active and engaged grandmother.
lead_paragraph: As chancellor of the New York City Education Department, the largest school district in the country, Carmen Fariña, 71, will have the daunting task of overseeing about 1.1 million students when they return to school on Sept. 4. But on weekends Ms. Fariña is first and foremost an active and engaged grandmother. Two of her grandsons, Charlie, 10, and Ben, 8, sleep over every weekend at the Brooklyn waterfront apartment she has shared with her husband, Antonio, 74, for 15 years. The Fariñas have both lived in and around Cobble Hill since they were born.

And a big oil producer split itself in two, cleaving off a multibillion-dollar division that now operates tax-free.

headline: The Truth About Down Syndrome
abstract: It’s associated with more happiness than you might think.
lead_paragraph: LAST week the biologist Richard Dawkins sparked controversy when, in response to a woman’s hypothetical question about whether to carry to term a child with Down syndrome, he wrote on Twitter: “Abort it and try again. It would be immoral to bring it into the world if you have the choice.”

headline: The Fall of France
abstract: Has President François Hollande doomed the European project as the disastrous consequences of austerity policies grow more obvious with each passing month?
lead_paragraph: François Hollande, the president of France since 2012, coulda been a contender. He was elected on a promise to turn away from the austerity policies that killed Europe’s brief, inadequate economic recovery. Since the intellectual justification for these policies was weak and would soon collapse, he could have led a bloc of nations demanding a change of course. But it was not to be. Once in office, Mr. Hollande promptly folded, giving in completely to demands for even more austerity.

headline: What Doctors Can’t Do

She has 25 of the University of Pennsylvania Health System’s toughest patients. It’s her job to help them set health goals and, step by step, carry them out.

headline: The Mental Virtues

lead_paragraph: We all know what makes for good character in soldiers. We’ve seen the movies about heroes who display courage, loyalty and coolness under fire. But what about somebody who sits in front of a keyboard all day? Vera Farmiga is Alex, the fast-moving executive who, for the first time, causes Bingham to rethink his life. “ ‘Up in the Air’ is an assertively, and unapologetically, tidy package, from its use of romance to instill some drama into the narrative (the book introduces disease instead) and the mope-rock tunes that Mr. Reitman needlessly overuses,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times about this adaptation of the Walter Kirn novel. Still, one of the film’s pleasures is that its actresses “share the frame with Mr. Clooney as equals, not props.” The film, chosen by Ms. Dargis as a critic’s pick, received Oscar nominations for its three leads and Mr. Reitman, as well as a best picture nod.

lead_paragraph: In the coming weeks, an Irish government committee is set to pick the country’s new data privacy regulator, a relatively obscure position but one with global sway, Mark Scott reports.

headline: A Lot of Places Resemble Ferguson, Statistically

lead_paragraph: Ferguson, Mo., stands out for the level of racial turbulence it has experienced this month. But as an economically lagging community that has undergone rapid demographic change in the last couple of decades, it’s not unusual at all.

keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Small Business']
abstract: How closely do the National Federation of Independent Business’s priorities match yours? If you were certifying candidates as small-business friendly, which issues would you cite?
lead_paragraph: With the fall midterm elections approaching, the National Federation of Independent Business has released a measuring stick to rate congressional candidates on their fidelity to small businesses. While this is standard political advocacy, this year it goes under the novel banner of making candidates “small-business certified.” But N.F.I.B.’s acid-test positions are hardly new.

headline: Morning Agenda: Playing the Tax Game
abstract: American companies are finding new ways to avoid paying taxes. | Dueling scholarship funds in China. | Detecting fraud in China may be riskier than committing it. | Consumers get some relief at the gas pump.
lead_paragraph: BUSINESSES WINNING THE TAX GAME | Across corporate America, companies large and small are finding new ways to avoid paying taxes, making it harder than ever for the federal government to replenish its already depleted coffers, DealBook’s David Gelles writes. As a result, business income tax revenue remains stagnant at about 2 percent of gross domestic product even as corporate profits hit records. Business taxes now make up less than 10 percent of federal revenue, down sharply from the years after World War II, when about 30 percent of federal revenue came from corporate taxes.

lead_paragraph: Two childhood experiences with water left Attis Clopton with a phobia that lasted for decades, until another major life event inspired him to face his fears.
