headline: A New Yorker Faces His Phobia, One Stroke at a Time
abstract: Traumatized by childhood incidents, Attis Clopton was deathly afraid of water, so he attacked his phobia by enrolling in a program of swimming lessons.
lead_paragraph: On the morning before he was to report to the pool, Attis Clopton sat in a storefront breakfast spot near his Brooklyn apartment munching a glazed doughnut. He was worrying. It was a glorious day, blue sky and hot. The kind when they say the only sensible place to be is in the water.

headline: Karen O Goes Solo with ‘Crush Songs’
abstract: Karen O, perhaps best known as the frontwoman for the Yeah Yeah Yeahs, is out with a solo project, “Crush Songs.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “I think we just ooh-ed it out,” Karen O said, instructing her musicians in a steady singsong. “ ‘Ooh-ed’ it on out.”

headline: More Mega-Change in the Retail World: Sarah Rutson Leaves Lane Crawford
abstract: Given the buying power of Asia and the retailer’s role there, the executive’s departure is significant in the fashion world.
lead_paragraph: Another major shake-up is in the works in the world of global department stores: After 21 years, Sarah Rutson, fashion director of Lane Crawford, Asia’s most recognizable luxury emporium, is leaving to “pursue new personal opportunities,” according to an announcement from the store.

headline: Denis Colomb’s Cashmere Connection to the Holy City of Kathmandu
abstract: The designer and his wife and business partner, Erica Lennard, source both materials and inspiration from the spiritual Nepali capital.
lead_paragraph: Twice a year for the past decade, the Los Angeles–based designer Denis Colomb has traveled to Kathmandu with his wife and business partner, Erica Lennard. They spend their weekdays visiting the five Nepali workshops that help create the cashmere collections for Colomb’s eponymous label. But on Saturdays the workshops are closed and the couple is free to roam Nepal’s capital. “Initially drawn here to Nepal by the quality of the hand-weaving techniques and the ability to procure the finest cashmere,” Lennard explains, “we are constantly in awe of the deep spirituality and traditional lifestyle that have been part of the Nepali way of life for centuries.” Their Nepali-Tibetan production coordinator, Namdu Bajracharya, shares with them the holiest corners of the city, from small temples to stupas, or Buddhist monasteries, with breathtaking views.

headline: Austerity and the Hapless Left
abstract: Why the weakness?
lead_paragraph: In today’s column I am not nice to Francois Hollande, who has shown about as much strength in standing up to austerians as a wet Kleenex. But one does have to admit that he’s not alone in his haplessness; where, indeed, are the major political figures on the European left taking a stand against disastrous policies? Britain’s Labour Party has been almost surreally unwilling to challenge Cameron/Osborne’s core premises; is anyone doing better?

headline: Death Toll in Ukraine Conflict Exceeds 2,200, U.N. Says
abstract: A surge in fighting around Donetsk and Luhansk brought the total number of people killed since mid-April to at least 2,220, and the number of injured to at least 5,956.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The United Nations said on Friday that casualties in the fighting between Ukrainian government forces and pro-Russian rebels had doubled in the past month, with an average of 36 people killed every day.

headline: Germany’s Sin
abstract: Not giving others the same chance they had.
lead_paragraph: Simon Wren-Lewis has two very good posts about the European situation, first laying out the problem, then taking on those who don’t get it. I just want to add a bit to one of his key points: the impossibility of a resolution unless Germany accepts higher inflation.

headline: A Weary Rebel Retreats to Fight Another Day
abstract: Kassem Eid, who helped make Moadhamiyeh a symbol of Syrian suffering after government forces blockaded the town in 2012, reluctantly decided to struggle from afar.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — AS he rode onto the base of the Fourth Division, the formidable Syrian Army unit that had been starving and bombarding his town near Damascus for months, Kassem Eid prepared for a moral reckoning tougher than any he had faced in three years of civil war.

headline: Classical Playlist: Gluck, Jonathan Biss, Morton Feldman and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: ‘DUETS OF LOVE AND PASSION’James McCracken, tenor; Sandra Warfield, mezzo-soprano(Decca 480 8165) Though the tenor James McCracken and the mezzo-soprano Sandra Warfield, who were married, did not make a point of performing together, they shared the stage many times in operas and concerts. This reissued recording, “Duets of Love and Passion,” originally released in 1964, presents the couple in scenes from Saint-Saëns’ “Samson et Dalila,” Bizet’s “Carmen” and two Verdi operas, “Otello” and “Aida.” McCracken’s muscular voice and intensity combine excitingly with Warfield’s dark colorings and warmth. Though Warfield, who died in 2009, had to accommodate her voice with some awkwardness to the subtle demands of Verdi’s Desdemona, a classic soprano role, she smolders as Verdi’s Amneris. The recording includes bonus tracks from “McCracken on Stage,” an aria album that shows this important tenor, who died in 1988, was not just in his element in Wagner, but bending phrases sensitively in Verdi. (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: Increasingly, Retirees Dump Their Possessions and Hit the Road
abstract: More retired Americans are getting rid of their homes and traveling, with 360,000 of them receiving Social Security benefits at foreign addresses.
lead_paragraph: SOME call themselves “senior gypsies.” Others prefer “international nomad.” David Law, 74, a retired executive recruiter who has primarily slept in tents in several countries in the last two years, likes the ring of “American Bedouin.”

headline: 1914: Correspondent in the War Zone
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Correspondent’s report from the war zone, The New York Herald in 1914.
lead_paragraph: Location withheld:— I have just arrived here from the Belgian frontier after inspecting the situation in the North. There was an air of expectancy in — when I reached it on Monday forenoon. News was scant and people were evidently becoming restless. Crowds were massed in the principal square watching the arrival from time to time of French soldiers with trophies captured from the enemy. Knots of men and women were gathered around villagers from the countryside and listening intently to vague accounts of fighting outside the city. About five o’clock the atmosphere in the streets began to change. It seemed panicky. Rumors were afloat that the Germans were arriving; that the Prefect had given orders for all the flags to be hauled down; that the Prussian cavalry would enter the city at nine o’clock! What these reports were worth at the time I do not know. But when, an hour or two later, I saw the officers in my hotel suddenly begin to pack their bags and pay their bills I considered it was time I prepared to move on, too, having no desire to be taken prisoner by the Germans. The tactics of the German cavalry is to appear here, there and everywhere, and the effect on the population is inevitable. We reached —— at noon. We felt at once that the Germans were near. There was that unmistakable atmosphere. A general air of deadness, stagnation and stifled fear; suspense and anxiety on every face. Scant news has filtered through of the great battle between Mons and Charleroi. It is, of course, a secondary line which has wisely fallen back on a stronger line in order to cope better with the German cavalry movement on our left, a movement which must be watched.— The New York Herald, European Edition, Aug. 30, 1914

headline: Residency Questions Roil Senate Race in Louisiana

headline: The Accidental Phone Tap
abstract: When voice mail keeps rolling.
lead_paragraph: My sisters called me on a conference line, hoping to connect the three of us for an important discussion. I wasn’t home, so one sister left a voice mail message and then disconnected — or at least she thought she did. But my voice mail kept recording as she and my other sister continued their conversation. When I returned home and retrieved the message, was I obliged to stop listening and hang up after my sister believed she had ended the call? JANET FLETCHER, NAPA, CALIF.

headline: Who Made That Tabasco Sauce?
abstract: A sugar plantation leads to spice.
lead_paragraph: In the years before the Civil War, Edmund McIlhenny was a New Orleans banker and bon vivant whose pleasures included boats, horses and spicy food. But after the war, with much of the South in ruins, McIlhenny was unable to find work. After pounding the pavement in New Orleans for months, he retreated to his wife’s family’s sugar plantation on Petite Anse (now called Avery) Island, a 2,200-acre salt dome rising from the marshes of southern Louisiana. There, in the late 1860s, he tended his garden — particularly his bushes of spicy red peppers.

headline: The Unexpected 3 a.m. Guests
keywords: ['Robberies and Thefts', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Porches, Patios and Decks']
abstract: Two strangers were on the porch — and I opened the door.
lead_paragraph: When you know a house well, especially an old house, there aren’t many sounds that surprise you. The squeak of the stairs, the metallic chime of heat traveling down the baseboards, the whine of the northwest wind running up along the siding edge — if you have lived in a place for long, these become familiar.

headline: Can Jill Soloway Do Justice to the Trans Movement?
abstract: With her new show, “Transparent,” the director ventures into a world in which some of the smallest words in our language — pronouns — can cause the greatest offense.
lead_paragraph: In April, Jill Soloway sat on a cushion on the floor of her home office in Silver Lake as she waited for the glue on her fake eyelashes to dry. She was reading through a list of talking points that Glaad, the L.G.B.T. media advocacy organization, had distributed to those walking the red carpet at its annual Media Awards show. Soloway was invited as a special guest. The list was mostly made up of words and phrases to avoid, some that were obviously offensive but others that seemed innocuous: “gay marriage” (which suggests it’s a different thing from the nongay variety); “gay lifestyle” (which suggests it’s a choice); “homosexual” (which has been hijacked by anti-gay activists).

headline: New N.F.L. Policy Is One Step on a Long Road to Regaining Some Fans’ Trust
abstract: There is some uncertainty whether the N.F.L. will follow through with its newfound sensitivity when it comes to domestic violence.
lead_paragraph: Hooray for Roger Goodell, the N.F.L. commissioner who finally came to his senses and decided that, gee, yes, domestic violence is really a serious issue and should be punished accordingly.

headline: Domestic Violence On the Rise Among Syrian Refugees
abstract: Syria’s civil war has triggered a shift in traditional family dynamics, leading to a rapid escalation in domestic violence among the nearly 3 million-strong refugee population.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, Lauren Wolfe, the director of Women Under Siege, a project at the Women’s Media Center, visited the Zaatari refugee camp on the Jordan-Syria border. There, she met a young woman with a baby who said her husband, out of work and angry, had started beating her every day.

headline: Book a Room, Be a Pop Star for a Day

lead_paragraph: Travelers who harbor dreams of being pop stars have the chance to make their wishes come true — at least in part — with the new Superstar Package at Chewton Glen, the luxury estate hotel in Hampshire, England.

abstract: Readers respond to recent reviews of “The Nixon Tapes, 1971-1972,” Elizabeth Pisani’s “Indonesia Etc.” and more.
lead_paragraph: One Nixon

headline: Priority Mail
abstract: A look at past reviews of the letters of Sylvia Plath, Flannery O’Connor and Saul Bellow.
lead_paragraph: Throughout the years, authors’ collected letters have often featured in our pages (this week, Henry Giardina reviews “The Animals: Love Letters Between Christopher Isherwood and Don Bachardy”). Assessing Sylvia Plath’s “Letters Home” in 1975, Maureen Howard said the author’s dispatches “can be read like a novel,” including those Plath sent while studying at Smith College: “The letters are like little stories; here she is, Cinderella waltzing in her silver dress at a debutante party, or talking about life and love with handsome boys at any number of Ivy League colleges, or stunning her professors (all of them ‘dears’) with another villanelle.”

headline: Stories We Tell Each Other
abstract: Letters between Christopher Isherwood and his partner, Don Bachardy, mock the world’s ridiculous spectacle.
lead_paragraph: In 1956, Christopher Isherwood wrote from Cheshire, England, to his partner, the artist Don Bachardy. It is the first entry in a 14-year correspondence: a brief, eccentric document that mentions, in a short space, Alexander Korda’s memorial service, incest between two cats and Courbet’s “Diligence in the Snow.”

headline: Muses and Inspiration
abstract: New books by Naomi Wood, Sally O’Reilly, Nina Siegal and Sheila Kohler.
lead_paragraph: MRS. HEMINGWAY  By Naomi Wood  Penguin, paper, $16.

headline: Choose Your Own Race
abstract: A man undergoes a surgical procedure to transform from white to black.
lead_paragraph: Do you ever dream of starting again in a new skin? This is the central question of Jess Row’s provocative and intriguing first novel, “Your Face in Mine.” It’s also a tag line of the shady enterprise in Bangkok where the book’s central character, Martin Wilkinson (né Lipkin), has paid a hefty sum to undergo something called racial reassignment surgery, to transform from a white Jewish man to an African-American one.

headline: Expatriate Acts
abstract: A restless executive subjects his family to an itinerant existence on three continents.
lead_paragraph: Elise, the mother in Brittani Sonnenberg’s debut novel, “Home Leave,” is one of those unknowable blondes often glimpsed in business-class lounges. Neither delayed flights to Singapore nor fussy children can rattle her poise, because looking serene while traveling is what she does. Elise’s husband, Chris Kriegstein, is a former high school basketball star who was mostly benched come senior year of college. He is competitive but not ambitious in the way of today’s Zuckerbergian entrepreneurs. Rather than start his own company, he stumps for someone else’s in conference rooms in Seoul, Bombay, Dubai — anywhere that’s not Chariton, Ind.

headline: Bridge to Nowhere
abstract: A frail humanity survives the unspeakable in Richard Flanagan’s novel of the Burma-Thailand Railway.
lead_paragraph: The title of Richard Flanagan’s sixth novel comes from a 17th-century Japanese classic, a little book by the poet Basho that mixes a prose travel narrative with haiku in its account of a long journey on foot. Basho went north from present-­day Tokyo through a mountainous land of often shattering beauty. Yet his walk was marked by moments of terrible loneliness, and he seemed to travel under a kind of compulsion, without a defined goal or purpose. Basho walks because he must, and in reading him the old cliché comes alive: Life is a journey. Whether that journey has any meaning, whether there’s anything beyond putting one foot in front of the other . . . well, that’s another question entirely.

headline: His Penetrating Gaze
abstract: A celebrated British author embarks on a strange new career in these linked novellas by Alessandro Baricco.
lead_paragraph: What is the line between creating and copying? How does the subject of a portrait, like a particle in a physics experiment, change and transform under the portraitist’s watchful gaze? How do writers hide and reveal themselves in their work, leaving sly traces that only their intimates might recognize? These questions lie at the heart of “Mr. Gwyn” and “Three Times at Dawn,” two clever interlocking novellas by the Italian writer Alessandro Baricco.

headline: Love and Visas
abstract: A Russian immigrant, deported from the United States, attempts to reunite with his family.
lead_paragraph: The ambitiousness of Vanessa Manko’s debut novel is well represented by its title, which Homer might have blushed to use. “The Invention of Exile” spans four decades and three continents to tell the story of an epic love frustrated but never destroyed by political antagonism between nations, namely the United States and the brand-new Soviet Union. Its beleaguered hero, Austin Voronkov, debarks on Ellis Island (where his given name, Ustin, is quickly and permanently Americanized) in 1913; despite his engineering background, he takes a proletarian job at the Remington gun factory in Bridgeport, Conn. The reasons for his emigration are never divulged, though the fact that he “didn’t believe that workers and trained engineers were equal” suggests he has picked an opportune time to get out of Russia.

headline: Out of His Shell
abstract: A tribute to an Asian superhero from the 1940s.
lead_paragraph: Hank Chu is your run-of-the-mill ­Chinese-American drenched in filial piety and surrounded by shelves of simple carbohydrates in his family’s grocery store. When we meet him, in the 1930s, he’s content to be a facsimile of his father, passing his days, item by item, behind the counter. The Chus sweep, they stock, they eat and if they’re lucky, one day they’ll die. Hank’s mother, Hua Chu, is the only one with enough chutzpah to desire more. She escapes the Chu family “Groundhog Day” by taking a job with a Mrs. Olson, who could be Miss Daisy, Cruella de Vil or any flavor of distinguished Caucasian woman with garden party headwear and a big body sedan.

headline: Seoul Survivors
abstract: Cultural influence has kept pace with South Korea’s growth.
lead_paragraph: In 1985, a 12-year-old Euny Hong moved with her family from suburban Chicago to Seoul, South Korea. Not just any place in Seoul, South Korea, but a neighborhood known as Apgujeong — the wealthiest, most exclusive cluster of addresses in the Gangnam district. The Hongs, in short, went “Gangnam Style” 27 years before it was a thing. And when it comes to South Korean history — as with meme superstardom — three decades is a long time.

headline: A Long Road to Recovery
abstract: Robert Timberg traces his personal journey from disfigured Vietnam veteran to author and journalist.
lead_paragraph: In January 1967 a land mine blew up under the not-quite-armored-enough Amphibian Tractor, or Amtrac, carrying United States Marine Lt. Robert Timberg. He was on a routine mission to deliver pay to front-line units in Vietnam. The gas tank carried 456 gallons of fuel with little protection from underneath. If it exploded, anyone inside would be, as the Marines said, “fricasseed.” So the passengers sat on the top or clung to the sides. Timberg was watching the road ahead, he writes, when “I felt myself lifted from the top of the Amtrac, as if in the eye of a hurricane, except in place of wind and rain I was being carried aloft by flames.”

headline: Bodies of Evidence
abstract: In a nameless city, women are abducted, tattooed with crude maps and released.
lead_paragraph: The cast includes women who’ve been abducted, hooded, forcibly tattooed and released with no explanation. A bum, a stripper, a life coach, a real estate agent. They have nothing in common but the maps inked onto their backs — evidence of an unskilled hand, the maps illegible and crude. Playing the leads: a killer, Wrobleski; a hired thug, Billy Moore; his precocious 12-year-old daughter, Carla; a real estate mogul; and one cranky driver. In addition, two innocents turned amateur detectives — think “the Bloodhound Gang” (see PBS’s “3-2-1 Contact,” not the band) — who commit themselves, with no prelude or wherewithal, to solving the mystery of the tattooed women. And, as backdrop, a nameless city that feels like New York in about 50 years, but isn’t New York. Just some run-down urban mecca: corrupt, filthy, mysterious, cinematic. Put it all together and you’ve got Geoff Nicholson’s new crime novel, “The City Under the Skin,” which compels the way a good crime novel should: by making you turn the pages at a clip.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: COMMAND AND CONTROL: Nuclear Weapons, the Damascus Accident, and the Illusion of Safety,  by Eric Schlosser. (Penguin, $18.) How do you deploy weapons of mass destruction without being destroyed by them? That’s the question at the heart of Schlosser’s disquieting examination of nuclear risk, which weaves a riveting account of an accident at a nuclear missile silo in rural Arkansas with a crisp historical narrative covering more than 70 years.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: GEEK SUBLIME: The Beauty of Code, the Code of Beauty,  by Vikram Chandra. (Graywolf, paper, $16.) With great subtlety and depth, Chandra, who is both a novelist and a programmer, traces the connections between art and technology.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Paul Ryan, the Wisconsin Republican whose first book, “The Way Forward,” is No. 5 on the hardcover nonfiction list, has opened up about his father’s alcoholism and early death.
lead_paragraph: Whistle-Stop: Representative Paul Ryan, the Wisconsin Republican who was Mitt Romney’s running mate in 2012, has been on the road lately to promote his first book, “The Way Forward,” which enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 5. In it, Ryan offers voters — oops, readers! — a softer, more personal account of his life, discussing among other things his courtship of his wife and opening up for the first time about his father’s alcoholism and early death. “Before I lost him to a heart attack,” Ryan writes, “whiskey had washed away some of the best parts of the man I knew.” None of this, of course, means the book isn’t full of your basic agitprop. Running a column about it last month, one Texas newspaper used the succinct headline “Ryan Blames Everything on Left.” So is this the first volley in a presidential campaign? Ryan has been noncommittal in interviews, saying he’ll wait until 2015 to decide. And despite the book’s calculated stagecraft and careful red-meat rhetoric (“I believe the conservative vision can appeal to the majority of our fellow citizens”), there’s at least one good reason to think he’s telling the truth: His whistle-stop book tour includes no scheduled appearances in Iowa or New Hampshire.

abstract: Private developers have built more than 100 mixed-income buildings over the past decade, mostly in Manhattan and gentrified parts of Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Brandon Deese lives just a few blocks from where he grew up, but it might as well be another world.

headline: Is Owning Overrated? The Rental Economy Rises
keywords: ['Consumer Behavior', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Start-ups', 'Dresses']
abstract: Entrepreneurs say the new way of consuming is part of a growing, post-recession movement to value experiences over possessions.
lead_paragraph: Things that you can now rent instead of buying: a power drill, a song, a tent, an office for an hour, a Prada handbag, a wedding dress, a painting, a dog, your neighbor’s car, a drone.

headline: In Greenpoint, a Situation Ripe for a Doughnut War
abstract: A longtime employee of a neighborhood institution, Peter Pan Donut and Pastry shop, opened Moe’s Doughs a few blocks away. Let the bakery battle begin.
lead_paragraph: Once Dominique Ansel secured a trademark for the Cronut this year, some New Yorkers might have thought that the city’s doughnut wars, or at least heated conversations about doughnuts, were over. Peace, whether in the form of a hybrid, classic jelly, or red velvet, had finally come.

headline: With Howard Out, U.S. Net Is Open for Guzan
abstract: Tim Howard’s decision to take a year off from the United States national team opened the door for Brad Guzan, his backup since 2006.
lead_paragraph: When the United States national team takes the field against the Czech Republic on Wednesday in Prague, it will do so without its most recognizable and valuable player from the World Cup: goalkeeper Tim Howard, who announced last week that he was taking a year off from international play.

headline: Harry Belafonte and Maureen O’Hara Among Academy Honorees
abstract: Ms. O’Hara will receive an honorory Oscar and Mr. Belafonte will receive a humanitarian award at the motion picture academy’s Governors Awards.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The actress Maureen O’Hara, the screenwriter Jean-Claude Carrière and the animation filmmaker Hayao Miyazaki will receive honorary Oscars for their lifetime achievement, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said on Thursday.

headline: One Residence, Two Different Worlds
abstract: In New York’s mixed-income buildings, market-rate tenants live right next door to low-income tenants.
lead_paragraph: In New York’s mixed-income buildings, market-rate tenants live right next door to low-income tenants.

headline: Here Comes September. There Lie the Mets.
abstract: There has been a metronomic regularity to this annual Mets ruination: glimmers of hope in the spring, a nice little run in June or July, then total and profound collapse.
lead_paragraph: Ah, to be a Mets fan in late August. The twilight is cool and sharp shadowed, and Citi Field is a retro delight. As for the state of the team as it makes its inevitable turn toward the autumn moon?

headline: Tough Decisions: Investing for a Nonprofit
abstract: Directors must make the same decisions as their counterparts at for-profit companies, but some choose to outsource investment decisions.
lead_paragraph: AFTER a steady run-up in the stock market, the members of the investment committee of the HudsonAlpha Institute for Biotechnology were faced with a decision this year that would affect the future of the nonprofit and the cutting-edge biotech research it funds.

headline: The Economic Value of Treating Workers Humanely
abstract: Can Myanmar improve labor conditions?
lead_paragraph: There has been so much regression on democracy and human rights in Myanmar recently that many people, this editorial page included, have suggested the United States must consider reinstating broad sanctions.

headline: Along the High Line: Top This!
abstract: Two condominiums are coming to the High Line from the architect Soo K. Chan, one of which will include private pools.
lead_paragraph: Soo K. Chan, an architect and developer from Singapore who has designed and built residences, hotels and museums around the world, is launching his first two projects in the United States in New York City. And it seems as if Mr. Chan and his company, SCDA Architects, intend to come on strong, with two condominiums along that magnet for brand-name architects, the High Line.

headline: Gaia Repossi’s Favorite New York Art Destinations
abstract: In honor of her new pop-up at Dover Street Market — and to kick off New York Fashion Week, which begins after Labor Day — the Paris-based designer shares a list of some of her favorite sources of visual inspiration in the city.
lead_paragraph: For the past seven years, the Repossi creative director Gaia Repossi has been turning out jewelry that toes the line between fashion and fine art. On September 3rd and 4th, her delicate new collection — called “White Noise” and informed by the mobiles of Alexander Calder and the color palette of Franz West — makes its debut in a special installation at Dover Street Market New York, marking the first time an entire Repossi collection will be available stateside. In honor of its arrival — and to kick off New York Fashion Week, which begins after Labor Day — the Paris-based designer shares a list of some of her favorite sources for visual inspiration in New York, where she frequently travels for work and to visit her boyfriend, the artist Jeremy Everett.

headline: Why a Video Game Critic Was Forced to Flee Her Home
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Cyberharassment', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: When a critic of sexism in video games tweeted that she’d been threatened, she helped touch off a larger debate about the future of gaming culture.
lead_paragraph: This week, a critic of sexism in video games tweeted that she’d been threatened, severely enough that she notified law enforcement and left her home. And her experience has prompted some to ask whether gaming culture is dying — or changing into something new.

headline: After Napa Jolt, Quake-Proofing Your Homeowner’s Insurance
abstract: Homeowner’s policies generally do not include protection against damage caused by earthquakes, and the risk extends well beyond California.
lead_paragraph: AS Napa County, Calif., recovers from the earthquake that jarred the area last weekend, many homeowners may be wondering whether they should buy special earthquake insurance.

headline: Seeking to Ease Worries, Obama Says the World Has Always Been ‘Messy’
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: The president finds himself trying to buck up supporters heading into a crucial midterm election season.
lead_paragraph: NEWPORT, R.I. — If the world seems troubled by all manner of calamities these days, President Obama does not want Americans to worry too much. After all, he said Friday, “The world has always been messy”; it is just more apparent because of social media. And, he added, today’s geopolitical threats are far less perilous than those of the Cold War.

headline: James Murphy Turns U.S. Open Matches Into Music
abstract: Each match from the tennis tournament is being turned into a soundtrack using a computer algorithm.
lead_paragraph: James Murphy has kept fairly busy since he disbanded LCD Soundsystem in 2011, with projects that have included writing film music, producing an album for the Yeah Yeah Yeahs and working with Arcade Fire. Over the next few weeks, he plans to add 400 hours of new music to his catalog.

headline: The Ringmaster Leaves Salzburg
abstract: With Alexander Pereira leaving for La Scala after three summers as the Salzburg Festival’s artistic director, the festival has an opportunity to redefine its identity.
lead_paragraph: SALZBURG, Austria — Alexander Pereira, whose final day as the artistic director of the Salzburg Festival, after three summers here, is Sunday, stood in the wings a few weeks ago at the Haus für Mozart, one of the festival’s theaters. The curtain had just fallen at the end of opening night of Schubert’s seldom-performed “Fierrabras,” the first time an opera by that composer had been staged here. Mr. Pereira, 66, grinned widely and doled out congratulations as the singers left the stage.

headline: New Cabinet in Turkey Mirrors That of Last Premier
abstract: The continued presence of Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s appointees at the head of key ministries left little doubt that the president would retain strong influence over the government.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Turkey’s prime minister-designate, Ahmet Davutoglu, announced a new cabinet on Friday that is dominated by holdovers from the administration of his predecessor, Recep Tayyip Erdogan. Mr. Erdogan is now the president and seeking to maintain a grip on power after moving to what until now has been a largely ceremonial office.

headline: Indian Economy Grows 5.7%, Its Fastest Pace in More Than 2 Years
abstract: Manufacturing and mining helped bolster the economy, but the new government still faces a long road to achieve substantial economic changes.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — India’s economy grew 5.7 percent in the three months that ended in June from the same period a year ago, according to government estimates released on Friday, signaling a gradual revival in Asia’s third-largest economy in the quarter in which it elected its new leader, Narendra Modi.

keywords: ['Grants (Corporate and Foundation)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Poverty', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: For Tenille Warren, the burden of growing up poor was too heavy for even the offer of a free ride to college to counter. But, about to turn 38, she is back on track at the Fashion Institute of Technology.
lead_paragraph: At the corner of Seventh Avenue and 27th Street, Tenille Warren waited impatiently for the light to change. She swept under the purple welcome banner into the Fashion Institute of Technology’s industrial-looking building, raced upstairs to her class and slid into the front row beside a mannequin dressed in a Lululemon jacket. This was no time to be fashionably late.

headline: For Some, ’Tis a Gift to Be Simple
abstract: Research shows that the older a person gets, the more happiness is derived from everyday activities, not extraordinary events.
lead_paragraph: Last month, I spent a day in a library for the first time in over 20 years. I was there to work, but I appeared to be the only one doing so. Everyone else lolled about as the rain fell outside, helping themselves to the endless shelves of newspapers and magazines or browsing the newest fiction.

headline: No PB&J Allowed? Put Dips Into Lunchboxes

lead_paragraph: A three-bedroom sponsor unit at the Marquand, a century-old building at 11 East 68th Street that underwent an extravagant conversion by the HFZ Capital Group last year, sold for $17,819,375 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: ISIS Fears Prompt Britain to Raise Terrorism Threat Level
abstract: Alarmed by the suspected presence of hundreds of British jihadists among Sunni militants in Syria and Iraq, the government also said new laws would be introduced to counter security threats.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Alarmed by the suspected presence of hundreds of British jihadists among Sunni militants in Syria and Iraq, Britain increased its assessment of the terrorism threat on its own soil on Friday and said new laws would be introduced to counter what Prime Minister David Cameron called “a greater threat to our security than we have seen before.”

headline: 13, and Surviving in the Woods on Squirrel Pizza
abstract: The 20-something mastermind behind my son’s outdoor survival program presented parents with no medical forms or really any assurances for our children’s safety. Yet my son has never been hurt any worse than he has playing with friends in our finished basement, and it has transformed him.
lead_paragraph: “Mom, Mom, I ate a squirrel testicle!” shouts my son’s friend Ollie as he darts out of the woods toward his mother. The expression on his face can be described only as ecstatic.

headline: Green Acres, the Place to Be
abstract: As part of a tourism project, the Hudson Valley town of New Lebanon, N.Y., is being reimagined as what it hopes will be a “living museum of contemporary rural American life.”
lead_paragraph: NEW LEBANON, N.Y. — Small rural communities are perpetually marketing themselves. Witness the annual Heritage Spudfest in Boonsboro, Md., or the World’s Largest Ball of Twine in Cawker City, Kan.

headline: On One Chinese Beach, a Parade of Curiously Covered-Up Style
abstract: The photographer Philipp Engelhorn spent eight days capturing swimmers in the northern Chinese city of Qingdao, where elaborate face masks and bodysuits are a local tradition.
lead_paragraph: The German-born, New York-trained photographer Philipp Engelhorn has spent the past 11 years living just off the beach in a village near Hong Kong. There, he has long been accustomed to seeing the local “Po Pos” (a slang term for elderly women) going for their morning swim. Engelhorn became intrigued, however, when he heard about how women in the northern Chinese city of Qingdao undertake the same ritual wearing colorful head masks and bodysuits. (The custom originated as a method of protection against the area’s giant stinging jellyfish, though many bathers also told Engelhorn their objective was to block the sun’s rays.) For eight days, he captured Qingdao swimmers in their elaborate armor — much of which, it turned out, was homemade.

headline: In Crown Heights, Small-Batch Food Scene Meets Beer Hall
abstract: Berg’n is a vast new place in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, with food vendors and craft brews.
lead_paragraph: After raising the tent on Brooklyn’s small-batch food scene, the Smorgasburg empire has expanded into Crown Heights. Berg’n, a new beer hall with longtime food vendors from the weekend festivals, threw open its glass garage doors on Wednesday, revealing a nearly 9,000-square-foot room of dark wood and light-painted brick walls that felt instantly cool and comfortably full by lunchtime. Culinary options include Asia Dog and Pizza Moto, while the bar offers craft brews like Peekskill Simple Sour and Sixpoint Sweet Action.

headline: Vice Media Stakes Future on A&E Networks Deal
abstract: A&E Networks will invest $250 million in Vice Media and receive a 10 percent stake in the company.
lead_paragraph: After spending the summer flirting with various suitors, Vice Media said on Friday that it was close to choosing a partner: A&E Networks.

headline: Hammerstein Festival Seeks to Inspire Great Lyrics
abstract: The Oscar Hammerstein Festival at the Bucks County Playhouse wants to encourage lyricists to engage with sophistication and wit.
lead_paragraph: Robyn Goodman and Alexander Fraser, the directors of the Bucks County Playhouse in New Hope, Pa., are presenting the first Oscar Hammerstein Festival next month. The festival, Sept. 26-28, will offer a weekend of performances and panel discussions, all open to the public. An affiliated yearlong mentorship program intends to remind composers and, particularly, lyricists in the early stages of their careers that musicals were once known for their sophistication and wit, and that they can be again.

headline: Height, Not Age, Restrictions at the Firing Range
abstract: The proprietor of the Arizona gun range where a 9-year-old lost control of an Uzi is kicking around a Disneyland-type policy.
lead_paragraph: Maybe the real problem was the 9-year-old girl wielding that deadly Uzi was a bit too short to be shooting it. That’s the postmortem thinking of the proprietor of the Arizona gun range where the pony-tailed youngster lost control of a war weapon in a burst that killed her instructor Monday.

headline: Just Add Farro
abstract: Wheat berries like farro, spelt and kamut are usually associated with cold weather. But they can be used for summer dishes, too. Farro is softer and good for stuffing vegetables. Spelt works well in salads.
lead_paragraph: Wheat berries like farro, spelt and kamut are hearty, and I usually associate them with cool-weather dishes. But I’m working on a pantry cleanout, as I do every summer, and I found a number of half-filled bags that needed my attention. I cooked up big pots of farro and spelt after soaking the grains overnight. I usually soak wheat berries for only an hour, but I thought I’d see what an overnight soak yielded. Then I used them in several cool summer dishes.

headline: Where Harmony Resided
abstract: An apartment at the Beresford that was owned by the Broadway composer Mary Rodgers enters the market for the first time in a quarter of a century.
lead_paragraph: A quaint yet elegant apartment at the Beresford that was owned by Broadway royalty, the author/composer/philanthropist Mary Rodgers and her husband Henry Guettel, and served for decades as a musical salon and gathering place for the denizens of Broadway theater, is about to enter the market for the first time in a quarter of a century.

headline: Experimental Drug Would Help Fight Ebola if Supply Increases, Study Finds
abstract: All 18 monkeys exposed to a lethal dose of the virus and given the experimental drug survived, raising hopes that ZMapp will work in people.
lead_paragraph: A new study provides strong evidence that the experimental drug given to two American aid workers stricken with Ebola in Africa really works and could make a difference in the current outbreak — if more of it could be produced.

headline: A Tower in Brooklyn, but Soon Just a Memory
abstract: The tower holding the Domino Sugar sign in Brooklyn is being torn down to make room for residential housing.
lead_paragraph: From the East River Ferry, it seems to belong more to the industrial Brooklyn Navy Yard than to the increasingly glass and steel skyline of Williamsburg: a hulking mass of brick, covered with graffiti, that could pass for a ruined castle were it not for the insistent modernism of the beige refinery tower that squats to its right. But the tower holds what to many is the most important part of the whole structure: the yellow letters that spell out Domino Sugar.

headline: Embarking on a New Path
abstract: The Giants went 7-9 and became an easy target for late-night television comedians and a frequent punching bag on sports-talk radio.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — In the final minutes of the Giants’ loss at Chicago last October, a game that included three Eli Manning interceptions and dropped their record to 0-6, the team’s co-owner John Mara vaulted from his seat in a rooftop box, growled in disgust and stormed into a hallway, where he stamped back and forth with his hands in his pockets.

lead_paragraph: On Wednesday night, air marshals intervened when two passengers aboard an American Airlines flight from Miami to Paris began fighting over the right to recline their seat.

headline: Square Feeling Squeezed From All Sides
abstract: Increasing competition and the need to diversify into other businesses are putting pressure on Square, Robert Cyran writes for Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Square is starting to look oddly hollow. The payments company, set up and run by Jack Dorsey, is set to raise $200 million in new financing, according to Bloomberg. That would value the company at $6 billion. While big, it is a deflated figure, considering Square’s former hype, the small amount raised and rivals’ ease in securing higher valuations.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama is considering a delay of his most controversial proposals to revamp immigration laws through executive action until after the midterm elections in November, mindful of the electoral peril for Democratic Senate candidates, according to allies of the administration who have knowledge of White House deliberations.

headline: Shakeup at the Pennsylvania Ballet
abstract: The ballet’s new artistic director, Ángel Corella, has replaced several longtime artistic leaders.
lead_paragraph: In what looks like a sudden bloodletting occasioned by a recent change of artistic leadership, the Pennsylvania Ballet has dismissed Jeffrey Gribler, who was ballet master, and Tamara Hadley, who was ballet mistress, as well as William DeGregory, who was director of the company’s ballet school and the Pennsylvania Ballet II training company. Michael Sheridan, the assistant to the artistic director, and others in the company’s marketing and fund-raising departments were also let go. Most of those who were fired had been with the company for most of their careers. Mr. Gribler, for example, came to the company as an apprentice in 1975.

headline: The Mystery of the New York City Parks Department’s Chandelier
abstract: Answering questions about the chandelier in the Arsenal; a renamed street in Queens; and the Bronx roots of Calvin Klein and Ralph Lauren.
lead_paragraph: Q. The lobby of the Arsenal, the former weapons storehouse in Central Park, which is now the headquarters of New York City’s Department of Parks and Recreation, has an odd feature for such a utilitarian building: a huge crystal chandelier that would be at home in an opera house. How did it get there?

headline: As Virginia Trial Ends, Jury Is Asked to Decide if Ex-Governor Was Corrupt, or Hapless Husband
abstract: Prosecutors warned jurors not to accept defense arguments that former Gov. Bob McDonnell was unfairly targeted by law enforcement.
lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Va. — Ending a five-week trial that pulled back the curtain on a Virginia governor’s acceptance of a Rolex, a borrowed Ferrari and sweetheart loans, jurors hearing the case against former Gov. Bob McDonnell and his wife, Maureen, were asked on Friday to decide if Mr. McDonnell was a corrupt politician who traded his office for luxury goods or a hapless husband caught up in a mess created by his wife’s greed.

headline: When a Child Kills

abstract: When I was 12, I shot my brother in a hunting accident. I grew up, but I never healed.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — WHEN I was 12 years old, I killed a younger brother in a hunting accident near our home in upstate New York. I returned to that memory this week, when I read about what happened to the young New Jersey girl who lost control of a submachine gun at a shooting range outside Las Vegas, killing her instructor.

headline: Tony Stewart Says Kevin Ward Jr.’s Death Will Affect Him Forever
abstract: After nearly three weeks without speaking publicly, Tony Stewart suggested returning to Nascar competition would best help him cope with the death of Kevin Ward Jr.
lead_paragraph: HAMPTON, Ga. — Tony Stewart ended nearly three weeks of silence since his racecar struck and killed a young driver at an upstate New York dirt track, voicing sympathy on Friday for the family of Kevin Ward Jr. and suggesting a return to Nascar competition this weekend would help him cope with lingering grief.

headline: Look at Life Through Autistic Eyes
abstract: Simulations of sensory overload can help us understand what it is like to live with autism.

In an old book bought in an antiques store, he explains, he found a pirate, a relative of his. Then he asks the guests for help finding his treasure.

headline: Freud’s City, From Couch to Cafes
abstract: Visiting Vienna, Freud’s longtime home, 75 years after his death.
lead_paragraph: Sigmund Freud’s feelings about Vienna ranged from ambivalence to outright hatred. “Vienna oppresses me,” he wrote in his letters, describing the city alternately as “disgusting” or “almost physically repulsive,” calling its glorious cathedral, St. Stephen’s, “that abominable steeple,” and complaining of his exceedingly cultivated, music-loving, cafe-crazed Viennese followers, “I wish they had a single backside so that I could thrash them all with one stick.”

lead_paragraph: A century ago, the windows of East 57th Street between Fifth and Madison Avenues were the art showcase of New York, but now not a single oil, gouache, etching or sculpture tempts the passer-by.

headline: 1,000 Islands, 2 Worlds
abstract: In the Maldives, escapist resorts coexist with the country’s strict Islamic government.
lead_paragraph: The restaurant was somewhere near the presidential palace. At least that’s what the Internet had said. It was dark in Malé, the capital of the Maldives, where we had woken up at our hotel, hungry after traveling for more than 40 hours. We’d slept through our chance to eat there: The kitchen downstairs was already closed. But Google Maps proposed a takeout place a couple of blocks away.

headline: For Andy Murray, the Idea of an Independent Scotland Starts to Hit Home
abstract: In a Q. and A., Murray spoke about his Scottish roots, his grandmother’s cooking and the prospect of playing under the Scotland flag.
lead_paragraph: The issue of what it means to be Scottish is a rising debate, with a referendum scheduled for Sept. 18 to determine if Scotland should be an independent country, separate from the United Kingdom. Andy Murray, one of the world’s most famous Scotsmen, has stayed quiet about his opinion on the vote, but says he has been following the debate “very closely.” After his comfortable 6-3, 6-3, 6-4 second-round victory over the qualifier Matthias Bachinger on Thursday night, Murray spoke to The New York Times about going home to Scotland. In previous conversations at the U.S. Open, Murray has discussed his perspective on this year’s tournament and female coaches in tennis. (This interview was condensed and edited.)

headline: And a Box of Tissues
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Photography', 'Psychiatry and Psychiatrists', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: It took Sebastian Zimmermann, a psychiatrist on the Upper West Side, 13 years to produce “Fifty Shrinks,” a book of portraits depicting “therapists in their natural habitats.”
lead_paragraph: Here’s something you rarely see: New York psychotherapists in their offices in August. It took Sebastian Zimmermann, a psychiatrist on the Upper West Side, 13 years to produce “Fifty Shrinks,” a book of portraits depicting “therapists in their natural habitats.” Dr. Zimmermann, who began studying photography as an outlet to counterbalance all the trauma and drama he was taking in as a therapist, said he was struck by the diversity of spaces in which his colleagues worked.

headline: Of Pot and Percocet
abstract: Is access to medical marijuana reducing painkiller overdoses?
lead_paragraph: PRESCRIPTION opioid painkillers like Percocet, Vicodin and OxyContin have come under intense scrutiny in recent years because of the drastic rise in overdose deaths associated with their prolonged use. Meanwhile, access to medical marijuana has been expanding — 23 states and the District of Columbia have legalized its broad medical use — and chronic or severe pain is by far the most common condition reported among people using it.

headline: In New Jersey, Making Labor Day Less Laborious
abstract: There are plenty of public events on Sept. 1, many of them free, to help entertain families in need of escape from their own backyards. After Labor Day, some of these outdoor attractions will continue for weekends to come.
lead_paragraph: Labor Day is supposed to be about honoring workers with a day of rest. But for families with young children, the holiday can be anything but relaxing. Camp is over, summer vacations are winding down and school, for many, hasn’t started yet. Thankfully there are plenty of public events on Sept. 1, many of them free, to help entertain families in need of escape from their own backyards. After Labor Day, some of these outdoor attractions will continue for weekends to come, as long as the temperate weather holds out.

Exhibit A: Henry and Henrietta, the pair of peregrine falcons that nest on a ledge high above Morningside Heights. Exhibit B: the Locrian Chamber Players, one of the most uncompromising contemporary-music ensembles in the city.

lead_paragraph: Every spring in Argentina, the local cowboys, called gauchos, gather in the historical town of San Antonio de Areco for a nine-day festival to show off their equestrian skills, and for the 75th year running from Nov. 1 to 9, the 19th-century ranch La Bamba de Areco is giving travelers a chance to participate in the celebration.

headline: Handmade Landscapes
abstract: We manufacture new vistas and move so comfortably among them that quite often we confuse them with natural habitats.
lead_paragraph: THE earth isn’t the same when you fly over it at 3,000 feet. It’s easy to lose your bearings. All the reassuring textures of daily life are lost. But it’s a grand perch for viewing our tracks on the ground — visible everywhere and just as readable as the cleft-heart footprints left by white-tailed deer.

headline: Comic Books Even Teachers Can Love
abstract: Toon Graphics is producing comic books it hopes will be studied as serious textbooks in the fourth grade and beyond.
lead_paragraph: When fifth graders at P.S. 124 in Brooklyn were given a sneak peek last winter of “Theseus and the Minotaur,” a retelling of the classic Greek myth by the French writer and cartoonist Yvan Pommaux, they immediately took to the tale, their teacher, Daniel Tandarich, said. And why not? The book, the first from Toon Graphics, is filled with gruesomely creative murders, feats of superhuman strength, misbehaving gods and bloodthirsty beasts. A scene in which a rampaging bull gores a Cretan youth was a particular favorite, Mr. Tandarich said. The best part about “Theseus and the Minotaur,” at least for this audience: It’s a comic book.

headline: Honoring an Instrument of Few Strings With the Strength of a Symphony
abstract: The Metropolitan Museum of Art is devoting an exhibition, “The Sacred Lute,” and accompanying performances to Ostad Elahi and the sacred tanbur.
lead_paragraph: Most mystics begin their lives in the wider community and then retreat into seclusion, but the musician and philosopher Ostad Elahi (1895-1974) followed the opposite path. After a sequestered youth perfecting his skills on the tanbur — a long-necked lute — in the company of mystics like his father, he moved to Tehran, became an influential judge and helped establish a new legal system in Iran.

lead_paragraph: The experience of watching “As Above/So Below” is much like observing a colonoscopy in the hands of a particularly inexpert and excitable physician. Instead of human intestines, we have the bowels of Paris — the mass cemetery known as the catacombs — into which a small group of rash young folks spelunks in search of the legendary Philosopher’s Stone.

headline: Pre-Labor Day Food News
abstract: Some good reads for the holiday weekend.
lead_paragraph: California: As the three-year drought drags on, the Bureau of Reclamation has decided to save some water for the fish. Last week the agency began releasing additional water from a nearby reservoir to supplement flows in the lower Klamath River. Thousands of adult Chinook salmon are struggling to survive in the river, whose waters are running dangerously low and warm due to diversion of river flows into the Central Valley for agriculture. While the move is a win for environmental groups and Indian tribes that depend on the salmon for subsistence, drought-weary farmers are crying foul.

headline: A Queen’s Forbidden Love
abstract: Victoria’s relationship with her servant had a flirtatious side.
lead_paragraph: THEIR relationship titillated a nation. For more than a century, biographers have tried to fathom the improbable friendship Queen Victoria had with her Scottish servant John Brown. It has been posited as one of the great unanswered questions of her reign. How intimate were they?

headline: Saving Our Birds

lead_paragraph: ITHACA, N.Y. — THE passenger pigeon is among the most famous of American birds, but not because of its beauty, or its 60-mile-an-hour flight speed. Nor is it a cherished symbol of our great country. No, we remember the passenger pigeon because of the largest-scale human-caused extinction in history.

headline: The 15th World Youth Teams Championships in Bridge
abstract: A team from France won the girls event, for players born after 1988.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — At the 15th World Youth Teams Championships here last week, in the girls event, for players born after 1988, the round-robin qualifying matches were followed by four 56-board quarterfinals. In these, there were easy victories for China, Italy and the Netherlands (over the United States). In the fourth, Australia led France by 27 international match points, with 14 boards to be played, but in a big last session, France triumphed by 12 imps.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Transition to Fall
abstract: As summer fades, women are adjusting to autumn with a deeper palette.
lead_paragraph: Crossroad As summer fades, women are adjusting to autumn with a deeper palette, from fir-tree greens to burgundies, charcoal and black. This summer will be remembered for its cool weather, calling for jackets and cardigans. The curiosities were the popularity of city shorts and one-piece playsuits, and of gladiator sandals. Lace shorts gained momentum for a second year. And the summer was not without whimsy.

headline: Swirls of Dust and Drama, Punctuating Life in the Southwest
abstract: Children, drivers and other residents have learned how to prepare for huge dust storms, sometimes called haboobs, that can turn day into night in seconds.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — The best way to explain a haboob is to say it is a tsunami of sand, in the sense that there is no stopping it or outrunning it. It is a supreme spectacle. The fierce winds that precede it make the leaves on palm trees stand as if they are hands waving an effusive goodbye, the sky darkens and the world takes the color of caramel as the dust swallows everything in its path.

headline: To Defeat Terror, We Need the World’s Help
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: No civilized country can shirk its responsibility to fight a global scourge.
lead_paragraph: IN a polarized region and a complicated world, the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria presents a unifying threat to a broad array of countries, including the United States. What’s needed to confront its nihilistic vision and genocidal agenda is a global coalition using political, humanitarian, economic, law enforcement and intelligence tools to support military force.

headline: Stop Dithering, Confront ISIS
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'Terrorism']
abstract: No one is advocating an invasion, but we need a military strategy, and a far greater sense of urgency.
lead_paragraph: AFTER more than three years, almost 200,000 dead in Syria, the near collapse of Iraq, and the rise of the world’s most sinister terrorist army — the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, which has conquered vast swaths of both countries — President Obama’s admission this week that “we don’t have a strategy yet” to deal with this threat is startling. It is also dangerous.

headline: Quarantine for Ebola Lifted in Liberia Slum

lead_paragraph: MONROVIA, Liberia — Liberia’s government announced Friday night that it would lift an Ebola quarantine on a large slum here in the capital, 10 days after attempts to cordon off the neighborhood from the rest of the city sparked deadly clashes and fueled doubts about President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf’s ability to handle the outbreak.

lead_paragraph: HAMPTON BAYS, N.Y. — All along the bucolic back roads of this blue-collar gateway to the more opulent Hamptons, residents agree: There is nothing sophisticated about the Ku Klux Klan’s continuing drive to recruit new members.

lead_paragraph: When exactly did Middletown become cool? Its spacious Main Street, sunlit and broad like a Midwestern town, seems an unlikely setting for culinary bohemianism. Yet it’s crammed with different kinds of restaurants — Vietnamese, Tibetan, Mexican; a diner; a pizza-and-bourbon joint; a vegetarian place; and on and on.

abstract: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission’s move means new nuclear plants can be built and old ones can expand their operations despite the lack of a long-term plan for disposing of the waste.
lead_paragraph: As the country struggles to find a place to bury spent nuclear fuel, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has decided that nuclear waste from power plants can be stored above ground in containers that can be maintained and guarded indefinitely.

headline: New West Renaissance
abstract: Welcome to an ecosystem where the urban and the wild depend on each other.
lead_paragraph: LAKEVIEW, Mont. — Just a teardrop down from the Continental Divide, in one of the most remote hideaways in the United States, is a place that should be called Hope. At 6,700 feet above sea level, Centennial Valley is high, mostly dry, and slack-jaw beautiful. The fact that there are more trumpeter swans here than people is a story that tells much about why the American West has never been more vibrant.

On Saturday, No. 12 Georgia will host No. 16 Clemson; No. 1 Florida State will play Oklahoma State in Arlington, Tex.; and last year’s top midmajor, Central Florida, will play Penn State in Ireland — now that the volcano gods have forestalled a feared Icelandic eruption, permitting the teams to travel.

lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo had no time for tortellini. Marching in a parade on Staten Island recently, he paused to pose for a picture with Vincent J. D’Antuono, the owner of Pastosa Ravioli, an Italian specialty shop, who proudly invited the governor to step inside for a look around.

headline: A Chef Finds a Kitchen of His Own
abstract: By the time he was 10, Scott Giordano knew that he wanted to be a chef. “I couldn’t stay out of the kitchen,” he said. Last May, he opened the Poached Pear Bistro, which he owns with his brother, Marc, in Point Pleasant Beach.
lead_paragraph: And still I think of the pear pizzetta appetizer. What a marvel: pizza dough cooked so expertly in a 500-degree convection oven that its light and flaky texture resembled that of pastry dough, with slivers of fresh pear, shaved radicchio, walnuts toasted to release oils that tasted like butter, and a thin layer of tangy Gorgonzola cheese running like lava across the surface of the whole, misshapen, messy pie. A drizzle of port wine, reduced until it resembled honey, united all the disparate elements.

In June, Mr. Schaudel, a restaurateur and chef, opened a new place called Petulant Wino in the heart of North Fork wine country. He told his staff the name was autobiographical. The employee who related this conversation to me in a phone call after my visits there said, “He’s not a bit petulant.”

headline: Werner Franz, Survivor of the Hindenburg’s Crew, Dies at 92
abstract: Mr. Franz was a 14-year-old cabin boy when the immense German zeppelin erupted into flames. He was believed to be the last surviving member of the crew.
lead_paragraph: Just before 7:30 p.m. on May 6, 1937, the Hindenburg, an immense German zeppelin that had spent three days crossing the Atlantic, erupted in flames as it approached its mooring mast at the Lakehurst Naval Air Station in central New Jersey. Seen around the world in newsreel coverage and photographs, the disaster, which was attributed to an electric spark igniting the hydrogen gas that kept the airship aloft, killed 35 of the 97 people on board and another man on the ground.

Children wearing bright white keikogi practiced their moves on the sidewalk and chased each other through the street. headline: Afghanistan: 6 Killed in Assault on Intelligence Office in Jalalabad
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'Terrorism', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Insurgents attacked the headquarters of the Afghan intelligence service in Jalalabad, in the country’s east, setting off a huge bomb that killed at least six people and wounded 45 others, Afghan officials said.
lead_paragraph: JALALABAD — Insurgents early Saturday attacked the headquarters of the Afghan intelligence service here in this eastern city, setting off a huge bomb that killed at least six people and wounded 45 others, Afghan officials said. The attackers, who included suicide bombers, were believed to have taken up positions in a nearby building to continue the assault, the officials said. The initial bomb, which the authorities described as huge, was hidden in a car and detonated outside the provincial headquarters of the National Directorate of Security here about 5 a.m. It was not immediately clear if the victims were intelligence employees or civilians. The bomb damaged many homes in the vicinity of the directorate offices, witnesses at the scene said.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) THE HOBBIT: THE DESOLATION OF SMAUG (2013) Benedict Cumberbatch lends his voice to Smaug, the menacing dragon who lords over the lost dwarf kingdom and vast treasure in this second installment in Peter Jackson’s adaptation of J. R. R. Tolkien’s book. Martin Freeman (who plays Watson to Mr. Cumberbatch’s Holmes on the television series “Sherlock”) once again portrays Bilbo, the hobbit who has been chosen to lead the fight for the reclamation. Mr. Jackson “has taken roughly five chapters from the middle of Tolkien’s book and turned them into a relentless adventure tale, teeming with rowdy action, slavering enemies and Elven gymnastics,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times, noting the director’s tendency “to pile it on.” Once again, she said, there are “too many busy, uninterestingly staged battles that lean heavily on obvious, sometimes distracting digital sorcery. But there are also pacific, brooding interludes in which the actors — notably Mr. Freeman, an intensely appealing screen presence — remind you that there’s more to Middle-earth than clamor and struggle.”
