headline: ISIS Displaying a Deft Command of Varied Media
abstract: ISIS, the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, is using every contemporary mode of messaging to recruit fighters, intimidate enemies and promote its claim to have established a caliphate.
lead_paragraph: The extremists who have seized large parts of Syria and Iraq have riveted the world’s attention with their military prowess and unrestrained brutality. But Western intelligence services are also worried about their extraordinary command of seemingly less lethal weapons: state-of-the-art videos, ground images shot from drones and multilingual Twitter messages.

headline: For a Career Guide, 42 Years of Soft Landings
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Careers and Professions', 'Social Media']
abstract: The writer of the popular career guide, first commercially published in 1972, updates the book each year, but some of its original points are still true.
lead_paragraph: Richard Bolles does not mince words. “Let us put the matter simply and candidly,” he writes. “The whole process of the job hunt in this country is Neanderthal.”

headline: Variety: Camouflage
abstract: Can you find the proper names or titles that Will Shortz has hidden from us?
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — Well, this was a fun and refreshing puzzle. As it says in the instructions, this puzzle was completed in seven minutes and 40 seconds by Jeffrey Harris of Nashville, Tenn., at the recent National Puzzlers’ League Convention in Portland, Me. That’s not exactly news, as he is an exceptionally brilliant person who tends to win most of these things, so sincere congratulations, Mr. Harris. To the rest of you, a word of warning: If you ever see Mr. Harris sharpening his pencil within your line of sight at a puzzle tournament, run for your lives.

headline: A Family Hits the Road
keywords: ['Road Trips', 'Families and Family Life', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Photography']
abstract: Our family lived on the road for several years when I was young. This summer, we tried it again.
lead_paragraph: RUSTED ROOT’s song “Send Me on My Way” is blaring as my sister, Cassidy, winds our little Nissan Sentra through the serpentine roads of the Cascade Mountains in Oregon. The fresh basil my dad bought as a “car freshener” is wilting on the dash, adding to the smells from our dirt-covered clothes, rich with the odors of helping out at a friend’s farm.

headline: No Canvas, No Leather: A Reboot for the Sneaker
keywords: ['Shoes and Boots', 'Sneakers', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Recycling of Waste Materials']
abstract: Unconventional footwear materials, like Tyvek, are offering a new take on the minimalist shoe trend.
lead_paragraph: When people first pick up a pair of sneakers designed by Steven Weinreb, they are typically perplexed.

headline: Ukraine President Says Europe’s Security Depends on Stopping Russia
abstract: President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine won no pledges of military assistance from the European Union, but his warnings helped set the stage for a new round of sanctions against Russia.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Accusing Russia of waging a campaign of “military aggression and terror” against his country, President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine told European leaders here on Saturday that their own countries’ security depended on stopping Russian troops from stoking a conflict in eastern Ukraine that he said could escalate into a wider war.

headline: When Did We Get So Old?
abstract: For many of us, it is a psychological quandary that is causing the most unpleasantness: looking around and suddenly being the oldest.
lead_paragraph: JOHNATHAN RODGERS, who is 68, knew that it was time to step down as president and chief executive of the cable channel TV One when he looked around the conference table. “I had almost always been the youngest through most of my career,” says the former media executive. “Now I was the oldest, and it caused great discomfort.”

headline: Liberal Zionism Today
abstract: Strong reactions to an essay saying that Israeli policies have tarnished the Zionist ideal.
lead_paragraph: Strong reactions to an essay saying that Israeli policies have tarnished the Zionist ideal.

headline: Endless Assault on Health Care Reform
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Law and Legislation', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: The latest jerry-built effort to destroy the Affordable Care Act is facing likely defeat before a full federal appeals court in the District of Columbia.
lead_paragraph: The opponents of the Affordable Care Act make no secret of their consuming hatred for the law that has already provided health care to millions of lower-income people.

headline: Stop Hiding Images of American Torture
keywords: ['Torture', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Freedom of Information Act', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Editorials']
abstract: America reinforces its values by being transparent — even about horrific abuses of those values.
lead_paragraph: A hooded man standing on a box, electrodes wired to his fingers. A naked prisoner lying on a cement floor, a leash around his neck held casually by an American soldier. The bloody bodies of dead inmates with their heads bashed in.

headline: Attack Kills 12 at Afghan Compound
abstract: A dozen people were killed when insurgents attacked the headquarters of the Afghan intelligence service in this eastern city Saturday.
lead_paragraph: JALALABAD, Afghanistan — A dozen people were killed when insurgents attacked the headquarters of the Afghan intelligence service in this eastern city Saturday.

headline: Broken Promises on National Service
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Volunteers and Community Service', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Washington’s dysfunction is resulting in missed opportunities to expand the public service program AmeriCorps.
lead_paragraph: AmeriCorps turns 20 on Sept. 12, and as the nation’s main public service program in those two decades, it has benefited numerous communities and given 900,000 Americans a chance to help people.

headline: With Memories Entrenched, Hallowed Site of U.S. Open Plows Forward
abstract: At the U.S. Open, where thwacks echo across eras, the grounds are in classic New York dig-we-must mode in preparation for a retractable roof in two years.
lead_paragraph: There is a Big Dig in Flushing Meadows Park — trash bins lined up in a gouged hillside off the Grand Central Parkway.

headline: High Tea With Mr. Fancypants Sheen
abstract: After playing everyone from Mozart to Tony Blair, the actor Michael Sheen puts the Master of Sex on top.
lead_paragraph: IS sex more important than music, war, sports and vampires? Is sex more important than Nixon?

headline: Diplomat and Warrior
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: We need Richard Holbrooke’s skill and resolve today.
lead_paragraph: ON Sept. 8, 2011, Hillary Clinton, then secretary of state, wrote to the secretary of the Army requesting that an exception to policy be granted to allow Richard C. Holbrooke to be buried at Arlington National Cemetery. Holbrooke had collapsed in her office nine months earlier. He died soon after while serving in the most thankless of his many assignments, as President Obama’s special representative for Afghanistan and Pakistan.

headline: When Whites Just Don’t Get It
abstract: White America should wipe away any self-satisfaction about racial progress. Many challenges remain to achieving equality.
lead_paragraph: MANY white Americans say they are fed up with the coverage of the shooting of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Mo. A plurality of whites in a recent Pew survey said that the issue of race is getting more attention than it deserves.

headline: Lesotho Military Moves on Police
keywords: ["Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Police']
abstract: The country’s prime minister said the actions amounted to a coup, although a spokesman for the army said the soldiers were only securing the country.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — A military coup in the tiny southern African kingdom of Lesotho has chased out the prime minister and apparently put the army in control of the landlocked nation, witnesses and journalists in the capital said on Saturday.

headline: Facing Hard-Liners and Sanctions, Iran’s Leader Toughens Talk
abstract: In the second year of Hassan Rouhani’s presidency, he has struck a new tone, echoing the longstanding Iranian view that the United States can never be trusted.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — For more than a year, Iran’s president, Hassan Rouhani, had been walking a political tightrope by trying to restore some level of relations with the country’s archenemy, the United States. His hard-line opponents pelted him with eggs for his efforts, while those who voted for him hoped for a possible thaw.

headline: The Original Charter School Vision
keywords: ['Charter Schools', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Education (K-12)', 'Organized Labor', 'Collective Bargaining', 'Segregation and Desegregation']
abstract: It was supposed to free up teachers and integrate students.
lead_paragraph: ALTHOUGH the leaders of teachers unions and charter schools are often in warring camps today, the original vision for charter schools came from Albert Shanker, the president of the American Federation of Teachers.

headline: A Former Ace Nurtures His Work in Progress
abstract: Noah Syndergaard, a top Mets prospect, is benefiting from the tutelage of Frank Viola, a former Cy Young Award winner and the pitching coach at the Mets Class AAA affiliate.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — As Frank Viola walked toward the mound, Noah Syndergaard kicked at the dirt and hung his head like a child who knew he had misbehaved.

headline: Getting Ferguson Majority to Show Its Clout at Polls
abstract: In the wake of the Michael Brown killing, there is a new focus on turnout in a suburb that is majority black but has mostly white elected leaders.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — Down the street from where the body of Michael Brown lay for hours after he was shot three weeks ago, volunteers have appeared beside folding tables under fierce sunshine to sign up new voters. On West Florissant Avenue, the site of sometimes violent nighttime protests for two weeks, voter-registration tents popped up during the day and figures like the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson Sr. lectured about the power of the vote.

headline: In E-Sports, Video Gamers Draw Real Crowds and Big Money
abstract: Professional video gaming is becoming a worldwide spectator sport offering big prizes to competitors and helping the game industry gain even greater cultural and economic clout.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — A bewitching creature — half woman, half deer — battles a shaman and a sentient tree. Lightning bolts strike. Weapons explode. Nasty spells are cast.

headline: Kvitova Is the Latest High Seed to Be Ousted; Djokovic Advances Easily
abstract: Aleksandra Krunic, a 21-year-old qualifier, knocked out Petra Kvitova, leaving the women’s draw without its Nos. 2, 3, 4, 6 and 8 seeds. On the men’s side, Novak Djokovic dominated Sam Querrey.
lead_paragraph: The first week of the United States Open has had no shortage of improbable stories: the victory by 15-year-old CiCi Bellis, the comeback of Mirjana Lucic-Baroni, the first Open experience for the 34-year-old fan favorite Victor Estrella Burgos.

headline: Syrian Rebels Trade Fire With Troops From U.N.
abstract: Gunfire broke out on Saturday between United Nations peacekeepers in southern Syria and the Islamist rebels who had been surrounding their base near the Israeli-occupied Golan Heights.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Two bases for United Nations peacekeepers came under fire in southern Syria on Saturday, the United Nations said. One base was evacuated, and soldiers on the second returned fire, and later left the area.

headline: Hey, Chef: Next Time, Skip the Fennel
keywords: ['Restaurants', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Pop-Up Stores and Restaurants', 'Chefs', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Consumer Behavior']
abstract: A pop-up restaurant company is dedicated to the notion that high-end chefs should listen to their customers’ feedback.
lead_paragraph: It was a late July evening, and Christopher Sorter had just finished cooking an exotic five-course meal that included such triple-dare dishes as beef heart ragù and crème brûlée with bone marrow. When the dinner began, there had been some apprehension about the food among the 120 guests who had gathered in a warehouselike space in Silver Spring, Md. But as waiters cleared the last plates, the event had a relieved and jubilant air, as if everyone had just narrowly dodged a bus.

headline: Palestinian May Push for Deadline to End Occupation
abstract: The president of the Palestinian Authority may use the annual United Nations General Assembly to publicly demand an end date for Israel’s occupation.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority may use the global stage of the annual General Assembly here in a few weeks to publicly demand a deadline for ending Israel’s occupation, according to his ambassador, while expecting that the Israelis — and almost certainly their American allies — will oppose that demand.

headline: Fire Sale Begins to Pay Off for Marlins, for Now
abstract: Miami entered Friday at 65-67, after finishing 62-100 last season. A winning record is a possibility few saw coming after the Marlins traded five veterans to Toronto after their expensive flop in 2012.
lead_paragraph: Five major league teams lost at least 95 games last season, and four find themselves far below .500 again, a bystander to the pennant races. The Houston Astros, the Chicago White Sox, the Chicago Cubs and the Minnesota Twins are all but assured of another lonely October.

headline: What the Arbitration Panel Didn’t Want to Hear
keywords: ['ARBITRATION, CONCILIATION AND MEDIATION', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: An employee of Deutsche Bank Securities is questioning the handling of an arbitration case he brought against the firm — and his lawyer is asking a state court to step in.
lead_paragraph: Five years ago, Sean Martin, a registered representative at Deutsche Bank Securities in New York, saw something troubling on his trading desk.

headline: In the W.N.B.A., Women’s Coaching Journey Gets Easier
abstract: This is the first time that four female head coaches have led their teams to the W.N.B.A.’s conference finals.
lead_paragraph: Seventeen years ago, Lin Dunn was coaching the Portland Power of the short-lived American Basketball League. Dunn believed in sharing her knowledge of the game, so she allowed college coaches to watch her practices.

headline: Using Gambling to Entice Low-Income Families to Save
abstract: A growing number of credit unions and nonprofit groups are using lotteries to encourage low-income families to save.
lead_paragraph: While building up savings offers the best route out of poverty, the glamourless grind of socking away a dollar here and there has a tough time competing with the heady fantasy of a Mega Millions jackpot. But instead of attacking lotteries, a growing number of credit unions and nonprofit groups are using them to encourage low-income families to save.

headline: Pakistani Opposition Clashes With the Police
abstract: Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif said Saturday that he would not resign and called the demands to do so by his opponents “unacceptable” and “unconstitutional.”
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Clashes broke out in the Pakistani capital on Saturday night after thousands of protesters led by two opposition leaders tried to march toward the residence of Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif.

headline: George Galloway, British Lawmaker, Is Released From Hospital After Attack
abstract: A spokesman for George Galloway, known for his vocal criticism of Israel, said the attack on Friday was related to his declaration that a city in northern England was an “Israel-free zone.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — George Galloway, a member of the British Parliament known for his vocal criticism of Israel, was released from a hospital on Saturday after being treated for injuries suffered when an assailant attacked him on the streets of London.

headline: Ukraine’s Success Rooted in an Atlanta Connection
abstract: Mike Fratello, who was offered the position as coach of a national basketball team by his former Hawks player Alexander Volkov, has guided the team to the FIBA World Cup.
lead_paragraph: Ask Mike Fratello how in the world he became the coach of Ukraine’s national basketball team, and a history book opens. It doesn’t rewrite the consensus belief that N.B.A. globalization began earnestly with the 1992 Barcelona Olympics. It does provide a supplemental context that the growth of the game wasn’t all Magic, Larry and Michael.

headline: And Fairly Won
abstract: Georgia 1864 on my mind.
lead_paragraph: One hundred fifty years ago today, William Tecumseh Sherman’s corps, which had pulled back from in front of Atlanta — deceiving the Confederates into believing that they were in retreat — were scything around south of the city, cutting the rail lines. Hood’s army got away, but the victory was nonetheless decisive, for political reasons: the fall of Atlanta convinced voters that the war could and would be won, and Lincoln was reelected.

headline: The Culinary Contenders
abstract: A quick look at the three finalist chefs who vied for high scores from diners at Dinner Lab events.
lead_paragraph: For 10 weeks, a group of Dinner Lab chefs cooked at events around the country, vying for high scores from diners and the opportunity to open their own restaurants. Here is a quick look at the three finalists and the types of restaurants they have in mind.

headline: The N.F.L.’s Cultural Juggernaut May Risk Market Saturation
abstract: Prognosticators of doom for the N.F.L. say the league is getting too greedy, particularly in the expansion of its television package.
lead_paragraph: When the Dallas Mavericks owner Mark Cuban said the N.F.L. was “getting hoggy” in reference to the expansion of its television package and predicted a decline in its popularity in a decade, he was mocked by the true believers.

headline: Hal Finney, Cryptographer and Bitcoin Pioneer, Dies at 58
abstract: Mr. Finney made advancing online privacy his life’s work, and he took part in the first Bitcoin transaction, when Satoshi Nakamoto sent him 10 Bitcoins.
lead_paragraph: Hal Finney, a cryptographer and one of the earliest users and developers of the virtual currency Bitcoin, died on Thursday in Phoenix. He was 58.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Aug. 31
abstract: President Obama drew criticism on Thursday when he said, “we don’t have a strategy yet,” for military action against ISIS in Syria. Lawmakers will weigh in on Mr. Obama’s comments on the Sunday shows.
lead_paragraph: In a news briefing on Thursday, President Obama urged restraint and calm amid the continuing violence in Iraq and Ukraine, but he drew criticism when he said “we don’t have a strategy yet” for military action against Sunni extremists in Syria. Josh Earnest, the White House press secretary, appeared on several networks that evening to clarify the comment, saying that Mr. Obama was only speaking of Syria, and that the White House did have a strategy to combat the ISIS extremists who have crossed into Iraq.

headline: Heartsick City Imports Hope
abstract: Johnny Manziel has spurred ticket and merchandise sales as well as hopes that the Browns may someday win a championship, something that hasn’t happened since 1964.
lead_paragraph: BEREA, Ohio — A Cleveland Browns fan for 36 years, Geoff Myers cringed when his team fell short of the Super Bowl in the 1980s, wept when it left for Baltimore in the 1990s and sulked as its successor failed to make the playoffs every year except one since the Browns resumed play a decade and a half ago.

headline: Jets Make Two Prominent Cuts; Saints Release a 12-Time Pro Bowler
abstract: Cornerback Dimitri Patterson and receiver Stephen Hill, two of the Jets’ training-camp disappointments, were released as the team trimmed its roster to the league-mandated 53-man limit.
lead_paragraph: Cornerback Dimitri Patterson and receiver Stephen Hill, two of the Jets’ training-camp disappointments, were the most prominent among 21 players cut as the team trimmed its roster to the league-mandated 53-man limit.

headline: Arthur H. White Dies at 90; Gauged Public Opinion and Encouraged Reading
abstract: Mr. White was a co-founder of the research firm Yankelovich, Skelly & White, who went on to help start many nonprofits, including Reading Is Fundamental.
lead_paragraph: Arthur H. White, a co-founder of Yankelovich, Skelly & White, an innovative opinion research firm that shed light on American cultural and political changes, who later became a prominent leader in the nonprofit world, died on Aug. 25 in Stamford, Conn. He was 90.

headline: California Governor Appeals Court Ruling Overturning Protections for Teachers
abstract: In a one-page appeal, Gov. Jerry Brown and the state attorney general, Kamala D. Harris, argued that a decision of such scope needed to be made by a higher court.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Wading into an intense national battle that has pitted teacher unions against a movement to weaken tenure protections, Gov. Jerry Brown has appealed a California judge’s sweeping ruling that threw out teacher job protection laws on the ground that they deprived students of their constitutional rights.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines.
lead_paragraph: Towel Use Seen as Foul, In More Ways Than One

headline: In Nod to Eastern Europe, E.U. Names Poland Premier to Key Post
abstract: The selection is the latest sign that Poland is emerging as a larger player in European affairs, particularly on issues involving the bloc’s eastern front.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Union selected an Eastern European to one of the bloc’s top posts for the first time on Saturday as tensions increased with Russia over its incursions into Ukraine.

headline: Massachusetts May Shut Down Casinos Before Even One Opens
abstract: Massachusetts approved legislation in 2011 to allow three casinos and a slots parlor, and voters will decide in November whether to repeal the law before a single casino has been built.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — With the casino industry showing signs of retrenchment, voters in Massachusetts may do something that voters nowhere else have done, at least in the last century: slam on the brakes on casino gambling.

headline: A Screenplay Challenge
abstract: “The Chair,” a competition series on Starz, has two first-time directors face off to see who can create the best movie from the same script.
lead_paragraph: Music buffs have a host of singing competition shows to choose from. Fashionistas have “Project Runway” and its imitators. And now comes a competition series for film geeks: “The Chair,” in which two first-time directors face off to see who can create the best movie from the same script.

headline: A Footwork Challenge
abstract: At the DanceNow Festival, 40 choreographers (10 each night) vie for audience approval at Joe’s Pub within a strict time limit.
lead_paragraph: Five minutes is barely enough time to make an entrance, let alone “a clear and complete artistic statement,” but that’s the challenge posed by the annual DanceNow Festival. In this spirited contest and cocktail hour at Joe’s Pub, 40 choreographers (10 each night) vie for audience approval within a strict time limit. The dimensions of the pub’s petite stage also encourage brevity. The nightly winners share an encore bill on Sept. 13 and, having made efficient use of time and space, receive more of both in the form of a creative residency in rural Pennsylvania.

headline: The Working Class Made Colorful
abstract: The self-taught artist Ralph Fasanella (1914-97), born in the Bronx to Italian immigrants, believed that painting could be a form of labor advocacy.
lead_paragraph: The self-taught artist Ralph Fasanella (1914-97), born in the Bronx to Italian immigrants, believed that painting could be a form of labor advocacy. He worked as an ice delivery man, a truck driver, a gas station owner and a union organizer, all the while developing his colorful and detailed scenes of working-class life (as in “Family Supper,” which shows his mother, a garment worker, taking her second shift at a crowded dinner table). He also made historical paintings, like the mid-1970s series of canvases documenting the 1912 “Bread and Roses” strike in Lawrence, Mass.

headline: Praise the Lord, and Chase the Ratings
abstract: “Preachers of L.A.,” one of last year’s most invigorating and surprising reality television debuts, is now in its second season on Oxygen.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, Deitrick Haddon — son of a preacher, a gospel music star and a preacher himself — fled his Detroit home and ministry for Los Angeles and a “war against God.”

headline: Chamber Music Festival Fills a Void
abstract: The New York Chamber Music Festival has stepped up during the early September lull in the classical music calendar with innovative programs at Symphony Space.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, the New York Chamber Music Festival has stepped up during the early September lull in the classical music calendar with innovative programs at Symphony Space featuring both established and emerging artists. This year’s festival offers some intriguing programs on Friday and Saturday.

headline: Project Inspired by Klezmer
abstract: John Zorn, the indomitable composer, saxophonist and multiplatform ringleader, presides over 12 ensembles in a festival of his Jewish klezmer-inspired Masada project.
lead_paragraph: John Zorn — the indomitable composer, saxophonist and multiplatform ringleader — has lately enjoyed a flourishing of his music in notionally unlikely places, like the Newport Jazz Festival and the Metropolitan Museum of Art. This week, he’ll be at the Village Vanguard, perhaps an even more surprising locale, presiding over 12 ensembles in a festival of his Jewish klezmer-inspired Masada project.

headline: At Ferguson March, Call to Halt Traffic in Labor Day Highway Protest
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: In the continuing protests over the killing of a black teenager by a white police officer, protesters were encouraged to tie up traffic on the Labor Day holiday.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — Activists on Saturday called for mass civil disobedience on the highways in and around this St. Louis suburb to protest the killing of an unarmed black teenager by a white police officer, with the leaders of one coalition encouraging supporters to stop their cars to tie up traffic on Labor Day.

headline: Rams Cut Michael Sam, First Openly Gay Player Drafted in N.F.L.
abstract: On the final day of cuts across the league, the St. Louis Rams released defensive lineman Michael Sam, a seventh-round pick out of Missouri.
lead_paragraph: Michael Sam, the first openly gay player drafted by an N.F.L. team, was cut by the St. Louis Rams on Saturday.

headline: John Edwin Mroz, Clandestine Envoy to Arafat, Dies at 66
abstract: Mr. Mroz was a co-founder and the chief executive of the EastWest Institute, a New York-based group specializing in international conflict resolution.
lead_paragraph: John Edwin Mroz, a consultant to governments in Europe, the Middle East and elsewhere who conducted secret talks with Yasir Arafat on behalf of the Reagan administration in an unsuccessful effort to persuade the Palestine Liberation Organization to accept Israel’s right to exist, died on Aug. 15 in Manhattan. He was 66.

headline: Top Bitcoin Proponent to Plead Guilty to Federal Charge
abstract: Charles Shrem, a leading backer of Bitcoin, is to plead to one federal count of aiding and abetting an unlicensed money transmitting business.
lead_paragraph: A prominent supporter of Bitcoin, Charles Shrem, says he will plead guilty on Thursday to resolve federal charges that he helped smooth the way for drug transactions on the online marketplace Silk Road. He is to plead in New York to one count of aiding and abetting the operation of an unlicensed money transmitting business.

headline: With Ellsbury Out, Yankees Are Shut Out
abstract: The Yankees, missing one of their top hitters in Jacoby Ellsbury, managed only one hit as they were shut out in Toronto.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Even with Jacoby Ellsbury in the lineup, hits and runs from the Yankees’ offense have been scarce for most of the season. In recent weeks, though, the trend had begun to change. The Yankees went on the road, and suddenly they were averaging more than five runs a game during the first five games of their current trip.

headline: John A. Walker Jr., Ringleader of Spy Family, Dies at 77
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Cold War Era', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Cryptography, Codes and Ciphers', 'International Relations']
abstract: Mr. Walker was a Navy communications specialist when he began spying for the Soviets at the height of the Cold War in 1967.
lead_paragraph: John A. Walker Jr., a former Navy officer who in 1986 pleaded guilty to recruiting his son, a brother and a friend into a spy ring that stole military documents and sold the information to Soviet agents, died on Thursday at the federal prison complex in Butner, N.C. He was 77.

headline: Expected to Dazzle, Jameis Winston and Florida State Survive
abstract: No. 1 Florida State had a surprisingly difficult start in its bid to repeat as the national champion, holding off Oklahoma State in its season opener.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Florida State had secured its No. 1 ranking in a landslide vote, and why not? The Seminoles were the defending national champions, and pundits had pretty much given them a pass into the semifinals of college football’s playoff bracket.

headline: 2014 N.F.L. Team Capsules
abstract: A look at how teams may do this season and at players who may have an outsize effect on their teams’ fortunes.
lead_paragraph: Quarterbacks take too much of the credit, and too much of the blame, on most football teams. An intricate dance of 22 players on the field is ignored in favor of the easy hero or scapegoat.

headline: Heard at the Movies
abstract: Joel Fagliano shows us that it’s all in how you pronouncify things.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — It’s a really good thing that Joel Fagliano and Will Shortz put the years of the movies in this theme, because the first and last theme entries were particularly tricky for me.

headline: Footage From an ISIS Drone
abstract: A scene from a recent hourlong ISIS documentary opening with footage shot from a drone over the Iraqi city of Falluja.
lead_paragraph: A scene from a recent hourlong ISIS documentary opening with footage shot from a drone over the Iraqi city of Falluja.

headline: As Scots Weigh Independence, Wales Takes Note
abstract: Welsh nationalists have made the Scottish independence bid their own in the hope that it will stir passions at home — if not for full independence, at least for more self-government.
lead_paragraph: CAERNARFON, Wales — Twm Morys was boiling carrots for his children when he momentarily stopped to recite a 15th-century battle chant in Welsh. Beating out the guttural consonants with a stave on his kitchen floor until they rang in every last corner of his farmhouse, Mr. Morys, a well-known poet, said it was time to put “fire in the belly” of his people.

headline: Coverage for End-of-Life Talks Gaining Ground
keywords: ['Death and Dying', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicare', 'Hospice Care', 'Living Wills and Health Care Proxies', 'Elderly', 'Medicaid', 'Doctors']
abstract: Medicare may cover advance care planning that was once decried as “death panels,” and some private insurers are not waiting for the political process.
lead_paragraph: DUNDEE, N.Y. — Five years after it exploded into a political conflagration over “death panels,” the issue of paying doctors to talk to patients about end-of-life care is making a comeback, and such sessions may be covered for the 50 million Americans on Medicare as early as next year.

headline: A Lot of Races but Little, or No, Drama
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, State Legislature']
abstract: Texans will elect a legislature that looks — philosophically, anyway — a lot like the legislature that it is replacing.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Community Makes Itself Known, With Discretion
abstract: In mostly conservative and religious Lubbock, the lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender community is gradually growing comfortable with stepping out at an annual festival.
lead_paragraph: LUBBOCK, Tex. — The rainbow flag did not fly at Lubbock’s fourth gay pride festival on Aug. 23. Instead it was tied to a chain-link fence behind a community center east of Interstate 27 in a rundown industrial part of town. Despite the humble location, the daylong event with speakers and live music attracted about 400 people and was a milestone for the lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender community in this mostly conservative and religious Panhandle city.

headline: For Two-Year Colleges, a Chance to Grant More Four-Year Degrees
abstract: Ahead of the 2015 legislative session, momentum seems to be building for more two-year institutions to get a chance to offer four-year degrees.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Since 2003, when South Texas College, Midland College and Brazosport College received permission to offer bachelor’s degrees, several other community colleges have tried to acquire the same authority.

headline: Out of Sight? Not James Brown
abstract: “James Brown Performance Compilation,” has two screenings on Sunday as part of a Film Society of Lincoln Center series on the godfather of soul.
lead_paragraph: James Brown’s 18-minute performance in the 1964 concert film “The T.A.M.I. Show,” in which he upstaged the Rolling Stones, is a performance as electrifying as Michael Jackson’s 1983 moonwalk dance moves, which it foreshadowed. It can be revisited in the “James Brown Performance Compilation,” which has two screenings on Sunday at the Walter Reade Theater, as part of the Film Society of Lincoln Center series James Brown: The Hardest Working Man in Show Business. Here is the godfather of soul in his limber prime, with his group the Famous Flames, performing a medley of “Out of Sight,” “Prisoner of Love,” “Please, Please, Please” (the high point) and “Night Train.” In the throes of passion, he feigns a collapse from which his musicians revive him, and executes a one-legged precursor of Jackson’s moonwalk.

headline: 1939: Britain on War Basis With Reservists Called, Navy Fully Mobilized, Telephone Connection Cut
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Britain starts preparing for war in 1939.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain, with its Navy completely mobilized and all Army reservists called up, was on a war basis tonight [Aug. 31]. A rigid press censorship was put in force during the day and all telephonic connections with foreign countries were cut. Evacuation of children, sick persons and invalids from London will begin tomorrow. A decree was promulgated tonight making it a violation of the law for a person to purchase more than one week’s supply of food at one time. The decree announcing the new military measures follows: “Following the measures already adopted, it has been decided to complete the naval mobilization and to call up the remainder of the reserves and supplementary reserves of the Regular Army. New effectives of the volunteer reserves of the Army of the Air will also be called up. The officers and men will await further instructions which will be made public immediately by each of the three Ministries concerned.” — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 1, 1939

headline: San Francisco Exhales During ‘Burning Man Exodus’

Putin of Russia called on Ukraine on Sunday to begin talks on “the statehood” of that country’s rebellious southeast, a vague and provocative turn of phrase he used while demanding that the Ukrainian government negotiate directly with pro-Russian separatists.

headline: The Secret to Happiness Can Be Found by Digging in the Dirt
abstract: Some research suggests that exposure to soil bacteria could treat not just physical ailments but mental ones, too.
lead_paragraph: By now, many of us are familiar with the “hygiene hypothesis” — the idea that an environment that’s too clean may actually increase our risk of disease. This hypothesis usually gets discussed in terms of ailments like allergies or autoimmune disorders, but some research shows that dirt might be good for our mental health, too.

lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — With American bombs raining down from the sky, Shiite militia fighters aligned with Iran battled Sunni extremists over the weekend, punching through their defenses to break the weekslong siege of Amerli, a cluster of farming villages whose Shiite residents faced possible slaughter.

abstract: The film is projected to take in $21.2 million over the four-day holiday weekend, for a five-week domestic total of $279.5 million.
lead_paragraph: The runaway hit “Guardians of the Galaxy” will repeat as the No. 1 movie in North America over a quiet Labor Day weekend, as two new wide-release films arrived with meager results. “Guardians of the Galaxy” (from the Disney-owned Marvel) is projected to take in $21.2 million over the four-day holiday, for a five-week domestic total of $279.5 million, according to studio estimates released on Sunday.

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 6:40 P.M. (Starz Cinema) MIDNIGHT IN PARIS (2011) In Paris with his fiancée (Rachel McAdams) and her parents, Gil (Owen Wilson, above, with Ms. McAdams), a California screenwriter and aspiring novelist, goes for long walks each night and is magically transported to the 1920s in this film written and directed by Woody Allen. Though Gil wakes up each morning in the present, he spends his evenings consorting with Picasso (Marcial Di Fonzo Bo), F. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times.

lead_paragraph: TELLURIDE, Colo. — Film festivals don’t really have themes, even though deadline-stressed journalists sometimes suggest otherwise. But seeing a lot of movies over a short stretch of time can lead you to notice patterns, trivial — like a fox showing up on screen in two consecutive movies, a horse in three — and less so.

headline: 1964: Mississippi Integrates Schools
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: African-American pupils attend public school in Mississippi for the first time in 1964.
lead_paragraph: BILOXI, Miss. — After years of resistance, Mississippi today [Aug. 31] desegregated its public schools for the first time. Sixteen Negroes were accepted in four elementary schools here and by 10 a.m. this morning 14 were in first-grade classes. One of the two remaining Negroes was rejected when it was learned that the child’s parents live outside the state. The other is to attend a school that starts classes later.  The fact that there were no incidents today contrast sharply with the rioting that claimed two lives when Negro James Meredith enrolled at the University of Mississippi at Oxford two years ago. White parents sat in their cars in the vicinity of the four Biloxi schools long after their children had entered, but there was no attempt to interfere when the Negro youngsters appeared and walked shyly, holding their parents’ hands, into the schools. The mother of one of the Negro pupils later told a reporter: “Everything is OK, but it ain’t over yet.” School desegregation also came peacefully today to Columbia, S.C., for the first time as six formerly white schools in Columbia enrolled 22 Negro students. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Sept. 1, 1964

headline: Jays Honor Jeter in Final Visit but Treat His Team Rudely
abstract: The star shortstop had a chance to tie the game in the ninth inning after a 3-0 Yankees lead evaporated, but a lineout to second base ended it.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Before Sunday’s game, which was almost certainly the last regular-season engagement here for Derek Jeter, the Toronto Blue Jays presented him with a special gift for his impending retirement: an all-expenses-paid trip to the resort town Banff, Alberta, including a helicopter tour of the Canadian Rockies, cooking lessons from the Jays’ executive chef and either skiing or golf tutorials, depending on the season.

lead_paragraph: Harry Houdini spent his later years debunking mystics and their séances, but he inadvertently proved that there is life after death in at least one sense: Make your time on earth grand and eventful, as he did, and people will be fascinated by you long after you’re gone.

headline: Amid Choruses of Despair, an Aria of Hope
abstract: After a near collapse, the San Diego Opera is engaging in a rescue mission, hoping to prove that opera can still thrive not only in San Diego but across the country.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — The offices of the San Diego Opera once filled the penthouse atop the Civic Center Plaza, with 12-foot ceilings and sweeping views of this city and its harbors. No more. These days, opera executives toil away in the decidedly less glamorous former offices of the public defender, with hallways stacked with boxes and unhung pictures lined against the walls.

headline: A Dancer Dreams Across the World

lead_paragraph: This week, like many other teenagers across the country, Máire New will return to school. She will reunite with the friends she missed over the summer, see familiar teachers and turn to homework in the evenings.

headline: Upsets Persist at U.S. Open as Caroline Wozniacki Ousts Maria Sharapova
abstract: Caroline Wozniacki, who had not advanced past the Open’s fourth round since 2011, threw one more wrench into the women’s draw, ousting fifth-seeded Maria Sharapova.
lead_paragraph: As long as Serena Williams and Maria Sharapova remained in the United States Open, the rash of upsets in the women’s draw was merely a novelty. With 22 major championships between them, Williams and Sharapova have often risen above chaos to bring tournaments to a more predictable conclusion.

headline: Delving Deep Into the Crannies of a Brutal War
abstract: “No Man’s Land: Fiction From a World at War 1914-1918” and “The Burning of the World” bring diverse voices to World War I literature.
lead_paragraph: In our high school history classes, teachers might have mentioned Verdun or the Battle of the Somme, but it’s unlikely they got around to the Brusilov Offensive, the Siege of Przemysl or the battles of the Masurian Lakes. Though World War I was the first truly global conflict, and the first to employ the technologies that now dominate warfare, most Americans’ knowledge of the fighting that began 100 years ago this summer is limited.

headline: Following Trails at the Welsh Countryside
abstract: The first season of the British detective series “Hinterland” is available Monday on Netflix.
lead_paragraph: The title of the cop series “Hinterland” refers to its location, a windy and rugged stretch of coast in western Wales, an out-of-the-way part of an out-of-the-way country. But it could also be a television in-joke: For the last decade, Wales has served silently as the home base and filming location for some of the most acclaimed TV shows set in England, including “Doctor Who,” “Life on Mars” and “Sherlock.” Here, finally, was a major show made by the Welsh about the Welsh.

Their task was to create their own dream shows, festivals or exhibitions, and the results were diverse: a Shakespearean battle royale, an art museum of the mind, eclectic music festivals and an exhibition of video games designed by women.

headline: Want More Wonka? A Lost Chapter Is Found
abstract: A lost chapter of an earlier version of the 1964 book “Charlie and the Chocolate Factory” was recently published for the first time in The Guardian.
lead_paragraph: It appears that Roald Dahl, below, once planned for Charlie Bucket to have a lot more company and a somewhat wilder adventure in “Charlie and the Chocolate Factory.” A lost chapter of an earlier version of this 1964 book that was found after Dahl’s death in 1990 was recently published for the first time in The Guardian. It reveals more temptations for a larger cast of characters and some variations on character names. The chapter opens with eight children — including Charlie, escorted by his mother instead of his Grandpa Joe — entering the Vanilla Fudge room. At this point, two other children, Miranda Grope and Augustus Pottle, who later became Augustus Gloop, have already fallen into the chocolate river. Inside the room, the visitors see a mountain of chocolate where hundreds of workers (later called Oompa-Loompas) are chipping away chunks of fudge that are then loaded onto wagons and transported through a dark hole in the wall. Two children, Tommy Troutbeck and Wilbur Rice, disobey Willy Wonka and jump into the wagons. They are quickly swept away through the hole into the “Pounding and Cutting Room.” Wonka tells the parents that this room is where the fudge is pounded “against the floor until it is all nice and smooth and thin.” After that, he says, “a whole lot of knives come down and go chop chop chop, cutting it up into neat little squares, ready for the shops.” The chapter did not make the book because it was “deemed too wild, subversive and insufficiently moral for the tender minds of British children almost 50 years ago,” The Guardian said. “Charlie and the Chocolate Factory” has sold more than 20 million copies worldwide in 55 languages, according to RoaldDahl.com, and has been made into two movies and a musical.

headline: Taylor Swift Joins Mentors on ‘The Voice’
abstract: Ms. Swift is to step in as an adviser to contestants on NBC’s “The Voice” this fall.
lead_paragraph: Players gonna play, haters gonna hate. Those and other words of wisdom from Taylor Swift’s latest Billboard-topping song, “Shake It Off,” might come in handy when she steps in as an adviser to contestants on NBC’s “The Voice” this fall. Ms. Swift, 24, left, is to appear as a mentor to competitors in its seventh season, Us Weekly reported. She’ll join previously announced guest mentors, including Gavin Rossdale, Stevie Nicks, Little Big Town and Alicia Keys, who are to work with members from teams led by the judges, Adam Levine, Blake Shelton, Gwen Stefani and Pharrell Williams. Ms. Swift, however, will work with competitors from all four teams, much as Chris Martin of Coldplay did in Season 6, according to US Weekly. NBC would not comment on the news. “The Voice” is scheduled to return on Sept. 22, and Ms. Swift is set to release her fifth studio album, “1989,” on Oct. 27.

headline: Absurd Tale’s Absurdly Long Trip to the Stage
abstract: The musical revival of “Red Eye of Love,” by the Tony winners Ted Sperling and John Wulp, is already a victory of sorts.
lead_paragraph: The spring he turned 50, John Wulp won a Tony Award as a producer of “Dracula,” a show he shepherded from Nantucket, Mass., to Broadway. That was 1978, the high point, so far, of his career in theater. But Mr. Wulp, who is 86 and has lived since the ’90s on an island in Maine, can be a very persistent man.

headline: A Bit of Caution Beneath the Thump
abstract: The Electric Zoo Festival, the annual electronic dance music gathering, took over Randalls Island a year after two festivalgoers died after using the synthetic party drug Molly.
lead_paragraph: How orderly can an electronic dance party be and still stay fun? That was the question facing the sixth annual Electric Zoo Festival, the three-day event on Randalls Island that started on Friday. In 2013, two festivalgoers died after using the drug known as Molly, containing MDMA, and the festival’s third day was shut down at the request of New York City. This year, caution was omnipresent. Concertgoers were required to watch a two-minute antidrug video clip, drug-sniffing dogs met arrivals, bags were searched, uniformed security personnel were plentiful all over the site, and there were highly visible booths and roving “ZooKeepers” to offer medical attention.

headline: Fantasy Football: Breaking Down the Rookies, Part 1
abstract: The 2014 class of rookies should contain several productive fantasy players, including the running backs Jeremy Hill, Carlos Hyde and Terrance West.
lead_paragraph: The conventional wisdom in fantasy football has traditionally been to avoid rookies. While some are definitely more flash than substance, rookies should not be underestimated or ignored. In recent years, many rookies have emerged to become top players at their position right away. Just last season, Eddie Lacy, Le’Veon Bell, Zac Stacy, Giovani Bernard and Keenan Allen emerged to be top 20 players at their respective position. Of those five rookies, only Lacy was expected to play to that level, and all five proved to be steals in fantasy drafts.

headline: Is Your Student Prepared for Life?
keywords: ['Hiring and Promotion', 'Careers and Professions', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Colleges need to create a required course that would teach students how to get, and succeed at, a job.
lead_paragraph: AS 16 million young adults set off for college this fall, they are looking at some frightening statistics. Despite the ever-rising cost of getting a degree, one number stands out like a person shouting in a campus library: According to a recent poll conducted by AfterCollege, an online entry-level job site, 83 percent of college seniors graduated without a job this spring. Even when these young people finally do get jobs, the positions are often part time, low wage or not related to their career interests. The problem isn’t the quality of higher education in the United States, so what’s missing?

headline: Sympathy for a Desert Dog
abstract: The Ju/’hoansi villagers I lived with communed with animals. So why didn’t they grieve for the dog who had befriended me?
lead_paragraph: Dog adopted me in 1995, six months or so into my first spell of ethnographic fieldwork among the Ju/’hoansi Bushmen in Namibia’s Kalahari Desert. I was living in the village of Skoonheid, named after an Afrikaner farm. He was the bravest of all the village dogs in seeking affection. The others loped around, their tails between their legs, trying to be invisible. They shied from physical contact with people but would respond with surprise and simpering gratitude if it was offered. Most of their physical interactions with people came in the form of kicks or flying stones.
